This is one of the most handsome shows of the season, and it is tireless in its attempts to please the audience. But mediocre material, no matter how it's sliced, is still mediocre material. ''Can-Can'' never was a firstrate musical, and now, almost three decades after its original production, it stands on even shakier legs.

description: Herschel Walker, the Georgia football star, said today would not turn pro with the Montreal Alouettes. ''I have made my decision, which is to play football at Georgia,'' Walker said in a statement.

description: United States auto production rose this week, but the number of workers on layoff without a recall date remained virtually unchanged from last week, industry reports indicated today.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DROPPED BY 0.4% IN APRIL
description: Prices that farmers receive for raw products declined by four-tenths of 1 percent in April but still were an average of 16 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: Luis Marin, or Pedro Davila, as he was known at Stouffer's Inn of Westchester, had a visitor last Dec. 4, according to his landlady in Port Chester, but the 25-year-old busboy was not at home.

title: A's, Yanks Rise With Pitching
description: Stan Williams, the Yankee pitching coach, leafed hastily today through a magazine story about the Oakland A's pitching staff, which has raced to the top of virtually every American League statistical category. ''Heck, we're right behind them,'' Williams said as the team prepared to begin a fourgame weekend series against the A's tomorrow night.

title: U.S. JOINS IN U.N. VETO ON SOUTH AFRICAN TRADE BAN
description: The United States, Britain and France tonight vetoed four Security Council resolutions to halt all trade with South Africa, widening the gulf between the Reagan Administration and black Africa.

title: THREE WHO HAVE CHOSEN A LIFE IN THE WILD
description: From the time all three were little girls, they wanted to be out in the wilderness, alone with their animals. They have now spent many years in the remotest corners of Africa and Asia, enduring isolation, torrential rains, heat, insects and, in the cases of two of them, long separations from their sons, who were thousands of miles away in England and British Columbia.

description: The nation's banking industry generally adopted an 18 percent prime rate yesterday in reaction to higher rates for the short-term funds that banks borrow from the Federal Government.

title: SCREEN: 'KING OF MOUNTAIN'
description: NOT since ''Lifeguard'' has there been a Southern California movie to equal the informed lunacies of ''King of the Mountain,'' a solemn film about the problems of growing up ambitious in and around Los Angeles. Steve (Harry Hamlin), an automobile mechanic with a very square jaw, spends his off hours racing his 1958 Porsche down Mulholland Drive, which, he tells us on the soundtrack, slices ''through the Hollywood Hills like a knife.'' He is ''king'' of that mountain and wants to stay that way.

title: DEMOCRATS ORGANIZE TO COMBAT CONSERVATIVE DRIVE
description: A group of prominent Democrats today announced the formation of a political action committee that plans to spend $1 million this year to reply to attacks on liberal Democrats by the National Conservative Political Action Committee.

title: How Well Does Workfare Work?
description: First the Reagan Administration wanted to put to work able-bodied parents receiving welfare aid for their dependent children, despite years of experience demonstrating that such ''workfare'' does little to reduce welfare or increase work. Now Senator Helms, the North Carolina Republican, wants to do the same with food-stamp recipients, despite evidence that food-stamp workfare makes even less sense.

title: Straddle Trade Ban Is Backed
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it favored changing tax law to eliminate benefits from the use of such tax-avoidance schemes as straddle transactions in commodities futures trading.

title: TEXAS POSTS ITS FOURTH SUCCESSIVE SHUTOUT
description: Rick Honeycutt pitched a fivehitter tonight as the Texas Rangers beat the Kansas City Royals, 7-0, the fourth successive shutout by Texas pitchers.

description: Pekka Rautakallio scored one first-period goal and set up another to lead the Calgary Flames to a 3-2 victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight, evening their National Hockey League semifinal playoff series at one victory apiece.

title: A FLOURISHING AERIE OF FOLK AND TRADITIONAL
description: THE Eagle Tavern, on the northeast corner of Ninth Avenue and 14th Street at the edge of Manhattan's meatpacking district, has become a flourishing citadel for folk and traditional music styles. By day, the 70-year-old establishment is an Irish-flavored workingman's bar and restaurant, frequented at lunch by meatpackers and truckers. But five nights a week - Saturday, Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Thursday -its backroom restaurant resounds with folk and traditional music played by some of the finest local musicians.

THEATER: BUCHNER, TRAGIC AND COMIC, ON ONE BILL
description: WHEN Georg Buchner died in 1837 at the age of 23, he left three unproduced plays, two of which, ''Danton's Death'' and ''Woyzeck,'' have become seminal works in the modern theater. His third play, ''Leonce and Lena,'' is seldom produced and often slighted in critical discussions of the author. At the Classic Stage Company, Christopher Martin has performed a distinct service for New York theatergoers and for Buchner by presenting a double bill of ''Woyzeck'' and ''Leonce and Lena.'' Contrasting two sides of the author - the tragic and the comic - offered in extremely actable English versions by Mr. Martin, the company demonstrates the breadth of this extraordinary dramatist.

title: B-WESTERN MOVIE ROUNDUP OPENS AT A TRIBECA RANCH
description: They're back in the saddle again this weekend at the Just Above Midtown/ Downtown Gallery, shooting their way to glory in what may be the most unlikely film festival of the month. The gallery's ''B-Western Roundup,'' which opens tonight at 7:30 and will run Fridays through May, has its share of such old favorites as Tom Mix, Roy Rogers, Hopalong Cassidy and Gene Autry. But Ray Whitley and His Range Ramblers? Fred Scott? Smiley Burnette in Africa?

title: ART: ROTHKO AS SURREALIST IN HIS PRE-ABSTRACT YEARS
description: HEARING the name of Mark Rothko, we immediately think of his famous later works - the totally abstract canvases divided into three luminous rectangles of color that seem to float in illusory space. But before these color meditations there were earlier Rothko phases, each very much a part of the era in which he worked. There was the Rothko who painted street and subway scenes in the ''social realist'' style of the 1930's. And then there was the Rothko who, after 1938, made a flying leap from this style to Surrealism, using biomorphic imagery drawn from - among myriad sources - science, mythology, archeology and Freudian discoveries about the unconscious.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1981
description: International The new top American arms negotiator is Lieut. Gen. Edward L. Rowny, who retired from the Army in 1979 to campaign publicly against the strategic arms limitation treaty with the Soviet Union. The pact was signed nearly two years ago but it has not been ratified by the Senate. (Page A1, Column 6.) The President denounced persecution in an emotional speech to a White House group that included survivors of Nazi genocide. Mr. Reagan said that the United States should not negotiate with any country unless the subject of repression was ''on that negotiating table,'' but a White House spokesman said that the President was not altering his policy of downgrading human rights overseas. The feature tomorrow at 2 P.M. will be the 1953 ''Sansho the Bailiff'' and on Sunday at 2 ''Street of Shame,'' made in 1956, the year Mizoguchi died. Fourteen of the films will also be screened at the Museum of Modern Art, from May 14 to June 4. The 1953 ''Ugetsu,'' set in medieval Japan, is a ghost tale about the dangers of vanity and ambition. description: LATIN AMERICAN art, manuscripts and books dating from antiquity to the late 20th century will be offered next week in four sales at Sotheby Parke Bernet's three galleries and in one sale at Christie's Park Avenue gallery. Sotheby's sale begins Tuesday at 171 East 84th Street with its first specialty sale of books and manuscripts relating to Latin America and the Caribbean . The offering with the highest presale estimate is also the largest lot in the sale, a collection of 300 broadsides, proclamations, pamphlets and printed ephemera relating to the Chilean struggle against the Spanish from 1811 to 1840. A letter from Simon Bolivar to his friend Marques Fernando del Toro may bring up to $15,000.

title: MUSIC: THE COMPOSERS' FORUM
description: THE Cooper Union Composers' Forum featured the music of Walter Boudreau and Bruce MacCombie Tuesday evening. Mr. Boudreau is a French-Canadian, and his three-movement ''Amon-Ra'' used the electronic keyboards of five Ondes Martenots to celebrate what the composer described as the inner life of the sun - the note values and textures of the music, according to the composer, intended as metaphors of quantitative and qualitative scientific observations. Given the Ondes Martenot's capacities for wailing glissandos and wildly varying sound colors, Mr. Boudreau's piece was only intermittently interesting - its beginning growling and moaning tediously, its middle brighter and more attractive.

title: Around the Maypole in Poland

The police said the bodies of two women and one man had been found, but they declined to identify them until relatives had been informed.

title: The Promise of Fact

In these days of bitter controversy over complex issues of health, safety and environment, every side marshals platoons of experts to present only a version of scientific truth. A confused, often cynical public has learned that there are as many scientific facts as there are sides in a controversy.

Back in a Berlin in the depths of the postwar depression, Paul is greeted by everyone, including his mother (Maria Schell), with the observation, ''I thought you were dead.'' It's as if he'd had the bad taste to survive.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1981
description: International Francois Mitterrand seems to be ahead of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing in the Presidential election on May 10. Two major polls were taken since last Sunday's first-round of balloting, one gave 51.5 percent of the vote to Mr. Mitterrand, the Socialist leader, and 48.5 percent to the President. The other poll, which was to have published in ''Le Figaro'' was withheld without explanation by the newspaper, which is strongly in favor of the President. (Page 1, Column 1.) Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig flew to Rome to attend a meeting of allied foreign ministers next week. title: What Place for Arms Control?

It doesn't want to negotiate from weakness and it doesn't want the SALT II treaty inherited from Jimmy Carter. The suspicion that President Reagan is innocent of any positive thoughts about the subject may concern the Soviet leaders. It certainly worries America's allies. And their fears are only partly allayed by the team that Mr. Reagan has now chosen to guide the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER GOES PLOTLESS
description: Just as the first week of American Ballet Theater's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House opened with programs of abstract ballets, so the first performances of the second week also featured plotless works. It is still unclear whether such similarities in programming are purely coincidental or whether they represent a deliberate shift in the policy of this company, which in the past was celebrated for its dance-dramas. Yet Monday and Tuesday night's performances at least demonstrated that abstractions can come in several different choreographic flavors.

title: RANGERS SEE HOPE DESPITE 2-0 DEFICIT

title: BACK ON THE BEACH
description: In this last of meeting places We grope together And avoid speech Gathered on this beach of the tumid river - T.S. Eliot, ''The Hollow Men'' Groped together like Eliot's ''Hollow Men'' near the end of a particularly violent century, we avoid speech on certain unpleasant topics. One is the continuing - and increasing - prospect of nuclear war. ''Our minds have adjusted to it, as after a time our eyes adjust to the dark,'' Jimmy Carter mused in his farewell address. Beyond some on-again, off-again statements on the neutron bomb reminiscent of the Carter years, the Reagan Administration has had very little to say about nuclear weapons. There may be a little-suspected reason for White House silence on the bomb: The Administration has perhaps concluded - rightly, I would think - that the long debate on nuclear-weapons policy, begun after Hiroshima, finally may be over.

title: ROSIE'S LIFE AFTER THE WAR WAS NOT SO ROSY

title: Commodities; HOG FUTURES ADVANCE; GRAIN, SOYBEANS ALSO UP

Hogs closed as much as 1.35 cents higher and ended the day at 49.70 a pound for delivery in June, partly because slaughter figures show producers took fewer animals to market during the week, said Bob Kuhn, an analyst in Chicago with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. He said slaughter were 8 percent lower than the same period a year ago, confirming last month's United States Agriculture Department report that foreshadowed tighter pork supplies by summer.

THE ELUSIVE ART OF WRITING PRECISE RECIPES
description: It used to be said in certain writing courses that to develop the highly desirable qualities of clarity and brevity, there could be no better exercise than the writing of copy for mail-order catalogues. Requiring a maximum of concrete description in a minimum of space, such catalogues trained writers to be succinct. I submit that an even better exercise is the writing of recipes, because it requires still more precision in describing, in limited space, motions and techniques that must be followed by unknown practitioners operating at varying levels of proficiency.

The case is the first to receive a final F.T.C. decision under its pre-sale warranty regulation, which says all warranties offered on products costing more than $15 must be available to customers before their purchase.

description: Police Officer John Scarangella, whose life had been sustained by a respirator since he was shot in the head April 16 on a Queens street, died yesterday of his wounds.

description: Scientists and human rights activists from several countries opened a meeting at Rockefeller University yesterday to honor Andrei D. Sakharov and to urge Soviet authorities to restore his political and academic rights.

title: PAUL TREBILCOCK
description: Paul Trebilcock, a portrait painter for many years, died April 8 at his Manhattan home. He was 79 years old. Mr. Trebilcock, who was born in Chicago and graduated from the University of Illinois, studied painting at the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: Treasury Dept. to Drop Alcohol Labeling Plan
description: The Treasury Department plans to rescind a regulation that would have required makers of beer, wine and distilled spirits to list ingredients in their products, a department official said today.

title: MRS. KING SAYS SHE HAD LESBIAN AFFAIR
description: Saying it was a ''mistake'' for which she accepted full ''responsibility,'' Billie Jean King, the tennis player, conceded today that she had had a lesbian relationship with Marilyn Barnett, her former secretary.

title: IN LEBANON'S BEKAA VALLEY, SYRIANS ARE IN CHARGE BUT STILL FACE SNIPERS
description: The Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon is Syrian territory.Syrian soldiers can be seen in virtually all the towns of a 20-mile stretch of the valley and on the peaks of Mount Sannin overlooking it. They control the approaches to this Lebanese Christian town, and their tanks are parked near it in fields of strawberries and corn.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: College libraries might not really expect donations of important research material from someone who calls himself Adirondack Dan, but Daniel D. Malmed had something major for Radcliffe's Elizabeth and Arthur Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America - more than 700 letters written by Emma Goldman, the turn-of-the-century anarchist and recent focus for feminist attention.

title: No Headline
description: Because of a translation error from Afrikaans to English, an article in The Times on Wednesday misrepresented a comment by Prime Minister P.W. Botha on the future of South-West Africa and the South-West Africa People's Organization, the insurgent group known as Swapo. The quotation should have read: ''As long as there is a National Party Government, we will not hand over South-West Africa to Swapo against the desires and wishes of its people.''

title: Company News; AVNET IN AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE SERTECH
description: Avnet Inc. the electronics manufactorer, has an agreement in pinciple to acquire all shares of the Sertech Corporation of Salem, Mass. for an undisclosed sum of cash, according to Anthony R. Hamilton, chairman of Avnet.

title: House Democrats File Suit To Stop U.S. Aid to Salvador
description: Eleven liberal House Democrats filed a civil lawsuit in United States District Court today to force the withdrawal of American military advisers and a halt to military aid to El Salvador.

title: METS LOSE TO PADRES FOR 7TH IN ROW, 4-2
description: A two-run homer by Rusty Staub in the second inning had the chilled crowd of 7,181 at Shea Stadium last night hoping that the Mets' sixgame losing streak might end.

title: WORK WEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 COLTS RESTORED TO DERBY FIELD
description: A county court judge held today that Churchill Downs had violated a state racing rule that concerns limits on the size of a field, and as a result the track was forced to restore two colts that had been dropped from tomorrow's Kentucky Derby.

title: Three Golfers Post 142's And Share One-Shot Lead
description: Hollis Stacy and Debbie Austin caught Sandra Haynie, the first-round leader, and set up a three-way tie for the lead after 36 holes of a $125,000 $125,000 women's professional golf tournament today.

title: Jersey's Blue Cross Granted 15% Rise
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The New Jersey Insurance Department approved an increase in Blue Cross-Blue Shield premium rates that will average 15 percent for 1.9 million individuals and small-group subscribers.

title: CONNECTICUT GENERAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DRAMA BASED ON THE JEAN HARRIS TRIAL
description: Paul Klein is a blustery, amusing man with a lot of theories about television. The one that made him a legend in his own mind (and modestly famous within his industry) took root during the five years that he spent as an audience-research expert for NBC during the late 1960's. Mr. Klein's theory is that television viewers do not turn on their sets looking for their favorite shows, but rather, select the least objectionable program - or, as it's come to be known, ''the LOP.''

title: Mr. Reagan's Gift to Big Auto
description: President Reagan, being a champion of the free market and foe of inflation, only ''volunteered'' to inform the Japanese of the sad plight of the American auto industry. And now the Japanese have responded by ''volunteering'' to limit their American sales to 1.68 million cars in 1981 - about 200,000 fewer than they might have sold. All that remains is for the American consumers to volunteer to pay a billion dollars more for all the cars they buy this year.

title: WILLIAMS IS GUILTY ON ALL NINE COUNTS IN ABSCAM INQUIRY
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey was found guilty last night of bribery and conspiracy charges stemming from the Justice Department's Abscam investigation of political corruption.

He said that the commission had been given six months to report.

title: Atlanta's Police to Speed Action on Missing Persons
description: The police are adopting a new policy in hope of avoiding delays in locating missing persons, especially those who match the profile of the 26 young blacks slain here since July 1979, the Public Safety Commissioner, Lee Brown, said today.

title: SHOES FOR HEALTHIER FEET
description: T HE widespread use of synthetic shoe materials, commonly referred to as man-made, are damaging the feet and causing fungus infections such as athlete's foot and corns, calluses, bunions, deformities and pain, foot specialists say. They maintain that because leather is porous, leather shoes breathe and eventually conform to the contours of the foot.

description: The Cosmos, with Hubert Birkenmeier playing one of his better games in goal, withstood a fierce attack in the second half and defeated the Atlanta Chiefs, 3-2, tonight.

description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in March 1981

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr., who was one of the American hostages in Iran, is expected to leave the Foreign Service to join the staff of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The 50-year-old former New Yorker was the economics counselor at the Teheran embassy.

title: No Headline
description: The Soviet press agency Tass condemned the United States today for its veto of United Nations sanctions against South Africa, calling it an ''imperialist'' act.

title: SANDS ASSERTS HE EXPECTS TO DIE SOON
description: Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army member on a hunger strike in prison, told a friend today that he expected to die soon, ''maybe tonight, maybe tomorrow morning.''

description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. In a televised address, President Reagan read a letter written by the second-grade pupil from Rockville Centre, L.I., urging him to get well quickly so that he would not have to make a speech in his pajamas.

Mayor Koch Honored by New Dramatists
description: Mayor Koch was the guest of honor yesterday at an anniversary luncheon at which the New Dramatists celebrated 32 years of encouraging and developing playwriting talent.

title: DR. HELENE S. ZAHLER
description: Dr. Helene S. Zahler, an associate professor of history at Brooklyn College until her retirement in 1977, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital.

title: T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for the 5-for-4 stock split declared May 1

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSED OF SHIFT ON SCHOOLS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said today that the Reagan Administration, like others before it, had retreated from its advocacy of aid to nonpublic schools upon taking office after having supported it during the election campaign.

title: PHILHARMONIC: FOCUS ON PLAYERS
description: The New York Philharmonic's subscription concerts this week highlighted the orchestra's players with unusual generosity. The program for Thursday and Friday consisted of a Vivaldi Concerto in D minor (P. 281), with Renee Siebert, the second flutist, and Carol Webb of the first violin section; the Liszt Piano Concerto No. 1 in E flat, with Ken Noda as guest soloist, and Richard Strauss's ''Ein Heldenleben,'' in which Glenn Dicterow, the concertmaster, took the violin solos. But Friday afternoon, ''Ein Heldenleben'' was replaced by Strauss's ''Don Quixote,'' with Lorne Munroe and Sol Greitzer, the orchestra's principal cellist and violist, and Mr. Dicterow - uncredited this time - in the prominent violin solo parts.

title: On Cooperating
description: To the Editor:

title: New Technology And Newborns
description: For all of my adult life, I have wondered how, when I was born, the doctor was able to put my mother's wedding band on my wrist (''The Child Savers,'' by Robin Marantz Henig, March 22).

title: Nicholas Maravell Weds Miss Cowles
description: Victoria Lloyd-Smith Cowles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Cowles Jr. of Pine Cay, Turks and Caicos Islands, W.I., formerly of Shelburne, Vt., was married in Washington yesterday to Nicholas Charles Maravell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nicholas Maravell of New York.

title: THERE'S LIFE YET IN THOSE OLD BONES
description: Two weeks ago, it was an experimental success with artifical skin. Last week, it was live bon produced from dead bone.

title: HAWAII PRESSES THERMAL PROJECT DESPITE A WITHDRAWAL OF U.S. AID
description: -Federal financing of a key element in an alternative energy project in Hawaii has been cut off, but scientists here say they will continue part of the program in hopes of easing the state's heavy dependence on oil.

title: GOLDIN AND BRONX LEADER DISPUTE BUS LINES' FEES
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin last week accused two supporters of the Bronx Democratic leader of ''holding senior citizens and the handicapped hostage'' and ''profiteering.''

title: XEROX STALKS THE AUTOMATED OFFICE
description: W HEN C. Peter McColough, chairman and chief executive officer of the Xerox Corporation, addressed financial analysts last week, he barely mentioned a seemingly important subject - copiers.

title: No Headline
description: An office is not a democracy! TThe pleasure of work is enhanced by certain amenities, and coffee may be a lubricant that greases the wheels of a productive enterprise. The issue of who should apply the grease is not a feminist issue, but one of equitable division of labor.

title: Mail-Order House Opens Its Warehouse
description: Lillian Vernon, the Mount Vernon gift store and mail-order business, will begin its inventory clearance Thursday evening at the Port Chester Warehouse with prices at wholesale or below, hourly additions and the Retinitis Pigmentosis Foundation receiving 10 percent of the proceeds. Be warned - last year's first clearance jammed the parking lot and surrounding streets. No credit cards; only cash or checks.

title: CONTAMINANTS FOUND IN LAKEHURST WATER
description: LAKEHURST TESTS of the drinking water at the Naval Air Engineering Center here have shown the presence of two hazardous chemicals, with one test registering extraordinarily high levels of both substances.

title: LIMIT IN SMALL CLAIMS COURT LIFTED
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives voted yesterday to raise the maximum amount to be adjudicated in Small Claims Court from $750 to $1,000. The House rejected a Republican-led attempt to make the limit $1,500.

title: On Balance
description: A woman riding a bicycle past the corner of 113th Street and Eighth Avenue was shot and killed by a young man a few days ago. As she toppled from the bicycle someone else came along, picked it up and pedaled away.

title: Winning Big At Baseball
description: As ballplayers' salaries inflate beyond imagination (as manifested by Dave Winfield's new salary), fans like me are becoming extremely disgruntled (''The Yankees' $20 Million Gamble,'' by Phil Berger, March 29).

title: AMONG ABSCAM UNCERTAINITIES ONE THING IS CLEAR: DON'T DO IT
description: The last major trial growing out of the Justice Department's controversial Abscam operation ended last week with the conviction of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., a New Jersey Democrat, and Alexander Feinberg, a co-defendant.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Pittsburgh Ensemble In Series of Premieres
description: It was either a sad irony or a graceful homage that the best piece on the first New York concert of the Pittsburgh New Music Ensemble on Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall under the auspices of the League-I.S.C.M. was by a New York composer.

title: TRAFFIC CHANGES
description: Because of the Citibank-American Youth Hostels' Five Boro Bike Tour, the following streets, highways, bridges and ferry services will be closed at various times today: The southbound Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 8:30 A.M. and 11 A.M. The eastbound upper level of the Queensboro Bridge between 9 A.M. and 11:20 A.M. The southbound lanes of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway from Flushing Avenue to 92d Street between 10 A.M. and 1:30 P.M. The eastbound lower level of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge between 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Staten Island Ferry service for autos between 11:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Detours will be marked for local street traffic.

title: JAPAN TO CURB AUTO SHIPMENTS TO U.S.
description: Japan agreed to cut back auto exports to the United States by almost 8 percent in a move to head off protectionist action by Congress. Japan's auto makers reacted with fury to the accord between governments but said they would obey the restrictions. Legislation in Congress would cut the imports by as much as 20 percent a year.

title: NEW HOUSING ADVANCES IN QUEENS
description: More than 2,000 new housing units are scheduled to come on the market in Queens in the near future and sales of 500 more units are under way.

title: PREMIER OF FINLAND GAINS AMID CRITICISM
description: To the consternation of his political foes, Finland's Prime Minister has survived a clash with President Urho Kekkonen, and has pulled even further ahead in opinion polls as the most likely successor to the President.

title: RICHARD BARSTOW, CHOREOGRAPHER FOR THE BARNUM & BAILEY CIRCUS
description: Richard Barstow, who began a theatrical career as a child and for 29 years served as director and choreographer of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, died yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital after a series of heart attacks. He was 73 years old.

title: Pentagon Says Nuclear Exercise Has Uncovered Flaws in System
description: The Pentagon has announced that the largest nuclear weapons accident exercise ever held uncovered problems in emergency response to nuclear disasters.

title: Helen Bryan Jersey Bride
description: Helen Quirk Bryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Dobbs Spaight Bryan of Rumson, N.J., was married at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church there yesterday to Frank Alan Hubbard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Curtis Hubbard of Farmville, Va. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: RAIL AND BUS FINANCING THREATENED
description: AS they sought to assess the impact of the proposed Reagan budget cuts on government programs in Westchester, county officials warned last week that they contained sharp reductions in Federal funds in the field of transportation and highways.

title: Giants 6, Phillies 2 Phillies 3, Giants 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Keith Moreland hit two home runs and Mike Schmidt one and Marty Bystrom pitched a three-hitter to give Philadelphia a second-game victory and a split of the twilight-night doubleheader.

title: JANE GUMLEY TO BE BRIDE OF PETER L. JANIAK OCT. 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Gumley of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ellen Gumley, to Peter Lee Janiak, son of Theodore Janiak and the late Mrs. Janiak of Framingham, Mass.

title: JAPAN, TRUE HOME OF THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: If Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki lacked the traditional Japanese reticence, he could probably during his visit to Washington this week tell President Reagan much more about ''supply-side economics'' than Mr. Reagan is likely to learn from the Americans who have popularized the term.

title: THE BUSINESS OF MOVING IS DECLINING
description: WESTCHESTER'S mobile society is not as mobile as it used to be. This year, for the third year in a row, moving companies expect a slow spring and summer, the usual busy seasons.

title: POLL FINDS NATION IS BECOMING INCREASINGLY REPUBLICAN
description: The United States is becoming increasingly Republican, but it is becoming more conservative only selected issues, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Julie Schuetz Wed To Stephen Lowe
description: Julie Louise Schuetz and Stephen Peter Lowe were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill. The Very Rev. Frederick W. Phinney performed the ceremony.

title: Susan O'Connell Bride of S. H. Johnson 3d
description: Susan Murrin O'Connell, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Francis O'Connell Jr. of Fort Worth, Tex., and the late Mr. O'Connell, was married at St. Ignatius Roman Catholic Church in Chestnut Hill., Mass., yesterday to Stuart Holmes Johnson 3d, son of Mr. Johnson Jr. and Mrs. Wynant Davis Vanderpool Jr., both of Washington.

title: SENATE ETHICS UNIT TO CONSIDER ACTION ON WILLIAMS VERDICT
description: The Senate Ethics Committee will meet tomorrow or Tuesday to begin considering action against Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey because of his conviction Friday night on bribery and conspiracy charges.

title: Eugene Doe Weds Mary G. Scudder
description: In Christ Presbyterian Church in Telluride, Colo., yesterday, Mary Gale Scudder was married to Eugene Francis Doe by the Rev. Margaret Balcom.

title: Stage View; AN 'OEDIPUS' FATALLY FLAWED
description: What is a good actress? A good actress is one who can stride onto the stage, playing Jocasta to an already deeply disturbed Oedipus, strive passionately to give her kingly husband the confidence he lacks, shake her head with great vigor as her intensity increases, lose an earring in the process, adroitly retrieve the earring from the earth of Thebes and go right on with her exhortation without permitting the least little snicker from her audience. That is what a good actress is.

title: BELEIVING IN BAGEHOT
description: While newspapers have significantly expanded their coverage of the business beat and business magazines continue to thrive, programs that prep journalists so that they may better report on the current financial scene are finding a lack of funds.

title: SIMONE SIGNORET ONCE THE 'IDEAL MISTRESS,' SHE IS UNAFRAID TO ACT HER
description: AGE By JOHN VINOCUR AUTHEUIL, France Over the past few years, Simone Signoret has played an aged prostitute, a revolutionary, a failed actress, an East European spy, a Gaullist underground fighter, an alcoholic with a limp, a peasant from the Dijon countryside, a housekeeper, an aristocrat called Lady Vamos, and on and on. She has forgotten for the most part about Alice Aisgill, the role in ''Room at the Top'' that won her an Oscar and launched, like little ships, a generation's fleet of private dreams.

title: CAMPAIGN SURPLUSES REPORTED IN ALBANY
description: Running for the State Legislature can be a profitable enterprise, according to a study by Common Cause, the public affairs lobbying group.

title: Loughlin Scores in Relay
description: Bishop Loughlin's distance medley relay team maintained its undefeated status yesterday by taking the championship event at the 16th annual New York Relays in Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: Television Week
description: Jean Harris The recent trial of Jean Harris, the school headmistress accused of murdering Dr. Herman Tarnower, the ''Scarsdale Diet'' author, hardly lacked for attention. It was covered extensively by newspapers and television, which provided daily accounts of the proceedings along with artists' sketches - for cameras, of course, were barred from the courtroom.

title: THEY ARE ON THE ATTACK AGAIN
description: HAVING recently sold the house and being euphoric in contemplation of carefree condominium living, it came as something of a shock, a jolt of deja vu, to receive the annual doomsday letter from the company that used to spray my trees. The letter, forwarded by a relentless Postal Service, was yet another indication of man's frailty against the implacable forces of nature; a reminder that no matter where you move, house or no house, they are continuing their attack.

title: HAIG, IN EUROPE, IS PRESSED TO AGREE TO NUCLEAR ARMS TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived in Rome today for a meeting of the NATO foreign ministers and immediately came under pressure from European governments to agree to an early resumption of talks with the Soviet Union on reducing European-based nuclear weapons.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 4 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 2 4 5 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) A journey through that greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all. 3 3 28 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune.

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY PLANS MOVE TO COLLEGE SITE
description: THE Westchester County Historical Society will have its day today, not just one way, but three - first with a heritage festival that kicks off the county's 1983 tricentennial celebrations, then a history seminar and then an announcement for a move to new headquarters at the Westchester County Community College in Valhalla.

title: FROM NATURE TO NEON, A CIRCUIT OF TAHOE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- WARREN LERUDE, formerly the publisher of The Nevada State Journal and The Reno Evening Gazette, is a writer based in Reno. By WARREN LERUDE

title: Dance View; THE HOUSTON BALLET STYLE
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's innovative ''Ballet America'' season closes this week with the Pennsylvania Ballet - the one company in the series that has been seen there regularly in annual residencies. Most of the out-of-town ballet troupes, however, were making their New York debut and the last in this category was the Houston Ballet.

title: THE LADIES OF THE GUTTER
description: ''Aging women with swollen ankles and ulcerated feet, toting bags, shuffling slowly across the street, poking into garbage cans, slumped on a park bench, dozing in doorways, sprawling across library steps, huddled among their possessions in the dreary waiting rooms of train and bus stations. Poor, sick, lonely, old, afraid.''

title: U.S.S. NEW JERSEY MAY GO SEAWARD
description: JERSEY CITY NOT unlike an old sailor who keeps re-enlisting long after his shipmates have retired, the U.S.S. New Jersey, the 45,000-ton battlewagon launched on Dec. 7, 1942, may be rearmed and made ready for action.

title: No Headline
description: Mayor John Carey of Rye joined postal workers picketing in Stamford Wednesday to protest the Postal Service's plans to move part of its operation from Stamford to Rye. Workers in Stamford have objected to the commuting distance involved and to the prospect of having their salaries taxed by New York State. Rye is opposed to the Postal Service's move because the Government's use of the property would take it off of the tax rolls.

title: Paula Jean Healey, Chemist, Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Edward P. Healey of Clifton, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Paula Jean Healey, to Richard L. Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore of Montclair, N.J.

title: PLEASANT COLONY HOLDS OFF WOODCHOPPER, WINS DERBY
description: Johnny Campo said for weeks that Pleasant Colony would win the Kentucky Derby, and racing people scoffed. He buttonholed passersby at racetracks, and they shrugged him off. But at 5:43 p.m. today, Pleasant Colony turned it on at the head of the Churchill Downs stretch and swept to a three-quarter length victory in the 107th running of America's most prestigious thoroughbred race.

title: LONG ISLAND HOUSING
description: RECENT HOME SALES; Nassau Bethpage Stokes Ave. 4-bedroom, 2-bath Colonial Cape $59,000 Fireplace, finished basement. Taxes $2,100 Hicksville Cambridge Dr.3-bedroom, 1-bath ranch $61,300 Finished basement, central air-conditioning. Taxes $1,600 Island Park Nassau Lane 3-bedroom, 1-bath Colonial $49,000 25 years old. Taxes $1,671 Locus

title: TEN FEET TALL?
description: The United States is about to embark on its greatest military buildup since World War II. If the Reagan Administration has its way in Congress, the defense budget will more than double over the next five years. There will be large numbers of new ships, planes, tanks, missiles -and up to 250,000 more men and women in the Armed Forces.

title: NEW DIRECTOR FOR SUMMIT CENTER
description: SUMMIT LARGE art museums, among them the Metropolitan in New York City, are as elaborately complex as corporations and conglomerates. To operate efficiently, they require several leaders who direct their managerial, administrative, financial and cultural functions.

title:
COMMENT;
PRICING GONE GLOOMY
description: A lot of national brand advertising used to carry a small asterisk beside the nationwide prices. And somewhere in fine print was the warning, ''slightly higher west of the Rockies.'' This told buyers that since it cost more to haul the product out West, they had to pay the extra freight costs. That used to be the only reason - outside of a one-time promotional sale -that many identical national products had different prices in different places.

title: THE ALL-STAR TEAM
description: AS baseball begins its annual renewal, familiar figures comfort with their presence (apart from the labor and management negotiators, of course, who are as welcome as a rain-out in July). Peanut hawkers are back in the stands, pushing a product now wildly inflated in price by recent crop failures. Announcers are clearing their throats and filling the longueurs between pitches on hundreds of stations all over the country. The players themselves have had a spring in Florida or Arizona to purge the talk of tax shelters from their conversations and to replace it with the tonic chatter of clubhouse and batting cage. And, up in the stands, the novelists are unlimbering their metaphors, preparing the newest generation of baseball fiction.

title: GOOD NEWS FOR THE 'BAD' SIDE OF TOWN
description: Examples abound of companies moving from crumbling cites to thriving suburbs. Last week, in a rare move the other way, the Connecticut-based firm of Pitney Bowes unveiled plans for a new headquarters in a section of Stamford that, even by inner city standards, is depressed.

title: Vietnamese Move Close to Border
description: About 1,500 Vietnamese troops with tanks have moved close to Cambodia's border with Thailand after reports of a Chinese arms shipment to an anti-Vietnamese group in the area, Thai army sources said today.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Birth by Abortion
description: A routine second-trimester abortion was under way at the Valley Abortion Center in Phoenix, where ''fees range from $90 to $225, depending upon uterine size.'' Evaluating patient information and the size of the fetus, a doctor at the center estimated the woman was 19 weeks' pregnant.

title: SUSPECT INDICTED IN BUFFALO MURDERS
description: The child killings in Atlanta have shocked the nation, but the clearly racially motivated murders of seven black men in the Buffalo area last fall were perhaps even more horrifying in their implications. The tensions stemming from those killings may have eased somewhat last week, however, as officials announced the indictment of an unnamed suspect in three of the deaths.

title:
Stamps;
100 YEARS OF RED CROSS
description: The American Red Cross is now 100 years old and a grateful United States has observed the anniversary of its founding in 1881 with a new 18-cent commemorative that pays tribute to what the organization does for America, and to the hundreds of thousands of volunteer Americans who do it.

title: Map U.S.A.; WILL VOTING RIGHTS SURVIVE IF VOTING RIGHTS ACT DOESN'T
description: Legislative hearings, important as a forum, are often formalities on the way to a forgone conclusion. But as Congress prepares for hearings this week on proposals to extend the Voting Rights Act of 1965, no one can predict the outcome. Whoever marshals the most persuasive facts and arguments may well prevail on the merits.

title: ACTOR SHARING TRADE SECRETS
description: EAST ISLIP ANTHONY HEALD is one actor who is willing to do away with the mystique that surrounds his profession. That's why this week, as he moves through the Town of Islip making 10 appearances in schools, libraries and centers for the elderly as the Islip Arts Council's Affiliate Artists resident performer, he'll share some trade secrets with his audiences.

title: U.S. TRIES TO BACK UP HAIG ON TERRORISM
description: In late January, eight days after the inauguration of President Reagan and three days after the new Administration's first Cabinet-level meeting on terrorism, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. accused the Soviet Union of ''training, funding and equipping'' international terrorists.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Helene Wickett, Pianist, Performs Brahms
description: Helene Wickett's debut piano recital Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House, presented by Pro Musicis, was a mixed success. Miss Wickett was born in California in 1955, has studied there and in Europe, and has performed frequently in this country, Mexico and Europe.

title: Headliners Billie Jean King's Affair
description: Women's professional tennis survived Renee Richards and, despite much fretting, it will no doubt survive the ''image crisis'' that welled up last week around Billie Jean King, one of its stars. Marilyn Barnett, Mrs. King's former secretary, filed a ''palimony'' suit for half of Mrs. King's earnings from a seven-year period in the 1970's when, she said, they had a lesbian relationship. Mrs. King at first denied the allegation. But later, with her husband, Larry, and her parents standing at her side, she said at a press conference she had had ''an affair'' with Miss Barnett, who is a paraplegic as a result of a fall last year. ''I just hope my fans will have compassion and understanding,'' said Mrs. King.

title: Camera; MEDIUM FORMAT MAKING A STRONG COMEBACK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper. Although the 35mm camera has become more popular than ever during the past decade, and although it is the only type of camera used by a large percentage of amateur and professional photographers, in the past few years there has also been an increasing amount of interest in ''medium format,'' 120 size roll film cameras that produce a negative which is considerably larger than 35mm.

title:
DINING OUT;
IT'S FRENCH, SANS TRADITIONAL FINESSE
description: IN A pastoral setting on the outskirts of New Hope, Pa., and just a stone's throw from the Delaware River, Barbara and Omar Arbani operate the very pleasant Hotel du Village. The hotel's restaurant is in a turn-of-the-century country manor house that is set back among tall trees well off the road. From 1925 until 1976, this building and the one across the spacious grounds where the Arbanis take in lodgers were part of a boarding school.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fame for Eureka
description: Propelled into the national limelight last fall by the Presidential candidacy of a noted alumnus, Ronald Reagan, tiny Eureka College in Eureka, Ill., was of two minds.

title: BUSINESS, GOVERNMENT AND NEWS BLUR AT A WASHINGTON CONFERENCE
description: On Monday morning, 100 foreign businessmen who control hundreds of billions of dollars in investments are to assemble in the Old Executive Office Building for the start of a three-day, invitation-only conference on the Reagan Administration's policies toward foreign investment in the United States.

title: SLOW SEDIMENTS ON POLLUTION LAW
description: When is a nuisance not a nuisance? When Congressional legislation overrides common law, according to a Supreme court ruling that Federal courts may not impose water pollution standard more stringent than those set by the Clean Water Act of 1972.

title: Anne Salmson Wed To David Altchek
description: Anne Salmson, daughter of Jean-Francois Salmson of Jouy-en-Josas, France, and Mrs. Alain Danet of Paris, was married at the Westbury Hotel yesterday to David Wilson Altchek, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Altchek of Middletown, N.Y. State Supreme Court Justice Abraham S. Isseks performed the ceremony.

title: EDITOR AT MAGAZINE
description: John Osborne, a senior editor and columnist for the New Republic magazine and an old hand at White House and political coverage, died here today at Sibley Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.

title: 'OWL AND PUSSYCAT' AT THE CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ALTHOUGH Bill Manhoff's ''The Owl and the Pussycat'' goes absolutely nowhere, Louise H. Gorham is definitely going places. You can now catch this exciting actress in Mr. Manhoff's old-fangled romance, which will be at the Crossroads Theater through May 24.

title: NEW EDITION OF BIBLE
description: GREENWICH IN medieval times, Bibles were rare because it took years for monks to handprint a single set. Even the invention of movable type, which made possible Johannes Gutenberg's famed Biblia Latina, published in the 15th century, did not solve the economic problems of bringing an artistic masterpiece within most people's reach.

title:
SPORTS;
RUNNER ATTEMPTS A MARATHON 'DOUBLE'
description: NORTHPORT WHO is Long Island's premier female runner? Sharon Given of Northport appears to be not only one of the Island's fastest but also one of the most active.

title: Katherine Humpstone, Textile Designer, Bride of Jeremy Koch of Time Magazine
description: Katherine Cheney Humpstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Humpstone Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeremy Bowen Koch, son of Jacqueline B. Koch of New York and Norfolk, Conn., and Richard H. Koch of New York. The Rev. Mills R. Omaly, rector of St. Paul's Church in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., and Episcopal chaplain at Vassar College, performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan home.

title: TAMMANY HALL HAS A NEW CHIEF AND A BIGGER MORTGAGE THAN EVER
description: Democrats in Manhattan picked a new county leader last week - unanimously in the public vote, but by the narrowest of margins in a private one just before it. In so doing, they provided a glimpse into the disarray that has befallen the party since the days of Tammany, when it wielded power not only in New York but in the nation.

title: Hidden Economy
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''No Cuts Here: The Life on the Tab'' (March 29), the claim by the restaurant industry that elimination of the expense account deduction would cause loss of jobs and closing of businesses is, in effect, a request for a Federal subsidy to support establishments that might not succeed on their own merits. While one can sympathize with their plight, it must not be forgotten that such high-priority causes as education, health and mass transportation are about to be cut back.

title: Children's Books
description: MORE TALES OF OLIVER PIG By Jean Van Leeuwen. Illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 64 pp. THREE BY THE SEA By Edward Marshall. Illustrated by James Marshall. 48 pp. RAINY SUNDAY Written and Illustrated by Eleanor Schick. 56 pp. New York: The Dial Press. Paper, $2.50 each. (Ages 4 to 8)

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IF YOU CAN'T LICK 'EM, EAT 'EM
description: THE annual battle between gardeners, on the one side, and dandelions and crabgrass, on the other, has begun. A lawn full of these plants is usually cause for despair. They are looked upon as noxious weeds that must be attacked with trowel and poison.

title: WORLD SOCIALISTS SUPPORT PEACE TALKS ON SALVADOR
description: A peaceful solution to the fighting in El Salvador, new pressure on the superpowers to reopen arms control talks, and a possible way out of Western Europe's economic troubles were the principal topics discussed at the Socialist International's World Leaders Conference here this week.

title: 'OPENING NIGHT' GALA
description: Tickets for the May 17 ''Opening Night'' party at Macy's, White Plains, beginning the Harold Clurman Theater Artists Fund at the State University at Purchase, are available for $100. Additional contributions from $500 to $5,000, will provide $30,000, with which the college plans to start a performance program in its four-theater complex under the guidance of resident professionals. ''We hope to build a repertory theater somewhat along the lines of the one at Yale,'' said a spokesman.

title: Cruise Ship Norway Limps Toward Miami With 2,637
description: The Norway limped homeward toward Miami today with her 2,637 passengers and crew members after engineers restored power aboard the vessel, the largest cruise ship in the world.

title: Terry Ellen Frishman Is Wed To Gary S. Gluck, an Ad Man
description: Terry Ellen Frishman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack J. Frishman of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Gary Stephen Gluck, son of Fred Gluck of New York and the late Iris L. Gluck.

title: BAR GROUP BLAMED FOR BIAS ON HIRING
description: The American Bar Association should declare discriminatory hiring and promotion by law firms unethical, a professor told a conference held here to explore the problems faced by lawyers who are members of minority groups.

title: POLITICS; LAWMAKING HAS A LANGUAGE OF ITS OWN
description: HARTFORD VISITORS in the galleries at the State Capitol watching the General Assembly in action these days may wish they had a scorecard at times to keep track of the participants in a debate. But they may also wish they had a dictionary as well.

title: LEADING THE HUNT IN ATLANTA'S MURDERS
description: Like so many of Atlanta's black children today, 15-year-old Jo-Jo Bell often boasted that ''no kid snatcher was going to get me.'' But last March 2nd, after finishing work at a fast-food fish restaurant near his home in southwest Atlanta, Joseph disappeared. On Easter Sunday afternoon, April 19, his mud-caked, decomposing body was pulled from the South River, in neighboring DeKalb County. The body, snagged on fallen branches at a bend in the narrow river, was discovered by a couple enjoying the budding green foliage along a bike trail. It was clad only in gym shorts. Jo-Jo Bell, who was suffocated before being dumped in the river, became still another victim of a tragedy that, with relentless regularity, knocks the breath out of a bewildered city. The table near the entrance to Northside High School's gymnasium is laden with brightly printed posters, bumper stickers and pamphlets that say ''Take a Minute, Save a Child'' and ''Help Keep Our Children Safe - Reward Up to $100,000.'' The adults filing in pick up the materials and head for the folding chairs. Most of the crowd is young and most of it, like the neighborhood around the school, is white. Off to the side, his hands in the pockets of his beige suit jacket as he chats with reporters and waits for the television cameras to be set up, is a tall, solidly built, light-complexioned black man. The woman who introduces him says he is here to discuss ''the situation in our city.''

title: A Plea to Consider Full Assessment's Boons
description: For generations, the belief that low assessments are related to low taxes (''Fair Assessments Are Within Grasp,'' April 12) has prevailed in the land. Somehow, this notion gives great comfort to the property owner who relishes the $8,000 assessment on his $80,000 house - never mind that his tax rate is 10 times what it would be on a market-value assessment.

title: A DIFFERENT OLD WEST NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- R. V. DENENBERG is a frequent contributor to the Travel Section. By R. V. DENENBERG

title: CITIZENS PARTY STILL ALIVE
description: TRENTON THE New Jersey Citizens Party, part of a nationwide organization created in 1979 to advance the candidacies of Barry Commoner and Ladonna Harris in the 1980 Presidential election, has committed itself to a continuing involvement in the state's politics.

title: SAILORS LOOK TO A SEASON OF VARIED YACHT COMPETITIONS
description: WITH the grinding hum of marine travelifts, the fleets of summer are being lowered into the water. A look at the season ahead shows that the Government's reach may be getting longer and that the world apparently continues to become smaller, in yacht racing at least, with a heavy schedule of trans-ocean competitions planned.

title: SATISFYING OFFERINGS IN GLASTONBURY
description: GLASTONBURY WITH its white-frame exterior and low ceiling, multiroom colonialstyle interior, the Blacksmith's Tavern looks as though it would be more at home in a restored village such as Old Sturbridge, rather than in its actual location on the main street of Glastonbury.

title: TAX HELP FOR BUSINESS
description: The Reagan Administration's current push for greater tax incentives for business investment is not a uniquely American phenomenon. High rates of inflation, a continued slowdown in productivity, and declining competitiveness in world markets have touched off what amounts to an investment-incentives race in the industrial West.

title: Bogus Tip Aids Jewelry Theft
description: While the police, acting on a bogus tip, were surrounding the Security Pacific bank five blocks away, a man made off with a $59,000 diamond ring from Mr. B's jewelry store on Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Town in Massachusetts Again Votes for Casino
description: Residents of this small coastal community have made it clear again: They want casino gambling, even if neighboring towns and the Legislature do not.

title: McCarthyism?
description: Could McCarthyism come back? Fears rose after last fall's elections. Strom Thurmond, the new Senate Judiciary Committee chairman, reinstated the old Internal Security Subcommittee. He gave it a title for the 80's - the Subcommittee on Security and Terrorism - but some of the look of the 50's. He appointed as chairman Jeremiah Denton, an Alabama Republican and former Vietnam war prisoner who has won attention for his superpatriotism and moralistic pronouncements.

title: LONG WINTER FOR CAMPERS
description: year-old owner, along with his wife Norma, of Travelers Recreational Vehicle Sales Inc. ''I know I'm almost dead.''

title:
LONG ISLAND HOUSING;
WHEN THE RETARDED LIVE AS A FAMILY
description: ANDREA FIERSTEIN, Ruth Goldberg, Teresa Ferro and the six other women who live together in a large Colonial house on a quiet residential street in Valley Stream call themselves a ''happy family.''

title: A Chicago Split; On Desegregation
description: If it is easier for a camel to pass through a needle's eye than for a rich man to enter heaven, then it would seem easier for a rich man to enter heaven than for the city of Chicago to agree on a plan to desegregate its public schools. Last week, the Board of Education, dividing along racial lines, submitted to a Federal court a desegregation plan that seemed to an outspoken black member a ''political document'' aimed at protecting ''the separation of the races with no guarantees of equal education.''

title: HOLLIS STACY LEADS BY 1 ON 214
description: Hollis Stacy, winner of the United States Women's Open in 1977 and 1978, has had considerable trouble putting for most of the last 12 months. This is one reason why Miss Stacy, a 27-year-old Georgia native, has not won in a year.

title: 'He Got the Best Out of Me'
description: John Mistler, the leading pass receiver last fall in the Pacific 10 Conference, was selected by the Giants last Tuesday in the third round of the National Football League draft. Yesterday, Mistler was at Giants Stadium for a minicamp and told about playing wide receiver at Arizona State under Frank Kush, the controversial head coach who has since moved to the Canadian Football League.

title: 'AMERICAN GLASS '81' DISPLAYS 400 WORKS
description: THE Westlake Gallery in White Plains, which has mounted a juried, invitational glass show annually for four years, opens its ''American Glass '81'' exhibition today, and this season's display promises to be the best one yet. The more than 400 pieces featured are the works of 50 craftsmen from 20 states. Many of the artisans have participated in this show previously and are established, recognized names in the contemporary studio-art glass movement. Others are emerging professionals.

title: Americans Leave Bermuda Because of Labor Strife
description: American vacationers left this island today because of a labor dispute between the white-dominated Government and the black labor movement.

title: 'TABLE MANNERS' OFFRS MEAL IN ITSELF
description: PORT JEFFERSON ''TABLE MANNERS'' is the first of three plays under the panoramic title ''The Norman Conquests.'' Written by Alan Ayckbourn, to whom plays are like puzzles, each piece involves the same people in the same house during the same weekend, but in a different room.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
IS LEGAL THE SAME AS ETHICAL?
description: ON trial last month in Federal District Court in Westbury was a political practice that some politicians, Democrats and Republicans alike, say is acceptable as a practical matter of political business. Lawyers argued that an insurance patronage system practiced by Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican leader, and previously employed by Democrats was legal and therefore all right.

title: THE NATION
description: After viewing his videotaped performances in a Federal courtroom, Harrison A. Williams Jr. said he had been merely ''foolish.'' More like a knave, concluded the jury, which convicted the New Jersey Democrat last week of all nine counts of bribery, conspiracy, receiving an unlawful gratuity, conflict of interest and interstate travel in aid of racketeering.

title: A PLACE FOR MEMORIES TO GATHER STEAM
description: Block-long lines of railroad buffs stood for hours in the strong sun today to buy tickets for a celebration of the American century when deep-throated whistles and the agonized puffing of steam locomotives climbing up grades were a part of almost every long journey.

title: FOES AND SUPPORTERS OF REAGAN POLICIES PLAN RALLIES
description: Opponents of United States military aid for El Salvador, higher military spending and budget cuts in social programs have scheduled an ''antiwar'' march to the Pentagon tomorrow. A counterdemonstration has been scheduled by supporters of Reagan Administration policies.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: PORT WASHINGTON HOWARD BLANKMAN (with a capital B and that rhymes with T and that stands for ''The Music Man'') rose from his front-row seat in Paul D. Schreiber High School after a particularly fast-paced scene and approached the stage apron. Mr. Blankman had been watching and directing one of the last rehearsals for the Port Singers' 35th spring production, and he sensed something he had been trying to put into words. Now he had found them.

title: Quake Drives Italians Outdoors
description: Thousands of people spent the night in cars, tents and sports stadiums in Castelli Romani, south of Rome, after a series of moderate quakes. The first tremor jolted the region shortly after 9 P.M. and it was followed by at least five others in the next 12 hours. The quakes caused cracks in some old buildings, but no injuries were reported.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Agnew Ordered; To Fork It Over
description: It's usually safe for a politician to rely on tradition, but it will cost Spiro Agnew almost $250,000. The tradition in question was the payment of kickbacks by Maryland contractors to leading politicians, a practice which in 1973 Mr. Agnew told his lawyer and good friend, George W. White Jr., had been ''going on for 1,000 years.''

title: SOME SEASON FINALES
description: SPRING may be a time for new beginnings, but it also has its farewells, as the bountiful music season in Connecticut gradually winds down. On the orchestral scene over the next fortnight, for instance, we can offer hail-and-farewells to the Norwalk Symphony and the Greenwich Philharmonia, chamber windups include Music From Marlboro and the Wall Street Chamber Players, and vocally it's so long for a while to Connecticut Opera and the Pro Arte Chamber Singers.

title: ERATOSTHENES OF ALEXANDRIA HAD AN IDEA
description: THE MAPMAKERS By John Noble Wilford. Illustrated. 414 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: WILLIAMS'S TRIAL IS THE LAST OF 8 MAJOR ABSCAM CASES
description: Abscam was the most sweeping undercover investigation of political corruption ever undertaken by the Justice Department - a two-year, multimillion-dollar inquiry that involved scores of agents, secret meetings, phony sheiks, hidden cameras, bribes and a parade of Congressmen.

title: Mary E. Churchill Is Married To D. Douglas Wyman Jr.
description: Mary Elizabeth Churchill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard James Churchill of Garden City, L.I., was married there yesterday to D. Douglas Wyman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Douglas Wyman of Dover, Del.

title: Roman Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORT FINDS PHILADELPHIA CRIME GROUP IN DISARRAY
description: This city's crime syndicate is now a mob in disarray, ''possibly leaderless'' after the slaying of six key members, including its latest chieftain six weeks ago, the Pennsylvania Crime Commission has concluded.

title: METS BEAT PADRES, 6-2, TO END SEVEN- GAME LOSING STREAK
description: The New York Mets got timely hitting and no-hit relief pitching yesterday at Shea Stadium and beat the San Diego Padres, 6-2, to end a seven-game losing streak.

title:
GARDENING;
GYPSY MOTHS: THE SEASONAL BATTLE BEGINS
description: BY now everyone must have heard the story of the scientist who, in his attempt to develop a hardy silkworm, inadvertently unleashed the gypsy moth. This occurred in 1869, when a container of insect egg clusters from France that M. Leopold Trouvelot had placed on a windowsill broke and fell to the ground. Try as he might, he was unable to recover them.

title: U.S. WATER RULES CITED AS RATES INCREASE
description: BRIDGEPORT ''WE are going to have fairly large numbers of people seeing their bills going up quicker than is customary,'' according to David J. Harrigan, vice chairman of the State Public Utilities Control Authority. To consumers familiar with annual increases in their electricity and natural gas rates, that might not seem to be news.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: 2081 A Hopeful View of the Human Future. By Gerard K. O'Neill. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: SCHOOL FLUORIDE TEST GETS GOOD GRADES
description: SETAUKET ABOUT 4,000 elementary school students in the Three Village School District leave their classrooms once a week to swish a fluoride solution between their teeth. At the school district's health offices, home-room teachers supervise the one-minute rinses, administered by part-time monitors, and remind the children not to swallow the bitter-tasting solution.

title: Free Met Concerts Open June 16 in Central Park
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 15th season of free summer concert-opera performances will begin June 16 on Central Park's Great Lawn with Puccini's ''Tosca.''

title: Recordings; POTENTIAL PROFITS LURE RECORD COMPANIES TO OPERA
description: Record companies are becoming more cautious with their money these days, and expensive opera sets rarely go into production without a strong reason to justify their existence. Even such a potential winner as Deutsche Grammophon's new ''Parsifal'' conducted by Herbert von Karajan (2741 001, five digital disks) must have given that company pause. ''Parsifal'' does not have the universal appeal of, say, ''La Boheme,'' and Polygram, DG's parent organization, has already cornered the market on Wagner's opera with four other versions on its various affiliated labels. Moreover, Mr. Karajan is an exacting maestro who takes his time in the studio - this ''Parsifal'' is rumored to be the most costly opera recording ever made.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR SHE HAS CONQUERED EVERYTHING BUT BROADWAY, AND NOW...
description: February, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: THE HAIR-DYE: WHEN GRAY TURNS TO PURPLE
description: I was supposed to be a black orchid, but I came up an eggplant instead. My hair has been cellophaned purple. Unlike the clinging wrapping on fruit baskets sent on happy and sad occasions, cellophane is the newest in natural hair coloring. Even after the promise that I would look 10 years younger, it was the color that seduced me - black orchid. Being a late bloomer in life, black orchid conjured up in my mind South African fantasies of jungle queens. With my long mousy hair cellophaned black orchid, I could envision myself on the welcoming committee of Fastasy Island, handing out leis.

title: PEACE CORPS RECALLED
description: ARDSLEY ''THERE isn't anything you can talk about today that doesn't in some way relate to my experience in the Peace Corps,'' said Margaret Chamberlin. ''It was the greatest experience in my life.''

title: ARE BRAINS GENETIC?
description: THE INTELLIGENCE CONTROVERSY By H.J. Eysenck and Leon Kamin. Illustrated. 192 pp. New York: John Wiley and Sons. $12.95.

title: DeLorean
description: To the Business Editor: In his excellent article ''Engineers Should Run the Auto Business'' (April 26), John Z. DeLorean misses the age of the now popular transverse engine front-wheel-drive layout by a factor of two.

title: Music View; THE SOUND OF CARNEGIE HALL
description: Carnegie Hall turns 90 this week, a grande dame who has survived the 20th century's social revolutions and musical crises without so much as having her tiara tilted. She is a symbol of stability, American music's version of the Queen Mother. However, Carnegie represents more than mere continuity, mere survival. The hall is an emblem of artistic integrity, reminding us daily by its brown, beetling Florentine presence that excellence is not only fleetingly attainable in this world but that, with luck and determination, it can be preserved.

title: HE FINDS THAT RISK HAS ITS DIVIDENDS
description: JOLYON STERN has long been certain about a couple of things: From the time he was a boy, selling soft drinks to fishermen while summering in Center Moriches, he knew he wanted to go into business. And then he saw no reason why his personal interests and his business interests could not be combined.

title: CENTERS FOR AGED FEEL CUTS IN FUNDS
description: LYNDA RISHKOSSKI found it hard to tell the 100 elderly people at the Coram Senior Citizen Center that they may soon be spending more time alone because of Federal budget cuts that have sliced into their nutrition program.

title: A Second-Best Voice on El Salvador
description: Just what is the American purpose in El Salvador? Is it to prevent a leftist takeover at all costs, even if American aid is mistaken as a license for butchery? The Reagan Administration has deplored the widespread violence, but it has not yet made its words emphatic or credible. It has thus earned the bipartisan kick from the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: CONGRESSIONAL BLOC SPLITS BY PARTY LINES ON BUDGET
description: WASHINGTON MOST members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation seem to agree that the scheduled House vote this week on differing Federal budget plans represents a choice between a potentially disastrous package and an alternative that is not totally satisfactory.

title: CHURCHILL DID BUSINESS WITH HITLER?
description: XPD By Len Deighton. 339 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Royals 7, Rangers 2
description: Amos Otis went 2 for 3 and drove in two runs and Willie Aikens went 2 for 2 and scored twice to pace Kansas City.

title: Navy Sued Over Sailor's Death
description: The parents of a 21-year-old sailor who died aboard the U.S.S. Ranger have filed a $4.1 million lawsuit against the Navy, charging that their son was subjected to cruel and unusual punishment. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court yesterday by William and Irene Trerice of Algonac, Mich. The Navy said that their son, Paul Trerice, died April 14 of cardiac arrest and heat stroke after he was forced to do punitive exercises.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
BEASTIES AND THINGS THAT GO BUMP IN THE NIGHT
description: IT must have been the painters who unleashed a curse when they broke my bedroom mirror. Superstitious silliness, perhaps, but with that shattered glass began a year of unprecedented invasions.

title: FOR JOCKEY OF THE DERBY WINNER IT'S A BIG 'WELCOME TO THE CLUB'
description: Before the race, Jorge Velasquez had said he wanted to win a Kentucky Derby ''so badly I can taste it.'' As he undressed in front of his locker in the Churchill Downs jockeys room a few minutes after winning the Derby on Pleasant Colony, he was savoring it.

title: 18 Food Handlers Cited As Health Law Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 18 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. The department also named two establishments that had corrected earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: THE AMERICAN DUEL OVER GUNS
description: Michael Norman is a frequent contributor to The Times Magazine. By Michael Norman Guns are a great and a brilliant example of the individuality of our citizens, just like owning an automobile. -WILLIAM B. RUGER, a gun manufacturer. ---

title: AT THE U.N., THE 'SO-CALLED THIRD WORLD' TURNS REAL
description: The foreign policy chiefs in the Reagan Administration learned last week that the third world is a real phenomenon after all, at least inside the glass and concrete precincts of the United Nations. The lesson was administered in the Security Council, where, despite misgivings by some, the six third world members voted together for a cutoff of economic and diplomatic relations with South Africa. Their ostensible aim was to increase the pressure on Pretoria to grant independence to South-West Africa, or Namibia. But their underlying purpose was to smoke out the Reagan Administration's position.

title: SEXUAL HARASSMENT ON FEDERAL JOBS CALLED COSTLY
description: Job turnover, health care costs and lost productivity because of sexual harassment of Federal workers cost taxpayers $189 million in a two-year period, a Government agency has reported.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Debating the Draft
description: The news dispatch last April 9 began: ''The Berkeley Board of Education will require high school students to take instruction that includes counseling on how to avoid the draft.''

title: FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH
description: An Army colonel found that a Japanese sword he owned was worth $70,000. Two paintings discovered in an old house were identified as works of Paolo Veronese and worth $378,650.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: PRIVATE TUTORING GIVES CITY CHILDREN A SECOND CHANCE
description: SPARTA WENDELL JONES'S struggles with third-grade studies in the big public school across the street from his tenement home in Newark seemed trivial among his family's concerns.

title: FILM ON REVELRY OF CHURCH TREK BANNED IN SPAIN
description: Freedom of artistic expression in post-Franco Spain is a matter of two steps forward, one backward. In the highest tradition of this dialectic, a judge in Seville has banned the showing of a documentary film about a popular Andalusian festival after a right-wing politician said it ''gravely insults and ridicules the Catholic religion.''

title: Marcos Insists on Vote June 16
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that presidential elections will be held June 16 in the Philippines even if he has no opponent because ''we are too far in now.'' The United Democratic Opposition, a coalition of anti-Marcos groups, has said that it will not offer a candidate and will campaign for a boycott of the election.

title: Marguerite Lorenze Is Wed
description: Marguerite Tracey Lorenze, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Doubleday Lorenze of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Anthony Donald Emposimato, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Emposimato of Middletown, N.J. Msgr.

title: STATES'S GAINS DEFENDED
description: Interest groups opposing President Reagan's spending reforms have taken some familiar shots at state government that simply aren't on target anymore. Their motives undoubtedly range from a genuine concern for those whom social programs are meant to help to a simple desire to protect bureaucratic turf in Washington. Their tactics, however, have involved the unfair resurrection of charges that the states are racist or incompetent or insensitive to the needs of the poor. These charges have little of the credibility that might have been present 20 years ago.

title: DEFENSE OPENS IN EXTORTION TRIAL OF EX-LEGISLATOR IN RHODE ISLAND
description: Edward P. Manning, who was once Speaker of the House in the General Assembly, is fighting Federal charges that he coerced two companies who were seeking business in the state to give him cash and carpeting worth $5,713.

title: A LOOK INSIDE PAUL VOLCKER'S FED
description: WASHINGTON O N the morning of March 30, Topic A for most Americans was still the shooting of President Reagan the day before. At the Federal Reserve, the nation's seemingly cloistered central bank, the buzzing in the corridors concerned monetary policy. A gathering of the Federal Open Market Committee was getting underway, just as it does every 45 days or so.

title: AWASH WITH LISTS AND CATALOGUES
description: DARCONVILLE'S CAT By Alexander Theroux. 704 pp. New York: Doubleday. $15.95

title: TOURING THE TRAILS WITH A BIKE GROUP
description: CYCLING on your own is one thing - you undertake a spirit of adventure, a devil-may-care attitude, adopting a hell-bent-for-thewind attitude as you ride through the countryside - but if you have the slightest element of reservation or if you prefer companionship in your quest for fresh air and the open wheel, there is a service group that's organized well enough to take care of you.

title: Columbus
description: To the Editor:

title: David Forster to Wed Dale Newson June 27
description: The Rev. and Mrs. David Hughes Newson of Bloomfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dale Elizabeth Newson, to David Chapman Forster, son of Mrs. Elizabeth Chapman Forster of Darien, Conn. and Norman D. Forster of New York and Washington, Conn. The wedding is planned for June 27 at the Watchung Presbyterian Church in Bloomfield, where Miss Newson's father is the minister.

title: R.E. Pace Weds Susan Andon
description: Susan Andon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ashod J. Andon of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert E. Pace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Augustine L. Pace of Hartford. The ceremony was performed at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

title: FASHION STUDENT IS HONORED
description: THREE years ago, Harlan Steffe drove his daughter, Cynthia, whom everybody calls Cindy, from his farm in Moville, Iowa, population 1,200, to New York to go to school. ''He's always said the hardest thing he ever did was leave me here,'' said Miss Steffe, now 23 years old and a resident of Purchase.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
OVERREACTING TO THE NEW PHILOSOPHY
description: AS moderate politicians throughout the country attempt to put a little spin on their public statements, to accent their similarities to the Reagan Administration's philosophy and to minimize their differences, I am struck at the extent of our political insecurity and anxiety.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Richard Trythall Offers His New Suite for Piano
