description: Like so many composers in their mid-40's, Richard Trythall seems to have experienced an esthetic crisis in the last couple of years. Before then, he had done all the fashionable things, toeing the post-Webern line, experimenting with electronic music and winning most of the available grants for a promising young avant-gardist.

title: Eileen Therese Drucker Bride
description: The marriage of Eileen Therese Drucker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Drucker of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, to Peter Allen Zwart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Zwart of Oreland, Pa., took place yesterday. The Rev. James Keenan performed the ceremony in Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: ANTI-ABORTION BILL OPPOSED BY 6 EX-ATTORNEYS GENERAL
description: Six former United States Attorneys General, half Democrats and half Republicans, have signed a letter describing as unconstitutional a bill designed to ban abortion by overruling a Supreme Court ruling.

title: AN ECONOMIST WITH STYLE
description: A LIFE IN OUR TIMES Memoirs. By John Kenneth Galbraith.563 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $16.95.

title: At Iowa, a Revenue-Sharing Plan in Sports
description: Men's athletic programs at the University of Iowa are giving the women's programs financial help. The women are using popular men's coaches to lure potential contributors to fund-raising luncheons. Proceeds from this year's intrasquad football game will help balance the women's budget.

title: MOSES MALONE AT CENTER STAGE
description: HOUSTON WHEN the endless National Basketball Association season finally ended and the playoffs began, when each day took on a meaning and every loose ball an urgency, when it was time to stop cruising and produce a maximum effort for 48 minutes a game, Moses Malone of the Houston Rockets did not need to make any adjustment.

title: Dr. Eve Elizabeth Slater Is Wed
description: Dr. Eve Elizabeth Slater, a cardiologist and assistant professor of medicine at Harvard University, was married yesterday to Adam Sanders Solomon, a vice president for corporate finance of Salomon Brothers in New York. The Rev. Dr. Edwin H. Cassem, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Harvard's Memorial Church.

title: Missy Cusick Bride Of Douglas Clifford
description: Edla Cusick and Douglas Patrick Clifford were married yesterday in New York. Civil Court Judge Bruce Wright of New York County performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's sister, Mrs. Douglas Eaton.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: COMMUNITY theater, at least in Brewster, means that nearly everybody gets into the act. The actors live in surrounding communities, and their neighbors, starting the night of May 8, will be asked at the box office to become actors. They will also be asked, quite literally, to judge the play.

title: Jim and Sandy
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''All Agog Over Jim and Sandy'' (April 26), what must worry many is whether Jim and Sandy are cut from the cloth of those consummate clowns who cannot separate ''I want'' from ''We need'' or, at hazard, substitute ''We shall overcome'' for ''We must examine completely.''

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC The Fabulous Thunderbirds play blues and blues-based rock and roll with punch, drive and authority. Unlike most white blues bands, they have found their own style within the blues tradition and project as originals rather than as imitators.

title: Bridge; HATS OFF TO CARDS
description: Amillenary is much more important than a centenary, and the ladies no doubt wear their best hats for the celebration. So this department and other writers on the game were decidedly remiss 12 years ago in failing to note the millenary of playing cards.

title: TONI BETH FINDER IS FIANCEE OF DAVID LIEMER, COPYWRITER
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Finder of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Toni Beth Finder, to David Charles Liemer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin D. Liemer of Warren, N.J.

title: Youth Held in Brother's Slaying
description: A Dutchess County teen-ager was charged with stabbing his brother to death today, the police said. They said 19-year-old Kevin Luty was charged after he allegedly stabbed his brother Mark, 18, in the heart with a 4-inch folding knife about 3:20 A.M., apparently following an argument at a party.Mr. Luty was held in the Dutchess County Jail without bail.

title: AUTOMATIC POLITICAL REACTION...
description: Too much of the political discussion that we hear divides along predictable lines, and the result is that we quickly guess what is coming next. The reason is the automatic response. The automatic response comes in several varieties, of which conservative and liberal are probably the most familiar. It is guaranteed to bore all but its true believers, and, far worse, it keeps us from seeing sensible solutions to our problems.

title: Dr. Anne C. Kossowan Wed To Gregory J. Blasi, Lawyer
description: Dr. Anne Carol Kossowan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John William Kossowan of Hamilton, Mass., was married there yesterday in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church to Gregory Joseph Blasi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Blasi of Delray Beach, Fla.

title: THE QUESTION S ARE HOW AND WHY
description: THE dream of finding a fountain of youth still belongs to the realm of science fiction; but a combination of medical advances and other factors means that more people are living a larger portion of their perhaps genetically appointed span. As more Americans live longer, older citizens have become an important constituency. It is a measure of their political power that Social Security retirement benefits were notably exempt from the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts; last week, bills were introduced in Congress to improve retirement income by refinancing Social Security and reforming the private pension system. The complex biology of the aging process and the special problems of older age have received new attention, partly under the impetus of the National Institute on Aging. The following articles bring together some recent findings on the physiology and the psychology of aging. By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: Teacher Penalized Over Use Of Aristotle and Machiavelli
description: A high school English teacher has been ruled insubordinate and suspended without pay for teaching works of Aristotle and Machiavelli to his 10th grade students despite the orders of his principal.

title: Follow-Up on the News;
description: For 16 years the painting had hung without fuss in a prisoners' dining hall on Rikers Island, looking to some like a 5-by-4-foot question from a Rorschach test. Then prison officials learned that the painting, a Salvador Dali rendition of the Crucifixion that the artist had given to the inmates, was worth $75,000 to $100,000.

title: COACH SAID, 'WE PLAY WIN'-- SO I SAT
description: THIS much, and not much more, can be said for sitting on the bench: it gives you time to think. Last summer I had plenty of time for that. I sat on the bench in an adult softball league in Westchester for 40 of 49 innings.

title: By TRACIE ROZHON
description: HADDAM THEY were everywhere. Big straw baskets in the dining room, penny straw baskets on the porch. Baskets in what was once the living room, baskets on the sill in the kitchen. An antique hat tree had a different-shaped basket hanging from every limb.

title: THE SETTING ENHANCES THE FOOD
description: MERELY walking through the door of the Old Inlet Inn in Bellport is appealing. The restaurant is situated in a gracious white Victorian house that was built in 1890. On July 4, 1980, it was included in the National Register of Historic Places.

title: THE MAKING OF DIVINE WILD FOREST
description: FLOWERS OF EMPTINESS Reflections on an Ashram. By Sally Belfrage. 240 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $10.95.

title: Betsy Nolte, M. T. Brown Are Married
description: Elizabeth Ann Nolte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Charles Nolte Jr. of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., was married at St. James Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Michael Thomas Brown, son of Mrs. Owen J. Brown of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mr. Brown. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett performed the ceremony.

title: OIL-BASED EXPORTS LAG
description: The earlier-than-scheduled decontrol of domestic petroleum prices, which took place two months ago, and the rising value of the dollar are hurting American exports of petrochemicals.

title: Boxer Fought Racism in Army
description: To the Sports Editor: It was with great interest that I read Harry Markson's article on Joe Louis (The New York Times, April 19, 1981). I was particularly intrigued by Louis's attempt to combat racism at Fort Riley, Kan., during World War II when he assisted Jackie Robinson in integrating the camp baseball and football teams.

title: Potvin Settles a Garden Issue
description: Denis Potvin did not seem the least bit perturbed last night when Madison Square Garden fans greeted his appearance with a torrent of boos. The Islanders' all-star defenseman and captain registered no signs of emotion when a section of Ranger fans chanted abuse at him or showered the ice near him with dead fish.

title: Vern Sneider, the Writer Of a Book on Okinawa
description: Vern Sneider, the author of the book ''The Teahouse of the August Moon,'' which was the basis for the Pulitzer Prize-winning play adapted by John Patrick, died Friday of a heart attack at his home in Monroe, Mich. He was 64 years old.

title: NEIGHBOR HELD IN KILLING OF L.I. MOTHER AND CHILDREN
description: A 23-year-old Hicksville, L.I., man was arrested late last night and charged with the murder of three of his neighbors, a 34-year-old mother and her two children, who were found stabbed to death Friday morning in a second-floor bedroom of their home.

title: BOUQUET OF CONCERTS BID SEASON FAREWELL
description: SPRING may be a time for new beginnings, but it also has its farewells, as Westchester's bountiful music season gradually winds down.

title: AMTRAK CHANGES ON SCHEDULE
description: WASHINGTON WHILE Amtrak and its supporters in Congress do a railroader's ''gandy dance'' in trying to save the bulk of the nation's passenger sys-tem from Reagan Administration budget-cutters, improvements are taking effect on the Washington-New York-Boston run, Amtrak's busiest stretch.

title: WIDER PRESS SHIELD PROPOSED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey is submitting a proposal to the Legislature to bar the use of a search warrant to recover documents held by journalists or news organizations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Senator Williams will have to ask himself whether he can effectively serve his constituents and the nation under the circumstances.'' - Senator Robert C. Byrd, minority leader. (1:6.)

title: Film View; OF FAITH AND THE MYSTERIES OF JERRY LEWIS
description: Let us now consider the ''Jerry Lewis Mysteries,'' as if Jerry Lewis, the performer-director-writer-what-have-you, were not a person but the dimly remembered god of an esoteric cult, a Demeter or a Dionysius whose followers regard him as the relic of the divine Minoan child. One cannot explain him. If one accepts any aspect of him, one must accept all of him. Faith, which was formerly backed by Paramount, is still paramount, though now backed by 20th Century-Fox. The initiation rites are rigorous, involving principally, a carefully acquired ability to cross one's eyes and keep them crossed for as long as 90 minutes, or whatever happens to be the running time of the Jerry Lewis movie being watched in whatever temporary sanctuary it's being projected, say, the Trans-Lux 85th Street Theater.

title: GYPSY MOTH SPRAYING RENEWS OLD DISPUTE
description: The proposed use of a pesticide to eliminate serious infestations of gypsy moths in portions of Van Cortlandt Park and Staten Island is being challenged by some community members. Their opposition has rekindled an old debate between those who oppose the use of pesticides and those who feel they are necessary to save the trees.

title: Abortion Group May Lose Aid
description: The Reagan Administration's personnel director, an opponent of abortion, said that he might drop Planned Parenthood as one of the agencies benefitting from the annual charity drive among Federal workers. He has the sole authority to make the decision. The group has participated in the Government's Combined Federal Campaign for 14 years and received $801,943 from Federal workers' voluntary contributions in 1979-80, a small fraction of its total $140 million budget.

title: THREE CENTURIES OF CONNECTICUT ART
description: NEW BRITAIN THOUGH modern buildings and highways have diluted its dour, northern character, the ''Hardware City'' retains many relics of its 19th- and early 20th-century past, including a handsome City Hall of reddish-colored stone that was designed by Stanford White. Still, for the reviewer, it was the churches of New Britain that, on a recent visit, primed the nostalgia pump - reminders of a time when commerce and religion worked in close conjunction with each other and to their great mutual benefit.

title: Shifting Pattern in; Atlanta Killings?
description: Now, the authorities fear, young Atlanta blacks of any age may be a killer's quarry. Last week a 21-year-old man was identified as victim Number 26 - and the fourth consecutive adult victim - in the sequence of so far unsolvable murders.

title: New Scorecard for; Arms Controllers
description: After months of infighting among conservatives, many of them vigorous critics of past regimes at the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the White House finally made clear last week who would be in charge there.

title: ANGLICANS ADDRESS WAR AND POVERTY
description: It may have started as the most English of institution and may have grown, in some opinions, too venerable by half; but last week's meeting of its primates seemed designed to demonstrate that the Anglican Church is now a worldwide religion, with its social consciousness thoroughly up to date.

title: Soviet and Afghan Forces Said to Attack Kandahar
description: Soviet and Afghan forces have sealed off Kandahar, Afghanistan's second largest city, and blasted its Old City quarter and nearby villages from helicopter gunships and tanks, an Afghan source said today.

title: PROGRAM FOCUSES ON CHILD'S I.Q.
description: TWO groups of Westchester sixth graders are participating in an experiment that seeks to prove intelligence can be taught. The program, called ''Instrumental Enrichment,'' is part of a national movement that is rapidly gaining prominence among educators as an effective method to identify and correct learning deficits.

title: Grant Approved for Warehouse
description: A $650,000 Federal grant has been approved for construction of a tobacco company's warehouse and office here, a spokesman for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato announced today. The concern, Modern Tobacco and Company of Port Chester, plans to use the Federal Urban Development Action grant along with $2,215,250 in private funds to construct a 40,000-square-foot warehouse and office building, according to the spokesman. The project is expected to result in 60 new jobs.

title: MARKET GROWS FOR ONE-ROOM 'STUDIO' HOUSE
description: The ''studio home'' is now selling for $26,990 in the New Jersey Pinelands. It is part of what the National Association of Home Builders predicts will be a movement toward construction of smaller homes.

title: TRIBUTE WILL HIGHLIGHT STORY OF A WEST SIDE RABBI
description: When Rabbi Edward E. Klein was in Roosevelt Hospital three years ago recovering from a stroke, a nurse asked him, ''Rabbi, are you Jewish?'' Amused, the rabbi wondered aloud at the question, he recalled the other day, and the nurse explained: ''Because so many priests come to see you.''

title: Jewish Heritage Week Beginning
description: President Reagan today proclaimed next week as Jewish Heritage Week ''in homage to the significant contributions made by the Jewish community to the United States.''

title: College Coaches And Their Failings
description: To the Sports Editor: I feel a need to comment on Ralph J. Sabock's, ''Advice for the High School Coach With a Star Athlete'' (The New York Times, April 26).

title: A TOUGH OIL MAN IN COAL, BUT HOW MUCH IS BLUFF
description: WASHINGTON

title: MRS KING OFFERS TO QUIT AS W.T.A. HEAD, SO NOT TO HURT PLAYERS
description: Billie Jean King said yesterday she was prepared to resign as president of the Women's Tennis Association, ''if they don't want me as president anymore.''

title: NEW LIFE'S CULTURAL DEMONS TORTURE LAOTIAN REFUGEE
description: In retrospect, there were clues that all was not well with Theng Pao Yang. But that would not seem unusual for a Hmong tribesman, one of the thousands who fled the remote shellscarred mountain fastnesses of Laos, eluding gunfire, disease and starvation, to begin a disturbingly strange new existence in the United States.

title: AZTEC FAMILY'S ART
description: ''Popular art is created by contemporary self-taught painters, primitive art is tribal and naive art is by people who would like to be thought of as primitive,'' Selden Rodman, art critic and author, said. He is curator of an exhibition at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk tomorrow through May 31.

title: Four Homers by A's Beat Yankees, 6 to 3
description: Manager Gene Michael of the Yankees accused Oakland's pitchers of throwing spitters today after the A's pounded New York's pitchers with four home runs in a 6-3 victory.

title: Trooper Acts as Pupil In Drug Investigation
description: Mike Pershing, a 34-year-old state trooper posing as a student, has been credited with breaking up a drug ring at Northrup High School when 20 arrests completed his five-month investigation. Nine students were charged with selling drugs and 11 adults were charged with providing the narcotics.

title: STAGE: 'THE MISER' REVISED AS MUSICAL
description: Earl McCarroll gives fair warning: In a director's note toward the back of the program for ''The Miser,'' the Equity Library Theater's current production, Mr. McCarroll writes that his concept and translation of the Moliere comedy take liberties with the text and plot in the interest of immediacy and accessibility.

title:
GARDENING;
GYPSY MOTHS: THE SEASONAL BATTLE BEGINS
description: BY now everyone must have heard the story of the scientist who, in his attempt to develop a hardy silkworm, inadvertently unleashed the gypsy moth. This occurred in 1869, when a container of insect egg clusters from France that M. Leopold Trouvelot had placed on a windowsill broke and fell to the ground. Try as he might, he was unable to recover them.

title: OPERA FROM THE HEART OF TEXAS
description: Deborah Trustman frequently writes on the arts. By Deborah Trustman On April 15, nine days before the Houston Grand Opera was scheduled to present the world premiere of Carlisle Floyd's ''Willie Stark,'' it staged a ''Willie Rally.''

title: FOR A NOVICE, LEARNING TO SAIL IS HARDER THAN IT LOOKS
description: What does it take to make a sailor? More than a boat, a breeze and a briny brew...

title: Opposition in India Backs Building of Atomic Arsenal
description: India's opposition Janata Party decided today that the country should build an arsenal of atomic bombs if Pakistan persists in developing the bomb.

title: GRIM YEAR FOR HOUSING
description: While last year's severe mortgage rates pushed the housing industry into its worst depression since 1975, builders in some areas of the country fared notably better than those in others.

title: SPECULATION BEGUN ON WILLIAMS'S SEAT
description: The bribery conviction of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. has heightened speculation, already started in New Jersey in this gubernatorial election year, about what might happen if the Senate seat should become vacant before Mr. Williams's term ends Dec. 31, 1982.

title: Videotapes Made At Women's Health Parley
description: Thank you for the recent coverage of the first national conference on health issues of women over 40 (in the article ''Women and Health: False Stereotypes Challenged for Aged'').

title: DNA & SONS: A HIGH RISK VENTURE
description: Bionics, the ALZA Corporation, Genex, Applied Molecular Genetics, and many others with similarly arcane names have joined their more well-known genetic engineering brethren, Genentech and the Cetus Corporation, in the race for investors' millions. But now that more than $1.5 billion has been doled out for the infant industry, people are wondering when they will begin to reap a return.

title: Exit Mr. Lederer
description: Last Election Day, when the five other Abscam defendants in the House were turned out of office, Representative Raymond F. Lederer, a Democrat from Philadelphia, was a winner despite his indictment. His luck ran out when he was tried and convicted of taking a $50,000 bribe from undercover G-men. And last week, after the House Ethics Committee recommended his expulsion, he announced that he would give up his seat in Congress. Mr. Lederer, who is appealing his conviction, said he was resigning because his ''personal legal problems'' were cutting too deeply into the time he could devote to his constituents' interests.

title: Jamie McGlone Is Married on L.I. to Stephen duPont Jr.
description: The marriage of Jamie W. McGlone to Stephen duPont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. duPont of Osprey, Fla., and Fairfield, Conn., took place yesterday. Judge Robert Roberto of the District Court of Nassau County performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. James William McGlone, parents of the bride, in Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: INNOVATIVE BANDS ON THE ROCK SCENE
description: Rock-and-roll is in a curious place these days, but not necessarily an uninteresting one if you know where to look. There are a few megalithic veterans who still tour the big arenas; as we speak, the Rolling Stones are apparently gearing up for their ritual triennial American tour. Lesser bands top the charts with industrious recyclings of the rock gestures of yesteryear. The airwaves are glutted with country, middle-of-the-road and slick soul. Even the clubs are swamped with faceless imitations.

title: Leisure; SHADY GARDENS CAN BE COLORFUL, TOO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lois B. Himes is a writer and lecturer on gardening. By LOIS B. HIMES

title: Ex-Tennessee Official Acquitted Of Selling Freedom to Prisoners
description: A Federal jury yesterday acquitted Charles Benson, a former extradition officer, of selling freedom to inmates in the administration of Gov. Ray Blanton.

title: No Headline
description: A plane of the International Committee of the Red Cross, carrying medical supplies, landed at the Beirut Airport today, the first plane to land there since April 22.

title: A CONSULTANT'S VIEW OF A GOVERNOR'S ROLE
description: PRINCETON NEW JERSEY voters will have to understand the difference between a leader and a manager if they are going to elect the right candidate for Governor.

title: Island-Hopper
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Warns On; Right-Wing Terror
description: In recent weeks, the White House had consigned El Salvador to the back burner, hoping to minimize distractions from its domestic economic program. No such luck. Last week United States citizens again were in jeopardy in San Salvador, even as the House Foreign Affairs Committee was voting to make military aid conditional on containing ''indiscriminate torture and murder'' by Salvadoran security forces.

title: U.S. AIDE CALLS JAPAN'S AUTO CURBS NONINFLATIONARY
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that Japan's decision to reduce auto exports to the United States would have little if any effect on price levels and should help domestic manufacturers raise the capital they need to meet future Japanese competition.

title: JUDGE FLIPS FAMILY ALBUM
description: Is a husband the ''head and master'' of his household? Should parents be notified by the doctor before their pregnant teen-age daughter can have an abortion? May minor children be permanently taken away from their parents if the parents don't do a good job of raising them?

title:
ANTIQUES;
TREASURE HUNTING AT THE FLEA MARKETS
description: A VARIETY of excellent indoor shows will be produced throughout the summer, but from now until the end of September, collectors will also be able to search for their favorite form of antique treasure in suburban meadows, school playing fields, town greens and on the grounds of historic house museums.

title: POSTAL SERVICE IS STILL BESET BY SEVERAL TOUGH PROBLEMS
description: As the United States Postal Service moves toward the July 1 observance of its 10th year as an independent agency, it finds itself beset by troubles that include growing opposition from members of Congress bent on reasserting a measure of control.

title: N.F.L. Draft Is Cool To 3 All-Americans
description: As always, there were a number of players in the National Football League's draft this year who were not chosen as high as as they had been led to expect by their agents, their college publicists, their family and friends or even some N.F.L. scouts.

title: Getting With It
description: To the Editor:

title: Bogus Doctor Guilty in Death
description: A former pharmacist who impersonated a doctor for five years at an industrial medical clinic has pleaded guilty to involuntary manslaughter of a diabetic patient who died under his care. Gerald Barnes, 47 years old, also pleaded guilty Thursday to a charge of practicing medicine without a license.

title: WASHINGTON-NEW YORK: COUPLES WHO LIVE IN BOTH
description: The biggest problem is having the right accessories in the right place at the right time. ''The shoes I need are always in the wrong city,'' says Nancy Kissinger. ''I have two of everything,'' says Ellen Straus. ''The disaster is when both black pocketbooks end up in the same place. ''I keep two sets of tails, one in each city, but I always seem to be dashing out just before a concert to buy another white tie,'' says Eugene Istomin, the concert pianist. Best of All Worlds

title: BUFMAN CARRIES OFF A THEATRICAL COUP
description: JUST when the producer Zev Bufman thought he could get rid of the label ''king of revivals,'' he enticed Elizabeth Taylor to make her stage debut in the 42-year-old play ''The Little Foxes,'' which opens on Broadway Thursday night.

title: Israel and Syria Step Across the Line in Lebanon
description: In 1976, Syria and Israel reached a tacit understanding over Lebanon. Syria got silent approval to police north-central Lebanon, Israel the go-ahead to pursue Palestinians in the south. Last week, both countries broke the rules, raising alarms from Beirut to Washington to Moscow over the danger of a wider Middle East war.

title: Amber Pass Scores An Upset in Carter
description: An entry trained by Hubert (Sonny) Hine finished first and second yesterday in the 81st edition of the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct. The stablemates - Entremont's Amber Pass and Mrs. Richard Davidson's Guilty Conscience - were shipped to New York from Maryland for the $82,350 race over seven furlongs. At the finish, Amber Pass, with Eddie Maple aboard, was a half-length ahead. His time was 1:23 and his payoff was $13.20 for $2 to win.

title: As Hazard to U.S. Cities
description: President Reagan's proposed budget cuts will affect the nation's cities much more adversely than anyone first suspected and could threaten their very existence, according to the United States Conference of Mayors

title: GLEN ISLAND AGREEMENT FACES BOARD
description: TWO Westchester restaurateurs who grew up together on the same block in the Knightsbridge section of the Bronx and who remember the last years of the Big Band era may get the chance soon to revitalize the Glen Island Casino, once a home for those bands.

title: Cuban Refugee Site Sought
description: The Federal authorities are trying to find a new location for the Cubans who will probably not have sponsors when a refugee resettlement center in Arkansas closes, says the acting head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. David Crosland told the agency's national advisory committee Thursday that the Fort Chaffee center was to close in June and at the rate the Cuban refugees were being released ''they won't all be out by June.''

title: Correction
description: Nabisco Inc. and Standard Brands Inc. are planning to merge. A reference to the proposal last Sunday inadvertantly misnamed Standard Brands.

title: Patricia O'Neill, Teacher, Affianced To Richard Lister
description: The marriage of Patricia Marie O'Neill, a third-grade teacher at the Pingry School in Short Hills, N.J., to Richard Arthur Lister, a senior engineer with Nabisco Inc. in East Hanover, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills. Msgr. John F. Ryan, the pastor emeritus, concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. HarroldA. Murray.

title: MARGIOTTA CASE TOO TOUGH TO CALL
description: For 64 hours over eight days, a Westbury jury tried to agree whether Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, had committed mail fraud and extortion, as the Federal prosecutor contended, or merely presided over routine political patronage, as Mr. Margiotta's attorney insisted. The jurors could not decided unanimously, and last week the proceedings, which had laid bare the inner workings of one of the state's most powerful county organizations, ended in a mistrial.

title: THEY COULDN'T BEAT A FAT MAN; Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. WHEN Pleasant Colony cantered back toward the winner's circle after the 107th Kentucky Derby, John Campo, his trainer, kissed him on the muzzle. Then he kissed several unidentified women, who may have been members of his family.

title: Children's Books
description: THE SNUG LITTLE HOUSE By Eils Moorhouse Lewis. Illustrated by Elise Primavera. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $8.95. (Ages 3 to 5) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: LENA HORNE ALOOFNESS HID THE PAIN, UNTIL TIME COOLED HER ANGER
description: At 63, Lena Horne has been in show business for nearly five decades, and for black entertainers in particular, it has been a half-century of remarkable change indeed. In the beginning, Miss Horne was called a ''chocolate chanteuse'' and a ''cafe au lait Hedy Lamarr,'' and for many years, she was denied a room in the very hotels that billed her as their star attraction. She was invited to Hollywood parties with the understanding that she ''sing for her supper,'' and she performed in U.S.O. shows at which German prisoners of war were given better seats than black enlisted men. White club owners suggested that she invent a Spanish name for herself and try to ''pass,'' while the black press chastised her for marrying the composer Lennie Hayton, who happened to be white and Jewish.

title: Linda A. Dayton Is Married
description: Linda Allen Dayton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Dayton Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., and Robert Joseph Kropacek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Kropacek, also of Port Washington, were married yesterday. The Rev. Frank Johnston, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I., performed the ceremony in the chapel of the United States Merchant Marine Academy in Kings Point, L.I. The bride is a secretary with the Air Tariffs Corporation in Port Washington. Mr. Kropacek is an administrative assistant with the Port Washington Water Pollution Control District.

title: 'CANDIDA' AT MAIN STREET
description: GIVEN its first public performance in 1904, Shaw's ''Candida'' is still widely performed today and in popularity ranks second only to ''Saint Joan'' in the Shaw catalogue. It differs from most of Shaw's other plays in that it makes few digressions from its central romantic theme for jabs at the world as Shaw saw it. Of course, being the work of George Bernard Shaw, it cannot help but wink a little as it discusses marriage.

title: MARTIN LIKES HIS TEAM TOUGH
description: The Oakland A's theme song, to the tune of the Coasters' ''Charlie Brown,'' includes a one-line solo by the manager, who asks in his gravelly, gunslinger's voice, ''Why is everybody always picking on me?''

title: ENVIRONMENTAL WARNING ON REAGAN STAND
description: MANY environmentalists are appalled by President Reagan's environmental appointments, and his environmentally insensitive statements and posture. They wait apprehensively to see what will happen next: whether there will be a major assault on the substance of the environmental-protection legislation of the last decade or whether there will be merely a push for more flexibility and realism in implementing regulations.

title: Gallery View; THE DIAL: SHOWCASE OF A PIONEER COLLECTOR
description: There has never been an exhibition of early 20th-century art quite like ''The Dial Collection'' that can be seen now and through May 10 at the Worcester Art Museum in Worcester, Mass. It is not on the scale of ''big, better, best'' that the show stands out. It is by no means the largest thing of its kind that we have seen. It is not composed of masterpieces only. Nor can it be called comprehensive. But it was made by one man, Scofield Thayer, over one short period (1920-24), and for a specific purpose. Thayer did not buy to furnish his house, or to impress the neighbors, or by way of speculaton. He bought in order to build up a bank of ideas for the illustration of a magazine called The Dial that he and a friend of his called J.S. Watson Jr. had bought in 1919.

title: HERE AND THERE IN THE GUBERNATORIAL
description: THE National Rifle Association has endorsed Representative James J. Florio of Camden for the Democratic nomination for Governor. In a letter to its New Jersey members, the association reviews Mr. Florio's voting record and says that he is clearly the Democrat most likely to support its position on ''firearms rights.''

title: Muffie Poor Bride on L.I.
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, L.I., yesterday, Lisabeth Rome Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barton Poor of Garden City and East Hampton, L.I., was married to Joseph Henry Cromarty 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cromarty Jr. of Waterville, Me. The Rev. Peter Garry performed the cermony.

title: MACARTHUR SEEKS MORE FLIGHTS
description: RONKONKOMA AS Alfred E. Werner, the manager of Long Island MacArthur Airport, put it the other day, business ''always picks up in the spring with the flowers.''

title:
GARDENING;
GYPSY MOTHS: THE SEASONAL BATTLE BEGINS
description: BY now everyone must have heard the story of the scientist who, in his attempt to develop a hardy silkworm, inadvertently unleashed the gypsy moth. This occurred in 1869, when a container of insect egg clusters from France that M. Leopold Trouvelot had placed on a windowsill broke and fell to the ground. Try as he might, he was unable to recover them.

title: CONTROVERSY ON INSURANCE LEADS TO CUTS IN NASSAU FEES
description: THE controversy over municipal insurance commission splitting in Nassau County - brought into sharp focus in the trial of Joseph M. Margiotta - has generated reviews of municipal insurance costs, some movement toward municipal self-insurance and some reported reductions in premiums in Nassau's three towns and two cities.

title: Practical Traveler; SUMMER TRAVELERS CAN FIND LODGING AT BARGAIN PRICES
description: While it will be easy in the United States this summer to spend $100 or more a night for a hotel room for two, it also will be easy to find comfortable, respectable lodgings for under $20 in most parts of the country, if you know where to look.

title: BALLET GROUP FEARS LEAN TIMES
description: HARTFORD MICHAEL UTHOFF, artistic director of the Hartford Ballet, was busy in the dance studios on Farmington Avenue with a full day of rehearsals for the company's spring season, which begins Friday, but his mood was optimistic.

title: STRECK IS UP BY 3 AFTER A 62
description: Ron Streck, a fifth-year touring pro with one victory to his credit, charged out of the field today with a course record 62 to take a three-stroke lead in the third round of the Houston open. Streck's 62 was nine under par for the Woodlands Country Club course.

title: HOPES FOR A NEW DAWN IN PALOMA AFTER 77 CENTURIES
description: Archeologists rarely claim immediate relevance for their finds, but the discovery of the ancient village site along the central coast of Peru did more than unearth past mysteries. Well-preserved artifacts and 7,700-year-old skeletons give vivid glimpses of agricultural life in the oldest known settlement in the Americas.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title:
Photography View;
A STARTLING THESIS ABOUT THE ORIGIN OF PHOTOGRAPHY
description: The bold idea underlying the Museum of Modern Art's upcoming exhibition ''Before Photography: Painting and the Invention of Photography,'' which will open on May 9, is bound to be constroversial, and nobody knows it better than Peter Galassi, the 30-year old director of the exhibition.

title: THE CAPITAL BECOMES A BOOM TOWN
description: Judith Miller is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By Judith Miller estled under a floral umbrella of lavendar azaleas, lace-white dogwood and pink magnolias, Washington at first glance looks like the same city that has been luring millions of Americans each spring. As always, thousands of camera-draped tourists line the streets around Pennsylvania Avenue each morning, waiting to tour the White House, and, all day long, busloads of high school seniors pour into the capital's marble galleries and museums. But anyone inclined to look a bit beyond the traditional tourist attractions sees another, changing, Washington.

title: MICHIGAN CONVICTS MAY GET OUT EARLY
description: Gov. William G. Milliken will try to begin freeing more than 1,000 convicts from Michigan's badly overcrowded prisons next week if the State Supreme Court approves the plan.

title: ADDRESS THE INJUSTICE THAT MOTIVATED SIRHAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Airport Master Plan: A Review of Facts
description: Trish Van Devere Scott's article, ''An Issue of Community Compatibility'' (April 26), emphasizes the plurality of the positions and emotions that have developed over Westchester County Airport. Beyond defining the airport issues as ones of noise and safety, there seems to be little common ground on which to build a rational dialogue. Differences of opinion aside, there should be no confusion about facts.

title: GAVIN TOWNSEND FIANCE OF BONNIE BETH BICKFORD
description: Col. and Mrs. William Bickford of Bowie, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Beth Bickford, to Gavin Edward Townsend, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Townsend of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: G.M. LOADS UP ON A JAPANESE STRATEGY
description: The ''stripper,'' as much a phenomenon of Detroit as of the burlesque stage, is going by the boards. When General Motors brings its new J subcompacts to market later this month, it will forgo the usual ''price leader,'' the spartan, bargain-basement model that generations of auto dealers have relied on to lure economy-minded buyers into showrooms. Instead, the new J line will come, well, if not exactly ''loaded,'' at least more than usually weighted down.

title: Reading and Writing; A FEW QUESTIONS
description: It's no use asking novelists or short story writers about the meaning of their work, because even if they knew, they wouldn't tell you. If they did, they could be thrown out of PEN.

title: CANADA ACCUSES ITS 2 MAIN NEWSPAPER CHAINS OF TRADE CONSPIRACY
description: Canada's two largest newspaper chains, Thomson and Southam of Toronto, have been charged by the Government with conspiring to reduce competition in four major cities.

title: QUIET BATTLE WAGED OVER BLOCK GRANTS
description: Five officials from antipoverty and community development agencies recently trooped into the Boston office of Representative Brian J. Donnelly. They were willing to accept their share of budget cuts, they told the Massachusetts Democrat, but they were more afraid of the White House proposal to dismantle many social service programs on the Federal level and send the money to state and local governments.

title: STATE GOES WEST FOR MOVIE BUSINESS
description: Michelle Kuhar, the new executive director of the state's Motion Picture and Television Development Commission, visited Hollywood last month in an effort to sell studio heads on the Garden State as a location for making feature films and television series.

title: SLOW PROGRESS ON BIKEWAYS
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY has never lacked innovative bikeway proposals. But getting the bike paths, lanes and routes built has been another matter. The county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation has had a regional bikeway system plan since 1976. In 1973, the town of Bedford completed a model bikeways proposal, a network of more than 20 miles of routes linking schools, parks and villages. Pound Ridge, Chappaqua, Yorktown and the City of Rye have also developed plans. During the early 1970's, a proposal was introduced to pave the 26-mile-long Old Croton Aqueduct as a bikeway.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 3, 1981
description: International The United States will back China and other Asian countries in efforts to put together a more unified resistance against Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed Government, Administration officials said. (Page 1, Column 4.) Political repression in Guatemala is increasing. Leftist and moderate groups are bearing the brunt of it as the Reagan Administration tries to repair relations with the military regime of Maj. Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia, which hopes that American military aid cut off in 1977 will be resumed. Guatemala's leaders are fighting a guerrilla movement that is increasingly successful in the countryside, are attempting to eliminate centrist politicians. with whom Washington could be expected to deal. (1:2-3.)

title: MOSHE MIZRAHI'S 'I SENT A LETTER TO MY LOVE'
description: Louise (Simone Signoret) has grown old taking care of her brother Gilles (Jean Rochefort), who has been confined to a wheelchair since childhood. They share the family's fine old stone house overlooking an especially photogenic stretch of beach on the coast of Brittany. Each day is like every other. Louise and Gilles bicker and make jokes and depend - far more than they realize - on the daily visits of their friend Yvette (Delphine Seyrig), a pretty, shy, no-longer-young woman who works in a bakery and is slipping into spinsterhood without apparent regret.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Daniel Spiegelberg Offers Ravel Piano Work
description: Although Daniel Spiegelberg gave his debut piano recital in the Abraham Goodman House on Tuesday night, he has had a European performing career. There were many moments when that experience was evident, along with a well-schooled musicianship.

title: HELPING HAND FOR SEA MAMMALS
description: ATLANTIC CITY WHEN a 12-ton sperm whale beached itself on Fire Island last month, the first person approached for help was Robert Schoelkopf, director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center here.

title: MORTGAGES AT RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: MICHIGAN AREA SHAKEN BY CLOSING OF CEMENT PLANT
description: For 60 years the big cement plant on the Lake Michigan beach a few miles west of this resort area employed many fathers and sons, cousins and brothers. But no longer.

title: PRAYER AND ABORTION ARE PRIVATE MATTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CHICAGO
description: JORY GRAHAM is a Chicago-based columnist and the author of guidebooks on the city. KEVIN HOCHBERG assisted in the preparation of this article. By JORY GRAHAM

title: Ulster Awaits; A Final Signal
description: Down the bitter decades, Irish rebels have often turned to martyrdom by hunger, a double-edged weapon against Britain and themselves. Last week, as Robert Sands slid nearer death in Maze Prison, Irish willingness to die was again being matched against British will to rule.

title: No Headline
description: The Hudson Valley Art Association's 53rd annual exhibition opens at the County Center in White Plains today with a reception from 3 to 7 P.M., and will be open to the public through next Sunday.

title: BALLET: BUJONES REACHES NEW HEIGHTS
description: There are times when technical prowess in a dancer is so astounding and unprecedented that even artistry must momentarily take second place. Fernando Bujones provided this kind of brief but unforgettable, even unbelievable, moment within the current ''Giselle'' marathon the American Ballet Theater is presenting at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: OPPOSITION GROWING TO LEADER OF MINERS
description: There was a time two years ago when Sam M. Church Jr., then the newly elevated president of the United Mine Workers, spoke openly of leavening the double dose of democracy the union membership received in 1973.

title: Food; HERB BREADS IN A HURRY
description: One of the most revolutionary things about the food processor is its ability to knead dough in seconds. We have found that the processor even shortens the soaking time normally required for yeast in the very beginning of the recipe. One puts the yeast and lukewarm water in the container, flips the switch and the flour is ready to be added.

title:
GARDENING;
GYPSY MOTHS: THE SEASONAL BATTLE BEGINS
description: BY now everyone must have heard the story of the scientist who, in his attempt to develop a hardy silkworm, inadvertently unleashed the gypsy moth. This occurred in 1869, when a container of insect egg clusters from France that M. Leopold Trouvelot had placed on a windowsill broke and fell to the ground. Try as he might, he was unable to recover them.

title: Vatican Seizes 'Father' From 'Saturday Night'
description: The Vatican police detained Don Novello, the American comedian who played Father Guido Sarducci on the ''Saturday Night Live'' television program, when he arrived at St. Peter's Basilica yesterday wearing a priest's cape, his photographer reported.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: winning ''The Woman Warrior'' writes about the men in her ancestry and the other Chinese men who came to this country to build Western railroads and work on Hawaiian sugar plantations. This blend of history, legend and myth was called by our reviewer Mary Gordon ''a triumph of the highest order of imagination, of language, of moral perception.''

title: The MX Missile Question
description: Stansfield Turner's call for abandonment of the MX missile system is a great public service (''Why We Shouldn't Build the MX,'' March 29). Retreating from this project, whose deployment would destabilize both nuclear parity and world economic security, is an absolutely necessary first step toward the goal of nuclear disarmament.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Junko Ota, Violinist, Plays A Central European Bill
description: Junko Ota brought a vigorous and technically assured style of violin playing to her concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on April 25. With the exception of Prokofiev's Sonata in F minor, this was a Central European program, with sonatas by Beethoven and Brahms and Schoenberg's Phantasy (Op. 47).

title: PRICING FAMILIES BACK INTO HOUSING
description: The windows may be broken, the walls marred and the plumbing damaged by vandals, but the roof and foundation are sound and the house is a bargain in today's tight real estate market. The going price is $950.

title: Notes; A SELECTION OF IDEAS FOR SUMMER
description: River and bicycle trips are expected to claim a lot of attention as vacationers and weekenders make their plans for the coming summer. Companies and organizations that have sprouted in recent years to accommodate the increasing interest in the outdoors are ready for the 1981 season with trips ranging from one day to several weeks, often combining camping and outdoor meals with river and bicycle travel. Here is a sampling of scheduled outdoor trips:

title: THE T-BILL WHEN YOU NEED TO SELL
description: Investors, lured by high interest rates, have been trooping by droves into Treasury bills. The bills pay far more than a savings account, the interest is exempt from New York State and New York City income taxes and the nearness of maturity -three months to a year - protects the investor against loss of principal. No matter how high interest rates go, and how much Treasury bill prices might then decline, the United States Government guarantees that at the bill's maturity the investor will be paid the full face value of the bill.

title: YALE JUNIOR PONDERS CAREER IN BASEBALL
description: NEW HAVEN FOR the last two months, Lucille Benanto has made a point of asking her husband as he left for work, ''When is he pitching again?'' Mrs. Benanto's interest is understandable. She has been getting as many as a dozen telephone calls a day from major league baseball scouts wanting to know when Ron Darling would next take the mound for the Yale baseball team.

title: WILDLIFE ORGANIZATIONS PROTEST KILLINGS IN UGANDA
description: Several of the world's leading conservation and wildlife organizations have filed formal complaints against the South Sudanese Government protesting the recently reported slayings of three men and the use of machine guns to kill wildlife by Sudanese soldiers in Uganda's neighboring Kidepo National Park.

title: Conservation Grant To Morgan Library
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has awarded the Pierpont Morgan Library a matching grant of $600,000 to help endow the library's conservation department. The library has three years in which to match the grant.

title: Jewish Historical Society Establishes a Film Center
description: The National Center for Jewish Film, an archive and study center of film material relevant to the Jewish experience in the 20th century, has been established by the Jewish Historical Society.

title: TV View; 'THE GOLDEN BOWL' DRAMATIZATION STILL SHINES
description: Henry James, Balzac, the Bellamys, Hudson and Mrs. Bridges, a Scottish writer named Lewis Grassic Gibbon, Alistair Cooke - the special mix can belong to only one television staple: ''Masterpiece Theater.'' Now in its 10th-anniversary season on public television, the series was launched as an imposing showcase for British television drama with ''The First Churchills.'' Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, a 22-week ''Festival of Favorites'' begins with an exquisite production of ''The Golden Bowl,'' first seen here in 1973. Favorites, as you may have guessed, is another word for repeats. In this instance, though, there should be few complaints.

title: FRENCH LEFTWARD TILT PUSHES COMMUNISTS TO THE FAR EDGE
description: An institution may be tested next Sunday when the French vote in the final round of presidential elections. Will the Fifth Republic, set up by de Gaulle 23 years ago, be able to pass its formidable presidential powers from center-right to center-left if - as seems increasingly plausible - Socialist Francois Mitterrand noses out the incumbent, Valery Giscard d'Estaing?

title: 'RIGHT-TO-DIE' BILL HAS BROAD SUPPORT
description: HARTFORD ONE spring night two years ago, Representative Yorke Allen Jr. of New Canaan rose in the State House of Representatives and told of his mother's long and arduous death as a terminally ill patient in a hospital.

title: Orioles 4, Blue Jays 3 Orioles 8, Blue Jays 3
description: BALTIMORE (UPI) - Eddie Murray ended a five-run sixth inning with a two-run single, leading Baltimore to a second-game victory and a sweep of a twilight-night doubleheader.

title: CURTIS INSTITUTE AND ITS TRADITION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Karp writes frequently about music. By JUDITH KARP

title: Common Cause Chooses Wertheimer as President
description: Common Cause, a citizen lobbying group, today chose Fred Wertheimer, the organization's senior vice president since 1977, as its new president.

title: BELMONT ABLOOM FOR RACE SEASON
description: ELMONT WHEN the first thoroughbred races across the finish line on Wednesday -opening day of Belmont -it's a sure bet that Paul Zukowski and his two growers, Sal Ciccarelli and Kevin DeStefan, will be looking at their flora and fauna more than the winning horse.

title: Derby Betting Sets Record
description: A record $4,566,179 was bet on today's 107th Kentucky Derby won by Pleasant Colony at Churchill Downs, surpassing the $4,425,828 bet in 1978 when Affirmed won.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; MARTIN CRUZ SMITH
description: When it comes to picking best sellers, publishers have the same 20-20 hindsight as the rest of us; foresight is another matter. But as early as last December, people at Random House were telling anyone who would listen that Martin Cruz Smith's ''Gorky Park'' was likely to be a best seller, and now here it is atop the list. ''We felt sure about it from the very beginning,'' said Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Random House. ''Eight of us here read it when it came in and all of us were intrigued by the interaction and the quality of the writing. The fact that it came from no place was just staggering. I don't think there was a moment of doubt in anybody's mind that this was going to make it.''

title: Cosmos Face Test Against Diplomats
description: After last night's narrow escape in Atlanta, the Cosmos are prepared to face another difficult test tomorrow when the Washington Diplomats visit Giants Stadium.

title: No Headline
description: Pakistan is evacuating villagers in an area of Sind Province near the border with India in preparation for an atomic test this summer, the news service Press Trust of India reported today.

title: A BRIEF PLACE IN THE SUN
description: WHEN HARLEM WAS IN VOGUE By David Levering Lewis. Illustrated. 381 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: DEVELOP DOWNTOWN, BRIDGEPORT ISURGED
description: THE Regional Plan Association, describing Bridgeport as ''a handsome, pleasant city, well kept, with magnificent parks and a fine setting,'' has urged development of a strong downtown to attract more office and service jobs.

title: SCUBA DIVING
description: To the Editor"

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
A STATEWIDE TAX: IT CAN WORK
description: GOVERNMENT fiscal policy is an important area of concern that we must analyze closely, especially in this era of expenditure limitations at all levels of government.

title: IRISH JET'S HIJACKER, SEEKING FATIMA'S SECRET, CAPTURED
description: A man claiming to be a defrocked Trappist monk seized a French airliner today with 102 people aboard and held it for eight hours before the French antiterrorist police stormed the plane and forced him to surrender. There were no injuries. No shots were fired.

title: Miss Miller Bride Of John Patterson
description: Melinda Earl Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornwall Miller of Essex, Conn., was married at St. John's Episcopal Church there yesterday to John Patterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Patterson of Durham, Conn. The Rev. Ann Coburn and her husband, the Rev. Michael Coburn, assistant ministers at Christ Church Cathedral in Hartford, performed the ceremony.

title: COMMERCE DEPT. STUDY CONFIRMS GAINS OF SUN BELT
description: In a reflection of growing Sun Belt prosperity, a study of Americans' per capita income shows that money flowed steadily to the South and West from the Northeast in the past decade.

title: PACKAGE TO MARK CARE'S 35TH YEAR
description: On May 11, 1946, an initial shipment of 5,000 food packages was unloaded on the docks at Le Havre, France, containing the first postwar relief furnished by a new private aid agency called CARE.

title: BAHAIS IN U.S. FEARFUL THAT 500,000 IN IRAN WILL BE EXTERMINATED
description: Members of the Bahai faith have expressed grave fears for the lives of 500,000 Bahais living in Iran. Nine members of the faith have been abducted and several executed, while an Iranian high court recently justified the execution of two members of the faith solely because of their beliefs.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Joseph Grado, Tenor, In All-Italian Program
description: Few of us have the fortitude to live out our middle-age fantasies - an unfortunate fact that makes Joseph Grado's New York debut as a dramatic tenor at Alice Tully Hall last Sunday a particularly cheering event. Mr. Grado has pursued music as an adjunct to his successful business career in the high-fidelity field. Now he seems to be seriously intent on being equally successful as a singer.

title: NOISE CODE: A REVISION CONSIDERED
description: 1486 By WALTER H. WAGGONER

title: DR. DAVID WECHSLER, 85, AUTHOR OF INTELLIGENCE TESTS
description: Dr. David Wechsler, a psychologist who was the author of widely used intelligence tests, died yesterday at his home on Manhattan's East Side. He was 85 years old.

title: THE LESBIAN MOTHER: NEW FRANKNESS
description: LESBIAN motherhood is becoming a more open life style on the Island, and lesbians who are having difficulty raising their children in two-woman parental relationships or as single parents are seeking counseling from social agencies and private psychotherapists in increasing numbers.

title:
Numismatics;
NATION'S EARLY FINANCIER
description: The name of Robert Morris is little known today except through passing references to him in books on American history. Students are taught that he was the financier of the American Revolution, but beyond that the service he rendered is not defined too sharply. This leaves the impression that his role, while important, was subordinate.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
PINNING HOPE ON PRIVATE INCENTIVES
description: PARAMUS ''FROM what I've observed so far, the real cutting edge of difference now between the Democrats and Republicans is that the Democrats fear local and state decision-making,'' said Representative Marge Roukema of Ridgewood during a recent interview at her office here. ''But the Republicans say, 'Why fear that?' Localities are in a better position to determine their priorities than the Federal Government.''

title: No Headline
description: A 14-member tribunal, patterned on the Bertrand Russell inquiry in 1967 into American involvement in Vietnam, began hearing testimony yesterday about alleged Soviet violations of international law in Afghanistan. The tribunal includes former Foreign Minister Ernesto Melo Antunes of Portugal, Eduardo Galeano, the Uruguayan author, and George Wald, the Nobel Prize-winning American biologist.

title: A HELPING HAND
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SCIENTISTS NOTE SAKHAROV'S CONTINUED INFLUENCE
description: Scientists at a symposium in New York said yesterday that Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and rights advocate, continued to exert a powerful influence on scientific and political thought throughout the world despite his isolation by the Soviet authorities.

title: NEARLY 40% OF BOSTON TEACHERS MAY LOSE THEIR JOBS IN THE FALL
description: About 40 percent of the teachers in Boston's public schools have been told that they may lose their jobs next fall because of declining enrollments and tax cuts required by a statewide referendum.

title: MEN AND WOMEN GROW OLD IN DIFFERENT WAYS
description: DR. Naomi Kroeger was troubled. In reading the latest psychiatric literature on adjustment to retirement, she found that most writers assumed aging women would have no difficulty moving out of the working world. Work played a major role in a man's life, they said, but for women, identifying primarily with home and house, retirement would mean going back to their first love. ''It simply didn't seem to apply to the people I knew who had put years into working and were retiring,'' said Dr. Kroeger, associate professor of sociology at Hunter College in New York.

title: U.S. DECIDES TO BACK RESISTANCE GROUPS ACTIVE IN CAMBODIA
description: The United States has decided to support efforts by China and other Asian countries to put together a more unified resistance movement against the Vietnamese-backed Government now in control of Cambodia, Administration officials said today.

title: Christine Grant Wilmer Is Wed
description: Christine Grant Wilmer, daughter of Mrs. Piero L. Blua of New York and Fishers Island, N.Y., and the Rev. Dr. Richard H. Wilmer Jr., was married yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, to Paul Richard Barkus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Barkus of Islip, L.I.

title:
LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
CULLING THE OYSTER LORE
description: WEST SAYVILLE ''THE old baymen came down here every week for two years to be interviewed, discuss the exhibit and generally sit around with their friends and talk about oysters, the Great South Bay and boats,'' said Peggy Holsten, project coordinator for the Suffolk Marine Museum's new exhibition, ''Oysters, Dutchmen and the Bay.''

title: No Headline
description: While it is true that we neonatalogists are saving extremely immature newborn infants, many of whom will have significant neurologic and other sequelae (diseased conditions resulting from previous diseases), it must also be recognized that this same technology has significantly diminished the frequency and severity of sequelae in higher birth-weight premature and full-term infants. The effect of modern obstetric and newborn care must be viewed as a continuum, with benefits accruing to infants of all birth weights and gestational ages.

title: THE POCONOS
description: To the Editor:$

title: MANY STARS ARE PLAYING PITCHMEN- WITH NO REGRETS
description: As he strolls across the littered floor of the New York Stock Exchange, John Houseman - producer, director, author, drama teacher and star of the much-praised television series ''The Paper Chase'' - deprecates the get-rich-quick strategies of some investment firms. ''Smith Barney makes money the old-fashioned way,'' he concludes, referring to the Wall Street brokerage house. ''They earn it.''

title: SAVING FOR A SUNNIER DAY: THE RATIONALE
description: In his address to Congress last week, President Reagan acknowledged that his proposal to cut individual tax rates while the budget was in deficit was ''of concern'' to members of Congress who feared that the move would make inflation worse.

title: Architecture; MIXED METAPHORS IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: onventional'' means a number of things in architecture, but usually it is taken to mean normal, familiar, not unexpected. A conventional building is generally a building that looks not so different from other buildings.

title: OLD MINING TOWN BECOMES TARGET OF BOMBINGS, POISON AND THREATS
description: This old coal-mining town in the mountains east of Pittsburgh has for the last year been the target of a string of bombings, mail threats, attempted extortion and the apparent poisoning of the public water supply. Many of the incidents seem to have been directed at the man who has been Mayor for 35 years.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE construction of a 1 1/2-mile seawall and promenade for Liberty State Park in Jersey City has caused some friction and court fights between old allies in the long campaign for a major urban park on desolate and blighted waterfront in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty. The discord stems from the disposal of sludge being dredged from the river bottom to form a firm base for the seawall.

title: PROUST RE-ENGLISHED
description: REMEMBRANCE OF THINGS PAST By Marcel Proust. Volume I: ''Swann's Way'' and ''Within a Budding Grove.'' 1,040 pp. Translated by C. K. Scott Moncrieff and Terence Kilmartin. Volume II: ''The Guermantes Way'' and ''Cities of the Plain.'' 1,197 pp. Translated by C.K. Scott Moncrieff and Terence Kilmartin. Volume III: ''The Captive,'' ''The Fugitive'' and ''Time Regained.'' 1,128 pp. Translated by C.K. Scott Moncrieff, Terence Kilmartin and Andreas Mayor. New York: Random House. Each volume, $25; boxed set, $75.

title: Children's Books
description: DEVIL'S DONKEY By Bill Brittain. Illustrated by Andrew Glass. 120 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 12) By MERRI ROSENBERG

title: IRAN SEEKS ADMINISTRATOR FOR SHAH'S ASSETS IN CITY
description: Iran has asked that an administrator be appointed to handle any assets the Shah of Iran left in New York, and the request is pending before Justice Irving Kirschenbaum in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: TRENTON: SEAT OF GOVERNMENT AND A STUDY IN CONTRASTS employment
description: This is the fifth article in a series on the decline of the state's major cities and their prospects for recovery.TRENTON ON A bright, clear day, this state capital looks splendid from the road that enters it from the north, along the Delaware River. The gold dome of the State House gleams amid the sharp geometry of moremodern state office buildings. The highway is smooth and new, and Pennsylvania, across the river, looks cool and green.

title: FLORAL ART: IT ISN'T ALL CLOYING
description: SUMMIT TO DESCRIBE some artists as flower painters is the most damning, the most derisive thing that can be said about them. Such artists earnestly believe that such a description implies that they are inexcusably decorative, dedicated to the pretty in art and do not harbor serious artistic thoughts. Many of them would prefer to be called anything but a flower painter, two very dirty words in the artist's lexicon.

title: DELOREAN
description: To the Business Editor: Engineers should run the auto business? Everyone knows that engineers run trains not on time, not cost effectively and not for their employers' profit. Once it was preaching ''production wisdom,'' then, economists' expertise and, now, Mr. DeLorean, how many years late in producing his cars, thinks engineers are the answer.

title: ATLANTA PLANS SUMMER PROGRAM TO PROTECT CHILDREN
description: City officials are taking extraordinary measures to protect children when school lets out for the summer because of the rash of deaths of young blacks in the last year.

title: Altiplano
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Robinson, Teacher, Married to Paul A. Farhi
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday, Sara Walton Robinson, who teaches English at the Chapin School, was married to Paul Aaron Farhi, a psychotherapist and social worker. The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton performed the ceremony.

title: CAN'T TELL A NATION BY ITS LABEL
description: To the Editor:

title: SUZUKI REJECTS U.S. REQUESTS FOR MORE ARMS SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, who leaves Monday for a meeting with President Reagan in Washington next week in which defense is expected to be a major topic, has sharply rejected renewed United States requests for higher Japanese military spending.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
IN DEFENSE OF THE OPEN PRIMARY
description: IN A recent Opinion Page article, David Norcross, the Republican state chairman, donned his best mourning garb and solemnly intoned a requiem for grass-roots political organizations. The slayer of the body politic, according to Mr. Norcross, was the enactment by the Legislature of an open primary law to govern New Jersey's gubernatorial and United States elections.

title: SMOKING-CURB BILLS: SPONSOR OPTIMISTIC
description: TRENTON NEW data on the dangers of smoke to nonsmokers may be just what are needed to get the Legislature to pass bills regulating smoking in public places, according to Assemblyman Martin A. Herman, Democrat of Woodbury.

title: Israeli Assails Schmidt On Issue of Arms for Saudis
description: If West Germany sells arms to Saudi Arabia, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir says, it will help ''finish off the job'' Nazi Germany started of exterminating the Jews.

title: British Strike Delays Liner
description: The British cruise ship Canberra, bringing 1,600 passengers back from the Mediterranean, was turned away here today after striking dock workers refused to service the vessel. Passengers shouted insults at union officials and sang ''Rule Britannia'' before being taken ashore later at Portsmouth by tender.

title: No Headline
description: Robin Henig speaks of a mother ''forced'' to love the premature infant months before she's ready. A social worker quoted in the article says of mothers of these infants, ''Part of being a woman is to produce a full-term, healthy, Gerber baby, and in this they've failed.''

title: NATIONAL ORIENTATION OF AMTRAK IMPERILED
description: cutters, service improvements are taking effect in the Washington-New York-Boston Northeast Corridor, Amtrak's busiest stretch.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
SPECIAL GAMES
description: Some very special athletes will be showing their talents this week: today from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., when the Nassau County Special Olympics for the mentally retarded takes place at Adelphi University in Garden City, with the Singing Boys of Long Island entertaining throughout the day; and Friday and Saturday, when Nassau Community College in Garden City and Eisenhower Park in East Meadow will be hosts to the Tri-State Wheelchair Games. A rigorous competition for the handicapped, the games will include swimming and weight-lifting contests at the college's Physical Fitness Center from 6 to 11 P.M. Friday, and field events and archery from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturday at the park's parking lot No. 4 and table tennis from 6 to 11 P.M. Saturday back at the college. The public is welcome to both programs. SUN FESTIVAL

title: CONDOMINIUMS: WORD GETS AROUND
description: ''The Thursday afternoon women's sewing and social group meets each Thursday at 1:30 P.M. in the social hall. All women residents are welcome. You don't have to sew. You can just enjoy gabbing with everyone.''

title: Pauline Dora Affianced To Richard P. Bourgeois
description: Mr. and Mrs. Mike Wallace have made known the engagement of Mrs. Wallace's daughter, Pauline Perigord Dora, to Richard Pierre Bourgeois, son of Doris R. Bourgeois of Lowell, Mass., and the late Albert L. Bourgeios. A May 30 wedding is planned at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: DEMOLITION THREATENS PARK AVE. BANK
description: Students of New York City's architectural heritage and leaders of midtown Manhattan's preservation movement are making a last effort to preserve the building of the New York Bank for Savings at Park Avenue South and 22d Street.

title: COLLEGE SPORTS MUST CHOOSE: AMATEUR OR PRO?
description: JUDGE Charles W. Joiner of the United States District Court recently ruled that colleges and public schools need not provide equal athletic programs for men and women as long as Federal funds are not involved in these programs.

title: 3 Women and 3 Children Found Slain in Maryland
description: Three women and three children were shot to death Saturday in a home in this secluded suburb about nine miles southeast of Washington, Prince Georges' county police said.

title: Children Respond To 'Fat Lady Sings'
description: Barbara Delatiner's recent article, ''The Opera Isn't Over Till the Fat Lady Sings,'' captured perfectly the entertaining approach that Christopher Keene took to introduce this special art form to his young audience. The children and their parents (almost 1,000 of them) were captivated by the beautiful music - expertly played by the Long Island Philharmonic - and the four attractive young singers who, using props to help tell the story, wholeheartedly threw themselves into their roles.

title: 'CAFE EXPRESS' WITH NINO MANFREDI
description: Nino Manfredi plays the humblest of rascals once again in ''Cafe Express,'' a spiritual if not technical sequel to ''Bread and Chocolate.'' With a different director and as a different character, Mr. Manfredi is once again cast as a meek, good-hearted, sometimes scheming fellow who waits on others. This time, he sells coffee aboard a train, getting into several fixes with various passengers. Selling coffee without a license is illegal, and the police are after him. So much for the plot.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Village of Freeport has hired the first woman for its police force. She is 27-year-old Susan Kretzmer, a former waitress who began her recruit training course last week at the Nassau County Police Academy.

title: LANDSCAPES IMPART ROMANTIC CHARM
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR MUCH of today's art engages in the practice of tub-thumping. It seems to do a lot of impassioned ranting and raving about its importance. Rather than uttering its messages to us quietly, it preaches loudly and boisterously.

title: RADIO TEMPEST OVER THE ICECAP RILES CANADIANS
description: A financially troubled Canadian radio station is being rescued from bankruptcy with the help of Radio Moscow, and the resulting controversy is sparking some hot tempers on both sides of the polar icecap.

title: Boston Does a Slow Burn Under Tax Lid
description: Not long ago, Boston was regarded as one city that just might thrive in old age. Now, its red-brick renaissance notwithstanding, the city has come down with the same financial sweats that have laid municipalities low all over the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Antiques; DOCTORS COLLECT MEDICAL INSTRUMENTS
description: Art dealers collect paintings. Stockbrokers buy outmoded stock and bond certificates. Graphics designers pursue period posters. And physicians have a passion for vintage medical instruments.

title: Oil From Tanker Washes Ashore
description: At least 1,000 gallons of heavy crude oil has washed onto the rocky shores of three islands off the coast of northwest Washington after a 2,000-gallon leak from a Greekregistered tanker, the Saint Anthony, the Coast Guard said today.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
ANSWERING THE SCHOOL-BUDGET CRITIC
description: ONE of the most interesting aspects of school-budget voting is that - whether the budget passes or fails - you are apt to hear the same comments and criticisms. Here are some time-honored examples, with my answers:

title: On Language: Behind the Stick By William Safire Kimble Mead
description: The person dispensing drinks from behind a bar is called a bartender. Customers who are fond of the archaic call him barkeep or innkeeper. (A clumsy bartender is called a shoemaker; one quick and capable is a mechanic. A woman tending bar is a barmaid, and there is relatively little pressure for beverage attendant (''On what airline?'' sneers one barmaid) or barperson. Bartendress is silly; waitron has been a neuter-gender suggestion.

title: The Vietnam Generation
description: It was six years ago this week that Saigon fell, an event that finally put an end to United States involvement in the Vietnam war. The anniversary merited some attention in the media, and perhaps by coincidence, two new books appeared in which veterans of the fighting recall, in searing words and images, their war experiences.

title: ACADEMY OF SCIENCE SELECTS 60 MEMBERS
description: Sixty scientists have been elected members of the National Academy of Sciences in recognition of their research accomplishments in a wide array of scientific fields.

title: A MORALITY FOR THE 80'S
description: LIMITS A Search For New Values. By Maxine Schnall. 339 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $12.95.

title: DUTCH POLICEMEN AND FLORIDA LOWLIFE
description: MURDERS By Janwillem van de Wetering. 186 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $9.95.FREE FALL IN CRIMSON By John D. MacDonald. 246 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $10.95.

title: CBS Reporter Is Seized at Airport In Guatemala and Held Overnight
description: A CBS reporter, George Natanson, was detained without explanation yesterday by airport immigration officials here, held overnight and then taken under armed guard to a plane bound for Tegucigalpa, Honduras, the United States Embassy said today.

title: Future Events Honors Galore and More
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Kudos for Diane May 6 - Diane von Furstenberg, former chairman of the Beauty and Fashion Industries Division of the New York Foundling Hospital/Center for Parent and Child Development, will be honored at the division's fifth annual Tribute Luncheon at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof. Tickets, $150. Benefit includes cocktails and 10-minute film on Foundling Hospital's programs.

title: REPRESSION IN GUATEMALA INCREASES AS U.S. IS SEEKING TO IMPROVE TIES
description: Violent Government repression of leftist and moderate groups in Guatemala is increasing at the very time that Reagan Administration officials are looking for a way to repair relations with the military regime of Maj. Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia.

title: Chipping Away Right and Left In South Africa
description: The solid white edifice of National Party rule in South Africa developed hairline cracks last week, but the country's black majority is not likely to benefit.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 5-1, TO TAKE A 3-0 LEAD IN PLAYOFF SERIES
description: The Islanders moved to within one game of clinching their Stanley Cup semifinal playoff last night, dominating the Rangers in every aspect of play and beating them, 5-1, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Police Battle Young Men In Two Towns in Ulster
description: Young men hurled firebombs and acid at policemen in Roman Catholic sections of western Belfast and Londonderry, and security forces responded with plastic bullets today as Robert Sands, an imprisoned Irish Republican Army member, sank closer to death on the 63d day of his hunger strike.

title: Schmidt Yields Not; To Arab Temptation
description: West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt tiptoed over the hot political sands in Saudi Arabia last week and slipped away without saying yes - for now - to Saudi hopes to be able to buy hundreds of Leopard-2 tanks and other sophisticated weapons.

title: A 'REDCOAT' PRINCE VISITS COLONIAL VIRGINIA
description: Prince Charles and a royal entourage of embassy officials, personal aides and security personnel swept into town for about three hours today to pick up an honorary fellowship at William and Mary College and tour the reconstructed Colonial buildings.

title: Sound; COUNTERFEIT CASSETTES- A BAD BARGAIN
description: The latest vogue in certain criminal circles is to manufacture fake audio cassettes. What the counterfeiters do is buy cheap tape from dubious sources and then put it into cassettes that look exactly like those used by premium brands. With a little help from corruptible dealers and wholesalers, those look-alike cassettes are insinuated into the regular channels of distribution with fat profits and payoffs for all involved except the unsuspecting customer, who is left to wonder why his recordings just don't sound right.

title: SUMMER MUSIC: A GUIDE TO FESTIVALS AROUND THE WORLD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- VERNON KIDD is a New York actor and writer. By VERNON KIDD

title: Critics' Choices
description: OPERA Beyond the Metropolitan and New York City Operas, New York is full of smaller groups, and those groups can often be counted on not only to give young singers stage experience, but also to fill the gaps in our operatic experience. On Sunday alone a number of such companies will offer their wares.

title: Donna Russell, P.J. Nammack Marry on L. I.
description: Donna Jean Russell, daughter of Sandra Stralem Russell of New York and Robert Alan Russell of Jackson, Wyo., was married yesterday to Peter John Nammack, son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Nammack of Mill Neck, L.I. The Rev. Stephen Babos and the Rev. Richard Mann officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L.I.

title: ANGLICANS INVITING CULTURAL DIVERSITY
