description: Anglican churches around the world have undergone a quiet revolution into a predominantly non-Western communion, diverse in beliefs and increasingly engaged with the problems of the world.

title: U.A.W. Crosses; The Threshold
description: Unity may not guarantee strength, but in the eyes of the United Auto Workers at least, when times are hard and getting harder, it allows a fighting chance. Last week, after a decade and a half of bitter division, rank-and-file delegates to the union's annual convention overwhelmingly approved an executive committee recommendation that the U.A.W. consider walking back into the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Vade mecums. What are you planning to do this summer? How you and other Americans answer that question is, in these uncertain times, a matter of concern not only to the travel trade but to the residents of Publishers Row, who carry on the tradition of the 19th-century German Karl Baedeker by issuing more than a thousand titles annually to help vacationers have a good time away from home. Some of them - firms like Rand McNally, Frommer, Fodor, Fielding and the Harvard Student Agencies, writers like Stephen Birnbaum, Robert S. Kane and Myra Waldo - make a practice of revising many of their works periodically. Such books must move through the stores speedily or the information they provide will be out of date.

title: Peter C. Fulweiler Weds Alice Kitchel In Greenville, Del.
description: Alice Harvey Kitchel and Peter Conrad Fulweiler were married yesterday in Greenville, Del. The bride is an investment assistant in the trust department of the Delaware Trust Company in Wilmington and her husband is an officer in the controller's office of the Wilmington Trust Company.

title: Palsy Suit Settled at $11 Million
description: A 2 1/2-year-old cerebral palsy victim and her parents have won an $11.1 million settlement in a lawsuit charging a hospital with negligence at the girl's birth. Oakland County Circuit Judge Steven Andrews ruled in a consent agreement Wednesday that JoAnn and Michael Taylor should receive $1.3 million from Crittenton Hospital in nearby Rochester. The judge also approved monthly payments, totaling $9.8 million, to their daughter, Nicole, said Stanley Schwartz, the family's attorney.

title: Man, 75, Is Shot to Death on L.I.  In an Apparent Robbery Attempt
description: A 75-year-old retired motorman for the New York City Transit Authority was shot to death early yesterday in the driveway of his home in Elmont, L.I., after returning with his wife from an evening of cards with friends.

title: By Sports of The Times; Hockey in Need of Don Quixote
description: DISCRIMINATION is usually associated with minorities. But with the current Stanley Cup semifinal between the Islanders and the Rangers televised on cable and pay-TV systems, rather than a free local channel, a majority has become the victim of both geographic and economic discrimination - all those New York area citizens whose homes are not wired for cable or pay television.

title: Leslie Leigh Has Nuptials
description: Leslie Susan Leigh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Stuart Leigh of New York, was married at the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday to Peter Colin Griffith. He is the son of Mrs. Edgar Clifford Griffith of Cardiff, Wales, and the late Mr. Griffith.

title: Skin and Bones
description: The paradox of progress was on display last week. From Boston came a second startling piece of medical news. Using a demineralized bone powder, doctors have been able to make new bone grow where none existed before.

title: KIBBEE ENDING HIS HIGHER EDUCATION
description: During a turbulent decade at the tope of the ivory tower at the City University of New York, a few people have tried to push Dr. Robert J. Kibbee off. Last week, the chancellor of the nation's third largest university decided he would come down-voluntarily-next year.

title: Panel Is Named to Plan A Holocaust Memorial
description: A task force to prepare a plan for creating a permanent memorial in New York City to victims of the Nazi Holocaust was announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Theresa Holland, Lawyer, Is Wed to Joseph G. Scali
description: Teresa Marie Holland and Joseph Girard Scali were married yesterday in Dallas. The Rev. William F. Pruitt, assisted by the Rev. David Erb performed the ceremony at the Highland Park Presbyterian Church.

title: Big 10 Places Illinois On 3-Year Probation
description: The Big Ten Conference has placed Illinois on three years' probation because of the university's role in the controversial eligibility case of the quarterback Dave Wilson.

title: COACHES REACT TO THE DECISION IN KUSH CASE
description: The player was not following instructions. He had been told to lay off the quarterback, yet each time the play was run in the scrimmage, the eager freshman kept coming at full speed and hitting the quarterback.

title:
DINING OUT;
QUALITY, LIKE A FISH STORY, GROWS
description: IN considering the distribution of decent restaurants in Westchester, it is surprising to find a conspicuous wasteland around the towns of New Castle and Mount Pleasant. Residents in these areas must do a bit of traveling in order to dine well. A not entirely unrelated consideration that has plagued us from time to time concerns the miserable showing of fish restaurants in the county. There are fish houses that serve fresh enough fish, but too often that fresh fish arrives bland, cooked dry, or both.

title: Airport Master Plan: A Review of Facts
description: Trish Van Devere Scott's article, ''An Issue of Community Compatibility'' (April 26), emphasizes the plurality of the positions and emotions that have developed over Westchester County Airport. Beyond defining the airport issues as ones of noise and safety, there seems to be little common ground on which to build a rational dialogue. Differences of opinion aside, there should be no confusion about facts.

title: REALTY NEWS
description: Condominium and cooperative conversions were the strongest sector in the country's housing market last year, according to a ''United States Housing Markets'' study published by the Advance Mortgage Corporation of Detroit, an affiliate of Oppenheimer & Company, investment bankers.

title: 3 AGENCIES HELP FIRE VICTIMS RECOVER AND RELOCATE
description: When a family is burned out of its home - it happened an estimated 20,000 times last year in the New York metropolitan area - the disruptions go deeper than having to find a new place to live. Besides their residences, furnishings and other personal possessions, fire victims lose a sense of place and, sometimes, even members of their family.

title: Rare Stradivarius Cello Given to Smithsonian
description: A rare 1701 violoncello, long sought after by collectors and museums, has been donated to the Smithsonian Institution's musical instruments collection.

title: Ostolozaga Wins 10,000 by Foot
description: Luis Ostolozaga of Manhattan had faith - and a plan. Both came through for him today as he won the 10,000-meter run in the 48th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate outdoor track and field championships, beating Solomon Chebor of Fairleigh Dickinson by a foot.

title: JUNIOR LEAGUE OFFERS A PEEK AT LUXURY
description: THE Junior League of Bergen County is offering a treat -and some decorating ideas, - to those who get vicarious pleasure from intimate glimpses of how the very rich live.

title: AUSTRIA'S JEWISH QUESTION
description: Paul Hofman, a former New York Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By Paul Hofman Nearly 60 years ago, an Austrian writer, Hugo Bettauer, set off a brief flurry with a futuristic novel, ''The City Without Jews.'' It turned out to be something of a prophecy.

title: Mary Catherine Skahen Wed to Raymond Walsh
description: Mary Catherine Skahen, daughter of Surrogate John F. Skahen of Rockland County, and Mrs. Skahen of Stony Point, N.Y., was married yesterday in Thiells, N.Y., to Raymond J. Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Walsh of Castleton Corners, Staten Island. The Rev. Raphael Ionnoni performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Holy Eucharist.

title: No Headline
description: More research should be devoted to prenatal care. Once we discover why a woman goes into labor as early as her 20th week of pregnancy, we are well on the way to preventing the heartbreak of premature births.

title: COMPLAINTS OF BIAS ON BORDER CONTROL UNDER INQUIRY
description: Complaints of widespread discrimination among white Border Patrol agents here, affecting both Hispanic-American patrol officers and illegal aliens, are under investigation by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: No Headline
description: The article on Dave Winfield worried me. Poor Mr. Steinbrenner; now he has to face Ron Guidry and Reggie Jackson for more millions. How about a few millions to needy New York City that is paying through the nose for a bad lease to the Yankees? SAMUEL M. KOOTZ, New York City

title: MODERN TALE OF 7 ORPHAN BEARS HAS SOCIAL WELFARE TWIST
description: New York State wildlife experts have added an activist social-welfare approach to their work with the black-bear community - acting as an adoption agency for orphaned cubs and placing them with foster-mother bears.

title: Robert Stallings Marries Marion Sloan, a Teacher
description: In St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church in Ridgewood, N.J., yesterday afternoon, Marion Elizabeth Sloan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter F. Sloan of Ridgewood and East Dennis, Mass., was married to Robert Berlinger Stallings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Stallings of Brick Town, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Alfred John Miller, rector emeritus, and the Rev. Richard Drake Sloan, brother of the bride and assistant rector of St. Elizabeth's, performed the ceremony.

title: 5 Council Committees Will Meet This Week
description: Five City Council committees have scheduled meetings in City Hall for this week. They are: MONDAY - The Committee on Transportation, considers parking privileges and special permits for handicapped drivers, 10 A.M. TUESDAY - The Committee on Housing and Buildings, considers requirements for smoke detectors in buildings, 1:30 P.M. WEDNESDAY - The Committee on State Legislation, considers tranfer of city park lands to the Federal Government and other bills, 10 A.M. THURSDAY - The Committee on General Welfare, considers terminology for describing handicapped persons, 10 A.M. FRIDAY - The Subcommittee on Status of Women, reviews the advisory board for women's employment, noon.

title: LOTS OF PLOT IN HONG KONG
description: NOBLE HOUSE By James Clavell. 1206 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $19.95.

title: 9 Dead, Not 29, in India Rioting
description: At least nine people were killed yesterday in rioting in the northern Indian town of Biharsharif, which has been placed under curfew, the Press Trust of India said today. Reuters erroneously reported yesterday that 29 people had died in the rioting.

title: Julie Simmons, Editor, Wed
description: Julie Simmons, executive editor of Heavy Metal, a New York magazine, was married yesterday to Alan Patrick Lynch, an artist who is the American representative for Young Artists Inc. of London.

title: THE ARTS NEED THE VISION OF NEW TALENT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Pertinent Question
description: To the editor: Joyce Carol Oates ought to consider whether the frequency of the ''familiar'' question ''Why Is Your Writing So Violent?'' (March 29) might not be a valid signal that she is indulging herself with the easy charge that the questioners are ''insulting, ignorant, and sexist.'' After repeated encounters with such episodes as those in her novel ''Wonderland,'' in which a doctor claims to have cut the womb from a cadaver and broiled it for dinner, and a man perusing himself in a mirror proceeds to slash his body with a razor, readers may well question whether they have been jolted by an honest view of ''the complexity of the world'' or by a cynical exploitation of the most manipulative human terrors and tensions.

title: CELTICS-76ERS IN SHOWDOWN BATTLE TODAY
description: The battle for the Eastern Conference championship of the National Basketball Association - between teams that finished with 62-20 records in the regular season and have split 12 games against each other - will be decided in one game tomorrow afternoon at Boston Garden.

title: CO-OPS LEVY 'FLIP TAX' ON SALES OF APARTMENTS
description: When the rental building where David T. Goldstick was living converted to a cooperative plan in 1973, he wondered where the shareholders would get the money needed to improve the building's appearance. The reserve fund would not be enough to keep up with the alterations the board of directors wanted to make on the building located at 515 West End Avenue.

title: Crime
description: Except for the work of such popular practitioners as Agatha Christie and Dorothy Sayers, specimens of the classic British mystery are not easy to come by. The books are long out of print, and anybody who wants to read such authors as Sax Rohmer, J.S. Fletcher, Henry Bailey, Freeman Wills Crofts, M.I. Cole is going to have a tough time of it. And though some writers in England continue to work in the traditional mainstream, they are no real substitute. The fun of reading the early books lies in their period charm, plus the nostalgia of picking up and rereading a book that was part of one's youth.

title: Catch and Release, Or Fishing for Fun
description: ALTHOUGH some graying country boys have difficulty with the concept, the practice of setting aside portions of trout streams for catch and release is firmly established in certain heavily-populated areas of the Northeast.

title: Editors' Choice
description: seller description. AN IMAGINED WORLD, by June Goodfield. (Harper & Row, $12.95.)

title: IRAN LEFTISTS FIGHT ISLAMIC EXTREMISTS
description: About 200 leftists gathered outside the gates of Teheran's closed university this morning and clashed with Islamic extremists, witnesses said.

title: BEYOND THE BASICS, A TROUBLING TREND
description: It seems that every silver lining in the nation's educational system comes wrapped inside a dark cloud. Such was the case last week, in a report by the National Assessment of Educational Progress on reading achievement of primary and secondary school students.

title: Walter Watson 3d And Ann Bailey Engaged to Marry
description: Rear Adm. Irving H. Chase, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Chase of Lincoln, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Chase's daughter, Ann Crowninshield Bailey, to Walter Watson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson 2d of Boston.

title: The Male Secretaries
description: Christine Doudna's article took me back to the dark days of the Great Depression (''Male Secretaries: New Men of Letters,'' April 5). I was graduated from Temple University in June 1934, with unmarketable degrees in English literature and political science.

title: What He Said,; What He Meant
description: President Reagan got a little ''out front'' of his Administration's policy on human rights last week and the White House had to clarify him back.

title: Sally Sprague Lee Bride of Edward Swift
description: Sally Sprague Lee, a vice president of Scott, Fittin & Company, planning and marketing consultants in New Haven, was married yesterday in Dorset, Vt., to Edward McKelvy Swift, a writer with Sports Illustrated. The Rev. Hal Miller performed the ceremony in the United Church of Dorset and East Rupert.

title: THE OLD EUROPEAN WAYS PERSIST AT BAKERY
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN ANY Monday, Tuesday or Wednesday, it is not uncommon to observe a worker on his way home, a woman planning to give a dinner party that evening or a waiter about to start the night shift wander down the driveway at 144 Cortlandt Street in this quiet village. The front door to Alter's Bakery remains closed, but below the shop the mammoth brick ovens hardly ever stop baking fresh, crusty bread and rolls in the old European style.

title: SADAT ACCUSES SYRIANS OF 'HOOLIGANISM'
description: President Anwar el-Sadat accused Syria today of engaging in ''hooliganism'' in Lebanon and said that Syrian aggression and the indifference of the Arab world had paved the way for Israel's intensified involvement in the Lebanese strife.

title: Chess; ON FREEING THE GAME
description: What do you do with the two bishops and a slight preponderance in space in a closed position where the enemy camp exhibits no weaknesses?

title: DANCE: ORDERED PLACES FROM SUSAN BUIRGE
description: Susan Buirge created a sense of ordered place peopled by alert and personable dancers Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, where the Paris-based Danse Theatre Susan Buirge will appear again tonight.

title: Dodgers Deal Expos First Home Defeat, 4-0
description: Ron Cey's three-run homer in the fourth inning and Ken Landreaux's bases-empty shot in the fifth backed a seven-hitter by Jerry Reuss as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Montreal Expos, 4-0, today.

title: Poland Takes Paths; Of Least Resistance
description: Polish leaders last week perfected the Kania shuffle - two steps toward greater democracy, one step back to mollify Moscow. Affirming the necessity for ''socialist renewal,'' Communist Party leader Stanislaw Kania formally proposed secret ballots in all party elections, a limit of two terms for high offices and a separation between the functions of party and state.

title: ALFRED BRENDEL HAS TAKEN THE WRONG ROADS TO SUCCESS
description: There is a feeling of quiet pride as Alfred Brendel talks about his career. Perhaps no other pianist of our time has so willfully avoided the ordinary channels to success and formulas for stardom and still arrived at the top of his profession. This stubborn insistence on musical development at his own pace and on his own terms has led Mr. Brendel along unlikely paths -from obscure recitalist in his native Austria, to budget-label recording artist, to cult figure for a small but discerning audience.

title: PROSPECTS
description: More Japanese Concessions

title: UNIVERSITY AID TO NEW HAVEN QUESTIONED
description: NEW HAVEN SHOULD Yale University pay taxes or make a contribution in lieu of taxes to the City of New Haven? Three years ago, one Yale administrator called the tax question a ''dead issue.'' But at a rally last month against proposed cuts in the city school budget, many in the crowd of more than 1,500 took up a common cry: ''Make Yale pay!''

title: DEAR JOHN...' WHEN A COMPANY IS JILTED
description: Not often do corporations reveal feuding by the chief executives of two multibillion-dollar enterprises. But that happened last week when J. Paul Sticht, chief executive of R.J. Reynolds Industries, went public with an exchange of telexes with Anton Rupert, head of South Africa's Rembrandt Group.

title: Judith Ann Hlavenka Is Wed To Benedict J. Torcivia Jr.
description: Judith Ann Hlavenka, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Hlavenka of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Benedict J. Torcivia Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Torcivia of Mountainside, N.J.

title: HAROLYN LANDOW WED TO M.H. CARDOZO 5TH
description: Harolyn Sue Landow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Landow of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday in Washington to Michael H. Cardozo 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cardozo of Washington. Rabbi Joseph P. Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: IS PEKING'S LIBERALIZATION REALLY OVER?
description: From a small room below street level in a student hostel at Hong Kong University, there is likely to issue, any day or evening, the crackling of broadcasts from China, the murmur of a cultivated Central European voice dictating Communist propaganda into a tape recorder, the noble lines of a Bach sonata for violin solo played by an accomplished musician or the barking of a robust German Shepherd dog.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: OCEAN COUNTY COLLEGE in Toms River, the first in New Jersey to be approved by county voters, the first to be established under the County College Act of 1962 and the first to move onto a campus designed specifically for its needs, now has its second president, Dr. George Silver of Toms River.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT was the sort of scene that could easily have struck a strained note. Youngsters, some encased in body casts, others sitting in wheelchairs, were gathered in a large room at Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, listening to a group of women sing upbeat songs. As the performers swung into numbers such as ''You Can't Be a Beacon if Your Light Don't Shine'' and the children clapped along as best they could, the impression might have been one of cheeriness imposed on a grim situation.

title: WHITE HOUSE HEADHUNTER FEELS THE HEAT
description: Even in a White House that has a high tolerance for ardent conservatism, the names of John Carbaugh and Jim Lucier draw frowns these days. They are the strategists of Senator Jesse Helms's rise to leadership of the Senate's far-right Republican faction. But their strategy requires that Mr. Helms gain political leverage by delaying confirmation of President Reagan's appointees to sensitive posts in the State Department. And White House aides blame Mr. Carbaugh and Mr. Lucier for creating a strain that threatened the old friendship between the President and Mr. Helms.

title: Dorothy Peck Wed To Scott Voorhees
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y., yesterday, Dorothy Anne Peck and Scott Alan Voorhees, graduates of the University of Miami and field biologists with the National Park Service in Homestead, Fla., were married by the Rev. Joseph P. Bishop.

title: CHANGE IN GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE MANAGEMENT SOUGHT
description: Willie Brown, Speaker of the the California Assembly, insists that he will push through his bill to take the Golden Gate Bridge away from the board of directors that has managed it since it was built in the late 1930's.

title: Derbygoers Handle The Extra Confusion
description: Michael Peak, a native of the city who has been to the Kentucky Derby eight years running, had found a few square feet of breathing room in the Churchill Downs grandstand to study his program and Racing Form with the idea of making a Derby pick. ''Now let me get this straight,'' he said to a companion. ''The two horses who went to court are in the program but not the Form, right? Does this mean they're in or out or still in court?''

title: UNDAMMING THE AMERICAN ECONOMY
description: According to the Reagan Administration, the economic problems of the United States have been caused by a group of eager but misguided liberal Democratic beavers. They created a dam out of the sticks of high tax rates and the mud of social-welfare spending and stopped the stream of economic progress. If this dam were simply ripped out, Washington's new reigning economists say, there would be an initial surge in the stream of economic activity as all of that pent-up energy is released. And then the stream would resume its normal, rapidly flowing course.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: VAN pooling has doubled in Connecticut over the last year, according to the Department of Transportation, which reported 635 van pools on the road now, up from 304 last April. The 6,985 riders have saved 3.8 million gallons of gasoline over the last year, the department said.

title: ELDERLY SUE BYRNE TO BAR TRANSFER OF $80 MILLION IN CASINO REVENUES
description: A group of elderly citizens sued Governor Byrne today in an attempt to block the proposed transfer of $80 million in casino fund revenues earmarked to aid the disabled and elderly. The $80 million would be used to help finance property-tax relief.

title: DESPITE DOUBTS, BYRD WILL BACK REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, said today that although the Reagan Administration's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1982 was based on some ''rather tenuous and questionable assumptions,'' he would nonetheless vote for it.

title: MRS. ROUKEMA MEETS THE VOTERS
description: PARAMUS REPRESENTATIVE Marge Roukema, Republican of Ridgewood, faced about 300 of her constituents at three town meetings last weekend, and found them politely hostile and frightened. They were hostile toward President Reagan's austere economic package and frightened over the effect that proposed budget cuts would have on their lives.

title: DESIGNERS PLANNING SLENDER TOWER
description: Cadillac Fairview Properties and Cohen Brothers Realty & Construction Company are considering building a 50-story office tower at 780 Third Avenue between 48th and 49th Streets and employing an unusual form of structure ing that would enable it to become one of the world's most slender skycrapers.

title: Franklin Anne Miller Is Bride
description: Franklin Anne Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Miller of Rye, N.Y., and Mark D. Rowland, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Rowland of Birmingham, Mich., were married yesterday by the Rev. Clark Hyde at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Delaware, Ohio.

title: COOKING A GOURMET CHINESE MEAL ON A BOAT
description: FOR me, sailing is a constant challenge. You're either trying to find the wind or trying to get away from the wind. There's always something to do. Someday, maybe this summer, I might buy a boat of my own, but for the last several years I've been sailing with friends. And they expect me to cook.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: OUTDOOR FURNITURE: IT REQUIRES A LITTLE TENDER, LOVING CARE, TOO By BERNARD GLADSTONE

title: Lily Richardson Bride of Richard Leonard
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass., yesterday, Lily Richardson, a laboratory technician at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, was married to Richard Huston Leonard, a vice president of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, investment brokers in New York. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gasoline
description: To the Business Editor: ''Why Gasoline is Getting Cheaper'' (April 12) exaggerates the degree to which a petroleum glut exists, demand will continue to fall, and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will be frustrated. By exaggerating United States and passenger demand to the exclusion of free world and freight (as well as passenger) demand, the article ignores medium- to long-run trends in total consumpton which are at least as important as the short-run glut. A colleague, Robert U. Ayres, has recently forecast demand of nations in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and has found the United States rate of increase to be the lowest of all O.E.C.D. countries -not a comforting conclusion in terms of future OPEC bargaining strength.WILBUR A. STEGER President Conrad Research Corporation

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IT'S A MAN, IT'S A WOMAN, IT'S SUPER-AD!
description: IT ALL started innocently enough, as most evil things are wont to do. Some years ago, while shopping for a scarf in an exclusive boutique, I was surprised to see that each one bore a different signature. When I told the salesperson that I didn't want someone else's name around my neck, I could almost see the blood rush from her cheeks as she gasped, ''But that is the look!''

title:
Architecture View;
500 PARK- A SKILLFUL SOLUTION
description: The small, silvery building at 500 Park Avenue, on the southwest corner of 59th Street, is at the top of the list, with Seagram and Lever House, of the city's few modern landmarks. Built in 1960 as the headquarters of the Pepsi-Cola Corporation and later bought, and then sold, by Olivetti, its fate has been hanging in the balance for some time. This is one of the superb ''skin'' buildings produced by Gordon Bunshaft for the architectural firm of Skidmore, Owings and Merrill; only 11 stories high, it is designed with the precise and beautiful refinement of an expensive Swiss watch. The taut delicacy of its sleek glass and aluminum facade and its perfectly adjusted proportions make it an elegant miniature among the city's large commercial structures - a kind of Pazzi Chapel of corporate design.

title: Rikki E. Langston Is Married To Wallace Ford 2d, Lawyer
description: Rikki E. Langston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland T. Langston of Philadelphia, was married there yesterday to Wallace L. Ford 2d, son of Mr. Ford of Washington and Carmen Ford of Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Leon Sullivan, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in Zion Baptist Church.

title: A KINDERGARTEN DAY: SHOULD IT BE LONGER?
description: ONLY 11 school districts on the Island have kindergarten sessions that are longer than the usual two and a half hours, according to the New York State Department of Education. But in recent months one school district has received approval from its local board of education for an extended kindergarten session to begin in September, another has considered and rejected the idea and a third is evaluating its kindergarten program and looking at the longer session as an option.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Phyllis Lamhut has been choreographing for 30 years now and she gets better and better with time. Her ''Mirage Blanc,'' a suite of wildly disparate dances set to eight piano waltzes by contemporary composers, will be performed by the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company Thursday through next Sunday, May 10, at Theater of the Riverside Church.

description: To the Editor:

title: 26-STORY OFFICE TOWER PROPOSED FOR ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S PROPERTY
description: A developer has offered to construct an office building adjacent to St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue at 50th Street that would be only about a third of its maximum permitted size.

title: No Headline
description: Correction A glance box last Sunday incorrectly stated Shearson Loeb Rhoades's 1979 revenues and American Express's 1980 assets. The correct figures are $304 million for Shearson and $19.71 billion for American Express.

title: LEGISLATORS IN SURVEY PREDICT INCOME TAX
description: THIRDS of the General Assembly opposes a progressive income tax, but a narrow majority thinks the state will have one within five years, according to a survey conducted over the last two weeks by The New York Times.

title: THE CASE OF DIGITAL SWITCH
description: W ALL STREETERS who have followed the short, checkered career of the Digital Switch Corporation are wondering whether it is gold, as its sponsors imply; dross, as its brief history suggests; or something in between, as changing circumstances may yet prove.

title: INDIA AND CHINA: A TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: Twenty-five years ago, it was common among experts on international development to contrast and compare India and China in terms of Arthur Koestler's metaphor, ''the Yogi and the Commissar.'' The Hungarian-born British writer had divided his world into followers of the Communist Commissar - who believes in change from without and in the principle that the end justifies the means - and the mystical Yogi, who believes that ''the end is unpredictable and that the means alone count.''

title: Brussels Fire Is Investigated
description: A fire early today destroyed the Yugoslav national tourist office and five rooms of the downtown hotel in which it is situated, the police reported. No injuries were reported. Authorities said they were investigating the blaze and were not ruling out arson.

title: MASTER CONTROL IS DNA - AND EVEN THAT GETS WEAR AND TEAR
description: IF aging is inevitable - if the human organism obeys an internal mechanism that irreversibly devolves until the end - then what is the nature of the processes that cause it? Dr. David E. Harrison of the Jackson Laboratories in Bar Harbor, Me., has likened alternate theories of aging to three ways in which a bicycle may become inoperative.

title: TENNIS OFF TO A BAD START
description: The second annual Tournament of Champions got off to a bad start at Forest Hills yesterday when many of the tickets purchased in advance went unused, rain caused two delays, and the featured match had to be postponed because the temperature took a sudden drop to 55 degrees.

title: WANTED: MORE SKILLED WORKERS
description: To meet the competitive economic challenge that is now coming from abroad, the United States is going to have to repair some of its major structural weaknesses. Nowhere are the repairs more urgent than in the institutions, or lack of institutions, for training skilled blue collar workers - the tool and die makers, machinists pipefitters and the like.

title: Right Turn on Red: A Miscalculation
description: Someone made a slight miscalculation, and as a result more than 3,000 pedestrians have been struck by vehicles - pedestrians who might otherwise have been saved pain, suffering and, in many cases, death.

title: ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE: SEEKING CHEMICAL CLUES
description: MENTAL deterioration is by no means an inevitable consequence of aging, but it is common enough to be a significant public health problem. Experts estimate that 15 percent of persons over the age of 65 have some mental impairment and about 5 percent - more than a million - are so seriously affected that they can no longer care for themselves.

title: WHY CAN'T LAWYERS WRITE IN PLAIN ENGLISH?
description: LAWYERS are in a class by themselves. Lawyers are intelligent, knowledgeable, perceptive. They are concerned people - concerned with civic affairs, social affairs, political affairs, civil-liberty affairs. As a rule, lawyers are articulate, outspoken, assertive. They can be expected to express a definite point of view. Lawyers are positive thinkers. They are communicators.

title: Soviet Writer, Beaten Year Ago, Still Can't Work
description: Valentin Rasputin, a Soviet writer whose theme is the spiritual cost of technological progress, has been suffering for a year from a beating he received in Irkutsk, the Siberian city where he lives, and has not been able to resume writing, according to friends in Moscow.

description: Mayor Koch asserted last week that Governor Carey had "flinched, blinked and lost" in his budget-delaying battle of wills with Senator Warren M. Anderson, and Senate Republicans hailed their leader as a victor. But if Mr. Carey did indeed leave the field empty-handed, he didn't leave entirely in defeat.

description: The engagement of Barbara Ann Curtis to Hugh Auchincloss Thacher has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. John Curtis of Danville, Ill., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Thacher of Riverdale, the Bronx.

description: ATLANTIC CITY WHEN casino gambling was approved in 1976, there were few complaints about this city's Police Department, which seemed to be doing its job.

title: No Headline
description: Before an already bloated defense budget is expanded, perhaps the new Administration will recall other recent problems of perception - an arms race to close a missile gap that didn't exist; a now dismantled multibillion-dollar antiballistic missile system that was uniformly criticized by Presidential science advisers as technically not practicable and strategically unsound (much the same criticism as for the MX); and a war that, according to President Nixon, continued to be fought in order to avoid the perception of weakness and win an ''honorable peace.''

title: Talks Stall in Hard-Coal Strike
description: No new talks are scheduled in a strike by approximately 2,000 members of the United Mine Workers' District 25, which represents hard-coal miners in northeastern Pennsylvania, the negotiators said today. The miners walked out Thursday night.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Craft Supplies At Stratford
description: Stratford Craft Supplies draws wholesale as well as retail customers from as far away as New York City. Craft groups representing all ages and skills show up month after month for supplies, with prices reduced for quantity purchases or the 13th item free.

title: ...AND INTELLECTUALS' FAILURE
description: Recurring violence and increasing political alienation highlight the failure of intellectual leadership in political life. Although there is continuing and frequently impassioned discussion of public-policy issues among intellectuals, there is little effort by them to inform the general public of the complexity of issues or to correct deliberately misleading use of data by political figures. Instead, intellectuals join politicians in tailoring their public positions to the results of public-opinion polling.

description: Faye Connelly Boyle and Randolph Hugh Elkins were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyerian Church by the Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones.

description: The bribery-conspiracy trial of a reputed organized crime chief and four other men is scheduled to resume next week after a recess in which the judge is studying some key issues.

description: The marriage of Christina Skalny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard L. Skalny of Rochester, to Albert M. Van Wagenen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Van Wagenen 3d of Rye, N.Y., took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Rochester.

description: NORMAN ROCKWELL is one of the most loved of American artists and any event concerning his life and work is bound to elicit enthusiasm - but particularly in Westchester, where he lived from 1912 to 1939 in Mamaroneck and New Rochelle.

title: Critics' Choices
description: VIDEO ART ''Time Zone,'' a video piece by Ira Schneider, provides global entertainment in a darkened room on the second floor of the Whitney Museum (through next Sunday, May 10). A busy surround of color and noise, it comprises 24 color television monitors, placed high up on pedestals arranged in a circle like ancient stelae.

title: HARTFORD BLENDS NEW AND OLD
description: HARTFORD A HELICOPTER hovers over an empty lot near downtown Hartford. A tall blond man points out the sights to the other passengers: the Connecticut River to the east, the Capitol's golden dome, the bright blue onion atop the Colt Armory nearby. The tour guide, Thomas K. Standish, is a developer, showing potential clients the view they would enjoy from the two office towers he plans to start constructing in the fall.

title: Jane M. Kohlmeyer, Banker, Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Jane Mitchell Kohlmeyer to John H. Kazanjian has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Harry Kohlmeyer of Seaford, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Mr. Kazanjian is a son of Mrs. Powel H. Kazanjian of Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. Kazanjian. A September wedding is planned.

title:
ART;
LIVELY EXPERIMENTS WITH THE STILL LIFE
description: SOUTHAMPTON THE still life, far from being a relic of academic art training or the exclusive province of the unimaginative amateur painter, is alive and well in the repertory of contemporary artists, as we see in the group exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum. The show of paintings and drawings by 28 East End artists is an excellent reminder that artistic skill and imagination can transform even the most mundane subject matter into captivating pictorial statements.

title: IT'S REAGAN'S STRONG SUIT AGAINST THE ODDS
description: WASHINGTON RONALD REAGAN was relaxed. The pace was leisurely, the humor abundant. When the New Jersey Congressman sitting beside him on the Oval Office sofa Thursday afternoon expressed fears that workers being laid off in his district were too old to find new jobs, the President quipped: ''What do you mean? - I got one at 70.'' When he learned that the Congressman headed a subcommittee on aging, the President joked: ''Well, I have to have a private talk with you - I have a few problems of my own.''

title: L.I.R.R. Track Work To Disrupt Service
description: Train service between Kings Park and Port Jefferson will be suspended today and through Thursday from 9:15 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. because of track maintenance work, the Long Island Rail Road reported.
