description: In the 1960's, when gasoline was cheap and highperformance cars ruled the roads, songs were written about Pontiacs. In fact, a tune by Ronnie and the Daytonas extolling the engine of the Pontiac GTO rose as high as No.4 on the pop music charts in 1964.

title: Iranians Capture Ship Of Houston-Based Concern
description: The official Iranian press agency Pars said today that an Iranian warship had seized a seismographic ship owned by the Houston-based Western Geophysical Company off its coast last week and ordered it into the Persian Gulf port of Bushire.

title: Prince Charles Rejoins Fiancee After Good-Will Visit to the U.S.
description: Charles, Prince of Wales and heir to the British throne, left the United States under tight security but unruffled today following a brush with hecklers that was the only incident during a good-will festival with the American people.

title: DOGERS VALENZUELA ROUTS EXPOS FOR NO. 6
description: Early today, Fernando Valenzuela relaxed in the dugout, taking photographs of his teammates. Davey Lopes shouted at him: ''Fernando, go in the clubhouse and meditate. Get ready for the game. You're making a joke of this game.''

title: Islanders Profiting From Power Plays
description: The story of the National Hockey League playoffs so far has been the Islanders' power play. With a success rate of 37.5 percent on power plays, the Islanders defeated Toronto in three straight games in the opening round. The Islanders were successful on 13 of 28 opportunities in the quarterfinals and knocked out the Edmonton Oilers. Now, after producing five more power-play goals in 17 attempts in the semifinal round, the Islanders lead the Rangers, 3-0, and are in position to clinch the series with a victory tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden.

title: CHAPLAIN IS REVEALED AS AUTHOR OF BOOK ON VIETNAM
description: The name of the Reserve lieutenant colonel who used the pseudonym Cincinnatus when he wrote the book ''Self-Destruction: The Disintegration and Decay of the United States Army During the Vietnam Era'' has been revealed to be Dr. Cecil B. Currey, a professor of American military history at the University of South Florida in Tampa who never served in Vietnam.

title: BICYCLISTS COVER CITY ON A 32-MILE TOUR
description: Hugo Magnillanes pedaled easily up the middle lane of the Pulaski Bridge with his baby daughter Ahinsa on his back around noon yesterday, without a thought of being crushed by the rush of trucks and cars.

title: MONDAY, MAY 4, 1981; Companies
description: Europe's auto makers are encouraged by Japan's moves to cut car exports to the U.S.: They think this will make it easier or their governments to extract similar concessions from Japan. (Page D1.)

title: ARSON DAMAGES INTENDED PARSONAGE OF A BLACK MINISTER IN FLUSHING
description: A house that a black minister had intended to use as his parsonage was badly damaged by fire over the weekend in a Queens neighborhood where there are no other black families. But the minister, the Rev. Richard F. Norris, said yesterday that he was ''more determined than ever'' to settle in the community.

title: JOHN FRANCIS M'SHARRY
description: John Francis McSharry, president of the RMJ Securities Corporation of 99 Wall Street, died of cancer at New York Hospital Saturday. Mr. McSharry, who was a resident of Manhattan, was 41 years old.

title: Birdie by Sally Little Wins 3-Way Playoff
description: Sally Little sank a 9-foot putt for a birdie on the first hole of a playoff today to beat Hollis Stacy and Kathy Whitworth in the sixth annual CPC Women's International tournament.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corporation, Baltimore, has named Edward A. Weisman, executive vice president and chief operating officer, to the additional post of president of the Macke Company, a subsidiary.

title: Ex-Im Bank Guarantees
description: The United States Export-Import Bank approved two financial guarantees, one of $104.2 million to the Philippines and another of $36.3 million to Sri Lanka, for the purchase of American-made goods. The guarantee to the Philippines will assist in financing additional purchases for a nuclear power plant being built on Bataan peninsula by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. The Sri Lanka guarantee will go toward purchase of two Lockheed L-1011 planes by the Government-owned Air Lanka.

title: Commodities; Interest Takes Toll On Futures
description: THE extraordinary rise in interest rates last week weighed heavily on all basic food and industrial commodity futures prices. At a time when there is no shortage of any raw material, it made trade hedgers loath to carry or add to inventories, while speculators eyed the rising yields on Treasury bills, certificates of deposits and other relatively safe short-term money market instruments.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt POKER STRATEGY. Winning With Game Theory. By Nesmith C. Ankeny. 189 pages. Illustrated with tables. Basic. $11.95.

title: INDIAN OCEAN BASES MAY COST TOO MUCH
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEANS WELCOME AUTO PACT
description: European auto makers welcomed Japan's decision to reduce car exports to the United States, saying they were now more optimistic that their governments would press for similar cuts and that Japan would agree.

title: A MEMORIAL 'CELEBRATION' IS HELD FOR JULES C. STEIN, MCA FOUNDER
description: Jules C. Stein, founder of the Music Corporation of America, who died last Wednesday of heart failure three days after his 85th birthday, was celebrated by 1,200 friends and Hollywood luminaries at a memorial service this afternoon.

title: Indonesia Gas Sales
description: Indonesia will start exporting liquefied petroleum gas to the Philippines in July at the rate of 2,000 metric tons a month, the state oil and gas company announced. The gas will come from North Sumatra, where expansion work on a liquefaction plant is to be completed next month, raising daily capacity to 100 tons. The initial price of $190 a ton will be adjusted after Jan. 1, 1982, according to a formula based on the price of Indonesian crude oil.

title: News Analysis
description: A little more than a month ago, a member of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government told a visitor that one of the Chancellor's concerns in trying to set up a weapons deal with Saudi Arabia was the effect the failure of such an effort might have on perceptions of his ability to make West Germany an influence in world affairs.

title: Suspect in Robbery Is Shot by an Officer
description: An off-duty police officer shot a robbery suspect at East 85th Street and Third Avenue, the police said. The suspect - Joseph Pinto, 35 years old, of Union City, N.J. - was taken to Metropolitan Hospital and reported to be in stable condition.

title: 2d Reward Posted In Officer's Slaying
description: An offer by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of a $10,000 reward has been added to the $10,000 posted by the city administration for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killers of Police Officer John Scarangella on April 16 in St. Albans, Queens.

title: Lion in Zimbabwe Kills Mother and 3 Children
description: A lion killed a woman and her three children in a village in northeastern Zimbabwe, a national parks spokesman said today.

title: KENYANS LOOK FOR ANSWERS AS THE ECONOMY GOES SOUR
description: In East Africa, perhaps in all black Africa except the Ivory Coast, the kindest words have always been reserved for Kenya. It worked, it was full of big game and fine lodges, and so it was fun to visit. It encouraged free enterprise, kept its human rights record fairly clean and, from the Western point of view, won high marks for shunning Soviet influence and retaining a devout commitment to capitalism.

title: GREGOREK WINNER IN RUN
description: It was a long time, said John Gregorek, since he had run a really good race. But Gregorek, a 21-year-old Georgetown junior from East Northport, L.I., ran a good one today, winning the 10,000-meter run in the Big East Conference outdoor

title: A NEW MRS. MELTON SPEAKS OUT
description: MELTON, who is back at her accustomed position as the leading money winner in the Ladies Professional Golf Association, says she does not expect to remain on the women's tour for more than another six years, or until she is 30 years old.

title: Military Analysis
description: Intelligence analysts here and in other NATO capitals say they expect a revival, and perhaps an intensification, of the war between Iran and Iraq.

title: Coal Industry Leader Says Talks Could Resume Soon
description: By The Associated Press The coal industry's top negotiator said yesterday that he expected talks with the United Mine Workers to resume this week in an effort to end a strike by 160,000 coal miners.

title: Essay; THE NOTRE DAME SHIFT
description: Early in his Presidency, Jimmy Carter went to Notre Dame University to deliver an address on foreign policy. He tried to mesh a hawkish speech draft by Zbigniew Brzezinski and a dovish speech draft by Cy Vance's State Department.

title: DANCE: GELSEY KIRKLAND AND CYNTHIA GREGORY
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV finally stepped into his own new restaging of the American Ballet Theater's ''Giselle'' on Saturday night, and he did so with his perfect partner, Gelsey Kirkland. During the matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House, Alexander Godunov was seen in New York for the first time as Cynthia Gregory's Albrecht.

title: CAPITAL RALLY ASSAILS ARMS TO SALVADOR
description: At least 20,000 demonstrators marched on the Pentagon today to protest United States military aid to El Salvador, proposed increases in arms spending and budget cuts in social programs.

title: News Analysis
description: The introduction by anti-abortion Senators of a bill that would define the legal commencement of human life as the moment of conception has given new urgency to a debate among scientists that began in July 1978, after the birth of

title: OPERA: Y OFFERS WEINER'S VERSION OF THE GOLEM'
description: JEWISH Opera at the 92d Street Y presented Lazar Weiner's ''The Golem'' last weekend.

title: Ken Norton's New Role
description: IN the hollow emptiness of the Beverly Hills Playhouse in California, the acting class had finished a scene. Up on the stage, the students, young and old and Ken Norton, gathered around Milton Katsellas, their instructor. ''You've got to do your best all the way through the scene,'' they heard him say. ''You've got to fulfill your role.''

title: NEW YORKERS PATROLLING STREETS TO WATCH FOR CRIME
description: An increasing number of New Yorkers have taken to the streets with flashlights and walkie-talkies in volunteer neighborhood patrols against crime.

title: Sir Vincent Tewson, 83; Ex-British Union Leader
description: Sir Vincent Tewson, longtime leader of Britain's labor federation, the Trades Union Congress, died Friday at his home in Letchworth, his family announced yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Lakers' Johnson Hints at Trade
description: By The Associated Press Magic Johnson, the second-year point guard of the Los Angeles Lakers, intimated yesterday that a trade involving his backcourt mate, Norm Nixon, might solve the team's problems next season.

title: The U.N. Today; May 4, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3 P.M.

title: GUATEMALAN KEEPS A STEP AHEAD OF RIGHTIST GUNMEN
description: ''When you participate in politics in Guatemala, you have to learn to accept many things,'' the young party leader said. He paused as he raised himself in his chair to ease the pressure on his back caused by the pistol stuffed under his belt.

title: MUSCIC BEETHOVEN BY CURTIS STUDENTS
description: THE Curtis Institute fielded an impressive student orchestra for its all-Beethoven concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday - equally as virtuoso as its counterpart from Indiana University, which visited New York last week. It enjoying the added benefit of Robert Shaw's serious musical leadership.

title: Let Pakistan Choose: Aid or a Bomb
description: After India exploded a nuclear device seven years ago, to chase after the Chinese, it was predictable if not inevitable that archrival Pakistan would set out on the same trail. The Pakistanis began with open purchases of sensitive technologies. When these were blocked, their purchases became surreptitious. Now they are building a tunnel to test a nuclear weapon. And India combines tough talk with visible preparation for another demonstration shot of its own.

title: Chrysler Sales Aide Switches to Toyotas
description: Jerry H. Pyle, a 44-year-old sales executive who has been helping the Chrysler Corporation in its battle against imported cars during the last two years, has joined the other side.

title: CHARLES SILBERMAN, EXECUTIVE, MARRIES SUSAN LYNN HARRIS
description: Susan Lynn Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Chester Harris of Scarsdale,N.Y., was married last evening to Charles I. Silberman,son of Corinne Silberman if New York and the late J. Sidney Silberman. Rabbi Max J. Mintz performed the ceremony at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. The bride, a graduate of Franklin and Marshall College is with Chester Harris & Company, a New York investment banking house specializing in municipal bonds, of which her father is president. Mr. Silberman, who was graduated from Columbia College, is vice president of the S. Parker Hardware Manufacturing Corporation, of which his father had been president.

title: EX-KARMAL ALLY, ON WAY TO U.S., TELLS OF THE AGONY IN AFGHANISTAN
description: For Mohammed Saddiq Farhang, his years as a statistical economist were in conflict with his passions as a refugee. The onetime Afghan Ambassador to Yugoslavia and economic adviser to the present Government in Kabul tried to give his assessment of developments in his homeland in a dispassionate tone.

title: SPENDING BY MILITARY IS DEFENDED
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Murray L. Weidenbaum, says there is no reason to expect the planned build-up of military spending in the next several years to cause a new surge of inflation.

title: Rangers 9, Royals 8
description: Pat Putnam led off the 10th inning with a home run. Putnam, who helped tie the score in the eighth, hit a 3-2 pitch in the eighth, hit a 3-2 pitch from Juan Berenguer (1-1) off the right-field foul pole, with John Henry Johnson (1-1) getting the victory. Texas scored twice in the first when John Grubb, who driven in 15 runs in his last 11 games, singled in two runs and made it 3-0 in the second on Bump Wills's sacrifice fly.

title: FOREST HILLS WAITS FOR THE BIG HITTERS
description: A major tennis event, the Tournament of Champions, began on the weekend at Forest Hills without many people paying attention. There was a sparse crowd Saturday, a cold, rainy opening day, and the final match ended with fewer than 300 people in the stands.

title: PURCHASING AGENTS TELL OF GAINS
description: A national survey of purchasing managers released yesterday indicates the nation's industrial economy improved in April, as key indicators such as production, incoming new orders and employment gained from the previous month.

title: Advertising; CBS-TV's Retailing Approach
description: IN the forefront of the television industry's drive to attract major retailers as advertisers has been WCBS-TV in New York with the other four CBS-owned stations close behind.

title: Youngblood Homer Gives Mets a Split
description: Joel Youngblood, who probably has been the only unhappy member of the Mets' family this season, injected the family with instant happiness yesterday. Youngblood, who already had stroked three singles, hit a three-run homer in the seventh inning of the second game that gave the Mets a 7-4 victory and a split of their doubleheader and their four-game series with the San Diego Padres.

title: OUTDOORS: TESTING THE WATERS OF LAKE ONTARIO ON A FISHING TRIP
description: Harassed by the same strong northerly winds that drove many participants in last month's Empire State-Lake Ontario trout and salmon derby off the water, Harold Herrick Jr. and William Pearce, both of Cape Vincent, N.Y., and I conferred at Ronnie Ditch's Sport Fishing Center at Henderson Harbor and concluded that a float trip down the Salmon River would provide more relaxing and rewarding angling.

title: Ex-New Yorker Publisher Selected by Harper's
description: David D. Michaels, one-time publisher of The New Yorker, is to be the new publisher of Harper's magazine. He was selected by the board of the Harper's Magazine Foundation, which is headed by Jerome S. Hardy, who was publisher of the old Life.

title: Alliance Formed to Support Bill On Deposits for Bottles and Cans
description: Officials from New York City and nearby counties have formed an organization called D.A.B.B. - the Downstate Alliance for Bottle Bills - to support legislation requiring a deposit on beverage bottles and cans. Their purpose is to reduce litter and solid waste.

title: Bermuda's Cabinet Meets To Review Impact of Strikes
description: The Cabinet met today for the second time this weekend to review the effects of strikes that have crippled the island's tourist industry.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIGNS OF THE TIMES

title: MONTANA DROUGHT REMINDS SOME OF DUST BOWL DAYS OF THE 1930'S
description: Here in the northern Plains, wheat fields are little more than dust, the new grass in the pastures is merely fuzz, and springs are drying up.

title: Addendum
description: * Us magazine will increase its circulation rate base, to 1.1 million, from one million, and its advertising rates 10 percent, effective with the July 7 issue.

title: Brian Teacher Wins
description: Brian Teacher of the United States defeated Israel's Shlomo Glickstein, 6-4, 6-2, today and won the $50,000 Elite Grand Challenge tennis tournament. The first prize was $17,000.

title: Governor Prepares to Act On Fund Bill to Aid Boston
description: Gov. Edward J. King was preparing today to act tomorrow on a bill that would release $9.4 million in state funds to help this city's nearly insolvent school system.

title: Scypion Outpoints Parker in 10 Rounds
description: Wilford Scypion slugged it out in an inside contest with Curtis Parker for 10 rounds today and scored a unanimous decision in their middleweight bout.

title: GAINS FOR LATIN AMERICAN CROPS CALLED NO HELP TO SMALL FARMERS
description: A decade ago, when the ''green revolution'' produced ''miracle'' wheat and rice, crop yields jumped dramatically throughout the developing world. But because the new seed required the heavy use of costly fertilizer, the wealthiest, large-scale farmers and their urban customers were the main beneficiaries, while the poorest peasants remained as destitute as before.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I appeal to the people to remain calm and have no fighting, and cause no death or destruction.

title: U.S. AGENCIES TO GET GREATER DISCRETION ON RELEASING FILES
description: Attorney General William French Smith is expected to announce a major change tomorrow in the way Federal agencies respond to public requests for Government information and files.

title: WHY DOCTORS MIGHT HAVE TO CLOSE SHOP
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Budget Allocates $25 Billion for Security
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's major oil exporter, announced a $90 billion budget today with more than a quarter of the money for the military and the police.

title: WHALE-WATCHER'S DELIGHT: SPUME IN ATLANTIC OFF L.I.
description: It was a performance that would have pleased even Captain Ahab: three quick geysers of water, three fast-moving fins and a glimpse of three glistening mammoth backs.

title: Karl Bechert, Physicist; Hid Jews From the Nazis
description: Dr. Karl Bechert, a physicist and educator who was a professor at Giessen University in Germany during the Hitler regime and remained a staunch anti-Nazi, died on April 1 in Weilmunster, West Germany, it was reported yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Women Quit Air Force Academy
description: The dropout rate among women at the Air Force Academy is higher than among men, and some women say it is because they have no role models who have succeeded as cadets at the academy. Nearly 60 percent of the women who entered the academy four years ago have dropped out, as against 40 percent of the men, academy officials said.

title: The Talk of Hardenburgh
description: An official at the New York State Thruway Authority, having checked a state map, declared there was no such place as Hardenburgh in the state of New York. A telephone operator drew the same conclusion, since the town was not listed in the telephone directory. ''Are you sure that's the correct spelling?'' she asked.

title: MCENROE BEATS KRIEK, 6-1, 6-2, 6-4, FOR HIS SECOND W.C.T. CROWN
description: John McEnroe frustrated Johan Kriek at every turn today and won the World Championship Tennis final, 6-1, 6-2, 6-4.

title: BROWN LUNGS
description: President Reagan has opened his war on health and safety protection with an attack on the Occupational Health and Safety Administration's cotton-dust standard.

title: WEST AFRICA'S CREEPING DEMOCRACY
description: The Nigerian capital of Lagos, last stop on a recent six-nation tour of West Africa, is the richest, dirtiest, most disorderly city of the region.

title: CITY DISCUSSING A HOTEL PROJECT ON SITE OF AUDUBON BALLROOM WITH
description: PRIVATE DEVELOPERS By CLYDE HABERMAN

title: President for Chromatics
description: Randolph G. Richmond, 42, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Chromatics Inc., a manufacturer of color graphic computers and displays, effective June 1. He will succeed Terence D. Hughey, 40, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, which has its headquarters in Tucker, Ga.

title: ALABAMA PRISON CHANGES CALLED REMARKABLE GAINS
description: The Alabama prison system, which was in such miserable condition that a Federal judge placed it in receivership not long ago, has made improvements in the last 18 months that some corrections experts say are remarkable and innovative.

title: Ex-Genesco Chief Heads Kuhn's
description: J. Owen Howell Jr., 56, has been named chairman of the executive committee and chief executive officer of the Kuhn's-Big K Stores Corporation, a general merchandising discount chain with 109 stores. As chief executive, he succeeds Jack W. Kuhn, a 62-year-old son of the founder, who continues as chairman of the Nashville-based company.

title: ANOTHER RISE IN PRIME FORECAST
description: Fixed-income markets open for business today on a common note: record yields in all sectors for long-term securities. Also, there is a consensus that the prime rate, now at 18 percent, is headed still higher. Last week, as costs of lendable funds increased for major banks, they raised this basic lending charge from 17 1/2 percent.

title: MARTHON MARKS FOR MRS. ARENZ
description: Jan Arenz, one of the nation's premier marathoners, chopped more than 10 minutes off the course record for women in the fourth annual Newsday Long Island Marathon today. She finished in 2 hours 46 minutes 32 seconds, placing 43d over all.

title: 'FRIDAY THE 13TH PART II
description: FRIDAY the 13th Part II'' will frighten you, at least for moments, although it will be a close-run thing whether it will be fright, nausea or simple distaste that gets to you first. The movie, which opened at Loews State II and other theaters Friday, exists for no other purpose than to shock. The plot is an excuse for joining together horrors, all of the sado-masochist kind, and the acting is rudimentary at best. It probably will make a fortune.

title: COLLECTOR OF GUNS SOUGHT IN SLAYINGS
description: The police began a manhunt in two Middle Western states today for a gun collector suspected of shooting and killing six people, including his wife, a police sergeant, in his home in a Washington suburb.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday on the New York Times/CBS News Poll erroneously described the Republican share of respondents who declared themselves members of one party or the other. Thirty-four percent of the respondents said they were Democrats; 26 percent said they were Republicans.

title: Califano's Unflattering Glimpse of Carter White House
description: Several former officials of the Carter Administration are working on books about their years in office, but few seem to be as far along as Joseph A. Califano Jr., a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. His 454-page memoir - ''Governing America: An Insider's Report from the White House and the Cabinet'' - is scheduled for publication this month.

title: Capital Idea
description: It took several decades before baseball players from the Negro leagues that thrived from the 1920's to the 1950's got their due. After a smattering of publicity in the 1960's, blacks from those leagues who were barred from major league baseball until 1947 were finally inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in the 1970's.

title: DIVERSITY STRENGTHENS UTILITIES
description: The Montana Power Company does more than sell the electricity that lights the homes and powers the factories in the Big Sky state. It also drills for oil, leases Canadian natural gas properties and mines for coal in Montana, Wyoming and Texas.

title: HUDSON POLLUTION IS NOT JUST A FISH
description: STORY To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL COUPLES, HOME AND AWAY
description: To outsiders, the life of a big league baseball player and his wife seems like a glamorous one, marked by big salaries, travel and the adulation of fans.

title: MYSTERY OF MEMORY THAT FAILS IN OLD AGE
description: F OURTEEN people clustered around the white Formica table in the cheery hospital conference room, and Dr. Lenore S. Powell, the gerontologist who was their therapy group leader, spoke to them gently.

title: HARD-LINE OPPONENT OF GUN LAWS WINS NEW TERM AT HELM OF RIFLE
description: ASSOCIATION By JOHN M. CREWDSON

title: LAWYERS' ABUSE
description: The most recent Harris poll on public confidence in various American institutions and professions puts lawyers last.Not long ago, Martin London, chairman of the New York City Bar Association's grievance committee, which handles complaints against lawyers here, attempted to explain lawyers' general disrepute. The reasons he gave, in a news report in The New York Times, included the Watergate scandal, a public tendency to blame lawyers for crime, the courts' involvement in setting new social policy, the proliferation of government and other regulations that impinge on everyone's life, the adversary nature of litigation, and the increasing resort to legal action to resolve problems.

title: STAGE: CLASSIC SATIRE, 'PATIENCE'
description: THE New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players recently completed a run of ''Patience'' at the Symphony Space, a production that must have cheered the hearts of all who believe in a traditional approach to this classic satire of fads and affectation. Matt Dolph's direction faithfully observed every bit of time-honored business, yet each moment came across with delightful freshness, wit and immediacy.

title: GISCARD OFFERS TO DEBATE MITTERRAND
description: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France offered today to participate in a television debate with Francois Mitterrand on terms agreeable to the Socialist challenger for the presidency.

title: 5-Week Strike Ends At Dannon Yogurt
description: Dannon yogurt was expected to return to grocers' shelves today following the settlement of a five-week strike.

title: INTOXICATION CHARGE FILED
description: A Long Island Rail Road engineer drove his train past three scheduled stops near the Queens border Saturday night, reaching high speeds and terrifying passengers before the train was stopped by its conductor.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player in the National Basketball Association steps to the free throw line and is handed the ball by an official. The player then bounces the ball a few times, and it strikes his foot and rolls away. Is he allowed to leave the free throw line to retrieve the ball? Can a teammate get the ball for him? Or is the free throw attempt forfeited?

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A jury has awarded $6.5 million in damages to a woman who became a quadriplegic at a Chicago hospital after cosmetic nose surgery.

title: A Meeting of the Minds in the Art World
description: ''I don't know all of you,'' the hostess said in her toast, ''but you are obviously very special.'' Indeed. The two dozen guests had paid $500 each to have dinner with the artist Christo and his photographer wife, Jeanne-Claude, who, in her toast Saturday night, summed up a feeling of admiration between artist and art lovers.

title: MUSIC: CHICAGOIANS PLAY 'FAUST'
description: THE Chicago Symphony has traditionally brought blockbuster programs to New York for its annual Carnegie Hall visits, and this last week was no exception. After first weighing in with the Mahler Ninth and Bruckner Fourth symphonies, the Chicagoans and their conductor, Georg Solti, offered a spectacular grand finale Friday and Saturday nights, Berlioz's Romantic choral masterpiece ''The Damnation of Faust.'' The Chicago orchestra has just recorded the score for Decca/London and with a superior quartet of soloists: Frederica von Stade, Kenneth Riegel, Jose van Dam and Malcolm King. Margaret Hillis's superbly trained Chicago Symphony Chorus predictably added an impressive choral luster to the proceedings.

title: FRUSTRATION GROWS AS LEADS FADE IN ATLANTA KILLINGS
description: For a few moments it seemed as if something good was about to happen in the long, depressing history of Atlanta's missing and murdered children and young adults.

title: VETERANS CALL CUTBACKS 'ANOTHER BETRAYAL'
description: Shortly after 7:30 on Tuesday evenings, the men gather in the first-floor office of a deserted building near downtown San Diego. They pull up chairs in a circle and speak quietly.

title: ASIAN DEVELOPMENT BANK CAN'T GO IT ALONE
description: During the three-day annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank, the Solomon Islands and the director general of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries signed an agreement for the partial financing of the islands' Lungga Hydropower Project by the OPEC Fund, a lending body for less-developed nations.

title: Rangers Unable to Find Reason for Losses
description: The trouble with the Rangers, according to the Rangers, is that they do not know why they have been playing poorly enough to be one loss away from elimination by the Islanders from the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Future Date
description: In 1980, the Pittsburgh Steelers played the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for only the second time in a regular-season game, but it is difficult to determine when they will meet again.

title: Dith Pran
description: BLESSING OF THE ANIMALS: Rabbi Joseph H. Gelberman of the Little Synagogue, left, and the Rev. John McConnell of St. Ignatius Loyola Church blessing parrots be-longing to Peter Brandon. Pets were blessed at Sherman Plaza as the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals launched its Be Kind to Animals Week.

title: KOCH CAN'T PLEAD IGNORANCE OF ELECTION LAWS
description: To the Editor:

title: FREDERICK J. OTTERBEIN
description: Frederick J. Otterbein, retired senior executive of General Foods Corporation, died yesterday in Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. Mr. Otterbein, who was a resident of Stamford and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was 69 years old.

title: Murdoch Gets 2d Ex-Im Loan
description: The United States Export-Import Bank has approved a second low-interest loan to a company owned by Rupert Murdoch, the controversial Australian publisher.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some editions of Business Day last Wednesday, the extent of Ford's anticipated second-quarter loss was incorrectly reported. Ford has said, in connection with the sale of some Ford Motor Credit Company notes, that it anticipates a loss in the second quarter that will be ''substantially smaller'' than the first-quarter loss of $439 million.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 4, 1981
description: International The U.S. will have to take a key role and probably provide many of the troops in the formation of an international peacekeeping force in Sinai between Egypt and Israel, a State Department spokesman said. The Administration has come to this conclusion, it was said, following consultations at the United Nations. The State Department said that meetings will be held in Washington today through Wednesday by Egyptian, Israeli and American military officials to discuss details of the international force, which may amount to 2,500 troops, half of whom might be Americans. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States might be willing to start talks with the Soviet Union before the end of the year on the reduction of European-based nuclear weapons, according to an impression reportedly given by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in separate talks with NATO's foreign ministers in Rome. The ministers are pressing the United States to set an early date for the talks, which is the No. 1 issue of their meetings today and tomorrow. (A1:5.)

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Age of the Bear

title: STAGE: MUSICAL EVANGELISM IN 'AIMEE'
description: WE know we are on to something good in ''Sister Aimee'' right from the start: The ensemble wanders on stage, each attractive member wearing the secret smile, full of conviction, that we associate with Disneyland guides, say, or television evangelists. In fact, the members of the ensemble are about to sing the praise of Aimee Semple McPherson and the Lord, both of whom they hold in reverence, and both of whom, to our delight, they will continue to sing about and praise during the evening. ''Sister Aimee,'' the musical at the Gene Frankel Theater, is wonderful.

title: Island Charm Wins Aqueduct Vagrancy
description: Island Charm, fifth at the halfway mark, closed through the stretch to win the 31st running of the Vagrancy Handicap for fillies at Aqueduct yesterday. Love Sign, the even-money favorite, was fourth.

title: Liner Norway Limping to Miami After Boilers Rupture on Cruise
description: The world's largest cruise ship steamed toward Miami, its home port, today at two-thirds normal speed, its boilers damaged, apparently by a chemical that ruptured their seams.

title: U.S., SOVIET AND SYRIA PRESS EFFORTS TO EASE LEBANON CRISIS
description: Behind-the-scenes negotiations to ease the current Lebanese crisis were under way at two levels today, as the guns remained quiet for the fourth day.

title: Meese Foresees Progress On Nuclear Arms Talks
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, said today that he expected movement toward United States-Soviet nuclear arms limitation talks during the year but the negotiations would depend on the international conduct of the Russians.

title: Revived ''Can-Can'' Closes After Five Performances
description: The Broadway revival of the 1953 Cole Porter-Abe Burrows musical ''Can-Can,'' which opened to weak reviews Thursday, closed after yesterday's matinee at the Minskoff Theater.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Adding Corporate Unit
description: Foote, Cone & Belding will join those agencies that have separate units to create corporate advertising. It's becoming quite a specialty and a growth area of advertising spending.

title: Grey Earnings Down
description: Grey Advertising reported Friday that its first-quarter net income was down 19.7 percent to $501,000, or 84 cents a share, from $624,000, or $1.02 a share, in the same period last year. Revenues however, were up 15.4 percent to $23.3 million from the same period last year, when they were $20.2 million.

title: School Registration Open for 2 Weeks
description: Children who will attend kindergarten and first grade classes in New York City public schools this fall for the first time may register today through May 15 at their local schools.

title: SCHMIDT'S ARMS POLICY SUFFERS SEVERE SETBACK AT A REGIONAL MEETING
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's policy of supporting a 1979 NATO decision to deploy additional nuclear missiles in Western Europe, if arms control talks fail, suffered a serious setback today when a regional conference of Mr. Schmidt's Social Democratic Party voted overwhelmingly for a review of the decision.

title: TV: ABC TAKES A LOOK AT SEDUCTION IN THE MOVIES
description: Question: What is the easiest way to assemble an all-star cast? Answer: Produce a salute or survey. In the wide, wide world of television entertainment, for example, there are those annual Bob Hope tributes, stuffed with clips from his television past. Mr. Hope and his guest stars can be recycled endlessly.

title: Bolivia Says Occupation Of U.S. Refinery Has Ended
description: Bolivia's military Government said tonight that troops ended the occupation of an Occidental Petroleum refinery by right-wing gunmen 125 miles south of the eastern city of Santa Cruz.

title: STUDENTS FOUND WITH A WEAPON TO BE SUSPENDED
description: New regulations calling for virtually automatic suspension of students found in possession of dangerous weapons were issued yesterday by Frank J. Macchiarola, the New York City School Chancellor.

title: NEWSPAPERS FIGHT TO BAN A.T.& T. FROM ELECTRONIC NEWS OR AD MARKET
description: The nation's newspaper industry has stepped up efforts to persuade Congress to keep the telephone company out of the business of providing news and advertising to readers at home.

title: People
description: * John Wiegand has been appointed executive vice president of the Chicago office of Creamer Inc.

title: SPENCER STARS
description: The Yankees rebounded from two dispiriting losses to the A's by winning both games of a doubleheader today, with Jim Spencer, an unlikely hero, contributing in each victory.

title: The Exorbitant Price of Davis-Bacon
description: In Maryland's Montgomery County, it costs about $9 an hour to hire an operator of heavy construction machinery. Yet bulldozer drivers working Maryland's portion of the Washington subway are paid about $14. Carpenters on one Boston apartment construction site earn $13. Others doing the same work down the street make $19.

title: Australia's Oldest Citizen Dies
description: Australia's oldest citizen, 111-year-old Jane Piercy, died today in her sleep, the Huntingdon Nursing Home here disclosed. Staff members said that Mrs. Piercy, who was reared on a dairy farm near Nowra, 75 miles south of here, attributed her longevity to nourishing food, fresh air and dancing.

title: William M. Cushman, 46, Headed Schieffelin, an Importer of Wines
description: William Michael Cushman, president and chief operating officer of Schieffelin & Company, wine and spirits importers, died Friday of pneumonia at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Cushman, who was a resident of Katonah, N.Y., was 46 years old.

title: Yellow Pages and a Fearful Press
description: As their careful readers may have noticed, newspapers have a direct interest in the growing debate about the future of American communications. It arises from the simple fact that technology is eroding the distinction between messages that are printed and those that are telephoned or broadcast. Words can now be written in electronic impulses, transmitted by air or wire and then reproduced as oral or written texts. No one knows, therefore, whether newspapers will always be dropped at the front door or be replaced one day by news and ads printed on screens, or even paper, in the home.

title: RISE IN GASOLINE PRICES SAID TO EASE
description: Amid plentiful world oil supplies and sluggish American demand, the average price of a gallon of gasoline in the New York City area rose in March by 3.8 cents, according to the most recent figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: CARDS BEAT REDS FOR 5TH STRAIGHT TIME, 5-4
description: The St. Louis Cardinals scored their fifth straight victory over the Cincinnati Reds this season, a 5-4 decision in St. Louis that gave the Cardinals their 11th victory in the last 12 games.

title: Accounts
description: * Globe Life and Accident Insurance Company, Oklahoma-based subsidiary of Liberty National Insurance Holding Company, to AyerDirect, the direct response division of N.W. Ayer Inc. for various life insurance plans.

title: EX-CORNELL AGRONOMIST
description: Dr. Richard Bradfield, professor emeritus of agronomy at Cornell University and a research consultant and trustee of the Rockefeller Foundation for many years, died Friday at a hospital in Everett, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: DOW JONES EXPANDS ELECTRONIC CAPABILITY
description: Dow Jones & Company started nearly a century ago by delivering handwritten financial news reports by messenger. It evolved to deliver news via the nation's largest circulation newspaper, The Wall Street Journal.

title: Summer Schedule For Vehicles in Park
description: Summer hours for the closing of Central Park drives to motor traffic take effect today, according to the city's Departments of Traffic and Parks and Recreation.

title: LEGISLATURE TO REVAMP PROPERTY-TAX SYSTEM
description: With 12 days remaining before a self-imposed deadline, the State Legislature is preparing to overhaul New York's property tax system, which was declared illegal by the state's highest court six years ago.

title: Allison, in Buick, Winner By Less Than Car Length
description: Bobby Allison outraced Buddy Baker, Darrell Waltrip and Ricky Rudd today to win the $347,000 Winston 500 Grand National stock car race by less than a car length.

title: 87 Keys' Worth of a Virtuoso Piano Performance
description: When William Carlson, a Canadian composer, dedicated his ''Voices for Piano'' to Natan Brand, an Israeli pianist, he apparently knew what he was doing.

title: Sands Backers March Up 5th Ave.
description: Hundreds of people chanting anti-British slogans marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday to show their support for Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army member who is on a hunger strike.

title: CANDLELIGHT, SONGS AND MEMORIES MARK WARSAW UPRISING SERVICES
description: Light from hundreds of candles flickered on polished mosaic tile as the sounds of the ghetto songs of decades ago echoed in Temple Emanu-El. As they have for 10 years, thousands of Jews and non-Jews gathered yesterday to recall the spirit of the Warsaw ghetto uprising of 1943 and to warn against a repetition of the Holocaust.

title: THEATER: 'MOONY SHAPIRO SONGBOOK'
description: THERE's the germ of a funny, spiffy satirical revue in ''The Moony Shapiro Songbook,'' the forlorn little musical at the Morosco. Monty Norman and Julian More, the show's British authors, are out to mock those proliferating musical anthologies that celebrate the likes of Fats Waller, Stephen Sondheim and Noel Coward. It's a timely premise, and the authors have a clever plan for executing it, too. They've created a fictitious hero who's an amalgam of virtually every songwriter, great and not-so-great, of this century. ''The Moony Shapiro Songbook'' is a ''Side by Side by Shapiro'': five performers take us on a tour of this fellow's anecdote-packed career and sing three dozen of his songs.

title: HAIG INDICATING TALKS THIS YEAR ON EUROPE ARMS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met separately today with all 14 NATO foreign ministers and indicated to some of them that the United States was willing to enter into highlevel talks with the Soviet Union before the end of the year on the reduction of European-based nuclear missiles.

title: ARBOUR AND PATRICK: 2 COACHES PURSUING A CUP FOR NEW YORK
description: As fate would have it, Al Arbour and Craig Patrick walked off side by side, trailing their teams into the Madison Square Garden locker rooms, as midnight approached Saturday.

title: POP SINGER: GARLAND JEFFERYS
description: GARLAND JEFFREYS'S music and his stage personality reflect so many ethnic crosscurrents in street styles that among contempory pop figures he probably comes closer than anyone to embodying the essence of New York street life. Opening a three-night stand at the Ritz on Thursday, Mr. Jeffreys turned in a scintillating performance that had its elements of comedy, in addition to a ferocious drive.

title: ASSAD SAYS ISRAELI IS SEEKING PARTITION OF LEBANON
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today accused Israel and the United States of attempting to establish Israeli ''domination'' over Lebanon and of plotting to partition it.

title: COLLEGE INSTRUCTORS SUSPEND STRIKE IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The unresolved issue of whether part-time teachers should be recognized as members of the faculty union at Community College here is at the heart of a five-week-old strike by college instructors that is due to end tomorrow.

title: GRAIN TO RUSSIA, CHAFF TO
description: AFGHANS To the Editor:

title: CURE THE BLUES, PROUD APPEAL WILL MISS PREAKNESS
description: Cure the Blues and Proud Appeal are out of the Preakness, but the filly Heavenly Cause will probably compete as the Triple Crown series switches to Pimlico in Baltimore May 16.

title: COSMOS 1-0 WINNERS ON A DISPUTED GOAL
description: A disputed goal by Francois Van der Elst gave the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over the Washington Diplomats at Giants Stadium today before a crowd of 34,189.

title: E. German Gymnast European Champion
description: Maxi Gnauck of East Germany dominated the 13th women's European gymnastics championships, winning the European title yesterday and gold medals in the beam, floor and asymetrical bars today.

title: NANCY ELLEN GREEN IS BRIDE OF LAWERNCE SCOTT SCHIEKEN
description: The marriage of Nancy Ellen Green, marketing coordinator of Metcalf & Eddy, evironmental engineers, to Lawrence Scott Schieken, who expects to recieve a medical degree next month from the Universidad Central del Este in San Pedro de Macoris, the Dominican Republic, tool place at the Scarsdale Golf Club in Hartsdale, N.Y., yesterday.

title: Washington Watch; Now U.S. Airlines Want Some Help
description: WASHINGTON AIRLINE representatives are coming to town this week to put before the Reagan Administration evidence of what they say is unfair competition from foreign, government-subsidized carriers.

title: CELTICS BEAT 76ERS, 91-90, GAIN FINAL
description: The Philadelphia 76ers folded for the third straight game today, and it cost them the National Basketball Association Eastern Basketball Association Eastern Conference championship.

title: U.S. ISSUES LEAD LIST
description: The Treasury's $6.75 billion refinancing operation will dominate offerings this week in the credit markets. Following the report late Friday of an unexpected bulge in moneysupply figures for the most recent week, some Government dealers conjectured that the Treasury bond to be sold on Thursday could carry a record-high interest coupon of 14 percent.

title: THE CITY
description: A rookie transit police officer escaped without injury from a knife attack because of the bulletproof vest he wore, the police said.

title: 2 PANDAS UNLIKELY TO GET SECOND MATING CHANCE
description: There were high hopes that Chia-Chia and Ling-Ling would produce a cub in captivity after the two 250-pound giant pandas were placed together in the National Zoo on April 14. But after 90 minutes of swatting and shoving, they were returned to separate cages, unlikely ever to meet again.

title: JAPANESE SET GOALS FOR GENE RESEARCH
description: Late this year, in Kyoto, Japan will sponsor its first major international conference on ''the future of DNA research.'' An hour's ride away on the bullet train, in Osaka, where the idiomatic morning greeting literally means ''Are you making money?'' several Japanese companies are trying to do just that with the field commonly known as gene-splicing.

title: END OF GRAIN CURB WORRIES ARGENTINA
description: It is now autumn in the Southern Hemisphere and Argentine farmers are just completing the largest harvest in their country's history: some 35 million metric tons of corn, wheat and other grains.

title: STAGE: JOSEPH CHALKIN'S 'TOURISTS AND REFUGEES'
description: ''TOURISTS AND REFUGEES No. 2'' is the continuing investigation of the meaning of personal displacement, as conducted by Joseph Chaikin and the Winter Project.

title: MOTHER PLEADS FOR CALM
description: Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army leader who is in the 64th day of a hunger strike, lapsed into a coma today, his supporters said.

title: K.G.B. BLOCKS EVENT MARKING HOLOCAUST
description: The K.G.B. security police have intervened to prevent several hundred Soviet Jews from commemorating the Holocaust today with a traditional gathering in the woods near Moscow, according to organizers of the outing.

title: STARS BEAT FLAMES FOR 2-TO-1 LEAD
description: Steve Christoff's goal early in the third period helped the Minnesota North Stars beat the Calgary Flames, 6-4, tonight. The North Stars now lead their four-of-seven semifinal playoff series, two games to one.

title: HOWARD HALE RENENSLAND MARRIES KATHLEEN J. FORBES
description: At St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University yesterday Kathleen Jeanne Forbes, daughter of Mrs. James Caryl Forbes of Larchmont, N.Y. and the late Mr. Forbes, was married to Howard Hale Renensland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Renensland of Leavenwoth, Kan. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Louis Goia, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Statistical Profiles
description: The PGA Tour came up with an innovative compilation of computer statistics last year, ranking its players in nine categories. But what does it all mean? Consider this year's latest statistics: The putting leader, based on average putts per round, is Bud Allin, who is 63d in money winnings.

title: Johanna Kaplan Wins Award for 'O My America'
description: Johanna Kaplan's ''O My America,'' about the life of a firstgeneration American, has received the $1,000 fiction prize of the second Present Tense magazine literary awards. The awards were made recently in a ceremony at the American Jewish Committee's headquarters in New York.

title: THE MOVIES THAT DRAW HATRED
description: LOS ANGELES AT a Saturday matinee in West Los Angeles, fewer than 100 people dot the 876-seat Bruin Theater. But five of the scattered patrons are angry enough at the movie they are watching - Universal's ''All Night Long'' - to ask for their money back.

title: NEIGHBOR CHARGED IN MURDER OF L.I. MOTHER AND CHILDREN
description: A 23-year-old Long Island man was arraigned today on charges of murdering three of his neighbors, a 34-year-old mother and her two children. Their bodies had been found with more than 240 stab wounds last Friday morning in a second-floor bedroom of their Cape Cod-style home in Hicksville.

title: Turks Seize Alleged Extremists
description: Turkey's military Government took 122,609 suspected extremists into custody between the time it seized power last September and April 10, the newspaper Milliyet reported yesterday. Quoting military sources, the paper said that 40,386 of the suspects were arrested or detained. The military has sought the death penalty for more than 900 people.

title: THE PAINT INDUSTRY HAS LED IN EFFORTS TO CHECK HEALTH HAZARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Keeping a Busy and Lucrative Schedule
description: Former Presidents may miss the power and grandeur of office, but there are certain compensations. In the case of Gerald R. Ford, they amount to about $900,000 a year.

title: THEORY TIES EXODUS FLOOD TO TIDAL WAVE
description: A new interpretation of historical documents by a professor at Johns Hopkins University puts the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt about 200 years earlier than had been previously assumed. And, he links the ''parting of the waves'' that then swallowed the pursuing Egyptians to a powerful tidal wave generated by the same volcanic eruption that apparently wiped out the Minoan civilization.

title: Bridge: Wei Team Wins Knockout After L.I. Play Ends in Tie
description: For the first time in the history of the Long Island Regional Championships, the knockout team final ended in an exact tie. At the end of play in Hempstead, L.I., late Saturday night, a six-deal playoff was required to decide the title.

title: CONFERENCE OF SORTS ON SEX AND LANGUAGE
description: The subject of the conference was sex and language, and Lina Wertmuller, the film director, sat on a vinyl chair and considered the proceedings from behind sleek white glasses. ''You may think that at a conference like this there is very much more language than sex,'' she reflected. ''But you really don't know what is going on all night.''

title: Yamani Sees Unity
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, was quoted yesterday as saying he expects the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on a unified price structure this year. But in an interview with the Beirut English-language weekly Monday Morning, he said he was not hopeful about getting an accord at an OPEC meeting to take place in Geneva at the end of this month. Asked if Saudi Arabia would press for lower uniform oil prices there, Sheikh Yamani said ''That is our hope; however if it doesn't happen in May, it will happen sometime this year.''

title: Geer, DuBois Chosen For Anso Carpet Account
description: After an agency review that reportedly took a couple of months and involved more than 20 agencies, the Allied Corporation's (formerly Allied Chemical) Fibers and Plastics Company has named Geer, DuBois as its agency for the $2 million Anso nylon carpet fibers account.

title: Market Place; Two From One At Engelhard
description: SINCE Wall Street pays more for steady progress than erratic growth, Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation is planning to separate its precious metals and chemical businesses from its trading company.

title: SANDS DIES IN NORTHERN IRELAND JAIL ON THE 66TH DAY OF HUNGER STRIKE
description: Robert Sands, the Irish Republican Army hunger striker and Member of Parliament, died early today on his 66th day without food. He had begun his fast in an effort to force the British Government to recognize I.R.A. inmates as political prisoners rather than common criminals.

title: Advertising; Premium Incentive Exhibition
description: REPRESENTATIVES from big companies, such as the RCA Corporation, which would like to get its electronic entertainment equipment used as incentive material for a dealer organization, to small operations, such as Sinrod Studios, a one-man show that would be pleased to put a company's logo onto stained glass, jammed into the New York Coliseum yesterday for the start of the 43d annual four-day Premium Incentive Show.

title: Company News; G.M. Introduces A New Chevrolet
description: The General Motors Corporation introduced its new Chevrolet Cavalier and inaugurated a marketing technique that has been highly successful for foreign auto makers.

title: Market Place; Analysts Assess Phillips Oil Find
description: THE Phillips Petroleum Company has soft-pedaled the extent of its oil discovery off the Ivory Coast, but Wall Street is betting that the find could be one of the most significant in recent decades.

title: Carlton Wins 5th Straight
description: Steve Carlton pitched his fifth consecutive victory, scored a run and batted in the deciding run tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies won their third straight game, beating the San Francisco Giants, 6-4.

title: NEWS AS ROUTINELY RECONSTITUTED REALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Loans Set By World Bank
description: The World Bank today approved loans of $37 million to Jamaica, $30 million to Paraguay and $3.7 million to Nicaragua.

title: SANDS SPENT THIRD OF HIS LIFE IN PRISON
description: Robert Sands, the imprisoned I.R.A. guerrilla who died this morning on the 66th day of a hunger strike, was catapulted only recently to the status of hero for those seeking unification of Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic.

description: A variety of services is available to crime victims, including counseling, relocation and low-interest loans, under a New York City program begun in 1978.

U.S. Ship Saves 55 Vietnamese
description: A United States Navy vessel reached Hong Kong today with 55 Vietnamese refugees it rescued from boats in the South China Sea. A government spokesman said that the U.S.S. Hepburn picked up 33 refugees off Thailand last week and 22 near Hong Kong yesterday.

title: ZIMMER HOMES CORP reports earnings for 16 weeks to Apr 18
PATTERN OF PROTESTS AND VIOLENCE
description: Dec. 12, 1980 - Six Protestant prisoners in the Maze prison start hunger strike to demand special political status and segregation from I.R.A. prisoners. Dec. 15, 1980 - Twenty-three prisoners join I.R.A. hunger strike. Dec. 16, 1980 - Another Maze prison inmate joins the hunger strike, raising to 40 the number of prisoners fasting in Northern Ireland.Mrs. Thatcher tells Parliament, ''There is no question, now or at all, of giving these hunger strikers political status.'' Dec. 18, 1980 - The seven hunger strikers end 53-day fast after Mr. McKenna is moved to military hospital and given last rites. Dec. 19, 1980 - The other Catholic prisoners end their hunger strike. Northern Ireland Secretary Humphrey Atkins says Britain did not concede political status but did agree on relaxation of discipline for all prisoners. Jan. 16, 1981 - The civil rights activist Bernadette Devlin McAliskey and husband Michael shot and seriously wounded in an attack on their home. Three men are detained. Jan. 21, 1981 - Three Protestants are charged with Miss Devlin's attempted murder. Norman Stronge, the former speaker of the Northern Ireland Parliament, and his son James are shot and killed in their South Armagh home. I.R.A. claims responsibility. March 1, 1981 - Bobby Sands, serving 14 years at Maze jail for possession of firearms, begins a hunger strike, claiming Britain reneged on concessions made in December. March 15, 1981 - Another Maze prisoner, Frank Hughes, starts a hunger strike. March 22, 1981 - Two more Maze prisoners, Raymond McCreesh and Patsy O'Hara, join hunger strike, raising number to four.

title: Science Library
description: Why Buildings Stand Up: The Strength of Architecture By Mario Salvadori. 311 pages. Illustrated. W.W. Norton & Company, $14.95.

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Apr 30

title: S.I. RAID FAILS IN MURDER INQUIRY
description: Officers armed with shotguns broke down the door of a Staten Island a partment yesterday in an unsuccessful search for a former member of t he Black Liberation Army wanted for the killing of Police Officer J ohn G. Scarangella and the wounding of another officer in Queens in A pril. The resident of the second-floor apartment, at 40 Park Hill Avenue w ere awakened by officers and detectives at 6:30 A.M. yesterday and s aid they knew nothing about the suspect, James Dixon York, according o to the police.

title: Real Depreciation, Real Inflation
description: Official Washington is convinced that a business tax cut is needed to spur industrial investment. But that is only half the battle. As the economists Dale Jorgenson and Peter Navarro point out on the opposite page, President Reagan is backing the flawed ''10-5-3'' accelerated depreciation approach over a more effective alternative. Congress can do better.

description: B-Net income after $80,000 loss from discontinued operations fo qr and $173,000 loss from discontinued operations

description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DOW PLUMMETS BY 16.48 SELL-OFF BROAD; BOND YIELDS AT RECORD LEVELS
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in reaction to sharply rising interest rates, including another jump in the prime rate at several major banks. The main casualties were the blue-chip and technology issues as well as Amax Inc., a producer of nonferrous metals.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Giants today signed nine free agents, including the all-America defensive tackle Jim Burt, at a minicamp at Giants Stadium.

title: April Mortgage Rates Up Again
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board yesterday reported that conventional mortgage rates quoted by major lenders for newly built single-family homes rose in April for the seventh time in the last eight months, but that the increase was half te? size of the previous month.

title: CINCINNATI FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
COMPLAINING CITIZENS TELL IT TO MAYOR FOR FAST RESULTS
description: Hundreds of New Yorkers with complaints about city services - from broken street lights to uncollected garbage to heatless buildings - have found that one of the best ways to get attention from City Hall is to go straight to the Mayor at one of his local ''constituent hours.''

title: The Doctor's World; THE SIMPLEST OF ACCIDENTS PRESENTS COMPLEX QUESTIONS
description: ONE Sunday morning in London, my hosts' 12-year-old daughter tripped, landing on her face as she was leaving church. When I examined her at the scene, there was no external bleeding, but a large egg-sized bump had formed on her forehead from bleeding beneath the skin. Within a few hours, two large black eyes would form after the blood seeped through the loose facial skin and settled around the eye sockets.

title: Pope Names Sainthood Expert
description: Pope John Paul II named Msgr. Antonio Petti today to be Promoter General of the Faith in the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for the Causes of Saints. The Promoter General scrutinizes the background of candidates for sainthood.

title: GIRL, 14, SLAIN IN PARK
description: A 14-year-old girl was stabbed to death by another girl during an argument in a park on the Lower East Side, the police said. They said the girl-Elaine Cheung, of 724 Ocean Avenue, Brooklynwas arguing with several other young girls at about 3:45 P.M. in the Sarah Roosevelt Park, near Chrystie Street, when one of them stabbed her fatally. There was no arrest.

title: DOUBLE JEPORDAY RULE ISEXTENDED BY COURT TO DECISION ON SENTENCING
description: The Supreme Court today for the first time extended the constitutional protection against double jeopardy beyond the question of guilt to the criminal sentence itself.
