description: B-After $367,000 extraordinary charge...C-Including $1,340,686 extraordinary credit

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, MAY 5, 1981; The Economy
description: The discount rate was raised to a record 14 percent from 13 percent. The Federal Reserve, struggling to curb recent sharp rises in the nation's money supply, also raised the surcharge that big banks that borrow frequently at the 12 regional Reserve Banks must pay to 4 percentage points from 3. (Page A1.)

title: PERCY SCRAMBLES TO RESTORE PRESTIGE OF SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, the historically prestigious panel controlled for the first time in more than two decades by Republicans, has been afflicted with ideological divisions, legislative disarray and political floundering.

title: REAGAN TO NOMINATE NEVADA LAWYER TO I.C.C.
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Reese H. Taylor Jr., a lawyer in private practice, to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a seven-year term.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WHY DILLINGHAM SEEKS TO SPIN OFF HAWAII REAL ESTATE
description: For years, the Dillingham Corporation has been known as the owner of one of America's most successful shopping center developments, the Ala Moana Shopping Center in Honolulu.

title: MUSIC: 'ITALIAN ARS NOVA' BY POMERIUM MUSICES
description: THERE is a school of thought that thinks the term ''Ars Nova'' should most properly be applied to French music of the 14th century. But others feel it is a more general term. In any event, the concert of ''The Italian Ars Nova'' presented by Pomerium Musices at the Abraham Goodman House proved a delight that transcended categorical quibbles.

title: BABENCO'S 'PIXOTE' SHOW THE BOYS OF BRAZIL
description: ''PIXOTE,'' the third feature film by the Argentine-born Brazilian director Hector Babenco, is a finely made, uncompromisingly grim movie about the street boys of Sao Paulo, in particular about Pixote - which, according to the program, translates roughly as ''Peewee.''

title: RUSSIAN CRITICIZES REAGAN'S 'ZIGZAG' FOREIGN POLICY
description: Georgi A. Arbatov, the Soviet Union's top expert on the United States, accused the Reagan Administration today of failing to formulate a coherent foreign policy in its first 100 days, and of generating anti-Soviet talk that was ''fraught with danger.''

title: WESTERN EXPERTS SAY SOVIET TROOPS ARE BUILDING RADIO TOWERS IN POLAND
description: Western military sources said today that Soviet troops were active in southeastern Poland and had built important communications facilities there.

title: STAGE: 'CRYSTAL TREE' FEATURES THE MUSIC OF LUTHER HENDERSON
description: TWENTY years ago Duke Ellington was pushing for the production of ''The Crystal Tree,'' a show with book and lyrics by Doris Julian and music by Luther Henderson, because he was so impressed by Mr. Henderson's music, according to Rosetta Lenoire, the artistic director of the AMAS Repertory Theater, which after two decades has given the musical a production at its theater at Fifth Avenue and East 104th Street.

title: EMPIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AMBASSADOR GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Net Up
description: Ogilvy & Mather International had a good first quarter. It reported yesterday that net income rose 74.8 percent, to $2.1 million, from $1.2 million, or 50 cents a share, compared with 29 cents a share. It had revenues of $66.3 million, a 14.7 percent gain over the $57.8 million in the comparable 1980 period.

title: UA-Columbia's Net Down 5.6%
description: UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., the cable television operator facing two attempts to take it over, reported today that its earnings in its second fiscal quarter fell 5.6 percent from the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: Hunter, the College, Honors Hunter, the Writer
description: In 1946 Evan Hunter, just back from World War II destroyer service in the Pacific, was among the veterans who were the first men ever admitted to Hunter College. Last weekend the novelist became the first man in Hunter's 111-year history to receive its annual Professional Achievement Award.

title: HOUSING OFFICER KILLED IN BRONX BY HOLDUP MEN
description: An off-duty Housing Authority police lieutenant was shot and killed early yesterday when three men attempted to hold up a Bronx tavern.

title: Horton Signs P.C.L. Pact; Tiant Passed Up in Recall
description: Willie Horton, the former major league slugger, signed a one-year contract today with the Portland Beavers of the Pacific Coast League, the Pittsburgh Pirates' Triple A farm club.

title: Business People; Posner Critical of Image
description: Victor Posner, the 61-year-old controversial entrepreneur whose name has long been identified with corporate takeover efforts, says that this public image is inaccurate. ''We have positions in 40 or 50 companies,'' he asserted yesterday in a telephone interview.

title: Union Leader in Bermuda Calls for a General Strike
description: The president of the Bermuda Industrial Union today recommended a general strike by workers unless the island's labor disputes were settled by tonight.

title: Rabbi Joseph Hager, 81, Of Wall St. Synagogue
description: Rabbi Joseph Hager, founder and senior rabbi of the Wall Street Synagogue, died Saturday. He was 81 years old. Rabbi Hager, who served the Orthodox congregation for more than 50 years, was born in Rumania.

title: SOUTHERN MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A WORD FROM THE SPONSOR; Paying for Public TV
description: If there were as much money around for public television as ideas for how to get it, no TV auctions would be necessary. Some people propose license fees on commercial broadcasters.

title: Science Watch; How Expectations Affect Pay
description: What an person expects to be paid can affect how much he or she is paid, according to Brenda Major, assistant professor of psychology at the State University of New York at Buffalo.

title: SEX AND LANGUAGE: MEETING DEFIES MEANING
description: ''A group is subject to the truly magical power of words'' - Sigmund Freud, ''Group Psychology and the Analysis of the Ego.'' By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN

title: Company News; Noranda Estimates Size of Alaska Claim
description: Noranda Mines Ltd.'s Green Creek claim contains three million to four million tons of high-grade silver, zinc and lead ore, plus slight amounts of gold and copper, Paul Glavinovich, exploration manager, said.

title: DENISON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company Earnings; COCA-COLA UP 8.7%; UNITED BRANDS DOWN
description: The Coca-Cola Company, the nation's principal producer of soft drinks, reported yesterday that higher prices for its products helped raise its earnings in the first quarter by 8.7 percent as sales increased by 14.5 percent.

title: GEOKINETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NATIONAL OLD LINE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
'Moony Shapiro Songbook' Closes After First Night
description: ''The Moony Shapiro Songbook,'' the musical that opened Sunday night at the Morosco Theater, closed the same night.

title: A Memorable Memorial Day Concert
description: In his first United States performance since defecting from the Soviet Union last month, Maxim Shostakovich will conduct the National Symphony in its Memorial Day concert on the Capitol grounds. The announcement was made in Washington Sunday night at a dinner in the Capitol's Statuary Hall, where a $50,000 gift from the host, Armand Hammer, to the financially beleaguered symphony was announced by its musical director, Mstislav Rostropovich.

title: Progress Reported On Subway Noise
description: Subway noise has declined significantly after five years of a subway noise reduction program financed principally by the Federal Government, according to the Natural Resourcess Defense Council, a public interest organization.

title: 'STIR CRAZY' GROSSES $100 MILLION AT THE BOX OFFICE
description: This week ''Stir Crazy'' became the third movie in the history of Columbia Pictures to gross more than $100 million at American and Canadian box offices. The Richard Pryor-Gene Wilder comedy, which opened at Christmas, is playing at 700 theaters.

title: SOUTHERN DEMOCRATS DISCOVER NEW STRENGTH IN UNION WITH G.O.P.
description: Representative Kent Hance, who comes from a family of conservative West Texas Democrats, represents the oil, cattle and grain-growing country around Lubbock that has always sent Democrats to Congress but has gone Republican in every Presidential election since 1952 except one.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why don't we take the salt out of ocean water to help the water shortage?

title: HAWAIIAN AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after $1,815,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: A New Chairman At Castle & Cooke
description: Henry B. Clark Jr., 65 years old, has been elected chairman of Castle & Cooke, the distributor of Dole, Bumble Bee and a wide variety of other products. Formerly vice chairman, he succeeds Malcolm MacNaughton, 71, who retired and was appointed chairman of the executive committee of the Honolulu-based company.

title: POLETOWN VIGIL FAILS TO STOP BULLDOZERS
description: Work began on the new $600 million General Motors plant in the Poletown area today while Ralph Nader's volunteers, seeking to prevent the bulldozing of hundreds of houses, continued their lonely fight to check the project.

title: SUPPORTERS OF DISCLOSURE ACT SEE THREAT IN U.S. SHIFT ON LA
description: WSUITS By PHILIP TAUBMAN

title: U.S. MAY CUT ITS CURRENCY ROLE
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, said today that the Administration was considering cutting back both on the Government's foreign currency holdings and short-term borrowing arrangements with foreign countries as part of a new policy of limiting intervention in currency markets.

title: Troops Dislodge Rightists At U.S. Refinery in Bolivia
description: Bolivian troops took control of an oil refinery owned by a United States company tonight that had been occupied for 72 hours by right-wing gunmen who were demanding the resignation of Bolivia's President, Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, military sources said.

title: WHEN A LAWYER MISAPPROPIATES THE FUNDS AS A CLIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Deadly Verdict on Laetrile
description: The scientific study designed to determine, once and for all, whether laetrile has any value as an anti-cancer drug has now reported its first conclusion: it's worthless. Of 156 cancer patients who were given this apricot-pit derivative, 104 have died and all the rest are in declining health. A few did show temporary improvement or felt better briefly. But none avoided deterioration for long. ''Laetrile has been tested,'' says Dr. Charles Moertel of the Mayo Clinic. ''It is not effective.''

title: Clippers Sold to a Lawyer
description: The struggling San Diego Clippers have been sold to Donald T. Sterling, a Los Angeles lawyer who said today that he was ''prepared to pay whatever it costs'' to make the team a winner.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ENVIROTECH'S SUDDEN STUMBLE
description: The Envirotech Corporation, a pollution control equipment manufacturer that grew rich on the environmental fervor of the 1970's, finds itself facing a huge debt, slow sales and heavy losses.

title: By Ann Crittenden
description: Talking Businesswith Thomas N. Urban of Pioneer Hi-Bred Gene-Splicing And Agriculture

title: GEICO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Witness in Tennessee Trial Admits Lying 51 Times
description: The Government's primary witness in the trial of former Gov. Ray Blanton conceded today that he had lied 51 times when first questioned by Internal Revenue Service agents.

title: Royals' Leonard, White And Brewers' Fingers Sign
description: Three of the American League's top players, Dennis Leonard and Frank White of the Kansas City Royals and Rollie Fingers of the Milwaukee Brewers, reached lucrative agreements with their clubs yesterday.

title: Reporter's Notebook; AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS- JOLLY, IN A SEDATE WAY
description: THE second annual American Book Awards went off with few hitches last week, and without any of the fireworks that accompanied last year's protest by authors and publishers that the ceremony was undignified because it too closely resembled the Oscar and Emmmy awards.

title: POSTAGE FOR TAX REFUNDS RUNS OUT AS STATE BUDGET TIE-UP CONTINUES
description: The State Department of Taxation and Finance said today that it had run out of postage money to mail out tax refunds because of the deadlock over the 1981-82 state budget. But a spokesman, Karen McCarthy Townsend, said the department was optimistic that money for mailing the refunds could be found in funds designated for other uses.

title: Boeing Net Up By 3.1% in Quarter
description: The Boeing Company, the country's leading manufacturer of commercial jets, announced yesterday that its net income in the first three months of 1981 edged up 3.1 percent, to $144.1 million, or $1.49 a share, from $139.8 million, or $1.45 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Sales increased 12.6 percent, to $2.42 billion, from $2.15 billion.

title: Sharon Steel Sells Its Foremost Stake
description: Victor Posner, the chairman of the Sharon Steel Corporation, announced yesterday that Sharon Steel had sold its entire stake of 1.5 million shares of Foremost-McKesson Inc. to Foremost-McKesson for $65.1 million, or $42 a share.

title: CONRAIL DEFICIT NARROWS TO $65.9 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation reported yesterday that it had a first-quarter loss of $65.9 million, the federally owned company's smallest deficit for the quarter since it was created in 1976 out of the ashes of the bankrupt Penn Central and six other railroads. The loss came on revenue of $1.06 billion, compared with $1.02 billion in the quarter a year earlier when the company lost $95.4 million.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS FEAR ISRAEL-SYRIA CLASH
description: Reagan Administration officials expressed concern today that Israel and Syria were moving toward a new confrontation over Lebanon that neither probably wants but that they may not be able to avoid without appearing to give in to each other.

title: JEFFERSON NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $638,000 loss from discontinued operationa and $168,000 realized capital loss C-Including $49,000 gain from discontinued operations and $72,000 ealize $72,000 realized capital gain

title: MOTHER OF 8 IS NAMED 1981'S BEST
description: A 61-year-old Kansas woman who was widowed twice by the age of 25 and who went on to marry for a third time and raise eight children was named the 1981 Mother of the Year yesterday.

title: INTERCRAFT INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
Bridge: Swiss Team Results on L.I.  Appear to Have Run Gamut
description: At any level of tournament play, Swiss team events, in which squads with similar scores are matched against one another after each round, close finishes are normal. An extreme exception to this and an extreme example of the norm occurred Sunday in the Long Island Regionals in Hempstead.

title: Company News; U.S. Steel Planning $1.1 Billion Outlay
description: The United States Steel Corporation's 1981 capital spending will be almost $1.1 billion, compared with about $800 million in 1980, David Roderick, the chairman, said.

title: LOOKING UP TO U.S. FASHION
description: Calvin Klein presented a dazzling collection of easy, fluid clothes that is certain to affect the course of fashion in this country and abroad. Geoffrey Beene changed his direction with a phantasmagoric mixture of fabrics and textures that evoked far-off places, interpreted for modern women. Perry Ellis developed, with his usual wit, clothes for fashion individualists.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 5, 1981
description: International Syria resisted diplomatic pressure to withdraw antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon. Informed sources in Beirut said that Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel had warned American and Soviet intermediaries that Israel would open fire on the missiles if they were not removed by a specific deadline. (Page A1, Column 6.) Robert Sands died in a Belfast prison after a 66-day hunger strike. The Irish Republican Army prisoner and Member of Parliament had fasted in an effort to force the British Government to recognize I.R.A. inmates as political prisoners rather than common criminals. (A1:3-4.)

title: Amax Stock Sinks After Socal Move
description: Amax Inc. stock plummeted in value yesterday in the wake of the withdrawal by the Standard Oil Company of California of a $4.3 billion takeover offer that could have been the largest acquisition in American corporate history.

title: INSECT-BORNE DISEASES MOVE EAST
description: SEVERAL potentially fatal insect-borne diseases that are normally prevalent only in Middle Western states or foreign countries are invading the Northeastern United States, scientists have reported. Although there has been only one death and relatively few other serious consequences so far, specialists say the establishment of the diseases in the Eastern environment poses possible dangers for the future.

title: EVERYDAY USE OF FOREIGN LANGUAGES IS RISING IN U.S.
description: In the United States, where English has long been the language of government and everyday affairs, the use of foreign tongues is becoming more and more common.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $5.9 million charge from the writeoff of motor carrier operating rights...C-Net income including $1.8 million gain from an insurance settlement

title: ARMY UNDER SECRETARY WAS A BOSTON LAWYER
description: Thaddeus R. Beal, a lawyer who served as Under Secretary of the Army in President Richard M. Nixon's first term, died last Saturday while riding his bicycle in Lyme, N.H., where he had lived for the last five years. He was 64 years old.

title: ELECTRO-BIOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AMICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $203,000 gain from the sale of the company's investm in Romicon Inc

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $803,000 foreign currency translation gain and $110,000 extraordinary tax credit from foreign subsidiaries... C-After $169,000 foreign currency translation loss

title: BOEING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER. By Italo Calvino. Translated from the Italian by William Weaver. 260 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: Science Library
description: Jungles Edited by Edward S. Ayensu. 200 pages. Crown Publishers Inc. New York. $35.

title: Carr Plays Vital Role for Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics' dressing room was nearly empty Sunday. Larry Bird had just finished a long shower and M.L. Carr stood in front of the mirror tying his tie.

title: Court Maintains Antitrust Stand
description: The Supreme Court yesterday refused without comment to reconsider its long-held position that Federal antitrust laws do not apply to major league baseball.

title: BRADY HAS SURGERY BECAUSE OF BLOD CLOTS IN LUNG
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, underwent two hours of surgery tonight after blood clots were discovered in his right lung, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Man Sentenced in Carter Threat
description: An inmate at the Kansas state prison was sentenced to three years in Federal prison today for threatening the life of former President Carter. Kenneth Harold Smith, 30 years old, of Manhattan, Kan., was convicted April 8 of sending a letter to Mr. Carter in April 1980 saying he would kill the President if he was not released from prison by 1981.

title: Trial of Ex-Rep. Hinson Put Off
description: The trial of former Representative Jon C. Hinson, Republican of Mississippi, who is charged with attempted sodomy, was rescheduled today for June 1.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Captain of the Islanders
description: OUT on the Madison Square Garden ice Saturday night, the Islanders were about to complete their 5-1 victory. More than half the Rangers' followers had departed in silence, but three Islander loyalists had moved down into the first row of loge seats behind the bench of the defending Stanley Cup champions. One was gloating.

title: U.S. TO PRESS SUZUKI ON DEFENSE
description: President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger plan to tell Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki this week that the United States expects Japan to undertake new responsibilities for the common defense of the Western Pacific, Administration officials said today.

title: THE REGION
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Governor Byrne officially nominated Daniel J. O'Hern to the State Supreme Court yesterday, and within hours, the Senator from Mr. O'Hern's home county dropped his plan to block the nomination.

title: Iran Seeks Kuwaiti Apology Before Freeing Ship It Seized
description: Iran is demanding an official apology from Kuwait before releasing a survey ship owned by a Houston-based company that was seized in the Persian Gulf last week, a senior Iranian official was quoted today as saying.

title: More Auto Dealers Close
description: The recession's toll on new-car dealers continued into the first quarter of 1981 when 221 dealers dropped out of business, Automotive News said today.

title: Chess: Dutch Defense Is Valuable When Risk Is Recognized
description: The Dutch defense has for some time been considered somewhat dubious positionally, but if one wants to risk it in an aggressive attempt to score a victory with Black, one should at least not resort to its most unsavory subvariations.

title: BANK LENDING RATE SET AT RECORD 14% BY FEDERAL RESERVE
description: The Federal Reserve Board, struggling to control the growth of the nation's money supply, today increased its bellwether interest rate on loans to commercial banks to 14 percent from 13 percent, a new high.

title: THAI PREMIER IS SLOW TO CONSOLIDATE HIS POSITION AFTER FENDING OFF COUP
description: The month that began with what is now called the ''April fool's coup'' has elapsed, and the Government of Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda has returned to the state of immobility and internal political bickering that provoked the attempted coup, according to Thais and Asian and Western diplomats.

title: GREAT PERFORMANCES YOU CAN LOOK UP
description: AT a recent Wednesday matinee, ''Amadeus'' was taped in performance, with a minimum of inconvenience to the audience. Two cameras recorded the show ''live'' from the rear of the orchestra, one taking in the full stage in a wide shot, the other being selective and shooting closeups. The aim was to unite all the elements of the production just as it is seen by an audience.

title: AMRITAJ DEFEATS SADRI, 6-4, 6-3
description: Vijay Amritraj, the veteran Davis Cup player from Madras, India, defeated John Sadri, 6-4, 6-3, last night in the Stadium at Forest Hills in the Tournament of Champions.

title: REAGAN WRITES LETTER TO BREZHNEV ABOUT TALKS ON MISSILES FOR EUROPE
description: President Reagan has written to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to inform him that the United States is ready to begin talks this year on limiting middle-range nuclear missiles in Europe, the NATO allies were told today.

title: VAGABOND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RANGERS GOAL: PRESSURE ON SMITH
description: The Rangers plan to avoid elimination from the Stanley Cup semifinals at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night by beating the Islanders with a basic tactic: shooting the puck frequently and from virtually any angle or distance at Billy Smith, the Islanders' goalie.

title: Iraqi Shelling Wounds 22 in Abadan, Iran Says
description: Iran said today that Iraqi artillerymen had shelled Iran's oil-refining city of Abadan, wounding 22 people.

title: Boxing Safety Bill Is Introduced
description: ALBANY May 4 - At the request of Governor Carey, legislation has been introduced that would make ambulances and medical equipment mandatory at professional and amateur boxing matches or exhibitions in the state.

title: Peanut Allotment Vote
description: The House Agriculture Committee today rejected an Administration proposal to eliminate an allotment system that restricts who can grow peanuts and how much can be grown.

title: Business People; A Rail Chief's Benefits
description: Richard M. Bressler, 50, who joined Burlington Northern Inc. as president and chief executive officer last June, was given the right in his employment contract to buy 25,000 shares of company's stock for 10 cents a share, according to the proxy statement for the annual meeting. The stock was worth $40.69 a share at that time and closed yesterday at $62.75.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
MAJOR MAGAZINES LOSING AD PAGES
description: Time magazine is down. Newsweek is down. Reader's Digest is down. TV Guide is down. The New Yorker is down. Woman's Day is down. Business Week is down. Cosmopolitan is down. Sports Illustrated is down. Such is the direction of first-quarter advertising pages for some of America's best-known and sturdiest magazines.

title: THE REGION
description: The Consolidated Edison Company announced that it had run into still another mechanical problem at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, and as a result would not be able to put the plant back in service until the end of May.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baldor Electric Company, Fort Smith, Ark., has named William T. Kirkpatrick executive vice president.

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS' REVISED ETHICS CODE COMES TO GRIP WITH REALITY
description: RECOGNIZING that its code of ethics failed to take into account some current realities, the American Psychological Association has significantly revised the code, which affects some 51,000 psychologists, as well as others working in the field and the nation's psychology students.

title: SYRIA IS RESISTING PRESSURE TO REMOVE MISSILES IN LEBANON
description: Syria reportedly resisted diplomatic pressure to pull its antiaircraft missiles out of Lebanon's Bekaa Valley today, seeming to dare a showdown with Israel.

title: CAMERAS, PROBING WITHIN BRAIN, CAPTURE IMAGES NEW TO SCIENCE
description: THEY look like small raindrops on a strand of spider web, but they are part of a scene from the interior of a monkey brain frozen in an instant of time. Those drop-like structures may be packets of a nerve-signaling chemical moving toward a nerve terminal where they would help a neuron fire and transmit a signal to an adjoining brain cell. This signaling is the common currency of the brain's ceaseless communication with itself, the body it controls and with the outside world.

title: GISCARD AND MITTERRAND ENCORE OF DEBATE TODAY
description: Until now the closest thing to a debate in the French presidential campaign, which is moving toward its conclusion next Sunday, has been a debate about a debate.

title: Bonn Prepares Loan Program
description: West German Government and banking officials this weekend put finishing touches on a program valued at nearly $3 billion to finance low-interest loans to business to offset the dampening effects of high interest rates on industrial investment.

title: Rates Soar on Action by the Fed; 6-Month Bills Yield 15.10%
description: Interest rates soared yesterday as the Federal Reserve continued its efforts to make credit scarce in the banking system and thereby encourage slower growth of the nation's money supply.

title: TERRORISTS IN SPAIN KILL GENERAL AND THREE POLICEMEN
description: Gunmen killed a 62-year-old general in a fashionable Madrid neighborhood today and in Barcelona two Civil Guards were slain while having breakfast in a bar.

title: ASIA BANK PLANS U.S. BID
description: The Asian Development Bank is preparing to return to the United States capital market after a five-year absence. ''In two years, we will need to raise more than $1 billion annually in world capital markets,'' said the bank's president, Taroichi Yoshida, who was in the United States for the bank's 14th annual meeting here. ''As our needs become greater, we cannot neglect the importance of the New York market.''

title: TELEPHONE CALLS BY PRINCE SAID TO HAVE BEEN TAPPED
description: British newspapers reported today that politically embarassing telephone calls made by Prince Charles from Australia were wiretapped.

title: Bill Is Signed to Revise Connecticut Profit Tax
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill grudgingly signed into law today a bill to change provisions of the state's tax on corporate profits, raising the yield to 10 percent from 9.1 percent.

title: BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $280,000 tax credit for the 9 mos

title: Currency Markets; FRENCH FRANC DOWN; ELECTION FEARS CITED
description: The French franc weakened further today and the price of gold in Paris rose well above levels in other countries on fears that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing may lose next Sunday's Presidential election to his Socialist opponent, Francois Mitterrand, who is committed to nationalizing private industry, expanding public works and taxing private wealth.

title: FOR SOME VICTIMS OF CRIMES, THE FEAR NEVER LEAVES
description: Blossom Jackson will never forget that November night when - at 10 minutes to 9 - her sister-in-law pounded on the door of her small Brooklyn house screaming, ''They've killed Jackson.''

title: FIRST WISCONSIN MORTGAGE TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Actor Sounds Warning About Television
description: He could be out of a job if his fans took his advice, but Robert Walden says he wishes people would read more. Mr. Walden, who plays the part of a newspaper reporter, Joe Rossi, on the television series ''Lou Grant,'' said some people took his character a little too seriously.

title: Bus Accident Kills 14 Brazilians
description: A passenger bus left a highway near here and plunged into the Fervedouro River, killing 14 people and injuring 19 today.

title: SWANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd

title: Dierking Worried Over Job
description: Scott Dierking, the Jets' starting halfback since 1977 but also a practical person, has started to imagine what life may be like on the special teams.

title: Education; BLACK ENGLISH DEBATE FADES IN ANN ARBOR WHERE IT BEGAN
description: NEARLY two years after a legal battle over ''black English'' thrust it into the national spotlight, the Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School in Ann Arbor, Mich., has returned to education as usual.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Backstage at Carolina Herrera there was champagne and tears. It was the showing of her first collection of evening clothes at the Metropolitan Club, and Miss Herrera had just returned from the runway with the last model, who wore a silk damask wedding dress with a long train.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HAMMER'S OUTLOOK ON OIL
description: Armand Hammer, chairman and chief executive officer of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, said yesterday that he believes the current oil glut is temporary and that the price of oil could more than triple to $100 a barrel within five years.

title: WHITE HOUSE FAVORS ARMS TO GUATEMALA

title: STAGE: 'ATTEMPT AT FLYING,' FROM BULGARIA VIA YALE REP
description: The stage is levitating at the Yale Repertory Theater, with the American premiere of ''An Attempt at Flying'' by the contemporary Bulgarian playwright Yordan Radichkov. This is a folk fable about dreams blockaded by a repressive society. It is a picaresque comedy - a wild balloon chase - a sardonic political satire and a serious overview of mankind trying to escape from reality. Textually, the many levels are too heavy a cargo for the play to carry. However, as staged by Mladen Kiselov in a setting designed by Michael H. Yeargan, this is, visually and metaphorically, an exhilarating escapade.

And cavil as we will whether or not the Army suffered ''defeat'' in Vietnam, few would insist that we emerged ''victorious.'' What is the situation in the Army today? ''He'll wind up hitting .280 or .290, maybe even .300, for the season. We've all had opportunities to drive in runs. We're all at fault. You can't single out one player. It's not fair to single Maz out. I'm disappointed to hear the fans react the way they do.''

description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan was given a preliminary report today on the collision between an American submarine and a Japanese freighter that said the submarine did not search for survivors because it did not know the ship had sunk, Administration officials said today.

description: Dr. Eugene J. Sheffer, professor emeritus of French and longtime director of the Maison Fran,caise at Columbia University, died yesterday at his West Side home. He was 76 years old.

description: Detroit, May 5 (AP) Chrysler said today that it had asked Japanese partner, the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation, for 67,000 of the 2.6-liter engines that are optional in Chrysler's "K" car series.

title: FILM: 'BLACK AND WHITE'
description: Wolfgang Petersen's ''Black and White Like Day and Night,'' which opens today at the Cinema Studio 2, is a very severe German film about the slide into madness of a chess-playing genius, a man with a mind like some super-computer not yet perfected, and one that goes to permanent pieces when overloaded. Its central role, Thomas Rosenmund, is scrupulously well acted by Bruno Ganz (''The American Friend,'' ''The Left-Handed Woman,'' ''Nosferatu''), a performer whose face, with those unreadable, deep-set eyes, has become the mirror for much of what is most interesting about contemporary German movies.

title: IMMIGRANTS REVITALIZE CITY, BUT STRAIN ITS RESOURCES

title: HENRY RONO QUITS TRACK TO CONCENTRATE ON STUDIES
description: Pullman, Wash.,May 5 (UPI) Henry Rono, among the best distance runners in history, has quit track to concentrate on finishing college, John Chaplin, the Washington State University track coach, announced yesterday. Rono, who is 30 years old and due to graduate this year, had to concentrate on either track or his studies.

title: Company News; Air Florida Cites Rise in Air Traffic
description: Air Florida, which since airline deregulation has expanded its routes in the Northeast and added an overseas route, reported a sharp increase in air traffic for April. System revenue passenger miles, including scheduled and charter flights, totaled 253.5 million in April, more than double the 119 million in April,1980.

title: Economic Scene; Free Traders' Defeat on Cars
description: UNDER heavy pressure from the Reagan Administration, Japan has agreed to impose quotas on its auto shipments to the United States for three years. This was a sharp defeat for the ''free traders'' in the Administration, led by Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, who thought they had already won the internal battle.

title: Company News; Victor Posner Sells Stake in Coachmen
description: Victor Posner divested himself of 453,400 shares of Coachmen Industries common stock, at $9.50 a share, representing all his or his companies' holdings in Coachmen.

title: MUSIC: CARNEGIE HALL'S 90TH BIRTHDAY
description: CARNEGIE HALL'S 90th birthday party Tuesday night was like a lot of successful parties: festive, jammed to the walls with friends and often so noisy that the neighbors must have been rapping on the heating pipes. In commemoration of the grand old structure's opening-night concert on Tuesday, May 5, 1891, Zubin Mehta conducted a program that recreated that historic occasion as nearly as possible. Musically it was a somewhat hollow affair, now as it must have been then, but the celebration was the chief point, and that went off like a firecracker.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IAM frequently fascinated by the various condiments or side dishes that are almost invariably served with one dish or another. In Italy, if you have a bollito misto, you almost always get a small service of mustard fruit on the side, and it is an undeniably great food association. Rarely in France are you served pates, terrines and sliced cold meats, such as salamis, without the pickles known as cornichons - and often mustard - as an accompaniment. In this country, sauerkraut is a perfect liaison for a frankfurter on a bun and cole slaw in many places is the inevitable side dish with hamburgers.

Trailing by 9-0 as they went to bat for the final time, the Mets sent 12 men to the plate. Seven hit safely and seven scored before Greg Minton, with the tying runs on base, got Mike Cubbage on a fly ball to left to end the rally and preserve a 9-7 victory for the San Francisco Giants.

description: The Boston Celtics continued on their dramatic track tonight at Boston Garden. For the fourth straight game, the Celtics shot poorly, fell behind by as many as 14 points late in the first quarter then rallied in the final minutes to win. This time they beat the Houston Rockets, 98-95, in the opener of the National Basketball Association championship round. It was the same pattern they used to defeat the Philadelphia 76ers in the last three games of the Eastern Conference championship.

description: At the trouble spots, gangs of young men, their faces hidden by scarves or ski masks, pelted the police and soldiers with bottles, bricks and fire bombs. The security forces responded by firing plastic bullets, a standard weapon in the long saga that the Irish call ''the troubles.''

description: Marked by youthful violence and dissent, West Berlin's election campaign is moving into its final phase before the voting Sunday, but so far no clear trend has emerged for either of the major contenders.

Yesterday, he discussed some of his immediate intentions at the Westport, Conn., corporation.

title: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS RETAINS ITS CHAIRMAN IN ELECTIONS BY BOARD
description: Jack W. Tarver, publisher of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, was re-elected chairman of the board of The Associated Press today.

title: Advertising; NBC and Mrs. King
description: NBC, which has had Mrs. King on an exclusive network contract for just over a month for expert commentary during tennis coverage, will use her in that capacity during the Wimbledon coverage in July.

description: A United Nations agency that was described in a preliminary inquiry as ''demoralized'' by fraud and favoritism has been cleared of wrongdoing by an aide of Secretary General Kurt Waldheim.

title: BELL SYSTEM SEEKING ALLIANCE WITH PRESS
description: A top officer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company told newspaper publishers here today that the Bell system would welcome them as partners in the development of electronic information services.

title: INDIA WILL NOT BUY WHEAT FROM ABROAD
description: In its eagerness to protect India's newly won image of self-sufficiency in grain, the Government has decided not to purchase wheat from abroad, gambling that a good monsoon and record procurement from Indian farmers will restore depleted Government stocks.

title: Synthetic Fuels Board Selected
description: The Reagan Administration, after a long delay, has picked six men to join Edward E. Noble, the designated chairman, as board members of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, industry and Congressional sources said today.

title: ROBERT MCNEILL JR., 75, EX-CHIEF OF MANUFACTURERS HANOVER TRUST
description: Robert E. McNeill Jr., former chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and its holding company, Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, died Monday at Florida Hospital in Orlando at the age of 75. He lived in Windermere, Fla.

title: Rally Stabilizes Interest Rates; 3-Year Notes Yield 15.81%
description: Despite six weeks of plunging bond prices, investors flocked to the Treasury Department's auction of three-year notes yesterday, attracted by estimates of rates close to 16 percent.

Company News; GOODYEAR TO CLOSE A PLANT IN AKRON
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today that it would close a plant that produces a variety of industrial rubber items here, resulting in the loss of about 500 jobs over the next year.

title: Nat Polen, 66, Portrayed Doctor On ABC-TV's 'One Life to Live'
description: Nat Polen, an actor who played a leading character on ABC-TV's ''One Life to Live'' for more than a decade, died of cancer Sunday in Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in East Norwich, L.I.

title: 'WORKFARE' IN SAN DIEGO COULD BE PREVIEW FOR U.S.
description: Debra Scherer left Peekskill, N.Y., last January, homesick for San Diego and dismayed at her rising fuel bills. Unable to find work as a nursery, or children's, aide in the last three months, Mrs. Scherer recently applied for food stamps and was told that San Diego County required her to take a public-service job for about 20 hours a month in exchange for the assistance.

title: PETROL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
OWNERS FINE EXECUTIVE $50,000
description: Harry Dalton, general manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, has been fined $50,000 by major league baseball's highly secretive disciplinary committee for comments that appeared to be critical of the owners' stand in their dispute with the players union.

description: Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FAST ACTION SEEN BY SENATE PANEL IN WILLIAMS CASE
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics voted unanimously today to investigate the conduct of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., who was convicted last week on nine counts of bribery and conspiracy.

title: NO BIG CHANGES IN PRIORITIES PLANNED IN CITY BUDGET DUE NEXT WEEK
description: Despite continued uncertainty over Federal and state aid, the Koch administration does not plan to make significant changes in its spending priorities in the 1982 budget that it will announce next Tuesday.

title: INTERNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Brewers' Molitor, Injured, To Miss at Least 8 Weeks
description: Paul Molitor, the Milwaukee Brewers' center fielder who injured his ankle in Sunday's game at California, suffered torn ligaments and underwent surgery tonight. He is expected to be sidelined at least eight weeks.

title: MTS SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CITY BALLET: 'IN G MAJOR,' BY ROBBINS
description: THE New York City Ballet seemed to be suffering from opening-week vapors at performances on Saturday afternoon and last Wednesday at the New York State Theater. Still, there were moments of transcending beauty, chiefly in Jerome Robbins's ''In G Major'' on Saturday.

title: SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SUZUKI, IN VISIT, MIXES BUSINESS WITH BUSINESS
description: Since he arrived in New York two days ago, Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan has followed an itinerary befitting the leader of the nation that is increasingly the merchant to the world.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAYS DEATH OF SANDS WON'T ALTER LONDON'S ULSTER POLICY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher served notice in the House of Commons today that Britain would not change its policy on Northern Ireland despite the death of Robert Sands on the 66th day of his hunger strike and the street violence that followed.

title: German Fuel Use Drops
description: West Germany's consumption of refined petroleum fuels dropped an average 11.5 percent in the first quarter of 1981, compared with a year earlier, the Federal Trade Office reported today. The trade office said that first-quarter consumption of light heating oil was off 13.4 percent, heavy heating oil consumption fell 22.6 percent and gasoline use dipped 4.2 percent. Diesel fuel consumption rose 4.1 percent in the first quarter, while the March increase was 14.4 percent, apparently due in part to sales of more diesel-powered autos.

title: INTERPROVINCIAL PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company is also listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock ex

title: WHITE HOUSE BACKS RATE MOVE
description: The Reagan Administration gave enthusiastic support today to the Federal Reserve Board's latest increase in interest rates, with one senior economist, Beryl W. Sprinkel, saying, ''If it leads to short-run problems, it's well worth the price we're paying.''

title: FINDING THE COMPONENTS FOR A KIR
description: AS the wine boom gathers momentum and American consumers increasingly turn away from cocktails at mealtime, they are selecting alternatives that enhance their ability to taste, that complement the foods and wines that will follow. Often their choice is a Kir, the quintessential Burgundian aperitif that has suddenly achieved great popularity on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Brady Described as Alert After a Third Operation
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, was in satisfactory condition today after two and a half hours of surgery to remove blood clots that doctors feared could have reached his heart.

title: Reporter in Cleveland Is Forced To Answer Queries About Article
description: A reporter for The Cleveland Plain Dealer, under orders by a Common Pleas Court judge, was forced to answer questions today regarding an article she wrote about a man who is being tried for murder.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SADAT, IN NEW BUDGET, PLEDGES TO KEEP FOOD SUBDIDIES
description: President Anwar el-Sadat's new budget gives high priority to continue subsidies on basic foods and necessities. Mr. Sadat's new fiscal plan, which is to take effect July 1, increases subsidies on tea, rice, sugar, cooking oil and bread from $2.1 billion to $2.8 billion, a hefty item in an overall budget that totals approximately $14 billion.

title: ISLANDERS WERE THINKING OF '79
description: When it came right down to it, the Islanders kept saying last night after their four-game sweep of the Rangers, '79 was on their mind in every game. They were referring, of course, to two years ago when the Rangers put them out of the playoffs in six games despite their winning the season championship.

Business Digest; WEDNESDAY, MAY 6, 1981; Companies
description: Rail unions joined with Conrail management to forgo about $229 million in wages and benefits a year in an attempt to make the system profitable and to head off Administration threats to sell it. The pact is subject to ratification by union members. (Page A1.)

description: George Katz, manager of Sonny Liston and other professional boxers, died yesterday at Abington Hospital at the age of 76.

description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh came to the rescue of the financially troubled Philadelphia School District today, promising to speed up the schedule of state-aid payments enough to prevent a paralysis of the city's educational system and to allow 13,000 high school seniors to graduate on schedule.

description: A bus and a truck collided in eastern Serbia today, killing 11 people and seriously injuring 10, the official Tanyug press agency reported.

description: Tucked inside a sleek, 15-story modern building here are the offices of 19 investment firms where brokers engaged in the trading of stocks, bonds and commodities have brought a corner of Wall Street to Montgomery Street.

title: Republic Airlines' Deficit Worsens
description: Republic Airlines, a major carrier based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had an operating profit of $5 million in the first quarter, but that large interest expenses left the company with a net loss of $15.2 million. In last year's first quarter, Republic had a net loss of $13.8 million.

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Antitrust Chief Sets Key Shift
description: The nation's new chief antitrust officer says the Justice Department has contributed to a doctrine of foolish fairness that has reduced some consumer prices in the short run but has driven quality and variety out of the American marketplace.

title: If Mrs. Thatcher Were Anwar Sadat
description: By willing his own death, Bobby Sands has earned a place on Ireland's long roll of martyrs and bested an implacable British Prime Minister. It is a bitter and joyless victory, but it was predictable. Despite proximity and a common language, the English have persistently misjudged the depth of Irish nationalism. In 1974, for example, they abandoned force-feeding of hunger-striking prisoners on the theory that defiance was less likely if the prisoners faced certain death.

title: U.S. SAYS OFFICIAL MOVED $60 MILLION 'IMPROPERLY'
description: In what a Government spokesman described as ''the great heist,'' the Treasury Department disclosed today that Carol S. Greenwald, an outspoken consumer advocate named by President Carter in 1979 to head the National Consumer Cooperative Bank, had ''improperly'' drawn $60 million from the Treasury in behalf of the co-op bank and refuses to give it back.

title: Company News; Macmillan in Talks To Sell More Units
description: Macmillan Inc., which reported a first-quarter loss of $1.7 million, is negotiating the sale of two more operating units, including the nationwide Brentano's Inc. bookstore chain, Edward P. Evans, Macmillan chairman, told stockholders.

title: 12 Bodies to Be Exhumed In Coast Inquiry on Deaths
description: The bodies of 12 elderly patients who died suspiciously at one of two rural hospitals under investigation in 26 deaths will be exhumed to determine if the patients were killed by a drug found in three victims, it was disclosed today. Court orders will be obtained to exhume the bodies, including two buried in New Mexico and Minnesota, the authorities said.

title: STORMY LABOR SCENE LAYS WASTE BERMUDA'S SEASON
description: At the Southampton Princess Hotel, the flowers have been taken off the tables, the candles put away, the tablecloths folded and placed in storage. The disco is dark and silent, the swimming pool and tennis courts empty. The $220-a-day rooms with their views of turquoise ocean and pink sands hold no tourists nursing rum punches and sunburns. The carpeted corridors of Bermuda's largest hotel, which had expected to be filled with 1,200 visitors by now, are ghostly and deserted.

title: THE VARIED SURPRISES OF FILIPINO FOOD
description: THE first time I sampled the cooking of the Philippines was more than 30 years ago, during World War II. My ship had docked briefly in Manila Harbor, and I wandered ashore one day and seated myself at a small restaurant with counter service. I sampled an egg roll called lumpia, which was crackling and crisp on the ouside and stuffed with an assortment of good things like shrimp, pork and peanuts.

description: Syria's Foreign Minister today dismissed as ''ridiculous'' Israel's demands that the Syrians remove their SAM-6 antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon.

title: McEnroe, Gerulaitis Lose at Forest Hills
description: For three days the $592,000 Tournament of Champions had been limping along with victories by such obscure tennis players as Larry Stefanki, Angel Giminez, Robbie Venter, Ricardo Cano and Gianni Ocloppo over equally uncelebrated opponents. Yesterday the big names started playing in the 40-man invitation tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, and there were fireworks.

title: McQuilken Retires
description: The Washington Redskins announced the retirement today of Kim McQuilken, their 30-year-old backup quarterback.

description: Evangeline Gouletas-Carey helped her first husband seek a divorce from his first wife and did not ask to have her marriage annulled for nearly two years after she learned of his alleged bigamy, according to court documents and her family lawyer at the time.

title: Democrat Asks a Study Of Political Action Units
description: Charles T. Manatt, the Democratic Party chairman, shared a platform today with his Republican counterpart and urged him to join in an examination of the influence of independent committees that campaign against political candidates with whom they disagree.

title: WEINBERGER TELLS OF NEW CONVENTIONAL-FORCE STRATEGY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger asserted today that ''if we value our freedom, we must be able to defend ourselves in wars of any size and shape and in any region where we have vital interests.''

title: PAUL GREEN, PULITZER PLAYWRIGHT AND DRAMA TEACHER, DIES AT 87
description: Paul Green, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1927 for ''In Abraham's Bosom,'' a drama of black life in his native North Carolina, and who went on to write many notable works for the American theater, died Monday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. The playwright and drama professor, who was named North Carolina's Dramatist Laureate by a resolution of the General Assembly two years ago, was 87 years old.

title: Editors' Group Denounces Rules On Release of Government Files
description: The American Society of Newspaper Editors today denounced new Justice Department guidelines on the release of Government files, calling them injurious to the ''free flow of information.''

title: KOGER PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ADM. RICKOVER PREDICTS GAINS IF NAVY BUILDS SUBS
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the outspoken builder of nuclear warships, today urged Congress to authorize the Navy to build attack submarines itself because he believed private shipyards were uneconomical and inefficient and often harassed the Government with inflated cost claims.

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIA CO. AND ANASTO'S 'DOMINO'
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet, which will perform at the Brooklyn Academy of Music through Sunday afternoon, brings the Academy's first ''Ballet America'' series to a close.

title: Japan-Canada Auto Talks
description: Japan will discuss possible voluntary restraint on car exports to Canada, but it will not accept any retaliatory action by Canada if no agreement is reached, the Japanese Ambassador, Michiaki Suma, said today.

HELMERICH & PAYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Bridge: 2 European Teams to Enter World Championship in Fall
description: The 1981 world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl, scheduled in Port Chester, N.Y., in October, will include two teams from Europe instead of the usual one. This marks a recognition by the World Bridge Federation of the great strength of European bridge.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar
Indonesia Oil Position
description: Indonesia has no intentions of shifting its oil sales from contract deals to a spot market system, Subroto, the Mining and Energy Minister, said today. He said Pertamina, the state-run oil company, would maintain the contract sales system in dealing with its traditional buyers. ''If there is a surplus of production over the contract amount agreement, Pertamina will first of all offer it to its traditional buyers,'' he said.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TOM PETTY: READY TO FIGHT THE GOOD FIGHT
description: RELATIONSHIPS between rock performers and the large corporations that most of them record for are not always cordial, but few rockers have fought as many battles with their record company as Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. The group's album ''Damn the Torpedoes'' was one of the best-selling rock lp's of 1980, but it was released only after a yearlong contractual dispute that at one point found Mr. Petty filing for bankruptcy and ended only after MCA records granted him the right to become the major artist on the smaller, more ''personal'' MCA subsidiary label, Backstreet Records.

title: Company News; DEALERS SPLIT ON JAPAN QUOTA RAMIFICATIONS
description: To say that John Cronin, the sales manager of Free World Foreign Cars Inc., a Datsun franchise in Manhattan, is pleased about the voluntary export quotas on Japanese automobiles is perhaps an understatement.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EVEN if modern technology could cope with such a task, a sciencefiction-sized laboratory with 140 miles of tubing and millions of filter units would be needed to duplicate the remarkable workings of the human kidneys, which weigh only about five ounces apiece.

title: TV: RED ARMY PROFILE
description: IN an unusually heavy evening of special programming, public television is sandwiching a documentary between two dramatized biographies. The documentary runs away easily with the honors.

title: Miami Judge Orders Closing Of a Home for the Elderly
description: A judge today ordered the closing of a boarding home here after a 101-year-old resident charged that the owners locked her in a closet while an inspector checked for alleged overcrowding.

title: British Jury Is Told 'Ripper' Felt He Must Kill Prostitutes
description: England's chief prosecutor told a murder trial at the Old Bailey today that Peter Sutcliffe, the truck driver who has confessed to murdering 13 women, is a paranoid schizophrenic who believed that he was on a divine mission to kill prostitutes.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK RANGERS, 5-2, SWEEP SEMIFINAL SERIES
description: The Islanders advanced to the Stanley Cup finals last night, eliminating the Rangers from the National Hockey League playoffs in four consecutive games by defeating them, 5-2, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Late-April Car Sales Rose 7.6%; Chrysler, Ford Up; G.M. Off
description: The Big Three domestic auto makers reported today that their new-car sales rose 7.6 percent in the last 10 days of April on the strength of a 69.5 percent gain at the Chrysler Corporation and a 19.9 percent rise at the Ford Motor Company. The General Motors Corporation, the largest of the domestic producers, reported a 4.7 percent decline.

title: Canadian Trade Surplus
description: Canada reported a seasonally adjusted trade surplus of $512 million (Canadian) in March, compared with a revised February surplus of $461 million, Statistics Canada said today. March was the 11th consecutive month that Canada's merchandise exports substantially exceeded imports.

title: PAPP AND PRESSMAN TO FILM 'PIRATES'
description: Although Joseph Papp said last December that he would make a film of the Shakespeare Festival's ''The Pirates of Penzance'' in collaboration with Francis Coppola at Mr. Coppola's studio in California, Mr. Papp announced yesterday that he had sold film rights to Edward R. Pressman Productions Inc. for $1.5 million. The movie will be made in England.

title: Firing Squad Executes 7 in Iran
description: A firing squad in the western Iranian city of Tabriz today executed seven men who were convicted by an Islamic court of sex and drug offenses, according to Teheran radio. The latest executions brought to 16 the number of persons, including two women, executed in various Iranian cities in the last 10 days.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: Four gunmen shot two people and beat a third during a robbery of 40 patrons at the Tap A Keg bar on Columbus Avenue at 75th Street. The victims - Patricia Read, 23, and Melvyn Young, 36, who were shot, and Peter Johnson, who was hit on the head with a gun - were reported in stable condition. ... A 36-year-old man whom the police suspect of being a drug dealer was found strangled in his apartment at 70-25 Yellowstone Boulevard in Forest Hills, Queens, apparently the victim of intruders who were admitted over the weekend. He was identified as Arnold Kaufman. ... The body of an unidentified man was found in the trunk of a car on Patterson Avenue in a residential neighborhood in the Midland Beach section of Staten Island.

title: G.O.P. MODERATES GETTING PRESSURE FROM WHITE HOUSE ON BUDGET VOTE
description: Last Friday, Representative Claudine Schneider went to the White House and told President Reagan that his budget would spend too much money on the military and not enough on the social programs that are vital to her Rhode Island district. When she emerged from the meeting, she said that she was still undecided about supporting the President and then flew home for the weekend.

title: MASSACHUSETTS EDUCATOR IS CHOSEN TO BE NEW HEAD OF TESTING SERVICE
description: Gregory R. Anrig, the Massachusetts Commissioner of Education and a proponent of ''truth in testing'' legislation, has been named the next president of the Educational Testing Service.

title: DR. RUSK'S APPROACH TO WORLD PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONRAIL UNIONS AGREE TO WAGE CONCESSIONS IN BID TO STOP ITS SALE
description: Conrail's management and leaders of its 14 unions joined today in an agreement to forgo about $229 million a year in wages and benefits in an effort to make the rail system profitable and head off threats by the Reagan Administration to break it up and sell it. The total Conrail payroll is currently about $1 billion a year.

title: WATER RATIONING TO START IN FLORIDA AS DROUGHT PERSISTS
description: A drought that has filled the air with haze from the burning Everglades and drained small lakes into puddles has now brought water rationing to the 3.5 million residents of eight south Florida counties.

title: BAYLOR HELPS ANGELS DEFEAT YANKEES, 6-2
description: Don Baylor, the American League's leading run producer in 1979, drove in three runs for California tonight as the Angels pieced together a 6-2 victory over the Yankees with 11 hits, nine of them singles.

title: SOVIET ENGLISH CLUBS CHOSEN
description: Southampton of England and Donetsk Shakhtyor of the Soviet Union have been chosen to join the Cosmos and the Seattle Sounders in the second annual Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup, the North American Soccer League announced yesterday. But there is some question as to whether the tournament, an N.A.S.L.-sponsored round-robin event to be played at Giants Stadium and in Seattle this summer, will take place.

description: To the Editor:

DOME BIDS FOR SHARES OF CONOCCO
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., a major Canadian oil and gas producer, announced last night that it would seek 14 million shares of Conoco Inc. for about $910 million and then trade some of them for Conoco's 52.9 percent holding in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company.

title: City U. Plans a Review of Athletic Policies
description: The City University of New York is expected to begin soon a review of its athletic policies following an announcement in March by Brooklyn College that it was planning to change its National Collegiate Athletic Association status from Division III to Division I.

title: Jani Becomes Producer Of Music Hall Productions
description: Robert F. Jani, president of Radio City Music Hall Productions, has given up his post and become executive producer for the shows at the Radio City Music Hall Entertainment Center.

title: LE CROSSIANT GOES AMERICAN
description: THE French seem to be paying us back for spreading American fast food across Europe. Two croissanteries, forerunners of chains, have opened in New York in the last month, and another is scheduled to open imminently. Within the next few months, more will be opening throughout Manhattan, part of a boom in croissant parlors across the country that hope to offer serious competition to such fast-food concerns as McDonald's or Burger King.

title: CHARLES S. ROBERTSON, EX-INVESTMENT BANKER AND A PHILANTHROPIST
description: Charles Sammis Robertson, a philanthropist and former investment banker in New York, died Saturday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old.

title: Austrians Leave for Saudi Talks
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, accompanied by an economic delegation, left today for an official visit to Saudi Arabia. Mr. Kreisky's party included representatives of two arms manufacturers, a steel producer and three leading banks.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Reported Prepared To Try Again on Detente
description: The chief United States delegate to the European Security Conference said today that the United States was ready to try one last time to reach agreement with the Soviet Union on human rights and detente.

title: REPUBLICANS IN STATE SENATE SUBMIT NEW SPENDING PLAN WITHOUT 'PORK'
description: The Senate Republicans today proposed to sweep aside all negotiations to date on the long overdue state budget and presented a new plan. It was devoid of nearly every spending program the Assembly Democrats had worked out with Governor Carey and to which Senator Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader, had previously agreed.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Guatemala yester- day incorrectly described the back- ground of Don McKinna, a Roman Catholic missionary who was reported to have joined guerrillas there. He is not affiliated with any order.

title: 'Yes, But' to Reaganomics
description: All the White House pressure notwithstanding, the final House vote on a budget resolution this week is not a vote of confidence in President Reagan's economic strategy. The choice is between two declarations that would have an almost identical effect on fiscal policy next year.

title: THE U.S.-JAPAN 'PIE'
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki's predecessor, Masayoshi Ohira, coined the phrase ''productive partnership'' to define the relationship between Japan and the United States. Mr. Suzuki's current visit to this country, and the agreement last week to restrict Japan's automobile exports to the United States, provide an appropriate opportunity to consider the questions: productive of what? for whom?

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: 1889'') has learned that there is this problem with being a writer in New York. ''You're constantly being asked what you're working on,'' he says, ''when a serious artist doesn't always know.''

description: Yr-ago restated for the June 1980 sale of Dunning Industries

title: The End Of the Rainbow
description: After 40 years in Washington, it is said that a man either goes crazy or goes fishing, and in the spring, an old man's fancy turns to fish. But where to go? Where is that rainbow trout at the end of the rainbow?

title: HOP-IN FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Home Beat; HEARTS, FLOWERS AND LOTS OF THRILLS
description: PINK and gray, and lots of hearts and flowers and frills. Frills on the bed, on the chair, on the curtains, on the dozens of pillows, even on the plates.

title: BILL WOULD PROHIBIT QUOTAS FOR HIRING
description: Saying it was a response to President Reagan's wishes, Representative Robert S. Walker, Republican of Pennsylvania, today introduced legislation that would bar the use of numerical quotas to increase the hiring or school enrollment of women and members of minority groups.

title: BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Notes on People; Alberta Hunter Honored
description: The Smith College Black Students Alliance had invited Alberta Hunter to accept the honor in person at their Black Arts Festival in March.

title: CINCINNATI GETTING SOPHISTICATED 2-WAY CABLE TV
description: The most advanced two-way cable-television system in the country will be introduced to this Cincinnati suburb tomorrow. Warner-Amex Cable Communications will activate a 60-channel service that will permit subscribers to express opinions, play games, shop at home, take courses and purchase movies on a per-view basis.

title: AUTODYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
THE QUIET KENNEDY SPEAKS UP
description: ''IDON'T know why people always think of the Kennedys as a Boston family,'' said Jean Kennedy Smith, sitting on her New York patio. It was the most glorious spring afternoon New York has seen this year. New York sparrows were chirping in the oak branches above, New York traffic hummed in the distance, and Mrs. Smith was there to talk about the two-day arts festival she'd helped bring to New York.

title: COLUMBIA PICTURES INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-After a gain of $4,017,000 from the sale of the company's record operations

title: 60 HURT AS S.I. FERRY AND A FREIGHTER COLLIDE
description: A Norwegian freighter and a Staten Island ferryboat bound for Manhattan carrying 2,340 passengers collided in dense fog yesterday morning, injuring more than 60 of the ferry's passengers and causing hundreds of others to scramble for life preservers.

title: KOCH ADMINISTRATION TO RAISE ITS OUTLAY ON PUBLIC-SERVICE JOBS IN FACE OF REAGAN CUTBACKS
description: The Koch administration plans a sharp increase in its spending on public-service jobs in New York City to pick up the slack created by President Reagan's call for the elimination of such positions under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: Moscow's Syrian Probe
description: A Soviet client state, on unfriendly terms with most of the Arab world and militarily weaker than Israel, is inviting war in the Middle East. Why?

title: WESTWAY PROPONENTS' DISTORTED VIEW OF THE 'TRADE-IN' ALTERNATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Automatic Data Processing Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 2 million post-split shares of its common stock, to be sold through a Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb group.

title: News of Music; REFORM SOUGHT IN WAY ORCHESTRAS AUDITION
description: THOUSANDS of young musicians audition every year for orchestral positions all over the country, and the entire procedure, according to Gunther Schuller, is a tremendous financial burden on young players, an inefficient barometer of their real talents and desperately in need of reform. Mr. Schuller has viewed the situation for many years from several perspectives, as an orchestral player, composer and former president of the New England Conservatory of Music. He is taking steps to improve matters by founding the International Video Audition Service Inc.

title: Deltona Net Up 60%
description: The Deltona Corporation, a land and housing developer, said first-quarter profits rose 60 percent, to $1.44 million, or 36 cents a share, from $901,000, or 23 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1980. The company said sales climbed 82 percent in the period, to $66.1 million, from $36.3 million. The company said land sales rose 12 percent while housing revenues more than tripled.

title: Around the Nation; Boston Council Approves Rehiring of Police Officers
description: City leaders tonight gave final approval to the rehiring of 400 police officers and firefighters and the reopening of neighborhood stations shut down in a budget crisis that still threatens the city.

title: REAGAN NAMES TASK FORCE TO STUDY NEW FORM FOR ENDOWMENT
description: President Reagan today announced the creation of a task force to study the possibility of converting the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities from Government agencies into ''public corporations.''

title: Sheep May Get Lonely
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Using sheep to keep your grass short is being done in Europe (''Tired of Lawn Mowing? Rent a Sheep, Only $35,'' April 23), and it is a much more serene way to do the work than with those deafening lawn mowers.

title: NEW YORK AND 3 NEARBY STATES COOL TO CONRAIL ROLE
description: Transit officials from New York and three other states served by Conrail said yesterday that they would refuse to run the line's troubled commuter operations under Federal labor laws, as has been proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: VIRGINIA FELLER
description: Virginia Feller, former wife of the Cleveland Indians pitcher Bob Feller, was found dead in her suburban Cleveland home. She was 62 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BankAmerica Corporation, San Francisco, announced that Robert G. Wade Jr. was joining it as senior vice president in charge of fiduciary investment management activities.

title: A Nuclear D-Day in Congress
description: If the Clinch River nuclear breeder reactor is ever to be stopped, it will have to be now.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Topics; LOOKING BACKWARD; Rear View
description: Those who think that the 80's will be a replay of the 50's have not reckoned adequately with automobiles. Cars were at the heart of the 50's culture and most people liked to flaunt their finned fantasies.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. said a molybdenum mine in British Columbia had been given tentative clearance by a Canadian Government-appointed scientific panel, despite strong opposition from environmentalists.

title: Worker Is Killed at Shuttle Site
description: A construction worker plunged to his death yesterday while working on the metal framework of the service structure for next September's scheduled second launching of the space shuttle Columbia. The worker was identified by the Brevard County authorities as Anthony E. Hill, 22 years old, of Rockledge, Fla.

title: Around the Nation; 4 Workers Badly Burned In Blast at Virginia Plant
description: An explosion ripped the roof off a building at the Radford Army Ammunition Plant today and four workers were severely burned.

title: No Headline
description: Cedric Maxwell of the Boston Celtics, who charged into the stands to fight a fan during the sixth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference final round, in Philadelphia against the 76ers, was fined $2,500 by the league Wednesday.

title: The Talk of The Falklands
description: These islands are a desolate place. There are no trees. The sky is gray two-thirds of the daylight hours. It can snow and hail any month of the year, and the wind blows almost perpetually, strong and biting.

title: Winners Focusing On McEnroe's Loss
description: The tennis player who commanded the greatest attention yesterday at the $592,000 Tournament of Champions was there only to play doubles at night.

title: TAX SAVING SEEN KEY TO DOME'S BID
description: An offer by Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada to pay $915 million for a minority stake in Conoco Inc. was made, without prior consultation with Conoco, as a way to avoid payment of capital gains taxes, insiders said yesterday.

title: When Politicians Fail
description: A common complaint by neo-conservatives is that ''activist judges'' nowadays interfere in matters better left to political decision. There is particular criticism of court orders requiring state financial action, for example, to relieve bestial conditions in mental hopitals and other institutions.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Parade magazine is trimming its length approximately 3/4 of an inch effective with the Jan. 3 issue.
