description: B-After capital gains of $23,000 and $25,000 in latest qr and yr-ago period, respectively, and tax credits of $1,405,000 and $510,000 in latest qr and yr-ago period respectively; the 1981 figures include the results of the Republic National Life Insur Co acquired Mar 1981

title: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company News; Bank Offering London Accounts
description: In a move to offer consumers high interest rates on their checking accounts, the Bank of California announced yesterday that it would open dollar checking accounts at its London branch for residents of the United States.

title: FRANK FITZSIMMONS OF TEAMSTERS DIES
description: Frank E. Fitzsimmons, a trusted deputy who became president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters when James R. Hoffa went to prison, died of cancer today in a San Diego hospital.

title: Dow Ends 6-Day Drop, Barely; Energy Issues Show Strength
description: Energy issues led the stock market slightly higher yesterday, following a sharp drop in the six previous sessions. The earlier pullback resulted from an abrupt tightening of credit conditions by the Federal Reserve in its effort to slow money-supply growth.

title: COMMITTEES SETTLING ON REAGAN CUTS IN FOOD STAMPS
description: Committees on both sides of the Capitol wrestled with the food stamp program today, and after hours of argument and negotiation a consensus began to emerge behind the cutbacks proposed by the Reagan Administration.

title: Phelps Dodge Sees No Move by a Bidder
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, one of the nation's leading copper producers, has not been approached by any other company interested in a merger or takeover, the company's chairman, George Munroe, told shareholders at the annual meeting in New York yesterday.

title: Passion for Survival
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The beaten woman said to have a ''passion for punishment'' (''Of Stoops and Steps, Salons of the Street,'' April 23) more probably had a passion for survival. Options for battered women are few, if any. To admit to police at your door your husband is beating you is to ask for a more severe beating once the police have ''calmed him down'' and gone on their way. CAROL ANNE CRYSTAL

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company News; Federal Paper Stake
description: The Reliance Financial Services Corporation said it had increased its stake in the Federal Paper Board Company to 1,758,800 shares, or 23.5 percent. In a 13-D filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Reliance said its purchases were for investment, but that it intended to acquire more than 25 percent of Federal Paper's stock. Reliance said it had purchased 69,000 shares of Federal Paper in April at an aggregate purchase price of $2,553,411.

title: HUNDREDS FLEE FLOOD IN ALABAMA
description: After a long night in the city auditorium, the lobby of the Hilton Hotel or a friend's spare room, hundreds of evacuated residents mopped out their homes today as floodwaters from a heavy rain receded.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER. By Jacobo Timerman. Translated from the Span- ish by Toby Talbot. 164 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: U.S. EXPELS LIBYANS AND CLOSES MISSION, CHARGING TERRORISM
description: The United States ordered today that Libya close its diplomatic mission in Washington and remove the mission staff from the country. It cited ''a wide range of Libyan provocations and misconduct, including support for international terrorism.''

title: STUDENT WINS WAR MEMORIAL CONTEST
description: A Yale University architecture student has won the competition to design a national memorial to Vietnam War veterans, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund announced today.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DANCE: AILEY PRESENTS WILSON'S 'CONCERTO IN F'
description: SPRING arrived at about 9:50 P.M. on Tuesday when the curtain went up on Billy Wilson's new ''Concerto in F'' at City Center, where the Alvin Ailey American Dance Company has just opened its three-week spring season. A swirl of pastel costumes and lights, extroverted Gershwin trills and toots, and sleek, hard-dancing bodies, ''Concerto in F'' is so much fun it ought to be illegal.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The shr earnings reflect 7-for-1 stock split last May

title: 22,000 SCORES REVISED AFTER ERROR IS DETECTED ON LAW SCHOOL EXAM
description: The scores of nearly 22,000 students who took the Law School Admission Test Feb. 21 have been changed after a test-taker found a flaw in the purported correct answer on a geometry question, the exam's sponsors said today.

title: BILL AGAINST RENT CONTROL REJECTED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: An attempt to attach an amendment against rent control to a housing bill in the House of Representatives was defeated today when proponents of controls were able to round up enough proxy votes.

title: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1981; The Economy
description: Interest rates are likely to climb and stay high for several months, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said. The deficit in fiscal 1981 could be as high as $60 billion, or $2 billion to $5 billion above earlier forecasts, as a result of rate increases since March, he said. Calling this year's budget experience ''a disaster,'' he put U.S. borrowing needs in fiscal 1981 at $75 billion to $80 billion. (Page A1.)

title: 23-Cent Stamp Possible, Bolger Warns Congress
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger warned Congress today that a 23-cent stamp could be on the way if the Postal Rate Commission did not act soon to raise the rate for firstclass mail to 20 cents.

title: No-Hitter Eludes Blyleven
description: Bert Blyleven, the Cleveland right-hander, pitched no-hit ball for eight innings and finished with a two-hitter as the Indians defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-1, tonight.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FLOWERS AND POTTERY
description: Flower Market, New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard, the Bronx.

title: U.S. Studies Shoe Curbs
description: The Reagan Administration today promised a decision in early June on whether to extend shoe import limits against both South Korea and Taiwan.

description: B-Includes an after-tax gain of $4,741,000 most of which came from the sale of an ocean-going vessel; the latest qr net inclu unrealized foreign currency exchange gains of $1,554,000 compar with yr-earlier foreign exchange loss of $1.6 million

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * The Advertising Council, to N.W. Ayer Inc., for a new public service campaign on alcoholism.

title: Design Notebook; A TEAHOUSE WITHIN A CITY CARRIAGE HOUSE
description: THE two-story brick-fronted building at 153 East 69th Street has never been a very conventional presence in mid-Manhattan. Its fanciful loosely Romanesque facade looks not unlike that of a number of carriage houses on the Upper East Side built, as this one was, in the 1880's.

title: CHAMBER: 'THE COELACANTH'
description: THERE is something decidedly smug about William Bergsma's ''The Voice of the Coelacanth,'' a set of 10 variations for horn, violin and piano commissioned by the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society. The piece received its world premiere on the group's final Alice Tully Hall programs of the season on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday nights.

title: Illinois Is Still Considering Withdrawal From Big Ten
description: Talk that Illinois may withdraw from the Big Ten Conference continued today, and Chancellor John Cribbet said the university is ''quite serious in considering it an option.''

title: STATE GETS OFFER BY CITY TO MAIL ITS TAX REFUNDS
description: New York City offered today to take over the mailing of state tax refunds still owed to about 2.4 million taxpayers throughout the state.

title: Around the NationZ; Judge Allows Use of Tapes In Organized-Crime Trial
description: Tapes secretly recorded by the Federal Bureau of Investigation contain enough conspiracy evidence to be presented to jurors in the racketeering trial of Carlos Marcello, a reputed leader of organized crime, and four other men, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: WhiteHouse Notes
description: Even as President Reagan ignored the advice of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on grain sales to the Soviet Union, senior White House aides have been hard at work trying to restore Mr. Haig's reputation as a trusted Reagan adviser.

title: 2 BUDGETS PROPOSED BY HOUSE LIBERALS SUFFER SOLID DEFEAT
description: The House rejected two liberal budget alternatives for the fiscal year 1982 in lopsided votes today that dramatically illustrated the liberals' loss of power.

title: ALGOMA CENTRAL RAILWAY reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Business People; Questor Names President And Chief Executive
description: James D. Milligan, 41, has joined the Questor Corporation as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Pierson M. Grieve, 53, chief executive officer since the corporation was founded in 1967 by the merger of two companies. Mr. Grieve was elected chairman.

title: Interior Dept. Reverses
description: Buffalo on Stationery

title: HUNTS' CASE APPEARS STRONGER
description: The Hunt brothers of Dallas, Nelson Bunker and William Herbert, have been complaining on philosophical grounds for years about Government interference in their multibillion-dollar business dealings.

title: Paultz Can Look Back on a Long Record of Success in Playoffs
description: Some sneered when Billy Paultz, now a center-forward for the Houston Rockets, left St. John's University 11 years ago and signed with the Nets, then a member of the American Basketball Association and playing on Long Island.

title: Advertising; Doyle Dane Earnings Tumble 84% in Quarter
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach's earnings plummeted 84 percent in the first quarter from the similar period last year, and this was partially caused, according to the agency, by clients shifting ''advertising spending to the latter part of the year.''

title: WATER RULES LIFTED IN 40 JERSEY TOWNS
description: Forty more towns in New Jersey were removed from mandatory water rationing yesterday, increasing the number of communities where controls have been lifted since mid-April to 96.

title: SOME PLATES LINKED TO ILLNESS
description: THE New York State Department of Health warned recently against regularly serving food on nine brands of tableware that have a bright orange glaze.

title: MACHINERY EXPORTS HELP TO NARROW TRADE DEFICIT
description: A surge in exports of heavy machinery helped narrow the nation's merchandise trade deficit in the first quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a gain of $201,000 from discontinued operations

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
COURT UPHOLDS U.S. RIGHT TO TRY EX-MEMBER OF PEOPLE'S TEMPLE
description: The United States can try Larry Layton, a former member of the People's Temple cult, on conspiracy charges in the death of Representative Leo J. Ryan, even though the slaying occurred in another country, a Federal appellate court has ruled.

title: 13 Are Promoted At Hughes Aircraft
description: In one fell swoop, the Hughes Aircraft Company has promoted 13 vice presidents to the position of senior vice president, establishing the second tier of top management under the chairman and the president. Yesterday Allen E. Puckett, chairman and chief executive officer of the Culver City, Calif., aerospace and electronics corporation, explained the reason for this action.

title: A MISCALCULATION BY KEMP-ROTH
description: To the Editor:

title: GRIEF FOR WAR DEAD IN ISRAELI CEMETERY
description: Israel marked the fragility of peace today as thousands of relatives of fallen soldiers poured into the military cemetery on Mount Herzl in Jerusalem to grieve over the flower-strewn graves of husbands and brothers, fathers and sons. A salute was fired, a bugle sounded, an army rabbi moved from grave to grave to chant the melancholy prayer for the dead.

title: HOUSEHOLD FINANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The latest qr results included foreign exchange losses of $2.7 million compared to losses of $7.3 million a yr-ago

title: SUZUKI IN WASHINGTON FOR ON ARMS SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for two days of talks with President Reagan that Administration officials said they hoped would lead to a Japanese commitment to increase military spending.

title: CRIMMINS STATEMENT ON MURDER AT MET IS READ AT TRIAL
description: A detective testified yesterday that Craig S. Crimmins had told him that he tried to rape Helen Hagnes and later ''killed the lady'' at the Metropolitan Opera House by kicking her off a sixth-floor roof into an air shaft.

title: Earth Tremors Jolt Parts of Italy
description: Earth tremors jolted mountainous areas in central and southern Italy today, panicking people but causing no damage, officials reported. The first tremor hit the earthquake-prone province of Macerata, south of the port city of Ancona, before dawn.

title: Philharmonic Society Elects New President
description: Mrs. Robert L. Hoguet has been elected president of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, effective July 1.

title: U.S. SENDING ENVOY TO GUATEMALA WITH VIEW TO RESUMING ARMS AID
description: The Reagan Administration will send an envoy to Guatemala next week to discuss United States conditions for restoring military aid, State Department officials said today.

title: 'The Election Was Over'
description: Don't try to tell Charles Manatt that there's no projectioninfection problem in national elections. He's now chairman of the Democratic National Committee, but last Nov. 4 he was walking a North Hollywood precinct for a California Congressman. Though the polls were still open, television had already projected the Reagan win. ''In three different households,'' he recalls, ''people said, hadn't I heard - the election was over. There was no point in going to vote.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday on the sale of Maxim's of Paris incorrectly reported the status of Maxim's restaurant in Chicago. It is still in business.

title: Notes on People; Wasting No Time in Expressing His Thanks
description: Eric Sloane, the painter and author, thinks he knows why the Dutch Treat Club chose him to receive the club's gold medal award at its annual dinner at the Plaza Hotel tonight. He paid for it in advance.

title: Company News; Telpak Discount, Ended By Bell
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, armed with a final court order, announced late today that its bulk-discount phone service known as Telpak would be discontinued at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow. The announcement had been expected since Monday, when the Supreme Court refused to grant the last of three petitions for review of a ruling by the Federal Communications Commission and a lower court.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 21 ON AIR FORCE JET ARE KILLED IN CRASH
description: A military jet exploded over a western Maryland farm today, killing all 21 crew members and scattering bodies, debris and documents over a wide area, the authorities said.

title: L.I.U. Wins Baseball Title
description: Long Island University won its first Metropolitan Collegiate baseball title since 1972 by defeating C.W. Post, 9-6, in the conference championship game at Shea Stadium yesterday.

title: KLAN RALLY INQUIRY FAULTS CONNECTICUT'S STATE POLICE
description: A legislative committee, completing a five-week investigation into why the Connecticut state police did not assist the local police at a Ku Klux Klan rally in Meriden on March 21, recommended changes today in the police agency's top leadership.

title: NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
President Pays Tribute To a 'Powerful Voice'
description: President Reagan expressed sorrow today over the death of Frank E. Fitzsimmons, calling the leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters ''an important and powerful voice in the American labor movement.''

title: News Analysis
description: He was a beefy, soft-skinned man more at home on the golf course than in a trucker's cab or on a loading dock. He brooked no nonsense and while he was a bumbling speaker, Frank E. Fitzsimmons probably was a lot smarter, at least in the ways of union power, than people thought.

title: 4 Censured in Death Of Asthmatic Youth
description: Two New York City Emergency Medical Service nurses were suspended yesterday and disciplinary action was taken against two of the service's telephone operators following the death of a Brooklyn youth.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company does not report revs

title: Notes on People; Who Is 'Deep Throat'? Ben Bradlee Replies
description: He won't say just when he found out, but Benjamin C. Bradlee, the executive editor of The Washington Post, says he now knows the identity of ''Deep Throat,'' the anonymous source who provided the Post's reporter, Bob Woodward, with leads in his Watergate investigation with Carl Bernstein almost a decade ago.

title: Advertising; New Marschalk Duties
description: Marschalk, which has a number of assignments from Revlon and its Norcliff-Thayer division, has been named by the division to do all of the network TV buying for all its brands: Esoterica Medicated Fade Cream and Nature's Remedy, a laxative, which the agency already has, as well as Tums, whose advertising is being created by Jordan, Case & McGrath.

title: Tigers 3, A's 2
description: Detroit's Tom Brookens drove in the tiebreaking run with a sacrifice fly in the eighth inning, sending Al Cowens home with an unearned run.

title: Brewers Paid Dalton Fine
description: The Milwaukee Brewers have paid the $50,000 fine assessed by major league baseball owners against General Manager Harry Dalton for remarks he made to a newspaper reporter about negotiations with the players union, The Milwaukee Journal reported today.

title: 3 Interior Nominees Confirmed
description: The Senate confirmed by voice vote today President Reagan's nomination of Robert F. Burford, former Speaker of the Colorado House of Representatives, as director of the Bureau of Land Management, a branch of the Department of the Interior. William H. Coldiron, vice chairman of the Montana Power Company, was confirmed as the department's solicitor. Carry Edward Carruthers, a professor of agricultural economics at New Mexico State University, was confirmed as an Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Bruce P. Andrews and Louis H. Beres have been elected to the board of Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising.

title: CANADIAN TIRE CORP reports earnings for 13 weeks to Apr 4
description: B-After a loss $447,000 on sale of property

title: PAPER-CRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company News; FORD SELLS OFFICE BUILDING IN MANHATTAN FOR $40 MILLION
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday sold its 19-story office building at 555 West 57th Street, near the intersection of 11th Avenue, for $40 million.

title: BEGIN AGAIN ATTACKS SCHMIDT ON ROLE UNDER HITLER
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel again denounced Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today, saying that, as an officer in the armed forces in World War II, Mr. Schmidt had remained faithful to Hitler until the end.

title: Around the World; Swedish Premier Facing Calls for New Elections
description: Prime Minister Thorbjorn Falldin today shuffled ministerial posts in his coalition Cabinet amid calls from the parliamentary opposition for new national elections.

title: A CHANGE IN COMMAND AT CP
description: Ian D. Sinclair, the blunt, brash business leader who forged the Canadian Pacific business empire from a large Canadian concern into an $13 billion multinational conglomerate, gave up the reins of power today - partially, at least.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The 1980 revs reclassified for comparative purposes

title: Lord Kagan, Jailed as a Swindler, Is Stripped of British Knighthood
description: Lord Kagan, a textile magnate who was jailed last December as a swindler, was stripped today of the knighthood awarded to him by Queen Elizabeth in 1970.

title: New York Air's Application to Use Westchester Airport Stirs Rebuff
description: An application to the Civil Aeronautics Board by New York Air to fly to 18 cities from the Westchester County Airport has been formally opposed by the county.

title: Around the World; Mrs. Gandhi Urges U.S.  To Avoid 'Confrontation'
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India expressed the hope today that the Reagan Administration ''will not have a global strategy which can only increase confrontation.''

title: Both Parties to Explore New Campaigning Ideas
description: The national chairmen of the Republican and Democratic Parties have appointed chairmen of committees to look into possible changes in election campaigns.

title: THEATER: BARBARA PERRY AS ALL OF THE 'PASSIONATE LADIES'
description: WOMAN show is a risky venture, made doubly hazardous if the actress is performing her own material. There are indications in Barbara Perry's ''Passionate Ladies,'' which opened Tuesday at the Bijou Theater, that Miss Perry may be a capable character actress, but as a writer she has done herself a disservice.

title: 8 Are Held in a Princeton Protest At U. S. Defense Research Center
description: Eight persons, including four Princeton University students, were arrested today after a protest march to the Institute for Defense Analysis, a research wing of the Defense Department. All eight were charged with obstructing a public highway and were released on their own recognizance.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT READ AT THE MET SLAYING TRIAL
description: Following is a statement the police said Craig S. Crimmins made to Detective Gennaro Giorgio at 11 P.M. on Aug. 29. It was read yesterday by Detective Giorgio from the witness stand in State Supreme Court in Manhattan at Mr. Crimmins's trial for the murder and attempted rape of Helen Hagnes on the night of July 23. Sexually explicit phrases have been deleted by the editors.

title: JAPAN AUTO MAKERS VIE ON EXPORTS
description: Japanese auto makers will vigorously debate their allocations for exports to the United States, Japanese Government and auto industry officials said today, although the quotas will be based mainly on previous export volume for each auto maker.

title: Notes on People; 1981 Costs for 1739 House Prove Too Much for Buckley
description: The toys have been passed down to the newest generation, according to William F. Buckley Jr., nor will there be any Yale and Vassar diplomas or other personal mementos for sale when the Buckley family puts the contents of Great Elm up for auction May 23 in Sharon, Conn. Annual maintenance costs for the 30-room, 242-year-old Georgian Colonial mansion have been exceeding $100,000.

title: Suspect Indicted In L.I. Murder of 3
description: A Nassau County grand jury handed up an 12-count indicment charging Donald J. Williams, a 23-year-old unemployed Hicksville, L.I., construction worker, with burglary, rape and murder in the stabbing deaths last Friday of a mother and her two children.

title: RETAIL SALES UP SHARPLY IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: Sales last month by seven major retailers with stores in New York City and the suburbs rose 19.4 percent within the city and 16.7 percent throughout the metropolitan area compared with sales in April 1980, a spot-check this week showed.

title: Company News; New Claims Official
description: George Aldrich, a United States representative on the United Nations International Law Commission, has been named to the U.S.-Iranian claims tribunal to replace Judge Malcolm Wilkey, of the Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia, who resigned.

title: Company News; Montgomery Ward April Sales Up 21.7%
description: Montgomery Ward & Company of Chicago, a unit of the Mobil Corporation, said April sales increased 21.7 percent over the 1980 month, the highest year-to-year increase since a 23.2 percent gain in September 1973. The big retailer said sales last month rose to $444.4 million while volume for the 13 weeks ended May 2 advanced 12.6 percent, to $1.29 billion.

title: IN LONDONDERRY, A FAMILY FEARS ANOTHER HUNGER STRIKER'S FATE
description: ''Shush, wait till we see if Patsy's on,'' said Peggy O'Hara as she turned up the television in her living room.

title: SANDS, BEGIN, MUGABE
description: There has been no shortage of propagandists who are prepared to defend both past and continuing British attempts to colonize Ireland. Between Robert, Earl of Essex, who as servant to Elizabeth I was the First Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, servant to Elizabeth II, there have been many who have attempted to justify the Crown's 382-year-old foreign presence in that most distressed country.

title: Business People; H.H. Robertson Makes Shifts In Top Management Posts
description: Hugh E. Seely, 55, has been named president and chief operating officer of the H.H. Robertson Company, a building products manufacturer, effective July 1. He will succeed Douglas A. Jones, 64, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the corporation, whose headquarters are in Pittsburgh.

title: Lindgren: Case of the Missing Runner
description: When Gerry Lindgren was 18 years old and a member of the United States Olympic team, hisworld was simple and wonderful. His voice was squeaky. He was as friendly as a pup. He loved to put people on. Although he had already become one of the world's great distance runners, he was more boy than man.

description: ''This is a horrible time. No idealism. No more talk of the disadvantaged.

title: Service on L.I.R.R.  Disrupted for Hour
description: Service on the Long Island Rail Road in and out of Pennsylvania Station was suspended for about an hour while workmen repaired a broken third-rail protection board in one of the railroad's East River tunnels. The board protects work crews against the high voltage of the third rail.

title: PANEL RESOLUTION SAYS WILLIAMS VIOLATED SENATE RULES
description: The resolution calling for a Senate ethics commitee investigation of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., which was made public today, says the New Jersey Democrat violated Senate rules because of his involvement in the Abscam scandal.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article April 14 on prominent black residents of Washington gave an incorrect first name for one of them. He was Rayford W. Logan, a historian.

title: BALLET: BARYSHNIKOV'S NEW 'SWAN LAKE'
description: American Ballet Theater's ''Swan Lake'' now resembles its ''Giselle.'' It is a new production within the shell of an old. As presented for the first time this season on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Alan Barker as conductor, ''Swan Lake'' retained Oliver Smith's settings and the basic action followed the outline of David Blair's old staging. Nevertheless, Mikhail Baryshnikov has made important alterations.

EL SALVADOR TURNS DOWN A PLAN FOR OUTSIDE MEDIATION
description: A major international effort to bring El Salvador's warring factions to the bargaining table has failed with the refusal of the Salvadoran army high command to accept an offer of outside mediation.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS AND LABOR LEADERS URGE A 10-YEAR EXTENSION OF VOTING ACT
description: Civil rights and labor leaders, saying that the wounds from a century of overt racial discrimination had not healed, urged Congress today to extend the Voting Rights Act for 10 years in its present form.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Cut In Nassau Prisoners
description: A Federal judge ordered Nassau County jail officials yesterday to reduce the total of prisoners in the jail beginning June 1 or face contempt charges.

title: AND IS HOSPITALIZED IN MISSOURI
description: Bess Truman, 96 years old, widow of President Truman, was hospitalized early today for a hip fracture suffered in a fall at her home in Independence, Mo..

title: PETER KEBER
description: Peter Keber, a retired officer of the IU International Corporation, died Sunday at his home in Villanova, Pa. He was 72 years old. Mr. Keber, a native of New York City and a graduate of the Harvard Law School, was a Wall Street lawyer for 32 years before joining the Waterworks General Corporation in 1965.

title: TROOPER PATROLS REPORTED 'WORKING WELL' IN TRENTON
description: Until eight weeks ago, Trooper Kurt Amburgey of the New Jersey state police spent his work shifts patrolling alone the back roads around Fort Dix, chasing speeders and investigating car accidents. Trooper Robert Singletary had a similar one-man beat in the thinly settled rural regions of Hunterdon and Mercer Counties, where collisions between cars and deer are common.

title: CONFLICTS OF WOMEN WITH JOBS
description: WOMEN are in the work force to stay, not only to help support their families, but also to achieve personal satisfaction, according to a national survey released yesterday.

description: B-Includes $863,000 gain representing the cumulative effect of a change in a accounting principle

title: HIGH SOVIET AIDE ARRIVES IN SYRIA AS LEBANON CRISIS GROWS
description: A senior Soviet official arrived here this afternoon for consultations with the Syrian Government in what was seen by Western diplomats as an intensified effort to prevent a wider Middle East confrontation between Syria and Israel.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company News; Chrysler Expanding Overtime at 4 Plants
description: The Chrysler Corporation said four of its domestic car and truck assembly plants will work six days on expanded overtime schedules next week to meet resurgent demand for its vehicles. The No.3 auto maker reported yesterday that sales in the last 10 days of April rose 69.5 percent from the same period in 1980.

description: Decolonization Committee, Subcom- mittee on Small Territories - 10:30 A.M.

description: Ellen V. Futter, a 31-year old lawyer who has been acting president of Barnard College for the last year, has been named permanent president of the 92-year-old college for women.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: There is no present judicial office as ''justice of the peace'' (in New York State). This office was abolished some time ago and has been replaced by the titles ''town justice'' or ''village justice.''
description: As you will note from Section 11, Subdivision 6, of the Domestic Relations Law, a town justice or village justice may solemnize a marriage anywhere within the territorial limits of the county or counties in which the town or village in which he is elected or appointed is located.

description: The Congressman stood on the east steps of the Capitol, bypassed by tourists yesterday as he insisted that this was the worst of times.

title: 10-1 Summing Wins At Belmont Opener
description: Belmont Park opened its spring meeting yesterday and, before a crowd of 18,042, Summing won the $59,500 Hill Prince Stakes. The opening was moved up from May 23 because of construction at Aqueduct.

title: Market Place; Lease Contracts As Investment
description: PHOENIX LEASING INC. calls leasing one of America's best-kept investment secrets, and the Mill Valley, Calif., company wants to change that so more investors will buy its partnership units.

title: FRANCOIS BORDES, 61, ARCHEOLOGIST, DIES
description: Francois Bordes, an internationally known French archeologist who was an authority on the culture of Neanderthal man and a pioneer in the study of how ancient man made and used stone tools, died April 30 in Tucson, Ariz., where he was lecturing at the University of Arizona, it was reported yesterday. He was 61 years old.

title: Prosecutor Sworn In
description: Thomas A. Duffy Jr. was sworn in as the new special prosecutor for the city's criminal-justice system. Mr. Duffy, 40 years old, the chief assistant in the office since 1979, succeeds Roderick Lankler, who resigned to become executive director of Governor Carey's new commission on the administration of justice.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: As an ordained Congregational minister since 1949 I have not only performed more than one wedding in homes, but also in gardens, beside rivers and lakes and in city parks. Having known several hundred Congregational pastors these past 32 years, I believe most of them would feel the same as I do.  REV. GRAHAM R. HODGES United Church of Christ

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. OFFER TO DISCUSS MISSILES IN EUROPE IS A 'MANEUVER'
description: The Soviet press agency Tass described today as a ''maneuver'' an announcement by the United States that it was ready to negotiate with the Soviet Union about limits on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Head of A.M.C.  Sees Sales Gain
description: The chairman of the American Motors Corporation yesterday predicted a turnaround in domestic auto sales in the next 6 to 24 months, but said many independent auto makers would have to merge to survive over the next two decades.

description: A bill to give the ailing steel industry more time to comply with the Clean Air Act while it tries to make its plants more competitive was approved today by a House subcommittee.

title: North Sea Drilling
description: A total of 36 oil companies filed applications with the Norwegian Ministry of Oil and Energy today for drilling rights to 10 North Sea blocks, the ministry's State Secretary, Harald Norvik, said. The blocks, to be allocated next autumn, are relinquished areas in the southern part of the North Sea basin close to existing processing and transportation facilities, he said. The oil companies represent a wide spread of nationalities, he said.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS PENSION CUTS PLAN
description: President Reagan's proposals for reductions in some Social Security benefits were unanimously approved by a House subcommittee today, but on a scaled-down basis that will save the retirement system a good deal less than the Administration had intended.

title: ROYAL FAMILY GETS A COURT INJUNCTION
description: Prince Charles was granted an injunction today to prevent the publication of purported transcripts of telephone calls he made from Australia to his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, and his mother, Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Home Improvement; REPLACING OLD, DRAFTY WINDOWS WITH THOSE THAT CAN CUT COSTS
description: TODAY'S high costs of energy and new housing have prompted more and more people to spend on updating their present homes rather than saving to buy newer and perhaps more fuel-efficient ones.

title: Tesoro Net Down 35.6% in Quarter
description: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter ended March 31 plunged 35.6 percent, to $23.3 million, or $1.42 a share, from $36.2 million, or $2.59 a share, in the first quarter of 1980.

title: Gardening; DWARF FRUIT TREES CAN BE CITY PLEASURES

title: TREASURY CHIEF SEES INTEREST RATES RISING MORE, CITES HARM TO BUDGET
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that interest rates would probably climb higher and stay high for ''several months.'' He added that rate increases since March had increased the Federal budget deficit for the 1981 fiscal year by $2 billion to $5 billion.

title: GEN. MELVIN ZAIS, 64, FORMER NATO CHIEF FOR SOUTHEAST EUROPE
description: Gen. Melvin Zais, a retired combat officer and four-star general who commanded North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in Southeast Europe in the 1970's, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Beaufort, S.C. He was 64 years old.

title: Hers
description: EVERY Mother's Day eve, I visit the altar of Sacrificial Motherhood, an awesome structure constructed from centuries of experts' advice to women, with a little shrine to Sigmund Freud placed prominently in front.

title: Around the World; Prosecution Says 'Ripper' Sought to Kill 14th Woman
description: The prosecution said today that the police caught Peter Sutcliffe, who has confessed to slaying 13 women, just as he was about to kill a 14th woman in northern England.

title: Notes on People; Jane Austen Is a Victim of a Nonfictional Mix-Up
description: Jane Austen fans are likely to be as perceptive as they are devoted. When a recent regional gathering of them saw the jacket portrait on a new Austen collection, the reaction was ''universal horror,'' according to J. David Grey of Manhattan Plaza, president of the Jane Austen Society of North America.

title: Blast Kills 4 on Italian Tanker
description: An explosion aboard an Italian tanker off Naples last night killed four crew members, officials said today. The 12,000-ton tanker Umiltas was sailing without a cargo at the time of the explosion.

title: 'A Beautiful Occasion'
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Bravo for the marriages at home (''Getting Married: No Place Like Home,'' April 30). My husband and I said our vows two years ago in our living room and it was a beautiful occasion - not the plasticized ritual most weddings have become.

description: Bermuda's Government and the leaders of striking Government workers agreed late tonight on a new contract to end the 26-day-old walkout that brought the island's vital tourist industry to a near halt.

title: MOON'S SECT IS TAXABLE, COURT RULES
description: An appellate court has ruled that the ''primary purpose'' of the Unification Church, headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, is not religious and that the church is not entitled to have three buildings it owns in New York City exempted from city property taxes.

title: FRENCH RACE ENTERS THE FINAL STRETCH
description: After last night's television confrontation between President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and Francois Mitterrand - which was less dramatic and probably less decisive than had been expected - the French presidential race has entered its final stages.

title: Credit Markets; 10-YEAR U.S. NOTES SOLD AT 14.56%
description: The United States Treasury, buffeted by high interest rates in the middle of a major financing, yesterday sold new 14 1/2 percent, 10-year notes at an average yield of 14.56 percent - the highest ever paid for a new issue with that maturity.

title: Advertising; N.F.L. Properties Plans To Publish New Magazine
description: National Football League Properties plans to begin publishing a magazine called Pro! next season and has already sold 30 pages of advertising for each of the seven issues.

title: Six-Year ABC Pact to Put Sugar Bowl on Prime Time
description: The Sugar Bowl, the Southeastern Conference and the American Broadcasting Company have signed a six-year contract that will move the annual New Year's Day football game to prime time on television.

STEARNS CATCHES
description: John Stearns went behind the bat last night for the first time in nine months, but neither that change nor several others spared the Mets as they lost again to the San Francisco Giants, 6-4.

title: SCIENTISTS SEEKING RESEARCH FUNDS ARE LECTURED ON POLITICAL SCIENCE
description: A contingent of leading American scientists came to Washington today to educate Congress about the importance of spending more for basic science and left with a stern lesson in political science from Representative David R. Obey.

description: WHILE the Islanders shop for a new supply of silver polish for the Stanley Cup that they should defend successfully in the next two weeks, the Rangers are out of the playoffs. Oooo La La, so soon.

title: CHAMBER: GOLDEN FLEECE LTD.
description: THE Composers Chamber Theater, otherwise known as the Golden Fleece Ltd., operates in a space not much bigger than a normal living room; and in its second-floor loft on West 22d Street, the audience becomes more like guests in a crowded parlor than segregated onlookers. Last weekend, the Golden Fleece presented its Spring Opera Cabaret - two one-act operas and a staged collection of 16 songs written by a variety of composers and sung here by a quartet of soloists.

description: A Japanese fisherman from Shimonoseki today became the legitimate owner of $738,000 worth of gold bars he hauled from the sea three years ago.

title: Axelson Gets Post
description: Dave Axelson, assistant athletic director at St. Louis University, has been named an assistant commissioner of the Metro Athletic Conference. He will assume his duties June 1.

title: SAN DIEGO REJECTS BOND PROPOSAL
description: In the nation's largest election by mail, voters today rejected a proposed downtown convention complex that San Diego officials had authorized without a public vote.

title: ISLANDERS-RANGERS WAS FRIENDLY SERIES
description: If there was one thing more surprising than the Islanders' fourgame sweep of the Rangers in their semifinal playoff, it was the lack of animosity shown by the players. The fans might have been boisterous and rude, and the participants may have thrown some vicious body-checks, but throughout the series, the New York rivals retained respect for one another.

title: Bridge: The Importance of Sensing When It's Smart to Reopen
description: Reopening the bidding when the opponents have come to rest in a part-score is one of the most delicate areas in the game. Most authorities dismiss the subject in a page or two and move quickly to firmer ground. But decisions in this area swing massive numbers of points, and it deserves a comprehensive treatment from an expert.

title: Look Who's Mediating a Missile Crisis
description: It may be foolish in these unsettled days in Washington to make too much of the matter. But those are American and Soviet diplomats working in concert in rival corners of the Middle East this week, helping Israel and Syria avoid a war that neither wants. Good for President Reagan. Good for Mr. Brezhnev. May they ever compete so sensibly.

description: Europcar, a subsidiary of Renault, the French state-owned auto manufacturer, has emerged in the past nine years as the No.3 car rental company worldwide and No.1 in the fast-growing European market.

description: Turkey's security forces, which have been waging a resolute campaign against terrorism, separatism and anarchy, have now struck out against male homosexuals.

title: Company News; O.E.C.D. Aid to Turkey
description: Member nations of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development will pledge about $1 billion in aid to Turkey this year, down from $1.16 billion last year, senior O.E.C.D. officials said today. The officials, accompanying the O.E.C.D. Secretary General, Emile van Lennep, on a visit here, told reporters the final amount was still unresolved, pending tomorrow's pledging session in Paris. Some members, still unable to commit themselves, may contribute to the aid package at a later stage, the officials added, but they did not name specific countries.

description: Q. My front door has a crack about 10 inches long and just wide enough so that I can see light through it. Can you tell me what I can do to repair this? - G.M.B., Pittsburgh.

description: The Defense Department said today that it was looking into the conduct of Staff Sgt. Joseph Subic Jr. of the Army while he was one of the American hostages held for more than a year at the United States Embassy in Teheran.

description: An American Roman Catholic priest who had been missing and feared dead for 10 days walked into the United States Embassy this afternoon in apparent good health, an embassy spokesman said.

description: After 10 years of planning and construction, the $700 million Louisiana Offshore Oil Port opened for business last night when a Texaco tanker longer than three football fields began discharging 1.5 million barrels of crude into a pipeline beneath the stormy ocean's floor.

The three one-act American operas are grouped under the title of ''Three Mysterious Tales,'' and although no masterpieces are revealed, each is well worth seeing.

description: Creed C. Black, the editor of The Herald Leader in Lexington, Ky., was telling a dozen publishers of medium-size newspapers yesterday about the kinds of news they ought to be looking for to enliven their columns and attract and hold new readers.

description: A group of leading Democratic and Republican legisdators today announced a proposal to make the administration of rent control and rent stabilization a responsibility of state government.

description: The city has auctioned 535 confiscated rifles and shotguns and a grade school has announced that children would be taught how to shoot. A prominent lawyer described the unrelated events as ''astonishing'' and ''self-defeating.''

description: The Government should concentrate its financing for energy research on a relatively few technologies, such as ''heavy'' oil and unconventional gas and alcohol fuels that are likely to have the biggest payoff, according to an 18-month Congressional study published today.

description: An American nuclear submarine surfaced close to a Japanese merchant vessel that it had just collided with as the ship was hoisting a distress flag, according to survivors.

description: THE JWT Group, whose largest component is the J. Walter Thompson Company, had the best earnings growth of any public agency last year, Don Johnston, chief executive, told the annual meeting yesterday. He also promised a 20 percent revenue increase for 1981.

His new forecast is that revenues will rise 13 percent, rather than 12 percent, with the contributions coming from national, up 16 percent; retail, 14 percent, and classified, 10 percent.

description: Roscoe L. Egger, the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue, says he hopes to wring more income taxes from the socalled underground economy through a combination of enforcement measures.

description: Three members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries called yesterday for an oil-price freeze in the face of the oversupply of crude worldwide that may be undermining the group's power to maintain current prices.

title: MARK RAPPAPORT WRITES AND DIRECTS 'IMPOSTERS'
description: THE style of ''Impostors'' is deliberately dead, but the film, to its credit, is by no means lifeless. Though its actors waltz with supreme boredom through a scenario that's mocking, ironic and painfully hip, Mark Rappaport's latest effort does have a certain flair. Maybe it's just the way one character tells another ''Come on, give it a whirl. It'll be fun! Take a chance on love!'' This sort of yawnriddled facetiousness may not be for everyone, but at least in Mr. Rappaport's hands it becomes more amusing than annoying.

description: Marilyn Horne is quick to explain that more than 20 years ago, when she sang the soprano part in the ''Missa Solemnis,'' she was unsure of the range of her voice - ''it thinned out at the top in those years and I had a lot of laryngitis.''

title: RISE OF 15% FOR PHONES REQUESTED
description: The New York Telephone Company applied yesterday for an $889 million rate increase, a rise of 15 percent, beginning in April 1982. In support of its request, the company cited expected continued double-digit inflation, the high cost of borrowing for a $1.6 billion construction program and regulators' orders requiring faster recovery of equipment costs.

title: RESTORERS THAT SPECIALIZE IN ANTIQUES

Help-Wanted Ads Declined in March
description: Help-wanted advertising in 51 major newspapers decreased in March after a fractional upturn in February, returning to a downtrend that began in November, the Conference Board said yesterday in its latest monthly survey of employment trends.
