description: Thieves smashed the glass door of a Madison Avenue gallery, entered and fled with two Tiffany lamps valued at more than $250,000. No other items were reported stolen.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS AGREE TO A REPRIEVE FOR CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY UNIT
description: Two key Senators agreed today not to abolish the Consumer Product Safety Commission but rather to allow the small but controversial agency to exist for at least one more year in its present form.

title: Air Fare Talks And U.S. Role
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board voted today to limit the participation of United States airlines in collective fare-setting on international routes, but postponed the effective date of its ruling until Sept.15.

title: POP: THE BIG SKY MUDFLAPS
description: PIECE band from Missoula, Mont., called the Big Sky Mudflaps dropped in for two nights last week at Cody's, at East 16th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, where country music is usually featured, to offer a repertory made up of western swing, boogiewoogie, rhythm-and-blues, Kansas City swing, be-bop and high-spirited enthusiasm.

title: PORCELAIN FORMS THAT GIVE AN ILLUSION OF MOVEMENT
Company News; Ontario to Consider Massey Stock Bill
description: The Ontario government has introduced a bill in the provincial legislature to authorize the purchase of up to $78 million in Massey-Ferguson preferred shares under terms of a $700 million refinancing program worked out for the ailing farm-equipment maker.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 7, 1981
description: International A U.S. mission will go to Guatemala next week, according to State Department officials. They said that a special envoy, retired Gen. Vernon A. Walters, would discuss American conditions for restoring military aid to the Guatemalan Government to combat leftist insurgents. International organizations have accused Guatemala's security forces of widespread killing of political dissidents. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) El Salvador has rejected mediation in its conflict with leftist guerrillas. The offer to help the combatants try to reach a political settlement was made by the Socialist International, the worldwide Social Democratic organization. (A13:1-3.)

title: Protestant Marriages
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I believe that the article ''Vows: Judges and Clergy'' (April 30) requires some amplification. Since there are several Protestant denominations, each of which is, to some degree, ''congregationalist'' in its ecclesiastical structure, it is important to correct the possible impression that their ministers ''would normally refuse'' to perform an out-of-church marriage ceremony.

title: SCULPTURE TO GRACE A GARDEN IS SHOWN
description: ABEIGE and tan marble owl sits stoically in a banana grove. In the humid air of a tropical jungle, a bronze Ophelia lies floating in a pond full of water lilies. And amid sprays of white primroses, poppies, lavender verbena and bluebonnets growing wild in an American desert rests a giant gray caterpillar whose smooth marble surface begs to be touched.

title: 40 Killed in Persian Gulf Storm
description: A rainstorm that moved across the Persian Gulf this week killed 40 people, including 33 in Oman, the Government said today. The 48-hour storm, which struck the United Arab Emirates, the southern Arabian Peninsula, the Horn of Africa and part of Iran, was described as ''the worst in living memory'' by the emirates' meteorological office.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Helpful Hardware; CHANGING DOORKNOBS
description: TWO handy items are available that enable the homeowner to customize or change doorknobs easily. A doorknob adapter makes it possible to use a wide variety of styles of knobs and lever handles on modern doors that have been drilled for a lock set.

title: Topics; LOOKING BACKWARD; Not Named Desire
description: With the disabled Flxible buses still stuck in the repair shops, New York City continues to depend on those red-white-and-blue Metro buses leased from the Washington D.C. transit agency.

title: A BROTHER OF BUSH MAY FACE WEICKER
description: The White House and Vice President Bush are making no effort to discourage Mr. Bush's brother Prescott Jr. from challenging Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut for renomination in 1982 - even though they expect Senate Republicans to be unhappy at the move.

title: SUSPECT IN BUFFALO AREA MURDERS SAID TO CITE KILLINGS IN MANHATTAN
description: The 25-year-old Army private who has been implicated in the slayings of four black men in the Buffalo area told Army nurses that he had also killed black men in New York City last December, according to law enforcement officials.

title: PADRES GET 19 HITS, ROUT EXPOS
description: Broderick Perkins drove in five runs with a three-run home run, a double and a triple, and Ruppert Jones knocked in three more runs as the San Diego Padres used a 19-hit attack to rout the Montreal Expos, 13-5, tonight.

title: JETERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DENT HURT
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, likes a fiery manager, so Gene Michael probably won more than a game tonight when he was ejected for the first time in his managerial career as the Yankees beat the California Angels, 5-2.

title: ACCORD ON INTEGRATION OF SHREVEPORT SCHOOLS IS GIVEN TO U.S. JUDGE
description: The Justice Department and a school board in Louisiana agreed today to end 16 years of litigation over efforts to desegregate the public schools of Shreveport and its suburbs.

title: BIO-RAD LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RANGERS ELIMINATED, BUT PATRICK IS PROUD
description: Fifteen minutes after the Islanders skated, passed and shot his team out of the Stanley Cup playoffs Tuesday night, Coach Craig Patrick was talking about the fine future he sees for the Rangers.

title: TIME AGAIN FOR A CONSERVATION CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: THE MURDER TRIAL OF JEAN HARRIS IS DRAMATIZED
description: IN what is probably a record production time of only a few weeks, ''The People vs. Jean Harris'' is being brought to NBC-TV in a dramatization that clearly has been constructed with great care. Using a somewhat awkward presentation schedule, the first two hours will be broadcast tonight, beginning at 9 o'clock, and the final hour can be seen tomorrow at 9. The arrangement is unfortunate because, purely as drama, the production's intensity builds gradually, too gradually in spots. The 24-hour interruption is likely to dissipate some of its impact.

title: Memorial Service for Paul Green, Playwright Who Won a Pulitzer
description: Services will be held Saturday for the Pulitzer Prize-winning dramatist Paul Green, who died Monday of a heart attack.

title: Critic's Notebook; SUSTAINING AN ILLUSION: TRICKY STAGE BUSINESS
description: IDON'T know why it should be, and it's perfectly possible that the reaction is one that's peculiar to me alone, but every time I hear an offstage door slammed shut in a play I invariably imagine that someone's just fired a cannon. The sound isn't a slam, you see, it's a boom! And it's very destructive of illusion, jolting me right out of the story I've been trying to make head or tail of and hurling me into the ''1812'' Overture instead.

title: ALABAMA-TENNESSEE NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FINAL PLEA FOR AN EX-NEW YORKER MADE IN 5- YEAR WAR CRIMES TRIAL
description: Defense lawyers for a former New York resident asked a court here today to dismiss charges that she had participated, as a concentration camp guard, in the murder of thousands of Jews.

title: PHARMACAPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WHOLESALE STRIKE LIMITING MEAT SUPPLIES IN NEW YORK
description: Butcher shops, small groceries and restaurants that would normally be stocking up on meat for Mother's Day dinners are beginning to feel the pinch of an unexpected wholesale butchers' strike in New York City.

title: French Force In a Vital Area; Sole Ally That Is Ready For Indian Ocean Move; Military Analysis
description: The French military presence in the Indian Ocean and adjacent regions has assumed a new importance as American strategic planning turns increasingly toward Southwest Asia. Alone among America's allies,

title: Topics; LOOKING BACKWARDS; Maneuvers
description: A colleague atoning for last fall's sins by raking up leftover leaves was startled last weekend by an alien sound, crackling much like the report of a pistol.

title: Around the Nation; San Jose to Negotiate Women's Lower Pay Issue
description: San Jose, the nation's 17th-largest city, has agreed to address the problem of unequal pay for women in forthcoming negotiations with municipal workers.

title: Orioles 5, Twins 4
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Al Bumbry scored the winning run for Baltimore as Minnesota botched a rundown that would have ended the ninth inning.

title: CHINA'S INNER MONGOLIA IS FOUND 'SERIOUSLY AFFECTED' BY DROUGHT
description: One-third of Inner Mongolia's 18 milllion people and nearly one half of its livestock have been ''seriously affected'' by the drought that has parched the North China Plain, according to agriculture officials here.

title: CONTINENTAL THWARTS TEXAS AIR MOVE
description: At an emotionally charged meeting today, stockholders of Continental Air Lines turned aside an attempt by Texas International Airlines to block an employee takeover of Continental.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT COR reports earnings for Qtr to Mar
MARINERS OUST WILLS
description: The Seattle Mariners, off to the worst start in the American League, dismissed Maury Wills as manager today and named Rene Lachemann to replace him on an interim basis. Lachemann was managing the Mariners' Triple A farm club in Spokane, Wash.

title: YOUTHS BATTLE POLICE
description: Six hundred additional British troops were sent to Northern Ireland tonight in what military spokesmen described as a precautionary measure.

title: Company News; Marriott Plans Hotel
description: The Marriott Corporation said it planned to build a second 300-room hotel in North Carolina at an undisclosed cost.

title: Area in India Sealed Off as 48 Die In Fresh Moslem-Hindu Fighting
description: Officials sealed off Nalanda district in northern India today to halt the spread of Moslem-Hindu fighting, which has claimed at least 48 lives in the last six days.

title: PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 4
description: Yr-ago results restated to reflect final effective income tax r for 1980 fiscal yr

title: SENATE UNIT FAILS TO PASS CONRAIL BILL
description: A deeply divided Senate Commerce Committee adjourned today without approving Conrail legislation that had been sought by the Reagan Administration, including provisions that would allow some parts of the system to be sold.

title: Rangers 4, White Sox 2
description: Bill Stein's run-scoring single for Texas in the seventh inning snapped a 2-2 tie.

title: OFFSHORE LOGISTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $1,817,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: INTERNATIONAL PROTEINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Company News; 21% Keystone Stake Held by Halperins
description: The former president and chief executive of McGregor-Doniger Inc., the apparel manufacturer, and his son, said they had raised their stake in Keystone Consolidated Industries to nearly 21 percent from 15.7 percent through the purchase of 95,800 shares last month.

title: FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MUSEUM SETS CRAFTS FAIR
description: DIMENSIONAL metal pie crimper in the shape of a rabbit, a life-size white-throated sparrow carved from basswood and batteryoperated blinking jewelry from the Netherlands are only a few of the items to be displayed at the first Cooper-Hewitt Museum Crafts Fair.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION:
description: Congregationalist ministers, who usually also go by the label United Church of Christ ministers, each set his or her own policy in such matters, but the majority of them, contrary to Anne-Marie Shiro's assertion, do perform wedding services in homes.

title: STAGE: MELBA MOORE IS 'INACENT BLACK'
description: ALTHOUGH it is the work of a living writer and contains a few contemporary references, ''Inacent Black'' looks like a relic from a very distant past. This comedy, written by A. Marcus Hemphill, is the kind of show that might have toured the Bible Belt, by bus-and-truck (or maybe horse and buggy), at least two generations ago. Even in those days, it wouldn't have dreamed of pitching its tent on Broadway.

title: 3,000 IN MARCH AT BRITISH CONSULATE IN NEW YORK MOURN SANDS'S DEATH
description: About 3,000 people gathered outside the British Consulate in New York yesterday afternoon to protest the death of Robert Sands, the young Irish Republican Army hunger striker who was buried in Belfast earlier in the day.

title: Commonwealth Oil Files Plan to End Bankruptcy
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, which has been operating under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act for more than three years, filed an ammended plan yesterday to bring it out of bankruptcy by the end of July.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE ASKS UPGRADING OF PENTAGON'S INTELLIGENCE AGENCY
description: In an effort to provide competing views on intelligence matters, a Senate committee has recommended that the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency be upgraded to provide analysis as effectively as the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SCHMIDT, IN PARLIAMENT, SILENT ON ATTACKS BY BEGIN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in a report to Parliament today on his recent Middle East trip, declined to respond to personal attacks by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and called on Israel and the Arabs to live together ''in a just and all-embracing peace.''

title: Slight Rise Posted For Money Funds
description: The nation's money market funds grew slightly, by $72.6 million, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: BARBARA HARRIS IN 'SECOND HAND HEARTS'
description: ''SECOND HAND HEARTS,'' directed by Hal Ashby from an original screenplay by Charles Eastman, is an ersatz country-and-western love story about two Texas losers who aspire to adorability - Loyal Muke, a boozy fellow who has trouble keeping a job in a carwash, and Dinette Dusty, a recently widowed waitress and would-be singer who marries Loyal to get back her children from their paternal grandparents.

title: BIOFUEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Valenzuela Eyes a Big Contract
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the pitching prodigy of the Los Angeles Dodgers, made his first visit to New York yesterday with his business agent, who cast a commercial look forward and said: ''We'll see how high the sky is.''

title: TV SCREENS DOMINATE EX-TENNESSEE GOVERNOR'S KICKBACK TRIAL
description: For the better part of three weeks, the extortion and kickback trial of former Gov. Ray Blanton made the Federal courtroom here appear more a television screening room than a legal battlefield.

title: Zemel Choir in Riverdale
description: Liturgical pieces and folk tunes will be performed in Hebrew, Yiddish and English by the Zemel Choir of London tomorrow night at 8:45 at the Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, at Henry Hudson Parkway and 250th Street in the Bronx.

title: 3-Mile Island Gets Backing
description: Stockholders in the corporation that owns the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant today approved the facility's reopening, despite the loss of $190 million in dividends since it was shut by an accident in 1979.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
IC Would Buy Stock Union Pacific Holds
description: IC Industries, a diversified consumer products concern and the operator of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, announced that it had offered to reacquire 2.1 million of its shares owned by the Union Pacific Corporation.

title: A BULLISH VIEW ON THE AIRLINES
description: MOST of the 10 major, established air carriers known as the trunk airlines had a dismal 1980: They logged a combined net loss of $381 million - a marked deterioration from their net income of $246 million in 1979.

title: Around the Nation; Missing Youth in Atlanta Is Found Safe After Search
description: A 14-year-old boy whose disappearance touched off an intensive police search for fear that he had fallen victim to the killers of 26 black youths was found safe in suburban Cobb County tonight.

title: Notes On People; Down on the Farm With the Archbishop of Canterbury
description: A visiting pig farmer from England couldn't have been more impressed yesterday when he visited a hog farm outside Dallas Center, Iowa.

title: Bridge: Foreign Experts Will Play In Cavendish Club's Event
description: Expert partnerships from several countries will compete this weekend in the Cavendish Club's annual invitation pairs. Among them are two from England, Irving Rose and Maurice Esterson and Zia Mahmoud and Robert Sheehan; one from Austria, Karl Rohan and Kurt Feichtinger, and one from Israel, Sam Lev and Maury Stampf.

title: LABOR, IN A COMEBACK, WINS COUNCIL VOTING IN MAJOR ENGLISH CITIES
description: The Labor Party, battered for two years by defections and splits, scored a convincing comeback in yesterday's elections to local councils in England and Wales -the first major test of partisan strength since the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took power two years ago.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John A. Fahlberg has been named to the new post of vice president of marketing and corporate planning for Murphy Motor Freight Lines Inc, St. Paul.

title: HOUSE PANEL OPPOSES REACTOR
description: A House committee dealt a major blow today to the Administration's plans to make greater use of nuclear energy by narrowly voting to ''de-authorize'' the Clinch River breeder reactor and to spend an initial $20 million to terminate the project.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Judge Orders Release Of Beef Seized as Harmful
description: A Federal judge ruled today that 170,000 pounds of seized beef allegedly contaminated with DES, the banned livestock growth hormone, would not be harmful to the public and ordered it released for retail sale.

title: Geoffrey Colvin
description: Know where I was when I heard that the space shuttle had landed? Aboard the Times Square shuttle. About to leave Times Square. The conductor got on the loudspeaker and said: ''Attention, please. Attention, please. The spaceship has landed safely on Earth.'' Then the doors closed, and we shuddered and lurched toward Grand Central.

title: A Walk Through History In Stuyvesant Park Area
description: The Stuyvesant Park area of Manhattan is the focus of a walking tour tomorrow that begins at 2 P.M. at the statue of Peter Stuyvesant in the park, 16th Street, between Second and Third Avenues. The tour will be led, rain or shine, by Rex Wasserman, a landscape architect who is working on restoring the park, part of the 17th-century farm of Peter Stuyvesant.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1981
description: International Close U.S.-Japan consultations on matters of vital interest to Tokyo were pledged by President Reagan in a White House talk with Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki, according to a United States official. Japan has objected to a lack of consultations on such issues as Mr. Reagan's decision to lift restrictions on grain shipments to the Soviet Union. (Page A1, Column 1.) Britain's Laborites scored a comeback in elections to local councils in England and Wales in the first major test of party strength in two years. The Labor Party took control from the Conservatives in London, Manchester, Liverpool, Birmingham and Leeds and staged surprising upsets in some rural Conservative strongholds. (A1:2.)

title: EFFORTS TO REHABILITATE CROWN HEIGHTS APARTMENT HOUSES
description: The architectural quality of the houses of Crown Heights in Brooklyn are generally believed to rival any in the city. But many of the imposing six-story English Tudor apartment buildings of the community have a look of faded glory.

title: Index; International
description: Political activity beginning to stir in Turkey again A2 Schmidt silent on personal attacks by Begin A3 U.S. doubts Libya will cut off oil in reply to ouster of diplomats A3 U.S. priest who was missing in El Salvador criticizes U.S. A4 Around the World A5 Mexican leader criticizes U.S. on Nicaraguan policy A6 Arms aid for Argentina passes a House hurdle A7 Special U.S. envoy reaches Beirut for talks in crisis A8 Mood in Damascus is calm despite crisis over Lebanon A9 Government/Politics Watt says national parks are in ''shameful'' condition A17 White House defends decision to abolish Carter judicial plan A17 D'Amato expected to recommend Federal judge in Brooklyn B3 General Around the Nation A16 Videotaped testimony dominates ex-Tennessee Governor's trial A16 Ten indicted in alleged Dominica overthrow plot A16 Pay raises in New York being outpaced in other areas B2 Jersey town seeks to cope with strike by firemen B2 Detective denies contention he coached Crimmins B3 Official discounts radar as cause of collision in harbor B3 Two wives among dead in Air Force plane explosion B6 Features/Notes Man in the News: Zenko Suzuki, blunt guest from Japan A10 Notes on People C30 News Analysis Hedrick Smith discusses Reagan's victory on budget A1 Weekend

title: N.Y.R.A. Franchise Renewal Questioned
description: The co-chairmen of the state's racing task force said that they had not been persuaded by testimony presented during hearings here today to extend the New York Racing Association's franchise past 1985 or to agree to a proposal to float some $70 million in bonds to help the N.Y.R.A. repay its current debt and make capital improvements at the tracks.

title: 3 EX-PRESIDENTS TENTATIVELY FAVOR SUNDAY VOTING PLAN
description: Three former Presidents said in letters introduced at a Senate hearing today that they welcomed, with reservations, a proposal to shift Election Day to a Sunday and to vote within nationally uniform polling hours.

title: Consumer Credit Up For March
description: Americans bought $3.11 billion more on credit than they repaid on old debts during March, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the largest growth of consumer installment credit in 18 months.

title: Agreement Reported In Purolator Case
description: One of the four defendants in the $1.9 million Purolator robbery in which three guards were slain has agreed to testify for the state in exchange for leniency, officials said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Citing sizable increases in interest rates recently, two Federal agencies said today that they would raise the rates under their Government-insured mortgage programs to new high levels.

title: Around the Nation; Proposal to Rescue Boston Is Defeated by Legislature
description: A bill that would have enabled Boston to free itself and its school system from a financial crisis was killed by a wide margin today in the State legislature.

title: Youth Sent to Jail For Anti-Semitic Act
description: A teen-ager was sentenced to six months in jail for painting swastikas and the word ''Jew'' outside the home of a Jewish neighbor last summer.

title: 125 New Fire Marshals Sworn In To Fight Growing Arson Problem
description: In response to the growing arson problem in New York City, Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes yesterday swore in 125 fire marshals - the largest number ever appointed at one time by the Fire Department.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Agripost Inc., Miami, has elected Edward C. West president and chief operating officer. Paul Faske, who resigned his previous post as president, retains the positions of chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Company News; NU-WEST BIDS AGAIN FOR CALGARY POWER
description: The Nu-West Group Ltd. today renewed a $517 million (Canadian) offer for 48 percent of Calgary Power Ltd., a major utility company that supplied more than 65 percent of the energy requirements in Alberta Province last year.

title: NATIONWIDE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A NEW BREED OF CLOWNS- BOUNCIER, BRIGHTER AND COED
description: THE carefree buffoonery of the 27 clowns, three of them women, who perform acts and entr'actes in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus unit playing Madison Square Garden through May 31, is a series of infinitely varied capers, a premeditated assault on the senses. If the circus is spectacle designed to numb the onlooker with extravagant panorama, clowning is its quintessential art, the one thing without which the circus simply could not be the circus.

title: Rockets Beat Celtics, Tie Series
description: Bill Willoughby, who has had trouble staying in pro basketball, and Allen Leavell, the 105th choice in the 1979 college draft, gave Moses Malone unexpected help tonight at the Boston Garden as the Houston Rockets defeated the Boston Celtics, 92-90, and tied the National Basketball Association championship series at a game each.

title: GALT MACDERMOT OFFERS NEW MUSIC WITH A PULSE
description: GALT MacDERMOT, who wrote the score for the innovative rock musical ''Hair'' in 1967 and won a Grammy Award for the ''Best Jazz Composition of the Year'' in 1961 for ''African Waltz,'' is now into a musical area on which he cannot put a label. It is music that he originally wrote for a band made up of his wife, himself and four of his five children that has since grown beyond the family to become an organization called the New Pulse Jazz Band.

title: Why Destroy Conrail to Save It?
description: Should Conrail, the lumbering rail freight giant, be given one last chance to make it on its own? Not according to President Reagan. He is asking Congress for permission to auction off the system's profitable lines and abandon all the rest. Few insiders believe he is bluffing.

title: Food Fair Payments
description: Food Fair Inc., which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act since October 1978, said it estimated that the first payment to trade creditors and institutional lenders after confirmation of its plan of arrangement would be 27 cents to 29 cents on the dollar, rather than the 30 cents originally contemplated. Food Fair said that it planned to seek confirmation of its plan of arrangement with funds on hand by June 30. The company said that the shortfall, totaling $3 million to $9 million, would be made up as soon as funds were available, but in no event later than Jan. 15, 1982.

title: 'LET THE IRISH INHERIT ALL THEIR LAND'
description: To the Editor:

title: RARE-BOOK FAIR OPENS AT ARMORY TOMORROW
description: One of the rare literary treasures that will be offered at the annual Antiquarian Book Fair - it begins tomorrow evening and runs through Monday afternoon at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street -is a letter from J.D. Salinger, the reclusive author of ''The Catcher in the Rye.''

title:
RED SMITH;
Baseball's Star Chamber
description: THE point to remember about baseball's kangaroo court that fined Harry Dalton $50,000 for telling the truth is that the court penalizes dissenters only. A majority of baseball's officials, including the commissioner himself, have had their say about labor relations in the business but they don't get fined as long as they parrot the party line.

title: GENSTAR LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Advertising; Philip Dougherty; Estee Lauder Products For Men Goes to AC&R
description: A C & R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates & Company, must have been doing a nice job for the various women's products from Estee Lauder Inc., because it has been rewarded with all of the men's.

title: Jail Officials Report That a Slayer Worked for 9 Months as a Guard
description: Shortages of personnel and funds are being blamed for an administrative oversight in which a convicted slayer was able to conceal his identity and work as a guard in the King County jail for nine months.

title: ANGELS DEFEAT YANKS,2-1
description: Gene Michael and Jim Fregosi exchanged strategic moves in the eighth inning tonight as the Angels nursed a one-run lead with Yankees runners on second and third base. Fregosi, the California manager, won the battle and the game as two Angel relief pitchers prevailed over two Yankee pinch-hitters and California took the last game of a four-game series, 2-1.

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DODGERS TOP PHIL'S BYSTROM,2-1
description: Steve Garvey's run-scoring single in the eighth inning tonight gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and handed Marty Bystrom his first major league defeat after seven victories.

title: 30 Said to Die as Argentine Plane Crashes Into the Rio de la Plata
description: An Argentine jetliner crashed into the Rio de la Plata today after two unsuccessful attempts to land in a thunderstorm. Airline officials said all 30 people aboard were apparently killed.

title: BOYCOTT ON RIGHTS AMENDMENT DIVIDES PSYCHIATRIC CONVENTION
description: When the American Psychiatric Association meets for its annual convention in New Orleans next week, some of its members will be conspicuously absent.

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
RECORD RATE ON 30-YEAR U.S. BONDS
description: The United States Treasury was forced yesterday to pay the highest price ever for 30-year financing of Government debt. The Treasury auctioned $2 billion of new 13 7/8 percent, 30-year bonds at an average yield of 13.99 percent, up from 12.68 percent in February.

title: The South Bronx Looks to Itself
description: Except when they need it as a backdrop for election-year portraits, Federal officials obviously prefer to forget the South Bronx. President Reagan's preoccupation is with economic recovery everywhere else, which only threatens the once promised relief for the Charlotte Street scene that moved him so.

title: 'KILL AND KILL AGAIN,' MELODRAMA FROM SOUTH AFRICA
description: ''KILL AND KILL AGAIN,'' which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters, is a martial-arts (a euphemism, it seems, for all variations of karate and kung fu) melodrama made in South Africa, with a predominantly South African cast headed by James Ryan and Anneline Kriel, a former Miss World. He is dark, lithe, wiry and fast. She is blond and pretty, recalling the young Ursula Andress. The movie is Occidental camp.

title: SAUDIS, OTHERS PLEDGE $25 BILLION FOR I.M.F. AID
description: The International Monetary Fund has obtained loan commitments from Arab oil exporting countries and some key Western industrial nations for up to $25 billion to help debt-ridden developing countries finance foreign payments and energy projects.

title: ROSSMOOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PUBLISHING: TWO MORE FROM ISSAC BASHEVIS SINGER
description: ALTHOUGH he has won the Nobel Prize and virtually every other major literary award, 76-year-old Isaac Bashevis Singer shows no signs of slowing down. Later this year Farrar, Straus & Giroux will publish another collection of his short stories, while next month Doubleday will publish ''Lost in America,'' the third volume of what the author calls ''an autobiography I never intended to write.''

title: WITNESS DENIES ANY COACHING OF CRIMMINS
description: A detective denied repeated contentions by the defense yesterday that he had suggested possible answers to Craig S. Crimmins about Mr. Crimmins's knowledge of the murder of Helen Hagnes at the Metropolitan Opera House last summer.

title: HOLLY SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
DelBello Stands Firm On Landfill Closing
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, announced that the Croton Landfill would close at the end of 1981 as planned, and not immediately, as the village had asked after a fire there two weeks ago.

title: STAGE: THE MISSES TAYLOR AND STAPLETON IN 'FOXES'
description: IT may have taken a long time for her to get to Broadway, but she has arrived in high style. In Lillian Hellman's ''The Little Foxes,'' Elizabeth Taylor has found just the right vehicle to launch her career as a stage actress. And she rewards the role of Regina Giddens, that malignant Southern bitch-goddess, with a performance that begins gingerly, soon gathers steam and then explodes into a black and thunderous storm that may just knock you out of your seat. Throw in a snappy supporting cast - led by Maureen Stapleton in a rending portrait of a fading, dipsomaniacal plantation belle - and you can begin to picture the crackling entertainment that opened at the Martin Beck last night.

title: 'THIS IS ELVIS,' THE OFFICIAL STORY
description: SICK and tired as anyone may be of the Presley mystique by now, ''This Is Elvis'' is fascinating. This isn't a particularly well-made film, or even a truthful one - as a matter of fact, its fraudulence is its one uncompromising aspect. And yet it is mesmerizing, if not as a drama or documentary, then as an artifact. Here is the lavishly embalmed Elvis that Elvis's caretakers would have you see. Here also is the buoyant talent on which the legend was made. And here, most haunting of all, is the process by which the talent deteriorated, by which the man became the relic. There's some fabulous performance footage, too.

title: U.S. DOUBTS LIBYA WILL STOP OIL FLOW
description: The State Department asserted today that the United States did not expect Libya to cut off exports of oil to the American market in retaliation for yesterday's order expelling Libyan diplomats from Washington.

title: Music Noted in Brief; by Peter G. Davis; Richard Shirk Treads Familiar Pianistic Path
description: Richard Shirk's piano recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night was a model of technical efficiency and good musical manners.

title: STAGE: 'THE IDOL MAKERS,' SOHO SOUTHERN GOTHIC
description: ''THE Idol Makers,'' a new play by Stephen Davis Parks at the SoHo Repertory Theater, is a gnarled southern Gothic tale about an ingrown backwoods family. In dealing with people who are largely inarticulate, the play is itself at a loss for words. When one of the characters says, ''I got a callus on my tongue,'' one must conjecture that the callus may be contagious.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE ROCQUEFORT PRINCIPLE
description: France's campaign for presidential elections this Sunday has turned into a suspense story, a good deal more exciting than most people supposed earlier this year.

title: NEW ACCORD TO END IMPASSE ON BUDGET REPORTED IN ALBANY
description: Legislative leaders and Governor Carey announced agreement today on virtually the same version of the $16.6 billion state budget they had presented as an accord on April 28.

title: Notes On People; A Musical Achiever in His Own Right
description: His mother was Dorothy Fields, the lyricist of some 500 Broadway and popular songs (''I'm in the Mood for Love,'' ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' ''The Way You Look Tonight''). His uncle, and her longtime collaborator, was Herbert Fields, and his grandfather was Lew Fields, of the comedy team of Weber & Fields.

title: ROCK: LONDON'S SPANDAU BALLET
description: BRITISH rock bands make New York debuts frequently these days, but most of them sort of skulk into town, victims of record-company austerity and the new wave's own antipretensions. Not so Spandau Ballet, which gave its New York first local performance Wednesday night at the Underground with a full, nostaglically old-fashioned blast of hype, complete with a London vanguard fashion show and a disco full of exotically costumed trendies.

title: DEMOCRATS IN HOUSE WHO BACKED BUDGET
description: Sixty-three House Democrats and all 190 House Republicans voted today to select a budget proposal for the fiscal year 1982 backed by President Reagan over a measure drawn up by the Democratic majority on the House Budget Committee.

title: A MODEST DEREGULATORY PROPOSAL FOR AUTOS
description: To the Editor:

title: PRUDENTIAL BUILDING MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
DANCES, EXHIBITS, TOURS AT INDIAN MUSEUM PARTY
description: When the late George G. Heye was working in Arizona as a mining engineer at the turn of the century, he spotted a Navajo Indian mending an embroidered shirt. He bought it for $5. Some 400,000 Indian artifacts later, Heye established the Museum of the American Indian on May 10, 1916, and turned over his holdings, with an endowment, to the trustees of the newly created institution.

title: Sports News Briefs; Army-Navy Game Set In Philadelphia Until '84
description: The Army-Navy football game will be held at Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium for the next three years, Mayor William J. Green of Philadelphia has announced.

title: BRISTOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TURKEY'S FROZEN POLITICAL LIFE IS BEGINNING TO MELT
description: A thaw has begun in Turkish political activity, which was frozen last September when the military leaders seized power.

title: Pop Jazz; NEW ORLEANS IS A RHYTHM FESTIVAL; NEW ORLEANS
description: THE 12th New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, which closes this weekend, presents approximately 3,000 musicians each year and boasts an annual attendance of around 250,000. It would be one of America's most impressive music festivals in numbers alone, but it is even more impressive for another reason: it is a festival with a vision.

title: RELUCTANT REFORMER OF THE TRANSIT SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: INGMAR BERGMAN CONFIDES IN STUDENTS
description: Intuition, says Ingmar Bergman, is the essence of creativity and the foundation of his unparalleled success as a film maker.

title: Administration Acts to Funnel Contracts to Depressed Areas
description: The Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition announced today that the Reagan Administration had pledged to continue for another year a program that funnels military procurement contracts into areas of long-term high unemployment.

title: A BROADWAY PARTY FOR ELIZABETH TAYLOR
description: Regina Giddens, the acid-tongued heroine of ''The Little Foxes'' may have wanted the world, as she proclaims in the play, but last night at the Martin Beck Theater it was Elizabeth Taylor Warner who won it, or at least that part of it that goes to first nights in New York.

title: Two Buy Cimco
description: The Federal Resources Corporation said it was joining Mid-Texas Inc. of Houston in the purchase of the Cimco Drilling Company from the Delhi International Corporation for $22.5 million. The transaction includes producing and prospective oil and gas leases in Gonzales County, Tex.

title: DRANETZ ENGINEERING LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ZONDERVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Appellate Division Says It Erred In an Opinion on the Moon Sect
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said yesterday that it had erred in an opinion that was quoted in an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday.

title: Loews' Sale of Stock
description: The Loews Corporation disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had sold 314,600 common shares of American Broadcasting Companies between April 15 and April 30, leaving it with 1.4 million shares, or 5 percent, of the common. The shares were sold at $32 to $36 a share, the company said.

title: Union Carbide Plans Silicon Factory
description: The Union Carbide Corporation confirmed that it planned to build a plant in the Pacific Northwest to produce 1,000 metric tons of polycrystalline silicon yearly, with production to begin in late 1984. The silicon ingots would be sold to the semiconductor industry.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
General Dynamics Drops
description: Citing the effects of a slow economy here and abroad, David S. Lewis, chairman of the General Dynamics Corporation, a diversifed maker of aircraft, submarines and building materials, told shareholders that the company's earnings declined 15.2 percent, to $30.8 million, or 56 cents a share, in the first quarter from $36.3 million, or 67 cents a share, earned in the first quarter of 1980.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: The U.N. Today; May 8, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Galen Brand Dies at 63; Designer and Ex-Editor
description: Galen Brand, an interior designer and a former editor at the magazine House & Garden, died Monday of cancer at Bennington Hospital in Bennington, Vt. She was 63 years old and a resident of Manhattan and Manchester, Vt.

title: DANCE: PENNSYLVANIA BALLET GIVES AN ECCENTRIC PROGRAM STYLISHLY
description: THE Pennsylvania Ballet, which usually dances well, danced well again on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But its program of two new productions and a revival was decidedly odd. One of the new productions was intentionally odd; the other, odd in parts. And the revival was as mad as a hatter.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Around the World; Purported Royal Tapes Barred by German Court
description: A court here today banned a magazine from publishing transcripts of what were said to be telephone conversations between Prince Charles of Britain and his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer.

title: TEXACO IN GUATEMALA: A LOW-KEY 'EUREKA!'
description: ''It isn't like in the movies, where it gushes out of the ground and people start shouting Eureka!,'' said Glen Frantz, a Texaco foreman from Longview, Tex., who speaks about as fast as heavy oil pours. ''More likely they just stand around and say, 'Well, there it is.' ''

title: Music Noted in Brief;  Rare Clarinet Works Offered by David Harman
description: Every composition David Harman's clarinet touched on Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall turned into music. He may not have the sweetest tone in the world, but the notes that emerged from his instrument bore striking relations to one another.

title: Mrs. Truman Is in 'Noble Spirits' After Surgery on a Fractured Hip
description: Bess Truman's fractured right hip was rebuilt with metal and acrylic glue today in a 75-minute operation, and her doctor said that the 96-year-old former First Lady was in ''noble spirits.''

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $564,000 tax credit for the quarter and $2,368,000 tax credit for the 9 months...C-Includes $312,000 gain from cumulative effect of a change in accounting

title: 2 AIR FORCE WIVES AMONG 21 DEAD IN JET WERE LEARNING OF JOB STRESS
description: Two servicemen's wives were passengers on an Air Force tracking plane that exploded yesterday, killing all 21 persons aboard, the Air Force said today.

title: Around the World; Friend Testifies 'Ripper' Vanished in Red-Light Areas
description: Peter Sutcliffe, the accused killer known as the Yorkshire Ripper, disappeared for short periods during drinking trips in red-light districts, a close friend said today at Mr. Sutcliffe's trial.

title: COURT UPHOLDS LAW REQUIRING LANDLORD TO PERMIT CABLE TV
description: The State Court of Appeals today rejected a challenge to a state law that requires landlords to permit the installation of cable television facilities for the use of his tenants, or of the tenants of other buildings.

title: MIDLAND MORTGAGE INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $360,000 extraordinary gain for the qr and $375,000 extraordinary gain for the 9 mos...C-Including $60,929 extraordinary gain for the qr and $1,760,000 and $101,643 extraordinary credits for the 9 mos

title: House Panel Approves Proposal Cutting Some Unemployment Aid
description: The House Ways and Means subcommittee on trade yesterday approved most of a plan by President Reagan to change and drastically reduce the program of Federal trade adjustment assistance for workers.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Di Bonaventura, Pianist, Plays Early Debussy
description: Anthony di Bonaventura's recital of piano music by Debussy and Ravel at the Abraham Goodman House on Sunday afternoon offered portraits of two artists as young men. Debussy's ''Danse Bohemienne,'' ''Ballade,'' ''Danse'' and ''Masques'' were all rich in invention but lacking in the architectural tautness that marks his best music. Mr. di Bonaventura played these pieces and Ravel's ''Miroirs'' with scrupulous care and elegance -though perhaps a little brutally above the level of forte.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Music Noted in Brief; by Peter G. Davis; Rosemary George Sings A Zumbro Premiere
description: Rosemary George displayed a pure soprano and admirable technical security at her Abraham Goodman House recital on Tuesday night accompanied at the piano by Margo Garrett.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: by Peter G. Davis
description: Mayor Koch, a former Spanish guitar student at the Greenwich House Music School, helped that organization celebrate its 75th anniversary in Town Hall last Saturday afternoon. For the concert's grand finale, Mayor Koch narrated Prokofiev's ''Peter and the Wolf'' with the Greenwich House Music School Orchestra conducted by Edward Houser.

title: 'SQUEEZE PLAY,' BURLESQUE-STYLE BASEBALL
description: ''SQUEEZE PLAY'' is a zesty movie of its kind, though its kind is bound to seem stupid to some and objectionable to others. This is a low-budget bawdy comedy, full of dopey routines and live-wire characters, one of whom actually goes so far as to eat a banana split with ketchup and pickles on top. The material is idiocy. But the actors are fresh and likable, and at least they don't stand still long enough to wear out their welcome.

title: Upper West Side Walk
description: A walking tour of the Upper West Side, with stops at churches, schools and historic sites, from the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to Grant's Tomb, will be given Sunday at 2 P.M. by the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: FIREFIGHTERS BATTLE BLAZE IN L.I. STATE PARK
description: Several thousand acres of state parkland on Long Island were swept by a fire today that destroyed pine trees, scrub oak and underbrush and threatened dozens of houses on the park's borders.

title: SURVEY SHOWS PAY RAISES IN CITY ARE LAGGING BEHIND OTHER AREAS
description: A wide range of samplings shows wage increases in New York City have been outpaced in recent years by those in the country's other major labor markets, a Federal labor official said yesterday.

title: LOS ALAMOS PHYSICIST MAY GET POST AS SCIENCE ADVISOR IN WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House is expected to name a 41-yearold nuclear physicist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., as science adviser to President Reagan, according to sources in the Government and the scientific community.

title: Notes On People; Sports as Seen Through the Eyes of an Artist
description: She ''played a little basketball,'' growing up in Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay area and at Erasmus Hall High School, but when Elaine de Kooning began painting basketball and baseball images in the 1940's ''the genesis was sports photos on the newsstands - they looked like exciting abstractions,'' the artist said yesterday. Soon she was going to games, traveling with the New York Yankees and Baltimore Orioles in 1953 and 1954.

title: At the Movies; by Chris Chase; Danny Aiello, the actor, still a working man.
description: THIS is about dreams. Describing the man Danny Aiello plays in ''The Floating Light Bulb,'' Woody Allen's new comedy at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Mr. Allen says the character ''is trapped in his job as a waiter,'' adding: ''He's not content to be that. He had bigger dreams.''

title: NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Business People; Japan's New York 'Dean'
description: Toshihiro Tomabechi, the 64-year-old president of the Mitsubishi International Corporation, is known as ''the dean'' of the Japanese business community in New York. And when Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan was in town earlier this week, Mr. Tomabechi, who is also president of the Japanese Chamber of Commerce in New York, played his part with elan and humor.

title: SPECIAL U.S. ENVOY REACHES BEIRUT FOR TALKS IN THE ISRAELI-SYRIAN CRISIS
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, arrived here today for talks aimed at calming the crisis over the presence in eastern Lebanon of Syrian antiaircraft missiles that Israel has threatened to destroy.

title: OAKWOOD PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; the company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Jill Kroesen Presents Music-Theater Piece
description: A sometimes charming aspect of 1960's avant-gardism was a spirit of childlike amateurism. Performers of erratic craft would appear in informal events in which the projection of personality - often a kookily glamorous personality - would take precedence over anything so old-fashioned as art.

title: Broadway; 'CAGE AUX FOLLES' DUE AS MUSICAL COMEDY SET IN NEW ORLEANS
description: THE Paris stage hit ''La Cage aux Folles,'' which has already had two film adaptations, is bound for Broadway next season as a musical comedy. The story will be basically the same, involving the owner of a homosexual nightclub and his transvestite lover who stars there, but the setting and title will be different. The show has been moved from the French Riviera to New Orleans and will be called ''The Queen of Basin Street.''

title: Judge With History Of Arrests Resigns
description: ALBANY (AP) - A State Supreme Court justice with a history of arrests for drunken driving stepped down yesterday, the same day the Commission on Judicial Conduct recommended his removal from office.

title: DURR-FILLAUER MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: 1980 net restated to reflect LIFO inventory accounting method adopted last year and share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split effective May 1, 1981

title: REPUBLIC MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income and after a tax credit of $62,000

title: Sports News Briefs; Rams Drop Reynolds
description: The Los Angeles Rams have released Jack Reynolds, their all-pro middle linebacker.

title: HARBOR CRASH LINKED TO RADAR, OFFICIAL ASSERTS
description: The collision between a Staten Island ferryboat and a Norwegian freighter in the fog Wednesday morning was not the result of radar malfunction, according to the head of the city's Bureau of Ferry and General Aviation Operations.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Botanical Garden Sale
description: Hundreds of plants, including floral, herbal and vegetable varieties and succulents, will be on sale this weekend at the annual flower market of the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and Moshulu Parkway in the Bronx.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope this time we've got it right.'' - Stanley Fink, Assembly Speaker, on New York State budget agreement. (A1:3.)

title: SANDS IS BURIED IN BELFAST WITH I.R.A. MILITARY SALUTE
description: The outlawed Irish Republican Army staged a funeral today for Robert Sands, burying him with what it called ''full military honors.''

title: A Caribbean Mother's Day
description: Calypso singers and musicians from the West Indies and Africa will perform at the fourth Mother's Day Caribbean All-Star Festival on Sunday at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: Advertising; Y.&R. and Ogilvy Await Decision by Hallmark
description: Young & Rubicam and Ogilvy & Mather are both awaiting a decision by Hallmark Cards on the destination of the Ambassador Cards division. This unit's advertising was previously handled by Barickman Advertising in Kansas City, Mo., a subsidiary of Doyle Dane Bernbach, that lost it when D.D.B. took on competition business.

title: Paul Winter at Cathedral
description: ''Earth Mass,'' a composition by Paul Winter, will have its world premiere Sunday at 11 A.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Equatorial Guinea Makes Arrests
description: The authorities in Equatorial Guinea arrested a large number of soldiers and civilians last week for allegedly plotting against President Teodoro Obiang Nguema.

title: Sports News Briefs; Watkins Glen Loses Race; Track Failed to Pay Debts
description: The International Auto Sports Federation, after a meeting of its Formula One commission, today removed the United States Grand Prix East at Watkins Glen, N.Y., from its schedule because of the track's failure to pay debts to race teams by May 1.

title: U.S. May Sell Butter Abroad
description: The United States is considering selling surplus butter on the world market - a move that could lead to Eastern Europeans buying it for less money than Americans pay, an Administration official said today.

title: IOWA-ILLINOIS GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
U.S. Vows to Link Aid To Nations' U.N. Votes
description: The Reagan Administration warned today that the way countries vote at the United Nations would help determine how much American aid they receive.

title: Brooklyn Men Held In Slaying in Tavern
description: Two Brooklyn men were held without bond in the Nov. 1 slaying of a Queens bar manager during a holdup in which 10 patrons were stripped of $1,500 in cash plus their jewelry.

title: NEW YORK CITY SCHOOLS BEGIN TO RECRUIT HUNDREDS OF TEACHERS
description: At a time when enrollments are declining and teaching jobs are supposedly scarce, the New York City Board of Education - which five years ago laid off 15,000 teachers - has opened a major recruiting drive.

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CITY CANNOT BAR DRIVER-ONLY CARS ON FOUR BRIDGES
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that New York City exceeded its authority in seeking to bar cars carrying only the drivers from entering Manhattan over the four toll-free East River bridges during morning rush hours.

title: MORSE SHOE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BASIN AND RANGE. By John McPhee. 215 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suit Filed in Effort to Get Tillis a Bout With Weaver
description: Attorneys for James Tillis, a heavyweight contender, today filed suit in Cook County Circuit Court in an effort to get Tillis a title bout with Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association champion.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
E. 55th St. Building Destroyed by Fire
description: A four-alarm fire of suspicious origin destroyed an East Side brownstone and damaged the two adjacent buildings, United Press International reported.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE guests who were invited to Barbara de Portago and Jason Grant's ''Pick-A-Tune'' cocktail party Wednesday night were a bit puzzled about just what the theme meant, since there were no tunes at all at the party - just your usual snappy New York conversation along with wine and hors d'oeuvres.

title: MORAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $989,000 gain from the sale of capiial assets; shr earnings refllct a 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov 1980

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earns reflect a 15 percent stock divd paid in Feb

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said it had negotiated a new $2 billion revolving credit agreement with a syndicate of 27 U.S., Canadian and European banks led by Chase Manhattan.

title: REAGAN TELLS SUZUKI HE PLANS TO CONSULT ON IMPORTANT ISSUES
description: President Reagan met Japan's Prime Minister, Zenko Suzuki, today and reportedly told him that the United States would ''closely consult'' with Japan on matters of vital interest to that nation.

title: MEXICAN ASSAILS U.S. ON NICARAGUA VIEWS
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo last night indirectly but sharply criticized United States policy toward Nicaragua and pledged that ''Mexico will defend the cause of Nicaragua as its own.''

title: BENGUET CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METS TURN BACK GIANTS, 3-2, AFTER TORRE SHUFFLES LINEUP
description: The Mets held a meeting with their manager last night, held another meeting without their manager and then broke their recent slide by defeating the San Francisco Giants, 3-2, with a heavily revamped lineup.

title: 31 Killed in Collision in Java
description: A bus and a train collided early today at a railroad crossing in central Java, killing 31 people and seriously injuring 20 others, the police said. They said that all of the victims were on the bus, which was dragged more than 150 yards on the tracks before the train could stop.

title: INTEGRAPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Advertising; U.S. News Appoints Head
description: After less than one year with U.S. News & World Report, James H. McIlhenny has become the boss. Yesterday, John H. Sweet, the 73-year-old chairman, president and chief executive, turned those last two titles over to his 53-yearold associate, who joined the company last August as an executive vice president and chief operating officer. He so quickly adapted to the business that by mid-October he was poolside in Palm Springs, Calif., enjoying the Magazine Publishers Association annual meeting with all the rest of the mighties.

title: HERITAGE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mobil Bids U.S.  Fill Oil Reserve
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Corporation, told the company's annual meeting yesterday that the United States should accelerate the filling of its Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Guatemalan Official Flies to U.S.  For Talks on Resumption of Aid
description: Foreign Minister Rafael Castillo Valdez left for Washington today for talks on the possible resumption of United States military aid to Guatemala, officials said.

title: FOR 'FALSETTOS' AUTHOR, WATCHFUL AGONIZING
description: Although ''March of the Falsettos'' has been doing splendidly at the box office since the musical opened to critical acclaim at the Playwrights Horizons a few weeks ago, its 29-year-old author, William Finn, has taken to cringing in the lobby. On a couch out there, where he can hear the performance, Mr. Finn scribbles notes for changes in the lyrics, agonizing aloud over words that displease him.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MOOD IN DAMASCUS CALM DESPITE CRISIS
description: For the last several days, the traffic islands of this hilly capital city have been manned by schoolboys and schoolgirls in smart crimson uniforms. Syria is observing ''International Traffic Week,'' and the schoolchildren are out in force as part of their civics lesson.

title: DEMOCRATS SPLIT ON KEY VOTE/PRESIDENT 'GRATEFUL'
description: The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives gave President Reagan a victory today by adopting a budget that is intended to curtail the growth of Federal spending sharply and to change the direction of government.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner Funeral Service Held for Slain Housing Officer Police officers carrying coffin of a Housing Authority police lieutenant, Jan H. Brinkers, into Roman Catholic Church of the Visitation in the Bronx. Lieutenant Brinkers was shot while off duty Monday when he tried to stop a robbery in a bar.

title: FROM DESSOFF CHOIRS, A MODERN VIEW OF BACH
description: Bach created his B minor Mass not for any singers or musicians he knew or would ever know, but for a posterity he could only guess at. Tonight's performance of this music by the Dessoff Choirs at Alice Tully Hall will try to bring together two worlds three centuries apart - mixing Bach's Baroque sensibilities with those of our own.

title: Ford Unit Wins Big Army Contract
description: A Ford Motor Company subsidiary won a $159.2 million contract for the first phase of construction of a new mobile antiaircraft gun, the Pentagon announced.

title: Utility's Ratings Lowered
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company's bond ratings were lowered today by Standard & Poor's, an action likely to force upward the interest rate on a planned sale of $200 million of first-mortgage bonds later this year. Standard & Poor's dropped the rating of the utility's first-mortgage bonds from A to A-minus.

title: WATT SAYS FUNDS FOR PARK LAND SHOULD BE USED FOR RESTORATION
description: Apologizing for what he called the ''shameful'' state of America's national parks, Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt said today that money set aside for acquiring park land should be used to restore and improve those areas already within the park system.

title: 'Prometheus' Alfresco
description: ''Prometheus,'' the tragedy by Aeschylus, will be presented for the next two weekends by the Gallatin Arts Project, a student acting troupe, at New York Unversity.

title: Carol Bellamy
description: When President Reagan made his dramatic plea to Congress last week for passage of his economic package, he called it ''the only answer that we have left'' to stem inflation and control Federal spending. He could - and should - look harder.

title: FOR STATE PLANES, UNOFFICIAL BUSINESS
description: New York State allocated $2.3 million last year to operate three state airplanes and two helicopters that were supposed to be used exclusively by state officials and employees on official business.

title: Sallie Mae Plans New Borrowing
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, said yesterday that it planned to begin borrowing in the capital markets under its own name on May 18.

title: NEWCOURT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income; 1980 results do not include the results of Nadler & Larimer Inc acquired as of Apr 1, 1980 and accounted for as a purchase

title: Energy Issues Lead As Dow Rises 5.05
description: A pattern of continued small but persistent gains in energy issues helped to send stock prices higher yesterday. Joining in the advance were retail, precious-metal, brokerage, computer and technology issues.

title: MISSING FOR 10 DAYS IN SALVADOR, PRIEST RETURNS AND CRITICIZES U.S.
description: An American priest who disappeared for 10 days in El Salvador strongly criticized Washington's support for the governing junta here before flying back to the United States today.

title: House Panel Backs Bill
description: For a 50 Silver Coin

title: Ex-Hostage to Head New Peace Center
description: One of the American hostages released by Iranian authorities on Jan. 20 - Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr.

title: Virgin Islands In Hess Pact
description: The Virgin Islands Senate today approved a 16-year tax agreement with the Amerada Hess Corporation, insuring that one of the world's largest oil refineries will continue operating in this American territory.

title: Fitzsimmons Rites Held With Few in Attendance
description: Four mourners attended a private funeral mass today for Frank Fitzsimmons, head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters for 14 years, who died yesterday of lung cancer.

title: Economic Scene; PROBLEMS FACE ADMINISTRATION
description: ALTHOUGH President Reagan won when the House voted on the 1982 budget, his economic program is still beset by a number of unexpected problems.

title: ST. LOUIS STUDENTS ASSAIL TUITION TIE TO INTEGRATION
description: A Federal proposal to further school desegregation here by paying college tuition for students who agree to attend primary and secondary schools outside their districts has come under harsh criticism from black and white students and parents.

title: Citibank Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Citibank, which says it is the biggest mortgage lender in New York, yesterday announced higher interest rates to finance the purchase of homes and cooperative apartments.

title: HOLDERS CRITICIZE AMAX CHIEF
description: The management of Amax Inc. was strongly criticized by stockholders at the company's annual meeting in New York yesterday for its rejection of a $4 billion takeover bid by the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: Company News; Wickes to Close Unit
description: The Wickes Companies said it would close its Tempo division, which operates 29 discount variety stores, mainly in the Western states. Tempo was acquired last August when Wickes bought Gamble-Skogmo Inc.

title: Butchers to Vote On New Pact Offer
description: The executive committee of a striking metropolitan wholesale butchers union unanimously recommended ratification of a new contract proposal yesterday, according to Joseph P. Neglia of the State Mediation Board. He said he could not divulge details of the tentative contract, pending the ratification vote.

title: COMMITTEE REJECTS A FOOD STAMP CURB
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today rejected a proposal by the Reagan Administration to reduce food stamp benefits for families with children eligible for free lunches at school.

title: Army Board Begins Investigation In Ammunition Plant Explosion
description: An Army board of inquiry today began an investigation of an explosion that injured four workers and blew a roof off a new $3.5 million building at the Radford Army Ammunition Plant.

title: Around the Nation; Missouri Attorney General Sued by Women's Group
description: The National Organization for Women filed a $10 million lawsuit today against the Missouri Attorney General, John Ashcroft, contending that he had intentionally damaged the women's rights movement.

title: MUSIC: SARAMAKA DRUMMERS
description: THE term ''maroons'' refers to runaway slaves who set up independent communities. Perhaps the best-known and most fiercely free of such societies grew up in the 18th century in the inland rain forests of the former Dutch Guiana, now known as Suriname. Long regarded as perhaps the most purely African of all New-World peoples, the Maroons actually evolved a remarkably vital culture of their own that conforms to African antecedents as much in spirit as in actual practice.

title: Mrs. King to Remain in Post
description: Billie Jean King agreed today to retain her post as president of the Women's Tennis Association. Mrs. King earlier had offered to resign following her public admission that she once had a lesbian relationship with her former secretary.

title: U.S. Oil Output Stable in Libya
description: Oil production in Libya by American companies proceeded normally yesterday in the aftermath of the Administration's decision to expel Libya's diplomats from the United States, oil company officials said.

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Japanese Car Sales
description: Domestic sales of four-wheel vehicles in April totaled 362,673, up 8.3 percent from a year ago, to exceed the level of the year before for the first time in 14 months, the Japan Automobile Dealer Association reported today.

title: GEIBERGER FOLLOWING A LIMITED SCHEDULE
description: In his 20 years on the PGA Tour, Al Geiberger has cheerfully played along with the jokes. People used to say he was so skinny he looked like a walking 1-iron. He was known as the golf pro who made peanut butter sandwiches famous.

title: Tuning Out Controls on Radio
description: It hasn't been long since the United States Court of Appeals was routinely insisting that Isaac Stern rather than Dolly Parton appear on some radio programs. The court sought to protect desirable and rare radio formats - those pledged to classical music. It thus instructed the Federal Communications Commission to give special weight, in reviewing station licenses, to a broadcaster's fidelity to any promises about unusual program content. But increasingly, the commission defied the court, arguing that the marketplace was a better judge of listener interest.

title: KLANSMEN ARE AMONG 10 INDICTED IN PLOT ON CARIBBEAN ISLAND NATION
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted 10 alleged mercenaries, six of them linked to the Ku Klux Klan, on charges of conspiring to overthrow the Government of the tiny Caribbean nation of Dominica.

title: TV Weekend; HOLOCAUST CHILDREN, ARMS SPENDING
description: AN excruciatingly painful subject is explored once again, tomorrow night at 7 o'clock on ABC-TV, in ''Children: the Holocaust.'' The hour opens with Liv Ullmann standing on a beautiful country hillside and watching a group of children playing. The place turns out to be Auschwitz, in Poland. She says: ''It is difficult to walk here and imagine that during another autumn, in my own lifetime, this serenity was shattered; that here, and throughout Europe, the earth lay, not warmed by sunlight, but scorched by the fire of war.''

title: A Constitutional Curb On Budget Is Approved
description: A Senate Judiciary subcommittee voted unanimously today for a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BASQUE TERRORISTS WOUND AIDE TO KING
description: A senior military aide to King Juan Carlos was seriously wounded today when Basque terrorists bombed his car. A colonel and two other soldiers were killed in the incident and a dozen passers-by were injured.

title: NATIONAL CITY LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Restaurants; by Mimi Sheraton; Big and glittering; small and intimate.
description: ONE of the more pleasant surprises we have had recently is Trumpets, the spacious and comfortably appointed restaurant in the Grand Hyatt, the relatively new hotel on 42d Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. After passing through the glitzy and extravagant lobby Trumpets turns out to be plush, somewhat sedate and thoroughly restful. Long beveled mirrors reflect the sparkle of candlelight, floral arrangements are graceful and the noise level is benign even when the place is filled or when the pianist plays in the adjoining cocktail lounge. The only flaws in the setting are chairs that are too low and slightly inadequate lighting that makes it difficult to read menus and checks. The staff is friendly and efficient, if somewhat unpolished. An especially hospitable touch comes in the matchbooks stamped with the name in which the reservation was made.

title: COAL UNION AND INDUSTRY RESUME TALKS
description: Negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the soft-coal industry resumed today after a three-week break, but there was no indication that the talks would bring a quick end to the 42-day nationwide strike.

title: Around the World; Mayor of Soweto Is Unhurt In Assassination Attempt
description: The Mayor of the South African black township of Soweto escaped an assassination attempt last night when he drove off just before a hand grenade exploded under his car, the police said today.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A FIRE STRIKE BY VOLUNTEERS UPSETS TOWN
description: While hastily trained substitute volunteers try to operate a Fire Department out of the city garage, the 70 plumbers, salesmen, real-estate brokers and others who make up the regular volunteer Fire Department here take turns picketing City Hall.

title: Sports News Briefs; Union Accuses the Owners Of Witholding Information
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association filed unfair-labor charges today with the National Labor Relations Board, accusing team owners of refusing to furnish financial information to the union.

title: Notes On People; Lots of Spirit, Not Too Much Organization
description: It was disco a hora Wednesday night as several hundred handclapping New Yorkers jammed together to celebrate Israel's 33d anniversary with a high spirited if somewhat confused birthday party at Xenon.

title: DANCE: A NEW AILEY HIT, ELISA MONTE'S 'TREADING'
description: TWENTY-ONE years after it was created, audiences are still clapping along, demanding encores and even rustling in anticipation of favorite sections of Alvin Ailey's ''Revelations,'' which was performed by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday at City Center. The dances that made up the rest of the program aren't likely to reach that status of American masterwork, but the company clearly has another hit on its hands with Elisa Monte's ''Treading.''

title: GUILD AND TIMES REACH ACCORD AFTER A BRIEF STRIKE
description: The Newspaper Guild struck The New York Times early yesterday for six and a half hours. The walkout ended after the two sides reached a tentative agreement in a contract dispute.

title: CENTRAL SOYA PATIENTLY CHANGES
description: Central Soya is a company that knows how to wait. Five decades of volatile commodity markets and prices have taught it how to muddle through slumps until better times arrive.

title: FILM: THE OSCAR WINNER FROM MOSCOW OPENS
description: THOUGH ''Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is a thoroughly Russian film, it may be the most devastating comment ever made about Hollywood, or at least about those members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that this year voted it the best foreign-language film. Among its competitors: Francois Truffaut's ''The Last Metro'' and Akira Kurosawa's ''Kagemusha.''

title: THE POSTAL SERVICE'S 'HALF-BAKED IDEA' TO ZIP UP TO NINE DIGITS
description: To the Editor:

title: REFRESHINGLY BLUNT JAPANESE: ZENKO SUZUKI
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan, who arrived in Washington yesterday to meet with President Reagan, is a short, thickset man whose surprising forte as a Japanese leader is to be frank.

title: Flames Defeat Stars, 3-1, To Stay Alive in Playoff
description: Bob MacMillan scored twice and revived Calgary's power play as the Flames defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 3-1, tonight to stay alive in their National Hockey League semifinal playoff series.

title: Business People; Westmoreland's Plans
description: Of his 20 years at the Westmoreland Coal Company, Pemberton Hutchinson recalls as the most challenging his days in Montana when he was seeking rights to mine coal from Crow Indians and ranchers.

title: Around the Nation; Florida Literacy-Test Foes Assailed as 'Un-American'
description: Florida's top education officer today called opponents of the state's literacy test ''un-American'' after a court's refusal to approve the examination.

title: And Why the Extra Burden for Commuters?
description: The Conrail rescue plan proposed by Representative Florio provides some hope of maintaining adequate freight service. But neither Mr. Florio nor the Reagan Administration seem very concerned about the fate of the 370,000 commuters in the New York and Philadelphia areas who depend on Conrail to get to work.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; FREE ITALIAN COMEDY FILM FESTIVAL
description: Five Italian comedy films will be on view free tonight through next Thursday at New York University's Schimmel Auditorium, 40 West Fourth Street, and at the Hunter College Auditorium, 695 Park Avenue, between 68th and 69th Streets. Stars of two of the films, Alberto Sordi of ''Everybody Go Home'' and Stefania Sandrelli (''The Traffic Jam''), and two directors, Salvatore Samperi (''Malice'') and Pasquale Festa Campanile (''The Thief''), will take part in panel discussions after each film, all of which have English subtitles. Showing tonight at 8 at N.Y.U. and tomorrow at 1 P.M. at Hunter is ''Everybody Go Home,'' a 1960 film directed by Luigi Comencini about the adventures of four army deserters. Tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. at Hunter it's Mr. Samperi's ''Malice'' (1974) and at 8 P.M. at N.Y.U. the United States premiere of Mr. Comencini's ''The Traffic Jam.'' The fifth feature is ''Come Have Coffee With Us,'' directed by Alberto Lattuada. Information: 354-4160. DOLL JOURNEYS AT MUSEUM OF THE CITY

title: BICKFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Around the World; 8 Czech Rights Activists Are Detained by Authorities
description: The Czechoslovak authorities have arrested Jiri Hajek, who was Foreign Minister during the short-lived 1968 liberalization period, and seven other rights activists, including the wife and brother of Vaclav Havel, a jailed playwright.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bail Is Reduced for Promoter
description: Bail for Ross Fields, a former boxing promoter known as Harold J. Smith, was reduced to $50,000 from $200,000 today on a charge that he had passed bad checks in North Carolina. Mr. Fields, who was already free on the higher bail, is a central figure in the alleged embezzlement of $21.3 million from the Wells Fargo Bank.

title: D'AMATO EXPECTED TO SELECT NEAHER FOR APPELLATE BENCH
description: Judge Edward R. Neaher of Federal District Court in Brooklyn has emerged as a leading candidate for an opening on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.
