Notes On People; Trying to Getting a Pilot Show Off the Ground
description: It's been more than a year since she appeared in the movie ''Fame,'' but Debbie Allen still remembers her lines - both of them. ''Two's enough, honey, if you say them right,'' explained Miss Allen, who still delivers the lines with gusto -''Wicked'' and ''He doesn't have one.''

title: BUSINESS PHONE COSTS TO RISE SHARPLY
description: The Federal Communications Commission set the stage today for a series of major increases in certain business telephone rates next week. The increases will raise the charges for 35,000 customers by a minimum of 35 percent and, in some cases, by 63 percent or more.

title: BRASS-CRAFT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ART: EXPLODING CANVASES OF ELIZABETH MURRAY
description: IT has always been mysterious to this observer that certain great paintings of the recent past do not simply fly apart by reason of the compositional forces generated within them. The shaped canvas, as developed by Frank Stella and others, is one way of dealing with this problem. But even the shaped canvas often seems to have trouble holding together, as if inner stresses were working upon it the way metal fatigue used to work upon aircraft.

title: CABARET: TONY BENNETT SMOOTH, SOFT AND EASY AT THE VANGUARD
description: TONY BENNETT has spent so many years trying to reduce huge auditoriums and concert halls to the dimensions of an intimate room that when he actually found himself in an intimate room on Wednesday evening - the Village Vanguard (capacity 123) - he started off with his usual concert-hall punch and projection.

title: THE BOTTLE BILL'S ILLUSORY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hartford M.I.S.L. Team To Be Moved to Memphis
description: The Hartford Hellions will be sold to a Memphis-based athletic group and moved to Tennessee, but the director of the Hartford Civic Center said he hoped to bring another indoor soccer team to Hartford.

title: China Reports Killing 100 Vietnam Soldiers
description: China said today that its frontier guards killed more than 100 Vietnamese troops yesterday after they had attacked a Chinese border commune, laid mines and looted property.

title: BALLET: FOR BARYSHNIKOV, A DEBUT IN 'SWAN LAKE'
description: UNDER Soviet ballet's rigid system of typecasting, Mikhail Baryshnikov was never allowed to dance the leading male role of Prince Siegfried in ''Swan Lake'' in the Soviet Union. His New York debut in this role, with Natalia Makarova as Odette-Odile, on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, can thus be considered an important addition to his repertory.

title: ART: CERAMIC CARICATURES BY ROBERT ARNESON
description: THE consensus about humor in painting and sculpture is unspoken but clear. Wit, irony and playfulness are all considered desirable and indeed have been prevalent in 20th-century work. But high art, like finance and religion, is not a realm where belly laughs are expected.

title: Sports News Briefs; Oregon to Drop 4 Sports
description: Oregon officials announced today that the university would drop four sports, including baseball, from its athletic program. Also being dropped at the end of the school year are women's golf and women's soccer. The cuts are part of $945,817 in reductions announced today to combat a projected budget deficit of $1 million in the 1981-82 fiscal year.

title: ART: EASEL TO CAMERA, A SHOW WITH A MESSAGE
description: THE exhibition called ''Before Photography: Painting and the Invention of Photography,'' which opens tomorrow at the Museum of Modern Art (through July 5), is a highly unusual event, and one that is certain to cause a great deal of discussion and debate. For this is an exhibition designed to illustrate an ambitious art-historical hypothesis that, if widely accepted as true, would significantly alter our understanding not only of the origins of photography but also of the development of modern art itself. For this reason, it may turn out to be one of the most important exhibitions ever mounted at the Museum of Modern Art - and the odd thing is, there isn't a single ''modern'' painting in the entire show.

title: TEXAS AIR KEEPS AFTER CONTINENTAL
description: Texas International Airlines announced two new proposals yesterday in the latest twist of its often bitter battle for control of Continental Air Lines.

title: MILITARY AID FOR ARGENTINA PASSES HURDLE IN HOUSE
description: In a victory for the Administration, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a measure today that would end a three-year-old ban on military aid to Argentina.

title: AHMANSON, H F, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SHOOTING OF REAGAN IS LEADING NOTABLES TO INCREASE SECURITY AGAINST ASSASSINS
description: The attempted assassination of President Reagan, following the murder of John Lennon, has prompted a growing number of public officials, show business celebrities and business executives around the country to employ new safety measures. They are hiring bodyguards, wearing bulletproof vests and taking other precautions while they are in public.

title: REAGAN JUDICIAL PLAN IS DEFENDED
description: President Reagan abolished the citizen commissions set up by President Carter to propose nominees for Federal appellate court judgeships, a White House official said today, because the panels had failed to depoliticize the nominating process or improve the quality of appointments and had resulted in delays.

title: Marshal Vladimir A. Sudets, 76; Led Soviet Antiaircraft Defenses
description: Air Marshal Vladimir A. Sudets, a former commander of the Soviet Union's antiaircraft forces, has died at the age of 76, the press agency Tass reported today.

title: Raider Trial to Start Monday
description: Attorneys for the Oakland Raiders, the National Football League and other parties in the Raiders' antitrust suit against the league cleared the way today for the trial to begin next Monday.

title: Rule Shifts Of N.A.S.L.  Permitted
description: The North American Soccer League was granted permission yesterday by FIFA, the world governing body for soccer, to continue using two modified rules until the conclusion of the season without being suspended.

title: Advertising; Braniff May Shift Agencies
description: NOT too many people in the advertising world will be surprised to learn that Braniff International's new head is considering getting a new ad agency.

title: Queens Leader Pleads for Action In a Possible Racial Firebombing
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens called yesterday for speedy punishment of those responsible for an apparent firebombing last Saturday in which a Flushing house scheduled for occupancy by a black clergyman was burned.

title: WHERE TO SPOT BALLET STARS OF TOMORROW
description: IT used to be that only the cognoscenti knew about the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet's annual spring workshop performances, which will take place tomorrow night and Monday afternoon and evening at the Juilliard Theater at Lincoln Center. But the workshops are now one of the rituals of New York dance, a benefit for and celebration of a school founded in 1934 to provide George Balanchine with a choreographic instrument that would reflect both the Russian traditions of the Maryinsky Theater, where Mr. Balanchine trained and performed in his youth, and the new American style of classical ballet forged by the choreographer.

title: FRIDAY, MAY 8, 1981; Markets
description: The U.S. Treasury was forced to pay the highest price ever for long-term borrowing when it sold $2 billion of new 13 7/8 percent, 30-year bonds at an average yield of 13.95 percent. The higher rates were attributed to the Federal Reserve's efforts to reduce money supply growth. (Page D1.) The nation's money market funds grew slightly, by $72.6 million, in the week ended Wednesday, to reach $118.5 billion. (D9.)

title: PARIS VOTE: PARTIES
description: With the French presidential elections this Sunday, Parisians will be mostly absent during the weekend, following the quaint old custom of voting ''dans leurs pays'' -in their regions - even if they have lived in Paris for decades.

title: Lessons From NATO
description: President Reagan's decision to enter talks with the Soviet Union on limiting the number of nuclear missiles in Europe only reconfirms what has been the American position. But John Vinocur of The New York Times reported from the Rome meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that the proposed talks were ''characterized by the Americans'' as a means of restraining Soviet power.

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Indonesian Oil Contracts
description: A South Korean concern and two United States companies will spend nearly $315 million over the next six years under oil exploration contracts signed today with Indonesia's state-owned oil company.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Kelly Kokinos, Pianist, In Schumman 'Carnaval'
description: Kelly Kokinos gave a thoroughly respectable performance of Schumann's ''Carnaval'' at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night.

title: Major sales of postwar art
description: PAINTINGS by Franz Kline are expected to command the highest prices in major sales of post-World War II paintings and sculpture at Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's next week. In Sotheby's sale next Tuesday at 8 P.M., Kline's ''West Brand,'' an oil on canvas dating to 1960 that measures 93 by 79 inches, may sell for as much as $400,000. At the Christie auction next Wednesday at 8 P.M. Kline's ''Yellow Square'' painted about 1952, may sell for up to $200,000.

title: A PLEDGE TO JERSEY MOTORISTS
description: State officials today pledged a major overhaul of the Division of Motor Vehicles, promising only five-minute waiting lines, telephones answered by the third ring and new computer systems for efficiency and fraud control.

title: Dibbs Ousts Kriek to Reach Quarterfinals
description: Eddie Dibbs, the effervescent baseline player from Miami, routed Johan Kriek of South Africa at Forest Hills last night, and the result completed the unexpected lineup for the quarterfinals of the Tournament of Champions, a $592,000 event seeking attention and warmer weather.

title: Around the World; Leader of Peasant Party In Poland Forced to Quit
description: Stanislaw Gucwa, head of the pro-Communist Peasant Party, resigned today after party members had attacked him for opposing an independent farm union.

title: Fruehauf Realigns Top Management
description: The Fruehauf Corporation, the big Detroit-based manufacturer of truck trailers, realigned its top management yesterday, elevating Frank P. Coyer Jr. to the new post of vice chairman and Thomas J. Reghanti to president and chief operating officer. It said the changes were made to help the company maximize its growth potential.

title: INDIAN LEADERS ASK WATT TO QUIT
description: Leaders of 150 American Indian nations, gathered here for a two-day conference, called today for the immediate resignation of James G. Watt, Secretary of the Interior.

JOBLESS RATE UNCHANGED AT 7.3% IN APRIL FOR THIRD STRAIGHT MONTH
description: The nation's unemployment rate remained at 7.3 percent for the third straight month in April amid diverging movements in the two main statistical series measuring employment, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SCA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Travelers' Earnings Off
description: Travelers Corporation, the insurance company, announced yesterday that operating earnings in the first quarter slipped 2.6 percent, to $83.6 million, or $1.97 a share, from $85.8 million, or $2.02 a share, in the 1980 quarter.

title: Between the Lions, a Feast Fit for Benefactors
description: It looked like some baronial feast in the great hall, with its 50-foot ceiling, Renaissance chandeliers and white-gloved waiters serving food and wines to 250 guests. ''This is a room I know very well,'' said Alfred Kazin, the author and critic, ''but I never expected to eat my dinner here.''

title: DALY OF THE NEWS QUITS OVER A COLUMN ON BELFAST
description: Michael Daly resigned yesterday as a columnist for The Daily News after a London newspaper charged that his Wednesday column, filed from Belfast, Northern Ireland, was ''a pack of lies'' and ''calculated to stir up American public opinion against Britain.''

title: Swiss Bank Rate Rise
description: The Swiss National Bank today announced increases of one percentage point in both the Lombard and prime bank rates in an effort to curb inflation and strengthen the Swiss franc. Effective from next Monday, the prime rate goes up to 5 percent and the Lombard rate to 6 1/2 percent, the National Bank said. It was the third time this year that the National Bank has raised the two rates in an effort to brake the rising value of the dollar, which has greatly increased the Swiss oil import bill.

title: CRIME HELD PRIME ISSUE BY DEGNAN
description: John J. Degnan calls himself an issues-oriented candidate. Crime in the streets, the economy, the need for government to be more flexible in regulatory areas - from one end of the state to the other, the former Attorney General sounds these themes in his race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AROUND THE NATION
description: BARRE, Pa., May 8 (UPI) -Anthracite industry negotiators today rejected the United Mine Workers' latest contract demands as ''impossible of accomplishment,'' putting an abrupt end to the renewed bargaining.

title: SATURDAY, MAY 9, 1981; The Economy
description: The index of producer prices for finished goods rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported, considerably below March's 1.3 percent and in line with the January and February rises. Rises in food, gasoline and heating oil prices slowed in April. One economist said, however, that ''double-digit inflation is going to be with us at least through summer.'' (Page 1.)

title: Jets Sign Top Defensive Pick
description: The New York Jets, moving quickly, signed their top defensive draft pick yesterday when Ben Rudolph, the quarterback-chasing tackle from Long Beach State who was picked on the third round, agreed to a three-year contract.

title: Smithsonian Guard Arrested In Theft of Historic Objects
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had arrested a 26-year-old guard at the Smithsonian Institution and two other men in the theft of historic objects from the museum but had not yet recovered the missing items.

title: A MIRO IN TROUBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Taylor Plans Extended 'Foxes' Runs
description: Elizabeth Taylor's career plans for the next year are tied up in ''The Little Foxes,'' Lillian Hellman's play in which she made her Broadway debut Thursday night. Even before the enthusiastic reviews came out, Miss Taylor had decided to extend her announced 10-week engagement on Broadway until Sept. 5.

title: DISCOVERY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Choice in France
description: Tomorrow's run-off election for President of France looks at first glance like a replay of 1974. Eight candidates were eliminated in the first round two weeks ago and it is once again Val ery Giscard d'Estaing, conservative, against Francois Mitterrand, Socialist. But things are not the same.

title: Spark Flying Into Methane Cited In a Mine Explosion Fatal to 15
description: An electrical spark, possibly from a damaged shuttle car cable, flew into a ''huge pocket of methane'' to set off a mine explosion last month that killed 15 coal miners in Redstone, the state's chief mine inspector said yesterday.

title: Cypriot Sees No Progress In Greek-Turkish Talks
description: Foreign Minister Nikos A. Rolandis of Cyprus said today that there had been no progress in the last year in the talks between Greece and Turkey on the issue of Cyprus.

title: STARRETT, L S, CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflects a 2-for-1 stock split on Jan 8, 1981

title: BEGIN IS SAID TO TELL REAGAN THAT ISRAEL FACE PERIL AS IN '67
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was reported today to have told President Reagan last week that, although he was willing to allow additional time for American diplomacy to try to resolve the crisis over Lebanon, the situation was similar to the 1967 Arab-Israeli crisis.

title: PREMIER SAYS FOREIGN STATES FOMENT TERROR IN SPAIN
description: With tensions running high after the assassinations of seven military men and Civil Guards in less than a week, Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo tonight accused unidentified foreign states of fomenting terrorism in Spain.

title: SANCHEZ: A SPECIAL NICHE
description: Fernando Sanchez has staked out a very special fashion niche for himself. He makes clothes to wear at home with a style of their own. It blends readily with what's going on in the rest of the fashion world. Some are the superseductive things - the satiny or transparent stuff with strategically placed lace inserts - that belong in what used to be called the boudoir.

title: 'CHEAPER TO KEEP'
description: ''Cheaper to Keep Her'' is a mild movie that certainly could have been a little better. Its main drawing card is Mac Davis, the singer who made his acting debut in ''North Dallas Forty,'' and Mr. Davis, while no real actor, is a movie natural. He's good-natured, recognizable and easy to like, and it shouldn't be hard to shape an amiable film around him. Furthermore, ''Cheaper to Keep Her'' has a reasonably fresh premise, with Mr. Davis playing a divorced husband who gets a job seeing to it that other divorced husbands keep up on their alimony payments.

title: Reagan Picks 4 For Fuel Board
description: President Reagan, three months after he dismissed the entire board of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, today announced four nominees to fill those vacancies in the agency that directs the Government's biggest energy program.

title: VICTIMIZED INDIANS HOLD KEY TO GUATEMALAN CONFLICT
description: When the fighters show up and ask for some beans, some corn or some tortillas in this highland area, the Indian inhabitants have two choices.

title: ALBANY ATTAINS BUDGET ACCORD ON SCHOOLS AID
description: The last negotiable item of the New York State budget fell into place today, as Assembly and Senate negotiators agreed on a new plan to distribute public school aid around the state.

title: Bomb Wounds 3 in Guadeloupe
description: TERRE, Guadeloupe, May 8 (UPI) - A bomb wrecked the local election campaign office of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France today, wounding two policemen and a civil servant, the authorities in the French Caribbean islands reported. A bomb, apparently planted by anti-French nationalists, exploded at Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe, last December during Mr. Giscard d'Estaing's visit there.

title: NICARAGUA BIDS MEXICO HELP BRIDGE GAP WITH U.S.
description: Nicaragua, anxious to avoid an open break with Washington, has asked President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico to take up the crisis in United States-Nicaraguan relations when he meets with President Reagan in Washington early next month.

title: by Burton Zwiebach
description: There is an unanticipated dividend for liberals in the conservatives' domestic program: further evidence, if more is needed, of the hollowness of the conservatives' commitment to freedom.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LATE FROST INPERILS CHAMPAGNE
description: A severe spring frost has struck the Champagne vineyards of France, damaging a significant portion of the vines and raising fears that another major decline in production will occur this year. The result may be a further increase in Champagne prices, which have already risen dramatically to reflect shortages arising from earlier crop failures.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW TRENDS AMONG THE WORK FORCE CLOUD VALIDITY OF UNEMPLOYMENT RATE
description: More Americans are looking for work, and finding it, than ever in history. On the other hand, a large percentage of the new workers are women or teen-agers who had never been counted as unemployed because they had never sought jobs before. This trend, made more pronounced by high inflation in recent years, means that many unemployed people find themselves jobless for a longer time or unable ever to re-enter the workforce.

title: FRANCANA OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
F.C.C. Allows Bell Rate Shifts
description: As expected, the Federal Communications Commission gave final approval today to a 16 percent rate increase for interstate phone calls and a 35 percent rate reduction for international calls, effective next Thursday.

title: LOUIS SCHANKER, 78, A PAINTER, IS DEAD
description: Louis Schanker, a painter, printmaker and sculptor, and member of a ''protest'' group of artists in the 1930's that sought to make American art more experimental and international, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 years old and had recently suffered a stroke.

title: ADVENTURES OF A PURSE SNATCHER'S VICTIM
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE OFFICERS, TOO, HAVE POLITICAL RIGHTS
description: To the editor: The scandal caused by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association's June 1980 contributions to the re-election campaign of Mayor Koch has been blown completely out of proportion. The prohibition banning police officers from belonging to political organizations dates back at least to 1892, when Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes (then a Massachusetts State Court judge) said that ''a man may have a right to talk politics, but not to be a policeman'' (McAuliffe v. Mayor and Board of Aldermen, 155 Mass. 2165, 29 N.E. 517 1892).

title: ON EAST 86TH STREET, AN ELEGANT HEDGE AGAINST DESPAIR
description: Sandy Levy went home for Mother's Day, her son at her side. She came to New York a year ago, looking for the simple miracle of life. She went home with it beside her, an elfin 10-year-old named Steven with a blue-and-yellow-striped lift on one running shoe who determined rather early on that bone cancer was not going to kill him. It looks as if he was right.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Tigers 6, Angels 1
description: Steve Kemp of Detroit hit his first home run of the season, a two-run shot in the sixth inning, to break a 1-1 tie.

title: G.M. Will Reduce British Unit's Output
description: The General Motors Corporation will reduce its British component output over the next year and will stop producing spark plugs, alternators and air cleaners here, a G.M. spokesman said.

title: by Elizabeth Barlow
description: The rebuilding of Central Park has been under way for a little more than two years. Grass grows once more on the Sheep Meadow, the figure of Columbia gleams again on top of the Maine Monument, and new pumps make jets of water spring from the Bethesda and Cherry Hill fountains.

title: Republic's Mexico Service
description: Republic Airlines has been granted permission to serve six cities in western Mexico from Chicago, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today.

title: PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTIONS
description: The Events and Openings listing in Weekend yesterday gave the time in- correctly for a concert tomorrow at Abraham Goodman House. The con- cert, ''For the Love of Music,'' is at 7:30.

title: A RECORD FOR ALBANY DELINQUENTS; by Sydney H. Schanberg
description: The New York Legislature has broken new ground again. It appears that this year's state budget will be enacted sometime next week, a month and a half past the March 31 statutory deadline - a record for Albany delinquency. Everyone had thought that the previous record of 17 days, set last year, would stand for at least a few sessions, but there is no holding back Olympic-quality competition.

title: Willoughby Finding Success as a Rocket
description: Bill Willoughby, lured from high school into pro basketball by big money, had been tagged an athletic failure and a washout at age 22.

description: B-Includes $1,205,422 gain from discontinued operations

A COONEY PUNCH HELPS SCRAMBLE GARDEN CARD
description: Three preliminary fighters on the undercard for the Gerry Cooney-Ken Norton heavyweight bout Monday night will have to be replaced, a Madison Square Garden spokesman announced yesterday.

description: B-Includes $1,015,000 tax credit

title: Emigres Say Czechs Now Hold 19 Who Support Rights Movement
description: A police roundup in which supporters of the Charter 77 human rights movement in Czechoslovakia have been arrested continued today, bringing the number of arrests to 19, emigre sources said.

title: Agency Rent-A-Car
description: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc., one of the smaller companies in the field, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it might seek to acquire control of the Spencer Companies, a shoe and clothing maker.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Town House Sold
description: The fine town house at 123 East 79th Street, formerly the home of Marietta Peabody Tree, a former member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, and the home since 1976 of John S. Samuels 3d, has been bought at auction for $4.05 million by the Brazilian Government. It will be the residence of Brazil's United Nations head of mission, currently Sergio Correa Da Costa.

title: TEXT OF COMMUNIQUE ON REAGAN-SUZUKI DISCUSSIONS
description: Following is the text of a joint communique issued by the White House today at the end of talks between President Reagan and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan: Special to the New York Times

title: CUSHMAN ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Seoul Grants Amnesty to 65, Including Kin of Dissident
description: The Government announced an amnesty today for 65 convicts, including the son and brother of the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung.

title: BANK SUSPENDS PLAN FOR LONDON ACCOUNT
description: Only two days after the introduction, the Bank of California said yesterday that it was suspending a new form of bank account that allowed depositors to collect interest rates as high as 17.25 percent.

title: Kirmayr Adds Taroczy to List of Victims
description: Carlos Kirmayr survived again yesterday at Forest Hills. The 30-year-old Brazilian, who came to the Tournament of Champions unseeded, unknown and unappreciated, remained undefeated by beating Balazs Taroczy of Hungary in another precipitous tennis match, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6.

title: U.S. ALLEGES DISCRIMINATION IN MOBILE ELECTION CASE
description: Moving to enter a historic civil rights case, the Justice Department asked a Federal court late tonight to declare that the form of government in Mobile, Ala., was unconstitutionally designed to maintain white supremacy.

title: A.M.C. Planning to Raise Prices
description: The American Motors Corporation will raise prices between 1 percent and 2.9 percent on some of its A.M.C., Jeep and Renault vehicles after its current 10 percent rebate program expires May 15, the auto maker said.

title: NEW CADILLAC MODEL SMALLEST SINCE 1905
description: The smallest automobile to be manufactured by the Cadillac Motor Car division of the General Motors Corporation since 1905 was introduced today as part of a company effort to lure younger buyers away from technically sophisticated imported sedans.

title: LABOR PARTY CHEERED BY LOCAL GAINS IN ENGLAND AND WALES
description: Voters in England and Wales have driven the Conservative Party from power in 23 of 54 key local government authorities.

title: AIDES TO REAGAN OPPOSE PETROLEUM FUNDING IDEAS
description: Top Administration officials testified before a Senate energy subcommittee this afternoon in opposition to various ideas for financing the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve through such devices as oil bonds, industry levies, Alaskan royalty oil or borrowings from the Synthetic Fuels Corporation.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $10,000 tax credit...C-Includes $68,000 tax credit

title: CAMFLO MINES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LOW RIDERS ARE BECOMING LEGION AMONG CHICANOS
description: The main thing about being a low rider, says Victor Vega, is that you don't hurry and you don't worry. ''You don't want to just whiz by, man,'' said the 28-year-old Mr. Vega, who is a low rider both by persuasion and profession, owing to his job as advertising agent for Low Rider magazine, the bible of the low and slow.

title: BEGIN, INVIGORATED BY CAMPAIGN, HAS THE LOOK OF A FRONT-RUNNER
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has jumped into his re-election campaign with such zeal and oratorical flourish that he is beginning to look like a front-runner.

title: WHEN IS FOOD RICH? IT'S ALL A QUESTION OF SEMANTICS
description: Among the many words commonly used to describe food, ''rich'' is one of the most difficult to define, meaning, as it apparently does, different things to different people. ''Avoid rich foods,'' we have all been admonished by a doctor at one time or another. And puritans give much the same warning in a manner suggesting that though the eating of rich foods is not among the seven deadly sins, it is at least a bona fide subheading under the general category of gluttony.

title: OPTIMISM TEMPERED AT BUSINESS COUNCIL
description: The rate of inflation will subside over the next two years, but not as much as the Reagan Administration is predicting, according to a report prepared by 20 top corporate economists.

title: JAPANESE PREMIER VOWS 'EVEN GREATER EFFORTS' ON DEFENSE
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan, concluding two days of talks with President Reagan, agreed today to make ''even greater efforts'' to improve Japan's defense capabilities, including the limited patrolling of commercial sea lanes in the western Pacific.

title: Newark Fire Dept.  Gets First Women
description: NEWARK (AP) - The city's first female firefighters were sworn in after passing a Civil Service test that, among other things, required them to run while carrying a 250-pound dummy.

title: Soldier Extradited In Buffalo Killings
description: BUFFALO (AP) - An Army private stationed at Fort Benning, Ga., was jailed here last night amid tight security after being extradited from Georgia. He is accused in the slayings of six blacks and a Hispanic man.

title: Tellefson Upset Winner By 2 Up From Zahringer
description: Frank Tellefson Jr., the 36-year-old golf coach at Wagner College, came from 3 down after 13 holes, won the last five holes and upset the defending champion, George Zahringer, 2 up, in the quarterfinal round today at the 34th annual William D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament.

title:
PATENTS;
Big Wind Fences Utilized To Produce Electricity
description: Wind fences that may be 500 feet high and five miles long have been invented to produce commercial electricity. Harry H. Bahrenburg, a principal field engineer for the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, was awarded patent 4,265,086 this week.

title: FREIGHTER PILOT SAYS OTHER SHIPS HID FERRY FROM HIS RADAR Charles Shuster
description: The pilot of the Norwegian freighter that collided with a Staten Island ferryboat in fog Wednesday morning said yesterday that he had not seen the ferry on his radar until about a minute before the collision, which injured at least 60 people.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary items not named at the present time

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BRONX IN BLOOM

title: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WHAM-O MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 9, 1981
description: International Syria rejected Israel's demand for the withdrawal of its antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon, despite Prime Minister Menachem Begin's repeated warnings that the missiles would be attacked militarily by Israeli forces if Syria does not remove them. The formal response from the Syrian Defense Ministry said the missiles ''exist now, and will in the future, wherever Syrian troops are, when they need them.'' Meanwhile, Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy, began discussions in Beirut toward averting a Syrian-Israeli war. (Page 1, Column 1.) Prime Minister Begin was pessimistic about Syria's removal of the missiles in Lebanon, and American and Israeli officials believed he might soon order air strikes on the missile positions. The officials said that Mr. Begin had said in a letter to President Reagan that he was willing to allow additional time for American diplomacy to resolve the issue, but the situation was similar to that 1967, when diplomatic efforts failed. (6:3-6.)

title: SUAVE SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CORRECTION
description: An article about psychiatrists. on the Style page in late editions yesterday omitted the attribution of a quotation. The comment that the percentage of medical graduates going into psychotherapy appears to have dropped was made by Dr. Alexandra Symonds.

title: Nassau G.O.P. Backs Dillon, a Democrat
description: The Nassau County Republican organization, in an unusual move, endorsed a Democrat, District Attorney Denis E. Dillon, for re-election in November. Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican chairman, said the prosecutor post should be treated as quasi-judicial and nonpartisan, although in the past the position has been contested by both parties.

title: by Linda Amster
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 38.

title: Stockman Moves to Kill Consumer Safety Panel
description: The Reagan Administration has recommended that the Consumer Product Safety Commission be abolished. ''Our preference would be to abolish the agency entirely,'' David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, wrote in a two-page letter today to Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, who had asked the Administration for its views.

title: BARTER: COMIC BOOKS TO BIG JETS
description: From his earliest years, Moreton Binn displayed all the instincts of a fast-talking, deal-making entrepreneur. Whether in marbles, baseball cards or comics (one Batman for two Superman), he was the champion trader of the neighborhood.

title: Police Say Kidnapping Suspected In Disappearance of Bronx Girl, 3
description: A 3-year-old girl disappeared from a shoe store in the Bronx yesterday, and the police said they suspected that she had been kidnapped.

title: ARGO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid Jan 1981

title: GETTING MIGHTY SMALL HERE; by Russell Baker
description: Here is a curious new development in physics: As things become bigger and bigger, the results become smaller and smaller. Note the phenomenon at work in oil. Oil companies grow and grow and become vast international conglomerates with revenues of billions and billions. What is the result? The cars served by these oily mammoths become smaller and smaller. Here is a classic instance of bigness producing littleness.

title: PHILARMONIC: ALL-CHORAL SEASON FINALE BY MEHTA
description: Zubin Mehta's farewell program for his third season as head of the New York Philharmonic made good sense on paper and, to a considerable extent, in practice. Our music director's programs sometimes look as if he had won them in a lottery, so little do they betray concern for logical progression or esthetic unity. The art of building programs, in fact, seems to interest leading conductors today much less than in the past. Many reasons can be advanced for this: recording commitments, overlapping subscription schedules, tour requirements and so on. But the dismal truth is that too many concerts are grab bags that should be coherent musical experiences.

title: 12 Soviet Dissidents Said to Fast In a Demand for Political Status
description: Twelve dissidents serving sentences at a labor camp in the Urals conducted a one-day hunger strike on Monday to support demands for status as political prisoners, the wife of one said today.

title: No Headline
description: Tom Watson, a four-time winner of the Byron Nelson Classic, shot a par 70 and maintained a one-stroke lead Friday in the second round.

title: Car Union Backed On Director Role
description: The Federal Trade Commission told the United Automobile Workers today that it probably would not violate antitrust laws for the union to be represented on the board of more than one automobile company.

title: AUTO-TRAIN COLLAPSE HELPS OTHER CARRIERS
description: After a Federal bankruptcy court flipped the deadman's switch on the Auto-Train Corporation last week, a host of smaller companies began scrambling to pick up its stranded customers.

title: FOUR SLAIN AND 20 WOUNDED IN BAR AS OREGON MAN SHOOTS INTO CROWD
description: A young man armed with a semiautomatic pistol walked into a crowded bar last night and opened fire, killing four persons and wounding at least 20 others before he was wrestled to the ground by customers.

title: Academy in Rome Awards Fellowships
description: The American Academy in Rome, a privately endowed center for American scholars and artists in Rome, has announced its Rome Prize Fellowships in the fine arts and the humanities. The recipients are 26 artists and scholars chosen from around the country in juried competitions.

title: GOVERNMENT OF SWEDEN RESIGNS
description: A dispute over how and when to begin lowering Sweden's high income tax rates led today to the fall of the coalition Government of Prime Minister Thorbjorn Falldin.

title: Casino Transfer In Atlantic City Set
description: In the first transfer of ownership of an Atlantic City casino-hotel, Dallas-based Inns of the Americas Inc. has taken over the controlling interest in the struggling Brighton Hotel and Casino under a previously announced agreement.

description: 1980 share earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid October 1980

title: FOR FRENCH 'ECOLOGIST' VOTERS, A PIVOTAL RUNOFF ROLE
description: Lounging in his dingy office in an unheated building in the Rue Chateau d'Eau, a few blocks south of the Gare de l'Est, Brice Lalonde reflected on the ironies of politics.

title: A's 2, Brewers 0
description: Steve McCatty of Oakland pitched a fourhitter for his fifth complete game and second shutout.

description: DETROIT (AL) - Restored Bill Fahey, r eserve catcher, to active roster, and placed D uffy Dyer, also a reserve catcher, on the d esignated-for-assignment list. MINNESOTA (AL) - Assigned Ray S mith, rookie catcher, to 21-day disabled list w ith broken right wrist. BASKETBALL SEATTLE (NBA) - Signed James Don- a ldson, reserve center, to two-year con- t ract.

title: 40 Palestinians Held by Police After Anti-Israel Demonstration
description: The police today broke up a crowd of rock-throwing Palestinian demonstrators in East Jerusalem and detained about 40 of them for questioning, a police spokesman said.

title: Coal Output Up in Week
description: The National Coal Association reported today that bituminous production for the week ended last Saturday totaled 8,570,000 tons, up slightly from the previous week's 8,535,000 tons. Production for the equivalent weekly period last year totaled 16,890,000 tons, nearly double the current strike-depressed output. Cumulative production for the first 18 weeks of 1981 totaled approximately 252,950,000 tons compared with 279,021,000 last year, the association said.

title: L.I. BROTHERS, 16 AND 17, GUILTY OF MURDER
description: Two teen-age brothers charged with taking part in the 1979 killing of a 13-year-old boy who saw them steal a motorless minibike worth $5 were convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in Riverhead, L.I.

title: John Michael Mancuso Weds Victoria Eugenia Garbanzo
description: Victoria Eugenia Garbanzo of Richmond Hill, Queens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Garbanzo of San Jose, Costa Rica, and John Michael Mancuso of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mancuso of Astoria, Queens, were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building in Manhattan by First Deputy City Clerk Herbert F. Ryan.

title: Davis Crime Allegations Ruled Out of Raider Trial
description: Allegations of an organized crime connection to Al Davis will not be allowed to be mentioned in the impending antitrust trial between the Oakland Raiders and the National Football League, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: TRACTOR TRAILER KILLS 2 CHILDREN IN THE 'VILLAGE'
description: Two children were fatally crushed yesterday morning by a 12-wheel tractor trailer as their mother was walking them and their baby brother across Seventh Avenue South opposite St. Vincent's Hospital on 11th Street.

title: IOWA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SYRIA TELLS ISRAEL IT WON'T WITHDRAW MISSILES IN LEBANON
description: Syria today formally rejected Israeli demands for withdrawal of antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon as Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, began discussions here on easing the crisis.

description: The Communist Party said today that it planned to work more closely with the Roman Catholic Church and Solidarity, the independent trade union.

title: TELERENT LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DANCE: AILEY PREMIERE
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater is one of the few companies that has been able to preserve the family feeling once common in the dance field. Past members come back to stage works or to make guest appearances. Even the company's occasional galas have the informal jollity of a giant block party - in honoring certain dance pioneers, these galas also honor the dance community to which they belong.

title: BIG ANDOVER FETE TODAY AS MUSEUM TURNS 50
description: The 50th anniversary celebration for the Addison Gallery of American Art tomorrow will not be one of those button-down affairs that normally reward arts patronage. But then, the Addison does not serve a button-down community. As part of the prestigious Phillips Academy in Andover, it is the only full-scale museum in the country that belongs to a secondary school.

title: Falling Limb Kills Golf Spectator
description: A spectator at the Byron Nelson Classic golf tournament was killed and three other persons were injured today when they were struck by a falling limb of a partly rotted oak tree.

title: Service for Victims Killed In Air Force Plane Crash
description: Flags were flown at half-staff and jets flew in formation overhead as about 1,000 mourners attended service at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio, for the 18 servicemen, two wives and a civilian technician who died when the plane in which they were riding on a training mission crashed Wednesday in Maryland.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTED BY HOUSE PANEL IN AUTHORIZATION OF MILITARY FUNDS
description: President Reagan's military budget continued to roll through Congress today as the House Armed Services Committee approved nearly everything the Administration requested.

title: COST OF 'DUMB' TERMINALS FALLS AS IMPORTS INCREASE
description: Computer terminals, which resemble television sets in outward appearance, are beginning to resemble them in another way as well: The terminal industry, like the television industry before it, faces competition from low-priced products made in the Far East, and American manufacturers are starting to move their own operations to stay competitive.

title: Bridge: 2 Events at Cavendish Club; To Start Today and Monday
description: The Cavendish Club organizes two major events each May that attract many players of world class. In one respect they differ from almost all other tournaments. In another they differ vastly from each other.

title: FOOD LAW AND THE CARCINOGEN PROBLEM
description: On June 30 the 18-month Congressional moratorium that blocked the Food and Drug Administration's decision to prohibit saccharin will expire. An effort will undoubtedly be made to extend the moratorium, again raising the difficult issue of the so-called Delaney clause.

title: Greece Protests NATO's Stand Against Maneuvers on an Island
description: Greece has protested NATO's refusal to include the northeastern island of Lemnos in recent alliance military maneuvers because of a belief that the island should be demilitarized.

title: LEGAL AID FOR THE RICH
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Industries Inc. said it had acquired 88 percent of Miconics Industries' 354,787 outstanding shares of common in a transaction valued at $2.1 million.

title: Three Police Stations in Athens Are Firebombed by Extremists
description: Extremists hurling firebombs from a car attacked three police stations in central Athens early today.

title:
PATENTS;
2 Color TV Pictures Sent At Once on Single Channel
description: An electronic engineer has patented a television system that can send two color pictures simultaneously over a single broadcast channel. The added picture is ''piggybacked'' onto a standard broadcast without interference.

title: M.T.A. VOTES TO LET THE BUS DRIVER DECIDE ON USE OF AIR-CONDITIONING
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday rejected a proposal that would have barred the use of air-conditioning on New York City buses unless the outdoor temperature exceeded 90 degrees. It said it would continue to leave such decisions ''to the discretion of the drivers.''

title: COURT BARS SURROGATE ADOPTIONS
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals this week upheld a law preventing a couple from adopting the child of a surrogate mother hired to bear a child for them.

title: KOCH TO ENLARGE HIS PLAN FOR MORE GUARDS AT JAILS
description: Faced with a jail population that has grown by 25 percent in the last year, the Koch administration intends to hire 400 more correction officers in 1982 than it had planned only a few months ago.

title: INFLATION UNTAMED BY MONETARISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Joza Brilej, Yugoslav Envoy, 71; Served at London, U.N. and Cairo
description: Joza Brilej, a Yugoslav diplomat who served as chief delegate to the United Nations in 1954-57, died today of lung cancer at a hospital in Ljubljana, Slovenia, his doctors reported. He was 71 years old.

title: PORTRAYAL ON TV REPORTEDLY DISPLEASES JEAN HARRIS
description: Jean S. Harris watched the first televised segment of the film of her murder trial with three lawyers last night in the Bedford Hills Correctional Center. She was reported by people who have seen her to be unhappy with Ellen Burstyn's portrayal of her.

title: Purported Royal Transcripts Published in West Germany
description: Despite a court ban, a West German magazine today distributed 950,000 copies of what were said to be transcripts of talks between Prince Charles of Britain and his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer.

title: VALENZUELA (7-0) TOPS METS BY 1-0 FOR HIS FIFTH SHUTOUT
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the 20-year-old rookie sensation from Mexico, appeared in New York for the first time last night and added to the legend by pitching the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 1-0 victory over the Mets.

title: 2 REFINERS CUT PRICES PAID FOR OIL
description: The Cities Service Company and the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday announced a $2-a-barrel reduction in the amount they will pay for crude oil. Their actions were a dramatic confirmation of the oil oversupply that is driving down prices.

title: Two Found Guilty In Toxic-Waste Case
description: TRENTON (AP) - Two former operators of Chemical Control Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., and two other companies were found guilty of conspiracy and mail fraud charges that stemmed from allegedly misreporting the location of toxic waste.

title: Jaycees Are Told to Admit Women to Minnesota Units
description: The national Jaycees organization cannot bar women from becoming full-fledged members of Minnesota Jaycee chapters, the Minnesota Supreme Court said today in an interpretation of a state law.

title: U.S. Air Fare Ceiling Abroad to Rise
description: Because of higher fuel prices, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would raise airline fare ceilings June 1 for United States carriers flying on foreign routes.

title: G.& W. Lifts Stake In Munsingwear
description: Gulf and Western Industries Inc., which has been buying and selling its interests in many companies over the years, said it had increased its stake in Munsingwear Inc., an apparel and men's wear manufacturer, and reduced its interest in Cluett Peabody & Company, a men's and women's apparel maker.

title: Japan Car Curb Termed Legal
description: Attorney General William French Smith has notified the Japanese Government that its plan for limiting auto exports to the United States does not violate this country's antitrust laws.

title: Scare Tactics in Politics Are Criticized by Carter
description: Former President Jimmy Carter today denounced the use of scare tactics by fringe political groups and said the voices of those calling for government to abandon the needy were not new, ''they are only louder.''

title: CORRECTIONS

Stage View; WOODY ALLEN MAKES A BRAVE TRY
description: As I see it, there are at least two kinds of floating electric light bulbs. There is the kind that magicians use, glowing objects suspended in space without - apparently - any wiring attached to them. Magicians are always passing hoops directly over them to prove that they're unattached. The other kind of disconnected but exceedingly bright bulb is the kind that turns up in the comic strips, hovering radiantly over the head of a popeyed figure who has just this minute got a beaut of an Idea. I am sorry to report that playwright Woody Allen has only got the first kind working for him in ''The Floating Light Bulb,'' his new memory-comedy at the Vivian Beaumont.

title: Film View; OF A HIT, A SERIES AND THE WORD
description: One of the questions a movie reviewer is asked most frequently (after ''How many movies do you see a week?'') is how he feels when a film he has liked becomes a flop at the box office or when a film he's panned becomes a smash hit. The answer: ''Curious.'' If the opinions of a movie reviewer coincide consistently with those of the ticket-buyers, he is clearly in the wrong job. He should be producing films instead of merely submitting to them for pay. But there are times when it's quite as difficult to understand - after the fact - why a certain picture has become a hit as it is to predict what the response will be before it opens. Some hits defy coherent analysis. They set no reliable precedents. The lessons they teach are worthless.

The musical concerned itself fictionally with Fanny Brice, a great talent of the Ziegfeld era, and it produced a major star, Barbra Streisand, to portray Miss Brice. Neither vocally nor physically did Miss Streisand resemble Miss Brice, but her talent was equally singular. If she never became Miss Brice, she easily convinced her audiences that Miss Brice was a lot like Miss Streisand.

title: Bridge; THE GREAT AMATEUR

title:
Forum;
RETHINKING ENVIRONMENTAL LAW
description: W HEN Congress passed the environmental laws, it didn't take into account the bureaucracy's delay. Underlying the programs controlling water and air pollution is the assumption that so long as a company meets the tests for a permit, it will be granted a permit. The simplicity of the approach is attractive, but it reflects a misperception of the setting in which decisions are made by environmental agencies. The time lost and the cost of obtaining permits can be a drag on the productive thrust of the economy.

But Smith, who is aggressive, has yet to draw a penalty. He is eager for the final round to begin, the series that decides the Stanley Cup championship.

description: Fact and metaphor are hardly incompatible, as any good storyteller knows. But when the stories are as old as the Bible, separating the two can become a matter of scholarly dispute.

description: ''In April 1977,'' says the jacket copy of Robyn Davidson's ''Tracks'' (Pantheon, $11.95), ''a 27-year-old woman set off to cross the rugged bush of her native Australia, accompanied only by four camels and a dog. It was a trip that began as a pure and ....'' Hohum, one thinks, another woman-alone-against-the-sea-or-whatever story.

title: ALBANY BILL DUE ON PARENTS' RECLAIMING CULT MEMBERS
description: Legislative negotiators are close to agreement on a new bill intended to allow parents to reclaim their children from religious and other cults. The measure, which has been negotiated in secrecy for several months, is expected to be introduced next week.

title: METS TOP DODGERS; YANKS LOSE IN 9TH, 6-5
description: The New York Mets lost a 4-2 lead in the eighth, then rallied in the bottom of the inning to score a 7-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon.

title: Virginia Commander Bride of David Knott
description: Virginia Gregg Commander, daughter of Mrs. A. Thomas Bradbury of Atlanta and the late Robert Charlton Commander, was married yesterday to David Mabon Knott, son of Mrs. William E. Stockhausen of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Dorset, Vt., and the late David Hurst Knott Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Harry A. Fifield performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Atlanta.

title: Business Conditions; EMPLOYEES OVERSEAS: EXPENSIVE
description: High taxes, rising inflation and a weak dollar have made the cost of maintaining American employees abroad an increasingly expensive proposition for United States companies. A sharp decline in the number of United States citizens employed overseas has ensued.

title: THE THEATER THAT SPARKED A REVOLUTION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington is London theater critic for The Guardian. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON For the past 25 years, a red-brick Victorian structure in Chelsea's Sloane Square has been at the center of the postwar revolution in the English theater. The Royal Court, home of the English Stage Company, was the launching pad, on May 8, 1956, for John Osborne's ''Look Back in Anger,'' the play that decisively broke open a theatrical world that was, in Arthur Miller's words, ''hermetically sealed off from life.''

title: Investing; LESSONS FROM A BOND FUND
description: L AST year, there was one and only one municipal bond fund that did not lose money, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc., which tracks some three dozen municipal funds. That was the Elfun Tax-Exempt Income Fund. It earned a total return of 5.5 percent.

title: MOTHER'S DAY: AMONG THE FORGOTTEN
description: IF you think Mother's Day is the day every child pays loving tribute to his dear mother, think again. For the entire five years of my son's life, I have been preparing him to worship the ground I walk on. To date, my crusade hasn't even gotten him to bended knee. For me, Mother's Day is just another day, but not for lack of trying.

title: TEEN-AGERS INVADE SUBWAY STATION IN QUEENS AND ATTACK A BYSTANDER
description: Half a dozen youths carrying knives, Molotov cocktails and a fivegallon can of ''strong-smelling fluid'' invaded an elevated train station in Woodhaven, Queens, shortly after 1 A.M. yesterday, doused the floor and benches and tried to stab a young bystander, according to a spokesman for the Queens District Attorney's office.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
From Stoneware To Cookware
description: A Norwalk reader who is a professional cook found a Westport store, Peggy Kahn's, with ''continual sales of high quality cookware and gifts.'' The shop was started eight years ago as a ''seconds'' outlet for Bennington Pottery, the Vermont stoneware, but switched one year ago to the company's ''firsts'' and added other products, many discounted 10 percent or more.

title: MARCH FOR ATLANTA DEAD
description: A Mother's Day March and Silent Vigil will be held at 2 P.M. today in Peekskill as a gesture of support for the mothers of Atlanta. Twenty-six placards bearing the names of the murdered youths will be carried by the marchers.

title: EVADING THE PARKWAY TRAFFIC JAM
description: WHAT's more frustrating than being stalled behind traffic on the Merritt Parkway on a morning when you have a meeting with your best client and your boss in Westchester?

title: Wine; SWEET, EFFERVESCENT AND RARE
description: he Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, perhaps the world's most renowned wine society, was established in the heart of the French Burgundy country, and its members vow during the initiation rites to permit no wine other than Burgundy to cross their lips. One purpose of the Confrerie, after all, is to celebrate the quality and rich character unique to the wines of the region.

title: THE BOX-OFFICE BOOM
description: Since Moss Hart and George S. Kaufman wrote ''The Fabulous Invalid'' in the late 1930's, a comedy about the ailments of the contemporary theater, Broadway has been periodically pronounced dead, dying, or at best limping along, helped, some say, by glitz, hype, or the obsessive illusions of those who work in it. Through the years, prophets of doom have bemoaned the lost Golden Age of the theater and waited in the wings for the Broadway funeral procession. And with good reason: In the 1930's, radio and the Depression seemed to be the theater's nemeses; in the 1940's, it was the war; in the 1950's, television and films (along with Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway) were the new usurpers; in the 1960's, it was American youth, whose counterculture rejected everything connected with the Establishment. And just recently, in the early 1970's, urban decay and cultural displacement were seen as the final blows: The theater was considered to be economically unviable, and its staunchest defenders and practitioners headed for the hills of California.

title: Economic Affairs; A FORMULA TO THWART BUDGET CUTS; by Paul W. MacAvoy
description: T HE Congress has now set out its plan to effect the largest cuts in Federal expenditures in history. Rather than proceeding with the customary annual growth in spending to a level of almost $740 billion, the plan calls for outlays to be held to $690 billion in the 1982 fiscal year. There are very good reasons to hail this reduction. Many programs have grown far beyond original needs, and the Federal shopping list is so long that it creates excess demands for goods and services throughout the economy.

title: Music View; OPERA DIRECTING- A PERILOUS CRAFT
description: People who choose opera direction as a career are like those small boys at carnivals who used to get paid for letting people throw baseballs at them. It is quite likely, although no document has been discovered to prove it, that after the first performance in 1597 of history's first opera, some critic had sharp things to say about the staging of Jacopo Peri's ''Dafne'': ''Why was it necessary for the composer, who himself portrayed Apollo in this stylistically muddled enterprise, to take the opportunity of studiously examining his fingernails and stalking about the stage whenever another performer was declaiming his part? And why could not Apollo himself, of all godly musicians, sing more clearly and enunciate more distinctly over the decidedly subdued accompaniment of the mistuned lutes? Does no one care anymore about the art of Italian diction?'' It is also likely that someone replied to the critic: ''I really wonder if you and I attended the same performance.''

title: Business Conditions; COAL CASTS A PALL ON RAILS
description: With stockpiles of coal at near-record levels, the economic impact of the United Mine Workers' strike, which entered its sixth week last Friday, has been minimal thus far. However, one group is suffering - the railroads, which traditionally rely on coal for about one-third of their total freight revenues.

title: PHILIPPINES PUTS STRESS ON IRRIGATION OF FARMS TO BRIDGE DRY SEASON
description: When the last of the monsoons subsided in November, the long dry season came to the Phillipines, except its southernmost islands. Now with the season almost spent in 98-degree temperatures, the land is parched and inhospitable to agriculture.

This weekend in Hartford, the Connecticut Opera is staging the full-length version, a premiere for the state, and a large contingent of the Gershwin family, friends and principals involved with earlier productions will be attending the Friday performance.

''I am a different player than I was in 1979,'' Davis said after practicing with the Cosmos Friday. ''Looking back, I'd have to say that I let 1979 go to my head. All that media attention. You could say I was carried away. All the good things that went on turned out to create problems for me last season.''

title: 'HARLEM TODAY RESEMBLES NOTHING SO MUCH AS FRANCE AFTER THE GREAT WAR'
description: History reserves a special paradox for great, dead cultures: They survive largely as resonant place names. That is Harlem's apotheosis now. Like Lawrence Durrell's Alexandria, G. W. Cable's New Orleans, and Carl Schorske's Vienna, Harlem is now acquiring an afterlife more vivid and varied, and more meaningful, than it had at any time before its slow, sleazy death in the late 1970's. For vividness and variety, there are the successive Broadway musical hits, ''Bubbling Brown Sugar,'' ''Eubie,'' ''Ain't Misbehavin','' ''Sophisticated Ladies''; for meaning, there is a lengthening bibliography of scholarly works.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Original Carl Hubbellito
description: FERNANDO VALENZUELA speaks only Spanish, but when he does, one word comes through clearly -screwball. Nothing is lost in translation. With the Los Angeles Dodgers rookie, of course, nothing has been lost at all. Including his 1-0 seven-hitter over the Mets at Shea Stadium on Friday night, the 20-year-old left-hander has a 7-0 record, an 0.29 earned run average and five shutouts in seven starts this season. Over his major league career of 80 2/3 innings that began late last season, he has an 0.22 earned run average.

title: TV View; 'HILL STREET BLUES'- A HIT WITH PROBLEMS
description: Getting to some comments on a series called ''Hill Street Blues'' demands a brief detour to the subject of Fred Silverman. The prognosis for Mr. Silverman's future at NBC is not good; trade speculation about the network president has shifted from ''if he will leave'' to ''when he will leave.'' Some insiders insist that the move will be made in July, after a new chairman takes over RCA, the parent company. Others insist that Mr. Silverman will be kept on until October when the new season's audience numbers should indicate if the network has any chance of climbing out of the ratings cellar. Of course, insiders have notoriously rotten prediction records. Mr. Silverman's fortunes could change virtually overnight and, as in some unbelievable television movie, he will have the press and publicity mills hailing him as a ''programming genius'' once again. The celebrity merchants giveth and taketh away with an arbitrariness verging on the perverse.

description: Brenda Jean Turnbull, an independent consultant on Federal policy research and analysis, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Robert Michael Tomasko, a management consultant with the Strategic Management Unit of Arthur D. Little Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. Dean Frederick H. Borsch performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Donald Pirone Offers Chopin Piano Works
description: All the music the Juilliard-trained pianist Donald Pirone played in his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night was impressively presented with intelligence and a firm musical technique.

title:
Speaking Personally;
THE IMPRINT THAT LETTERS FROM A MOTHER CAN MAKE
description: THERE will be no more letters from my mother. As I reflect upon the past years, I don't know what prompted me at the age of 9, while I was at a camp 94 miles from home, to decide to save all her letters.

title: BYRD SAYS RIGHTISTS' ADS DISTORT DEMOCRATS' VIEWS
description: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate minority leader, accused the National Conservative Political Action Committee today of spreading ''unmitigated lies'' about him and other Democrats, and he urged the broadcast media to reject what he termed false and misleading political advertisements.

title: KEEPING ALIVE THE 'POP BAND' ESTHETIC
description: The rock and roll of the mid-60's thrived on a peculiar, intriguing tension. Since its beginnings in the mid-50's, rock had been marketed to consumers in the form of single records that were two to three minutes in length. Sometimes these singles were collected on albums, but singles remained rock's basic unit of measure. During the mid-60's, the Beatles and other rock groups began testing the limits of the rock and roll single. They tried new song structures, new guitar sounds, quirky little breaks and other details one might not notice on the radio but would almost certainly notice when listening at home.

title: CONSERVATIVE BRAIN TRUST
description: The long banquet table at Washington's elegant Hay-Adams Hotel was spread with a generous supply of pate, brie, grape leaves and assorted hors d'oeuvres. It was an unusually mild Sunday afternoon in mid-February, as some 200 guests drifted in for a 5 o'clock cocktail party that seemed to be a cross between an old-school reunion and a second inaugural for the Reagan Administration. In fact, the affair was both. The guests of honor were all newly appointed members of the Reagan team, and all were affiliated with the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Re-search (A.E.I.), a Washington think tank that is probably the leading source of conservative intellectual firepower in the country today. Among the institute's chosen fellows were Murray L. Weidenbaum, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers; Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the new United States Ambassador to the United Nations; James C. Miller 3d, a key figure at the Office of Management and Budget; Michael Novak, the special United States representative to the United Nations Human Rights Conference in Geneva; Roger Fontaine of the National Se-curity Council and Lawrence Korb, one of six key undersecretaries in the Department of Defense.

title: Nancy Griswold Plans Nuptials
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Howell Griswold 3d of Monkton, Md., of the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Montague Griswold, to William Augustus Read Knox, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Knox 3d of Buffalo.

title: DAYS IN THE LIVES OF 2 WOMEN WHO SERVE MRS. REAGAN MUFFIE BRANDON,
description: Muffie Brandon had a thick red loose-leaf book and several fat file folders piled on the desk in front of her. The telephone s kept ringing, its bell sounding a discreet melodious note, and her assistant and executive assistant popped in and out with the regularity of bread emerging from a toaster.

title: Leigh Barbour Married To William J. Deehan
description: Leigh Carrere Barbour, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Barbour of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y., to William Joseph Deehan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. Deehan of Medford, Mass. The Rev. Dr. John D. Verdery, an Episcopal priest and retired headmaster of the Wooster School, performed the ceremony.

title: Time for Surgery on Social Security
description: The Social Security system needs a major overhaul if it is to remain solvent through the next decade. Yet President Reagan has talked only about modest changes of transitory value. Preoccupied with other budget issues and eager to shed his reputation as the enemy of this most popular social program, the President has no taste for another fight. But thanks to pressure from Representative J.J. Pickle and his Democratic colleagues on the Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Reagan may have no choice.

title: GISCARD RALLY: TIGHT SCHEDULE AND BOOMING ORATORY
description: The classic political rally, beautifully orchestrated and tightly controlled, is mostly a sentimental memory in the United States. In France, it is alive and well, and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is its master.

title: CELTICS ROUT ROCKETS, 94-71, LEAD, 2-1
description: The Houston Rockets matched a statistic in the National Basketball Association record book today. It was not one they would like to remember.

title: Miss Wortham And U. S. Aide To Wed in Fall
description: Leah Wortham, acting deputy director of the United States International Development Cooperation Agency in Washington, and Eric L. Hirschhorn, deputy assistant secretary for export administration of the United States Department of Commerce in Washington, plan to be married in October.

title: South Jersey Held in Need Of Genuine Leadership
description: Although many may be amused by the number of candidates for Governor, it is a serious matter in South Jersey, especially Camden, which is in dire need of political leadership.

title: Anne P. Wagley Married To Charles Rice Gow 3d
description: Anne Paxton Wagley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Franklin Wagley of Baltimore, was married in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer there yesterday to Charles Rice Gow 3d, son of Mr. Gow Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Dorothy G. Day of Danvers, Mass. The Rev. Robert Patterson, assisted by Rev. Michael Fonner, performed the ceremony.

title: FREEDOM RIDERS FIND PRIDE AND PAIN ON '61 ROUTE
description: The two women sitting in the front of the Greyhound bus had spent much of the ride from Birmingham exchanging thoughts on a variety of subjects: life in Traverse City, Mich., and Youngstown, Ohio, the cities from which they came; their grandchildren; the rising cost of bus and plane fares, and what they hoped to achieve in the remaining years of their lives.

title: 1-1 TIES FORCES A REPLAY IN ENGLISH F.A. CUP FINAL
description: -Manchester City and Tottenham played to a 1-1 tie after 30 minutes of overtime today in the l00th Football Association Cup final at Wembley Stadium.

title: The Nation; Mormons Reject The MX Missile In Their Backyard
description: The Pentagon's multibillion-dollar scheme for shuttling the MX missile in tunnels around the Southwest has already attracted some formidable skeptics, among them Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and Presidential friend Senator Paul Laxalt. Last week, it attracted some formidable opponents, when leaders of the Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints wired their protest to the Utah and Nevada Congressional delegations and to President Reagan.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY By Gene Thornton Humphrey Spender's photographic view of England in the 1930's - on view at the Prakapas Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, through May 23 - seems nostalgic, even poetic, today. But it was conceived and executed in the spirit of truth-seeking and truth-telling that informed so much art during the 1930's.

title: DR. SEBASTIAN T. PASCALE
description: Dr. Sebastian T. Pascale, director of surgery at St. John's Queens Hospital in Elmhurst, died Friday at St. John's after a long illness. He was 55 years old and a resident of Manhasset, L.I.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR putting in more than 14,000 hours of volunteer service on behalf of the elderly, Harry Griffin has received a reward: He's been named the winner of the Nassau County Senior Citizen of the Year Award for 1981. The award is presented annually by the county's Department of Senior Citizen Affairs.

title: 'BOLD STROKE' CASTS ACTOR IN 'DAMIEN'
description: IT seems unlikely that Eugene Troobnick, who is the very model of a contemporary American Jewish comic in appearance and in sensibility, is playing the Catholic ''patron saint'' of a leper colony in the 19th century.

title: Ideas and Trends; FOR DOCTORS UNION, STRIKING IS A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH
description: The late labor leader George Meany was asked once what he thought about organizing physicians as part of the country's unionized work force.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Turning the Tables Before NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' took a pratfall in the ratings, ABC tried to capture some of the youthful, late-evening audience - on Fridays - with a similar comedy/variety show, imaginatively titled ''Fridays.'' After a slow start, the ABC show has proved popular enough to be renewed for next season.

title: Uri Zvi Greenberg, 83; Hebrew and Yiddish Poet
description: Uri Zvi Greenberg, a Hebrew and Yiddish poet and onetime guerrilla and member of Parliament, died yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: Helen Jolene, P. Nurse, Will Be Married in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Forsyth Joline 3d of New York and Duxbury, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Helen Pendleton Joline, to Michael Raymond Sirois, son of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond Joseph Sirois of Nashua, N.H. The wedding will take place in July at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Hanover, N.H.

title: Just Bopping Along
description: The following bulleted items make up a fusillade of usage: ''You have to be at your best, too,'' Farrah Fawcett told an interviewer three years ago, ''- bopping along all the time, happy, upbeat, friendly.'' ''You do not just bop off to China for a holiday,'' wrote Lorraine Davis in ''The Passionate Traveler.'' ''Now we need a boppy ending,'' said a reporter for People magazine, interviewing Doe Lang, author of ''The Charisma Book.''

title: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER TALKS OF POLAND'S NEEDS AND PERILS
description: MIECZYSLAW RAKOWSKI, the Polish Government's chief negotiator with the Solidarity trade union, is the longtime editor in chief of the weekly newspaper Polityka, the most prestigious official Communist publication in Eastern Europe. His appointment as Deputy Prime Minister in February was an important step in opening up the Government's information policies and in forming a working relationship with the independent union.

title: FEAR AS A FORM OF POLLUTION
description: I find it appalling that an official from the state's Department of Environmental Conservation wrote such an irresponsible article on the subject of fear with respect to toxic substances found in the environment.

title: 10 Acquitted in Illinois In Killings in Prison Riot
description: A Cook County Circuit Court jury today acquitted 10 Pontiac Correctional Center inmates facing charges that could have led to the death penalty for nine of them. The seven-anda-half-month trial was described as the biggest civilian death penalty case in American legal history.

title: City Hall Notes; KOCH MAY SUPPORT HIGHER FARE IF ALBANY AGREES TO AID M.T.A.; City Hall Notes
description: When a state budget is finally adopted, attention in Albany will turn to ways for salvaging the ailing, debt-ridden Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It is becoming ever more likely that any solution will include a fare increase.

title: No Headline
description: For the past 21 years, the same dentist has examined, X-rayed, filled, capped and otherwise tended to my teeth in a highly professional and competent manner, with a personal touch. In an emergency, he is generally available.

title: 33 FOOD PLACES CITED FOR VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health this week released the names of 33 food establishments that it said had violated the health code. The department also named three restaurants that had corrected earlier violations and four that had been closed for failing to do so. The businesses were listed as follows.

title: THUNDERBIRD JET PILOT KILLED IN PLANE CRASH AFTER A SHOW IN UTAH
description: An Air Force Thunderbird jet crashed today as it attempted to land after a precision flying show for about 80,000 spectators at Hill Air Force Base. The pilot died in the crash.

title: WAS A VICE ADMIRAL
description: Vice Adm. John Mylin Will, who served as president of American Export Lines after a 40-year career in the United States Navy, died Friday at Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington. Admiral Will, who was a resident of New York City and had a home in Deerfield Valley, Va., was 81 years old.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE BOOK OF EBENEZER LE PAGE, by G.B. Edwards. (Alfred A. Knopf, $13.95.) A posthumously published novel about life on the Channel Island of Guernsey.

title: Ideas and Trends; OF SMOKING, CHILDREN AND A DEEP BELIEF IN
description: IMMORTALITY By ROBERT REINHOLD

title: MUSIC: 'MISSA SOLEMNIS'
description: Beethoven's ''Missa Solemnis'' is a work so grand that it even dwarfs most performances of it. It was to the credit of Lorin Maazel, his wonderful Cleveland Orchestra and Robert Page's equally wonderful Cleveland Orchestra Chorus that their performance Friday night at Carnegie Hall managed to call admiring attention to itself and serve Beethoven as well.

title: Benjamin Bloom Will Marry Lauren Cotton Next Month
description: State Supreme Court Justice Wallace R. Cotton and Mrs. Cotton of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren H. Cotton, to Benjamin Bloom, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Bloom of Kings Park, L.I.

title: NORTH STARS WIN, 5-3, ADVANCE TO FIANALS
description: A month ago, during their first-round Stanley Cup playoff series with the Boston Bruins, the speedy young Minnesota North Stars decided to grow beards as long as they lasted in the playoffs.

title: Miss Hauge, R. M. Sword Wed
description: Elizabeth Larsen Hauge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Hauge of New York, was married in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday to Richard Morgan Sword, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sword of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the River Club.

title: MORE CHURCHES QUIETLY FORGING INDEPENDENT PATHS
description: John Wimber's blond curly hair and bushy beard are turning gray now, but he retains the countercultural verve of the 1960's. A rock musician, about to leave on a nationwide tour, he became a convert to the evangelical ''Jesus'' movement. He never made the trip, he says, because the Lord led him in another direction.

title: EFFORTS TO EASE PRISON CROWDING SNARLED IN POLITICS
description: IT WAS a hot spring day in Newark, and even hotter in the cramped Records Room of the Essex County Jail. The 13-story building, designed to hold 550 prisoners, was bulging with 712. Tension was high among both the inmates and staff.

title: Bradford L. Peery Marries Cristine Traxler
description: The marriage of Cristine Marie Traxler of Westport, Conn., daughter of Marie Koch English of San Antonio, Tex., and the late John Griffith Traxler, to Bradford Lee Peery, also of Westport, took place there last evening. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Edmund Delaney of Newport Beach, Calif., and the late Roger Clarence Peery.

title: FOYT LEADS RAIN-CURTAILED INDY QUALIFYING
description: For the last part of 10 miles, A.J. Foyt drove along the jagged edge this afternoon. During his third of four laps on the first complete run on the first day of qualifications for the 65th Indianapolis 500, Foyt was face to face with the wall between turns 1 and 2. But seconds after avoiding an accident, he became the leader in the rain-delayed competition for the pole position.

title: The Action Isn't Over When One Turns 50
description: Brain death at 50?
