Judith Greene (in ''An Old Warrior' Seeks New Battles,'' Opinion Page) bemoans her fate that having reached her 50th birthday, she is no longer ''received'' into the kind of hot debates that raged in the 1960's and 1970's - debates she seems to believe are the undisputed turf of the under-30-year-olds.

title: THE REAL LINING BEHIND THE CLOUD OF 3-MILE ISLAND
description: RELATIONS men are professional optimists, and so it was not surprising to learn that Samuel Laird, manager of public relations for the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, sees a big silver lining in the cloud of Three Mile Island (''The Long-Term Benefits of Three Mile Island Will Eclipse Its Short-Term Consequences,'' Opinion Page, April 19).

title: DAMASCUS RADIO REBUFFS 'THREAT'
description: A special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived here today for talks with Syrian officials intended to prevent a wider confrontation between Syria and Israel.

title: Quake Shakes Northern Japan
description: A strong earthquake hit northern Japan today, rattling windows and doors but causing no major damage or casualties, the Central Meteorological Agency said.

title: AUDUBON GROUP GETS NATURALIST'S TREASURE
description: ''WOODS, open fields, swamps, two good-sized brooks, and a waterfall. In my mind, I ticked off the list of things we had hoped for in a country home. Miraculously, they all seemed here.'' The late Edwin Way Teale was describing Trail Wood, the 130-acre homesite in the northeast corner of Connecticut that he shared with his wife, Nellie, for 21 years. Now the stewardship of this land that nurtured the Pulitzer Prize-winning naturalist has fallen upon the Connecticut Audubon Society. Mrs. Teale, who is an accomplished naturalist in her own right, will maintain life tenure of the farmhouse and its immediate environs.

title: Ideas and Trends; Missouri Declines A Costly Honor
description: Not for nothing is Missouri's slogan, ''Show Me.'' State officials last week quickly rejected a novel desegregation plan for St. Louis schools which was the brainchild of the Justice Department, but which would have Missouri foot the bill.

title: Raiders' Trial Could Affect N.F.L. Power
description: The National Football League will go to court Monday to defend one of the foundations that has helped professional sports grow into a huge and lucrative industry in America - the right of a handful of team owners to allocate markets and regulate economic competition among themselves.

title: The Region; Disarmament Edict; For City Schools
description: It would be hard to imagine a more serious breach of discipline than carrying a gun or other dangerous weapon in school. Yet the New York City public schools have left punishment of such offenses essentially at the discretion of principals, without even a firm requirement that the police be notified.

title: TRIBUTE TO THE RIVER BY ELIZABETH SWADOS
description: YONKERS ''THE whole idea is that you are in a boat, rowing from river to river,'' Carolyn Dutton told about 20 Westchester children last week at the Hudson River Museum. Miss Dutton, a musician, was arranging the overture for Elizabeth Swados's premier of ''A Tribute to the Hudson River.''

title: Children's Books
description: PERFECT THE PIG Written and Illustrated by Susan Jeschke. Unpaged. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: NOT MUCH TIME TO COOL CRISIS OVER LEBANON
description: After months of worrying about potential explosions in Poland or Central America, Washington last week was faced instead with the possibility of war between Syria and Israel in the tinderbox region that the Administration assumed until recently did not require priority consideration. With all the ingredients present for a major clash over Lebanon, it was the Reagan Administration's first international crisis.

title: Ideas and Trends; Spared Once, Spared Forever
description: By the narrowest margin, the Supreme Court last week gave a new twist to the Fifth Amendment protection against double jeopardy. Voting 5 to 4, the Court reversed a decision of the Missouri Supreme Court that a defendant once convicted of murder, but spared the death penalty, could be sentenced to death after a new trial which the courts had granted.

title: Leadership Is a Good Horse
description: The news of the week was THE REAGAN VICTORY. At least it was part of the news. When the Democratic House voted for the President's stringent budget by a 77-vote margin, even Democrats were impressed. ''He's a winner and he's a hero,'' said Thomas Foley, the Democratic whip.

title: Sihanouk Says He Accepts A Chinese Offer of Arms
description: Prince Norodam Sihanouk, the former Cambodian head of state, said today that China had offered him enough arms to equip an army of 3,000 men to fight the Vietnamese and that he had accepted.

title: Miss Kreamer Wed to Writer
description: Anne Enggas Kreamer, distribution manager of international sales for the Children's Television Workshop, was married at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York yesterday to Kurt Byars Andersen, a writer with Time magazine and author. Msgr. Myles Bourke of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church and the Rev. Stephen Garmey of Calvary performed the ceremony.

title: NIGHTMARES SUSPECTED IN BED DEATHS OF 18 LAOTIANS
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta is conducting an intensive inquiry into the manner in which 18 apparently healthy Laotian refugees died mysteriously in their sleep in this country within the last four years. One possibility being explored is that they were frightened to death by nightmares.

title: Sermon or Soda Water
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon to Speak in Seattle Today Amid News Media Dispute on Fee
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon will deliver a fund-raising speech here tomorrow, but most of the Seattle area news media will boycott it because the Republican Party wants each reporter to make a $150 political contribution.

title: Fear as a Form Of Pollution
description: The fact that a woman may have called Morris Bruckman (''Fear, Too, Is a Form of Pollution,'' Opinion Page) pleading for the safety of her children does not mean that all her fears were unfounded. His analogy between a man's dying as a result of being hit on the head with a baseball bat and the risk assessment factor is ridiculous.

title: A PIONEER FEMINIST SAVORS GRANDMOTHER ROLE
description: HAIRED and gracious, a welcoming smile spread across her deeply-lined face, Chase Going Woodhouse tugged furiously at the recalcitrant wrought-iron latch that fastens the side door of her 1774 red clapboard farmhouse on the hill. All about her, tulips and daffodils were bursting into bloom. It is the season of rebirth, she acknowledged, as she opened the door.

title: MIDTOWN ZONING: LEAVE IT ALONE; BY Der Scutt The writer of the following article, the partner in charge of design for the firm of Swanke Hayden Connell & Partners, served on a committee of architects of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects that considered city rezoning proposals for the midtown area. He submitted a dissenting report on its recommendations.
description: Proposed changes in the zoning law governing office development in the midtown area have serious and perhaps unrecognized implications for the city's future.

title:
Comment;
DON'T SELL CONRAIL
description: P UBLIC statements by the Secretary of Transportation, Drew Lewis, have opened the door to the possible reacquisition of Conrail by the same financial interests that destroyed America's Eastern rail establishment. The time seems ripe for this new ripoff, now that the taxpayer has substantially rehabilitated this rail structure.

title: Is 'Closed,' Israeli Aide Says
description: A dispute that developed this week after Prime Minister Menachem Begin sharply criticized Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany should be regarded as closed, Foreign Minister @Yitzhak Shamir said today.

title: CUTTING ARTS BUDGETS IS A MISTAKE
description: THERE seems to be no justification for cuts in the budgets of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: SPRINGTIME IN THE ROCKIES BRINGS OMENS OF A DROUGHT
description: Along the front range of the Colorado Rockies this week the shoulders of the highest peaks were still draped with snow. But below the 10,000-foot level the mountains were bare and so was the cupboard of snow-melted water on which vast sections of the High Plains east of here depend for irrigation and municipal water supplies.

title: HAIG ASSERTS SOVIET WANES SPIRTUALLY, BUT RISES AS THREAT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said here today that the Soviet Union was showing signs of ''spiritual exhaustion'' and was facing ''an extremely gloomy future.'' But such problems, he warned, might make it a more dangerous adversary.

title: QUILTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS AT THE NEUBERGER
description: PURCHASE THE Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York here is at the moment exceptionally rich in shows, all of them on view through Aug. 23. The monochromatic silk-screen prints of Robert Rauschenberg and ''New Acquisitions and Selections from the Permanent Collection'' will be the subject for a later review. Under consideration now are 30 quilts from Kansas and a portfolio of dance photographs by Barbara Morgan who was born in Kansas in 1900 but now lives in Scarsdale.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Luggage Bargains In White Plains
description: Victoria Luggage, in business in the White Plains area for 32 years at successively larger locations and now owner of its own building, offers free initialing and gift-wrapping on mostly domestic wellknown brands of luggage, attache cases and personal leather goods. The luggage, briefcases, envelopes and attache cases all are discounted at 25 percent off suggested retail prices, unless otherwise marked down by greater margins as styles change or lines are discontinued.

title: W.H. Faude Weds Constance Robinson
description: Constance Brainard Robinson 2d, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seymour Robinson Jr. of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Wilson Hinsdale Faude, son of Mrs. John Paul Faude of Farmington, Conn., and the late Mr. Faude. The Rev. Allan House O'Neil performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford.

title: Latest Bulletin: Conrail Travels at a Dog's Pace
description: Conrail commuters are often delayed and many learn to respond with a shrug. On Friday morning, however, some passengers responded with a smile when told the Stamford local was following a dog down the tracks at a pace more like that of a snail.

title: YALE PRESENTS MAJOR EXHIBITION OF 15TH-CENTURY GERMAN
description: A BEAUTIFULLY designed and displayed exhibition that is international in its scope and importance is on view at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven until June 14. Entitled ''Hans Baldung Grien: Prints & Drawings,'' it is the largest and most ambitious show of the artist's work ever put on in this country. Although his name is by no means a household word, Baldung, as he is usually called, since Grien was his nickname, is considered by scholars and connoisseurs to be among the greatest of German artists, ranking only slightly behind artists such as Albrecht Durer, his teacher. His extraordinary paintings are certainly equal in quality to his drawings and prints, but Baldung worked on wood panels, which we know today to be too fragile to travel. Only three of his paintings are in this hemisphere, and those in Europe are unlikely ever to leave the museums and churches where they are currently located. So, short of traveling in Europe, the comprehensive show at Yale is the best chance we will have to encounter this complex artist.

title: Sex-Education Article Called Logical Claptrap
description: I have no firm opinions on the subject of sex education, but I become furious on the subject of claptrap logic, that time-honored tool of demagogues. And Elizabeth A. Sadowski's throwaway remark that ''... ever since 'relevant education,' basic skills have gone downhill'' (''Local Control of Sex Education Is a Myth,'' Opinion Page, April 26) is enough to set me off.

title: POLICE PRESS SEARCH FOR A BRONX GIRL, 3
description: The disappearance of a 3-year-old girl from a Bronx shoe store Friday afternoon has prompted a search by more than 50 police officers and scores of friends and relatives in the Fordham Road neighborhood where the girl was last seen.

title: ARMED FORCES DAY: MUSKETS AND MISSILES
description: ROCKAWAY TOWNSHIP HOSTAGES will be rescued by helicopter and paratroopers will stage an invasion at the Army Research and Development Command here next Saturday in a program marking Armed Forces Day.

title: NORTON'S LEGS ARE QUESTIONED BUT HE'S RATED IN GOOD
description: SHAPE BY MICHAEL KATZ

title: COUP FAILED, BUT SPAIN'S POLITICS STILL REELS FROM THE AFTERSHOCK
description: Two and a half months after a military putsch nearly felled Spain's infant democracy, politicians, journalists and other public figures have become gloomy, edgy and demoralized, holding their breath as if waiting for the next blow. The fright created by the February attack on Parliament, which was held hostage for 18 hours, has altered some basic assumptions of Spain's politics.

title: Russian Cruise
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Teamster Chief Ordered To Pay $10,000 in Libel Suit
description: A jury today ruled against Dave Beck, the former teamsters' union president, and awarded Peter Marinoff $10,000 in damages in his $500,000 libel suit involving a dispute between the teamsters and Mr. Marinoff's former brewery in Tacoma in the 1930's.

title: Leisure; IT'S ALMOST TIME TO PLANT THE BACKYARD TOMATO PLANT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Chandoha is a professional photographer who gardens as a hobby. By WALTER CHANDOHA

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1950's, ''Lord of the Flies,'' here recounts the fortunes of Matty, who is destined by mutilations he suffered during the London blitz to contend with visions of the forces of evil during a checkered career in England and Australia. Our reviewer John Thompson called William Golding ''a wizard'' and suggested that ''this strange story, a magical fable'' may symbolize his own experience.

title: BREZHNEV URGES TALKS BUT SAYS FORCES ARE READY
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, declared today that the Soviet Union favored a ''broad dialogue'' with the West but was ready to respond to any military challenge.

title: Bigger Stadium Planned
description: The Brigham Young University Board of Trustees has approved a bowl expansion of Cougar football stadium which will nearly double its seating capacity, bringing it from 35,000 to 68,000.

title: Dance View; KENNETH KING IS A THINKING MAN'S CHOREOGRAPHER
description: Looking back, it now seems appropriate that one of Kenneth King's most acclaimed early dances was accompanied by a reading from an essay by Rene Descartes in which the French philosopher, after declaring his intention to seek truth by re-examining the evidence of his senses, asked himself one of the classic questions of epistemology: ''Am I awake or am I dreaming?''

title: No Headline
description: Historically, a man who had title to a vast amount of acreage and who could not maintain his estate or pay the tax collector was considered ''land poor.'' John Wilford's article leaves me with the eerie feeling that the American vision is becoming increasingly clouded by dreams of spacial glory and the resultant inevitability of becoming ''space poor.'' ELEANOR HERLANDS, Stamford, Conn.

title:
Stamps;
A TRIBUTE TO SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSOCIATIONS
description: For the past 150 years, savings and loan associationshave been a prime force in enabling Americans to realize their dream of owning a home of their own. These institutions have also been staunchly devoted to Benjamin Franklin's famous precept: ''A penny saved is a penny earned.''

title: REASONING MAY BE EVOLVING, NOT FAILING
description: To the Editor:

title: '13 RUE DE L'AMOUR'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE AT the Arena Players, the title of the play does not appear in lights outside the theater, but this wishful description does: ''A funny French farce.'' In the playing at Arena, it is no such thing.

title:
Gardening;
MULCH AND OTHER WATER-SAVING METHODS
description: THERE is still concern over the prospects for serious summer drought. Although spring rains may have provided sufficient moisture to meet the immediate needs of plantings, they have done little to replace the moisture deep within the soil or in the storage reservoirs. Unless adequate precipitation arrives before the normally hot, dry midsummer, a critical moisture level will prevail for most plantings.

title: Abroad at Home; TERROR AND TRAGEDY
description: A group of terrorists, highly disciplined and utterly brutal in its disregard for human life, set out to overthrow the existing order and establish a Marxist state. Its methods are murder and intimidation; most of its victims are innocent civilians.

title: CAREY PROPOSES CREATING AGENCY TO FINANCE LOCAL WATER SYSTEMS
description: Governor Carey proposed legislation today that would make new funds available for work on water and sewer systems around the state, including completion of the third water tunnel in New York City.

title: FINANCIAL ANALYSTS WARY ABOUT LILCO'S FUTURE
description: AS the Long Island Lighting Company moves toward the final phase of construction on its long-troubled Shoreham nuclear power plant, the utility's future financial health remains uncertain, independent financial analysts said last week.

title: JUDGE ASSAILS VACANCIES ON COURTS
description: A prominent judge has told a judicial conference that vacancies for judges constitute ''the most severe problem facing us this year'' in the Federal court circuit covering New York, Connecticut and Vermont.

title: Mom
description: A mother is a woman who, one Sunday in May, is presented with a ruffled blouse. Or perfume. Or breakfast in bed. A phone call anyway. And honored with a Presidential proclamation. ''Mothers,'' this year's reads reassuringly, ''... remain the heart of the American family.''

title: Plane's Brakes Lock at Newark
description: The brakes on an Eastern Air Lines jet with 133 persons aboard locked as it accelerated down a runway at Newark International Airport today, forcing it to halt its takeoff on a flight to Tampa, Fla., officials said.

title: Chess; INCONSISTENT PLAY
description: The very talented crop of young American hopefuls was disappointed in failing to achieve any grandmaster norms in the Louis Stratham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif. Indeed, the only players who hit the requisite score for a leg toward being awarded grandmaster rank were those who already had the title.

title: A NURSERY WITH A FLAIR FOR THE UNUSUAL
description: LITCHFIELD EACH spring a Litchfield hillside bursts into such spectacular bloom that even frequent visitors catch their breath upon turning into the tiny parking lot at its base.

title: DESIGN CHOSEN FOR 15-STORY U.S. TOWER IN JAMAICA
description: A 15-story, $92.7 million building that will house a regional center of the Social Security Administration in downtown Jamaica, Queens, is expected to provide 3,000 permanent jobs for the long-depressed business district when it is completed in from three years to five years.

title: Kings' Marriage Commended
description: To the Sports Editor: As a career-oriented woman and an athlete, I commend the relationship of Billie Jean King and her husband, Larry. In a world that is subject to the strains of changing sex roles and the constant exposure of the private life of famous athletes such as Mrs. King, it is admirable to hear Larry King express his love and support of his wife without the slightest hint of self-consciousness or a bruised ego because of her affair with a woman.

title: Considering Prospects For Art Grants
description: I enjoyed the article concerning Norwalk Mayor William Collins's program in public art (Murals Brighten City's Older Areas, April 19). Unfortunately, the budget cuts proposed by President Reagan will seriously undermine such activities.

title: NURSES VOTE TO END A 3-DAY STRIKE AT THE JERSEY CITY MEDICAL CENTER
description: Striking nurses at the Jersey City Medical Center ratified a new two-year contract today, ending a three-day walkout, hospital officials said.

title: Why Derby Didn't Fit Favorite
description: Stanley Hough had a feeling that Proud Appeal was wrong on the morning of the Kentucky Derby. The colt had not been finishing his food since arriving in Louisville a week earlier and had been nervous in his stall all week, bothered by the noise from the race track, which virtually runs through the Churchill Downs barn area.

title: The Nation; More Freedom, Less Information?
description: Loopholes in the Freedom of Information Act, adopted in 1966, have grown narrower and narrower under amendments by lawmakers and interpretations by law-enforcers. Now the Reagan Administration has apparently concluded that it's time to move more decisively toward getting the public off the back of the Federal bureaucracy.

title: A REFUSAL TO PERCEIVE SOCIAL PROBLEMS
description: THE demographics of the 1980's, from my point of view, are little different from what they were 30 years ago when I hitchhiked from Minnesota to New York City to live and work as a student group worker on 124th Street, around the corner from the St. Theresa Hotel.

title: Richard Yates
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Conditions; A DRAG ON ALUMINUM
description: Demand for aluminum, as with many basic materials, generally lags a shift in economic conditions. And so it is with the steep downturn of late last year.

title: The Nation; Dear Mr. Wilson: Don't Build It
description: In the case of San Diego, neither the prospects of a quick fix for downtown nor the pleas of an ambitious mayor could stay the taxpayers' revolt. Voters participating in the largest balloting-bymail ever undertaken in this country, according to results announced last week, rejected a proposal to build a $224 million convention center in the rundown center city.

title: The World; Host and Guest Equally Pleased
description: President Reagan provided the pomp and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki did his best under the circumstances last week. After two days of Presidential hospitality, including 50 White House honor guards carrying dozens of Japanese and American flags, the two leaders were ''speaking openly as real buddies,'' aides said, about getting Japan to increase its contribution to Western defenses.

title: GOING ON-ON-ONE WITH EXPECTATIONS
description: AS seasons go in the life of writers, this has been a very good spring for Tom Philbin of Centerport. Three of his books have just been published. ''Home Repairs Every Woman Can Do'' is out in a Prentice-Hall paperback. ''Ninja: The Clan of Death,'' another work of nonfiction, written with Al Weiss, editor of Official Karate Magazine, has been issued as a Pocket Books Original. And, perhaps most important of all for a man 47 years old whose dreams of a literary career were inspired in youth by the image of Ernest Hemingway, Mr. Philbin's first novel has been published.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: CONNECTICUT business leaders, who visited the Peoples Republic of China last May, are preparing to return. ''We have formed a trade mission which will be leaving July 11 and returning July 26,'' with stops in Peking, Shanghai, Canton, and Hong Kong, said Leon Lemaire, president of the Connecticut-China Trade Council in Hartford.

title: DANCE: BY SARA RUDNER
description: Friday night's program by the Sara Rudner Performance Ensemble at the White Dog Studio could easily be divided into the preliminaries and the main event.

title: Hidden Economy
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''No Cuts Here: The Life on the Tab'' (March 29): The conference or sales luncheon may be very profitable to the host, but that is no reason for transferring (via a tax deduction) much of the cost of that luncheon to the bulk of the taxpayer population.

title: A CLEANING FIT UNEARTHS FADING MEMORIES
description: I NEVER know when it's going to strike. For months, even years, I'll be immune. Then, like catching the flu, I'll have an attack. Only it doesn't send me to bed, but under it. It's unnerving.

title: The Region; No Raw Nukes For New Jersey
description: With an abundance of man-made environmental hazards, New Jersey hardly needs to stir up any natural ones. That was a distinct possibility when Exxon Minerals and Standard Oil of Ohio began exploring a large and potentially rich deposit of uranium in the Ramapo Mountains.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ By John Wilson Maxine Sullivan was 26 years old when she caught the imagination of the Swing Era by singing an old Scottish folksong, ''Loch Lomond,'' with a gently swinging beat. It was the arrangement by Claude Thornhill - the pianist who led a very unusual big band with French horns, woodwinds and what was called ''hanging walls of sound'' - that gave Miss Sullivan the basis for her now-classic performance.

title: Sound; VIDEODISKS BATTLE FOR CONSUMER FAVOR
description: We are being dragged, willy-nilly and perplexed, into the era of the video wars. The opening skirmish is now being fought between two rival systems of videodisks. Defending its priority as firstcomer is the Laserdisc, developed by Philips and espoused by Magnavox and Pioneer. It is now challenged by RCA's wholly different videodisk, launched in March with nationwide hoopla. Both are now battling in the market, issuing hopeful and contradictory bulletins. And to thicken the plot, a third contender waits in the wings. It is the VHD videodisk, spawned by a Japanese consortium under the banner of Panasonic, ready to pounce by Christmas. All three are incompatible. They're out to kill each other, and we -the public - are to decide who wins by paying our money and taking our choice.

title: GEO: LIME GREEN EDSEL OF A MAGAZINE SEARCHES FOR AN IMAGE THAT WORKS
description: T HE dream was that it would become a Cadillac among magazines. Many bags of gold were laid aside to insure success. The West Germans promised to pump $20 million into it, a lot of money in any man's language, and it was clear they were not kidding. The sumptuous penthouse offices at 450 Park Avenue alone were testimony to that.

title:
ART;
UNFOLDING THE ESTHETICS OF THE COBRA GROUP
description: HEMPSTEAD ONLY 10 years after the Cobra group was formed in Paris in 1948, its work was already being called ''probably the most neglected body of modern art in existence.'' The situation has changed little in the intervening years, but now ''A Cobra Portfolio'' at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery gives us a sampling of works by the group's members, as well as shedding some light on why the group came into being and what it signified to the artists of postwar Europe.

title: SISTERHOOD IS BRACED FOR THE REAGANAUTS
description: For the women's movement, which until the election of the new Administration seemed well on the way to becoming an accepted interest group, these are hard times. Now there is a President who opposes the Equal Rights Amendment, who is lukewarm on affirmative action, who favors a ban on abortions and who has endorsed budget cuts in programs of special relevance to women, from education to food stamps.

title: Phillies 9, Padres 6
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Steve Carlton gave up nine hits but struck out 11 as he won his sixth game of the season without a loss. Gary Matthews drove in four runs, three with a homer, for the Phillies.

title: No Headline
description: To an increasing number of Americans, the vision of America shown in the cover picture as two astronauts imprisoned in their console is about as appealing as an industrial landscape near Elizabeth, N.J., or Pittsburgh. The real frontier is to make the United States a humane and livable place, and there are millions working on this in communities across the land. PETE SEEGER, Beacon, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: In the article ''College Sports Must Choose: Amateur of Pro?'' (The New York Times, May 3) there was an editing error in the last paragraph. The paragraph should have read: The time has come for men and women to insist that universities make a public commitment either to the educational or to the business model of sport.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Dessoff Choirs Offer Bach's B Minor Mass
description: When Bach's B Minor Mass was conducted by Michael Hammond in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, nothing was seriously out of place. But the 67-member Dessoff Choirs and the small orchestra, like the competent soloists -Susan Belling, soprano; Catherine Robbin, mezzo; Constantine Cassolas, tenor, and Arthur Burrows, baritone -aimed more often for secular energy than religious drama, without doing justice to either.

title: 8 COMPANIES IN A DANCE FESTIVAL
description: ELIZABETH DANCE is alive in New Jersey, but Richard M. Stickles says most residents of the state are unaware of what he calls one of its great virtues. He plans to change all that next Saturday.

title: CONGRESS ACTING TO EXTEND V.A. COUNSELING CENTERS
description: Terming the Reagan Administration's plan to abolish 91 storefront counseling centers for Vietnam veterans ''disgraceful'' and ''devastating,'' Congressmen have quietly moved to restore funds for the outreach program.

title: Common Market Talks Open
description: Foreign ministers of European Common Market nations today began a two-day informal meeting that Market sources said was expected to concentrate on the Middle East.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
BLUESTONE FOREVER
description: THE last bluestone driveway on our street is what we have here. Over the years, one by one, the others have defected: our neighbors. Calling in the blacktop people; getting their cars off the premises so that the driveway can set, like a new black scar; edging it with bricks or blocks; lining it, finally, with smart little lights all the way to the door. Sleek, Untroubled. A driveway's driveway.

title: NEW HOUSING CREATED FOR THE ELDERLY
description: THE schoolroom clocks and the knee-high drinking fountains have been pulled off the walls of the 75-year-old Washington School in New Rochelle.

title: Peggy Nash Bride Of Edward L. Marx
description: The marriage of Peggy Nash, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eric J. Nash of Forest Hills, Queens, to Edward Lurie Marx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Marx of Bethesda, Md., took place at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club yesterday. Rabbi Steven Pinsky officiated.

title: TRANSPORTATION DEATHS INCREASED TO MORE THAN 56,000 LAST YEAR
description: The National Transportation Safety Board reported today that in 1980 more than 56,000 people were killed in transportation accidents.

title: Headliners Off With His Headset!
description: Royalty once had real power, and knavery such as Britain's Prince Charles suffered from last week would have cost some rascal his life. During his recent visit to Australia, it was reported, someone bugged the Prince's telephone, recorded his conversations with his mother, Queen Elizabeth, and his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, and sold transcripts to a journalist.

title: Kathleen Staniewicz Is Bride
description: In the Chapel at St. Lawrence Seminary in Beacon, N.Y., yesterday, Kathleen Elizabeth Staniewicz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Staniewicz of Beacon, was married to Michael Allen Cox, son of Mary Lee Jamison Cox of Boston and the late Allen Ernest Cox. The Rev. Vincent Fortunato performed the Roman Catholic cermony. The bride is an alumna of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing. Mr. Cox expects to graduate May 24 from the University of Massachusetts Medical College.

title: Terry Antrim, John Leness to Marry July 18
description: Dr. and Mrs. Harry T. Antrim of Coconut Grove, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Terry Carter Antrim, to John Southworth Leness, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Leness of New York. The wedding is planned for July 18 at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Greenwood, Va.

title: The World; Mexico Keeps a Promise
description: When the Reagan Administration, charging that Nicaragua was helping Salvadoran guerrillas, cut off aid to Managua, Mexico promised to take up the slack. Last week in Mexico City, the two countries signed aid agreements that may total $200 million by 1983.

title: Keeping Well With Vitamins
description: Jane E. Brody's article, ''Deficiencies of Vitamins'' (March 29) was unnecessarily negative. It is true that certain cautions should be undertaken before using vitamin-mineral supplements.

title: MALL QUESTIONED
description: Bright lights are not the only signs of glitter and sparkle along Broadway these days. Development prospects and planning controversy on the blocks north of Times Square are providing a show of their own.

title: The Week in Business; RATES SPIRAL UPWARD
description: Interest rates pushed upward last week and there were predictions by the nation's top executives in the Business Council that rates would stay high. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan made the same forecast. The Federal Reserve raised the discount rate to a record 14 percent from 13 percent and major banks increased the prime lending rate to 19 percent from 18 percent.

title: TURKEY'S COMEBACK SUCCESSFUL TABLED
description: HACKETTSTOWN SUNDAY dinner at the Kuhn home here will be something special today - and not just because it's Mother's Day. What will give the meal that extra touch is the 17-pound gobbler that will sit on the Kuhns' table. The tom came not from the frozen-food case of the local supermarket, or from a butcher shop, but from the woods near Walpack Valley in the Delaware Water Gap, where last Monday Louis Kuhn became the first New Jersey hunter in 68 years to bag a wild turkey.

title: Air Travelers' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: No Evidence of Sabotage Found in Plane's Wreckage
description: The president of the Air Force Investigation Board said today there was ''absolutely no evidence'' of sabotage in the crash of a military plane Wednesday in which 21 persons were killed. All possible explanations for the crash are still under investigation, he said.

title: VACATION SITES BID BY FRESH AIR FUND
description: ''IT was one of those moments when to desire is to resolve.'' And so, in the August 1881, issue of Lippincott's magazine, Philip G. Hubert recalled the birth of the Fresh Air Fund, the independent, nonprofit organization that is once again seeking to provide free summer vacations in the country for underprivileged children from New York City.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 1 5 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 3 4 17 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) Anillustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 4 6 3 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 5 2 6 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) A journey through that greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all. 6 5 5 REFLEX, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A British jockey copes with blackmail and discovers his own missing past. 7 3 29 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history.

title: Patri Captures Richardson Golf
description: Tom Patri, a senior at Florida Southern University who plans to turn professional June 1, won the 34th annual William D. Richardson memorial golf tournament today, and his age advantage helped him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet system is showing signs of spiritual exhaustion,'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (1:6.)

title: LITERARY SET DISCOVERS A HAVEN
description: STONY BROOK NEXT Saturday evening, a surprisingly large group of local writers, novelists and poets are expected to gather at the Corner Bookshop here to celebrate the publication of yet another book by one of their own - ''Cocktails at Somoza's,'' an account of the Nicaraguan revolution by Stony Brook's Richard Elman.

title: REGIONAL POWER SEEMS AIM IN MEXICO'S U.S. JET DEAL
description: Mexico's decision to modernize its antiquated air force by buying a dozen F-5E fighters from the United States seems prompted by a desire to consolidate the nation's prestige and influence as a regional power in the convulsed Caribbean basin.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK: JOE ELY
description: Joe Ely's late show at the Bottom Line Thursday was underattended for a musician of Mr. Ely's stature, and the set suffered from some dogged, loud and rather repetitous jamming. But at his frequent best, Mr. Ely reaffirmed his position as one of the brightest, cleverest lights of modern-day country-rock music.

title: AT JOHNS HOPKINS
description: THE Johns Hopkins University Press's all-time best seller, with almost 100,000 copies sold, is called ''The Johns Hopkins Atlas of Human Functional Anatomy.'' Now that is not exactly a catchy title, but the book sells steadily to students learning to be paramedical technicians and even makes its way into high school science classrooms.

title: by STANLEY CARR
description: A glimpse of the plowed field where Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer are believed to have first met; the use of an armchair in front of a wide-screen television set in a duke's stately home on the wedding day and chauffer-driven trips to Windsor and other royal sites are among the ingredients of tours to Britain that are being offered to Americans.

title: RALPH SHAPEY AT 60- HE DEFIED NEGLECT
description: This spring is the season in which the musical world is celebrating the 60th birthday of Ralph Shapey. The only trouble with that statement is that not everyone in the musical world may be quite sure just who Ralph Shapey is, and the celebrations, while fervent enough, are not exactly widespread. Mr. Shapey, who turned 60 on March 12, is not a household name like Aaron Copland, or an omnipresent local figure like William Schuman, or as beloved a teacher on the New York scene as Otto Luening - to name three other composers who recently celebrated milestone birthdays.

title:
CRAFTS;
HUNKS OF WOOD TO WHIRLINGS
description: NEITHER snow nor rain nor gloom of night stays these couriers from their appointed rounds. The same can be said of Rubye Copus, a contemporary woodcarver. Her ''rounds'' consist of a short trip from her house to the barn on her property on Ring Road in the tiny rural town of Salt Point, about a 30-minute drive from the northern Westchester border. The former horse barn is now Miss Copus's workshop, and it is here that she performs her woodcarver's magic - even on days so cold in the unheated barn that she must wear two pairs of gloves to work.

title: Children's Books
description: WESTMARK By Lloyd Alexander. 184 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $10.25. (Ages 10 to 14) By JEAN FRITZ

title: BIRMINGHAM TO RESUME LIMITED BUS SERVICE JUNE 1
description: The board of the local transit system voted yesterday to restore limited bus service June 1 to the Birmingham area, where 11,000 riders have been served for 10 weeks by taxicabs and a makeshift fleet of 13 church buses and vans.

title: MOSCOW SAYS SHOSTAKOVICHES WERE LURED TO WEST
description: The Soviet press reported for the first time this week that the son and grandson of the late composer Dmitri Shostakovich had defected, branding the son, Maxim, a ''would-be successor'' who was lured away by Western agents promising wealth and glory.

title: No Headline
description: I agree with John Wilford's conclusion that the people are once again ahead of their leaders - the American people are champing at the bit to get back into space in a big way.

title: Typographical Union Is Honored
description: The International Typographical Union, formed 129 years ago in Cincinnati, has been honored by the Ohio Historical Association as the oldest existing national labor union. A bronze marker was installed Tuesday in the sidewalk outside Cincinnati City Hall. The old National Typographical Union, which later changed its name, was formed in the City Council chambers on May 5, 1852.

title: FEAR AS A FORM OF POLLUTION
description: Three cheers for Morris Bruckman, who is fighting the battle against fear and ignorance. Dioxin and nuclear radiation are the twin targets of the ignorance lobby.

title: New Jersey Guide; ON WITH THE DANCE
description: May O'Donnell, a member of Martha Graham's original dance company in the 1930's and one of New York City's top modern-dance teachers for more than 30 years, has been stirring a flurry of interest recently with her new troupe, the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company.

title: WHY PUBLIC TV FACES A CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Desmond Smith, a news producer with the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation in Toronto, has worked for ABC, CBS and NBC. By DESMOND SMITH

title: NEW ART FOR RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK FOR nine years, Harry Devlin of Mountainside, an author and illustrator of children's books with his wife, Wende, has sought to set up a repository in New Jersey for such works.

title: WHERE WRITING OUTRANKS POLITICS
description: THE 1980-81 literary season in France has been framed in thunderbolts. In September ''Les Nouvelles Litteraires'' ran the stark headline ''La Theorie Est Foutue'' (''Theory Is All Washed Up'') to summarize a long interview with Christian Bourgois, a publisher who had invested heavily in literary theory. A few weeks later the influential Marxist philosopher Louis Althusser strangled his wife in their apartment in the Ecole Normale Superieure and was promptly locked up in St. Anne's mental hospital. Every newspaper in Paris editorialized about the relations between intellectuals, insanity, Marxism and educational institutions. The shock this spring has been the stinging verdict by a Paris court against Francoise Sagan for ''illicit reproduction'' (plagiarism) in her last novel, ''Le Chien Couchant.'' All remaining copies and the printer's plates must be destroyed. Sagan is already enmeshed in a nasty contractual suit with her publisher, Flammarion, and has announced that a different house will publish her new book, an 800-page novel.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
A MOTHER'S COCOON OF LOVE
description: SOMETIMES, in the pain of the night, a mother needs to reach out. She needs to feel the presence of her children. She seeks them out in silent, tearful defense of her own womanhood. She has passed from childhood on the wings of these angels.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 10, 1981
description: International The Soviet Union is showing signs of ''spiritual exhaustion,'' and faces ''an extremely gloomy future,'' and this may make it a more dangerous adversary, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in a commencement address at Syracuse University. Continuing the Reagan Administration's attacks on the Soviet Union, Mr. Haig for the first time drew attention to Soviet Union's weaknesses as well as its strength. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: WEST BERLINERS TO VOTE TODAY ON A RANGE OF HEATED ISSUES
description: In an election that could indicate growing dissatisfaction with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government in Bonn, West Berliners go to the polls tomorrow in a City Council election.

title: THEATER: 'THE CAT WALK'
description: For 15 years, Roger Furman, as founder and artistic director of the New Heritage Repertory Theater in Harlem, has been stimulating a theatrical community with plays by himself and other dramatists. It was clear from a recent performance of Mr. Furman's current effort, ''The Cat Walk,'' a new play by Allison West, that the New Heritage is conducting a responsive dialogue with its audience.

title: MAYOR INDICATES VETO IS PLANNED
description: The City Council passed a bill today allowing the sale of $75 million in bonds to aid the public schools and reimburse businesses for property tax overcharges, but an aide indicated that Mayor Kevin H. White would veto the measure because it would cut his spending power.

title: SAN FRANCISCO UPSET BY TOURISM DECLINE
description: Tourists still crowd the cable cars, the sidewalks at Fishermen's Wharf and the big hotel lobbies. But there are fewer of them, about 8 percent fewer last year than in 1979, and that worries a lot of people here.

title:
LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
PUBLIC ART GOES TO STONY BROOK
description: STONY BROOK ''FOR everyone who has to wait in the bus shelter twice a day, at least it could be an interesting experience,'' said Mindy Greenberg, an art student at the State University at Stony Brook, explaining why she painted the 20-by-8-foot bus shelter on campus in bright orange, red, yellow, blue, green and white abstract designs.

title: PRESS IN POLAND CONDEMNS BURNING OF A POLICE STATION
description: The Communist press condemned an incident last night in the town of Otwock, 19 miles east of Warsaw, in which youths who were angered over alleged police brutality attacked a police station and burned it to the ground.

title: Children's Books
description: THE COMEBACK DOG By Jane Resh Thomas. Illustrated by Troy Howell. 62 pp. New York: Houghton Mifflin/Clarion. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By MARJORIE N.ALLEN

title: Music Noted in Brief
description: Friday's concert by the Group for Contemporary Music at Cooper Union featured modern America at its two extremes - first George Crumb, high priest of the sound effect, and then Elliott Carter, musical architect par excellence.

title: Harper of Jets Out of Hospital
description: Bruce Harper of the Jets has been released from Lenox Hill Hospital after a month's recuperation from a heart and lung inflammation.

title: The World; U.S. Lobbies Its Western Allies
description: After his recent brushes with unfriendly powers - not to mention the White House staff - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was back on more congenial turf last week. Meeting in Rome with Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, he obtained unanimous agreement on a tougher stance toward Moscow and was rewarded afterward with Presidential kudos.

title: CAMDEN IS DOWN, BUT FAR FROM OUT
description: CAMDEN ONCE a month, the sad heart of this shrunken city pulses with life. Traffic and pedestrians fill the streets, and there are long lines outside the downtown banks.

title: Fresh Air and Friendly Towns
description: Brenda screamed. The creature in front of her looked huge, and its horns threatening. Thinking back on the experience, Brenda says, ''At first I was scared because the cow be so big. Then I take the rope and lead her around the pen.''

title: THE ENGAGED MAN OF LETTERS
description: MATTHEW JOSEPHSON, BOURGEOIS BOHEMIAN By David E. Shi. Illustrated. 314 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95. By JUSTIN KAPLAN

title: Music: Noted in Brief; De Peyer, Clarinetist, Conducts Melos Sinfonia
description: Gervase de Peyer, who is well known here as a clarinet virtuoso and member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, seems now to be making a bid for local recognition as a conductor. At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, he apppeared as conductor (and soloist) of the Melos Sinfonia of New York, an orchestra of freelance players he had brought together under the sponsorship of the World of Musicians Ltd., of which he is founder and music director.

title: The World; Libyans Sent Home For Bad Behavior
description: Every day, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya sells 640,000 barrels of oil to the United States, and gets back $25 million, or more than $8 for each Libyan man, woman and child. Too often, in Washington's view, this wealth has financed ''provocations and misconduct, including support for international terrorism.''

title: A NATIONL JOB REGISTRY HAS YET TO MATERIALIZE
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH CAROLINA STUDIES WORKER COMPENSATION LAW
description: A Duke University professor and former Presidential adviser has told the State Legislature that the state's workers' compensation act brings to bear ''the most poignant kind of cruelty'' on industrial employees.

title: WELCOME TO L.A. AGAIN
description: LIVING ALONE By John Givens. 178 pp. New York: Atheneum. $11.95.

title: THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: ''IT WAS one of those moments when to desire is to resolve.'' And so in the August 1881 issue of Lippincott's magazine, Philip G. Hubert recalled the birth of the Fresh Air Fund, the independent, not-for-profit organization that is once again seeking to provide free summer vacations in the country for underprivileged children from New York City.

title: A CHANGING PRACTICE
description: NEW CANAAN CONNECTICUT'S growth over the last decade as a center for corporate headquarters has altered the character and enlarged the scope of the architecture practiced by many state firms. Local architects, who once contented themselves with designing schools, municipal buildings and residences, now have dozens of small corporate offices and speculative office developments to their credit, and they are becoming involved in designing interiors and planning expansions for major corporations.

title: Miss Howard And a Trader Are Married
description: At St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday Khristi Bancroft Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Howard of New Vernon, N.J., was married to E. Whitmore Miller, son of Mrs. Adrian C. Israel of Stamford, Conn., and C. Nicholas Miller of Jupiter Hills, Fla. The Rev. James H. Purdy performed the ceremony.

title: Susan E. Savage Planning Nuptials Late in the Spring
description: Susan Ellen Savage, a program-marketing manager for education and systems training in the government systems marketing division of Control Data Corporation in New York, and Gregory Fusco, vice president for governmental relations and community affairs at Columbia University, plan to be married late this spring.

title: BARGAIN FARES FROM NEW YORK TO THE PACIFIC
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: ON-HUDSON LYDIA says she had a nagging concern: ''Am I being a good mother?'' Donna comments that husbands get compliments on their work at the office but that for mothers at home there is often little feedback. Kate says of children, ''They're so innocent - you want everything to turn out just right for them.''

title: Tax Shelters
description: To the Business Editor: The Reagan tax package is the fiscal counterpart of the neutron bomb: it wipes out the poor while leaving tax shelters standing. It's more than morally wrong to call for such unequal sacrifice. It's shortsighted policy.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; James Kibbie Performs Episodic Organ Program
description: James Kibbie, a Michigan-based American organist who has won prizes in competitions in France and Czechoslovakia, made his New York debut Wednesday in the Organ Interludes series at Alice Tully Hall. His program consisted of Bach's Toccata, Adagio and Fugue in C, Franck's Chorale No. 2, Alain's Trois Danses and the Passacaglia from Sowerby's Organ Symphony in G.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday incorrectly characterized the attendence at a conference of Socialists in Amsterdam. The people listed - including Francois Mitterrand of France, Tony Benn of Britain and Senator Edward M. Kennedy - were actually present at a conference in Washington in December sponsored by the Institute for Democratic Socialism, which sent a delegation to the Amsterdam meeting.

title: Pamela Brown And an Actor To Wed in Fall
description: The engagement of Pamela Suzanne Brown to Anthony William Sherer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Sherer of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Douglas Brown of Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y., parents of the future bride.

title: Antiques; DOLLS CATCH THE EYES OF COLLECTORS
description: Most dolls lead at least two lives. Each is chosen by a child to be loved, and in that role is fondled, scolded, fed, dressed, bathed, taken on outings and, sometimes, left very much alone. In that life, too, a doll knows smiles and tears in endless hours of play, hears wishes whispered, dreams recalled and confidences confessed.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Ubatuba' Put Inside
description: It appeared that someone did not like abstract art. Or at least the two-ton granite version called ''Ubatuba,'' by Antoine Poncet, a French artist.

title: Crime; by Newgate Callendar
description: Arthur Lyons's first powerful private-eye book, ''The Dead Are Discreet,'' introduced Jacob Asch, a West Coast operator, very much in the style of creations by Hammett and Ross Macdonald. Since his debut in 1974 Asch has remained an exemplar of the private eye: motivated by a quest for the truth, he is sensitive and compassionate, but tough when necessary. The gallant knight who assists the needy or the stricken, he is a loner who occasionally feels sorry for himself.

title: A SINKHOLE IN FLORIDA BURIES SEVEN VEHICLES AND ENGULFS BUILDING
description: A giant sinkhole gulped down a frame cottage, six expensive imported cars from a car lot and a camping vehicle today in this central Florida town. Still growing late in the day, the hole was nibbling at other buildings and a municipal swimming pool.

title: Photography View; ARBITRARINESS IS THE ENEMY
description: If there is such a thing as a photographic establishment, then certainly Tod Papageorge, whose recent black-and-white photographs are on view at Daniel Wolf Gallery (30 West 57th Street, through May 30), is a member. His credentials are impeccable. He teaches at Yale, where he is Walker Evans professor of photography and director of studies of photography. He has lectured at M.I.T. and Harvard. He has a close association with the Museum of Modern Art; in 1977 he curated Garry Winogrand's ''Public Relations'' exhibition there. Most recently, he helped edit Winogrand's book ''Stock Photographs'' and created the exhibition ''Walker Evans and Robert Frank: An Essay on Influence.''

title: Reading and Writing; THE AUTHOR SCHOLARS
description: As William Blake said, ''You never know what is enough unless you know what is more than enough.'' But it is only in the university presses that we can count on meeting the more-than-enough. The word academic is generally used now to mean unnecessary, yet it is the academic authors who seem most driven by necessity, who write not in the hope of fame or financial rewards, but out of a sense of what is due to civilization.

title: WORD- WATCHERS AT WORK
description: ERIC PARTRIDGE IN HIS OWN WORDS Edited by David Crystal.251 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $13.95.

title: COLLEGE PRESIDENTS PRESS FOR AID
description: TRENTON SPEAKING on behalf of New Jersey's more than 319,000 college students, six of the state's most influential educators have started a coordinated campaign to get the Legislature to appropriate an additional $23 million in aid for the 1981-82 school year.

title: Hollis Stacy Leads by 2
description: Hollis Stacy birdied the last two holes, broke out of a five-way tie and took a two-stroke lead today after the second round of the Lady Michelob golf tournament.

title: THE CROTON DUMP TO BE SHUT THIS YEAR?
description: THIS is the year they will close the Croton dump. Or is it? In 1974, the County Board of Legislators voted to close the landfill by the end of this year, and last Wednesday County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat, told Croton officials that he was all for that schedule. The Village of Croton wants the dump shut down even earlier and so does Edward M. Gibbs, the Republican who represents the village on the Board.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Big Fight at the Garden
description: EXACTLY four years ago tomorrow night, Ken Norton threw an overhand right into the comely features of Duane Bobick, a refugee from the 1972 Olympics who had whipped 38 more or less professional heavyweights, leaving 32 of them for dead. Bobick tottered forward, hands lifted as though in supplication. Norton threw six or eight more rights that connoisseurs deemed redundant.

title: THE FINAL SOLUTION IN ARGENTINA
description: PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER By Jacobo Timerman. Translated from the Spanish by Toby Talbot. 164 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95.

title: Stuart Serenbetz To Wed Jean Butler
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Carr Butler of Hudson, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Louise Butler, to Stuart Weygand Serenbetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Lewis Serenbetz of Harrison, N.Y.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
LEARNING AN 'URBAN SURVIVAL SKILL'
description: PATRICK MORRISSY calls tenant advocacy an ''urban survival skill,'' something as necessary as knowing how and when to call the Fire or Police Department in case of an emergency.

title: SOMETIMES A BEST SELLER
description: BECAUSE university presses were established to serve scholarship, their officials are likely to squirm whenever the conversation turns to matters of money. ''I always say the two things university presses should avoid are bankruptcy and best sellers,'' quipped Matthew N. Hodgson, director of the University of North Carolina Press. With average sales ofless than 2,000 copies, the presses have proven uncommonly adept at avoiding best sellers. Nevertheless, despite their reputation for dealing largely in ''hardcore pedantry,'' many university press books have attained sales that even the commercial publishers might envy.

title: SILENCING THOSE SQUEAKY STEPS
description: ALTHOUGH there may be some unusual cases where silencing a squeaky step or stairway may require the services of a professional carpenter or builder because major structural repairs are required, repairing a noisy step, in a vast majority of cases, is a comparatively minor job that the average do-it-yourselfer can easily handle.

title: DAYS IN THE LIVES OF 2 WOMEN WHO SERVE MRS. REAGAN SHEILA P. TATE, PRESS SECRETARY
description: The limousine carrying the two women purred through the streets. There were possibly one or two spectators who didn't recognize Nancy Reagan, and there were possibly an equal number who did recognize her companion. That's the way it goes with press secretaries.

title: SHIELDS TAKES STEEPLECHASE
description: Jim Shields of Garden City, L. I., won the 3,000-meter steeplechase by more than l00 yards in 8 minutes 54 seconds at an all-comers track meet at St. John's University Saturday.

title: DAN WAGONER'S DANCES RISE FROM HOMELY RURAL ROOTS
description: ''Color enters the picture, a little color, like checkered curtains in the window,'' the poet-performer George Montgomery says, speaking on stage in the opening moments of Dan Wagoner's dance, ''A Play, With Images and Walls.'' Mr. Wagoner, whose company will open a week from Wednesday in a five-performance engagement at Pace University's Schimmel Center, has been creating vivid moments of homely, incidental color for 11 years now. Dancers may suddenly break out of the flow of demanding, non-stop movement to form a rocking chair, or pause to listen to each others' heartbeats, or lumber like bears - giving expression to curiously specific tenderness or wit. Both earthy and abstract, Mr. Wagoner's dance spills across the stage in clear, cantilevered, pivoting shapes that hug the ground as the dancers bound playfully across it, informed by the whimsical good manners of another time and place.

title: HOMEMAKING AS A SECURE AND PROTECTED PARTNERSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Gallery View; SHAKESPEARE'S EFFECT ON BRITISH ARTISTS
description: NEW HAVEN The lesson of ''Shakespeare and British Art'' at the Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is that if the chosen theme is strong enough it is perfectly possible to make a fascinating exhibition without help from great art. Drawn almost entirely from the Center's own voluminous holdings, the show is made up of paintings, drawings, prints and books from the 18th and 19th centuries. It is not a parade of masterpieces - how could it be, when the star of the show is a large painting by Pieter van Bleeck? - but even its insufficiencies are enlightening. People who approach it in that light will have a very good time, and they will go home with some new answers to the question ''What's so special about Shakespeare?''

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Government Wins a Confidence Vote
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government today won a vote of confidence, the first such test it has faced since coming to power in the election of January 1980.

title: IN GUATEMALA, A DEBILITATING AND INEPT WAR
description: Religious processions, rich in custom and costume, fill the streets and the calendar in Guatemala and the most noted is the Good Friday cortege through the cobblestone roadways of Antigua, the colonial capital. This year, it drew the usual tens of thousands of onlookers to watch the massive wooden floats topped with statues of Jesus bearing His cross.

title: Practical Traveler; CHECKING UP ON THE RIGHT WAY TO PAY
description: For Sidney S. Rubin, it was a very special occasion - a birthday party for his wife at a posh hotel - and he wanted everything to be just right. Instead, because Mr. Rubin had counted on paying for the evening with a personal check, a lot went wrong.

title: Crafts
description: NORTH BRANCH THIS season's proliferation of exhibitions featuring paper as an expressive medium includes ''Paper: Surface and Image,'' the current offering at the gallery of the Printmaking Council of New Jersey.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: FLOATING over the countryside in a hot-air balloon has become an increasingly popular sport in the state for both participants and spectators. Since 1972, the number of licensed New Jersey balloon pilots has grown from seven to perhaps as many as 50. No longer is ballooning simply a private recreational outing for the pilots and a few of their friends. Formal meets and races now lure thousands of fans.

title: THOSE JOB-HOPPING CARTER PEOPLE
description: ''THE sweetheart relationship between regulatory agencies and the regulated industries must be broken up, and the revolving door between them should be closed.''

title: FERVOR: A MEASURE OF A PIANIST'S FORTE
description: HICKSVILLE MORTON ESTRIN started studying the piano at the age of 8, and by the time he was 9 he was performing in public. Now, almost half a century later, he is still performing - despite a long career as a teacher (privately as well as at Hofstra University), often long hiatuses between performances and the knowledge that a New York recital means sticking his neck out.

title: SPOUSES' RETIREMENT PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: M.T.A. ASSAILS CONRAIL FOR AIR-CONDITIONING DELAYS
description: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority official has criticized Conrail's management and work force for delays in getting air-conditioners ready on commuter cars this year.

title: SCARE TACTICS
description: DANSE MACABRE By Stephen King. Illustrated. 400 pp. New York: Everest House. $13.95.

title: GHOSTS AND CRISES
description: THE KNIFE AND OTHER POEMS By Richard Tillinghast. 63 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. Cloth, $10. Paper, $4.95.

title: TENANTS IN S.R.O. HOTEL SAY LANDLORD IS 'BLITZING' THEM
description: City officials, community groups and tenants say the new owner of a single-room-occupancy hotel on the Upper West Side is trying to ''blitz'' the building empty, apparently to convert it to more expensive apartments or resell it for a quick profit.

title: SWEEP BY ARIZONA STATE
description: -For the first time in the event's seven years, men's and women's teams from the same school won the titles in the national collegiate bowling tournament today. Arizona State accomplished the feat, beating Indiana State in the women's final and West Texas State in the men's.

title: Women Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR PLANT SHUTDOWNS: DEBATING COSTS AND SAFETY
description: Though much of the friendly glow has dimmed, nuclear power still has many proponents in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Recently, however, their case has been complicated by a series of shutdowns, some planned, some not, at many of the area's nuclear installations.

title: TOCKS ISLAND MUST STAY IN ITS GRAVE
description: ONE of the results of the water shortage in New Jersey has been an intense lobbying effort on the part of a few special-interest groups to revive the moribund Tocks Island reservoir project on the Delaware River.

title: The Textile Industry Shakes Itself Up
description: The yarn whips across the Nissan loom 10 times a second, piling up cloth at the rate of 12 inches a minute. A jet of water propels each strand, driving it across the face of the fabric three times faster than the fastest shuttle loom - and far less noisily. It is quiet enough to hear the robots beep as they wheel down the wide aisles, picking up rolls of finished cloth and carting them off to the trucks.

title: AMID TURMOIL, CHANGE IS SEEN IN LONDONDERRY
description: The last 10 years have brought change, turmoil and mixed blessings to this ancient walled city built on the site of a sixth-century monastery.

title: HOSPITAL RX: A BLENDING OF THE VISUAL AND MEDICAL ARTS
description: MOUNT HOLLY PATIENTS at Burlington County Memorial Hospital here are receiving an unusual invitation with their lunch trays these days. ''Housecoats and bedroom slippers are very welcome at pavilion galleries,'' the printed card says. Since last October, the 362-bed hospital has been offering patients, staff members and visitors a collection of art works in a project designed to blend the visual arts and the medical arts.

title: MAHLER-NO LONGER A RARITY ON RECORD
description: With Mahler's symphonies now firmly entrenched in the standard repertory and popular favorites with both conductors and audiences everywhere, it seems hard to believe that a mere 20 years ago performances were scarce. Not only that, when these scores began to be played with growing frequency back in the 1960's, they were still regarded with mixed feelings - indeed, some people even now cannot abide the leisurely time scale of the composer's massive symphonies and his almost embarrassingly personal musical confessions.

title: Washington; REAGAN'S 'HISTORIC VICTORY'
description: The capital of the United States was so pretty this weekend and the Reagan Administration was so happy about its ''historic victory'' in Congress that it almost took everybody's mind off the facts.

title: Officials Fearful Of Housing Aid Cuts
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposal calling for a major cutback in publichousing funds does not sit well with William J. Sirchio, comptroller of the Newark Housing Authority.

title: The Numbers Game
description: One of those busybodies who poke around in other people's private lives and publish the findings in magazines with undressed nymphets stapled into the centerfolds oiled his way into the office and demanded the secret of my successful marriage.

title: The Region; The Brothers Bush In Washington?
description: The Reagan Administration may not be trying to purge Lowell P. Weicker Jr. from the Senate. But then, it is not exactly discouraging Vice President Bush's brother from opposing the senior Connecticut Senator's renomination next year.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about plans for rallies over aid to El Salvador misidentified the sponsor of a pro-Administration counterdemonstration. It was the Collegiate Association for the Research of Principles. The Institute on Religion and Democracy and William Doherty, the director of the American Institute for Free Labor Development, had no connection with the event.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE whole point of commuting is to live a double life. In spring, the double life approaches schizophrenia. Moving from one world to the other produces round-trip culture shock.

title: SECRET AGENTS
description: THE AMATEUR By Robert Littell. 252 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $12.95. THE HEIGHTS OF RIMRING By Duff Hart-Davis. 309 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title:
Gardening;
MULCH AND OTHER WATER-SAVING METHODS
description: THERE is still concern over the prospects for serious summer drought. Although spring rains may have provided sufficient moisture to meet the immediate needs of plantings, they have done little to replace the moisture deep within the soil or in the storage reservoirs. Unless adequate precipitation arrives before the normally hot, dry midsummer, a critical moisture level will prevail for most plantings.

title: FAMILY RELATIONS
description: LOVE, DAD By Evan Hunter. 407 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95. BY IVAN GOLD

title: Future Events; A Mixed Bag
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Hidden Talent May 13 - There's more to Olympians than just athletic prowess: witness the paintings done by six gold-medalists, using the tools of their trade, so to speak. Wilma Rudolph, the sprinter, and Frank Shorter, the marathon runner, for example, dribbled acrylic paint on the canvas, then ran across it to create lively abstract designs. Their work, along with that of Bill Russell, the basketball great; John Naber, the swimmer; Al Oerter, the discus thrower; and Mike Eruzione, captain of the 1980 ice hockey team, will be auctioned by Christie's at a benefit luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom. The event is part of the Olympic artwork program sponsored by Budweiser to raise more than $1 million for the United States Olympic Committee by 1984. If you can't afford to hang in there for an original, content yourself with a framed and signed lithograph ($198.40) or a poster reproduction ($4.84.) It's all for a good cause. Luncheon tickets, $100, from 980-1212.

title: CAN 'DEATHTRAP' SURVIVE ON SCREEN?
description: On stage at the Music Box, where it has become Broadway's longestrunning thriller, Ira Levin's ''Deathtrap'' draws shrieks and giggles from its audiences by shamelessly playing every card in the whodunit deck. The walls of the set, a mystery writer's Westport study, are studded with an arsenal of deadly-looking weapons. The electricity fails at precisely the wrong time. Lightning flashes to reveal a murderous silhouette, poised to kill. It is all increasingly claustrophobic, larger than life and theatrically potent.

title: Miss Means Bride Of S. H. Gardner
description: Elizabeth Newberry Means, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hammond Means of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stephen Hayes Gardner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Gardner of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Lutheran Church.

title: Ideas and Trends; Private Patrons, Public Endowments
description: Before there was a National Endowment for the Arts, there was art. Before there was a National Endowment for the Humanities, there was study in the humanities.

title: Politics; BUSINESS NEXT ON O'NEILL'S AGENDA
description: HARTFORD WHEN the General Assembly departs the State Capitol next month, Governor O'Neill plans to turn his attention to an unusual venture that could enhance his standing with both business and labor in the state.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
FINE, FINE - BUT NOW, WHAT ABOUT YOUR REFERENCES?
description: DEAR Sir: I am responding to your advertisement regarding challenging and interesting employment with excellent salary and benefits for a college graduate with diverse experience.

title: MEMORIAL FOR PAUL GREEN IS HELD IN THEATER NAMED FOR PLAYWRIGHT
description: Nearly 400 people joined the family of Paul Green today at a memorial service for the playwright. ''The dream still lives, it lives, it lives and shall not die,'' a line from Mr. Green's famed outdoor pageant, ''The Lost Colony,'' was read at the service in a theater named for Mr. Green at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: The Last Co-op
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Driver Teaching Good Road Habits
description: When Tom Sneva, a two-time United States Auto Club national driving champion, is not wheeling his racing car at 200 miles an hour around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway or some other race track, he is likely to be engaged in his previous work, teaching children.

title: No Headline
description: People have the ''need'' to go to a dentist when they want to, and not when the dentist can see them. It appears clear that seven-daya-week availability, early and late hours, fills the gap left by the private practitioner.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Monty Barnard, Baritone, Sings Handel and Brahms
description: Monty Barnard brought a cultivated and often attractive baritone voice to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday evening. His tastefulness was also reflected in the music he chose to sing - ranging from Purcell and Scarlatti to Debussy, Duparc and Grieg.

title: Charles Royster Wins Parkman History Prize
description: The Society of American Historians has awarded the Francis Parkman Prize for 1980 to Charles Royster, assistant professor of history at the University of Texas, for ''A Revolutionary People at War.''

title: Connecticut Housing; NEIGHBORHOOD 'WATCH' ON CRIME
description: NEW HAVEN IT is seven-thirty on a wet and stormy night. For the moment, the tree-lined streets in the predominantly residential Westville section of the city lie deceptively deserted.

title: The Nation
description: Well before the courts decide whether or not Harrison A. Williams Jr. was improperly snared in the Government's Abscam net, the United States Senate may render a verdict of its own. Mr. Williams could become the first Senator expelled since the Civil War.

title: Personal Finance; NEW, IMPROVED LIFE INSURANCE
description: PERMANENT life insurance policies, guaranteeing yearly interest rates with a ceiling of 4 percent, have suffered mounting ridicule as a means of accumulating retirement savings. Many consumers, spotting higher rates elsewhere, defected to less costly term policies that offer death benefits and nothing else.

title: AUTHORS FIND GRANDPARENTS TO BE VALUABLE RESOURCE FOR CHILDREN
description: ''IT'S O.K. to be a grandparent'' and to insist on spending time with the grandchildren, according to the two Westchester authors of the book ''Grandparents/ Grandchildren.''

title: COURT ORDERS U.S. DRUG AGENCY TO RESTORE BLACK OFFICIAL TO POST
description: A Federal judge has ordered the Drug Enforcement Administration to reinstate an official who he said had been demoted in retaliation for testifying in a discrimination suit by black agents.

title: Nancy E. Metz Married To George N. Lindsay Jr.
description: Nancy E. Metz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Metz of Hatfield, Pa., was married in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday to George N. Lindsay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay of New York and Syosset, L.I. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: A NEW LIFE FOR OLD FILM PALACE
description: TARRYTOWN FROM the ''Perils of Pauline'' to ''Casablanca,'' Raymond Wylock remembers the movies that were shown at the Music Hall on Main Street. The 74-year-old retired director of maintenance at the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills worked at the theater as a stage hand while he was going to high school here during the 1920's.

title: YANKS LOSE IN 9TH, 6-5
description: Before an exultant crowd of 51,903 at the Kingdome, the Seattle Mariners won their fourth straight game under their new manager, Rene Lachemann, defeating the Yankees, 6-5, tonight with a three-run homer by Tom Paciorek in the bottom of the ninth inning.

title: DRIVE TO COMBAT ARSON IN STATE REPORTED GAINING
description: A YEAR and a half after a Federal grant of $600,000 prompted three insurance companies and state agencies to join forces to combat arson, Connecticut has started to improve its ability to deal with the crime that has long had one of the lowest rates of conviction.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC By Edward Rothstein Until now, Prof. Peter Schickele has been content to besmirch the name of Bach and the cause of culture only once a year, in annual presentations of the ''music'' of P.D.Q. - that justifiably neglected, consistently soused and reportedly non-existent son of Johann Sabastian. But the good professor has never been one to let questions of taste deter his quest for the tasteless.

title: SOLAR POWER EMERGING FROM THE SHADOWS
description: EAST HAMPTON FOR William Chaleff, a 34-year-old architect, it's been a 10-year struggle to design buildings that can be heated by the sun's rays. ''When I first started to talk about building solar houses,'' he said, ''people would laugh at me. I was treated like some kind of weird mystic.''

title: Connecticut Guide; FROM THE SMITHSONIAN
description: Many of the 4,000 Connecticut members of the Smithsonian Institution, along with the public, will attend a series of programs to be conducted by Smithsonian staff members at the Thames Science Center and the Lyman Allyn Museum in New London, New London Historical Society and Mystic Seaport. Because several of the events scheduled from Friday through May 20 are sold out, they will be presented twice.

title: Halting the Exodus Of Students Seeking Jobs
description: The article ''Island Tries to Cut Exodus of Graduates'' brought attention to the plight of some of our students. Not all are successful in locating employment on Long Island. What is education doing to help?

title: Robert Lawrence, Debora Adir Wed
description: Debora Ann Adir, daughter of Mrs. Bernice Adir and Shillo Adir, both of New York, was married yesterday to Robert Willis Lawrence, son of Philip A. Lawrence of Kent, Conn., and the late Mrs. Bernice Lawrence of Southbury, Conn.

title: MAIL KEEPS COMING TO EX-CONGRESSMEN
description: Some people just have not got the message that there have been some changes in the United States Congress. Six months ago, 44 members of Congress were voted out of office, but former legislators are still being inundated with mail from departments and agencies of the Federal Government as well as from former constituents who seem unaware that ''their Congressman'' is no longer in office.
