title: ART, MONEY, JITTERS AND JEALOUSY SPICE THE CANNES FILM FESTIVAL
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Chutkow is a freelance writer based in Paris. By PAUL CHUTKOW CANNES, France

title: A VOTE BUT NO EARLY VERDICT AT HARVARD'S LAW REVIEW
description: Few members of the Harvard Law School faculty are unfamiliar with the affirmative action legislation of the past two decades; several helped draft the laws and defend them before the Supreme Court. So it is all the more curious that one of the newest challenges to affirmative action is taking place in Harvard Law School's own backyard and, to some extent, among its own faculty.

title: Another Challenger's First Race
description: Like Aaron Godfrey, I was a challenger ''the first time out'' in a recent election. It could have been my story that appeared on the Opinion Page entitled ''Running, Losing and Learning.''

title: RELIGION BECOMES AN IMPORTANT PART OF BASEBALL SCENE
description: THE God Squad. That nickname has followed the San Francisco Giants since 1978, eventually giving them a reputation of a team somehow weakened by the presence of several ''born-again'' Christians.

title: Other Business; LOST AND FOUND: OLD BANK ACCOUNTS
description: When W.C. Fields was an itinerant juggler playing the vaudeville circuit, he adopted a peculiar banking system. Fearful of thievery on the road, he would open a bank account everywhere he went. There was one problem. The star of ''My Little Chickadee,'' ''The Bank Dick,'' - and ''Never Give a Sucker an Even Break'' - was better suited to comedy than to keeping track of the 700 accounts he was known to boast of. Many got lost and his heirs were left with a tangled mess that was never completely sorted out, according to his agent.

title: WINNER IN A WALK NEXT ROUND IS ON TAXES AND ROSTENKOWSKI HOLDS THE KEY
description: WASHINGTON FOR Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the situation could hardly be more awkward. Not two weeks ago an aide to the new chairman of the Ways and Means Committee asserted that the panel's 23 Democrats, under the chairman's discipline, would send to the floor a bill that cut individual income taxes for only one year.

title: A Substitute's Common Lament
description: To the Sports Editor: Michael Hart (''Coach Said, 'We Play to Win' - So I Sat,'' The New York Times, May 3) points a finger at the implications of ''playing to win.''

title: WHERE HAVE ALL THE GRANDPARENTS GONE?
description: Who needs old people? Children do. In particular, they need their grandparents and grandparents need them. Lengthy interviews during the last three years with 300 children and as many grandparents have convinced us that the bond between grandparents and grandchildren is second in emotional power and influence only to the relationship between parents and children. Indeed, such is the power of this basic biological bond that grandparents affect the lives of their grandchildren, for good or ill, simply because they exist.

title: Legislation to Curb Abuse of Aged Urged
description: As Ombudsman for the Institutionalized Elderly, I wish to alert readers to the need for an Adult Abuse Reporting Bill. My office has had to deal directly with abuses of the elderly in boarding homes, nursing homes and mental institutions. From our experience, we can attest to the need for such a bill.

title: No Headline
description: Jane Brody's insistence on controlled clinical trials to test the efficacy of vitamins seems, at first glance, to be quite reasonable.

title: ARTS PANEL GRAPPLES WITH BUDGET CUTS
description: THIS week the Connecticut Commission on the Arts is to decide how to apportion $658,908 in grants for the 1981-1982 fiscal year among arts councils, institutions, centers and individual artists.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an At a Glance box accompanying an article on Xerox last Sunday the company's 1980 stockholders' equity and dividend for the first quarter of 1980 were misstated.

title: DEMOCRATS LOSE MORE THAN BUDGET
description: IN the history books, the meaning of the House vote on the President's budget will be only partly in the Reagan victory - though it was, as predicted, substantial. It will also lie in the scope of the Democratic defeat. Having lost the White House and the Senate at the polls in November, the Democrats last week may have lost effective control of the House of Representatives.

title: TOWARDS A NEW DEFENSE STRATEGY
description: Admiral Stansfield Turner, U.S.N.(Ret) is a former director of the Central Intelligence Agency. Capt. George Thibault, U.S.N. assisted him in the preparation of this article. By Stansfield Turner When the coming version of any weapons system appears to be virtually the ultimate in cost and sophistication, like our new tanks and aircraft carriers, one can safely assume that the evolution of that system is well past its peak. The best battleships, for example, were built during World War II, well after their usefulness had been eclipsed by the airplane and the submarine.

title: Multiple Cinemas Produce Multiple Sounds
description: I am glad you published the article ''Multiple Cinemas Increasing.'' At the Shore Theater in Huntington, I saw one film (''The Formula''), but heard the sound tracks from two films.

title: Danse Macabre
description: Fans of Stephen King will not be surprised to learn that Mr. King is a fan himself, for he regularly lets his enthusiasms show through in his books, ''best-scarers'' such as '' 'Salem's Lot,'' ''The Dead Zone'' and recently ''Firestarter.'' He has now assembled a trick-ortreat bag of goodies - childhood reminiscences, anecdotes about fellow writers, plot synopses of favorite films, novels, stories and television programs, a selected reading list, even a quiz -that deals with the genre in which he has so far chosen to work.

title: ALLIES ANGERED AS U.S. SLASHES SCIENCE OUTLAYS
description: It was a determined and angry Vittorio Manno who stepped into the chill Paris morning and headed for Orly Airport on the Monday after President Reagan announced his budget revisions in February. He boarded a Concorde for New York, where he was met by two Americans - high officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration - in a private Air France lounge at Kennedy International Airport.

title: SEEKING CHANGE IN OLD BRISSAC, A MIDI VILLAGE
description: I cannot recall exactly where I was when my definition of an ideal vacation hit me. I may have been stretched out under the huge striped awning behind our rented maisonette in Brissac, a minuscule village in an unfashionable reach of southern France. Or perhaps I was sitting with my back propped against the cool, stone facade of the house, idly gazing at the south keep - the one dating back to 996 - of the town chateau as I waited for one of the locals to pass by and occasion a brief conversation. Either way, I remember clearly the key word of my definition: change.

title: LOCAL MATTERS
description: CONNECTICUT may have picked the wrong slogan. ''Better Yet Connecticut'' does not express what many consider to be the state's dominant feature -provincialism.

title: Art View; KANDINSKY'S SPIRITUALISM; WASHINGTON
description: No event in the entire history of modernist art has proved to be more fateful, both for art and for its public, than the creation of abstract painting. Partisans of abstraction have naturally tended to view its advent in Europe some 70 years ago as the dawn of a new era - but so too, much to their distress, have its diehard opponents, among which must be numbered many of the leading artists of the age. What has changed in our time, of course, is that it is now more often the latter -the opponents of abstract art - who are sometimes regarded as cranks and renegades, whereas the apostles of this oncedespised artistic phenomenon have lived to see their cause triumphant not only in the marketplace of culture but in the very area of the mind where definitions of art are debated and resolved.

title: School Costs: Public and Parochial
description: The article ''Parochial Pupil Rise Causing Difficulties'' is enviably naive about inflation.

title: TANDOORI ENTREES IN ELEGANT SETTING
description: WHEN Sitar opened in Melville in 1978, it was astonishing. Imagine a large, beautiful Indian restaurant built from the ground up on Route 110 surrounded by stretches of office buildings and banks, not exactly a hub of fine dining. Yet Sitar, with its traditional clay tandoor oven, could be compared favorably with some of Manhattan's better Indian restaurants.

title: Dining Out; A MENU WITH ORIGINALITY
description: GREENWICH THE space was familiar - the small two-level dining room at the Gryphon Cafe, with its oak tables, free-standing palms, hanging plants, and abstract paintings all bore a certain similarity to many of the restaurants that have opened in Connecticut in the past two years. But to our considerable surprise and pleasure the Gryphon Cafe had a menu with more than a spark of originality.

title: Accuracy of Ratings For Yachts Debated
description: Since three of the country's leading ocean racing yachts were accused of irregularities relating to handicap ratings nearly six weeks ago, questions have arisen regarding the validity of the handicapping system.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; WILLIAM WRIGHT
description: In the fall of 1978, William Wright, a 47-year-old writer and opera aficionado who once worked as general manager of the Spoleto Festival in Italy, heard that an autobiography of Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor popularly known as ''King of the High C's,'' was being planned.

title: POLITICS; THE TURNOUT AT THE TRIAL
description: A MAJOR thrust of the prosecution of Joseph M. Margiotta was that the taxpayers had been defrauded by the patronage system of splitting municipal insurance commissions between the broker who handled the insurance and politicians who did little or no work for the money.

title: A ROYAL SUMMER IN LONDON
description: One hundred and eighteen years ago, the last time a Prince of Wales took a bride, the streets of London, according to a contemporary account, were ''fully alive to the great occasion, and right and left and up and down, wherever the eye turned, there were emblems of festivity to be seen, an entire population making holiday.''

title: No Headline
description: A union delegation headed by the Solidarity leader Lech Walesa left today for a one-week visit to Japan. Mr. Walesa is making his second trip abroad as leader of the independent union.

title: No Headline
description: A picture caption today on the cover of The Guide, section 2A, incorrectly describes a program by Claude Kipness Mime Theater. The company, will perform Thursday through Sunday at the Riverside Dance Festival, is named for its founder, who is deceased.

title: Ali Offers to Add $400,000 To Atlanta Reward Fund
description: Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight boxing champion, said today that he would donate $400,000 to a reward fund for information leading to the arrest of a killer in the slayings of 26 young blacks.

title: Gale Stuart Pyles and Roy A. Hunt 3d Wed
description: Gale Stuart Pyles and Roy Arthur Hunt 3d were married yesterday in Waltham, Mass. at the Lyman Estate-the Vale, the estate of the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities, by the Rev. Richard Paine of the First Unitarian Church of Ashby, Mass.
MONTCLAIR A SUBSTANTIAL exhibition of recent works by Clinton Hill is now on view at the Montclair Art Museum, where it will continue through June 21.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Leonard Cole's article contains a factual error regarding the American Dental Association's figures on annual income of dentists. The article states that the median income for dentists in 1978 was $48,000 after taxes. The citation should read that the mean net income of independent dentists in 1978 was $48,000 before taxes. JOHN M. COADY, D.D.S., Executive Director, American Dental Association, Chicago

title: * To the Editor:$
description: While heartily agreeing with the feelings and opinions expressed by Dr. Rae Andre, I would like to offer one further suggestion. I believe that the concept of what a marriage is, or should be, is in urgent need of revision, or perhaps I should say resurrection. The fact that the functions of husband and housewife are entirely different does not mean that their tasks are unrelated, or that the two are unequal in their contributions to the support of each other - or that the achievements of each are not joint accomplishments of both.

title: DALLAS MEANS BUSINESS AND VICE VERSA
description: When Jack Evans was sworn in as Mayor of the nation's seventh largest city last week, it seemed a perfect match. Evans rose from modest beginnings to become a millionaire businessman, president of the Cullum Companies Inc., a food and drug retailing chain with sales of almost $1 billion. In the same way, Dallas almost willed itself from a desolate prairie trading post to a boom town that seems exempt from most of the nation's urban ills.

title: NEW YORK OFFICIAL SAYS THE AGED COULD LOSE MILLIONS IN U.S. CUTS
description: Older residents of New York State will lose more than $250 million in 1982 alone if President Reagan's budget reductions win final approval in Congress, according to the head of the State Office for the Aging.

title:
Antiques;
COUNTRY FURNITURE AT OUTDOOR FAIR
description: WOODBRIDGE A CARAVAN of 125 dealers from throughout the Northeast will gather here early next Saturday morning to set up displays for the eighth annual Woodbridge Outdoor Antiques Festival. The show and sale is a benefit for the Amity-Woodbridge Historical Society and that organization's restored 18th-century headquarters-museum, the Thomas Darling House.

title: POLICE ARE DEPLOYED TO FIGHT WAR AGAINST ROBBERY
description: A little more than a month ago, Police Officer Stephen Auditore was concerned with prostitutes and gamblers in the Bronx. Officer Jack Marchesi was chasing drug dealers in Manhattan.

title: FRESH AIR FUND AIMS FOR ITS SUMMER GOAL
description: ''IT was one of those moments when to desire is to resolve.'' And so, in the August 1881 issue of Lippincott's magazine, Philip G. Hubert recalled the birth of the Fresh Air Fund, the independent, not-for-profit organization that is once again seeking to provide free summer vacations in the country for underprivileged children from New York City.

title: ADVICE ON THE COUNTY AVAILABLE IN REAMS
description: THERE are black and white pamphlets and multicolored brochures, single-page flyers and 100-page reports. There is a tabloid newspaper and a slick packet filled with more than a dozen inserts. A large briefcase can barely contain them and a partial stack weighs more than 10 pounds.

title: MUSIC: 'SURPRISE' CONDUCTOR AT SYMPHONY FINALE
description: THIS has been a tough year for conductors: concurrent with Siegfried Landau's resignation from the White Plains Symphony, came word that Raffael Adler was stepping down from his post as music director of the Westchester Symphony and would not conduct the final concert of the season Saturday.

title: CRITIC OF THE NEW COUNTY SONG SINGS PRAISES OF A GURLING, GOLD SYMBOL
description: WHEN I read that Westchester now has a county song, I smiled. The report went on to say that the lyrics of that song include the neologism ''success-chester.'' That rhymes with Westchester, you see. I snickered.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE OZARKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- TOM WEIL, a St. Louis writer, is the author of ''A Balance of Power,'' a novel to be published in June. By TOM WEIL

title: Pamela Constable Becomes the Bride Of Mark C. Ashida
description: Pamela Groome Constable, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Cheston Constable of Essex, Conn., was married in Monkton, Md., yesterday to Mark Calvin Ashida, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Ashida of Oceanside, Calif. The Rev. Felix Joffrion, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: WHO HELPS PAY THE FARE IF WASHINGTON DOESN'T?
description: NOT long ago, transportation officials around the country were getting their modes in a row to debate what promised to be the industry's central issue of 1981: Is mass transit rightly a Federal social obligation, essential to the survival of cities and the mobility of the poor who live in them? Or, as New Jersey Transportation Commissioner Louis J. Gambaccini recently put it, should transit ultimately be seen as ''a business that doesn't deserve to exist if the rider can't pay for it.''

title: Kathleen E. Slusser Is a Bride
description: Kathleen Elizabeth Slusser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Santa Rosa, Calif., was married yesterday to Robert Welch Mullen Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mullen of New York.

title: AMERICAN KESTREL; Falco sparverius
description: Size: Nine to 12 inches. Color: Back, barred chestnut; tail, bright rufous with black bar, tipped with white.

title: FRANCE'S PRESIDENT FACING A SOCIALIST IN TODAY'S ELECTION
description: The French will decide tomorrow whether to keep the center-right coalition that has governed them for 23 years or turn power over to the left for the first time in the history of the Fifth Republic.

title:
Dining Out;
A Menu in Need of More Seafood
description: NEAR the railroad station in Elberon, which is part of Long Branch, is a storefront with the word Kessler written in bold letters across the window. Closer inspection reveals a door to one side bearing the name of a restaurant called The Side Room.

title: KIRMAYER, DIBS IN NET FINAL
description: When John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis, the local products who were supposed to pull in the crowds at Forest Hills, both lost last Tuesday in the $592,000 Tournament of Champions, Lamar Hunt was stunned. Hunt, the director of the sponsoring organization, World Championship Tennis, had never heard of Carlos Kirmayr, the 30-yearold Brazilian who eliminated McEnroe that day, thus establishing himself as a pest.

title: PRAISED METHADONE CLINIC ORDERED CLOSED IN DISPUTE
description: Audrey Smith, 40 years old, describes herself as a homemaker and taxpayer and will tell you how hard she and her husband have worked to send two of their three children to college.

title: The Region; Familiarity Breeds Respect at Barnard
description: Though she isn't much older than those earning degrees, Ellen V. Futter will soon be conferring them. Last week, the 31-year-old lawyer was named president of Barnard College, becoming the youngest chief executive of a major American college.

title: AL OERTER AT 44: SET NO LIMITS BECAUSE OF AGE
description: THERE is no single competitive athletic event that requires more preparation than the Olympic Games. All athletes who hope to compete in the Olympics face the monumental task of organizing their mental and physical resources so they will be at their best on one specific day.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: The Region; The Moon Church Is Many Things, But Not Tax Free
description: Is the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon a religion, an economic program or a political movement? An appellate court in Manhattan decided last week that it is all three, and followed up with a ruling that the church is not entitled to New York City property tax exemptions on three buildings valued at more than $2.6 million.

title: NEW JERSEY IS FACING THE DILEMMA
description: APOSSIBLE preview of coming distractions in the transportation industry is now playing in New Jersey, where the prospective loss of Federal operating aid has added a sharp twist to a story already heavy with political, fiscal and racial subplots.

title: Other Business; A ZOO IN EVERY DRAWER
description: Men are beasts. What feminism hasn't conclusively proven, sport shirts have. The alligator, Izod Lacoste's logo, began creeping across knit shirts 50 years ago when French tennis pro Rene Lacoste was nicknamed ''the croc'' for his speed. Now, it's a veritable bestiary of the chest. Ralph Lauren's polo horse, Giorgio Armani's eagle, the tiger of Sweden. These atavistic insigniae mean the sports shirt involved sells for $30 to $40. And the designer shirts are sans the $25 Izod's extralong back flap so practical in a vigorous game.

title: VIBRAHARP: MILT JACKSON
description: When the Modern Jazz Quartet broke up in 1974, Milt Jackson, who had been the group's vibraharpist from its beginnings in 1952, started a career as a single, traveling alone most of the time and picking up accompanists wherever he played.

title:
ON THE ISLE;
ON THE FARM
description: If you want to spend a day down on the farm and there's no ancestral farm in your family, fear not. Suffolk County operates one in Yaphank and will be happy to share - visually, at least -its 300 acres, 175 beef cattle, 250 swine, 1,500 turkeys and 1,400 chickens with anyone who wanders by on weekends between 9 A.M. and 3 P.M. Using a map, visitors can tour the 110-year-old facility with its old hay barn and antique machinery displays along with livestock and crops that are raised to feed jail inmates, patients at the Suffolk County Infirmary and participants in nutrition programs for the elderly. The farm is on Yaphank Road (Exit 66 on the Long Island Expressway) and admission is free. For information, call 924-4535.BUSY PLAYERS

title: 2 RODRIGUEZ HOMERS HELP YANKS WIN, 5-2
description: With George Steinbrenner fuming at his home in Tampa, Fla., and the Mariners looking for a sweep of the series, the Yankees pulled themselves together tonight and beat Seattle, 5-2, to end a three-game losing streak and a two-week road trip.

title: U.S. ENVOYS BONE UP ON TERROR TACTICS
description: The film showed an American businessman, blindfolded, manacled and surrounded by armed terrorists, being led through the jungle on a chain.

title: A Lawyer Is Appointed To Key Piedmont Post
description: William R. Howard, a 58-year-old lawyer who learned to fly at age 16, has been named president and chief operating officer of Piedmont Aviation Inc., a regional airline based in Winston-Salem, N.C. He succeeds Thomas H. Davis, the carrier's 63-year-old chairman, who continues as chief executive officer.

title: Ramirez Rolls Up 50th Ring Victory
description: Jose Luis Ramirez of Mexico won a unanimous 10-round decision over Ezequiel (Cocoa) Sanchez of the Dominican Republic in a lightweight bout today at the Forum.

title: FLAGS OF CONVENIENCE CAN BE INCONVENIENT
description: To the Editor:

title: She Didn't Make Broadway but She Has No Regrets
description: She was an aspiring actress. He was a stage-door Johnny. He won her heart, and she gave up a promising career in the theater for marriage, motherhood and life as the wife of an Ohio industrialist.

title: WITH OR WITHOUT THE PUCK, BRYAN TROTTIER IS STARRING
description: Bryan Trottier has ugly toes. They are gnarled and reddish, black and blue. His ankles aren't much prettier. But that's what happens to feet that stop hockey pucks. But Bryan Trottier is not famous because he stops people from taking shots. He is known as a playmaker and scorer, the Islander center who is one game away from tying Bobby Orr's record for registering at least one point in 14 straight playoff games in one year.

title: Man Seized in Effort To Burn Legion Hall
description: The police charged a man with trying to set fire to an American Legion hall filled with 100 people, including 22 sleeping children.

title: THE CITY CAN'T AFFORD TO NEGLECT THE GIFTED
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIONS AND CITY TALK OF GOALS
description: Two groups that are often in conflict, city officials and labor leaders, met here for a weekend conference with a common concern - the migration of people and businesses from New York City - and a common goal - greater worker productivity and improved services that might halt that migration.

title: BALLET TEATER: A FEAST OF SWAN AND PRINCES
description: TWO haunted Romantics and their glacial ideal, and a feckless kid and his vision of womanliness: three performances by American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House last week proved that that hoary classic ''Swan Lake'' will sustain a variety of interpretations.

title: TAX CUT MOMENTUM EXPECTED
description: Fresh from a House of Representatives victory for the Reagan Administration last week on its budget, Treasury Donald T. Regan said today that the White House was counting on popular support to ''give us the victory'' for the Kemp-Roth tax cut of 30 percent over three years.

title: MOST OF WALL STREET BACKS REAGAN PlAN
description: Since taking office in January, the Reagan Administration has been saying that the performance of the money and stock markets would be the best indicator of Wall Street's acceptance of the President's economic program.

title: On the Stick
description: The 73-year-old gentlemen, peering through his eye glasses at Adelphi University's lacrosse field while leaning on his silver, lion-headed cane, obviously was impressed by what he saw. The man, French Julien, who has been a player or an official since 1923, said in awe: ''Look at those goals.''

title: Roberts, on Yamaha, Winner of 2d in Row
description: Kenny Roberts drove his Yamaha to victory today in the rain-marred 500-cc race of the Grand Prix of the Nations, the fourth event of the 1981 series.

title: KAREN LYNN LITCHMAN WED TO FREDRIC L. SAX
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I., yesterday Karen Lynn Lichtman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marc M. Lichtman of East Williston, L.I., was married to Frederic Lee Sax, son of Mrs. Karl Sax of Frankfurt, West Germany, and the late Mr. Sax. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Sternstein officiated.

title: Aide to Boston Mayor Says Fund Plan Will Be Rejected
description: A spokesman for Mayor Kevin H. White said today that the Mayor would reject the City Council's latest proposal to keep Boston's public schools open and keep the city from becoming insolvent.

title: BEHIND SEPERATE VACATIONS
description: Rhoda and Ernest Graf are back from vacation, she looking tan, he looking slightly frostbitten. Mrs. Graf went to a health spa where she lost 2 pounds and then to Atlantic City where she won $215 at blackjack. Mr. Graf went dog-sledging in Greenland where he slept in a tent at 25 degrees below and took 400 photograpic slides of ice caps.

title: PROJECT FOR DREDGING PCB'S FROM HUDSON WINS FEDERAL APPROVAL
description: A New York State project to dredge up and safely re-bury poisonous chemical contaminants from up to 40 ''hot spots'' in the Hudson River north of Albany has been approved by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: COST SQUEEZE MAY FORCE EARLY MARKETING OF BEEF
description: As Scott McKinley eased his Jeep station wagon toward them, the sleek yearling steers drowsing in the warm dust of the trail heaved themselves to their feet and reluctantly moved away.

title: Della Femina Scoffs At Emery Air Rumor
description: There have been a number of reports that the Emery Air Freight Corporation is shaking loose from Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, its agency since 1972. The agency scoffs at this, noting that it has just completed a pool of TV commercials that got very high test scores.

title: Striking Nurses Reject Contract
description: One hundred nurses who have struck the Ashtabula General Hospital for 43 weeks today voted to turn down a 12 percent raise and continue the walkout until they win a union shop and get their jobs back. By a 79-to-13 vote, the nurses, who walked out last July 21, rejected a contract that would have raised their base pay to $8.10 an hour, from $7.25. The proposal was the first to reach a vote since the strike began.

title: FIZSIMMONS' LIKELY SUCCESSOR UNDER INVESTIGATION
description: Roy L. Williams, a vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who is expected to succeed the late Frank E. Fitzsimmons as head of the union, is being investigated in a Chicago case concerning the alleged use of illegal influence in the handling of trucking deregulation legislation, a Justice Department official said today.

title: JESSE LAVENTHOL
description: Jesse Laventhol, a former Philadelphia journalist, died yesterday at the age of 80, according to his family. He suffered a stroke six weeks ago.

title: CONCERT: SPRING VISIT BY QUEENS PLAYERS
description: The Queens College Orchestral Society of New York made a spring vist to Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening playing Beethoven, Liszt, Verdi and Glazunov.

title: LIETZKE CAPTURES NELSON EVENT, DEFEATS WATSON ON PLAYOOF HOLE
description: This was the wrong week for Bruce Lietzke's 10th effort to stop smoking. There were moments today, he said, when he positively craved cigarettes as he made up a three-stroke deficit to catch Tom Watson and then beat him to win the Byron Nelson Classic on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff.

title: OPTIMISM ADDS IMPETUS TO CORPORATE OFFERINGS
description: Greater optimism among underwriters about attracting investors for new corporate debt issues apparently led to the scheduling of over $1.2 billion of notes and bonds were reported on the schedule for public offering this week.

title: EXPOS' CHARLIE LEA PITCHES 4-0 NO-HITTER
description: Charlie Lea pitched the first no-hitter in the major leagues this season as the Montreal Expos beat the San Francisco Giants today, 4-0, in the second game of a doubleheader. The Giants won the opener, 5-1.

title: ATTACKS MOUNT AGAINST PEREZ EMPIRE IN LOIUSIANA
description: Amid the hundreds of square miles of trembling swamp grass that make up most of oil-rich Plaquemines Parish, a political empire appears to be crumbling.

title: Cardinals' Rincon Has Fractured Arm
description: The St. Louis Cardinals received a jolt today when it was determined that their rookie right-hander, Andy Rincon, suffered a hairline fracture of his right arm in a game last night against the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: TIPPER VERSUS GIPPER; BY: WILLIAM SAFIRE
description: ''I have been in public life for 46 years,'' the embittered white-haired Speaker of the House told his colleagues, ''and the day that I have to look at the next election, instead of looking at America, then I do not want to be in public life.''

title: CHINAGLIA SCORES 3 IN COSMOS' 5-1 VICTORY
description: Overcoming a lethargic start, the Cosmos scored five goals in the second half, three by Giorgio Chinaglia, and defeated the Toronto Blizzard today, 5-1.

title: A Guard and a Pinup Thwart Jail Escape
description: A prison guard who stopped to stare at a magazine pinup hanging on a cell wall at the Bergen County Jail annex in Hackensack, N.J., thwarted an escape attempt before it got started, jail officials said.

title: Alaska to Support California Suit On U.S. Sale of Offshore Leases
description: Alaska will file briefs supporting California in a lawsuit challenging the Federal Government's authority to disregard management plans for coastal zones in the sale of offshore oil and gas leases, state officials say.

title: CITY SURPLUS PUT AT $243 MILLION FOR FISCAL YEAR
description: New York City will close the fiscal year with a $243 million surplus, its first since the early 1960's and almost twice the previously projected figure, the city's budget director said yesterday.

title: Cooney Is 225 1/4
description: Gerry Cooney weighed in yesterday at 225 1/4 pounds for tonight's scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden with Ken Norton. Norton weighed 225, about 6 pounds over his best fighting weight of several years ago, but he was wearing shoes, sweatpants and sweatshirt.

title: HISPANIC PEOPLE FOUND TO BE SLIGHTED BY FOUNDATIONS
description: Hispanic people, the country's fastest-growing minority, are not getting adequate financial assistance from foundations in the United States, according to two separate studies.

title: PRINCE ANDREW, HEIR OF LAST RUSSIAN CZAR, AT HIS ENGLISH ESTATE
description: Prince Andrew of Russia, the oldest surviving relative of Czar Nicholas II, died Friday at his home here, his family announced today. He was 84 years old.

title: DEBORAH BERNICK ANALYST, IS MARRIED TO BIJON MISHRA
description: The marriage of Deborah Bernick, a legislative analyst for the New York City Department of Social Services, to Bijon Mishra, a management scientist with American Express, took place yesterday at the Swan Club in Roslyn, L.I. Village Judge John P. McGuire of Sea Cliff, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: COUNCIL LEADERS PROPOSE ADDING 2 DISTRICTS
description: In the first New York test of political redistricting to reflect the 1980 census, leaders of the City Council have agreed on a plan that would add two districts.

title: ABORTION CLINICS IN VIOLATION OF THE RULES
description: To the Editor:

title: Pet Inc. Assignment To Gardner Advertising
description: Pet Inc. in St. Louis has pulled assignments out of both Tracy-Locke and the Bloom Agency in Dallas to form a package called the Branded Grocery Products that it has dropped at the door of Gardner Advertising, its St. Louis neighbor, which is a subsidiary of Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: INDIANS' GARLAND DEFEATS TWINS
description: One of the surprising elements in the Cleveland Indians' hold on first place in the American League's Eastern Division is their lack of power. The team has hit only four home runs although winning 14 of 21 games, the latest a 5-1 decision over the Minnesota Twins yesterday in Blooomington.

title: t; Market Place  Robert Metz; Energy Outlook In Australia
description: SANTOS LTD. is middle-sized as energy companies go, with proven gas reserves somewhat larger than those of the Pennzoil Company. But in its own bailiwick, Santos is the biggest and stands in about the position at home that Dome Petroleum did 20 years ago in Canada. Santos could emerge over the next five to 10 years as a giant in the South Pacific.

title: MARION SMITH WEINSTOCK WED
description: Marion Smith Weinstock of New York, widow of Harold Weinstock, was married yesterday to Dr. Sidney A. Bernstein, also of New York, a widower and an orthopedic surgeon.

title: THE ACHIVEMENTS OF WOMEN? YOU COULD LOOK IT UP
description: The list of reference books about what women, mostly American, have done, said and been over the years is growing ever longer. At least half a dozen have come out since 1979, celebrating women's heretofore buried accomplishments. ''The first real wave of women's books was much more political and rhetorical and had to do with basic issues to which feminists had to address themselves,'' said Atheneum's Neil Nyren, who edited Womanlist, which has just been published, and Betty Friedan's 1976 retrospective, ''It Changed My Life.''

title: DECEPTION DENIED BY REPORTER FOR VOICE
description: Teresa Carpenter, a reporter for The Village Voice, says there was no attempt to deceive readers in one of her stories that last month won the Pulitzer Prize for feature writing.

title: Olympians Criticize Los Angeles Climate
description: The Dutch National Equestrian Association has sent a letter to the European Equestrian Federation to express its concern about what it thinks the likely weather conditions will be at the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Consumers Said to Be Optimistic
description: The nation's consumers are optimistic that economic conditions will improve late this year, but they continue to be ''disenchanted'' with inflation and unemployment, according to a Conference Board survey released today.

title: Nixon Says the G.O.P. Will Need 8 Years to Undo Democrats' Work
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon said today that Republicans would need ''at least eight years'' to undo what Democratic-controlled Congresses have done in the last 25 years.

title: Republican Assails Albany Aid Program
description: The New York Senate's deputy majority leader says that ''Carter moles'' in the Reagan Administration have authorized $45 million in unused Federal heating aid to be distributed by the state ''without verification of need.''

title: ROCKETS TOP CELTICS, TIE SERIES AT 2-2
description: Some reminders on the green blackboard in their dressing room today told the story of the Houston Rockets' 91-86 victory over the Boston Celtics that tied the National Basketball Association championship series at 2-2.

title: Washington Watch; New Lobbyists For Japanese
description: WASHINGTON BEFORE the Japanese Government finally agreed to set quotas on shipments of cars to this country, Japanese auto makers were gearing up their lobbying in Washington by putting several key Republicans on consultancy payrolls.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 11, 1981
description: International A Socialist will lead France for the next seven years. In a close presidential election Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist Party leader, defeated incumbent President Valery Giscard d'Estaing by what is expected to be four percentage points, a victory unexpectedly solid by French standards. For the first time since Charles de Gaulle established the Fifth Republic in 1958, control has passed from the right and center-right groupings to the left and centerleft. Exuberant Parisians sang and danced in the Place de la Bastille, the traditional celebration ground of the working class. (Page A1, Col. 6.) West Germany's coalition Government was strained by a parliamentary election in West Berlin that dealt the Social Democratic Party, the party of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, its worst losses since World War II. No party won a majority in West Berlin, but the Christian Democrats made strong gains and became the dominant party in the city legislature, and the Social Democratic Mayor, Hans-Jochen Vogel, announced that he would step down. (A1:3.)

title: OUR VULNERABLE SATELLITES
description: To the Editor:

title: When Lewis Rudin Gets Cuff Links, They'll Have Class
description: When a New York businessmen needs a pair of cuff links and wants to catch a movie, he might pop into, say, Brooks Brothers and then hop a cab to a theater.

title: LEVELING
description: The decision to grant a pardon lies solely within the discretion of the President. Congressional consultation is not required and judicial review is not permitted. It is a political act for which he is responsible only to the public.

title: NONCONFORMIST POLITICIAN: FRANCOIS MAURICE MITTERRANDws
description: For close to two generations Francois Mitterrand has pursued his zigzag and unpredictable way in French politics. In effect, he has had three political careers, and the first two were unremarkable and not very successful.

title: EXOTIC TRIPS FOR THE RICH--OR THE DREAMERS
description: MOST hunters and fishermen confine their activities to one or two states and would consider themselves fortunate if, once or twice in a lifetime, they could spend a few days on a first-class Atlantic salmon river, a grouse shoot in Scotland or a bonefish trip in Florida.

title: Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin, 83, Dies; Led Congregation in Jersey City
description: Rabbi Benjamin Plotkin, founder and spiritual leader for more than 50 years of Congregation Emanu-El of Jersey City, died Saturday at New York University Hospital.

title: CROWD AT PLACE DE LA BASTILLE TAKES IN WINE AND VICTORY
description: Down the Boulevard Beaumarchais they came, singing the ''Internationale'' and the ''Marseillaise.'' They danced along the Rue St.-Antoine and, arm in arm, 10 across, they strode along the Boulevard Henri IV and the Rue de Lyon. They merged by the thousands on the vast Place de la Bastille to celebrate the victory of Francois Mitterrand, the new President of France.

title: TAX CUTS WEIGHED FOR BANKS TO KEEP THEM IN NEW YORK
description: In meetings at City Hall and in Albany, city and state officials concerned about competition from banks in other parts of the nation have been discussing a reduction in taxes on New York banks.

title: Enough of State Capitalism
description: For some states and businesses, it's a very good deal: instead of borrowing from a bank to build new facilities, the state borrows for the business. Because state bonds for industry or anything else are exempt from income taxes, they sell for 3 or 4 percentage points below the private market rate. The company keeps the difference. The community gets jobs - and maybe more property taxes as well. And because the bonds are backed only by the revenues of the business, the state's credit is unaffected.

title: People
description: * Morton Frank, publisher, has been named chairman, and Patrick Linskey president of Family Weekly magazine.

title: Cohen Captures Jersey Marathon
description: Gary Cohen of Edison Township won the New Jersey Marathon today in a time of 2 hours 24 minutes 57 seconds.

title: Indonesia in Plane Venture
description: Indonesia is to build a new passenger-cargo plane in collaboration with the Spanish Cassa Aviation Company, the semi-official Antara news agency said today, quoting a Government announcement.

title: Belfast Hunger Striker Is Said to Lose Eyesight
description: An Irish Republican Army inmate, Francis Hughes, has lost his eyesight on the 57th day of his hunger strike in the Maze Prison near here and has little time to live, his brother Oliver said today.

title: IT'S COONEY'S NIGHT TO ANSWER CRITICS
description: THERE comes a time when candy-coated leprechauns and Gentleman Jim Corbett's walking stick will not work, a time when gimmickry of gorilla costumes and yarmulkes must give way to the hard sell of left hooks and meaningful victories.

title: THE SHIBBOLETH OF PRODUCTIVITY
description: Conventional wisdom attributes the crisis of the American economy to a decline in the work ethic. We have supposedly lost our capacity to work long hours, produce high-quality goods, and save our money, and all this in turn is driving our corporate economy toward bankruptcy. There are ubiquitous pleas to return to the historic values of personal discipline and sacrifice.

title: Gunman in West Germany Wounds a State Official
description: The economics minister of West Germany's Hesse state was shot and seriously wounded by a gunman at his home early today, the police said.

title: Gasoline Prices Decline a Bit
description: Gasoline prices are softening at both the wholesale and retail levels across the country, an oil industry analyst said today.

title: PLAN WOULD LET MEXICANS WORK AS U.S. GUESTS
description: Despite opposition from organized labor and many Mexican Americans, the Reagan Administration is considering the institution of a large guest-worker program as a means of improving United States-Mexican relations and curbing illegal migration.

title: TO GET THE WORLD TO OBEY THE WORLD COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Alberto Rios Wins Poetry Prize
description: Alberto Rios, author of ''One Night in a Familiar Room,'' has been chosen the winner of the 1981 Walt Whitman Award by the Academy of American Poets.

title: SPURRED BY FEAR, MORE AND MORE WOMEN LEARN HOW TO USE GUNS
description: Jo Ann Colomb, a suburban mother of three young children, has never allowed her 11-year-old son Chris to own a toy gun. Cindy Parr, an office manager for a doctor, used to be ''scared to death'' of guns.

title: It's No Joke After All for Ed Herlihy to Get a Degree
description: He's had a distinguished career as an actor and radio and television announcer, and he's been active in Catholic charities, but Ed Herlihy says he needed the intercession of a Jewish businessman to line up an honorary degree from a Catholic University.

title: WHAT MAYOR KOCH IS DOING TO JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard REMEMBRANCE OF THINGS PAST. By Marcel Proust. The definitive Pleiade Edition, translated from the French by C.K. Scott Moncrieff and Terence Kil- martin. Volume One: ''Swann's Way,'' ''Within a Budding Grove.'' Volume Two: ''The Guermantes Way,'' ''Cities of the Plain.'' Volume Three: ''The Cap- tive,'' ''The Fugitive,'' ''Time Re- gained'' (translated by Andreas Mayr). 3,365 pages. Random House. Boxed set, $75; each volume, $25.

title: SCHMIDT PARTY OUT IN WEST BERLIN VOTE
description: The Social Democratic Party of West Berlin suffered its worst losses since World War II in city elections tonight, straining the West German coalition Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt.

title: The U.N. Today; May 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TV: THAT 'BRIEF ENCOUNTER' COUPLE REUNITED IN INDIA
description: TREVOR HOWARD and Celia Johnson. Rarely have two names been so inextricably linked by a single production, in this case a film. ''Brief Encounter'' was made in 1945 and its Noel Coward story of bittersweet love in a suburban English railway station has ensconced itself in the ''Casablanca'' category of movie classics. Tonight at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, Miss Johnson and Mr. Howard have been reunited, some 35 years later, for the Granada television production of ''Staying On,'' based on a Paul Scott novel. The team's very special chemistry still works splendidly.

title: Hong Kong Banking Bills
description: The Hong Kong Government has introduced legislation to strengthen ''prudential supervision'' of banks and deposit-taking companies.

title: Executive Vice President Is Named to Head Winnebago
description: Ronald E. Haugen, 39, has been elected president of Winnebago Industries, the large recreational-vehicle manufacturer. He succeeds John K. Hanson, 67, who has been the major factor at the company, which is based in Forest City, Iowa, since 1959.

title: MARGARET LINDSAY, ACTRESS, DIES AT 70
description: Margaret Lindsay, who appeared in 88 movies during her 30-year career, died of emphysema at Good Samaritan Hospital on Friday. She was 70 years old.

title: Dibbs Triumphs In Final
description: For Carlos Kirmayr, taking points from Eddie Dibbs in the Tournament of Champions tennis final at Forest Hills yesterday was like pulling teeth. Kirmayr extracted only a few as Dibbs quickly and decisively beat the 30-year-old Brazilian, who had enjoyed an incredible week of upsets, 6-3, 6-2.

title: A REUNION FOR BRONX GIRL, ,3, MISSING 2 DAYS
description: A 3-year-old Bronx girl who disappeared from a shoe store last Friday was reunited with her family yesterday in a joyously impromptu Mother's Day celebration, just hours after an unidentified woman left her at a Manhattan police station.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Winner
description: Chris Evert Lloyd won the Perugia open tennis tournament today for the second year in a row, beating Virginia Ruzici of Rumania, 6-1, 6-2.

title: Victory for Expressive Dance
description: Mrs. Bertram R. Firestone's Expressive Dance scored easily in the $58,700 Comely Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday before a crowd of 19,875.

title: The Economy
description: Two House Democratic leaders rejected Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's view that the Administration's three-year, 30 percent taxcut proposal was headed for passage. The two, Representatives Dan Rostenkowski and Thomas S. Foley, reiterated earlier criticism that the plan was inflationary. (Page D1.)

title: Tokyo Newspapers Greet Suzuki With Cool Response to U.S. Trip
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki returned today to a cool response in the Japanese press to his first meeting with President Reagan.

title: China Doll, a Sloop, Wins on L.I. Sound
description: Sidney Kiwitt's China Doll, a 34-foot Pari sloop, captured the overall title for grand prix yachts today in the 72d annual Stratford Shoals race on Long Island Sound.

title: Angels 4, Tigers 3
description: Trailing by 3-0 in the eighth, the Angels staged a game-winning four-run rally.

title: BARRETT F. WELCH
description: Barrett F. Welch, a marketing and advertising executive, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old. He was chairman of the board of Princeton Visual Communications, a company that produces educational films for industry. Mr. Welch joined Foote, Cone and Belding in 1947 following service as a captain with the Air Transport Command in World War II.

title: Cubs-Braves Halted
description: Following a 61-minute rain delay after the 14th inning, the game was rained out and will be replayed in its entirety as part of a doubleheader on July 21. All records in yesterday's game will count. The Braves had led, 5-2, in the ninth, but Hector Cruz sent the game into extra innings with a two-out, three-run homer.

title: Irving Florman, Envoy To Bolivia for Truman
description: Irving Florman, former United States Ambassador to Bolivia in the Truman Administration, died Saturday at Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Florman, a resident of Manhattan, was 88 years old.

title: Japan Vehicle Exports
description: The International Trade and Industry Ministry today denied a report in the financial daily, Nihon Keizai, that Japan would reduce 1981 vehicle exports to Belgium by 5 to 7 percent from last year's level of 112,000.

title: SOCIALIST VICTORY REVERSES TREND OF 23 YEARS IN FRANCE
description: France today elected Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist candidate, as President for the next seven years in its biggest political shift in a generation.

title: ROSE GETS HIT NO. 3,600, BUT PHILS LOSE, 8-4
description: Pete Rose plays to win, so he wasn't very talkative after the Phillies dropped an 8-4 decision to the San Diego Padres yesterday in Philadelphia. The Phillies stayed in a virtual tie with the St. Louis Cardinals for first place in the National League Eastern Division because the Cards lost at home to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Brewers 13, A's 5
description: Mark Brouhard, the replacement for the injured Paul Molitor, drove in five runs as the Brewers mounted a 16-hit attack on the highly rated Oakland pitching staff.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday that reported the firstquarter earnings of the Grumman Corporation, incorrectly described the impact of the company's Flxible Division loss. The company said that first-quarter operating income was up 42 percent from the same period last year, including the Flxible Division loss.

title: Red Smith Not Rowdies Nor Cheats
description: THANKS to the spontaneous generosity of one reader, we are able to bring others abreast of baseball developments in upstate New York in the 1860's. This was about 20 years after Alexander Cartwright and other young sprouts were playing the game beside Sunfish Pond on Murray Hill in Manhattan. The following historical notes, published in the quarterly journal of the New York State Historical Association, were clipped from the Oxford Times in Oxford, N.Y., which is northeast of Binghamton, not far from Norwich:

title: Body of Man Found in River
description: The body of a New Jersey man has been found in the Delaware River, a week after he disappeared in a boating accident, the state police said today. The police said they found the body of Thomas Holton, 30 years old, of South Amboy, N.J., yesterday. He had been missing since May 3.

title: NEW DRUG LIFTS SQUIBB'S HOPES
description: Squibb Corporation shareholders, who gathered last week for their annual meeting in the company's futuristic headquarters in Princeton, N.J., heard the company's executives once again sing the praises of Capoten, its new drug for serious forms of high blood pressure that it hails as a medical breakthrough.

title: Bridge: Leaders Are Closely Packed In Invitational at Cavendish
description: The field was tightly bunched into the final day's play in the Cavendish Club's invitational pair championship here yesterday. Four New York partnerships were in contention, accompanied by one British pair.

title: Notes on the U.N.
description: Alicja Wesolowska, the United Nations secretary who has spent nearly two years in Polish jails on unspecified charges of spying, appears to be one brief step from freedom. United Nations officials said her appeal for clemency has been approved by a subcommittee of the Polish State Council, but for some reason, the Council has not acted on the recommendation.

title: A No-Win Policy on Namibia
description: The most charitable view of the Reagan Administration's new policy on Namibia is that it is too sanguine by half. It asks a lot of black Africa, and much too little from South Africa. Moreover, it proposes that Angola yield up gratis its main bargaining chip - the presence of some 20,000 Cuban troops. If that becomes the final position of the United States, the Cubans and their Soviet helpers will be around indefinitely. And the self-evident merits of the Western case on Namibia will be lost in the bargain.

title: The Lady Is a Champ
description: WITH a modest majesty, Kathy Whitworth has been out there on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour 22 years - almost as long as most of the other women pros have been alive. She was 19 when she turned pro in 1959, a tall Texan who had grown up in Jal, N.M., and she remembers when the galleries were so small, the spectators strolled along the fairways with the golfers. When the crowds got larger, she remembers how the golfers themselves hammered the stakes into the ground and strung the ropes. She also remembers when there weren't quite so many good golfers on the L.P.G.A. tour.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE TOILER AND THE SKEPTIC

title: Chilean Guerrilla Killed in Raid
description: Unidentified guerrillas opened fire on a local police station from a passing car here last night, the police said. Policemen returned the fire, killing one of the attackers, identified as a 43-year-old woman, Orsa Busto Fierro. The police said the attackers were probably leftist guerrillas.

title: JANT SUSAN BERNEY BRIDE OF HENRY THOMAS HUNT 3D
description: At Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers yesterday Janet Susan Berney and Henry Thomas Hunt 3d, graduating seniors at the University of Pennsylvania Law School, were married by Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has elected to its board John G. Linvill, professor of computer systems and director of the Center for Integrated Systems at Stanford University. Martin G. Landin was elected vice president of domestic sales.

title: U.C.L.A. Captures 8th Volleyball Title
description: U.C.L.A. won its eighth National Collegiate volleyball title last night, beating top-seeded Southern California in five games at Santa Barbara's Campus Events Center.

title: News Analysis
description: While public attention has focused on the budget battle that dominated both houses of Congress last week, another series of skirmishes has been taking place in committee rooms all over Capitol Hill.

title: AN OLD HORSE TRIES NEW TRICK
description: A former throroughbred race horse, now retired to more mundane work carrying riders on Central Park bridle paths, apparently sought to return to his old glory yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Sero Shirtmakers Inc., New Haven, Conn., to David Deutsch Associates.

title: Advertising; One Club Honors Agencies
description: AT the One Show presentation, run by the One Club for Art and Copy at the New York Hilton Hotel Friday night, gold and silver awards were bestowed for 39 categories. Scali, McCabe, Sloves walked away with seven golds and five silvers - none for television; Doyle Dane Bernbach, four golds and five silvers, and Ally & Gargano four golds, three for Federal Express television spots.

title: Nyambui Wins Pair
description: As he predicted, Suleiman Nyambui beat Doug Padilla in the 1,500- and 5,000-meter races and led Texas-El Paso to the Western Athletic Conference track and field title yesterday.

title: PARISH FORMED BY OUTCASTS BUILDS TIES TO COMMUNITY
description: As the Archbishop of Canterbury spoke from the pulpit in St. Philip's Church in Harlem yesterday, light shone in through a brightly colored stained glass window depicting the church tower against a background of New York skyscrapers.

title: AMY ALCOTT WINNER
description: Amy Alcott scored five birdies over a six-hole stretch today for a six-under-par 66 and a one-shot victory in the $125,000 Lady Michelob tournament.

title: URGES COMMUNITY AID
description: Nearly two centuries of New York history met 15 centuries of Christian history yesterday as St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Harlem greeted the Archbishop of Canterbury with applause and gifts in a service that attracted more than 1,000 people to the large, 70-year-old edifice.

title: How Mitterrand Sees The Issues
description: Francois Mitterrand's campaign program is a milder version of a more radical Socialist program approved by the party two years ago. During the campaign, Mr. Mitterrand was attacked by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing on some of the points in the original program. Mr. Mitterrand says that he is committed only to his campaign platform.

title: Tiger's Purolator Stock
description: Tiger International Inc., the nation's largest all-cargo airline, has increased its stake in Purolator Inc., a delivery service, to 551,000 shares, or 12.4 percent of those outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tiger International said it had purchased an additional 190,000 shares of Purolator common stock on May 5 for $10.3 million.

title: Pirates 8, Cardinals 2
description: The Pirates salvaged the final game of a three-game series as Dave Parker drove in three runs with four hits - two singles, a double and his fourth home run. Parker, leading an 11-hit attack, helped hand Lary Sorensen his first loss in five decisions. John Candelaria (2-2) and Enrique Romo combined to set down the Cardinals on six hits, including a double and single by Keith Herndandez. Candelaria was forced to leave the game in the seventh because of a pulled muscle in his pitching arm. Phil Garner's hit gave Pittsburgh its first run in the second and Candelaria singled home another to make it 2-0. The left-hander allowed the Cardinals only three hits in the six innings he worked. A single by Dale Berra drove in a Pittsburgh run in the fourth and Parker made the score 4-0 with his homer one inning later. The game, the first in five in which the Pirates have been able to top the Cardinals, was played in 42-degree weather with a light rain falling through the final innings.

title: CANNON PRODUCER EXPECTS OUTPUT RISE
description: It all started with one officer and 80 soldiers, and its mission was to supply armaments for the War of 1812. Today the Watervliet Arsenal, which consists of 73 buildings on 140 acres of land in this city, is the sole producer of big cannons in the United States and one of just four Government-owned arsenals left in the country, only two of which manufacture arms in substantial quantities.

title: TITOISM WITHOUT TITO: LEGACY SEEMS BUOYANT
description: On a recent ordinary weekday, 12,000 people filed solemnly through the villa here where Marshal Tito lived and worked and through the garden pavilion where he is buried.

title: BEGIN SAYS SYRIAN MISSILES WILL BE ATTACKED IF THEY ARE NOT WITHDRAWN
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said at a political rally here today that if the United States failed to persuade Syria to remove its antiaircraft missile batteries from Lebanon, he would order air strikes against them.

title: It's Wise to Keep the Jury in Mind Before It Even Exists
description: According to Roy M. Cohn, it happened just this way. During a late night party at his East Side town house last week, a representative of one of the lawyer's clients came to the door in a state of extreme agitation.

title: Macmillan Names New President
description: William F. Reilly, 42, who joined Macmillan Inc. just five months ago as executive vice president, has been appointed president of the diversified corporation. He succeeds David J. Culbertson, 54, who came to Macmillan about a year ago in that position.

title: Presidential Ball
description: As the Jets' president, Jim Kensil has given away dozens of autographed footballs. But he discovered the other day that it is not quite so simple to give one to a former president - if the recipient happens to be former President Ford.

title: Church to Sell a Painting That Is Both Loved and Hated
description: On Fifth Avenue just north of Washington Square, at the 140-yearold Episcopal Church of the Ascension, the John LaFarge mural on that theme thoroughly upstages another late 19th-century art work: A Sorolla painting on the east wall is not even visible from the entrance, although it measures 83 by 113 inches and has hung there ''at least 50 years,'' the gift of former parish members from the Berwind coal-mining family of Pennsylvania and Newport, R.I. .

title: ACQUITTALS IN ILLINOIS PRISON RIOT TERMED THREAT TO RELATED CASES
description: The acquittal last night of 10 inmates charged with committing murder during a prison riot could mean that no one will ever be convicted in the deaths of three guards, prosecutors said.

title: LIBERALS AND ANGOLA
description: The curious reasoning processes of many Western liberal democrats have been highlighted following President Reagan's decision to try to lift the five-year Congressional ban on United States support, open or covert, for opposition movements in Angola.

title: PAUL J. DUFFY
description: Paul J. Duffy, a retired Hudson County Court judge, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark.

title: EFFECTS OF THE COAL STRIKE RIPPLING ACROSS THE U.S.
description: The coal strike, now in its sixth week, is taking a toll on the nation's economy and is likely to cause serious harm if it persists beyond June 1, according to several economists and business leaders interviewed last week.

title: LINEUP IN PREAKNESS IS DEEP AND VARIED
description: There have been 20 different spellings of Preakness since the Minisi Indians used the word to describe quail woods. Johnny Campo, the high school dropout who trained Pleasant Colony for his Kentucky Derby victory, says he doesn't care how they spell Preakness, just so long as he wins it.

title: Iran Calls New Suggestions For Peace 'Encouraging'
description: A peace mission seeking an end to the seven-month-old war between Iran and Iraq today suggested ways to end the conflict, and Iran responded with its most positive assessment of peace efforts in nearly a month.

title: BLACKJACK 'COUNTERS' AND OTHERS FACE RISK OF EJECTION BY CASINOS
description: Ruth Altman, an Atlantic City businesswoman, said she was ejected from Bally's Park Place gambling casino as a professional card counter at the blackjack table.

title: STAGE: 'I WON'T DANCE,' HAILEY'S BLACK COMEDY
description: ''IDON'T care what you do with your life, it always helps to be crazy.'' So says Dom, the paraplegic hero of Oliver Hailey's new comedy, ''I Won't Dance.'' He's right, of course: insanity is a good shield for deflecting life's pains and indignities. But sometimes craziness alone isn't enough to do the trick. If you're going to endure Mr. Hailey's preposterous play, to take a handy example, might I suggest that you arrive at the theater armed with ear plugs and a good book?

title: MOOREHEAD KENNEDYS: BUILDING A BETTER LIFE
description: There were moments toward the end of the hostage crisis in Iran, Louisa Kennedy recalled the other day, ''when I faced all kinds of possibilties, including wondering what is this man, my husband whom I haven't seen in 14 months, thinking after all this time. Maybe he has decided he doesn't like me.''

title: Weinberger to Ask Help Of NATO in Gulf Area
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will ask the Western European allies this week for more help in defending the Persian Gulf region, possibly including an international strike force, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: IS ROTH REALLY WRITING ABOUT ROTH?
description: IN Philip Roth's latest book, ''Zuckerman Unbound,'' an earnest young student of literature writes an extravagantly comic novel about sexual liberation and finds, to his horror, that he has achieved not the literary honor he always dreamed of, but a kind of awful notoriety. Nathan Zuckerman is accosted by strangers, gossiped about on talk shows, accused of ''depicting Jews in a peep show atmosphere of total perversion,'' mistaken for his hero, Carnovsky, and pictured on the cover of Life magazine. In short, he experiences the same kind of fame his creator, Mr. Roth, experienced some 10 years ago with the publication of ''Portnoy's Complaint.''

title: MOSCOW, PIQUED, ASSAILS HAIG SPEECH
description: The Soviet press reacted quickly and angrily today to a speech in Syracuse yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., terming it an exercise in ''rabid anti-Sovietism and anti-Communism.''

title: PROFESSOR COLEMAN'S TROUBLES
description: Sociology at its best is the study of the development and structure of society and social relationships. While not a precise science that can predict behavior, it is nonetheless a valuable discipline assisting the search for more rational social arrangements.

title: SHIFTS IN SOMALIA
description: To the Editor:

title: SHARP TURN FOR FRANCE
description: Today's election of Socialist leader Francois Mitterrand as President of France will bring much more than a new administration. It marks a new era, the first time since de Gaulle founded the Fifth Republic in 1958 that the opposition has come to power.

title: MUSIC: MAAZEL LEADS CLEVELAND IN A MAHLER THIRD TO SAVIOR
description: Mahler's Third is his longest and possibly his most richly detailed symphony in sheer expressive diversity. Certainly, the work holds the prospect of a very full musical evening, although whether it should be performed with an intermission after the first movement, as Lorin Maazel elected to do with the Cleveland Orchestra in New York's Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, is debatable.

title: Andretti Faces Familiar Problem at Indy
description: Mario Andretti raised the question again: Will the Indianapolis 500, the self-proclaimed ''World's Biggest Sporting Event,'' consider the problems of drivers who want to compete in other events?

title: Nurse Questioned in Deaths Says He Plans to File a Suit
description: A nurse who was questioned by the authorities about the mysterious deaths of 27 elderly patients in two small rural hospitals said he planned to sue county officials for $100 million, alleging defamation of character.
