title: Foote, Cone Assigned Sun Glass Products
description: In other account news, Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, has been assigned the Sun Glass Products out of Corning Glass Works, that were at Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector since 1972.

title: 28-3 LEAP DISALLOWED
description: On a hot, cloudless day at the U.C.L.A. Pepsi Invitational today, a breeze barely over the allowable wind limit kept Carl Lewis from officially recording the second-best long jump ever. Lewis, a University of Houston sophomore, whose mother flew in from New Jersey for the meet, jumped 28 feet 3 inches on his last attempt, but the wind at his back was .02 over the allowable 2.00 meters per second. For his winning leap, he had to settle for an official 27-9 1/4, the longest distance ever jumped in the United States.

title: OPEC Avoids U.S. Banks
description: Only a small fraction of the huge $110 billion surplus of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last year was deposited in American banks or their foreign branches, and liabilities of the United States banking system to Middle East oil exporters declined $2 billion in 1980, according to a study by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: TOP STATE COURT SUPPORTS POLICE ON A SEARCH WITHOUT A WARRANT
description: In a ruling that could increase the power of the police to conduct warrantless searches under certain circumstances, New York's highest court has unanimously upheld the conviction of a New York City man for the attempted murder of a housing police officer.

title: MARK HAMILL TO PLAY 'ELEPHANT MAN' LEAD
description: Mark Hamill, who starred as Luke Skywalker in the film ''Star Wars'' and its successor ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' will make his Broadway debut June 9 in the title role of ''The Elephant Man,'' beginning a 15-week engagement.

title: Oil Price Pact Called Unlikely
description: The current downward pressure on world oil prices and the disarray in petroleum markets are unlikely to dissipate quickly, despite a scheduled meeting in two weeks of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to a variety of oil experts.

title: STAGE: 'IT HAD TO BE YOU,' TAYLOR-BOLOGNA COMEDY
description: THE 1980-81 Broadway season reached its official conclusion last night with the opening of ''It Had to Be You,'' the last show to arrive in time to qualify for this year's Tony Awards. I'm afraid the season didn't end with a bang or even a whimper - just an attenuated yawn.

title: Salvador Prelate Sees A 'Beginning' of Justice
description: The acting archbishop of San Salvador, Msgr. Arturo Rivera Damas, said today that the arrest of six Salvadoran military men in the murders of four American churchwomen marked the ''beginning'' of justice.

title: DIVERGENT FORECASTS ON RATES ABOUND
description: Rarely have the credit markets been confronted with such varied interest rate forecasts. Last week, yields rose to record high levels for every maturity beyond one year, but that did not mark the end of the disagreements among those who expect interest rates to decline and those who expect rates to rise still further.

title: William H. Armstrong, 59, Dead; A Founder of Investment Concern
description: William H. Armstrong, a founder and director of research of the Jennison Associates Capital Corporation, an investment management concern, died Thursday of a heart attack in his office at 270 Park Avenue. He was 59 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: LABOR AND WHITE HOUSE TRADING BLAME ON SILENCE
description: A curtain of irritable silence has descended between the Reagan Administration and organized labor, with each side bemoaning the lack of communication and blaming the other side.

title: Lung Association Faults Curb on Advertisements
description: By dropping plans for an antismoking campaign featuring the model Brooke Shields, the Government may be yielding to tobacco industry interests, the president of the American Lung Association charged today.

title: MAYOR KEEPS OFFICE IN RIO GRANDE TOWN
description: McALLEN, Tex., May 10 - After charging that ''outside influences'' were attempting to take over the city government, Mayor Othal Brand yesterday narrowly defeated the strongest drive ever mounted by McAllen's Mexican-American residents to give this border city its first Hispanic mayor.

title: Sports World Specials
description: On another Mother's Day, a few years ago, Betty Ellis, who has five children, was officiating a First Division soccer game on the West Coast. It was 108 degrees, and she recalled the problems: ''I could feel the tension building and building. I was calling a tight game.'' Suddenly, as the pressure mounted, a player kicked a hard pass.

title: MITSUBISHI UNDAUNTED BY AUTO EXPORT REIN
description: Tomio Kubo had reason to be pleased. As the chairman of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, Japan's fourth largest auto maker, he had just concluded a breakthrough agreement with the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Grey Agency Adds Scoundrel Fragrance
description: Grey Advertising started the weekend with the good news that it would be adding Scoundrel fragrance to its fat kit of Revlon assignments.

title: POP: BY MACDERMOT
description: ''AN Evening of New Music With Galt MacDermot,'' presented Friday evening at the Symphony Space, might more accurately have been described as an evening of unfamiliar music by the composer who is best known for his score for ''Hair.''

title: TWO 4-YEAR-OLD COUSINS DROWN IN BAY OFF QUEENS
description: Two 4-year-old cousins drowned in Jamaica Bay yesterday afternoon after they apparently fell off an unmarked embankment while playing with a toy car in a public park in Queens, the police said.

title: CHAMBER: BRENDEL AND Y GROUP
description: THERE were many felicitous moments Saturday night at the 92d Street Y when Gerard Schwarz conducted the Y Chamber Orchestra; they all involved the confluence of national musical temperaments.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: When the catcher misses the third strike, the batter is permitted to try to reach first base, provided the base is unoccupied or is occupied with two out. Is it legal, however, for a batter with two stikes and two balls on him to deliberately swing and miss a wild pitch so that he can try to reach first?

title: Lucky to Be a Yankee
description: After May 15, Marshall Brant can be a Yankee again, according to major-league rules. He had been released by the Yankees on Nov. 3 last year, and though he was signed by the Yankees' Columbus farm club later, he fell under a rule that says players released by a major-league club after Aug. 31 cannot be signed again by that club until after May 15 of the following year. The rule was instituted to prevent teams from stockpiling players. Brant had been called to New York a few weeks ago, but when he got to the stadium he learned that that there had been a misinterpretation of the rule and he could not wear a Yankee uniform until after May 15. He expressed his disappointment before he was sent back to Columbus.

title: News Analysis
description: In November 1979, Andrei A. Gromyko, the first Soviet Foreign Minister to visit Madrid, reportedly made an extraordinary private offer to his Spanish counterpart at the time, Marcelino Oreja.

title: C.I.A. Reportedly Prompted Soviet Pilot's Defection in '76
description: The Central Intelligence Agency, aided by a British intelligence agent, prompted the defection of a Soviet pilot with his MIG-25 interceptor plane in 1976 so that the West could study the craft, the Kyodo news agency said today.

title: Kicked Around
description: The Hartford team of the troubled Major Indoor Soccer League probably will be sold to a Memphis-based Christian athletic group, Athletes in Action, before the month is over and moved to Tennessee, according to team officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review in Weekend last Friday of a piano recital given in the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night misspelled the name of the pianist. She is Nelly Kokinos.

title: LAW SCHOOLS REVISING QUESTIONS AND SCORING OF ADMISSION TESTS
description: The nation's law schools are embarking on a $2 million revision of the Law School Admission Test, a key hurdle for students aspiring to enter law school.

title: Fears for Businesses Grow As Florida Sinkhole Widens
description: A sinkhole that has swallowed a three-bedroom bungalow, half a swimming pool and six Porsche automobiles since it opened Friday ate away at a side street today and threatened a main street.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: OTTAWA: NEW ELECTRONICS CENTER
description: A staid, sleepy, inward-looking city with traditional ways: That has been the Canadians' generally disparaging view of their capital. But that reputation has faded with the Ottawa region's emergence as the country's biggest center for advanced technology research and manufacturing, particularly in telecommunications.

title: ANGELS ACQUIRE RAU
description: The California Angels added Doug Rau, a left-handed pitcher, to their roster today and placed the left-hander Bill Travers on the disabled list. Rau, 32 years old, who last appeared in June 1979, worked four games for San Antonio of the Texas League last season as part of a rehabilitation program after suffering a torn rotator cuff in 1979. Travers has been suffering from tendinitis in his left shoulder.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Only the entire national community can respond to the requirements of the present time.'' - Francois Mitterrand, new President of France. (A8:3.)

title: Asean Plans Meeting in London
description: The foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations have ''accepted in principle'' an invitation to meet with their counterparts in the Common Market in London in October, Foreign Minister Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said today.

title: Lewis W. Cutrer, a Lawyer, Dies; Was Three-Term Houston Mayor
description: Lewis W. Cutrer, a former Mayor of Houston, died Thursday after a long illness.

title: Robert Erb, 83, Retired As Melville Shoe's Chief
description: Robert C. Erb, former president of the Melville Shoe Corporation, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 83 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Commodities; Caveats On Minor Metals
description: STRATEGIC metals, critical metals, exotic metals, or, as they have always been known in the trade, minor metals: Whatever one terms them, the markets in these commodities have suddenly caught the attention of many small investors and speculators.

title: Is Roth Really Writing About Roth?
description: In Philip Roth's latest book, "Zuckerman Unbound," an earnest young student of literature writes an extravagantly comic novel about sexual liberation and finds, to his horror, that he has achieved not the literary honor he always dreamed of, but a kind of awful notoriety. Nathan Zuckerman is accosted by strangers, gossiped about on talk shows, accused of "depicting Jews in a peep show atmosphere of total perversion," mistaken for his hero, Carnovsky, and pictured on the cover of Life magazine. In short, he experiences the same kind of fame his creator, Roth, experienced some 10 years ago with the publication of "Portnoy's Complaint."

title: NORTH STARS SEE FINAL AS 'TOUGHEST SERIES'
description: The Minnesota North Stars will rely on youth and speed and fortuitously bouncing pucks in the Stanley Cup final against the Islanders beginning Tuesday night at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: MUSIC: THE BORODIN TRIO
description: THE Borodin Trio attended to a pair of oft-heard standards in Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon, Beethoven's ''Ghost'' Trio and Schubert's Trio in B flat (D. 898). The three Russian-trained musicians took a different view of these scores from most American ensembles, a genially relaxed approach that eschewed any sense of tautly drawn excitement or drama.

title: Rangers 7, Orioles 3
description: Danny Darwin scored his third consecutive pitching victory, as Texas got five runs in a mistake-filled second inning. The defeat ended Baltimore's five-game winning streak.

title: BETH ELYSE PAYTON IS BRIDE
description: Beth Elyse Payton, a government relations consultant for La Fete, the New Orleans summer festival, was married yesterday to Phillip Warren Beard, a cinematographer. State Supreme Court Justice Beatrice Burstein performed the ceremony at her home in Lawrence, L.I. The bride is the daughter of Mildred Payton of Forest Hills, Queens. The bridegroom's parents, Mary Silva and Warren Preston Beard, live in New Orleans.

title: HABIB HANDS SYRIA A REAGAN MESSAGE ON LEBANON CRISIS
description: The special American envoy to the Middle East, Philip C. Habib, met here today with President Hafez al-Assad to discuss the dispute between Syria and Israel and delivered a message from President Reagan to the Syrian leader.

title: Walesa Arrives in Tokyo For Week's Visit to Japan
description: Japanese labor leaders today welcomed Lech Walesa, head of Poland''s independent Solidarity union, and a delegation of other Polish unionists for a weeklong visit.

title: Newark Fire Is Fatal To Father and Son, 2
description: NEWARK (AP) - A 2-year-old boy and his father were killed when the second fire in two hours spread through their kitchen, fire officials said.

title: FORMER OWNER OF SATURDAY REVIEW QUITS AS EDITOR
description: Finding the role of employee less suitable to his nature than that of owner, Carll Tucker has resigned as editor of the Saturday Review magazine, effective July 1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Armco Inc., Middletown, Ohio, has elected George A. Kay vice president-commercial affairs and communications, and Richard W. Slagle vice president-administrative services.

title: 'AMADEUS' UP FOR SEVEN TONYS
description: ''Amadeus,'' Peter Shaffer's drama about Mozart and his rival Salieri, has been nominated for seven Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, topping all competition in the straight-play field. Its closest rival, with five nominations, was Lanford Wilson's ''Fifth of July.''

title: COMMODITY HOUSE IN BRITAIN PRESSING FOR SUGAR TAKEOVER
description: It was not too long ago that S.& W. Berisford Ltd. was a sleepy company making a nice profit importing food and handling the distribution of sugar in Britain. Then, under new management with new ideas, the company threw itself into the highstakes business of commodity trading.

title: SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

title: Brooks Recounts Day to Forget
description: Of the 69 men that the Mets have used at third base since the club was formed in 1962, none ever had a more frustrating inning in the field than did Hubie Brooks on Sunday in a 5-3 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers at Shea Stadium.

title: BIG BANKS RAISE PRIME HALF-POINT, TO 19 1 2%
description: The nation's banks increased their prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday, to 19 1/2 percent, and many bankers predicted this key rate would climb still further.

title: WESTERN CASUALTY & SURETY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TV: 'FIVE OF ME,' MULTIPLE PERSONALITIES
description: ''THE FIVE OF ME,'' tonight's movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock, is the story of a multiple personality whose true case history, we are informed at the outset, spanned 37 years. The production has several substantial ingredients - imaginative direction by Paul Wendkos; a carefully constructed script by Lawrence B. Marcus, who wrote the screenplay of the ''The Stunt Man,'' and, especially, a strong performance by David Birney in the lead role. But ''The Five of Me'' either ignores or refuses to deal with too many nagging questions.

title: AAR Merger Terms
description: The AAR Corporation, a leading supplier of products to the aviation industry, said that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Brooks & Perkins Inc., a diversified maker of air cargo handling systems, aerospace and nuclear components. AAR said that shareholders of Brooks & Perkins would receive $8 in cash and AAR stock with a formula value of $17 for each Brooks & Perkins share tendered.

title: Suspect in Six Slayings Surrenders After Manhunt
description: A Maryland man accused of shooting to death his estranged wife, two children and three family friends in his suburban Clinton, Md., home surrendered to the Federal Bureau of Investigation early today, ending a nationwide manhunt.

title: No Headline
description: AdvertisingPhilip H. Dougherty Art Director Awards Presented

title: CONSUMER BANK AND U.S. AGREE ON DISPUTED FUNDS
description: The National Consumer Cooperative Bank agreed today to return nearly $60 million that its president withdrew from the United States Treasury and deposited in private banks in a challenge to Reagan Administration budget cuts.

title: Rockets' Dunleavy Is an Unlikely Hero
description: ''Great game, Mike, how's the eye?'' said the cashier in the Houston Stouffer's Hotel coffee shop Sunday. The question was directed at Mike Dunleavy, who had scored a playoff career high of 28 points in the Rockets' 91-86 victory over the Boston Celtics earlier in the day. He also got a black eye after he had been tagged with an elbow in the first period.

title: Marching Against Midden
description: Summer is coming. People are shifting their lives to the out-ofdoors. A harbinger of green smells, lazy afternoons, daydreams - and garbage.

title: Taiwan Posts Trade Deficit
description: Taiwan's foreign trade deficit in the first four months of 1981 amounted to $603 million on a volume of $14.14 billion, official sources said today.

title: Loan From World Bank To China Reported Near
description: The World Bank has completed negotiations with China on a $200 million loan application to improve science and engineering teaching at universities, bank sources say.

title: PAKISTANI SEES FLAWS IN U.S. AID OFFER
description: The proposed $500-million-a-year package of American military and economic aid for Pakistan falls short of matching Soviet military assistance to India, which, according to a senior Pakistani official, was what his Government wanted Washington to do.

title: SUPRON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CORRECTIONS
description: A Business Day article yesterday misstated the sales plans of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation in the United States.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-After tax credits of $128,000 for the qr and $190,000 for the 9 mos

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Apple Computer Inc. announced that it filed on Friday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the secondary offering of about 2.3 million shares of common stock by about 100 selling shareholders, to be sold through a group of underwriters managed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Raider Trial: 3 to 4 Months
description: The long-awaited trial of the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League opened today with prospective jurors being told the trial could last three to four months.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $59,319

title: PILOTS' UNION URGES CREW OF 3 FOR JETS
description: A Presidential committee, opening hearings on whether safety requires two or three crew members in cockpits of new airliners, was told by the pilots union today that the latest technology meant an increase, not a decrease, in the work load.

title: 3 CHILDREN KILLED IN FIRE IN ELIZABETH
description: Two young sisters and their infant cousin were killed today in a fire in the upstairs kitchen of a twofamily home in the Elizabethport section here.

title: SILK, SATIN AND LACE: NEW LINGERIE BOUTIQUES
description: A few years ago ready-to-wear boutiques were opening so fast that even the most inveterate shopper could not keep track of them. Now it is lingerie shops.

title: 9 Chosen to Participate In Moscow Ballet Contest
description: Dana Lewis of the New York City Ballet is be among nine American dancers chosen under the American Ballet Competition's stipend program to compete at the Moscow International Ballet Competition from June 9 to 27.

title: TOM BOSTIC
description: Tom Bostic, a former president of the National Association of Broadcasters and a past chairman of the CBS Affiliates group, died here yesterday.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN PLAN CUTS IN SEMICONDUCTOR TARIFFS
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that the United States and Japan had made a significant breakthrough in liberalizing trade in semiconductors, the tiny memory chips that are at the heart of much advanced technology.

title: STAGE: 'AH,MEN,' MUSICAL, AT SOUTH STREET THEATER
description: AS she demonstrated last season in her one-woman Off Broadway evening, Jane White has become a first-rate musical performer. Someone should find, or write, a show that will take advantage of her considerable musical talents, her dramatic ability to convey the emotion within the lines of a lyric. Last night, at the South Street Theater, Miss White opened, along with Jack Betts, Curt Dawson and Stephen Lang, in ''Ah, Men,'' a new, mildly engaging collage about the male experience, written by Paul Shyre and Will Holt. The actress is our ingratiating guide in a thesaurus of quotations with a musical binding.

title: Dallenbach Will Attempt To Qualify for Andretti
description: Wally Dallenbach, retired as an active driver, agreed today to attempt to qualify Mario Andretti's Patrick Wildcat for the Indianapolis 500 while Andretti is competing in the Belgian Grand Prix next weekend.

title: Accused Briton Asserts Killing Was God's Will
description: Peter Sutcliffe, who admits killing 13 women, said at his trial today that God gave him a mission to kill prostitutes because they were ''the scum of the earth.''

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 12, 1981
description: International Financial turmoil gripped France after the election of Francois Mitterrand as the first Socialist President since Charles de Gaulle founded the Fifth Republic in 1958. Securities prices tumbled, the franc came under heavy speculative pressure, the price of gold soared, and the Goverment sent additional customs officers to airports and frontier crossings to prevent any smuggling of valuables to foreign havens. (Page A1, Column 3.) American-French amity was stressed by President Reagan in a message congratulating Francois Mitterrand for his victory in France's presidential election. Mr. Reagan said he looked forward to working with the Socialist leader, but he expressed concern about the possibility of Communists being invited to join the Government.(A6:1-4.)

title: Merrill to Aid Sale Of Bank C.D.'s
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. will announce today that it has created a program to enable small banks across the country to sell their certificates of deposit to money market mutual funds, according to banking industry sources.

title: The Police Blotter
description: An 11-year-old girl apparently kept and cared for Denise Ramos, a missing 3-year-old girl from the Bronx who was the subject of an extensive police search for two days. The older girl returned Denise, who had disappeared Friday from a shoe shop on East Fordham Road, to a police station in Upper Manhattan.

title: Notes on Fashion
description: T O begin with, Gianfranco Ferre was in town, which caused enough hub and bub to get everyone going. Mr. Ferre, who is 36 years old, Milanese and appealingly ursine, has been producing clothing under his own name for only three years, and is currently one of the few fashion talents intent on exploring new ideas in clothing design. A former architect, he is called an intellectual by some, a successor to Balenciaga by others.

title: Going Out Guide
description: LADIES' DAY

title: AN AMERICAN GROWTH INDUSTRY KNOWEN AS WELFARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Son of Mrs. Gandhi Entering Indian Politics
description: After almost a year of wavering, Rajiv Gandhi, the 36-year-old son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, plunged into electoral politics today by declaring his candidacy for the parliamentary seat left vacant by the death of his brother, Sanjay, in a plane crash last June.

title: Ex-Lieutenant Governor Cleared After Inquiry in Massachusetts
description: Former Lieut. Gov. Donald R. Dwight of Massachusetts, named in an investigation of public construction contract awards, has been cleared of any wrongdoing after a Federal inquiry, the United States Attorney, Edward Harrington, said today.

title: OPERA: 'THE APOTHECARY'
description: THE apothecary in Haydn's farcical opera, ''Lo Speziale,'' does not create any inspired chemical mixtures. But when ''The Apothecary,'' in a new English translation, finished a four-performance run at the Queens College Opera Theater on Sunday afternoon, the opera's various ingredients were frothily and expertly combined in an amusingly seductive prescription.

title: SOVIET WRITER REBUKED FOR DEVIATION IN HIT PLAY
description: MOSCOW A POPULAR Soviet playwright has been rebuked in the Soviet press for ideological deviation in his latest hit, a long-running play at the Moscow Art Theater that takes an unblinking look at the corrupt and shoddy aspects of Soviet life and milks them for laughs.

title: ROTHKO WORKS AVAILABLE TO SCHOLARS
description: MORE than 1,000 works left by the late Mark Rothko to a foundation bearing his name are assembled in a storage and viewing facility on West 55th Street, open to scholars and others by appointment. For security reasons, the foundation declines to give the exact address.

title: YANKS HOME TO FACE A'S AND STEINBRENNER
description: Willie Randolph found his wife and son waiting for him near the baggage carousel at Newark Airport early yesterday morning, and he clutched 5-month-old Andre to his chest and planted one kiss after another on top of the baby's head. ''It feels like I haven't seen him in four months,'' Randolph said. ''I brought a picture with me, but I might as well throw it away he's changed so much.''

title: ANIMAL, VEGETABLE; City Mushrooms
description: Add to the list of small recurring miracles of urban nature the feral mushroom.

title: ATTENDANCE DECLINE IS WORRYING COSMOS
description: The Cosmos, concerned by a drop in attendance so far this season, said yesterday they would use next Sunday's game against the Chicago Sting at the Meadowlands as an indicator of whether the decline might continue.

title: The U.N. Today; May 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
BRADY'S RECOVERY:DOCTORS DESCRIBE DRAMATIC SEQUENCE OF LUCKY MOMENTS
description: Six weeks ago today, White House Press Secretary James S. Brady was critically wounded by a shot in the head during an attempt on the life of President Reagan. The bullet destroyed a large segment of the right side of Mr. Brady's brain, and even his neurosurgeon, Dr. Arthur I. Kobrine, was initially pessimistic about Mr. Brady's chances for survival. Indeed, for a time television networks erroneously had declared Mr. Brady dead - as indeed he might be, were it not for a web of fortunate circumstances that Dr. Kobrine and others close to the case detailed as they reconstructed in recent days the crucial moments that contributed to what has so far been a remarkable recovery.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
UNITED ARTISTS DISMISSES A TOP PRODUCTION OFFICIAL
description: In the latest of a series of executive changes at United Artists that has followed the poor box-office showing of the $36 million western ''Heaven's Gate,'' Steven Bach, the company's vice president in charge of production, was dismissed today.

title: Indians 3, White Sox 1
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Joe Charboneau's tie-breaking two-run homer in the seventh inning and Bert Blyleven's four-hit pitching paced Cleveland. Charboneau's homer was his first of the season and only the fifth for Cleveland.

title: DOLE CITES PANEL DOUBT ON TAX CUT
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that President Reagan now lacked majority support on the tax-writing committee for the Administration's proposed three-year, 30 percent tax cut.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ANIMAL, VEGETABLE; Wild
description: Physty the whale, recovered from pneumonia and last seen heading for the open sea, has a new life. Seven orphaned Catskills bear cubs, lugged by wildlife experts to the Adirondacks and the welcoming paws of some somnolent she-bears, have new moms.

title: COSTA RICA BREAKS TIES WITH CUBA
description: Costa Rica broke diplomatic relations with Cuba today because of what it called the ''offensive tone'' of a Cuban letter to the United Nations.

title: Cut in Oil Reserve Prices Sought
description: The Government is trying a variety of measures to lower the price of the oil it buys for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve during the current oil glut, officials said today.

title: POP VOCALIST: MARION TAYLOR
description: A NEW restaurant at 34th Street and Park Avenue called Park Ten is accompanying its air of low-key elegance with two singers who, in different ways, have low-key approaches of their own.

title: U. S INQUIRY AT FULTON FISH MARKET BRINGS MORE THAN 100 SUBPOENAS
description: More than 100 subpoenas have been issued in a Federal investigation of alleged criminal activities at the Fulton Fish Market in lower Manhattan.

title: Pitney Bowes Names President And Chief Operating Officer
description: George B. Harvey, 50, has been named president and chief operating officer of Pitney Bowes Inc., the big business and retail equipment and services manufacturer. He succeeds Fred T. Allen, 64, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: New Stock Issue Planned by Apple
description: Apple Computer Inc., the California-based computer maker that went public in December in an eagerly awaited offering, said yesterday that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a secondary stock offering of 2.25 million outstanding shares by about 100 selling shareholders.

title: Notes on People; Jeffersonian Theory Gets New Lease on Life
description: What ever happened to the Jeffersonian theory that science and the scientific method would help mankind clarify its goals and make citizens more fit for democratic society?

title: News Analysis
description: Many French voters were taken by surprise yesterday when they elected Francois Mitterrand as their President. Many events of magnitude are surprises, even when they are expected or half-expected.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Notes on People; Bee Gees and Manager Settle Suits Out of Court
description: Ending a long dispute in which multimillion-dollar lawsuits were filed against another, the Bee Gees singing group and their longtime manager, Robert Stigwood, have figuratively kissed and made up.

title: Genesco Reports Profit
description: Genesco Inc., one of the country's largest manufacturers of footwear and men's tailored clothing, yesterday reported earnings of $3.6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the three months ended April 30 in contrast to a loss of $5.9 million in the corresponding three months a year earlier. Sales increased by 6 percent, to $165.5 million, from $156.1 million.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOIDS 2 VOTES IN CLASH ON FOOD STAMPS
description: The keen emotions that have come to surround the huge food stamp program spilled over in Congress today and brought proceedings at the House Agriculture Committee to an angry halt. With Democrats and Republicans accusing each other of shady tactics, the committee took the highly unusual step of voiding two close votes on key amendments and agreeing to try again tomorrow. This is one of a series of occasional articles tracing the progress of one program, food stamps, through the budget process.

title: THE SIMPLE DEFINITION OF A HUMAN BEING
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers 9, Royals 1
description: Bump Wills drove in three runs with four hits and scored a run in leading Texas. Wills got three singles and a double and improved his r.b.i. total to 22 from his leadoff spot in the Rangers' batting order. He is the American League runner-up in runs batted in.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Stores Corp. expects to increase capital spending this fiscal year to about $115 million from $97.1 million last year.

title: Market Place; Wheeling Steel: Rising Interest
description: FOR those with negative feelings toward steel companies, the indications are intriguing that nearly 60 percent of Wheeling Pittsburgh Steel shares are in strong hands.

title: PANEL IS WARNED OF REVENUE LOSS IF FUNDS FOR TAX AGENCY ARE CUT
description: Voluntary compliance with the nation's income tax laws will suffer if the Internal Revenue Service budget is reduced as President Reagan recommends, Congress was told today.

title: HIDDEN IN GREAT ART ARE CLUES TO AILMENTS OF THE
description: PAINTERS By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: PREGNANCY LAB REPORTS A SUCCESS
description: FOR the first time an American woman has become pregnant following the insertion into her womb of an embryo that had been fertilized in a glass dish by sperm from her husband, it was announced yesterday in Norfolk, Va.

title: UNBEATEN FRAIER WINS ON KNOCKOUT IN 6TH
description: Marvis Frazier, the 20-year-old son of Joe Frazier, the former world heavyweight champion, passed another test in his professional boxing career last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: POP: LEE ROY REAMS, SINGER
description: LEE ROY REAMS, who is playing what is identified as ''the Dick Powell role'' in the musical ''42d Street,'' did a nightclub act after the show last weekend in the New Room at O'Neal's, 57th Street at Avenue of the Americas (he will be there again Thursday through Saturday), in which he showed an unusual ability to enlarge on some singing styles of the 30's to make them seem contemporary.

title: Tunnel Is Found At Jacobson's Prison
description: Correction officials yesterday said they were investigating the possibility that Howard (Buddy) Jacobson tried to escape through a tunnel from the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y.,

title: Cablevision Merger Waiting Period Ends
description: Columbia Cablevision Inc., Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. and Dow Jones & Company said they had been advised by the Federal Trade Commission that the antitrust waiting period with respect to the merger of UA-Columbia into a joint company owned by Knight-Ridder and Dow Jones ended last Friday.

title: Salomon Partner Cuts Back on Duties
description: James D. Wolfensohn, the polished 47-year-old investment banker who has been the Chrysler Corporation's chief guardian on Wall Street during its often melodramatic struggle for financial survival, will be leaving his full-time duties at Salomon Brothers in October.

title: Conrail Sale Gets Backing
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis said today that 15 major shippers and groups, including the three largest auto makers, had endorsed the Administration's proposal to sell Conrail to private railroads.

title: U.S. STEEL LIFTS PRICES 8% TO 9.7%
description: The United States Steel Corporation announced price increases yesterday for a number of products that reportedly range from 8 percent on bar steel, used widely in manufacturing, to 9.7 percent for sheet and strip, used extensively in the auto industry.

title: A DISTURBED DRIFTER'S GRIM PATH TO ASSAULT CHARGES
description: Three weeks after he was beaten and kicked by a vagrant during a fight in a subway station, a New York City transit police officer is still semicomatose.

title: Red Sox 7, Blue Jays 6
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Gary Allenson drove in five runs, including the winning run in the ninth inning, and Rick Miller tied a major league record with four doubles in the Boston victory over Toronto.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss

title: British Car Sales Rise
description: British car sales in April rose nearly 19 percent from a year earlier, to 136,000 units, while imports fell to 55.3 percent of the market from 58.5 percent, according to figures released today by the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders.

title: INVESCO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Indictments May Be Near In Slaying of Texas Judge
description: In an indication that indictments may be near in the assassination of Federal Judge John H. Wood Jr., a committee announced today that one or more persons had qualified for a $100,000 reward.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Notes on People; Chinese Exporter Hailed at Rochester Commencement
description: The title may be informal, but it wasn't for nothing that Chu Ching-win, a Hong Kong businessman, was referred to at the University of Rochester commencement ceremonies Sunday as ''honorary financial aid officer'' of the university.

title: President Mitterrand, Still Running
description: Thirty million French voters, we would like to believe, can't be wrong. A majority of them voted for change and they are sure to get it, perhaps more than they bargained for. What kind of change? That, alas, even Francois Mitterrand, the winner in Sunday's presidential runoff, is in no position to say.

title: STATE LEGISLATORS DELAY $44 MILLION PLAN TO AID BOSTON
description: The Massachusetts House of Representatives delayed action today on a $44 million plan to ease Boston's fiscal problems, making it necessary for the city's officials to find their own solution to the monetary problems threatening to close the public schools.

title: Court Order Upheld For S.R.O. Building
description: A State Supreme Court justice continued an order restraining the owner of a single-room-occupancy building at 342 West 85th Street from harassing tenants.

title: COONEY CONQUERS NORTON IN ROUND 1
description: Exactly four years to the night on which he knocked out Duane Bobick in 58 seconds, Ken Norton was knocked unconscious by Gerry Cooney in 54 seconds last night in what was believed to be the shortest heavyweight main event ever at Madison Square Garden.

title: LEBANON FEARS ARAB-ISRAELI WAR FOUGHT ON ITS LAND
description: This once rich little country, ripped apart by a half dozen years of violence, again stands at the brink of war.

title: DIVERSITY AMONG EVANGELICALS
description: A statement issued recently by a group of United States evangelical leaders criticizing United States policy in El Salvador demonstrates that not all born-again Christians in this country are standing with the Rev. Jerry Falwell in the congregation of the New Right.

title: HEIST, C H, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
INTERSTATE MOTOR FREIGHT SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Correction
description: Because of an editing error, the name W. Mark Felt, former acting associate director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was misspelled in Francis J. Martin's article, ''Leveling,'' yesterday.

title: Armed Services Exceed Their Enlistment Aims
description: The four armed services exceeded their enlistment objectives for the last six months, the Pentagon has reported. It said that the educational quality of the recruits was up about 22 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: ALLIED PAYS $358 MILLION FOR BUNKER
description: The Allied Corporation has purchased the Bunker Ramo Corporation for $55 a share, or $358 million in cash, notes and convertible preferred stock, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Londoner Takes Key Job At Foote, Cone & Belding
description: After two and a half years of work Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, has lured the executive creative director of its fast-growing London office, to take the same job here.

title: Baseball Talks Resume, But No Progress Reported
description: The first meeting in two weeks in baseball's labor dispute produced no progress yesterday. No date was set for the next meeting in the dispute between the owners and players over free-agent compensation that could lead to a strike May 29.

title: 5 YEARS A CAPTIVE, MRS. PERON IS STILL A RALLYING POINT
description: The high-walled compound sits, a foreboding presence, on the edge of this lushly foliaged town. The people of San Vicente, 25 miles outside Buenos Aires, have tried to inure themselves to it and its sole occupant.

title: KOCH BUDGET SEEKS $100 MILLION MORE FOR TRANSIT OPERATING COSTS
description: Mayor Koch's proposed budget for the 1982 fiscal year calls for an increase of $100 million in New York City's share of Transit Authority operating expenses, including more money to overhaul broken-down subway cars.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RURAL AREAS GROW AGAIN BUT THE DAY OF MITCHELL, KAN., WILL NEVER RETURN
description: At high noon today, judging by fresh tire tracks, no more than a handful of vehicles had been out and around town. The only pedestrian was a grimy goose waddling down the middle of one of the muddy streets.

title: Opening of 'Wally's Cafe' Is Put Off Until May 28
description: 'Wally's Cafe,' the play by Sam Bobrick and Ron Clark that was to have opened Sunday at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, has had its opening delayed until May 28. Previews will begin tomorrow afternoon.

title: ROCOR INTERNATIONAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SUSPECT PLEADS NOT GUILTY TO THREE MURDERS IN BUFFALO
description: Army Pvt. Joseph Christopher, who is accused of killing three men here last fall, pleaded not guilty today and said he wanted to conduct his own defense.

title: REAGAN BACKS CUTS FOR SOME PROGRAMS IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: President Reagan approved a package of proposed reductions in some Social Security benefits today. The intent is to preserve the solvency of the system and reduce Social Security tax increases scheduled to take effect in the next several years.

title: Esmark Files Intent To Buy Purex Stake
description: Esmark Inc., the Chicago-based food and consumer goods holding company, has filed under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act to purchase up to 25 percent of Purex Industries Inc. in a transaction that could be worth upward of $60 million.

title: DISPOSAL CONCERNS' CHIEF FIGHTS STATE CLOSURE PLAN
description: The president of two hazardous-waste disposal companies on Long Island that are facing shutdown for lack of official permits yesterday denied charges of illegal dumping and organized crime connections and displayed documents he said entitled him to keep operating.

title: Inquest Told of Large Crack In Mine Where 15 Died
description: Two men who entered a western Colorado coal mine where 15 men died April 15 in a methane explosion said today that they had seen a large crack in the tunnel ceiling that could have released the gas.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Comebacks
description: THE gym owns them. As boxers, they despise the ordeal of the sparring, the bag-punching, the rope-skipping and the exercises. But as their perspiration drips into the canvas, it also drips into their psyches. When they stop boxing, they discover that just as they could not live with the gym, now they cannot live without it. Invariably they return. At first it's just to stay in shape, but if they're not too old, one day they snap a jab and they think they can still fight.

title: U.S. Aides Say They Are Studying Bonanno Family Power Struggle
description: Federal law-enforcement authorities said yesterday they were investigating an internal power struggle in the New York-based Bonanno crime family that they believed led to the slaying last week of Alphonse Indelicato, a captain in the family who had apparently tried to seize control.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Together we face serious challenges to the security and wellbeing of our peoples and to the cause of peaceful progress worldwide.

title: Science Watch
description: Sickle cell diagnosis

title: SCHMIDT'S BONN ALLY MAY JOIN HIS FOES IN WEST BERLIN
description: A day after Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Social Democratic Party suffered an election setback here, his coalition in Bonn came under more pressure today as the Free Democrats, his party's coalition partner, indicated readiness to join the victorious Christian Democrats in a West Berlingovernment.

title: Botha Calls Namibia Rebels Acceptable if Duly Elected
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said today that South Africa could ''live with'' a government in South-West Africa that was dominated by the insurgent movement known as the South West Africa People's Organization, if it came to power by constitutional means.

title: House Members Receive Rise in Expense Money
description: House members have been granted substantial increases in travel and office expense allowances to help them meet higher costs.

title: The Dog Law, Gone to the Dogs
description: To the surprise of almost everybody, New York City's dog cleanup law worked well for a time after owners were made legally responsible three years ago. People armed with odd devices to retrieve pet droppings became a common sight, and the city, at minimal cost, became cleaner underfoot. But the novelty of good citizenship has worn off. Sanitation Department officials say compliance has declined from 80 percent to 50 percent and Sanitation Police are again on the prowl for violators, especially in the parks.

title: California Plane Crash Kills Four
description: A single-engine Bonanza Beechcraft plane fell to the ground shortly after takeoff yesterday and crashed in flames into a hangar at Burbank-Glendale-Pasadena Airport, killing all four persons on board. The victims were not identified.

title: Auto Inventory Up for April
description: United States auto makers' inventories swelled to a 65-day supply of new cars on April 30, up from a 44-day supply March 31, as auto production increased 12.6 percent from April 1980, an industry journal reported today.

title: Pertamina Sets Expansion
description: The state oil company, Pertamina, today signed three contracts worth $1 billion for the expansion of two refineries in Java and Kalimantan, part of Indonesia's $6 billion plan to end dependency on imported oil by the mid-1980's.

title: FERRY CAPTAIN GIVES INQUIRY HIS VERSION OF CRASH IN FOG
description: The captain of a Staten Island ferryboat that was in a collision last week with a Norwegian freighter in a thick fog testified yesterday that the freighter had not responded to the ferryboat's whistle prior to the accident.

title: International
description: Turmoil gripped French financial markets following Francois Mitterrand's victory over President Valery Giscard d'Estaing. The French central bank raised its minimum lending rate a record 2 1/2 percentage points, to 16 percent, in a bid to stop the run on the franc, which dropped to a 10-year low. Prices on the French stock market fell the maximum 10 percent allowed, and trading was suspended soon after the market opened. The Finance Ministry said it had drafted extra customs officers to prevent residents smuggling out currency, gold and other valuables to havens abroad. (Page A1.)

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
IF TWO STATES BOUGHT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Sanders-Bluhm Beat Field In Cavendish's Invitational
description: The Cavendish Club's invitational pair championship ended Sunday night in a victory for Tom Sanders of Nashville and Lou Bluhm of Atlanta.

title: RELIGIOS PUBLISHING: GOING SKYWARD
description: RELIGIOUS publishing, which mainly had a reputation for issuing theological tracts and reprints of sermons, has recently taken on a whole new image. Today it addresses such broad concerns as family relationships, self-awareness, personal finance and money managment. There is even a growing body of ''Christian novels'' with biblical themes.

title: MUSIC: ORQUESTA FILARMONICA DE LA CIUDAD DE MEXICO ON TOUR
description: ALTHOUGH founded as recently as 1978, the Orquesta Filarmonica de la Ciudad de Mexico seems to have played in almost every part of the globe during its short life, from South America and Europe to the Far East. At the moment, the orchestra is making its debut tour of the United States, and Sunday nigh,t the musicians played in Carnegie Hall under the direction of their music director, Fernando Lozano.

title: BEGIN SAYS SYRIANS HAVE INCREASED MISSILES IN LEBANON AND ON BORDER
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said in Parliament today that Syria had increased the number of its antiaircraft missile batteries in Lebanon and disclosed that the Israeli Air Force was poised on April 30 to attack the three batteries then in Lebanon.

title: Man, 21, Convicted In Officer's Slaying
description: JERSEY CITY (AP) - A 21-year-old Irvington man was convicted yesterday in the December shooting death of a Port Authority policeman. A Hudson County jury found Fernando (Malik) Odom guilty on 14 counts of an indictment charging him with murder, robbery, kidnapping, criminal coercion, aggravated assault and several weapons offenses, according to a court clerk.

title: DANCE: PHYLLIS LAMHUT IN 'STONES, BONES AND SKIN'
description: PHYLLIS LAMHUT has been making her audiences laugh along with her for so long that it comes as something of a shock when she's dead serious. There is no hope in her new ''Stones, Bones and Skin,'' performed by the Phyllis Lamhut Dance Company on Sunday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, but the choreographer etches this bleak world so expertly it retains a reassuring artistic distance.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Howard Johnson Units Return to N.W. Ayer
description: N.W. Ayer, which had Howard Johnson for a client from 1950 to 1964, has just gotten it back, at least the restaurants, hotels and motor lodges.

title: ROGERS E.M. WHITAKER, WRITER AND EDITOR FOR THE NEW YORKER
description: Rogers E.M. Whitaker, an editor and writer for The New Yorker since 1926, the year after the magazine began publishing, died of cancer yesterday in Calvary Hospital, the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

title: Mrs. Truman's Doctor Calls Condition Critical
description: Bess Truman, 96-year-old widow of President Truman, was in critical condition today at a Kansas City hospital where she underwent surgery last week to repair a fractured hip.

title: 15% WELFARE GRANT RISE WINS PASSAGE IN ALBANY
description: The first increase in welfare grants in seven years received final passage in the Legislature today when it passed the Assembly by a vote of 78 to 68 as the legislators began formal adoption of the overdue state budget.

title: STOCKS FALL SHARPLY AS BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE A HALF-POINT, TO 19 1 2%
description: Against a backdrop of rising interest rates at home and political worries abroad, stock prices plunged anew yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.96 points, to 963.44, reaching its lowest level since late February.

title: New Stouffer's Suit
description: The wife of a Canadian accountant who was killed in the Stouffer's Inn fire in Harrison, N.Y., last December sued the Stouffer Corporation in Federal District Court for $20.4 million in damages.

title: FORESTRY NOMINEE QUERIED BY KENNEDY
description: John B. Crowell Jr., nominated to oversee the nation's forests, today was asked for a formal response to questions about his responsibilities as an antitrust expert for the country's second biggest timber producer.

title: A SHOWCASE FOR ISRAELI FASHIONS, AND A BIT OF NOSTALGIA
description: It's one of the longest running fashion shows in existence. Of course, the clothes change, but the models and a good portion of the audience keep returning. Yesterday, the 27th annual Israel Bond Fashion Show and luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel showed off the country's styles (clothes are second only to diamonds in Israeli exports), raised the usual $1 million in bond sales and served as a reunion for the volunteer models, who have watched their children grow up and produce grandchildren during their years of service.

title: Japanese Aide Denies Formation Of Anti-Soviet Alliance With U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito of Japan denied today that Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki's recent talks with President Reagan in Washington had established a United States-Japanese military alliance against the Soviet Union.

title: Watt Named Champion by Ring
description: Because James Watt, the W.B.C. champion, has already beaten Sean O'Grady, the new W.B.A. champion, in a title fight, Ring magazine has recognized Watt as its lightweight champion.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FRAMPTON SUIT PUTS FOCUS ON COHABITATION LAW
description: In 1976, when his album ''Frampton Comes Alive!'' was at the top of the sales charts, Peter Frampton, the British rock star, was living in Westchester County with Penelope J. McCall.

title: John Hancock Mutual Elects New Chairman
description: John G. McElwee, 59, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, effective next Jan. 1. He will be succeeded as president and chief operating officer of the Boston-based insurer by James Morton, 54.

title: FOES OF MARCOS PLAN A JOINT DRIVE
description: A broad alliance of opposition groups announced today that they had reached an agreement to undertake a civil disobedience movement against the authoritarian Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: HONEYBEES THREATENED BY MITE INFESTATION
description: AN organism that preys on honeybees, a tiny mite once found only in Asia, has spread in recent years to many parts of the world and now threatens the pollination benefits and honey production of one of the earth's most valuable insects. Scientists fear that because there is no known way to control the mites, they may soon become endemic in every nation where honeybees are raised.

title: Islanders Favorites
description: To listen to Lou Nanne, the general manager of the Minnesota North Stars, the disparity and ability between his team and the Islanders is so great, he all but concedes the Stanley Cup to the defending champions.

title: MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FIRESTONE SELLS OHTSU INTEREST
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said that it had sold its 19 percent interest in the Ohtsu Tire and Rubber Company Ltd. of Japan to Unitika Ltd. of Japan, which already was the largest shareholder in Ohtsu. The purchase price was not disclosed. Firestone said the transaction was not connected with its previously announced discussions with the Bridgestone Tire and Rubber Company, Japan's largest tire maker, relating to production of radial-ply truck tires.

title: LEADING BALLET THEATER DANCERS
description: Paul Petroff, a ballet teacher and a leading dancer with the American Ballet Theater, died of a heart attack April 27 in Antwerp, Belgium, where he and his late wife, the ballerina Nana Gollner, had operated a ballet school. Mr. Petroff's death came eight and a half months after that of his wife. He was 73 years old.

title: People
description: * Charles A. Humm has been appointed vice president-marketing for the United States Rent A Car division of the Avis Rent A Car System.

title: PACIFIC TIN CONSOLIDATED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Article 116963 -- No Title
description: As the publicly financed campaign for the June 2 gubernatorial primary moves into its final stages, reports filed with the state by 13 Democrats and eight Republicans showed today that $4.5 million in public funds has already been allocated. In addition, the disbursement of $500,000 more to several candidates was approved.

title: FINANCIAL MARKETS IN FRANCE BATTERED BY VOTING OUTCOME
description: The French financial markets were thrown into turmoil today, following Francois Mitterrand's election yesterday as the country's first Socialist President since Charles de Gaulle founded the Fifth Republic 23 years ago.

title: TPC COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
La Rue Applegate, 67, Executive Held Press Post at Merrill Lynch
description: La Rue Applegate, former vice president in charge of press relations and publications for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the stockbrokerage concern, died last Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 67 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: The Pressuring of Prosecutor Korman
description: There is no sure cure for political meddling in the criminal justice system, but for a while it seemed that the United States Senators from New York had taken a small dose of preventive medicine. First Senator Moynihan, a Democrat, and later Senator d'Amato, a Republican, pledged to let incumbent United States Attorneys serve out their four-year terms after a change of national Administrations. After that, the Senators would recommend new prosecutors of their own political persuasion.

title: About Education; COMPUTERS IN THE CLASS
description: WILL the microcomputer transform the school or is it destined to join the teaching machine and other technological gimmicks in the graveyard of failed panaceas? A preliminary report by Bank Street College of Education on the experiences of three school systems tries to answer the questions school people across the country ask about the new technology.

title: Man Indicted in Oregon Slayings
description: A grand jury today indicted an unemployed mill worker on four counts of murder in connection with a shooting in a tavern that left four people dead and 19 others wounded. The indictments were returned against Lawrence W. Moore, 25 years old, of Scio, Ore.

title: USR Industries Unit
description: Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd., a unit of Mitsubishi Industries, said in Tokyo that it had agreed with USR Industries Inc. to purchase its wholly owned subsidiary, USR Chemical Products Inc., for about $2.3 million. Mitsubishi said that the New Jersey-based company, a manufacturer of fluorescent materials for television picture tubes, had 1980 sales of $4.5 million.

title: Ryan Tops Reds, 5-0, As He Strikes Out 11
description: Nolan Ryan of Houston struck out 11 batters tonight, extending his major league record of 10 or more strikeouts in a game to 133 games, and Jose Cruz slammed a two-run homer, pacing the Astros to a 5-0 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

ESCAPING STEAM KILLS 1, INJURES 8
description: A cleaning woman was scalded to death early this morning when steam exploded out of a broken valve in the basement of the Diamond International Building at Third Avenue and 46th Street, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: Notes on People; Irving Berlin Observes 93d Birthday Quietly
description: The composer who wrote the song that informally rivals ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' as a national anthem quietly observed his 93d bithday yesterday.

title: CLOSER TIES SOUGHT BY LONDON AND BONN
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany sought closer links between their countries today at a meeting made more urgent by the election of Francois Mitterrand as President of France.

title: Lehman Arts Center Lists 1981-82 Season
description: The 1981-82 season of the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College of the City University in the Bronx will include five series: Celebrity, Dance, Theater, Music and Matinees.

title: Puerto Ricans Form New Group in City
description: A dozen organizations have set up an Association of Puerto Rican Executive Directors to identify health and welfare needs, establish a data bank and promote services to Puerto Ricans in New York City, starting June 1. The new group has a first-year grant of $78,375 from the Greater New York Fund/ United Way.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES CURBS ON SALVADORAN ARMS AID
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to impose restrictions on United States military aid to El Salvador that would require President Reagan to certify that the Salvadoran Government was making ''significant progress'' in implementing human rights, economic, and political changes.

title: Outer Critics Circle Picks 'Amadeus' as Best Drama
description: The Outer Critics Circle, an organization of writers and broadcasters covering the theater for weekly newspapers and the outof-town media, has chosen Peter Shaffer's ''Amadeus'' as the outstanding play of the season. The play's star, Ian McKellen, won the award for best performance by an actor.

title: PROPOSAL TO BAR REAGAN'S TAX CUT IS VOTED DOWN BY SENATE, 74 TO 14
description: The Republican-dominated Senate tonight rejected, 74 to 14, an amendment to next year's budget that would have prevented enactment of President Reagan's proposed three-year reduction in personal income taxes.

title: Addenda
description: * Omni magazine to increase its circulation rate base 3.1 percent, to 825,000 from 800,000, and its advertising rates 22.3 percent, effective with the October issue.

title: PIANO: GRAHAM PLAYS BACH PARTITA AT Y
description: DANIEL GRAHAM is at home in many styles, and his program of piano music at the 92d Street Y on Sunday evening worked as well in the intricate architecture of Bach's C minor Partita as in the foggy, often convoluted gloom of the Szymanowski Third Sonata.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
'I Won't Dance' Closes
description: ''I Won't Dance,'' a play by Oliver Hailey that opened Sunday afternoon at the Helen Hayes Theater, closed after 1 performance and 12 previews. Directed by Tom O'Horgan, the black comedy about a paraplegic's fantasy world starred David Selby, Gail Strickland and Arlene Golonka. The production was presented by David Merrick.

title: FLORIDA SINKHOLE CONTINUES TO WIDEN
description: ASINKHOLE in Winter Park, Fla., that had already swallowed a house, five sports cars, a camper and a swimming pool was growing wider yesterday, with parts of other houses starting to fall in.

title: IRT PROPERTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a capital gain of $2 million

title: SETTINTHE V.A. RIGHT
description: Already into the second quarter of his first year in office, President Reagan still has not filled the top slot in the Government's second-largest agency, the Veterans Administration. The appointment of the V.A.'s 11th administrator, when it occurs, may briefly and belatedly focus the public spotlight on an agency that can ill afford exposure on center stage.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES UP SFARPLY
description: Interest rates for new Treasury bills rose sharply at yesterday's auction to 16.43 percent for three-month bills and 15.53 percent for six-month bills.
