title: Chess: Fedorowicz Tops 20 to Win The Manhattan's 90th Title
description: John Fedorowicz, a New York international master, won the 90th Manhattan Chess Club Championship with a score of 5-1, topping a Swiss system field of 20 entrants.

title: INFLATIONARY LESSON OF THE KENNEDY TAX CUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Gloria Swanson and Her Carnation Habit
description: Where, someone wondered at an East Side party the other night, had Gloria Swanson gotten her long-stemmed red rose? ''Why,'' Miss Swanson wondered back, ''do men always call a carnation a 'rose?' '' Perhaps because in the presence of feminine beauty they become oblivious to the nuances of floral display. Miss Swanson, however, is not one to be taken in by such romantic nonsense.

title: Belfast Snipers Wound Two British Soldiers
description: Snipers seized a house here today and opened fire from a window, wounding two British solidiers who were escorting a shipment of money to a post office in West Belfast, the police said.

title: JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. CONGRATULATES MITTERRAND BUT TELLS OF A CONCERN
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it looked forward to working with the new French Government of Francois Mitterrand, but it expressed concern about the possibility of Communists being invited to join the Government.

title: CRIMMINS HEARD ON 2 VIDEOTAPES IN OPERA MURDER
description: In one of two videotapes viewed yesterday by the jury in the murder trial of Craig S. Crimmins, a Metropolitan Opera stagehand, Mr. Crimmins said that he had been in a backstage elevator with Helen Hagnes on the night she was killed at the opera house.

title: Who's For the Hit List?
description: ''Dear Conservative,'' begins a letter I've just received from one John T. (Terry) Dolan. ''Will you do me a personal favor?'' Actually, Mr. Dolan wants two favors, plus money, lots of money. As chairman of the National Conservative Political Action Committee and a leading campaign hit man, he already is oiling up his weapons for 1982. And he wants us conservatives to tell him which of such dangerous liberal senators as the following he should ''target'':

title: Spanish Police Arrest 27 Suspected as Basque Rebels
description: The police arrested 27 people suspected of being Basque guerrillas today after officials said plans for a breakout by separatists from Madrid's main jail had been foiled.

title: Bermuda Hotels Reopening
description: One major Bermuda hotel reopened today and the hotel owners' association said the others shut by islandwide strikes two weeks ago will open their doors again by Thursday.

title: 2.08-Billion-Bushel Wheat Crop Seen
description: The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1981 winter wheat harvest at a record 2.08 billion bushels, up 10 percent from last year's harvest of 1.89 billion, the previous high.

title: WEST GERMANY FEARS TERRORISM WAS MOTIVE IN POLITICIAN'S KILLING
description: West Germany's chief prosecutor said today that the assassination of the treasurer of the Free Democratic Party was being investigated as an act of political terrorism.

title: NORTH AMERICAN MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: 1980 loss included $8,432,345 loss from litigation; previous yr figures included a loss from litigation of $954,569

title: DEAR SUGAR
description: To the Editor:

title: VW Lifts German Prices
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G. said today that it was raising most domestic car prices by an average 3.9 percent, effective immediately.

title: ADVERTISING
description: New-product introductions in April were two up from the 120 that made their debuts in April of last year, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, which also reports that the first four months of the year had a total of 387 compared with 398 in the same period in 1980.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE CHANEYSVILLE INCIDENT. By David Bradley. 432 pages. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Does hot tap water contain more chemicals and metals than cold tap water?

title: ANDERSON MOVING TO FORM A PARTY TO FIELD CANDIDATES IN '82 AND '84
description: John B. Anderson, who received 5.7 million votes as an independent Presidential candidate last fall, is moving toward forming a political party that could field candidates in 1982 and back another try for the White House in 1984.

title: SOUTHWEST FACTORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $113,208 interest on tax settlement

title: Jewish Welfare Board Bestows Book Awards
description: The 1981 National Jewish Book Awards have been announced by the Jewish Welfare Board's Book Council. The awards, which include a $500 prize, were given to Johanna Kaplan for ''O My America!'' in fiction, Randolph L. Braham's ''The Politics of Genocide -the Holocaust in Hungary'' in Holocaust studies and Mark R. Cohen's ''Jewish Self-Government in Medieval Egypt'' for Jewish history.

title: Homosexuality Sets Off Tremors
description: Four years after David Kopay became the first pro football player to admit publicly his sexual preference for men, he is still unable to land a coaching position.

title: Two Queens Convicts Flee From Courthouse Two convicts - including a man who had sought to delay his sentencing on drug and cocaine possession charges so that he could marry - overpowered a corrections officer outside a Queens courthouse and escaped yesterday, the police said.
description: The convicts fled as they were being led, handcuffed to a third man, to a van parked outside the Long Island City courthouse.

title: WHITE-VIETNAMESE SHRIMPING FEUD REPORTED TO EASE
description: Witnesses on both sides of the dispute between local and Vietnamese shrimp fishermen on Galveston Bay testified in Federal court today that actions by the Texas Legislature in the last few days had lessened the potential for violence when the shrimping season opens on Friday.

title: ICL Abandons Merger Talks
description: Britain's only big computer concern underwent a top management shake-up today and stepped away from exploring merger prospects with a foreign competitor.

title: DISSENT AND DESPAIR
description: THAT the right of free expression by scientists in the Soviet Union continues to be trampled is scarcely news. We may even stifle a yawn when reminded of the situation there, as we were at a recent New York symposium of scientists honoring Andrei Sakharov.

title: Braves 3, Pirates 2
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Bruce Benedict drilled a run-scoring single with two outs in the 10th for Atlanta.

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Per shr figures reflect a 5-for-4 stock split

title: COURT BARS EVICTING OF CARD MEMORIZERS
description: Blackjack players who use memory skills to keep track of what cards have been dealt cannot be barred from Atlantic City gambling casinos, according to a ruling today by a three-judge panel of the Appellate Division of State Superior Court.

title: CONOCO SUES TO BLOCK OFFER BY DOME TO BUY 13% INTEREST
description: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that it had filed suit to stop Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s bid to buy at least 14 million shares, or 13 percent, of Conoco's stock, alleging violations of the Securities Exchange Act.

title: UNITED INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TEAMSTER AIDE DENIES CRIME LINK
description: Roy L. Williams, the leading candidate to become the next leader of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said today that he had done a ''good job,'' dismissing allegations that he was tied to organized crime.

title: Military Analysis
description: West Germany, for a decade considered the most powerful European member of NATO, is facing military problems ranging from the high costs of weapons and energy to the growing alienation of the young from the armed forces.

title: ILLINOIS PAPER SEEKS LIBEL-CASE SUPPORT
description: Last June, The Alton Telegraph was ordered to pay $9.2 million for libeling a local contractor in a memorandum that two of its reporters sent to a Government investigator. Now, after a year of trying unsuccessfully to negotiate a smaller settlement, the paper is trying to rally other papers to help overturn a decision that many press freedom advocates say sets an alarming precedent of punishing a paper for a libel it did not print.

title: Jury Rules Out Indictments In Police Slayings of Blacks
description: An Orleans Parish grand jury decided today not to issue any indictments in the deaths of four blacks shot by policemen hunting for the killer of a fellow officer last November.

title: CADILLAC FAIRVIEW HOILDS MERGER TALKS
description: Two major Canadian real estate development companies, both with large-scale operations in the United States, announced today that they were holding preliminary merger talks.

title: POSTAL SERVICE MODIFIES CONTRACT STAND
description: The United States Postal Service, in a surprise move, today dropped its opposition to beginning negotiations on a new labor contract and said it would consult with union leaders about the appropriate ground rules.

title: Ted Turner Files a Suit Against 3 TV Networks
description: Ted Turner, chairman of the Cable News Network, filed an antitrust suit today accusing the three major television networks and the White House of limiting his organization's access to the news.

title: Don Hogan Charles Archbishop of Canterbury Ends Three-Week Visit to the United States The Most Rev. Robert A. K. Runcie, Archbishop of Canterbury, concelebrating mass yesterday at noon at Trinity Church with the Rev. Richard May, left, the vicar, and Gabriel Bonadie, a parishioner.  Later, Archbishop
description: Runcie told of a meeting he had with female Episcopal priests that, he said, ''might have helped me, if I am still a bit sexist.'' Unlike the Episcopal Church in the United

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS: PROGRAM LAGS
description: The Reagan Administration seems to have become almost casual about synthetic fuels in light of the current oversupply in world oil markets.

title: Fiat Subsidiaries in Bid
description: A group of five private companies, including two Fiat subsidiaries, Fidis S.p.A. and Pirelli E.C. S.p.A., said in a joint statement today that they planned to acquire the Italian Government's shareholding in Montedison S.p.A., an industrial holding company. The other companies involved are the Bonomi group holding company, Invest S.p.A., Societa Metallurgica Italiana S.p.A. and Mediobanca, a Fiat spokesman said. Details of the offer, and the participation of each of the five, are yet to be decided.

title: HOLLYWOOD CUTTING BACK AS STRIKE LENGTHENS
description: Columbia Pictures discharged all 12 of the employees in its East Coast story department last weekend as a result of the Hollywood writers' strike. The strike entered its fifth week Saturday.

title: TAKE THE PROFITING OUT OF DRUG TRAFICKING
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $209,000 extraordinary credit from utilization of prior periods tax loss carryforwards

title: ANIMAL, VEGETABLE; LISC Is Independent
description: Friday's editorial on the South Bronx wrongly described the Local Initiatives Support Corporation as affiliated with the South Bronx Development Office. The corporation, established with Ford Foundation support, is an independent entity and financial backer of projects planned by the Development Office.

title: BLACK PRESIDENT OF WHITE SCHOOL URGES NEW VIEW ON MINORITIES
description: PHILADELPHIA DR. MAURICE C. CLIFFORD, who was inaugurated last month as the nation's first black president of a predominantly white medical college, says that he is keenly aware of the ''societal need'' for more minority students to follow his steps into medicine. But at the same time he confesses frustration about the lagging pace of their enrollment.

title: No Headline
description: In October 1979, a company called E-S Pacific Development and Construction Ltd. became the first foreign concern to sign a joint venture contract in China, under new legislation passed by the gradually liberalizing Peking regime.

title:
RED SMITH;
A Garden Party
description: WHEN all the questions had been asked and answers given, Victor Valle burst into song. ''Come along with me, Gerry boy,'' he warbled, casting sheep's eyes at Gerry Cooney. There really is such a thing as a law of compensation, and when you hear Victor Valle sing you know for sure that he must be very good at something else. Like training a fighter, which is a service he performs for Gerry Cooney.

title: HOMESTAKE ESTIMATE IN GOLD STRIKE LIFTED
description: Almost a year after announcing a major gold strike in California, the Homestake Mining Company told its stockholders yesterday at the company's annual meeting that the find is at least three times larger than the more than one million ounces originally estimated.

title: MARCOS SEES 'NO REASON' FOR A VISIT TO WASHINGTON
description: President Ferdinard E. Marcos, who has not yet paid an official visit to the Reagan Administration in Washington, said today that he had ''no reason to go to the United States.''

title: Need to Pay Good Salaries Stressed by BBDO Chief
description: At the annual meeting of BBDO International yesterday, Bruce Crawford, the chief executive, had some interesting remarks on the need to pay good salaries to make good money.

title: T.W.A. TO REDUCE KANSAS CITY STAFF
description: Trans World Airlines said that it planned to cut the management force in its maintenance and engineering department in Kansas City by about 10 percent as part of an effort to cut costs and raise productivity.

title: President of Morrison To Be Chief Executive
description: E. Eugene Bishop, 51, president of Morrison Inc., has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds David R. Cowert, 64, who will continue as chairman of the cafeteria and food service concern with headquarters in Mobile, Ala., and cafeterias primarily in the Southeast.

title: Question of Loyalty
description: His diamond ring, token of the Mets' 1969 world championship, was the biggest piece of jewelry at the East Side reception, but it was his thin gold watch that kept drawing William A. Shea's nervous glance Monday evening.

title: Weizman Sees Problem With Attacking Missiles
description: Ezer Weizman, a former Israeli Defense Minister, said yesterday that Israel ''can blow away'' the Syrian antiaircraft missile batteries in Lebanon, but he wondered whether the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin had considered the consequences of doing so.

title: The U.N. Today; May 13, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the sec- ond special session of the General As- sembly devoted to disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: KENYAN REGION GIVES COMFORT ONLY TO BANDITS
description: They killed a priest here the other Sunday. He had said one mass in a distant corner of the parish and was driving to the site of a second when he ran into a gang of ngorokos, or bandits. They shot him and set fire to his old car.

title: FORMER U.S. AIDE PROPOSED FOR FEDERAL RIGHTS JOB
description: Attorney General William French Smith has recommended that President Reagan nominate William Bradford Reynolds, a Washington lawyer, to be Assistant Attorney General in charge of the civil rights division of the Justice Department.

title: Soviet Navy Squadron Winds Up A Monthlong Visit to Cuban Port
description: A four-ship Soviet naval squadron has left Cuban waters after a monthlong visit and operations in the Caribbean Sea, the United States Navy reported today.

title: HOUSE PANEL ACTS TO MAINTAIN BAN ON MILITARY AID TO ANGOLAN REBELS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved measures today that would retain a legislative ban on military aid to Angolan rebels and tie military assistance to Argentina to improvements in its human rights record.

title: SCHWEIKER'S PENSIONS STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement today by Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, announcing proposed changes in the Social Security System:

title: RETURN OF THE Y.W.C.A. COOKIE
description: WASHINGTON The capital's cookie eaters can relax now. The famous - famous in Washington, anyway - Y.W.C.A. chocolate-chip cookie has returned by way of the street corner vendor.

title: Echo of Iran Heard on Iowa Campus
description: Having gone through 444 days of captivity in Iran, Kathryn Koob was able to look with some detachment upon an incident at a college in Iowa in which a speech she was giving was interrupted by shouting Iranian students.

title: Stronger Impact Found From Four-Color Ads
description: Four-color ads are having a stronger impact on readers now than they did a decade ago, according to studies by Starch INRA Hooper, the research company. Not only that, according to the company, but four-color also generates a larger reading increase over black-andwhite advertising than does a two-page spread over a single-page ad.

title: UNDER MITTERRAND, 'GAULIST' FOREIGN POLICY
description: France's allies can expect Francois Mitterrand to launch not only a radical program of domestic recovery, but also, more important for them, dramatic changes in foreign policy.

title: TV: A PAIR OF TRIBUTES
description: PUBLIC television offers tributes to two exceptionally gifted Americans tonight -Ansel Adams and Duke Ellington. ''Ansel Adams: Photographer'' is on WNET-TV, Channel, 13 at 8 o'clock. ''A Salute to the Duke'' follows at 9.

title: Pleasant Colony, at 5-2, Likely Preakness Favorite
description: Pleasant Colony, winner of the Kentucky Derby, was installed today as a probable 5-2 favorite to win the Preakness Saturday, and the field was reduced to l3 possible starters.

title: INSURER'S STOCK AND MUIR ROLE
description: THE Security America Corporation, one of the many new issues marketed by John Muir & Company of late, appears to have fizzled only months after the shares were sold to the public.

title: Bravery, at Last, on Social Security
description: Sometimes sacred cows lose their halos. Just a few months ago no Congressman who valued the view from Capitol Hill would dare admit publicly that Social Security costs had to be contained. Now, thanks to bold challenges from the House and Senate - and an equally bold response by President Reagan - there is a real opportunity for change. The three initiatives deserve a speedy and sympathetic hearing.

title: Sharon Debt Ruling
description: A spokesman for the Sharon Steel Corporation said yesterday that a Federal District Court judge had ruled that Sharon must redeem, at par value, up to $113 million of public indebtedness that had been incurred by UV Industries Inc., the assets and liabilities of which were assumed by Sharon in November 1979. The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, trustees for some debt holders, had alleged that UV had defaulted on other debt assumed by Sharon, which automatically put the indentures into default, the spokesman said. Sharon said that it would appeal the decision.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT NORTH STARS, 6-3, IN OPENER OF CUP FINAL
description: The Islanders, getting two-goal efforts by Anders Kallur and Wayne Merrick and setting a playoff record for short-handed goals, routed the Minnesota North Stars, 6-3, tonight in the opening game of their Stanley Cup final series at Nassau Coliseum.

title: YANKEES DOWN A'S BY 4-1
description: The Yankee Stadium fans, as expected, warmly welcomed Billy Martin last night, but the Yankees inflicted the first road loss of the season on the Oakland A's manager.

title: NEW YORK STATE FINDS A SITE FOR TOXIC WASTE PLANT
description: A 2,800-acre site near Lake Ontario originally intended to house a nuclear power plant has been selected as ''potentially suitable'' for a plant to treat hazardous waste, the State Environmental Commissioner announced today.

title: TV Notebook; RCA MOVE INTO PAY CABLE EXPECTED
description: Among the three television networks, NBC is the only one to make a move into cable television. ABC has begun a cultural programming network and is developing a cable service aimed at women. CBS intends to begin its cultural and performing-arts network on cable systems in the fall.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Oil and Gas Corp. plans to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of 4.4 million shares of its common stock, now owned by the Amax Petroleum Corp., a unit of Amax Inc.

title: St. John's Bats Hot Despite Spring Chill
description: In March, while young baseball players in the Sun Belt are romping on sunlit fields, the players up North are still waiting for their bats to stop stinging their hands and for the snow flurries to die down.

title: CHANGING THE OLD RULES; New Deal
description: When do you split nines? Kenneth Uston can tell you the answer by rote: when the dealer is showing anything from two to nine, but not seven. Kenneth Uston is a card counter, a master of complex rules for playing blackjack.

title: MCNEIL SHUNS JET CAMP
description: Freeman McNeil, the star running back from U.C.L.A., whom the Jets made their top draft choice, was the surprise absentee from the voluntary rookie minicamp today.

title: Wine Talk; GOOD REDS AT ATTRACTIVE PRICES: THE RELIABLE RIOJAS FROM SPAIN.
description: CONSUMERS in search of a good bottle of red wine for less than $5 are becoming ever more frustrated, for high quality at a moderate price grows more elusive as inflation rages on throughout the world. But there is a picturesque area in northern Spain, the Rioja district, that continues to supply good reds at attractive prices, and they are increasingly being discovered by value-conscious consumers.

title: Around the Nation; Missing Terrorist Reported In Witness Protection Plan
description: Alfredo Mendez, a convicted Puerto Rican terrorist who disappeared from his downstate prison cell, has been transferred to the Federal witness protection program, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Prisons said today.

title: Adolph Coors Trying Corporate Ad Campaign
description: For the first time in its long history, the Adolph Coors Company, brewers in the golden West, will try a corporate advertising campaign.

title: ISRAEL SYRIANS FIRED THEIR MISSILES BUT MISSED AIRCRAFT
description: Missiles were fired from Syrian territory today at Israeli reconnaissance aircraft over Lebanon, the Israeli military command announced. The missiles missed their targets, according to an Israeli spokesman, and the planes returned safely to base.

title: Emery Announces New Operating Chief
description: Gen. William G. Moore Jr., 60 years old, who retired two years ago as commander in chief of the United States Military Airlift Command, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Emery Air Freight Corporation. He succeeds John C. Emery Jr., 56, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the big air-cargo forwarding company based in Wilton, Conn.

title: BENJAMIN SHEARES, 73, PRESIDENT OF SINGAPORE AND NOTED PHYSICIAN
description: President Benjamin Henry Sheares of Singapore, a world-renowned gynecologist who served 10 years as head of state, died today after having suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last Friday. He was 73 years old.

title: Senate Unit Approves an Envoy
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved and sent to the Senate the nomination of Robert G. Neumann to be Ambassador to Saudi Arabia. Mr. Neumann, a career diplomat and former Ambassador to Afghanistan and Morocco, was the head of President Reagan's State Department transition team.

title: OIL HUNT OFF INDONESIA
description: Four Australia companies have reached an agreement with Total Sepasu, the Indonesian oil exploration company, to conduct joint offshore exploration east of Kalimantan, Indonesia, one of the Australian companies, Santos Ltd., said today. Santos and the other three, Endeavour Resources Ltd., Bridge Oil Ltd. and the Australian Oil and Gas Corporation Ltd., will each acquire a 10 percent interest from Total Sepasu, which will hold the remaining interest.

title: City's Reservoir Levels At 74.1% of Capacity
description: The rain in the last two days raised the levels in New York City's reservoirs to 74.1 percent of capacity and those in northeastern New Jersey to 78 percent, officials said yesterday.

title: Futures Exchange Shift
description: The executive committee of the New York Futures Exchange's board will take over operation of the exchange until a replacement is found for William M. Smith, president, who is resigning, the exchange announced yesterday. Mr. Smith, 37 years old, announced in April that he would resign to return to the brokerage business. The executive committee is headed by Harry B. Anderson, retired chairman and director of Merrill Lynch & Company, the diversified financial services concern. A spokesman said exchange officials had not set a specific time period in which to select a new president.

title: Bond Prices Ease Moderately; Short-Term Bill Rates Rise
description: Several long-term bond issues met with good buyer reception yesterday, while short-term rates for Treasury bills moved briskly higher.

title: Around the Nation; Sports Promoter Convicted In Fraudulent Passport Case
description: Ross Fields, the sports promoter accused in a lawsuit of taking part in a $21.3 million embezzlement from Wells Fargo Bank, was found guilty today of falsifying a passport application.

title: N.&W. MERGER PLAN ADVANCES
description: Conrail said today that it had reached a tentative settlement with the Norfolk & Western and Southern railways that coud resolve its objections to a merger of the two rail lines.

title: OIL OUTPUT CUT CITED IN KUWAIT
description: Kuwait is reducing its production of crude oil to 1.25 million barrels a day from 1.5 million barrels, the newspaper Al Siyassa reported today.

title: U.S. RETAIL SALES FELL 1% IN APRIL
description: Dragged down by sinking auto sales, the nation's retail sales fell by 1 percent in April, the first monthly decline in 11 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Perks of Stardom
description: As the producer who persuaded Elizabeth Taylor to make her Broadway debut in ''The Little Foxes,'' Zev Bufman knows how to cosset, pamper and otherwise please his star.

title: AUTO FASHION BUSINESS IN DETROIT IS OLD HAT
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGING THE RULES; Family Economics
description: Sometimes the best economics comes from people who don't take the discipline all that seriously. Consider the work of Barbara Toohey, a California writer and librarian who formulates economic theories for fun.

title: The Pop Life; RIDING THE COUNTRY'S WAVE OF PATRIOTISM?
description: THE phenomenal popularity that country music has enjoyed recently - the success of the movie ''Urban Cowboy'' and its soundtrack album, the No. 1 pop hits for Dolly Parton, Eddie Rabbitt and others, at least nominally ''country'' singers - may have something to do with the general resurgence of political conservatism and patriotic fervor.

title: SHEIL AND MCGANN GAIN RUNOFF IN JERSEY CITY'S MAYORAL ELECTION
description: State Senator Walter N. Sheil and Councilman Gerald McCann foinished at the top of a six-man field of candidates for Mayor of this industrial city today and will face each other in a runoff election scheduled for June 16.

title: The New Missile Diplomacy
description: The relations between the United States and Israel are going through another of their many stormy chapters, and this one is more serious than most.

title: ENERGY COMPANIES RANK HIGH ON LIST OF BLACK-OWNED BUSINESSES
description: Energy-related companies dominated the list of the top 100 blackowned businesses in revenues, while car dealerships, usually the largest category on the list, lost ranking as a result of the general slump in the auto industry, according to Black Enterprise magazine's ninth annual survey of the top 100 black businesses.

title: Article 118333 -- No Title
description: The famed ''blue boy'' cover has been sold to a European stamp collector for $1 million, reportedly the highest price ever paid for a philatelic item, a dealer announced here today.

title: House Panel Backs a Bill to Give Priority to Agent Orange Cases
description: The House Veterans Affairs Committee approved a bill today directing the Veterans Administration to give priority medical treatment to veterans who believe their ailments spring from exposure to Agent Orange in Vietnam.

title: U.S. SEIZES AUSTRIAN JET AND ARMS
description: Customs agents arrested six persons today and confiscated a Boeing 707 jetliner and more than 2,200 military weapons, including automatic rifles and grenade launchers, the authorities said.

title: Founder of Atlanta Ballet Wins Award
description: Dorothy Alexander, cited as the ''architect of the regional ballet movement and founder of the Atlanta Ballet,'' has won the 30th annual Capezio Dance Award.

title: POLICE LEARNING HOW TO COPE WITH A HOLDUP IN A BAR
description: The New York City Police Department is now training all its officers and detectives for situations they might encounter if they are in a bar when a holdup occurs.

title: SAMUELS, NEW YORK CITY OPERA CHAIRMAN, RESIGNS
description: John S. Samuels 3d, his financial empire in apparent disarray, said yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the board of the New York City Opera. At least for the time being, he will retain the chairmanships of the City Center of Music and Drama and the Lincoln Center Theater Company at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. His successor as chairman of the opera board will be Robert W. Wilson, a 54-yearold private investor.

title: POLISH FARM UNION LEGALLY RECOGNIZED
description: A Warsaw court granted legal recognition today to an independent farm union, ending an eight-month-long struggle by Poland's 3.5 million private farmers to gain the same union rights as industrial workers.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: 2d Youth Is Convicted In Slaying of an Editor
description: A 16-year-old resident of a school for delinquent boys was convicted today of helping another youth murder 67-year-old Eleanor Prouty, a retired Reader's Digest editor.

title: JAPANESE COMPANIES CONTROL 225 U.S. CONCERNS, STUDY SAYS
description: Japanese industry controls, wholly or in part, 225 American manufacturing companies with operations in 42 states and a combined work force approaching 60,000, according to a survey by the Japan Economic Institute.

title: N.F.L. Again Seeks Shift Of Site in Antitrust Trial
description: Attorneys for the National Football League said today they may try again to have the site of a $260 million antitrust trial against the league moved because questionnaires from prospective jurors show an impartial panel cannot be found in Los Angeles.

title: SEXUAL PORTRAYALS USING CHILDREN LEGAL UNLESS OBSCENE, COURT RULES
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that the state could not prohibit the use of children in portrayals of sexual activity in books, films, photographs or plays unless it could prove that the resulting materials were legally obscene.

title: CONCERT: MEXICO'S PHILHARMONIC
description: THE major works in the second New York concert by the Orquesta Filarmonica de la Ciudad de Mexico at Carnegie Hall on Monday night were inspired by Italy, not by the orchestra's native land. But Fernando Lozano's conducting of Mendelssohn's ''Italian'' Symphony and Respighi's ''The Pines of Rome'' really suggested no particular location at all.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES TO KEEP PRODUCT SAFETY AGENCY
description: A Senate committee today approved a two-year bill that would reduce funds for the Consumer Product Safety Commission but would not change the structure of the agency, which the Reagan Administration had wanted abolished.

title: 2D HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN BELFAST JAIL
description: Francis Hughes, an Irish Republican Army hunger striker, died in the Maze Prison near here this afternoon in his 59th day without food.

title: HIALEAH CITY AIDES GET CLOTHING BONUS
description: insurance coverage, city officials here have won a more unusual benefit: a $345 yearly clothing allowance.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: 'LENA HORNE: THE LADY AND HER MUSIC'
description: ABOUT midway into the first half of her show at the Nederlander, Lena Horne does the one thing we know she's going to do before we even arrive at the theater. Sliding into her best Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer stance, she looks up into a spotlight and proceeds to sing the hell out of ''Stormy Weather.'' The moment doesn't disappoint. As Miss Horne has already demonstrated in the evening's warm-up numbers - ''From This Moment On,'' ''Where or When,'' ''Can't Help Loving Dat Man of Mine'' - she's in transcendent voice and, at age 63, as beautiful and elegant as ever. You can be sure that she sings ''Stormy Weather'' so it will stay sung.

title: SYRIA SAYS IT DOWNED AN ISRAELI PLANE
description: A Syrian military spokesman said today that Syrian forces operating inside Lebanon shot down an Israeli military reconnaissance plane early this morning, but he did not specify how.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme United Corp., Bridgeport, Conn., has elected Andrew T. Harrison senior vice president for regulatory affairs/quality control.

title: New Talks Set on Algerian Gas
description: Three United States companies will reopen negotiations with Algeria later this month on resumption of shipments of liquefied natural gas to the United States under a new pricing system, an American gas official said today.

title: SIMON LISSIM, A CERAMICS ARTIST, PAINTER, STAGE DESIGNER, TEACHER
description: Simon Lissim, a painter, stage designer, ceramacist and teacher, died of a heart attack Sunday en route to a hospital from his home in Naples, Fla. He was 80 years old and had moved to Naples from his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., in September.

title: Economic Analysis
description: For a while earlier this year, it seemed as though the longawaited decline in interest rates had arrived. Seven weeks ago, key short-term rates were touching yearly lows. A relative calm prevailed in the money markets amid guarded optimism that the new economics of the Reagan Administration might bring inflation under control while pushing interest rates down as well.

title: THE AMERICAN MEDIA'S BIAS ON NORTHERN IRELAND
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1981
description: International A second Irish hunger striker died in a prison outside Belfast in his 59th day without food. Francis Hughes, a member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, had been serving a life sentence for the murder of a British soldier. The latest death touched off new sectarian violence. (Page A1, Column 1.) Missiles were fired from Syrian soil at Israeli reconnaissance aircraft flying over Lebanon, apparently for the first time, the Israeli military command announced. But an Israeli spokesman said that the missiles had missed their targets and that the planes had returned safely to base. (A1:4.) A Syrian military spokesman said that Syrian forces in Lebanon had shot down an Israeli military reconnaissance plane, but he did not specify how. (A16:4-6.)

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1981; The Economy
description: The Republican-controlled Senate adopted a $700.8 billion budget endorsed by President Reagan that was intended to reduce the size and scope of the Government for the 1982 fiscal year. The Senate budget was similiar to the $689 billion conservative fiscal blueprint adopted by the House last week. It envisions eliminations and reductions for many agencies and social programs. (Page A1.)

title: 4 CROATIANS GIVEN 20 TO 35 YEARS FOR PLOT
description: Prison sentences of 20 to 35 years were imposed yesterday on four Croatian nationalists convicted of conspiracy to assassinate a political opponent and bomb buildings in New York.

title: REGULATORY TASK FORCE CITES GAINS
description: The Reagan Administration told Congress today that its program of regulatory relief had already yielded billions of dollars in savings and that more than 100 separate reform actions taken so far were ''only scratching the surface.''

title: Iran Arrests the Agent Who Seized Khomeini
description: The former general with Savak, the Iranian secret police, who arrested Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in 1963 for opposing the Shah has been arrested, Teheran newspapers said today.

title: TOUGH ANTITERRORIST LAW IN PERU DRAWS FIRE FROM RIGHTS GROUPS
description: Human rights and opposition political groups are questioning the constitutionality of a tough antiterrorism law decreed by Peru's civilian Government, which took office last July after 12 years of military dictatorship.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAID TO BACK SALVADOR IN REFUSING TALKS WITH OPPOSITION
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to support El Salvador in rejecting negotiations proposed by the guerrilla-backed leftist opposition, according to United States and Salvadoran sources.

title: Liberians Oust Libya's Diplomats And Demand Cuts in Soviet Staff
description: The Libyan Embassy here has been ordered to close, the Liberian Government announced today.

title: REAGAN ASSAILED AT MEETING ON AGING
description: A state conference on aging, convened to prepare for a White House session later this year, put aside its agenda today to condemn President Reagan's most recent proposal to trim Social Security benefits.

title: STATE COMPLETES CASE
description: Saying that there was ''a risk'' that Craig S. Crimmins might try to flee, the judge in his murder trial revoked his bail yesterday and ordered him jailed on Rikers Island, pending the outcome of the case.

title: U.S. Predicts Wheat Price Drop
description: The Agriculture Department, following a crop report forecasting a record winter wheat crop of 2.08 billion bushels, predicted today that farmers' wheat prices would drop slightly this coming season.

title: Reds 2, Cubs 1
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Leon Durham's wild throw from right field on Ron Oester's base hit allowed Ray Knight to score the winning run from first base in the bottom of the ninth.

title: GETTING FELONS OUT OF THE NURSING-HOME INDUSTRY IS A PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. On occasion when I shop for eggs, I find them, lying open and unrefrigerated, on the supermarket or grocery shelf. Some recipes call for eggs at room temperature. I am confused: should I refrigerate eggs or not?

title: FIRST MAJOR CUTS IN SOCIAL SECURITY PROPOSED IN DETAILED REAGAN PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration today announced details of a proposal for the first significant reduction in Social Security benefits since the retirement system was adopted 46 years ago, and the plan was immediately assailed by some members of Congress and groups representing the elderly.

title: Sperry-I.C.L. Steps In Venture Cited
description: J. Paul Lyet, chairman of the Sperry Corporation, said Sperry had been approached by International Computers Ltd. concerning a possible joint venture, but he said that Sperry had never planned to acquire a majority of I.C.L. Sperry would still be interested in such a deal if it could be resurrected, he added.

title: W, NOW 10, CONTINUING TO GROW
description: FAIRCHILD PUBLICATIONS' W entered its 10th year last month, and Michael F. Coady, its editor, still does not know what to call it. It is probably unique, being the size of a standard newspaper but on 40-pound stock with lots of color beautifully reproduced. The late Charles Revson, thinking of it as an advertising vehicle, said, ''It's a billboard,'' and used two-page color spreads to introduce Revlon's Charlie fragrance.

title: THE SLIPPAGE IN OPEC POWER
description: THE meeting of the Organization of Petrolium Exporting Countries in Geneva on May 25 will take place in the midst of a worldwide oil glut that is putting intense pressure on prices. Spot prices, which exceeded $40 a barrel a year ago, have now fallen as low as $33. The OPEC ceiling price was set at the last meeting at $41, and the base price at $36.

title: Sydney Dance Troupe in U.S. Debut May 27
description: The Sydney Dance Company, Australia's 16-year-old ''national contemporary dance company,'' will make its American debut at City Center from May 27 through May 31 with a repertory of 10 ballets by Graeme Murphy, the company's artistic director and principal choreographer, Barry Moreland, and Paul Saliba and Carl Morrow, members of the company.

title: All You Have to Do Is Ask
description: Brooklyn's Methodist Hospital has pulled out all the stops in celebrating its 100th birthday Friday.

title: Ruland, Former Iona Star, Signs Pact With Bullets
description: The Washington Bullets moved today to fill the opening created by the retirement of their center, Wes Unseld, by signing Jeff Ruland, Iona's career-leading scorer.

title: Around the World; English-Language Paper To Start in Peking on June 1
description: The China Daily, an English-language paper, will start publication here on June 1.

title: SHAH'S ADMISSION TO U.S. LINKED TO MISINFORMATION ON HIS SICKNESS
description: Jimmy Carter's decision to admit the Shah of Iran to the United States, the decision that ignited the 444-day hostage crisis, was based in significant ways on misinformation and misinterpretation of the nature and urgency of the Shah's medical problems.

title: Illinois Gains a Delay On Wilson Case Sanctions
description: Big Ten faculty representatives agreed today to a two-month delay on the imposition of penalties against Illinois for its handling of the grade-transcript case involving the quarterback Dave Wilson.

title: News Analysis
description: In the years Valery Giscard d'Estaing has been President of France, economic and foreign policy in Western Europe has essentially meant a French-West German directorate in which the two countries operated in approximate tandem.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on April 20 incorrectly described a television appearance by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister. Sheik Yamani, who appeared April 19 on NBC's news program ''Meet the Press,'' was also interviewed in 1979 on CBS's ''60 Minutes.''

title: Best Buys; BEEF PRICES LEAD RISE IN MARKET BASKET.
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City jumped 70 cents, to $103.21, during the two-week period from April 27 to May 8, according to the market basket survey of the Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid $9.18 more than in the corresponding period last year.

title: Personal Health; IF YOUR MEDICAL AGE IS TOO GREAT
description: MOST people dread the idea of looking older than they really are, but few realize that, medically speaking, they may actually be older than their chronological age. That is a lot worse than simply looking old because it means that they may have a shorter life expectancy than their age would give them. It also means that they are susceptible to serious illnesses that normally afflict older people.

title: CALIFORNIA ANTICRIME PLAN BARELY CLEARS FIRST HURDLE
description: A proposal by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. to finance an anticrime drive through a tax increase barely cleared its first hurdle in an Assembly committee today.

title: Gourmet's Night Out
description: Here is what happens when you go to dinner at a restaurant nowadays: Waiter brings menus. Asks if you want alcohol before ordering. Departs. Open the menu and begin elimination. Don't want shrimp cocktail at $2.50. Ridiculous price for four tiny, very cold shrimp escorted by finger bowl of ketchup, even if ketchup is spiced with horseradish.

title: 2 Seen in Line For Top Post At W.R. Grace
description: Charles H. Erhart Jr., 55, who this week took over as vice chairman and chief administrative officer of W.R. Grace & Company, moved into a highly visible position at the New York-based chemicals, natural resources and specialty consumer products corporation. With his promotion and others announced two months ago, Mr. Erhart and Carl N. Graf, 54, the new president and chief operating officer, appear to analysts to be the leading contenders for the top post of chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Great Western Drops Merger Bid
description: The Great Western Savings and Loan Association said today that its planned merger with Financial Federation was off because certain amendments to its original offer could not be negotiated. Financial Federation, however, said it was still willing to be acquired.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Around the time that the 20th century began to become particularly unsavory to her, Lenon Holder Hoyte retired to the company of her dolls. She had been a teacher in the New York City school system for 42 years, giving up a great deal of her own after-class time to teach recalcitrant boys and girls what was good for them, but when the children began to hit teachers, she got out.

title: BALLET: ANNUAL WORKSHOP TAKES NEW APPROACHES
description: AN odd but highly satisfactory blend of exhumation and creativity marked this year's edition of what the School of American Ballet calls its Annual Workshop Performance.

title: BUDGET IS PASSED IN ALBANY,42 DAYS LATE
description: The Legislature tonight completed approval of a $16.6 billion state budget, which had been due April 1, after defeating efforts in both houses to delete Medicaid funds for abortion.

title: BRITISH POLICE INVESTIGATING BLAST AT OIL PLANT DURING QUEEN'S VISIT
description: An explosion at a Scottish oil terminal during a visit by Queen Elizabeth II last Saturday was not caused by equipment failure as originally thought.

title: ENERGY USE DOWN
description: The United States set a record in 1980 for coal production, but energy consumption by one measurement fell to its lowest level since 1975, the Energy Department said today.

title: Discoveries; GOURDS TRANSFORMED INTO HANDBAGS; 1. Organic Handbags
description: Some of the most unusual handbags around look like gourds. And no wonder: they're made of gourds, although in their finished state, they bear no resemblance to the @squashes that grow in a garden.

title: SENATE, 78-20, VOTES $700 BILLION BUDGET
description: The Republican-controlled Senate tonight adopted, by a vote of 78 to 20, a $700.8 billion budget endorsed by President Reagan and intended to reduce the size and scope of the Federal Government.

title: Earnings Plunge 32.9% At Foote, Cone & Belding
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications released a less than happy first-quarter financial statement yesterday. Although revenues were up 7.4 percent, to $38.4 million, from $35.8 million, net income plumeted 32.9 percent, to $1 million, or 39 cents a share, from $1.6 million, or 59 cents a share, in last year's first quarter.

title: Cardinals 3, Astros 2
description: HOUSTON (AP) - A suicide-squeeze bunt by Tommy Herr of St. Louis scored Gene Tenace from third base with the winning run in the 10th inning.

title: Ethiopian Rebels Report Gain
description: Guerrillas seeking autonomy for Ethiopia's northern province of Tigre said today that they had gained control of 80 percent of the province.

title: NATO IS TOLD SOVIET IN DISARRAY POSES A BIGGER PERIL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told the Defense Planning Committee of the Atlantic alliance today that internal failures in the Soviet Union might lead it into military adventurism.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: To four or five heaped teaspoonfuls of Colman's mustard powder add a little sugar (say a quarter to half a teaspoonful), a good pinch of salt and several twists from the peppermill. Then stir in wine vinegar (preferably tarragon vinegar) until you get the consistency you want. Water to wet the Colman's. I picked it up from some Lithuanian dancers in a refugee camp in Germany when I was a war correspondent with the French Army. That was probably before you were born, but I've used it ever since, off and on. Especially good with bangers.  EVELYN IRONS
description: Brewster, N.Y.

title: Dr. Gerald S. Shibley Dead at 91; Specialist in Infectious Diseases
description: Dr. Gerald S. Shibley, a former professor of internal medicine at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and a specialist in infectious diseases, died yesterday at his home in Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, N.J. He was 91 years old.

title: CHANGING THE RULES; Ring Requirements
description: It is the end of a round. One boxer staggers to his corner and collapses, unconscious. Can his manager detect possible brain damage? Not necessarily, since neither he nor the other handlers are required to possess paramedical training.

title: CONGRESSIONAL PANELS ADOPT REAGAN'S PLAN TO SLASH FOOD STAMP PROGRAM
description: The Reagan Administration won an important victory today as the Senate and House Agriculture committees adopted legislation that would drastically slash the food stamp program and could mean reduced benefits for all 22 million Americans now receiving nutritional aid.

title: Operating Profit Margin Of 5% Is Pan Am's Goal
description: Pan American World Airways' chairman, William T. Seawell, said yesterday that the company, which had a record overall loss of $114.5 million for the first quarter, ''must attain an operating profit margin of 5 percent'' on its airline business to be able to generate the capital necessary to buy new, fuel-efficient jetliners to ''cope with higher fuel prices.''

title: 27 Hurt in Iowa Farmhouse Blast
description: An explosion and fire that ripped through a farmhouse crowded with young 4-H members destroyed the interior of the house and injured 27 persons yesterday, the authorities said. Eight were still in critical condition today. The cause of the blast had not been determined, but officials speculated that it occurred when the owner of the house, Donald Burzlaff, tried to light a propane gas furnace in the basement.

title: ALBANY PLEA ON ARAB BANK BID
description: In an effort to press the case of a group of Arab investors who are seeking to gain control of Financial General Bankshares Inc., Clark Clifford, the former Secretary of Defense and an influential Washington lawyer, paid an unusual visit to the state's Capitol here today.

title: BLACK TEEN-AGER IS FOUND KILLED OUTSIDE ATLANTA
description: The death of a black youth whose body was found in DeKalb County early this morning, only hours after he was reported missing, might be linked to a string of murders here in recent months, county police officials said this afternoon.

title: News of the Theater; STEVENS COURTS NEWMAN AND REDFORD
description: ''Starring Paul Newman and Robert Redford'' makes for an attractive sign to hang on a theater marquee - which is exactly what the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington is trying to do. The Kennedy Center is negotiating with the two actors to star next season in a revival of ''What Price Glory?,'' Maxwell Anderson and Laurence Stallings's 1924 play about two rivals in World War I, Captain Flagg and Sergeant Quirt under his command.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HISTORICAL ECHOES

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration asked Congress today to gore one of Washington's most sacred cows, Social Security benefits.

title: Seminar on Dance Copyright
description: The Black Theater Alliance will present a free seminar on copyright law and dance tomorrow from 2 to 5 P.M. at the Department of Cultural Affairs Auditorium, 2 Columbus Circle. Among the topics to be covered will be the copyrighting of new dance works, the uses of notation and video recording, copyrighting and cable television, and the permitted use of recorded music.

title: Homemade Ice Cream
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Having made 12 quarts of ice cream a week for years, we particularly enjoyed Pierre Franey's article on the Vermont icecream maker.

title: BARGAIN HUNTERS HELP LIFT DOW
description: The stock market, which has been under selling pressure in recent weeks because of rising interest rates, yesterday rose moderately as a late rally strengthened many issues.

title: Audit Finds Cleveland Surplus
description: The first independent audit of city finances ever conducted here shows that Cleveland, which went into default in 1978 and emerged 23 months later, balanced its budget in 1980 for the first time in years. The city recorded a $3.9 million surplus in 1980.

title: Around the Nation; Kentucky Governor Presses For End to Miner's Strike
description: Negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the coal industry resumed bargaining today, with no apparent progress in their effort to end a 47-day-old strike.

title: ADDING A J TO ANZUS
description: SALINAS Calif. - Since World War II, the United States has consistently encouraged Japan to play a larger security role in the Western Pacific. But Japan, harboring bitter memories of its militarist past and unwilling to jeopardize its economic prosperity, understandably has been reluctant to permit any significant expansion of its security role.

title: Sylvia Wright, a Writer And Harpers Ex-Editor
description: Sylvia Wright, a freelance writer who frequently and humorously commented in national magazines on trends in modern living, died of cancer Saturday at her home in Cambridge, Mass. She was 64 years old.

title: U.S. Is Suing a Medical Supplier
description: The Federal Government sued a major medical equipment supplier today to recover more than $200,000 that the Government said the company obtained through Medicare overcharges. The defendants in the civil action are Eastco Medical Equipment Inc. of Willow Grove, Pa., its president and six subsidiaries that operate in several Eastern states, including Pennsylvania, New York and New Jersey, and in the District of Columbia.

title: Dome Unfazed By Conoco Suit
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that while it was ''disappointed'' by a suit filed by Conoco Inc., it would proceed with plans to purchase Conoco shares in an indirect bid for control of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company Ltd.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: As one who tries to watch her weight, let me remark that although grainy mustards may indeed go well with sausages, pork and other savory no-nos, they can also be experienced as classy and noncaloric pick-me-ups with such simple fare as hard-cooked eggs and small chunks of Swiss cheese. Like seltzer water in a wine goblet, if you know what I mean.  SHARON GREENFIELD
description: New York

title: STEEL OUTPUT GAINS
description: Steel production rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to 2.595 million tons, in the week ended last Saturday, from 2.588 million tons in the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: BOSTON'S ANTI PARTY
description: For a month now, hundreds of irate Bostonians have been blocking several traffic routes into the city at rush hours, causing delays of up to an hour or more. It's the latest form of political protest in the town that first demonstrated the symbolic possibilities of tea.

title: EARNINGS AT LOEWS INCREASE 102%
description: The Loews Corporation, a diversified company that produces cigarettes and watches and operates hotels and movie theaters, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter soared 102 percent on an increase in revenues of 14.1 percent.

title: APPAREL FIELD OFFERS CHALLENGES
description: AT least one-third of the apparel and textile companies in business today will fail or disappear through mergers within 10 years, according to Peter Dingeldey, a principal in Thorndike Deland Associates, a management recruiting firm based in New York.

title: JAZZ: ED PALERMO AND HIS BAND
description: A 16-PIECE rehearsal jazz band that was put together a year and a half ago by Ed Palermo, an alto saxophonist who is also a composer and arranger, in order to hear his music played, has moved out of the rehearsal hall and is now playing on Monday nights at Seventh Avenue South, the double-decker club at Seventh Avenue South and Leroy Street.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: TO anyone with an in-depth knowledge of cooking, professional or not, it is obvious that all or almost all foods fall into individual categories. And if you learn the basic techniques for making one category, you therefore know approximately how to go about making the rest of the related dishes in that sector.

title: Bess Truman Called Seriously Ill,
description: With Pneumonia in Both Lungs

title: FIRST DINNER PARTY: A COOK'S ADVENTURES
description: ALTHOUGH for years I watched my mother, a terrific cook, entertain with apparent ease, I approached my own first dinner party with trepidation. My feelings, as it turned out, were well-founded. If I had only known how to choose dishes that were simple to make and that could be prepared in advance - such as the menu for six guests described in the accompanying article - I could have saved myself much agony.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE AMATEUR. By Robert Littell. 252 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95. XPD. By Len Deighton. 339 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Article 118273 -- No Title
description: The House Armed Services Committee gave final passage today to a $135.6 billion military authorization bill for the fiscal year 1982.

title: SAVE SPECIAL EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TALE OF A GIANT CATFISH OF LAOS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Levy is food correspondent for The London Observer. By PAUL LEVY

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL VOTE ON BUDGET
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted the 1982 fiscal year budget tonight: FOR THE BUDGET - 78 Democrats - 28 Baucus, Mont. Bentsen, Tex.

title: Panel Bars Reagan Plan To Alter Student Loans
description: The House Appropriations Committee today sought to assure college students and lending institutions that there would be no changes in federally guaranteed student loans for the academic year starting this fall.

title: LONDON AND BONN TACKLE COMMON MARKET
description: Britain and West Germany today warned their partners in the European Economic Community, including France, that they intended to fight hard for basic changes in the way the community pays its bills.

title: REBUILDING PLAN FOR CITY PROPERRTY OFFERED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a capital budget of more than $2 billion that he said was the start of a 10-year reconstruction program for New York City's aging roadways, bridges and sewers and its deteriorating mass-transit system.

title: Zabriskie, Whitfield Tied For L.I. Open Lead on 72's
description: Bruce Zabriskie, a 22-year-old assistant pro at nearby Southampton, and Rick Whitfield, 33-year-old head pro at The Creek in Locust Valley, shot par 72 today and shared the opening-day lead in the 54-hole Long Island open.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adobe Oil and Gas Corp. reached an agreement to acquire all the oil and gas properties of MacDonald Properties Inc., in an exchange of cash and securities worth about $10 million.

title: IF THE MIDDLE CLASS LOSES STUDENT LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Im Bank Finances Jets
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it had approved financing for the sale of three Boeing Company 747 jets worth $233.6 million. The bank made a loan of $55.4 million to Union de Transports Aeriens of France for the purchase of aircraft with a total cost of $171.6 million.

title: Mahoney Quits Manhattan
description: Brian Mahoney resigned yesterday as Manhattan College basketball coach to return to St. John's as an assistant to Lou Carnesecca. Mahoney, an alumnus of Manhattan, had served as an assistant under Carnesecca for five seasons before going to Manhattan, where his teams compiled a 16-62 record in three years.

title: Excerpts from message, page B2.
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $14.7 billion budget for 1982 in which he asserted that under his stewardship the once fiscally troubled City of New York was ''well on the way to recovery.''

title: COAL STRATEGY: LONG CONTRACTS
description: John Bickford, president of the sales group for the Westmoreland Coal Company, recalled the marathon sessions during which he and officials of the Israeli Electric Company sat blearyeyed trying to agree on a 30-year contract to deliver steam coal to the utility.

title: Around the Nation; Charles Evers Is Defeated In Mississippi Mayoral Race
description: By The Associated Press Charles Evers, the first black person elected mayor of a Mississippi town, conceded defeat last night in his bid for re-election, losing to a black lawyer in the Democratic primary for Mayor of Fayette.

title: Nigerian Airports Are Shut Down In Second Day of General Strike
description: International flights to and from Nigeria were halted today when air traffic controllers joined a general strike that disrupted economic life here for the second day.

title: Kitchen Equipment; CALPHALON POTS
description: IN these days when copper is so expensive that it might as well be gold, I am often thankful for aluminum, a metal with talents in the kitchen that are very nearly the equal of copper's.

title: New Yorkers, etc.; THE CHALLENGE OF GETTING TO 'THE END' OF THOSE DULL BOOKS
description: THERE'S no getting around it. The same book that delights one reader is absolute zilch to another. That is all very well most of the time, except when the book has had a long and glowing review, in which case the reader who finds it nothing but a big yawn is apt to get a large inferiority complex, and except for people who feel a moral obligation to finish a book no matter what.

title: HOYT W. FULLER, A LITERARY CRITIC AND EDITOR OF BLACK PUBLICATION
description: Hoyt W. Fuller, literary critic, editor of several black intellectual publications and a leading proponent of the concept of a black literary esthetic, died Monday evening in Atlanta following a heart attack. He was 57 years old and lived in that city.

title: MUSIC: MARLBORO FINALE
description: THERE was a predictable aura of excellence about the final Music From Marlboro program of the season in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. As at past concerts, the musicians have all been closely associated with the Marlboro Music Festival, where they spend summers studying chamber music, and this particular combination of seasoned veterans and youthful talents once again proved to be a winning one.

title: CELTICS WIN, 109-80, FOR 3-2 LEAD
description: The Boston Celtics are one victory from hanging a 14th National Basketball Association championship flag from the rafters of the old Boston Garden.

title: Love's Labor's Arbitrated
description: Nearly five years ago the California Supreme Court decided that a Miss Triola was entitled to a trial on her claim that she and a Mr. Marvin had an unwritten agreement re the disposition of income and property from the time they lived together. On that day, cohabitation law was born and so, it's fair to say, was a new unease in the always touchy roommate situation.

title: Around the Nation; Videotapes of Klan Leader Shown at Shrimper Hearing
description: The Grand Dragon of the Texas Ku Klux Klan was shown on videotape today as he trained about two dozen men in guerrilla war tactics, telling them, ''We're going to assume authority in this country.''

title: Around the World; 35,000 People in Mandalay Are Left Homeless by Fire
description: A wind-whipped fire on Sunday swept through Mandalay, a city of half a million people, destroying more than 6,000 buildings and forcing 35,000 homeless people to take refuge in monasteries and temples.

title: CORN BELT WAITS FOR RAIN AND CUT IN INTEREST RATE
description: How much rain falls in the next six weeks and how high interest rates go this spring are of more concern in the Corn Belt this week than whether the Russians will buy any more American grain.

title: WHERE A GENTLE ARE IS STILL PRACTICED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Goodman is a freelance writer and novelist living in London. BY SUSAN GOODMAN LONDON IT is a comforting thought that in this age of mass production the ancient and gentle art of embroidery has not been lost. All the time-honored stitches and methods such as whitework, churchwork and crewel still flourish at the Royal School of Needlework here.

title: Turner to Quit Racing Yachts
description: Ted Turner, a former America's Cup yachting champion and board chairman of the company that runs the Atlantabased Cable News Network, said today that he is finished with major yachting competition.

title: Webster Aitken, 72, Presented All the Schubert Piano Sonatas
description: Webster Aitken, the pianist, died Monday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 72 years old. One of Mr. Aitken's most highly regarded achievements was his performance of the complete Schubert sonatas in London and New York City in 1938, a time when Schubert's piano sonatas were rarely played.

title: THE CITY commissisoner Anthony R Ameruso; Highway Chief Asks A Westway Decision
description: The Federal Highway Administrator, on his first visit to New York since being named to the post, told local officials yesterday to make up their minds on the Westway project because ''the escalation in costs is just horrifying.'' The Westway is to replace the dilapidated West Side Highway from 42d Street to the Battery.

title: FRENCH AFTERMATH: STUNNED WINNERS, SOUR LOSERS
description: At particularly tricky spots French highways carry what must be the world's most frustrated-looking road sign. It is totally blank, except for an exclamation point.

title: FARE RISE OF 50% APPROVED FOR JERSEY BUSES AND TRAINS
description: Officials of the New Jersey Transit Corporation today approved 50 percent fare increases for commuter trains and buses. About half the increases would take effect by July 1, and the rest would be made early next year unless other sources of revenue can be found.

title: Transit Report
description: Brake trouble forced a southbound F train out of service at 8:15 A.M. in Manhattan, causing 40-minute delays on trains behind it, and 10-minute delays were reported on the E, GG and N lines. On the IRT, the No. 2 and No. 3 trains were delayed 10 to 15 minutes during the morning rush.

title: 30 WITNESSES SEE SLAYING SUSPECT IN LINEUP AT BUFFALO
description: Army Pvt. Joseph G. Christopher appeared today in a special lineup before 30 witnesses to a series of murders of black and dark-skinned Hispanic men here, in New York City and in Rochester.

title: Around the World; Bolivia Says It Has Quelled Rebellion by Paratroops
description: The Government announced today that it had forced the surrender of a rebellious paratroop unit by rallying commanders loyal to the President, Gen. Luis Garcia Meza.

title: Bridge: Some Players at Cavendish Wanted More Competition
description: Most of the competitors in the Cavendish Club invitational pairs had had enough bridge when their two days of fierce competition came to an end Sunday night. However, a few dedicated players, with some new blood added for a total of 36, lined up Monday night for the first of three sessions of individual play.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: ONE knows, because New Yorkers often tell you, that New York City is not an easy place to live in, but as a visitor it is difficult to be cynical when a derelict rushes halfway down the street to return a tortoise-shell comb you dropped, and once, when you were standing on a curb, an old man in the back of a passing cab impulsively reached through the open window and shook your hand.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Manhattan G.O.P.  Votes to Back Koch
description: Republican leaders in Manhattan authorized giving their party's line to Mayor Koch, a Democrat, in his re-election campaign this year.

title: Mustard Thoughts
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I note that you have followed the recipe on the Colman mustard box, which instructs the user to mix the powder with water (''Of 187 Mustards,'' April 29).

title: National Advertising Grew In Newspapers in March
description: National advertising spending in newspapers continued strong in March, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, which reported yesterday that expenditures in that category were up 34.2 percent over the same month last year.

title: Congressional Units Act on Conrail Bill
description: A Senate committee approved for floor action today an Administration plan to turn Conrail over to private owners, but hours later a House subcommittee defeated it and voted instead to give the troubled federally subsidized railroad more time to recover.

title: MILOSZ, ENDING EXILE, TO VISIT POLAND
description: Czeslaw Milosz, the poet who won the 1980 Nobel Prize for Literature, will return to his Polish homeland next month after a 30-year self-imposed exile to receive an honorary doctorate from the Catholic University of Lublin. ''I've been present in Poland all along through my writing, now I'll be there in person,'' Mr. Milosz said yesterday from his home in Berkeley, Calif.

title: CAROL BURNETT'S LIBEL AWARD CUT IN HALF, TO $800,000
description: Castigating The National Enquirer for ''a form of legalized pandering,'' a judge nonetheless cut in half today the $1.6 million libel award to Carol Burnett, and the comedian said that she was ''very satisfied.''

title: HELPFUL HINT TO NOVICES: FIX MAIN DISHES AHEAD
description: THE accompanying dinner, based on ideas gleaned from books on French cookery by Julia Child and Elizabeth David, is a safe bet for the novice because the important dishes can be made the night before. There is no need to hang up the saucepans forever if something goes seriously wrong.

title: NEW YORK COUNTY G.O.P. LEADER
description: Vincent F. Albano Jr., the chairman of the New York County Republican Committee since 1962, died last night after suffering what was believed to have been a heart attack outside his office in the Roosevelt Hotel. He was 67 years old and resided at 50 Sutton Place South.

title: RCA Introduces New Line of TV's
description: The RCA Corporation, projecting a strong year for color television sales in 1981, said it had introduced a new line of receivers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Somebody has to take credit. It might as well be me.''

title: Post Security Guard Arrested After Fires
description: A 21-year-old security guard at The New York Post was arrested and charged with setting four small fires in the sixth-floor office suite of Dorothy Schiff, the former Post publisher, at the Post plant at 210 South Street on the East River.

title: BL to Speed Up Cuts in Work Force
description: BL Ltd., the ailing British auto maker, said it would speed up a program designed to cut its work force by 20,000 workers by the end of 1982. BL said the plan, designed to protect a $2 billion capital investment program over the next five years, would use the capacity of key plants to greater effect while shutting down others.

title: Holiday Inns Casino Plan
description: Holiday Inns Inc. said today that it wanted to buy out its California partner in the $145 million, 504-room Harrah's Marina, the fourth of Atlantic City's seven casino hotels.

title: MAXWELL'S PLUM OPENS IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Herb Caen, the columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle who probably comes as close as anyone to being an arbiter of taste in this city, was more or less speechless after visiting the new $7 million Maxwell's Plum restaurant, which officially opened here last night.

title: REAGAN AGAIN PLEDGES TO INCREASE POWER OF STATES
description: President Reagan declared today that he intended to push strongly for enactment of his ''New Federalism'' proposal, which would give states greater control over Federal expenditures. The concept is running into increasing resistance from Democrats, special-interest groups and dissident Republicans.

title: ELECTION SHOCK GRIPS BOURSE
description: At 1:15 this afternoon, 45 minutes later than usual, a brass bell clanged and a roar filled the cavernous, gloomy interior of the Bourse, or Paris stock exchange.

title: DIVESTITURE URGED FOR I.T.T. UNIT
description: A Federal Trade Commission judge ruled today that the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company, the world's largest baker of bread, had for nearly 15 years engaged in illegal price discrimination and other anticompetitive practices aimed at monopolizing the wholesale baking business.

title: Handy & Harman Studies Liquidation
description: Handy & Harman, the New York-based gold and silver refining concern, is studying the possibility of liquidation by Jan. 1 and has retained Goldman, Sachs and Company to advise it, M.W. Townsend, its chairman, told the annual meeting.

title: CITY OPERA LISTS FALL SEASON
description: The New York City Opera will open its fall season on Aug. 27 with three weeks of operetta, alternating performances of ''The Student Prince'' and a new production of ''Song of Norway.'' This will be the first New York City production of ''Song of Norway'' since its twoyear run on Broadway in the 1940's.

title: Broker Rates Cut by 2 Banks
description: Two big banks cut their broker loan rate yesterday in the first sign in weeks that the effect of high interest rates may be giving borrowers a respite from high borrowing costs.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Mugabe Begins Visit to China
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe arrived here today on his second visit since his country won independence last year. Chinese officials have made public no details of his visit but diplomats expected that Chinese aid for Zimbabwe will be a major topic of discussion.

title: Stars' Ciccarelli Glows Faintly
description: Eight hours before his Minnesota North Stars began to skate against the Islanders in the first game of the Stanley Cup playoff final tonight, Coach Glen Sonmor said the team's rookies had ''a little bit of cockiness and a whole lot of talent.''

title: Mets Open Coast Trip With Loss to Padres
description: The geography changed tonight but not the result, as the New York Mets opened a two-week trip in California with a 3-0 loss to the San Diego Padres.
