description: ESTIMATE Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's budget message to the City Council and the Board of Estimate:

title: Mayor Koch's Loose Change
description: New York's Mayor Koch has a problem, and he's trying to hush it up. Well, almost.

title: A PROTEST AY CROSSING WHERE TRUCK KILLED 2
description: More than 200 parents and children demonstrated yesterday, shouting slogans and waving signs, to demand more protection at the busy Greenwich Village intersection where two children were killed when hit by a truck last Friday.

title: HAIG HOPEFUL ON AVERTING MIDEAST WAR
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that it was too early to predict whether the Administration's special Middle East envoy, Philip C. Habib, would be able to prevent an Israeli-Syrian clash over Lebanon, but he said that he was ''very hopeful.''

title: UNLIKELY CHAMPIONS OF LATINS' RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: A SCHOOL WHERE COOKING AND NUTRITION ARE PART OF CURRICULUM
description: ''WHAT'S this?'' Jane Horwitt asked her cooking class at the Caedmon School last Thursday. ''Garlic,'' said Sammy Rubin, one of her students.

title: Around the World; U.S. Pistol Reportedly Used To Kill West German Aide
description: The .22-caliber pistol used to kill a West German state minister was stolen more than 10 years ago from a United States Army garrison, officials said today.

title: Niekro's No. 235 Is A 2-Hitter
description: Phil Niekro pitched a two-hitter and recorded his 235th career victory tonight as the Atlanta Braves defeated Pittsburgh, 2-0, for their 11th consecutive victory over the Pirates.

title: 'GREAT PERFORMERS' OPENS NOV. 8
description: The 1981-82 ''Great Performers Series'' at Lincoln Center will open on Nov. 8 with a piano recital by Alicia de Larrocha. Other artists appearing in Avery Fisher Hall will include the pianists Martha Argerich and Maurizio Pollini; the violinists Itzhak Perlman, Yehudi Menuhin and Pinchas Zukerman; the soprano Jessye Norman in a recital with Garrick Ohlsson, the mezzo-sopranos Christa Ludwig and Marilyn Horne, the flutist James Galway, the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy with the pianist Bella Davidovich and L'Orchestre National de France conducted by Leonard Bernstein.

title: SAUDI MEN STILL HOLD FIRM REIN, BUT WOMEN HAVE EASIER TIME
description: Fawzan wears the traditional head-to-toe veil, but in her furniture store she appears in fashionable European clothing.

title: Sleepwear Bill Sent to Senate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would allow companies to recover losses incurred from a Government ban on the production of children's sleepwear treated with the chemical Tris, a suspected cancer-causing agent.

title: Cooney-Weaver Agreement Reported
description: Gerry Cooney, who punctuated the question marks about him with several exclamation points during his 54-second battering of Ken Norton Monday night, will meet Mike Weaver for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title in September or October, according to Sam Glass of Tiffany Promotions.

title: Brascan Profit Climbs
description: Brascan Ltd., a large Canadian minerals and natural resources concern, announced yesterday that net income increased 14.8 percent, to $22.5 million (Canadian), or 83 cents a share, from $19.6 million (Canadian) or 72 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Revenues rose 22.7 percent, to $43.3 million (Canadian) from $35.2 million.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 14, 1981
description: Shooting of the Pope Pope John Paul II was shot and seriously wounded as he was standing in an open car moving slowly among more than 10,000 worshipers in St. Peter's Square. His accused attacker was identified as an escaped Turkish murderer who had threatened the Pontiff's life in the name of Islam. The Pope, who was struck in the abdomen, right arm and left hand, underwent 5 hours and 25 minutes of abdominal surgery. A hospital bulletin said he was in ''guarded'' condition, but the director of surgery expressed confidence that ''the Pontiff will recover soon.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) The most serious damage was done to the Pope's intestines. Three sections of the bowel, or intestines, were removed in surgery, which was termed successful. A second operation will be required to reconnect portions of the bowel that were severed in a surgical procedure. Recovery is often complete, provided no complications develop. (A1:6.)

title: VIEWS OF THE POPE ON SOCIAL AND RELIGIOUS QUESTIONS
description: Since his election on Oct. 16, 1978, as the 264th Pope, John Paul II, from his throne at the Vatican and in his world travels, has frequently spoken on secular and religious subjects. Following is a selection of his statements.

title: Trial to Start June 1 In Slaying of Lennon
description: The trial of Mark David Chapman on charges of murder in the Dec. 8 slaying of John Lennon, the former Beatle, was scheduled yesterday for June 1 in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

Kevin Brownlow and John Kobal, authors of ''Hollywood: The Pioneers,'' and Alexander Sesonske, author of ''Jean Renoir: The French Film, 1924-1939,'' also received awards from the association for outstanding books in the film field.

FREEDMAN CHICAGO THREE students at the Illinois Institute of Technology here are bringing the ethos of storefront law offices to architectural consulting and passing the benefits of home rehabilitation on to the poor.

title: METS LOSE TO PADRES ON ANOTHER SHUTOUT
description: The New York Mets held an extra workout and a team meeting, and even contained Broderick Perkins to a degree tonight. But that was all that they did as they lost again to the San Diego Padres, 5-0, and scored no runs for the second straight game.

title: Tap Musical to Open May 28
description: Tap dancers Jane Goldberg and Charles (Cookie) Cook will star in ''Old, New, Borrowed & Bluesy,'' a new tap musical that opens on May 28 and will run weekends through June 7 at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, 330 Bowery.

title: THEATER: ALEC MCCOWEN RETURNS IN A SOLO 'ST. MARK'S GOSPEL'
description: ALEC McCOWEN'S one-man version of ''St. Mark's Gospel'' is a prodigious feat of memory, an act of faith and a virtuoso performance - as it was when the actor first brought his show to New York in 1978. The evening opened at the Playhouse Theater last night for a limited return engagement.

BOYS 7 AND 9 CHARGED IN DROWNINGS
description: Two boys, one 7 years old and the other 9, were charged last night with the drowning deaths of two 4-year-old cousins in Jamaica Bay who were pushed off an an embankment in a Queens Park last Sunday. .

It said it viewed the options as an investment.

description: Two brothers from Cleveland, with no publishing experience but with 28 fellow investors, are planning a new magazine with an immediate circulation of 20 million.

title: SATISFACTION VOICED BY U.S. ON NATO ROLE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he was ''very satisfied'' with the recognition by the European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that they might be required to ''facilitate'' United States deployments in areas outside Europe.

title: Oil Well Flow Off China
description: An offshore oil well drilled under a Chinese exploration venture with Japan is yielding 7,000 barrels a day of high-quality low-sulfur crude from a depth of more than 8,500 feet, the New China News Agency said today. The well is 120 miles east of the port of Tanggu in Bohai Bay, in northern China. Under an agreement concluded in May 1979, Japan will get 42.5 percent of the oil output over 15 years.

title: MUSIC: RECENT PARNASSUS WORKS
description: PARNASSUS chose only music of the last 10 years for its Goodman House chamber-music concert Monday. In the process, it seemed to be pointing to the more melodic and lyrical directions new music has taken.

title: Nothing Sacred
description: Because the word ''charisma'' has been carelessly appended to every politician with a good smile and every rock star capable of unnerving adolescents, one hesitates to use it when describing Karol Wojtyla. Until, that is, one reads again the dictionary definition: ''An extraordinary power of healing ... a personal magic.''

description: In the rarefied world of thoroughbred racing, where the John Hay Whitneys and the Thomas Mellon Evanses move with the ease that affluence assures, Henry Greene says he feels perfectly at home.

description: Patti Catalano, the American record-holder for the women's 10,000-meter run and the marathon, has entered the L'eggs Minimarathon in Central Park May 30, officials said yesterday.

description: Democratic and Republican legislative leaders proposed a bill today that would give local governments wide freedom in determining how they assess property.

description: Esteban DeJesus, former World Boxing Council lightweight champion, was convicted today of first-degree murder in the shooting death of an 18-year-old youth in a traffic argument last Nov. 27.

description: Literaturnaya Gazeta, the weekly paper of the Soviet writers union, accused Poland's industrial trade union today of becoming a political movement in competition with the Communist Party.

description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said it planned to sell a majority of its nearly 20 percent interest in the Yokohama Rubber Company of Japan for an undisclosed price.

MONTREAL (NL) - Placed Rowland Of- fice, outfielder, on the disabled list and recalled Chris Smith, infielder, from Denver of the American Association.

description: Home builders here, suffering from their longest and most severe postwar slump, have ripped a page from the auto industry's marketing manual and are offering home buyers a $2,000 rebate when they buy a new house.

title: WHY JOHN PAUL II IS VULNERABLE
description: The Bishop of Rome has now taken the terror of the world into his own body. No Pope has ever made himself so vulnerable as John Paul II. He makes himself vulnerable because of his basic confidence in mankind. John Paul II has a deep sense of the importance of the sacramental, religious processions, and extra-liturgical devotions. His Wednesday audiences at the Vatican provide occasions to move among the people out-of-doors. He not only understands the importance of religious pageantry but he also enjoys it himself as he moves through vast cheering throngs on one local contraption or another. It was while he was in a white jeep making his way through St. Peter's Square before giving a general audience that he was shot in an apparent assassination attempt.

description: The Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, recently rebuffed in an attempt to acquire the Bache Group, disclosed that they had acquired 305,300 shares, or a 5.4 percent interest, in Revere Copper and Brass Inc. at a cost of about $5.2 million.

title: MILES DAVIS HAS KOOL JAZZ DATE
description: Miles Davis will perform at the Kool Jazz Festival here in July, the first public appearance by the jazz trumpeter in five years. At the same time, Columbia Records will release his first studio recording in five years.

title: 4 Accused of Stealing $1 Million In Premiums from Lloyd's Group
description: Four men were charged Tuesday with converting to their own use more than $1 million in premiums assigned to an underwriting group at Lloyd's of London.

title: AGENTS ARREST 6 IN $1.2 MILLION HOUSTON ARMS SALE
description: Bonds totaling $3.8 million were set today for six men charged with attempting to illegally export 1,486 military weapons and ammunition to South Africa.

title: MAINE NEWSPAPER EDITOR
description: Richard S. Saltonstall Jr., co-owner and editor in chief of three weekly newspapers in Maine who was a former White House correspondent for Time magazine, collapsed and died last night while working on this week's issue of The Belfast Republican Journal. He was 44 years old.

title: Nevelson Sculpture Going To Maine Payson Gallery
description: A wood sculpture by Louise Nevelson will be presented to the Joan Whitney Payson Gallery of Art at Westbrook College in Portland, Me., on Saturday by Mr. and Mrs. John Payson during commencement exercises at the college.

title: Business People; Head of Asbestos Calls Quebec Talks 'Friendly'
description: Guy Fiske, chairman of the Montreal-based Asbestos Corporation, made a statement yesterday that many stockholders at the company's annual meeting considered quite remarkable.

title: VICTIM A HERO, KILLER A FOOL, AND FOR THE REST, UNMEANING PAIN
description: With expressions of abhorrence and shock and puzzled lamentations about the nature of irrationality that would impel an attack on a holy man, eminent writers, philosophers and theologians reacted yesterday to the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II. Archibald MacLeish Poet and playwright, speaking from his home in Conway, Mass.

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS NOMINEE VIEWS PLANS WITH SOME RESERVATIONS
description: Edward E. Noble, the Oklahoma businessman nominated by President Reagan as chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, expressed reservations today about the wisdom of promoting a broad range of synthetic fuel technology. But he pledged that he would follow both the letter and spirit of the law requiring the corporation to do so.

title: Going Out Guide
description: IRISH EPIC

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS COUNCIL BACKS HIGHER ARMS OUTLAY
description: A ''substantial increase'' in military outlays to support the United States ability to use force in unstable regions was urged yesterday in New York by a panel drawn largely from leading figures in four recent Administrations.

title: Senate Rejects Move for a Role By Congress on MX Missile Sites
description: The Senate today defeated an attempt to give Congress a role in the decision on deploying the MX nuclear missile system.

title: BUILDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $200,000 for the quarter and $262,000 for the 6 months

title: POP: TINA TURNER AT THE RITZ, THE MAE WEST OF ROCK MUSIC
description: AT the age of 41, Tina Turner is well on her way to becoming the Mae West of rock music. Making her first New York appearance in five years at the Ritz last Thursday, Miss Turner presented the same bawdy female caricature that has endeared her to rock audiences ever since she toured with the Rolling Stones 12 years ago.

title: CAVITRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $101,600 for the quarter and $182,600 for the 6 months

title: News of Music; SAN DIEGO OPERA DOING NEW 'ZAPATA'
description: The San Diego Opera has commissioned a work to celebrate its 20th anniversary season in 1984-85, an opera composed by Leonardo Balada expressly for the singing and acting talents of Sherrill Milnes. For his libretto, Mr. Balada has turned to the life of Emiliano Zapata, the Mexican patriot who was killed in 1919 after a decade of guerrilla warfare against the dictator Porfirio Diaz and his successors - a legendary hero of Mexican history and the subject of the 1952 film ''Viva Zapata'' starring Marlon Brando.

title: Philadelphia Sends Atlanta Aid
description: This city's public schools have presented a $43,217 check to aid schoolchildren in Atlanta, where 27 young blacks have died in mysterious murders since July 1979. The money, raised in a school fund-raising drive, is to be used to reopen Operation Latchkey, an after-school program for 6,000 children who live in Atlanta's public housing projects, and will finance a $5,000 scholarship for college-bound students.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A MELLOW ROMAN EVENING SHATTERED BY SALVO, FOLLOWED BY WAIL OF SIRENS shooting
description: A joyful, cosmopolitan crowd of tens of thousands was filling St. Peter's Square this afternoon, cheering Pope John Paul II and holding up rosaries to be blessed by him. Suddenly a sharp salvo of what sounded like firecrackers was heard.

title: NLT President Adds Chief Executive Post
description: Walter M. Robinson Jr., the 58-year-old president of the NLT Corporation, has been elected to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive officer, effective July 1. He will succeed Russell L. Wagner, who has reached the company's mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: Fed Changing Rule to Foil Coast Bank's Plan to Pay Higher Interest
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that it would change its rules to prevent the Bank of California from establishing highinterest checking accounts at its London branch for residents of the United States.

title: Magazine in Colombia Predicted An Attempt on Life of the Pope
description: An article in a Colombian magazine, available on the streets this morning, predicted that Pope John Paul II would be the victim of an assassination attempt.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $4.7 million gin from the sale of assets for the qua and $3.2 million extraordinary gain for the 9 months...C-Includ $18,000 gain from the sale of assets

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Patrols Due Today At 'Village' Crossing
description: The Greenwich Village intersection where two children were killed when hit by a truck last week will be patrolled daily from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. by either a police officer or a traffic enforcement agent, the offices of the city's Transportation Commissioner and the Manhattan Borough President announced yesterday.

title: Galletta Wins L.I. Golf In Playoff With Kudysch
description: Mal Galletta Jr., 39-year-old Glen Cove pro whose 70-year-old father still competes as an amateur, won his third Long Island open golf championship today.

title: DOMINION STORES LTD (CANADA) reports earnings for Yr to March 21
description: Year-ago period consists of 53 weeks The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: STROH BREWERY'S BID FOR SCHAEFER COMPLETED
description: The Stroh Brewery Company completed its acquisition of the F.& M. Schaefer Corporation today, converting the once publicly held New York beer company into a subsidiary of the privately held Stroh company.

title: General Foods Net Climbs by 21.6%
description: The General Foods Corporation said yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended March 28 rose 21.6 percent from the same period in 1980, while profits for the fiscal year were virtually unchanged.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES BILL PROVIDING 3 YEARS' PUBLIC-BROADCAST FUNDS
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee cleared for floor action today a bill that would provide three additional years of Federal aid for public broadcasting, but in declining amounts.

title: BESIDES SWISS GUARD, NEW FORCE NOW PROTECTS POPE
description: Only a week ago, Pope John Paul II reminded the Swiss Guards, arrayed before him in their Renaissance uniforms, that they had sworn to die, if necessary, in defense of the Holy See and its spiritual leader.

title: FRENCH MAGAZINE EDITOR OUSTED IN DISPUTE ON AN ELECTION COVER
description: Sir James Goldsmith, the British owner of L'Express, the weekly French news magazine, dismissed his managing editor today in a dispute over the cover of an issue five days before the presidential election that depicted the incumbent President in a fashion that the owner apparently regarded as an endorsement of the Socialist candidate, Francois Mitterrand. Mr. Mitterrand won the election last Sunday.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $2,905,000 foreign exchange loss...C-Includes $944,0 foreign exchange loss

title: GUESTS HELP RENOVATE A CAPE MAY HOTEL
BRESLER & REINER INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Prices on Bourse Rebound a Bit After Vote Shock
description: Stock prices today recovered some of the sharp losses they had suffered earlier in the week following the election of Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, as President.

title: YANKS RALLY LATE BUT FALL TO A'S, 5-4
description: The presence of their owner for the first time in nearly three weeks did not sufficiently inspire the Yankee hitters last night. After Matt Keough held them hitless for five innings, they awoke belatedly but lost to the Oakland A's, 5-4.

title: SOME OPTIMISM IS REPORTED IN COAL TALKS
description: Leaders on both sides expressed guarded optimism today about the negotiations to end the coal miners' contract strike, now in its 48th day.

title: Players Ask Injunction for Owners' Data
description: Chances for a settlement in baseball's compensation dispute before the players' May 29 strike deadline continue to be dim, but there is a possibility that a strike could be delayed even without an agreement between the players and the owners.

title: WALLACE DEPLORES ROME ATTACK
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, wounded by a gunman in an assassination attempt almost nine years ago, said today that the attack on Pope John Paul II ''is an attack on the entire world.'' Mr. Wallace added that it was ''tragic that a good man, a man of peace and love, would be subject to such a senseless attack.''

title: Business People; Bunker Chief Cites Merger's 'Opportunities'
description: Duane L. Burnham, 39, has been president and chief executive officer of the Bunker Ramo Corporation, which makes electronic components and fabrics and provides a stock quotation service, for just seven months. But this week he was one of the key participants in the agreement to sell his company to the Allied Corporation for $358 million in cash, notes and convertible preferred stock.

title: 1,000 WORKERS IN YONKERS TO GET $655 IN ARBITRATION
description: An arbitration panel today awarded $655 in fringe benefits to each of about 1,000 municipal workers in Yonkers who staged a two-day strike last month.

title: ISRAEL DERIDES SYRIAN PHOTOS
description: The Israeli military command today derided a Syrian contention that an Israeli plane was shot down yesterday by antiaircraft missiles.

title: 6 Indicted in Newark In Marijuana Case
description: NEWARK (AP) - Six men were indicted on charges that they imported and sold 12,000 pounds of marijuana with a street value that Federal authorities estimated at $6 million.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES LITTLE CHANGED
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as the credit markets remained extremely nervous and uncertain about the near-term direction of rates.

title: F.T.C. ENDS CAR MAKER INQUIRIES
description: The Federal Trade Commission today officially ended its five-year antitrust investigation of auto manufacturing in America, one of the nation's largest and most concentrated industries.

title: NEW GRADUATES AT BARNARD GET ADVICE ON ROLE
description: Ellen V. Futter, who was named president of Barnard College last week, presided at the college's 89th commencement yesterday. She told the graduating class that ''you must not let yourself be trapped into trying to become superwomen - to being all things to all people at one time.''

title: U.N. Environmental Talks Open
description: The 58 members of the United Nations Environment Program today began two weeks of talks on world environmental issues. The meeting is to cover such subjects as renewable energy sources, water pollution and the increase of toxic chemicals in food.

title: Home Beat; DESIGNERS' SUBJECT: GEOMETRY
description: MOST of all, they wanted to avoid ''a sea of lamps.'' So when Lella and Massimo Vignelli of Vignelli Associates were asked to design a to-the-trade showroom for Artemide, an Italian lamp and furniture manufacturer, at 150 East 58th Street, they grouped the lamps ''by family'' and separated them with fabric panels.

title: Bonn Approves Increase Of $373 Million in Arms
description: West Germany decided today to increase its military spending this year by an additional $373 million in a compromise agreement after months of controversy in the Cabinet.

title: Dutch Joblessness Up
description: Dutch unemployment rose to a postwar record of 353,400 in April from 340,700 in March, according to seasonally adjusted Government figures released today. In April 1980 the jobless figure was 222,200.

title: The Cost of Inflation Strikes Home
description: One consumer group calls it ''outrageous,'' another ''irresponsible.'' The object of this wrath is the Federal Government's decision to allow Federal savings and loan associations to write home mortgages whose interest rates are indexed to fluctuating market rates.

title: ABC Entertainment to Go To Los Angeles in July
description: ABC announced yesterday that its entertainment division would be moved from New York to Los Angeles in July, and that Anthony Thomopoulos, president of ABC Television, would take on added duties, including all business affairs and on-air promotion of entertainment programs.

title: TV COVERAGE CONSPICUOUSLY CAUTIOUS
description: Television's ''instant journalism,'' live coverage of a breaking news story, has become noticeably more cautious, but it still remains for its practitioners, in the words of CBS's Dan Rather, ''a very humbling experience.''

title: W. HERBERT ALLEN
description: W. Herbert Allen, former president and chairman of the board of the Title Insurance and Trust Company of Los Angeles and a southern California civic leader, died yesterday at Huntington Memorial Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: U.S. ANNOUNCES HAIG WILL GO TO CHINA IN LATE JUNE
description: The State Department said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. will visit Peking at the end of June. It would be the first high-level contact between the Reagan Administration and the Chinese leadership.

title: CHAMBER: HARMONIE ENSEMBLE PERFORMS ROSSINI AND MOZART
description: THE term ''harmonie'' refers in general to all music for wind instruments and more specifically to the chamber wind ensembles maintained by the Continental aristocracy from the mid-18th century to the early 19th century. More recently, New York's Harmonie Ensemble has borrowed the term, and on the basis of its delightful concert Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the group does honor to its predecessors.

title: POPE'S TOP AIDE A MASTER OF DIPLOMACY
description: The second-in-command to Pope John Paul II at the Vatican, Agostino Cardinal Casaroli, is a discreet 40-year veteran of the quiet diplomacy at the center of the Roman Catholic Church's power.

title: An Appraisal
description: It is not yet built, and a lot of things can happen between now and 1987, when it is due to be completed. But if Battery Park City is built according to the plans just announced by the State Urban Development Corporation and the developers Olympia & York, it will be the finest grouping of skyscrapers since Rockefeller Center.

title:
Notes on People;
Spurned Statue of 'Rocky' to Return to Coast
description: Stung by reports that Philadelphia's art commission was less than enthusiastic about his promised gift of a statue of himself in the role of the boxer ''Rocky,'' Sylvester Stallone has decided to take it back to California.

title: NATIONAL SILVER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SENATE PANEL SOFTENS BAN ON AID TO REBELS IN ANGOLA
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted overwhelmingly today to lift a legislative ban on assistance to pro-Western rebel forces in Angola, provided that future aid is tied to ''substantial progress'' toward resolving the conflict in neighboring South-West Africa.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: EAZOR EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.N. DISPUTE LOOMS ON INFANT FORMULA
description: A dispute over the sale of artificial milk to third-world countries is likely to break out next week when the United States casts what may be the sole vote against a code outlawing the promotion of infant formula.

title: SURGEONS TERM CONDITION; TURK, AN ESCAPED MURDERER, IS SEIZED 'GUARDED'; MADE THREAT IN '79
description: The first reports said only that he spoke no Italian, that he was young and that he had dark hair. But within a matter of minutes, a picture of the man accused of shooting Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square yesterday afternoon began to emerge, a picture of a militant Turkish terrorist, already convicted of one murder, who escaped from a maximum security prison in 1979 and then threatened in a letter to assassinate the Pope.

title: Bridge: Berkowitz Individual Victor In Cavendish Club Tourney
description: If all the New York experts were asked to select the best bidder or the best player from their own ranks, there would be many nominations and no clear-cut winner. But ask them to choose the most adaptable performer, and most of them would select David Berkowitz. He has won many titles with many different partners, but his adaptability credentials stem from the annual Cavendish Club individual tournament.

title: CONSUMER MAGAZINE FOR THE YOUNGER SET
description: TO the littlest consumers, buying power means penny power. And to help youngsters from ages 8 to 14 decide how best to budget their weekly allowance, which bicycle is right for them, or what afterschool snack is the most nutritious, Consumers Union is publishing Penny Power, the nation's only consumer magazine for children.

title: House Panel Approves Financing For Product Safety Commission
description: A House subcommittee today approved a bill providing money for the Consumer Product Safety Commission for the next three years and, on a separate vote of 10 to 10, defeated an attempt to make the agency a part of the Commerce Department.

title: Steel Dumped in Canada
description: Belgian and Spanish exports of brasscoated steel wire to Canada have caused material injury to the production in Canada of similar goods, the Canadian Anti-dumping Tribunal said today. Material injury to Canada's sole producer of such goods, National-Standard Ltd, is likely to continue unless offset by anti-dumping duties, it said. The Belgian company, Bekaert, is responsible for the shipments from both countries, it added.

title: THEATER ROW AT 3: JUBILATION AND ANXIETY
description: Theater Row took to the street yesterday to celebrate its third birthday, and notables from the entertainment world and government joined the party.

title: MEENAN OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed March 19, 1980 The 1981 9 months results and 1980 quarter and 9 months results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interest

title: CONNECTICUT ACTS TO QUIT TRISTATE PLANNING GROUP
description: Connecticut has begun pulling out of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, the much-criticized 20-yearold agency that has been the main clearinghouse for Federal grants to the New York metropolitan area.

title: Company News; Bonn's Oil Imports Down
description: West German crude oil imports fell by about 20 percent, to 150 million barrels, in the first quarter of this year compared with the same period a year ago, the Federal Statistics Office said today. However, West Germany's oil bill in the first three months rose by 15 percent, to $5.35 billion, as the average price of crude oil rose by 43 percent.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Abraham & Straus to Spiro & Associates, Philadelphia, for its Pennsylvania stores.

title: Union Oil Plans Sale Of Canadian Unit
description: The Union Oil Company of California said yesterday that it was offering to buy all the minority interest of its Canadian subsidiary, the Union Oil Company of Canada Ltd., for about $54 a share (United States), or $108 million cash.

title: SPECIAL SADNESS AFFECTING SMALL JERSEY COMMUNITY
description: A special sense of shock and sadness washed over this small suburb today as news that the Pope had been shot spread from house to house.

title: Thieves Take $100,000 in Gems
description: More than $100,000 in diamonds and gold was stolen from two jewelry concerns on Manhattan's West Side by thieves who gained access through an air-conditioning duct, the police said yesterday. The burglary occurred sometime Tuesday night, according to the police said. They said several cinder blocks in a large safe room, shared by Ultimar Creations and Alton Jewelry, of 25 West 36th Street, were knocked out and the jewels removed.

title: BOSTON CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A U.S.-BRITISH TORPEDO FIGHT
description: America's traditional dominance of a small but lucrative part of the world defense market - the manufacture of torpedoes for underwater warfare - has been challenged by a British electronics company that says it has developed a new generation of so-called intelligent torpedoes.

title: Hers
description: I'VE just returned from another phone conversation with a student this morning, another request for an ''incomplete'' grade for the semester. She was the sixth such casualty so far in the class headed for final exams tomorrow, another long-distance runner who expired before crossing the finish line.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are not available since the company became publicly owned in January 1980

title: Customs Official Denies Taking Gifts
description: NEWARK (AP) - A former New York regional commissioner of the Customs Service pleaded not guilty to Federal charges that he had accepted illegal gratuities.

title: NEW SURGERY REQUIRED
description: The medical information on the shooting of Pope John Paul II, although incomplete, showed that the most serious damage was done to the intestines.

title: I.T.T. EARNINGS OFF 50% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Earnings by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation tumbled 50.1 percent in the first quarter, the company disclosed at the annual meeting here today.

title: It Tolls For Thee
description: This is a column about two physicists, or more accurately about two human beings who happen to be physicists. They are from countries far apart in miles and in politics. They do not know each other. What they have in common, apart from their science, is their experience of that contemporary phenomenon: the terrorism of the state.

title: Senate Panel Cuts Funds For Commodity Support
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today cut about $1 billion from commodity support programs approved two weeks earlier, bringing its 1981 farm bill close to next year's spending targets.

title: Company News; Century Tender
description: Century Banks Inc., a Florida-based bank holding company, filed suit yesterday against Marvin L. Warner and companies he controls, seeking to thwart Mr. Warner's unsolicited tender offer for up to 1 million shares of Century's common stock, valued at $12.5 million. Through companies he controls, Mr. Warner's holdings in Century amount to 7 percent, or 470,530 shares, of the 6.5 million outstanding shares. Mr. Warner's tender offer for the additional shares expires June 5.

title: HAZLETON LABORTORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gas Found in Australia
description: Esperance Minerals said yesterday it had discovered a large natural gas deposit while drilling for oil shale at Nagoorin and Lowmead basins near Gladstone, Australia. However, drilling had to be abandoned for safety reasons. A blowout occurred during drilling, and natural gas has continued to flow unabated at rates over 500,000 cubic feet a day for over 39 days to date.

title: Reagan Aide Sees Interest-Rate Drop
description: A leading Reagan Administration economist predicted today that surging interest rates would peak within a month or two and then subside significantly in the summer.

title: COLUMBIA GRADUATES TOLD U.S. AID CUTS ARE GROSS ERROR
description: In his first commencement address since becoming Columbia University's 17th president last July, Michael I. Sovern sharply attacked the Reagan Administration yesterday for ''gross error'' in its proposed cuts in funds for basic research and student aid.

title: Sports of the Times; ISLANDERS NOT EMPTY-HANDED WHEN SHORT-HANDED
description: NEAR the end of the first period in Tuesday night's opener of the Stanley Cup final, the Islanders were leading the Minnesota North Stars, 3-0, after two short-handed goals. But now the Islanders had gone a few minutes without scoring and high on the steep slopes of the Nassau Coliseum a voice could be heard chanting.

title: Gold Bars Unearthed by Filipino
description: A bulldozer operator has unearthed gold objects valued at $3 million in a village in the southern Philippines, and thousands of treasure hunters have swarmed to the site, the military said today. One newspaper said the discovery was the treasure of gold bars, coins and jewels reputedly buried by Gen. Tomoyuki Yamashita of Japan as he was retreating from United States and Filipino forces in World War II.

title: Company News; BL INC. ANNOUNCES IT WILL STOP MAKING TR7, TR8 TRIUMPHS
description: Production of Triumph TR7 and TR8 roadsters, the last of the British sports cars that captured the imagination of American road racing enthusiasts in the 1950's and 1960's, is ending, BL Ltd., the company that owns Triumph, announced today.

title: CADENCE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Net income after $205,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: NLT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
DOW DECLINES BY 3.06 AFTER A DAY OF SWINGS
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in an initial reaction to the shooting of Pope John Paul II and then recovered, only to decline again in late trading. Market analysts linked the late setback to weakness in leading energy issues and other blue chips.

title: IN ULSTER, REMINDERS OF OLD ENMITY TOWARD DUBLIN
description: In the spring of 1916, in the weeks after the pivotal Easter Monday rebellion in Dublin, the British Army court-martialed and executed 15 of the leading rebels, including Patrick Pearse and James Connolly. Almost immediately, Irish public opinion shifted sharply against Britain, and what had been a fringe radical movement became an unbeatable popular revolution, with independence following a few years later. In his poem ''Easter 1916,'' Yeats describes that shift in the national mood this way:

description: B-After $152,360 loss from discontinued operations

title: Salvador Appoints Judge In Slain Missionaries' Case
description: A judge has been appointed to the court that will hear charges against six soldiers accused of the murders of three American nuns and a Roman Catholic lay worker, officials said today.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUSE PANEL REBUFFS REAGAN AND BACKS KEEPING LEGAL AID FOR POOR
description: The House Judiciary Committee, by a 22-to-6 vote today, rejected the Reagan Administration's plan to eliminate Federal financing of legal aid for poor people.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company is offering $100 million principal amount of first-mortgage bonds due 1991 at a price of 99 3/8 percent, yielding 16.122 percent, to be sold through a Morgan Stanley & Company group.

title: Company News; Bethlehem Offers New Steel Product
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that it had introduced a lightweight, high-strength sheet steel product with an alloy coating of aluminum and zinc for use in light construction.

title: ATLAS VAN LINES INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWPORT, R.I., IS TAKING A CLOSER LOOK AT GROWTH
description: The time has come, this city says, to speak of other things: of slowing down and staying small - not but not of fast-food buildings Since the urban reawakening of the 1970's first touched this community on an island in Narragansett Bay about eight years ago, the talk has been of boom and expansion, of growth and rising property values, of hotels and restaurants and boutiques and condominiums.

title: Pro Football Notebook Jets, McNeil Hinted Close to Agreement
description: The Jets and Freeman McNeil, their No. 1 draft choice who has decided not to attend the club's voluntary rookie minicamp, may agree to terms next week, McNeil's agent indicated yesterday.

title: EAGLE LEGALS
description: There is an elite group of Washington lawyers whose control over the defense budget is very large and largely unknown. You won't find their firms' names buried in the budget, and they probably won't surface in armed service committee hearings on Capitol Hill. They certainly won't contribute to either a strong military or better ''hardware.'' But the 200 or so Government-contracts attorneys who make their living suing the Pentagon end up costing the taxpayers millions of dollars that are thought to be going for armaments. Taken together, they are one of the great hidden costs in our expanding defense budget, and one of the few sure winners in the coming arms buildup.

title: Gardening; ALTERNATIVES TO IVY: GROUND-COVER PLANTS
description: PACHYSANDRA, myrtle and ivy are workhorses for gardeners. Ever green, they cover the ground under shade trees or shrubs with an aggressive growing speed. Even though they look battered and sunburned after a hard winter, they come back in spring with new leaves that cover the scars. Later on, pachysandra dresses up with creamy flowers and myrtle follows with pretty blue petals.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PLANNING A CRAFTY VACATION: SUMMER ARTS WORKSHOPS FOR ADULTS
description: FOR crafts enthusiasts, one way to spend a vacation is to stay at one of a number of colleges and other educational institutions around the country that offer summer workshops in various crafts.

title: Pessimism on Auto Recovery
description: The nation's economic problems could delay recovery of the auto industry for several years beyond the 1985 target date, Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis told a House panel today.

title: EVICTING FURRY INTRUDERS FROM THE HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arlene Fischer is a freelance writer. By ARLENE FISCHER

title: BENEFICIAL STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boston's Mayor Refuses Deal Yielding Power of Post
description: Mayor Kevin H. White, vowing not to turn Boston over to the City Council, has said he would rather see the city go bankrupt than accept a financial aid plan that would entail turning some of his power over to the panel.

title: U.S. ENVOY IN BEIRUT WITH A PEACE PLAN
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, returned here today from Jerusalem carrying a compromise proposal for easing the crisis over the Syrian deployment of missiles in Lebanon and Israel's insistence that they be removed.

title: Reservoirs in Jersey At 85.7% of Capacity
description: The heavy rains of Monday and Tuesday have filled major reservoirs in northern New Jersey to 85.7 percent of capacity, and state water management officials have scheduled a meeting Monday to study the possibility of lifting mandatory rationing still in effect in 94 communities. The New York City reservoirs were reported at 77.2 percent of capacity.

title: Notes On people; GARTH ADVISING BEGIN
description: With the Koch re-election campaign apparently running on a smooth track, David Garth, the Mayor's media specialist, is spending a week in Israel advising Prime Minister Menachem Begin's campaign strategists, but not on a contractual basis.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 14, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan is prepared to compromise on the size of his tax cut because of the unsettled financial markets, a senior White House official said. However, the President, who proposed a three-year, 10 percent-a-year reduction in tax rates, would not give way on the concept of a multiple-year break, the official said. He labeled the alternative proposed by Representative Daniel D. Rostenkowski for a one-year, $28 billion cut unacceptable. (Page D1.)

title: THE PRIMAL URGE TO EMBELLISH
description: ONE of the most basic human instincts is the need to decorate. Nothing is exempt - the body, the objects one uses, from intimate to monumental, and all personal and ceremonial space. It is an instinct that responds to the eye, for pure pleasure; to the rules of society, for signals of fitness and status, and to some deep inner urge that has been variously described as the horror of a vacuum and the need to put one's imprint on at least one small segment of the world.

title: STRIPPING FURNITURE THAT'S UPHOLSTERED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: FRENCH CABINET QUITS, CREATING VACUUM
description: The French Government resigned today. It was a formal step but an unusual one, and it emphasized a vacuum in France's untested transition procedure.

title: EMPIRE OF CAROLINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Overdoses of Cancer Drug Blamed as 2 Die in Memphis
description: Overdoses of anticancer medication were blamed today for the deaths of two young patients at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, largest childhood cancer research center in the world.

title: CONNECTICUT LEGISLATURE REACHES ACCORD ON A $2.79 BILLION BUDGET
description: Connecticut's House and Senate agreed tonight on a $2.79 billion budget for the next fiscal year after weeks of haggling on a revenue package.

title: Pope Discussed Regret At Need to Be Guarded
description: In his frequent pleas for peace in the world and respect for human rights, Pope John Paul II spoke out against terrorism and violence. One such occasion was his essay, ''I, the Pope: My Thought, My Service,'' which was published in the newspaper Corriere della Sera of Milan on April 13, 1979.

title: U.S. Asks Court to Nullify Order To Release Secrets on Tax Audits
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal appeals court today to withdraw its order requiring the Internal Revenue Service to release by tomorrow secret computer tapes detailing how tax returns are selected for audit.

title: Lietzke: A Golfer and His Private World
description: Bruce Lietzke, whose hobby is caring for his high-performance racing car, likes being different from the other touring golf pros who travel on commercial airliners and drive more conventional autos. ''My car just doesn't fit their jet-set image,'' he says.

title: SURGEONS TERM CONDIION; TURK, AN ESCAPED MURDERER, IS SEIZED 'GUARDED'; 2 BULLETS HIT PONTIFF
description: Pope John Paul II was shot and seriously wounded yesterday as he was standing in an open car moving slowly among more than 10,000 worshipers in St. Peter's Square.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday on Social Security changes proposed by the Reagan Administration incorrectly stated one provision. For people who continue to work after age 65, benefits are reduced by $1 for each $2 earned above the earnings ceiling. The ceiling would be raised to $10,000 a year in 1982 and to $15,000 in 1983, and would then be removed entirely.

title: TIME TO FIRE UP COAL CONVERSIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Spanish General Shot, Apparently a Suicide
description: A general involved in legislation designed to force Spanish officers to retire at an earlier age than usual died today when his gun went off in his office at army headquarters in central Madrid.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,889 for the quarter and $1,793,000 for the 6 months...C-Net income after losses on disposal of discontinued operations of $250,000 for the quarter and $293,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary credits of $110,000 for the quarter and $250,000 for the 6 mont

title: REAGAN TAX TESTIMONY DRAWS SKEPTICISM
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan went before the Senate Finance Committee today to build support for President Reagan's three-year tax relief bill and ran into a hail of skeptical questions from Republicans as well as Democrats.

title: Phone Rate Increases Suspended
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a surprise move late today, temporarily blocked a 16 percent increase in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's interstate longdistance phone rates and a 35 percent reduction in international rates. The changes were to have been effective tomorrow.

title: AVANT-GARDE: LIZ PHILLIPS SOUND
description: ENVIRONMENTAL sound installations are not a musical form with which the average concertgoer is very familiar. The aural equivalent of a visual-arts earthwork or a Christo wrapping, such pieces consist of electronically generated sounds that in some way interact with the environment - either passively, when an unchanging sound or pattern of sounds is heard mixed in with everyday life, or actively, if the system is continuously modified by the environment itself.

title: Notes On People; Can We See the Next Chimp, Please?
description: During the 50 years the Cincinnati Opera operated in an open-air pavilion at the city zoo (earning the affectionate sobriquet ''the Cincinnati Zoo Opera'') not once, apparently, did it occur to directors of ''Aida'' to use zoo animals for the opera's ''Triumphal March.'' This may have been because the libretto does not mention animals.

title: LEASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Leasco, formerly a subsidiary of Reliance Group, was spunoff in 1979

title: NORRIS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CALIFORNIA HOSPITAL ORDERED TO CLOSE
description: A hospital in rural Riverside County, where 25 elderly patients died mysteriously in March and April, was closed today after California state health officials suspended its operating license.

title: DANCE: MISS VAN HAMEL AS NIKIYA IN 'BAYADERE'
description: NATALIA MAKAROVA'S staging of ''La Bayadere,'' which the American Ballet Theater offered for the first time this season Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is one of the most historically instructive items in the repertory, for it exemplifies 19th-century notions of ballet as visual spectacle.

title: PERSONAL PRIVACYIN A SOCIAL WELFARE AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: INVENTORIES UP BY 0.2% IN MARCH
description: Inventory stockpiles kept by American businesses grew a mere two-tenths of 1 percent in March, remaining close to the relatively low levels they have held for months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Researchers Find Heavy Drinking Increases Risk of Mouth Cancer
description: Heavy drinkers of whisky, beer and wine may run a greater risk of mouth cancer than people who smoke two packs of cigarettes a day, the American Cancer Society Journal reported yesterday.

title: AMID PRAYERS, WORLD VOICES ITS INDIGNATION
description: Prayers, shock and indignation resounded around the world yesterday after the shooting of Pope John Paul II. President Reagan, recovering from wounds inflicted six weeks ago by a gunman, said he would pray for the Pope. In a message Mr. Reagan said, ''All Americans join me in hopes and prayers for your speedy recovery.''

title: IN A BLIGHTED GUATEMALA VILLAGE, INDIANS PRESERVE A PRIZED CRAFT
description: The Indian mother rocked her wailing infant in her arms and looked imploringly at the priest. The child's eyes pinched into slits as his feverish body trembled.

title: Protect Orphans First
description: There is no more vulnerable group of Americans than the halfmillion homeless children who live in state-run foster care programs. As things now work, few of them will ever be adopted into stable homes. Most will shuttle in and out of foster care institutions until they mature.

title: AMCOLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock

title: RADIO UNIT 'PROPERLY LICENSED'
description: The Omega radio navigation system seized by the United States Customs Service Tuesday night aboard a Soviet airliner was described by the manufacturer as standard commercial equipment used for many years by major airlines of the world, including Aeroflot.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF MOVES CLOSER TO PUBLIC SUPPORT OF KOCH
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Brooklyn Republican chairman and the key to a G.O.P. endorsement of Mayor Koch, moved closer to open support of the Mayor last night as he met with the executive committee of the Brooklyn Republican organization.

title: Spanish Rail Loan Signed
description: The Bank of Montreal said today it had signed an agreement in London for a $175 million (Canadian) loan to Spain's national railway company, Red Nacional de los Ferrocarriles Espanoles. The bank said the nine-year loan carried interest of 3/8 point above the Canadian prime rate for the first four years and 1/2 point above thereafter.

title: Sports News Briefs; Illinois Says Conference May Relax Stiff Penalties
description: Officials at the University of Illinois, encouraged by a two-month delay of Big Ten sanctions against the school's athletic teams, say the conference may eventually relax its stiff penalties.

title: 30 Parents Protest Over New Principal
description: More than 30 parents picketed and staged a peaceful sit-in at Public School 11 in Woodside, Queens, to protest the appointment of a principal who they said did not meet their approval.

title: Part-Time vs. Full-Time
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: It is disheartening that the Louis Harris study of women as wage earners revealed that 51 percent of women in professional, managerial or executive positions chose part-time work, with only 10 percent content with their full-time responsibilities. (''Conflicts of Women With Jobs,'' May 7.)

title: RAVITCH WARNS OF A $1 FARE WITHOUT RISE IN TRANSIT AID
description: Richard Ravitch, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the New York City Transit Authority faced a deficit of $383 million - more than double his previous assessment - and a $1 fare in the next fiscal year unless the State Legislature acted immediately to increase the state operating subsidy.

title: SINCE HIS ELECTION IN 1978, THE POLISH POPE HAS WON AFFECTION
description: THROUGHOUT THE WORLD By M. A. FARBER

title: Girl, 8, Tells Carolina Jury Garwood Tried to Rape Her
description: An 8-year-old girl whose parents had befriended Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marines testified today in Superior Court that the convicted collaborator molested and tried to rape her after taking her for an ice cream cone in his automobile.

title: Market Place; Brighter Outlook at Anta
description: FOUR SEASONS NURSING was one of the most popular companies in the bull market of the late 1960's. Institutions owned the shares by the tens of thousands, and the share price seemed to know no limits.

title: Company News; Paper Makers In Talks on Linkup
description: The Fort Howard Paper Company and the Maryland Cup Corporation said jointly that the two manufacturers of disposable paper products were holding ''preliminary discussions looking toward a possible combination.''

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP 7.2% IN EARLY MAY
description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that domestic car sales had risen only 7.2 percent in the first 10 days of May from the comparable period last year, when auto sales were deeply depressed by last spring's recession.

title: U.S. and Iran to Discuss Claims
description: United States and Iranian representatives will meet in the Hague Monday to discuss setting up a tribunal to settle billions of dollars in claims from the hostage crisis, the United States Embassy announced today. It said three representatives will be present from each side. The 52 American hostages were freed Jan. 20 after 444 days in captivity in Iran.

title: Switch Problems Delay Trains Up to 90 Minutes
description: Switch trouble in Pennsylvania Station resulted in extensive delays on all incoming and outgoing trains last night, forcing thousands of passengers to wait up to 90 minutes for their trains.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house has hand-split cedar shingles that were once coated with an asphalt-base paint. I had them sandblasted to get this old coating off, and they are now down to the bare wood. I was advised that the bare shingles should now be waterproofed. What can I use that will still retain the original color? - P.K.K., Woodmere, N.Y.

title: Stockman Seeks a Rise In His Agency's Budget
description: David A. Stockman, the Federal budget director, spent several hours today trying to explain to Congress why his own agency would need more money and manpower next year.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE WILL PRAY FOR THE POPE
description: President Reagan, still recovering from wounds inflicted by an assassin six weeks ago, was informed immediately of the shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: FOR NEW YORK, TEARFUL MEMORIES
description: In the rectory basement at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Harlem, the women in the Senior Citizens Group wept quietly over the crepe paper banner they were making for a dance and recalled how the Pope leapt from his car to kiss the ground in front of their church.

title: Idaho Opens Its Challenge Over Rights Amendment
description: Congress overstepped its authority by extending a 1978 deadline for ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Federal Constitution, Idaho's Attorney General told a Federal judge today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''How could they do it?'' - Pope John Paul II. (A1:6.)

title: MORGAN TO SELL BIG SHARE IN BRITISH MERCHANT BANK
description: In a move more of historic than market significance, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company confirmed yesterday that it was planning to sell most of its holdings in the British merchant banking organization of Morgan Grenfell Holdings Ltd.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $76,718 tax credit

title: PLANS DISCLOSED FOR OFFICE CORE AT BATTERY PARK CITY
description: Planners of Battery Park City's long-delayed commercial complex yesterday disclosed designs for office buildings, plazas, restaurants, gardens and even an ice skating rink, all to rise from a landfill site in lower Manhattan.

title: BUFFALO WOMAN ON TOUR ALSO WOUNDED
description: Ann C. Odre, a 58-year-old retired beautician from Buffalo, was leaning against a barricade and waving an American flag that was the rallying banner of her tour group when she was critically wounded in yesterday's attack on Pope John Paul II.

title: FIRST THE PRESIDENT, THEN THE POPE: AMERICANS FEEL NUMB ON HEARING
description: THE NEWS By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

title: FOUND: A LONG-LOST FAULKNER MS.
description: SOME of William Faulkner's more revealing letters are turning up in the Berg Collection at the New York Public Library, rather than in the literary repositories of Southern universities. This has puzzled some scholars. But the main reason why certain of the Nobel laureate's letters are in New York rather than in Mississippi or Virginia is that the Berg, by a combination of luck and speed, acquired the manuscript of his first novel, ''Soldier's Pay.''

title: Ruling Upsets Timetable For Harvester Debt Plan
description: The First National Bank of Commerce of New Orleans today won a motion for summary judgment for $3.5 million against the International Harvester Corportion. The judgment, which Harvester said it would appeal, upset Harvester's plan to complete its $4.9 billion debt restructuring plan by May 15.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Canada said it would spend $156 million (Canadian) to acquire replacement jet engines from the General Electric Co.

title: TASSASINS' DESERTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; IS THE THEATER ALL A JUGGLING ACT?
description: TOSSING a tennis ball up and down in one hand, Michael Davis says, ''It's not what you do, but how you do it.'' Mr. Davis is joking, but he is also clearly a man of style. He is an inspired juggler-comic - a distinguished hyphenate once worn by W.C. Fields. Mr. Davis survived the wreckage of the short-lived ''Broadway Follies'' and has gone on to assume a featured role in ''Sugar Babies.'' How is the newcomer faring in his second Broadway show of the season? A deadpan comedian in broad, burlesque surroundings, he is next to last on the bill, a choice spot, the vaudeville equivalent of batting third in a baseball lineup. He has 13 solo minutes in the spotlight, time to offer a distillation of the Davis art.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carson Pirie Scott & Company, Chicago, has elected Carroll E. Ebert, president, to the additional post of chairman, succeeding Harold R. Spurway, who is retiring. Robert P. Bryant, president of Dobbs Houses Inc., will become vice chairman, a new position.

title: LEADERS AROUND THE WORLD VOICE SHOCK AND ANGER
description: World and church leaders expressed shock and indignation today at the news of the shooting of Pope John Paul II in Rome.

title: BEAUPRE IN GOAL AS STARS REGROUP
description: Don Beaupre, a short, slender 19-year-old rookie who looks as if he weighs less than his protective padding, will be the starting goalie for the Minnesota North Stars tomorrow night in the second game of the Stanley Cup final against the Islanders.

title: COUNTRY MUSICIANS RIDE 'HEARTWORN HIGHWAY'
description: ''HEARTWORN HIGHWAY,'' which opened yesterday at the Art Cinema, isn't exactly a concert film and it isn't exactly a documentary. It's more like a series of impressions and a parade of visits. During each of its various stops, the camera hunkers down to observe songs, conversation and atmosphere. The last, as seen by the film's director, James Szalapski, can be anything from levers on the mixing board of a recording studio to glimpses of cattle in the snow.

title: IN POLAND, PRAYERS FOR A NATIONAL HERO
description: Hundreds of thousands of Poles attended special masses or prayed on street corners tonight for the recovery of Pope John Paul II.

title: Aircal Sale Set To Two Developers
description: A Federal judge has approved the sale of Aircal, a California commuter airline, to two real estate developers, William Lyon and George Argyros, for $61.5 million in cash, a bid that topped a competing offer from Air Florida Systems Inc.

title: Pope Is Shot in Car in Vatican Square; Surgeons Term Condition Serious
description: ROME, Thursday, May 14  Pope John Paul II was shot and seriously wounded yesterday as he was standing in an open car moving slowly among more than 10,000 worshipers in St. Peter's Square.

title: U.S. SEIZES DEVICES IN SOVIET JETLINER'S CARGO
description: Federal law-enforcement agents detained a Soviet airplane at Dulles International Airport here last night and seized several items of its cargo on suspicion of a possible violation of export-control laws. It was later determined that radio navigation equipment seized by the agents had been properly licensed for export.

title: Notes On People; Pacino Makes a Winning Choice: Off Broadway
description: He had the choice of Chicago, London, Spoleto or Off Broadway for his revival of ''American Buffalo,'' and Al Pacino apparently made the right choice. According to production officials, the play, which begins previews at the Circle in the Square on Bleecker Street on May 22, has racked up a record advance sale Off Broadway.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION, TEARS, PRAYERS AND CALLS FOR GUN CONTROL
description: Residents of the New York metropolitan area and their religious and political leaders responded to the shooting of Pope John Paul II in Rome yesterday with tears and outrage, expressions of incredulity and prayers for the Pontiff's recovery.

title: Maxwell Emerges as Celtics' Top Candidate for M.V.P. Award
description: Puffing on a big cigar, Red Auerbach, president and general manager of the Boston Celtics, talked today about the first time he saw Cedric Maxwell play.

title: BLACK YOUTH'S DEATH LINKED TO OTHER ATLANTA KILLINGS
description: The number of cases being investigated by the special police group on missing and murdered children here rose to 28 today with the addition of a homocide involving a 17-year-old black youth whose body was found early yesterday.

title: Sammy Byrd, Played For Yanks and Reds, Then Starred in Golf
description: Samuel Dewey Byrd, an outfielder who played six years for the Yankees and later became a professional golfer, died Monday at Mesa, Ariz. He was 74 years old.

title: KANSAS-NEB NATIONAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid July 25, 1980

title: INDIANS WIN IN 16 ON ORTA CLOUT
description: Jorge Orta led off the top of the 16th inning with a homer to right field to lift the Cleveland Indians to a 4-3 victory tonight over the Chicago White Sox.

title: AIDE HINTS AT REAGAN TAX SHIFT
description: President Reagan, concerned by the unsettled condition of the financial markets, is prepared to accept less than the full amount of his proposed tax cut but wants the Democrats in Congress to make the first move toward compromise, a senior White House official said today.

title: Republic Steel Plans Caster
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest steel company, plans to build a continuous slab caster at its plant in Cleveland at the cost of about $100 million, William J. De Lancey, chairman and chief executive, said yesterday at the company's annual meeting.

title: Nuclear Executives in Japan Resign Over Recent Mishaps
description: The chairman and the president of the Japan Atomic Power Company resigned today in the wake of a series of leakages of radiocative material from the Tsuruga nuclear power station, one of which was not disclosed for nearly a month.

title: STAGEHAND TESTIFIES CRIMMINS DRANK 2 DOZEN BEERS ON DAY OF MURDER
description: A defense witness testified yesterday in State Supreme Court that Craig S. Crimmins, a former stagehand, was ''pretty drunk'' when he reported for the evening performance of the Berlin Ballet on the night the violinist Helen Hagnes was slain at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Music Project Benefit
description: The Music Project, a New York-based chamber ensemble, will appear in a benefit for itself Sunday at 8 P.M. in the concert hall of the Abraham Goodman House. The guest artists will include two performers from the ''The Pirates of Penzance.'' Linda Ronstadt will sing music by Villa-Lobos and Faure, and Rex Smith will perform four of the ''Songs of Travel'' by Vaughan Williams.

title: Advertising; Co-op Ads' New Look At Doner
description: WHEN a newspaper ad for a supermarket is full of individual nationally branded items, that's cooperative advertising. When a television commercial by a perfume manufacturer ends up with a fivesecond message giving the name of a store at which it is available, that's a co-op ad, too.

title: ON U.S. TRIP, POPE'S EXPOSURE CAUSED POLICE JITTERS
description: On the night of Oct. 2, 1979, as Pope John Paul II was paraded in triumph from the right-field bullpen at Yankee Stadium, elevated in clear sight of 80,000 people, the latest of two dozen threats on his life that day was being received by the largest security operation in New York history.

title: CONFLICTING ACCOUNTS BY SUSPECT ARE ALLEGED IN FIRE THAT KILLED 26
description: The 25-year-old man charged with arson and murder in connection with last winter's fire at Stouffer's Inn told investigators conflicting stories about his actions in and his departure from the hotel's conference center at the time of the fire, according to papers filed today in Westchester County Court.

title: Company News; Xerox Introduces Two Telecopiers
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced two new high-speed facsimile machines that it said could transmit an average single-page letter anywhere in the world in one minute or less.
