title: GYPSY MOTH STARTS AHEAD OF SCHEDULE
description: THE gypsy moth has begun its onslaught about two weeks ahead of schedule. Unusually warm periods of spring weather have made the eggs hatch, and tiny caterpillars can be seen on tree trunks as well as on buildings, fences, outdoor furniture and people working in gardens.

title: Syrians Publish Photos of Plane
description: Al Baath, the newspaper of the ruling Baath Party, and Tishrin, a Government paper, published photographs today of what was said to be an Israeli reconnaissance plane shot down yesterday in Lebanon. Israel has denied that any plane was lost.

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A.Buel Trowbridge, Professor At American University, Is Dead
description: A. Buel Trowbridge, professor emeritus at American University who was the author of several books, died here yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital after a stroke. He was 82 years old.

title: NEGLIGENTLY UNMASKING AGENTS WOULD BE CRIME UNDER U.S. PLAN
description: The Justice Department has told Congress that its preferred wording of a bill to make it a crime to publish the names of covert Government intelligence agents would cover cases of ''negligence'' by journalists.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ROOSEVELT I. PREMIERE
description: ''The Tower'' - a musical theater piece by the Pulitzer prizewinning composer Michael Colgrass - will be given its American premiere on Roosevelt Island tonight at 8 by 20 schoolchildren. Roosevelt Island? Schoolchildren? Yes. The musical, a modern, urban version of ''Jack and the Beanstalk,'' was written to be performed by children. Nancy Breth, a pianist who lives on the island, planned and raised funds for the community event. The Canadian composer auditioned and helped in rehearsals. Various professional people, including Diana Baffa Brill, a choreographer who is directing the work, donated their time. The site is the Chapel of the Good Shepherd on Main Street. Tickets are $4 ($2 for children, the elderly and the handicapped). Information: 753-6889 or 371-4642. UKRAINIAN 7TH ST. FESTIVAL

title: 'A SECOND CHANCE' WITH CATHERINE DENEUVE
description: Claude Lelouch's ''A Second Chance'' casts Catherine Deneuve as a murderer who has just spent 16 years in jail. Granted, there are other roles in which Miss Deneuve would be no less believable; as a salty old fisherman or a traffic cop she would undoubtedly be just as out of place. And granted, this is only one of Mr. Lelouch's feats of unnecessary daring in the film. He fractures the narrative. He disrupts scenes by zooming back and forth like a honeybee. He even sabotages his own drama at every turn. If this isn't daring, what can it be?

title: Business People; CHAIRMAN TO RETIRE FROM BURLINGTON
description: Louis W. Menk, the former railroad telegrapher and 45-year railroad veteran who has been chairman since 1971 of Burlington Northern Inc., the railroad and natural resources company, said yesterday that he would retire at the end of the year.

title: HISTORIAN SORTS OUT FACT IN DATA ON VIETNAM WAR
description: The puzzle of the Vietnam War may never really end for those like Vincent H. Demma who have been hired to have the final word. He is one of eight historians now on a long-term mission to write a 20-volume history of the war for the Army. He is a historian who is particularly mindful of the profession's rule that victory is always far easier to describe and document than defeat.

title: Persico Surrenders to Marshals In Federal Parole Violation Case
description: Carmine Persico Jr. surrendered to United States marshals yesterday on charges of violating his parole from a Federal prison by allegedly associating with reputed members of organized crime, authorities said.

title: Music Noted in Brief; The Philomusica Offers An All-Schumann Concert
description: By rights, the New York Philomusica's Schumann concert at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night should have been an occasion for much rewarding listening. This seasoned emsemble is made up of of some of the leading freelance musicians in New York, and they were applying themselves to works of consequence - the Piano Trio No. 1 in D minor, the Adagio and Allegro for Horn and Piano and the Piano Quintet in E flat.

title: PRICE CUTS SPREADING FOR U.S. OIL
description: The United States petroleum industry is fast reaching a consensus that crude oil is too expensive, and a dozen oil companies have reduced the price they will pay for a barrel of domestically produced oil by an average of $2 a barrel.

title: BARBARO WILL OPPOSE KOCH IN PRIMARY
description: Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro said yesterd that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City.

title: ZAIRE DIAMOND SALES PLAN
description: Antwerp,Belgium, May 14(Reuter)-Zaire has ended its exclusive diamond sales contract with De BEers Consolidated Mines Ltd's Central Selling Organization, a dealer, David Susskind, said today. Mr. Susskind told Reuter that Caddi and Giasol N.V. both based in Antwerp, and the International Diamond Company of London would market Zaire diamonds, worth $100 million a year, beginning the end of May. Under the new deal,the participating companies will receive guarantee monthly diamond shipments, from Zaire, Mr. Susskind, managing director of Caddi, said.

title: Music Noted in Brief; John Covelli of Michigan Leads Training Orchestra
description: The National Orchestral Association's function as a training orchestra is presumably a valuable one. But its concerts have to stand or fall in competition with the rest of New York's busy musical life.

title: NEW IDRIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including income of $25,000 for the quarter and $74,000 for the 9 months from the cumulative effect of changing to a differ depreciation method, $562,000 loss for the 9 months from discontinued operations and $183,000 gain for the 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: News Analysis
description: Ruling on an issue of great interest to prosecutors, civil libertarians and the police, New York State's highest court has unanimously approved the use of hidden television cameras in criminal investigations, even though such surveillance is not specifically allowed by any state law.

title: BALLET THEATER: 'LA BAYADERE'
description: PASSION and drama were the keynotes of the strongly projected performances by Natalia Makarova, Patrick Bissell and, in a local debut, Magali Messac, when this new cast stepped in to lead ''La Bayadere'' Tuesday night for American Ballet Theater.

title: In Park This Weekend
description: Central Park will provide the setting for a minirun tomorrow and the annual United Cerebral Palsy Bike-a-Thon on Sunday. Novice runners can complete two, four or six miles on the ''Run for Fun,'' tomorrow, sponsored by Citibank and the New York Road Runners Club.

title: Notes on People; Pele Acclaimed
description: The award to Edson Arantes do Nascimento seems a bit premature, but Pele, as he is better known, plans to stop in Paris today to pick it up anyway.

title: A FRESH APPROACH TO THE DESEGREGATION HURDLE
description: To the Editor:

title: DOME MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS Names Directors
description: Walter Cronkite, the television news broadcaster, and Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense in the Carter Administration, were appointed directors of the board of CBS Inc. yesterday. It is the second directorship for Mr. Cronkite, 65 years old, who was named to the board of Pan American World Airways shortly after retiring from his evening news programs last March.

title: METHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $71,000 for the quarter and $201,000 for the 9 months...C-including $17,000 gain for the quarter and $15,0000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations

title: Six Wise Strings for El Salvador
description: Henry Kissinger once remarked that the cardinal test of any foreign policy is its ability to muster domestic support. By that standard, the Reagan Administration's policy in El Salvador remains on shaky ground. Doubts are hardly limited to scruffy students brandishing antiwar placards, or to Catholic activists concerned about official violence that an American-backed junta seems unable to control. They now extend to a portent less readily shrugged off - the Republican-run Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: A TROUBLED SHIP HAUNTS S. I. BERTH
description: The cargo freighter Atra is a troubled ship. Her hold is full of unsold scrap metal, her fuel tanks and food lockers are almost empty and her bridge is plastered with liens from creditors, including her crew, which has not been paid since March.

title: GENERAL AMERICAN OIL CO OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mrs. Truman Making Progress; Condition Is Still Called Serious
description: Bess Truman, still in serious condition after hip surgery, was making progress today in her battle against pneumonia, her doctor said.

title: STAGE: 'RUNNING IN PLACE,' A CONSCIOUSNESS RAISER
description: BARBARA SCHOTTENFELD'S ''I Can't Keep Running in Place,'' a musical dealing with a women's consciousness-raising encounter group, has some isolated bright spots, but it never gets its act together. With book, lyrics and score by Miss Schottenfeld and direction by Susan Einhorn, the show opened last night at the Westside Arts Theater after a tryout last year at La Mama.

title: DOW CLOSES UP 5.31 AFTER A LATE RALLY
description: A late rally by energy issues and other blue chips sent the market ahead yesterday, while utility and transportation stocks extended their recent advance.

title: Pop Jazz; ELLINGTONIANS SALUTE SWING ERA CLARINETS
description: THE clarinet, which was a major instrument in the swing bands of the 1930's and 40's, has virtually disappeared from jazz. The instrument has had no place in the new big bands that have appeared since then. Even in Woody Herman's band, one of the few to survive the Swing Era and in which the leader himself once played clarinet, Mr. Herman now does most of his playing on alto or soprano saxophone.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis May 7 on the Inter- national Brotherhood of Teamsters in- correctly characterized the state of health of Jackie Presser, a vice presi- dent of the union. Mr. Presser is in good health.

title: FILE OF TURKISH POLICE ON SHOOTING SUSPECT
description: Following is the security force file on Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of trying to assassinate Pope John Paul II, that was made public here today. The document, in French, English, Spanish and Arabic, was sent to Interpol earlier this year.

title: WHY SHOULD ARMS AID TO PAKISTAN RAISE THE SPECTER OF AN AGGRESSOR?
description: To the Editor:

title: TOOTSIE ROLL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
PENINSULA RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Japan Car Exports Up
description: Despite a Japanese Government pledge to hold auto shipments significantly below the previous year's level, exports to the United States are reported to have risen 6.9 percent in April from a year earlier. Japan's Kyodo news service quoted industry sources as saying exports to the United States last month totaled 169,881 vehicles. At the beginning of May, Japan agreed to hold down auto exports to the United States for three years, effective April 1.

title: LANCASTER IN A COMIC WESTERN
description: The time is the late 19th century, and the Western frontier is disappearing, as it's been doing with increasing frequency in western movies in recent decades. Civilization is catching up with the good old bad guys. There's less and less room in which they can lead their disordered lives as free spirits, exemplifying the kind of heedless, winner-take-all capitalism that, with hindsight, movie makers find so romantic.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Defends Dropping
description: Of Anti-Smoking Ads

title: Company News; G.E. Joins Chloride In Battery Research
description: The General Electric Company said that it had reached a five-year agreement with Chloride Silent Power Ltd. of Britain for joint research and development of a battery for utility energy storage and to power vehicles.

title: THE CITY; Judge Throws Out Youths' Confessions
description: A State Supreme Court justice threw out the confessions of two Brooklyn youths who the police say admitted killing a Queens teenager on his way home from a high school prom in March, United Press International reported.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Adage Inc. said it planned a public offering of 500,000 common shares, of which 400,000 would be offered by the company and the rest by shareholders.

title: PROGRESS IS REPORTED ON NAMIBIA IN HAIG TALKS WITH SOUTH AFRICAN
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha of South Africa said today that new proposals made by the Reagan Administration offered ''a real possibility of moving ahead'' on negotiations for establishment of an independent nation of Namibia in what is now the territory of South-West Africa.

title: JERSEY WATER SPILLS AWAY
description: TROY HILLS, N.J., May 14 - The overflowing Boonton Reservoir, which is serving rationed portions of northern New Jersey, has lost 1.8 billion gallons of water to the sea in the last three days, officials say. That is equivalent to a day and a half's supply for all of New York City.

title: 'HAPPY BIRTHDAY TO ME'
description: ''Happy Birthday to Me'' looks like a comparatively expensive ripoff of such teen-age love-and-meat-cleaver films as ''Friday the 13th'' and ''Prom Night.'' As written by a gang of three totally confused writers and directed, without apparent style, by J. Lee Thompson, it's a mystery-horror movie with a fatal flaw - the denouement, in which a half-dozen grisly murders are explained, requires almost as much footage as the murders themselves. In addition, the reversals on what we've been shown earlier, make no sense whatsoever, even when you think about them, which isn't easy.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES TO LIFT RESTRICTIONS ON PAKISTAN AID
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee passed a measure today that would lift restrictions on aid to Pakistan and authorize $100.6 million in economic and military assistance for that country next year.

title: A PRIVATELY FINANCED'STING'BRINGS ARRESTS IN WATERBURY Griffin of Waterbury, Conn, in center is Ralph Raucci
description: An operation financed by four insurance companies has led to four arrests and the recovery of more than $200,000 in stolen gold and silver jewelry, guns, electronic equipment and other valuables, Connecticut's Attorney General said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will continue to try just as long as our efforts would make a constructive contribution.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1981; Markets
description: The credit markets were surpised by a quick rally that raised some long-term bond prices more than 2 1/2 points. Most analysts attributed the rebound to technical factors such as short covering by speculators. Some Treasury bill rates fell by about a quarter of a percentage point. (Page D1.)

title: SULLIVAN, FLOYD SHARE LEAD AT 66
description: Ray Floyd birdied the final hole for a four-under-par 66 today and a tie for the lead with Mike Sullivan in the first round of the $300,000 Colonial National Invitation golf tournament.

title: Fair at the Cathedral
description: A race for youngsters around the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. will kick off the spring fair of the Cathedral School, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

title: Around the World; Mine Kills 2 Civil Guards In Basque Region of Spain
description: Two Civil Guards were killed and another injured today when guerrillas detonated a mine under a convoy escorting dynamite near the town of Lemona.

title: FRANCE'S FOREIGN CAR SALES
description: Foreign car makers increased sales in France in April to a provisional 47,696 units, 3.7 percent above the March figure of 45,981, and 15.9 percent above the April 1980 figure of 41,150, the car manufacturers' association said today. French car sales on the domestic market dropped to 130,889, 1.6 percent below the March level of 132,976 and 24.1 percent below the April 1980 record of 172,556, it added.

title: Credit Markets; TRADERS SPUR QUICK BOND RALLY
description: The credit markets were suprised yesterday afternoon by a quick rally. One trader called it a ''nervous spasm,'' but it was nevertheless strong enough to raise some long-term bond prices more than 2 1/2 points.

title: Extra Budget Cuts Called Minor
description: White House officials said today that additional cuts in this year's budget would probably be minimal, despite the Administration's desire to counter spending overruns resulting from higher-than-expected interest costs.

title: Cunningham Dance-Film
description: ''Torse,'' a collaborative dance-film project by Merce Cunningham and Charles Atlas, will be shown tomorrow at 9 P.M. at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio, 463 West Street.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Around the Nation; Mine Negotiations Slow; Subcontracting Seen as Key
description: Talks between coal industry and union representatives bogged down today in an apparent dispute over provisions the United Mine Workers are seeking to limit the extent to which their employers can hire nonunion subcontractors.

title: Jury Is Told Police Isolated Crimmins
description: The father and stepfather of Craig S. Crimmins testified yesterday that the police had prevented them from seeing the 22-year-old stagehand while he was being interrogated through the night and early morning of Aug. 16 and 17 at the Metropolitan Opera House about the murder of Helen Hagnes.

title: Ease Off Kemp-Roth
description: Back during the Presidential campaign, candidate Reagan wedded himself for life to the notion of a three-year, 30 percent acrossthe-board cut in personal income tax rates. But now with the detailed proposal headed for Congressional decision and with skepticism spreading throughout the economy, the marriage may be in trouble.

title: CAMPBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SUSPECT SAID TO HAVE LIVED IN GERMANY
description: Reports circulated in West Germany's large Turkish community today that Mehmet Ali Agca, who is accused of trying to assassinate Pope John Paul II yesterday, spent long periods underground here after his escape from a Turkish prison in 1979.

title: No Headline
description: TWO NEW SINKHOLES IN CENTRAL FLORIDA: Sinkhole, measuring 40 feet across and 25 feet deep, that swallowed fence and garden between two homes in Altamonte Springs. Joel Kimrey of U.S. Geological Survey has said more sinkholes could be expected in the area because the current drought has lowered underground water table.

title: Restaurants; From the Levant to York Ave. Gallic.
description: AMONG the world's great ethnic appetizer combinations, none is more sensual or diverting than Middle Eastern meze, that array of salads, spreads and dips accented with sesame, mint, scallion and yogurt, and meant to be eaten with hot and grainy pita bread. The most subtly delicate version of these hors d'oeuvres appear in Lebanon, and so it should come as no surprise to find really wonderful meze at Beirut, the lively restaurant and nightclub on 32d Street, just west of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: THEATER: 'WRONG GUYS,' A MIXED-MEDIA CIRCUS, AT THE PUBLIC
description: IN ''Wrong Guys,'' the new Mabou Mines production at the Public, the inventive visual effects almost never quit. This 95-minute theater piece, created by Ruth Maleczech from a book by Jim Strahs, might loosely be described as a meditation on hardboiled-detective fiction. For the Mabou Mines, that doesn't mean idle Grand Guignol. Instead of routine blood and guts, we get a precisely designed mixedmedia circus in which black-and-white movies combine with live actors, flying lights and a complex network of rope and wire pulleys to take us on a manic descent into a volatile, imaginary criminal underworld.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advest Group Inc., Hartford, has elected Anthony A. LaCroix, president and chief executive officer, to the additional position of chairman.

title: Russian and Rumanian Are Launched Into Orbit
description: A Rumanian astronaut and his Soviet commander were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz 40 spacecraft, Tass, the official press agency, announced.

title: SONY A 'GLAMOUR' STOCK AGAIN
description: The Sony Corporation, whose stock was spurned by American investors through the late 1970's, today has regained its once-lustrous image as a coveted issue.

title: CELTICS BEAT ROCKETS, 102-91, AND WIN A 14TH N.B.A. TITLE
description: The Boston Celtics' season, which began in gloom when the center Dave Cowens unexpectedly announced his retirement near the end of training camp, ended in glory tonight.

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31
Art People; A partner to his kiln.
description: YOU might say that Robert Arneson, the West Coast ceramic sculptor, is putty in his own hands. In his show at the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street (through May 30), he deals a lot with the Arneson face. Sometimes he batters, twists and pushes around its features in sculptured and painted self-portraits that would make a mother weep; at other times he gives it a noble cast that reflects a firm ego. One Arneson head, for example, of clay in giant scale, is as flat as a pancake, its nose and mouth compressed as if the face had been pushed against a window. ''That's my Clem Greenberg piece,'' says Mr. Arneson, referring to the art critic who's made a fetish of flatness in contemporary painting.

title: Pope's Wounds Termed Worse Than Reagan's
description: Dr. Corrado Manni, director of the intensive care unit at the hospital where Pope John Paul II is being treated, said today that the Pope's wounds appeared to be more dangerous than those sustained by President Reagan in the attempt on his life in March.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard LA PRESIDENTA. By Lois Gould. 349 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: From a Canoe
description: There's nothing like a canoe. A friend in New England recently put in an asparagus bed he won't be able to enjoy a meal from for two years.

title: CAREY OFFERS BILLS CALLING FOR LIQUOR DEREGULATION
description: Governor Carey today sent to the Legislature a collection of bills that would substantially deregulate the state's liquor industry, including a proposal to allow retail liquor dealers to accept major credit cards.

title: SYRIAN SOLDIERS ARE JUBILANT AS MISSLE BRINGS DOWN ISRAELI DRONE
description: There was a red flickering flash in the blue morning sky over the Bekaa Valley today as the Syrian missile struck. Then smoke appeared followed by the white dot of a parachute drifting downward.

title: ABC SHIFTS TV HEAD TO DEVELOP CABLE FIELD
description: ABC Inc. announced a restructuring of its television division yesterday that will free Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president of the company, to devote substantially more time to developing new technology, chiefly cable television.

title: Advertising; Kurtz & Tarlow Resigns Tyco Toy Account
description: Kurtz & Tarlow announced yesterday that it had resigned the Tyco Industries toy account. The agency also noted that the client had already decided on its new agency, but the client reported that at the request of the new shop it was withholding for the moment the name.

title: HOUSING INFLATORS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE PANEL TOLD CABLE TV IS A THREAT
description: Witnesses told a House panel today that the growth of cable television, insulated from high program costs by Congress, threatens local broadcasting, live sports and the movie business.

title: Life Ends, Institutions Endure
description: The attack on the Pope has suddenly diverted France from its total obsession with its own politics. The mindless act was another reminder of the fragility of our lives, even the lives of our most revered or powerful figures, and of how arbitrary and illogical reality can be despite the human compulsion to try to make sense of things.

title: Murderer Sentenced To a 2d Life Term
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A man already serving a life term for the murder of an elderly Hamilton Township woman was given another life sentence for the slaying in December 1979 of a socialite, Emma Jane Stockton.

title: Brooklyn Heights Antique Show Is On
description: A walking tour of Brooklyn Heights and a lecture on the home care of antiques are part of the third Brooklyn Heights Antiques Show, which runs this weekend at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, on Orange Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets.

title: Notes On People
description: Enough Jokes People in high places in Cleveland are getting touchy about jokes and alleged slurs against their city.Rich Little, the comic impressionist, found that out when he made a mild anti-Cleveland joke during his appearance at the inaugural gala last January.

title: 2 Swim From Helicopter Crash
description: A helicopter flying under a bridge crashed into the Houston Ship Channel yesterday, and the two passengers aboard swam across the channel to safety. One of the passengers was hospitalized but was in stable condition.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
FORD PLANS BRITISH LAYOFFS
description: London, May 14(Reuters)-The Ford Motor Company said today that it was laying off nearly 3,000 workers at its Southampton plant in southern, England stopping van production, and might lay off workers at one of its Dagenham, Essex, plants, stopping production of the Cortina and Fiesta cars.

title: DEVELOPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NINTH AVENUE THROWS PARTY IN ITS ETHNIC KITCHEN
description: WHAT has evolved into the city's quintessential neighborhood celebration, that extended block party known as the annual Ninth Avenue International Festival, arrives for the eighth consecutive year this weekend, promising once again to be a high-spirited sampler of New York's many ethnic identities and their foods.

title: The U.N. Today; May 15, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Sec- ond Special Session of the General As- sembly Devoted to Disarmament - 10:30 A.M. and 3P.M.

description: B-After $4 million loss for the latest period and $10 million gain for the year ago period from foreign currency translations and $5 million for the year ago period from equity in net incom F W Woolworth & Co Ltd this year's first quarter net income did not include any equity from British Woolworth Year ago results also include a refund of advanced corporation tax of $20 million

title: FILM: 'MS. 45,' A WOMAN DOING A 'DEATH WISH' JOB
description: POOR Thana. She is raped not once but twice during the first 10 minutes of ''Ms. 45'' and is so distressed that she beans the second rapist with a paperweight. She kills him. She saws him into small pieces. She stashes these in her refrigerator. Some people's snacking habits are not to be believed.

title: Real Estate; Town Houses Rise on L.I.
description: unit town-house project called Southampton Commons deep into construction near Route 27, with a gatehouse off Hubbard Lane, and he wants to get the houses ready for buyers by ''the season.''

title: Broadway; Harlem's Apollo to be 'star' of new Broadway musical.
description: THE Apollo Theater, once the entertainment capital of Harlem, is the inspiration for a new musical slated for Broadway. It's called ''The Apollo ... It Was Just Like Magic,'' and it will try out in Washington at the Warner Theater in mid-July before coming to New York in the fall. The book and lyrics are by David Smyrl, Timothy Graphenreed and George Faison, who is also the director and choreographer. Mr. Faison is best known on Broadway for the dances he created for ''The Wiz.'' The music is a combination of popular songs and original tunes by Mr. Graphenreed.

title: AERO SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SOVIET SPY MAY HAVE SOLD MORE DATA SINCE HIS ESCAPE, EX-CONVICT INDICATES
description: A former convict said today that he met several times with Christopher John Boyce, the escaped spy for the Soviet Union, and delivered a package from him to a man with a ''Russian-sounding voice'' in Lima, Peru, last year.

PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $48,000 tax credit

title: AIDES TRY TO BRIDGE GISCARD-CHIRAC RIFT
description: Stunned and divided after the election of Francois Mitterrand as President of France, the country's conservative political forces are trying to regroup and work out their strategy.

title: Ship's Captain Fined for Oil Spill
description: The captain of the cruise ship Veendam was fined $40,000 yesterday for discharging oil in Bermuda's waters. Cornelius Hoenderos, 55 years old, a Dutchman, said debris in two discharge valves caused the oil slicks.

title: Robert DeNiro Festival
description: A series of 11 films in which Robert DeNiro, who won an Academy Award for his role in ''Raging Bull,'' appears will begin today at the Harold Clurman Theater, 412 West 42d Street, with screenings of ''New York, New York,'' and ''The Last Tycoon.''

title: JERSEY EASES CURB ON POLITICAL LEAFLETS
description: A ban on the distribution of political campaign literature at New Jersey's Meadowlands Sports Complex has been eased after Ann Klein, one of 13 Democratic candidates in the state's gubernatorial primary on June 2, filed a freedom-of-speech suit against the restriction.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OFFICIALS AREN'T SURE THAT CHECKPOINTS COULD STOP A MEHMET ALI AGCA
description: The head of the State Department's counterterrorism office said today that it would be very difficult for American authorities to spot an international terrorist like Mehmet Ali Agca, the alleged assailant of Pope John Paul II, if he tried to enter this country.

title: AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid May 1, 1981

title: Notes on People; Moving From Princeton to Off Broadway
description: It's not that Barbara Schottenfeld had anything against Princeton, but by the time it came time for junior year in Europe, she said yesterday, she'd sure ''had enough of academic papers.'' So much, in fact, that Miss Schottenfeld persuaded her professors to let her try a creative effort instead of an academic tome for her senior thesis.

title: YANKS TOP A'S AMID PROTESTS, 9-5
description: How did the umpires cost the Oakland A's a 9-5 loss to the Yankees last night? Let Billy Martin count the ways. According to the Oakland manager, they checked his starting pitcher, Mike Norris, more often than they did the Yankees' starting pitcher, Rudy May, in their search for wet or greasy baseballs. They upset Norris by arguing with him. They called Larry Milbourne safe at second base when he clearly was out. They didn't call Bucky Dent out for leaving third base early on a fly to center field. And they allowed a Yankee photographer to take movies of Norris from a field photographer's box.

title: POLICE TRACE THE PATH OF THE SUSPECT FROM TURKEY TO ST. PETER'S SQUARE
description: The head of the antiterrorist squad at the Rome police headquarters was quite sure this morning what sort of man he was dealing with in Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish youth who is accused of trying to assassinate Pope John Paul II yesterday.

title: A BUOYANT TAGLIAVINI IS BACK
description: Before Ferruccio Tagliavini made his Metropolitan Opera debut in 1947, reports had it that here was an Italian tenor well equipped to carry on the golden-age vocal traditions of Caruso, Gigli and Schipa. And sure enough, for seven seasons Mr. Tagliavini did indeed build up a strong following in New York, both at the Met and as a nation-wide radio personality on the old Bell Telephone and Firestone Hours.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March
BROOKINGS STUDY URGES CUT OF 4.3% IN REAGAN PLAN ON MILITARY OUTLAY
description: A leading authority on military budgets, William W. Kaufmann of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, asserted today that the Reagan Administration's five-year military program could be cut by the equivalent of 4.3 percent without harming national security.

title: All-Species Day Parade and Festivities
description: On Sunday, Fifth Avenue will resemble a Noah's Ark as those taking part in All-Species Day festivities march from Rockefeller Plaza to Columbus Circle in costumes or masks representing their favorite animals or plants. The parade, the 11th held nationally since 1978, is sponsored by All-Species Projects, a bioenvironmental group concerned with harmonious survival for all species of animals and plants.

title: TRIMAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'HANDS OFF LEBANON'
description: President Anwar el-Sadat called on Syria and Israel today to adopt a policy of ''hands off Lebanon'' and urged the Palestinians to form a provisional government because ''the day will come when Israel will sit with you.''

title: MOVIE RIGHTS TO 'EVITA' BOUGHT BY PARAMOUNT
description: After nearly a year of negotiations, Paramount Pictures Corporation has acquired movie rights to ''Evita,'' the immensely successful musical play that has grossed $83 million since it opened in London three years ago. The movie version of ''Evita,'' budgeted at below $15 million, will go into production by the end of the year if Hollywood labor difficulties do not delay the filming.

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Article 120656 -- No Title
description: VISITORS to New York's two major art auction houses will have an opportunity to see paintings valued at $60 million this weekend before they are put up for sale next week. Among the more than 1,000 works are paintings by Degas, van Gogh, Cezanne, Gauguin, Matisse, Picasso and Renoir that are expected to sell for $1 million or more each.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THOMSON NEWSPAPERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: 1980 first quarter results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of F P Publications Ltd The company is listed on the Toronto and Montrial stock exchanges

title: Company News; BL Ltd. May Close If Deficit Persists
description: Sir Michael Edwardes, chairman of BL Ltd., Britain's state-owned auto maker, said that he would shut down the company by 1984 if it continued to operate in the red.

title: A Bomb Scare Forces Joan Baez To Change Site of Argentine Talk
description: A bomb scare disrupted a news conference by Joan Baez today at the offices of an Argentine human rights organization.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: STATIONARY GUZZLERS OF
description: PECIOUS ENERGY

title: POPE'S SECRETARY OF STATE IN CHARGE
description: The central government of the Roman Catholic Church appeared to be functioning almost normally today, according to visitors to the Vatican.

title: 30 ON FORD FOUNDATION STAFF LOSING JOBS
description: The Ford Foundation has told about 30 staff members, most of whom are program officers responsible for making grants, that their contracts will not be renewed. A spokesman for the foundation said the dismissals, which affect all program divisions, were being made in connection with a major restructuring of the foundation's programs that was announced last month.

title: The Editorial Notebook; THE TRIALS OF TRUTH ON TELEVISION
description: On television, the good can be the ally of the worst. A case in point was NBC's regrettably superior docudrama, ''The People vs. Jean Harris.'' I wish it had been slapdash and offensive, and that Ellen Burstyn had not been quite so compelling in her depiction of Mrs. Harris.

title: NERVOUS BANKS IN FRANCE AGAIN LIFT INTEREST RATES
description: French banks raised interest rates sharply today in an effort to stem the export of capital that has been caused by last Sunday's Socialist victory in the Presidential elections. The outflow has been aggravated by the pull of the strong dollar.

title: MOTH CATERPILLARS BELIEVED TO BE A CAUSE OF SKIN RASH
description: The first larval stage of the gypsy moth, a tiny caterpillar that hangs by a thread from trees and is transported wherever the winds carry it, is suspected of being the cause of a skin rash, unreported in previous years, that has afflicted several hundred people in Connecticut and New York in the past few days, according to physicians and scientists studying the problem.

title: ART: A TRANQUIL SHOW OF AMERICAN LANDSCAPES
description: ''THE Contemporary American Landscape'' at the Hirschl and Adler Gallery, 21 East 70th Street, is a tranquil show that offers no arguments, but then it's been 150 years or more since landscape painting was a vehicle for philosophical ideas.

title: MUSKETS AND TOMAHAWKS: AN ESCAPE INTO THE PAST
description: In these awesome days of nuclear missiles and laser beams, the irregular crackle of muskets and long rifles and the acrid smell of black powder evoke an almost comforting nostalgia along the muddy waters of Laughery Creek in a wooded valley on the edge of this peaceful southeastern Indiana farming hamlet.

title: SONMOR IS ENRAGED BY REFEREE, TROTTIER
description: Glen Sonmor one of the National Hockey League's volatile coaches, almost controlled his anger tonight after his Minnesota North Stars lost to the Islanders, 6-3, in the second game of the Stanley Cup final. Sonmor was fined $1,000 by the League in February for condoning his team's brawling in a game with the Boston Bruins that set a league record of 406 minutes in penalties. The coach and his team had been relatively peacful then, working their way to the final without benefit of brawn. Tonight, however, Sonmor became furious again. The objects of his ire were Referee Bryan Lewis and Bryan Trottier, the Islander center. Lewis called a hooking penalty on Neal Broten, the North Star rookie center, at 6 minutes 22 seconds of the third period with the score tied, 3-3. Before expired, Denis Potvin had put the Islanders ahead to stay with his second goal of the game.

title:
NOtes On People;
Diana Ross Signs Up With RCA Records
description: Eight months ago, Diana Ross, one of popular music's superstars, dropped a shoe that made a thunderous sound in the recording industry: After 20 years with Detroit's Motown Records, she said, she was shopping around for a new recording agreement.

title: Around the Nation; Garwood Reported on Trip During Alleged Molestation
description: A woman who says she plans to marry Robert R. Garwood testified today that the Marine private was making a six-hour motorcycle trip to Charlottesville, Va., at the time he is accused of sexually molesting a little girl in his car.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mexico Oil Output Rise
description: Mexico's daily oil production this year is likely to average 2.79 million barrels, above the ceiling of 2.75 million set by the Government, the Planning and Budget Ministry said in a report released today. The report said the target of the state oil company, Pemex, this year was to drill 458 new wells and extract 2.79 million barrels of crude daily and 4.09 billion cubic feet of natural gas.

title: LIBYAN VOWS NOT TO DENY U.S. OIL
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said today in a television interview that he would not retaliate with an oil embargo for the expulsion by the Reagan Administration of Libyan diplomats in the United States.

title: POLICE INTERROGATE SUSPECT
description: Pope John Paul II was recovering today from a fivehour operation for wounds sustained in an assassination attempt yesterday, but he remained on the critical list, and his doctors said he was expected to be hospitalized for at least a month.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HOUSE UNIT SHIFTS FUNDS TO PROVIDE MORE TO POOR
description: A House subcommittee approved a major shift today in the spending priorities established in the Reagan budget by allocating $1.5 billion extra for social programs that aid the poor, including welfare and adoption assistance.

title: TEXAS INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-after $123,000 loss for the latest first quarter and $1,002,0 gain for the previous first quarter from discontinued operation

title: Tottenham Wins by 3-2 In Replay of Cup Final
description: Ricardo Villa scored two goals to give Tottenham Hotspur a 3-2 victory over Manchester City in the F.A. Cup soccer final replay at Wembley Stadium before a sellout crowd of 92,000 tonight.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'BEYOND THE REEF'
description: ''BEYOND THE REEF,'' which opens today at the Criterion 3 and other theaters, is about a Polynesian boy and his shark, a sort of underwater ''Lassie'' set on and around the spectacularly scenic island of Bora Bora. It's melodramatic and pretty and simple, in the manner of fiction designed for children from 9 to 11, and considerably less simpled-minded than ''The Blue Lagoon.'' You might think of it as a benign ''Jaws.''

title: METS SQUANDER 3-0 LEAD AND BOW TO PADRES
description: The slide became a plunge for the Mets today when the San Diego Padres rallied with five runs in the eighth inning to whip New York, 10-6, and sweep their three-game series.

title: Around the World; Belfast Policeman Is Killed As Rocket Smashes Vehicle
description: One policemen was killed and several more were wounded this evening when their armored vehicle was ripped apart by an Irish Republican Army rocket, the police said.

title: ANNIE STEIN
description: Annie Stein, who was instrumental in developing plans for the decentralization of school boards in New York City, especially in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section of Brooklyn, died of cancer Wednesday, at New York Hospital.

title: Sports of The Times; The Athlete as an Idol - And Human Frailty
description: ON a drizzly London morning in June 1973, an American couple ate an English breakfast and discussed the vacation agenda for the day. When the newspaper proclaimed that Billie Jean King was playing at Wimbledon that afternoon, it meant that Windsor Castle could wait for another day.

title: ZERO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Around the World; Arm of Solidarity Threatens Strike Over Police Beating
description: The Solidarity trade union movement said today that it was sending a delegation to the northeastern Polish city of Bialystok to investigate a report of alleged police brutality.

title: TV Weekend; THE PREAKNESS; 'PAPER CHASE' RERUNS
description: RACING'S Preakness Stakes will be carried live tomorrow afternoon at 5 on ABC-TV. In the 106th running of the classic, 3 year olds will race a mile and three-sixteenths for a purse estimated at $275,000. The horses will include, of course, Pleasant Colony, recent winner of the Kentucky Derby. Reporting from Baltimore for ABC will be Jim McKay, Howard Cosell, and Eddie Arcaro, the famed former jockey.

title: Official Reported Ready To Quit Commerce Post
description: William D. Hassett Jr., New York State's Commerce Commissioner, has told Governor Carey that he plans resign, administration officials said today.

title: GOV. CAREY SIGNS BILL TODAY TO REDUCE TAXES
description: Governor Carey is expected to sign into law tomorrow a broad series of tax reductions that will include help for elderly homeowners with high property taxes and farmers who face high maintenance costs for equipment. ''It's a targeted, esoteric potpourri,'' said Ralph Laws, secretary of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

title: JUDGE ISSUES BAN ON KLAN THREAT TO VIETNAMESE
description: A Federal judge, acting on a complaint by Vietnamese shrimp fishermen that they had been harassed, threatened and intimidated over a period of months by an alliance of white shrimpers and Ku Klux Klan members, issued a preliminary injunction tonight against such treatment.

title: GUATEMALA, SALVADOR
description: A Republican President was in the White House. He had appointed as Secretary of State and chief delegate to the United Nations two sternly anti-Soviet strategists, and had chosen a veteran intelligence officer to head the Central Intelligence Agency. He had warned the public of the possibility of a ''Communist outpost'' in a small Central American country that had just received a shipment of Communist arms. The State Department, contending that the people of that country were living under a ''reign of terror,'' issued a white paper documenting Communist ''infiltration.'' Our United Nations representative had warned the Soviet Union againsd ''meddling'' in Central America, saying: ''Stay out of this hemisphere. Don't try to start your plans and conspiracies here.'' The C.I.A. chief had privately informed his colleagues that the United

title: AN ANATOMY OF LENA HORNE'S TRIUMPH
description: The critics were undecided: Was Lena Horne simply incomparable or was she comparable to, say, Edwin Booth in ''Hamlet'' or Caruso in ''I Pagliacci''? Miss Horne opened at the Nederlander Theater on Tuesday night, and for the last two days people have queued outside the box office to buy tickets. By everyone's reckoning, ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' is a triumph.

title: MEAT COMPANY HEAD AND 8 OTHERS ACCUSED OF HIJACKING FOOD TRUCKS
description: A meat company owner and eight other men were charged yesterday with operating a major hijacking ring that allegedly sold stolen meat, fish and other products to restaurants in the New York City area.

title: Smaller Is Necessary
description: Speaker Tip O'Neill, milking the most sacred cow in American politics, says President Reagan's proposals to reduce Social Security costs are ''despicable'' and ''a rotten thing to do.''

title: U.S. PARLEY ON YOUTH CANCELLED
description: The White House Conference on Children and Youth, a national assembly traditionally held here once each decade since 1909, will be replaced this year with smaller state conferences that will have little to do with the White House.

title: FASHION TWO TWENTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
VALENZUELA GOES TO 8-0 ON 3-HITTER
description: Pedro Guerrero homered to lead off the ninth inning to preserve Fernando Valezuela's eighth straight victory and lift the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 3-2 victory tonight over the Montreal Expos.

title: Company News; Alcoa Cuts Output
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's leading aluminum producer, said that it would reduce primary aluminum output at its Vancouver, Wash., and Badin, N.C. smelters on June 1 to adjust inventories in the face of a sales decline. The company said it would idle facilities at Vancouver and Badin. The Vancouver plant's total annual production capacity is 110,000 metric tons and capacity at the Badin smelter is 113,000 metric tons.

title: SUNBEAM CORP reports earnings for Yr to March 31
NO CONTRABAND FOUND IN SOVIET CRATES
description: The chief of the United States Customs Service said today that there had been two technical violations but no substantive violation of Federal export laws by the shippers exporting cargo on a Soviet airplane detained for three and a half hours at Dulles International Airport Tuesday night.

title: SALLY LITTLE CREDITS WEIGHT LOSS WITH HER IMPROVEMENT IN GOLF
description: Few people who watch Sally Little sink long putts and hit straight drives can imagine that this tall, slim South African was once so overweight that she was jeopardizing her career on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: COUNCILMAN RICCIO Is CONVICTED IN CONSPIRACY ON NO-SHOW JOBS
description: A State Supreme Court jury today found Councilman Vincent A. Riccio of New York City guilty of grand larceny and two misdemeanor charges in his fraud and conspiracy trial here.

title: Company News; Sun Banks Intends To Acquire Century
description: Sun Banks of Florida Inc. said that it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire Century Banks Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for a combination of cash and notes valued at about $111.2 million. Combined assets of the two institutions total $4.6 billion.

title: DEL LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Music Noted in Brief; Morton Estrin, Pianist, Plays Schumann Etudes
description: Morton Estrin's recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Wednesday night was a thoroughly invigorating affair by a pianist who is not afraid to dig into the keys and produce bold, dashing effects. Most notable in this respect was Schumann's Symphonic Etudes.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JUDITH RASKIN: HER HEART'S IN RECITALS
description: The story sketched out in the poems of Schumann's song cycle ''Frauenliebe und -leben'' tells of a woman's passage from early idealistic love to late bitter loss. The music ends with the beginning phrases seemingly recollected in sorrow, recalling the first glimpse of the lover: ''like in a waking dream, his image floats before me.''

title: SYRACUSE JURY CLEARS 4 OFFICERS OF ASSAULT
description: A State Supreme Court jury cleared four city police officers today of charges that they criminally assaulted a suspect who collapsed from a heart attack while in their custody and later died.

title: Company News; Bramalea Talks End
description: Bramalea Ltd. and the Cadillac Fairview Corporation said they had terminated their previously announced merger discussions.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Announced that Jack Clark, outfielder, has signed a five-year contract.; BASKETBALL CLEVELAND (NBA) - Signed Gus John- son, a former N.B.A. all-star, as an assistant coach and radio commentator.; COLLEGES UNIVERSITY OF UTAH - Named Lonnie Keeter head basketball coach.; FOOTBALL BALTIMORE (AFC) - Announced the retirement of George Kunz, offensive tack- le.  DALLAS (NFC) - Signed John Wangler, quarterback.
description: DALLAS (NASL) - Acquired Milton, a f orward who played for the team in 1979, f rom Guadalajara of the Mexican League. MINNESOTA (NASL) - Announced that G eoff Barnett will replace Freddie Goodwin a s head coach. VANCOUVER (NASL) - Purchased B arry Siddall, goalkeeper, from Sunderland o f the English First Division.

title: BLYTHE DANNER AND HER CROSS-COUNTRY FAMILY
description: ''I miss my dishes,'' said Blythe Danner, the actress. ''I want my blue sweater,'' said her husband, Bruce Paltrow, a television producer and film director. The couple (both are in their mid-30's) and their two children have been living out of suitcases in a sublet apartment in Manhattan for the last few months. But they don't complain too much: at least the whole family is together.

title: O'Hern Confirmed As Justice in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Senate confirmed the nomination of Governor Byrne's chief counsel, Daniel O'Hern, as an associate justice of State Supreme Court. The vote was 27-3, with 21 votes needed for passage.

title: 2 POLICE OFFICERS FORCED TO RETIRE FOR LIES IN TRAIL
description: A New York City police inspector and a captain were disciplined and forced to retire yesterday for lying when they said at a recent departmental trial that they did not know that police officers were taking payoffs from Harlem gamblers in 1969.

title: FARM BILLS EXCEED REAGAN'S LIMITS FOR MILK AND GRAIN PRICE SUPPORTS
description: The House and Senate Agriculture Committees today completed writing new farm bills that would cost taxpayers far more in the next four years than the Reagan Administration wants or than House and Senate budget resolutions call for.

title: LIFE OF BABY IS APPARENTLY SAVED BY DOSES OF VITAMIN BEFORE BIRTH
description: By feeding a pregnant woman heavy doses of a B-vitamin daily for three months, scientists in California appear to have saved the life and health of her endangered baby.

title: PUBLISHING: THE RETURN OF 3 OLDIES BUT GOODIES
description: Decades after they were first published to the accompaniment of headlines and fanfare, three huge-selling novels have recently been reissued in paperback editions: ''The Naked and the Dead'' by Norman Mailer, ''Peyton Place'' by Grace Metalious and ''Doctor Zhivago'' by Boris Pasternak.

title: JERSEY SAYS MOB HAS LINKS TO A CASINO-HOTELS UNION
description: The New Jersey Division of Gaming Enforcement has recommended to the Casino Control Commission that it prohibit casinos from automatically deducting dues from employees' checks and giving the money to a union whose officials it says have connections with organized crime.

title: 6 KILLED IN BRIDGEPORT FIRE
description: At least six people, including a mother and three of her children, were killed early today when a fire that apparently had been set swept through a four-story apartment building.

title: Market Place; Successful Hunt For Bargains
description: FOR years thoughtful investors have challenged the theory that the market is efficient - that the price of every stock reflects all the facts concerning a company's prospects. These skeptics reason that relatively few companies are followed by brokers and institutions. Thus, hundreds of companies are neglected, their shares priced at levels below intrinsic value.

title: Robert B. Oxnam Named President of Asia Society
description: Robert B. Oxnam has been elected president of the Asia Society, a nonprofit center that sponsors fine-arts exhibitions, performing-arts programs and public-affairs activities to inform Americans about the traditional cultures and contemporary societies of Asia. Mr. Oxnam, 38, will succeed Phillips Talbot as president on July 1.

title: Around the Nation; Rehnquist Backs Secrecy On Tapes in Tax-Audit Case
description: The Washington Star WASHINGTON, May 14 - A Supreme Court Justice gave the Federal Government temporary permission today to keep in secrecy the computer tapes that give clues as to which taxpayers will be audited.

title: LURIA, L, & SON reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Around the Nation; G.M. Offer to Move Church In Detroit Is Rejected
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese and the City of Detroit today rejected an offer by the General Motors Corporation to move their church to save it from demolition so G.M. can build a new auto plant.

title: COMCAST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in April 1981

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Acting To Calm Street
description: WALL STREET remains nervous about President Reagan's economic program, fearing that it will lead not to a solution but to an aggravation of inflation. Despite the President's striking proof that he had control of Congress for his deep budget cuts - a demonstration his supporters had said would cause the securities markets to strengthen - long-term bond prices plunged, short-term interest rates soared and equity markets weakened.

title: REDESIGN OF BEAUMONT AND STATE THEATER SET WITH $8 MILLION GIFT
description: Lincoln Center has accepted an $8 million gift from the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation for the architectural and acoustical renovation of the Vivian Beaumont and New York State Theaters.

title: FOOD STAMP PROPOSAL- HOW NEEDY WOULD FARE
description: Although it seems likely that some cuts will be made in the Federal food-stamp program, present proposals in Congress call for less of a reduction for recipients than originally sought by the Reagan Administration.

title: Article 120579 -- No Title
description: The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today applied for a $225.1 million rate increase that would raise the cost of a coin call to a quarter and increase the average monthly residential phone bill by $2.90.

title: SHELTER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ford Predicts End of Losses
description: After a year and a half of heavy losses, the Ford Motor Company should approach the break-even point in the current quarter, which ends June 30, Philip Caldwell, the company's chairman, told shareholders today.

title: MESTA MACHINE CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge: Bridge and Marriage Offer Some of the Same Features
description: Bridge partnerships and marital partnerships have some features in common. They may be entered into lightly, or after careful consideration and preparation. They may be a source of harmony or discord. And they may last for a few hours or endure for a lifetime.

title: 2 ARMS DEALERS ACCUSED AT TRAIL OF SEEKING TO SELL TO 'TERRORISTS'
description: Two arms merchants were so eager to deal with undercover agents they thought were terrorists that one of the merchants, displaying lethal poisons, said, ''Let's go up to Harlem and get somebody,'' an assistant district attorney testified yesterday.

title: GIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $259,000 tax credit

title: THE POLITICOS' CONTRIBUTION TO ELECTRIC RATES
description: To the Editor:

title: Company News; MARYLAND COMPANY IS EARLY CONTENDER IN SATELLITE TV RACE
description: When the Federal Communications Commission put out the welcome mat not long ago for ideas in satellite television broadcasting to homes, the big surprise was that Comsat was not alone in bidding to introduce the new technology.

title: 37 Greeks Hurt at Rock Concert
description: Clashes broke out between the police and music fans after a concert last night by the American rock group Steppenwolf, injuring at least 37 people, including 7 policemen, the authorities said. Six youths were arrested.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 27
Crafts Fairs in Sugar Loaf and Nyack; In Sugar Loaf and Nyack
description: Those driving north from New York City this weekend might want to stop at crafts fairs in Nyack and Sugar Loaf. More than 60 artisans from across the country will exhibit their works tomorrow and Sunday at the seventh Sugar Loaf Crafts Fair, along Kings Highway and in Scott's Meadow in Orange County.

title: TORNADO INJURES 28 IN TEXAS TOWN
description: The authorities sealed off this small town in northeastern Texas today to prevent looting after a tornado flattened nearly two dozen buildings and injured 28 persons last night.

title: Woolworth Posts A Loss for Quarter
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said yesterday that it had lost $6 million in the three months ended April 30. Losses from the translation of foreign currencies into dollars offset most of a $6 million tax credit in the three months, the company said.

title: CHINA CRITICIZES MEESE ON TAIWAN
description: China sharply criticized a high-ranking White House official today for remarks he made Tuesday about United States relations with Taiwan.

title: CONOCO ASKS DOME FOR TAX GUARANTEE
description: Conoco Inc., vigorously opposing a bid by Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada to acquire Conoco's 53 percent stock interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, challenged Dome late yesterday to indemnify it against any tax liability if Conoco accepted the Dome offer.

title: CAPTIVE INSURERS COME OF AGE
description: When the Phillips Petroleum Company set up its own insurance outfit thousands of miles away from its dusty Oklahoma home, in the pleasant, unregulated climate of Bermuda, it was seeking a tax break, O.W. Armstrong, a Phillips vice president, said flatly.

title: BAY STATE GAS reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HEDY WEST RENEWING FOLK TRADITIONS
description: ALTHOUGH buffeted by fashion and largely ignored by the rest of the musical world, this country's Anglo-American folk purists forge ahead. They go to concerts on a circuit of folk performers, they gather for singing and picking sessions, and they flock to special weekend and summer festivals. Moreover, they seem to have an absolutely wonderful time doing all of it.

title: HANNAFORD BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
53 Die in Korean Train Accident
description: An express train rounding a blind curve struck the rear of another passenger train today, killing at least 53 people and injuring 233 others.

title: A THREE-DAY CELEBRATION OF BRONX FOLK CULTURE
description: Spiritualists and scholars, teen-age street dancers and retired factory workers, musicians, a pastry cook and a bagel baker - these are just a few of the people getting together this weekend to celebrate the folk culture of the Bronx. A three-day conference on that subject at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts this weekend promises to turn into a boroughwide festival of urban folklore, with films, walking tours, visits to shops, churches and a synagogue, even a ride on the elevated train. It is all in honor of Bronx Week, and what's more, it is almost all free.

title: No Headline
description: The New York Times/Keith Meyers A Good Day for a Bike Ride to Brooklyn Riders crossing the Brooklyn Bridge on a partly sunny afternoon when the mercury climbed to a high of 75 degrees. The temperature today should be much the same, but there is a chance of occasional showers.

title: At the Movies; Good fortune has creator of 'Hand' nervous.
description: horror movie, ''The Hand,'' which opened in New York and Los Angeles to many enthusiastic reviews, is going national.

title: St. John's and Seton Hall Gain in E.C.A.C. Baseball
description: Frank Viola extended his undefeated streak to nine games this season and 17 in the last two years by pitching St. John's to a 7-1 victory over Wagner yesterday in the opening round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey baseball playoffs at St. John's field in Jamaica, Queens.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
HAIG FEELS 'TIME IS RUNNING OUT' FOR HEADING OFF ISRAEL-SYRIA CLASH
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that even though he had not given up hope, ''time is running out'' for American efforts to avoid a Syrian-Israeli clash over Syria's deployment of antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon.

title: ARMADA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Includes $34,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: Business People; BURNS ELECTS NEW CHIEF
description: James J. Cronin, the 54-year-old president and chief operating officer of Burns International Security Services, a leading private protection company, has been elected to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive officer. He will succeed George E.B. King, 59, a grandson of William J. Burns, who founded the company in 1909.

title: REAGAN SON TO QUIT JOB IN CONTROVERSY
description: President Reagan's son Michael said today that he would resign from his job with a military contractor, just after the White House defended his use of his father's name in seeking Air Force contracts on behalf of the concern.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 15, 1981
description: International The Pope's condition remained critical on the day after he was gravely wounded by an assassin's bullets and underwent five hours of abdominal surgery. The director of surgery at Gemelli Hospital in Rome said that the vital signs of Pope John Paul II were ''satisfactory, but the prognosis remains guarded.'' His doctors said he was expected to be hospitalized for at least a month. (Page A1, Column 6.) The accused assailant of the Pope underwent more than 12 hours of questioning by the police in Rome. The chief of the antiterrorist squad described the prisoner, Mehmet Ali Agca, as ''cold, lucid and well trained to shoot.'' Officials in Ankara said they had uncovered links between the 23-year-old Turk and extreme right-wingers. But the Italian authorities were uncertain who had trained him, who had helped him to escape from prison in Turkey and who had paid for his extensive wanderings through Europe. (A1:5-6.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Century Trust said that Amstar Financial Corp., Dallas, and affiliates had increased their holdings of American Century common shares to 20 percent from 14 percent.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After tax credits of $437,000 for the quarter and $2,320,000 for the 9 months...C-Net income includes $250,000 tax credit

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pleasant Colony Gets Post 13 for Preakness
description: Dr. Janice Runkle has been mistaken for Johnny Campo's daughter and his exercise rider. But she is the veterinarian caring for Pleasant Colony, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the overnight 5-2 favorite for Saturday's Preakness.

title: CONFEREES APPROVE $695.5 BILLION LEVEL FOR THE 1982 BUDGET
description: House and Senate conferees today split their differences and approved a $695.5 billion budget intended to fulfill President Reagan's conservative goal of slowing the growth in Federal spending by curtailing the social programs that have expanded in the last half-century.

title: HABIB AND BEGIN TALK AFTER SYRIA DOWNS A DRONE
description: A pilotless Israeli reconnaissance plane was shot down by a Syrian missile today over the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, provoking an unexpected return to Israel by President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib.

title: ISLANDERS DOWN NORTH STARS, 6-3, LEAD FINAL SERIES, 2-0
description: Having shown the Minnesota North Stars their record-breaking penalty-killing in the first game of their Stanley Cup final, the Islanders displayed their record-breaking power-play in tonight's second contest at Nassau Coliseum. It produced two goals, including the tiebreaker, and the Islanders won, 6-3, for a 2-0 lead in the championship playoff.

title: Judge Again Tries to Settle Raider Suit Against N.F.L.
description: As jury selection continued today in the Oakland Raiders' antitrust suit against the National Football League, the judge called in a mediator to see if he could bring about a settlement without going to trial.

title: Company News; Tarkett to Acquire GAF Flooring Unit
description: Tarkett AB, part of the Swedish Match Group, said that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the GAF Corporation's total worldwide sheet vinyl flooring, floor tile and flooring tile business. The planned purchase price was not disclosed.

title: SENATE VOTES MILITARY FUNDS IN VICTORY FOR REAGAN
description: The Senate approved a $136.5 billion military authorization bill with almost no opposition today, giving President Reagan another clear victory for his Federal spending plans.

title: NOMINEE DENIES PRICE-FIXING TIE
description: John B. Crowell Jr., President Reagan's choice to oversee the nation's forests, says he had no reason to suspect that a company he was affiliated with was involved in a timber price-fixing case.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FROM NEW DELHI TO IOWA, INDIGNATION AND PRAYERS
description: Around the world, political and religious leaders and ordinary people continued yesterday to pray for a speedy recovery for Pope John Paul II and express concern about the attempt on his life.

title: ROME, TRYING TO FORGET, BUSIES ITSELF WITH THE BUSINESS OF A LANGUID THURSDAY
description: Rome seemed very quiet today, the city seeking refuge from the awfulness of the shooting of Pope John Paul II in routine and deliberate normalcy.

title: Gangster Faces New Jail Term
description: William Cammisano, a gangster in Kansas City, Mo., has been ordered to serve a new prison term for refusing to testify before a Senate committee last year, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today. As a result, Mr. Cammisano's current five-year Federal prison term for extortion will be interrupted while he serves the sentence for contempt of Congress, which will expire at the end of the 97th Congress next year.

title: Pope's Swiss Visit Postponed
description: The Conference of Switzerland's Roman Catholic Bishops formally confirmed today that the six-day visit that Pope John Paul II was to make to Switzerland beginning May 31 had been postponed.

title: Ottawa Alters Oil Plans
description: The Government, in a major concession to the petroleum industry, announced today that it was modifying its original plan to claim a 25 percent interest in oil and gas discoveries made before this year in Federally owned frontier areas.

title: PIEDMONT MANAGEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including realized capital gains of $192,932 for the latest first quarter and $26,260 for the year ago first quarter and $347,214 extraordinary credit for the year ago first quarte

title: Article 120552 -- No Title
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved legislation to authorize $725 million for Amtrak in the fiscal year 1982.

title: GREENSPAN URGES CUT IN U.S. BORROWING
description: Alan Greenspan, one of the Reagan Administration's economic consultants, told Congress today that inflation would not turn down without a cut in Federal borrowing and ''a continuous reduction in the rate of growth of bank credit and the money supply.''

title: Michigan Court Upholds Law Releasing Prisoners
description: A new state law giving early freedom to 1,000 inmates of Michigan's crowded prisons was upheld today by the State Supreme Court.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS 'MISSIONARIES' IN MORMON COUNTRY
description: Emeline Johnson, a bank auditor, was much happier four years ago when she was the only woman in the office. ''I prefer to work with men, because women are so petty and they're always tired and sick,'' Miss Johnson told her visitors as she continued with her gardening. ''They want the same pay and the same title, but they don't want the responsibility.'' The equal rights amendment ''missionaries'' were getting nowhere.

title: energywatch
description: MAY 8 Supplies of crude oil slipped to 399.4 million barrels, despite what energy experts believe to be the lowest level of refining activity on record.

title: Company News; Air Florida Flights
description: Air Florida said that it would begin service to Bermuda from White Plains and Chicago on June 18. Daily nonstop Boeing 737 jet service between Westchester County Airport and Bermuda, and daily direct, same-plane service between Chicago and Bermuda has been scheduled.

title: New Trial Ordered; Judge Is Criticized
description: ALBANY (AP) - New York State's highest court ordered a new trial for a man convicted of a 1975 murder in the Chinatown area of New York City, saying the man had been ''denied a fair trial'' by the judge.

title: 2 Producers Follow U.S. Steel Price Rise
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation and the National Steel Corporation have followed the industry leader, the United States Steel Corporation, in announcing price increases for all their steel products.

title: ART: WHEN THE AUSTRIANS TURNED TO EXPRESSIONISM
description: CERTAIN aspects of the modern art of Austria are nowadays so much admired - and in some quarters, indeed, so chic -that an entire generation has come of age on this side of the Atlantic with no memory of the obscurity that once surrounded its great achievements. For a large part of the American art public, the work of Gustav Klimt (1862-1918) and Egon Schiele (1890-1918) remained more or less unknown until the 1960's. Even Oskar Kokoschka (1886-1980), who lived long enough to become a legend in his lifetime, tended in earlier years to be classified with his German counterparts in the Expressionist movement rather than with his Austrian contemporaries.

description: Dance is where you walk on stage a peasant and take your bow as a swan, or begin the evening in a choreographed chain gang and end up as a silken jazz baby. It's the world where you're accepted into a dance company in a blaze of private exultation, then wonder, after a year or two among a multitude of other swans, why you ever hoped so. And dance is the world where suddenly, it seems, you're noticed. Whether a bright newcomer to audiences or a newly promising body to dance directors, you've arrived or are hovering at the brink. The three major dance companies performing in New York this weekend offer performances by a number of exciting young dancers who have reached that moment.

His letter, published below, argues that it would reinforce the work ethic, shrink the food stamp rolls and provide some useful public services.

On a summer's evening, the show's heroine (Deirdre O'Connell) has an extraterrestrial experience. Touched by an unseen visitor from another planet, she imagines - or takes? - a trip past the Northern Lights. In the morning, she returns to her hearth and husband but is unable to come down to earth. She hears voices, has visions and can read minds; she is literally spaced out.

title: FOR THE JAPANESE, SUDDEN MISGIVINGS ABOUT NUCLEAR POWER
description: There is a haiku by the 17th-century poet Basho about this remote inlet: ''Yes, lonely, more remote than Suma, this beach in autumn.'' The poet referred to Suma, a traditional place of exile, and he found Urazoko to be a still more melancholy spot, but beautiful. Now there is a nuclear power station around the corner of the bay. There is a road around the coast, constructed since the power station was built 10 years ago, that runs past the white beaches that Basho admired. And Urazoko, a hamlet with fewer than 100 people, according to the local policeman, has visitors in the summer, except this year.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 16, 1981
description: International Saudi Arabia's intervention in the Israeli-Syrian dispute over the Syrian missiles based in Lebanon is being sought by the Reagan Administration through the American special envoy to the Middle East, Philip C. Habib. American officials believe that an Israeli attack on the missile emplacements is imminent. The State Department ordered the United State Embassy in Beirut to hasten the evacuation of American dependents and to advise nonofficial Americans in Lebanon to leave. (Page 1, Column 6.) Israel will continue to use diplomacy to settle the missile crisis in Lebanon with Syria, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said following a meeting in Jerusalem with Mr. Habib, who was expected to remain in the Middle East at least several more days. Israel was expected to delay any military action against Syria until Mr. Habib's ends his attempts at peacemaking. (6:3-6.)

title: Japan Asks Clarification On Submarine Collision
description: Japan has asked the United States to explain discrepancies between American and Japanese reports on the collision April 9 between a United States nuclear-powered submarine and a Japanese freighter, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: 2 Found Slain in Gangland 'Hits'
description: Two men were found shot to death yesterday in separate incidents that the police said had the mark of gangland ''hits.'' One victim, 40-year-old Thomas Genovese of Staten Island, who was linked by the police to the Genovese crime organization, was found in the trunk of a car in Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section. The other, William Capparelli, 35, of Queens, was found in a parked car on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

title: Atlanta Asks Help Of New York Officer
description: Inspector Joseph Borrelli of the New York City Police Department, who was second in charge of the 1976-77 investigation into the socalled ''Son of Sam'' murders, has been asked to go to Atlanta to assist police authorities there in the investigation of the murders of young blacks.

Petar Stambolic, a Serb, became Vice President, putting him in line to succeed Mr. Krajger next May 15 as head of the nine-member body Tito designed to avoid power struggles after his death a year ago.

description: Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers union, said today that the American auto industry had undergone a permanent change and he doubted that it could recover totally from its slump.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP ROBUST 0.4%
description: The nation's industrial output rose fourtenths of 1 percent last month, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. It was a surprisingly robust performance that economists said cast increasing doubt on the view that the economy has slowed markedly since January.

title: 21 PERSONS HURT IN IND CAR FIRE AT E. 53D STREET
description: Twenty-one persons were injured yesterday after an electrical device beneath a subway car apparently dropped off an IND train at 53d Street and Third Avenue. The device hit a rail and shortcircuited, causing a fire and thick clouds of smoke as passengers pushed to escape the crowded train.

description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Steve Carlton (7-0) pitched a five-hitter and Mike Schmidt drove in two runs with singles as Philadelphia ended a fourgame winning streak by San Diego.

title: HOW THE IMPRIMATUR OF A PRESIDENT CAN BENEFIT AUTHORS AND THEIR BOOKS
description: The success of George Gilder's ''Wealth and Poverty'' is something of a surprise in publishing circles, because books about economic theory rarely sell well - unless they are suffused with Galbraithian wit, for example, or unless the author carries the credentials of a Milton Friedman, who is a Nobel laureate in economics. But one important thing the Gilder book has going for it is the imprimatur of President Reagan, who has publicly endorsed its tax-cutting message and has given it as a gift to others.

title: NOTHING BUT THE TRUTH
description: Life has become a constant burden, thanks to the recent surge of skepticism about the accuracy of what is written in the newspapers. Last night, for example, my garage was invaded by investigators looking for evidence that fictions have been published in this column. Imagine my rage. That anyone should think I might stoop to publishing fiction in the newspaper ....

title: FEAR OF CRIME LEADS IN SURVEY ON REASONS TO LEAVE BIG CITIES
description: Fear of crime is a leading reason for dissatisfaction with large urban areas, according to an extensive survey conducted by the Gallup organization for the National League of Cities and the Kettering and Mott Foundations.

title: Woodside Parents End Sit-In Over a Principal
description: Parents of children at Public School 11 in Woodside, Queens, who have been protesting the appointment of a principal of whom they did not approve, ended their three-day-long sit-in at the school's administrative offices late yesterday afternoon.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING VOTES TO LIQUIDATE
description: Directors of the Pittsburgh Brewing Company, a 120-year-old concern that operates the city's last remaining brewery, voted today to liquidate after striking workers rejected what management called a final contract offer.

title: BARKER OF INDIANS HURLS PERFECT GAME AGAINST BLUE JAYS
description: Len Barker of the Cleveland Indians, aided by Tom Veryzer's fine fielding play in the first inning, pitched the first perfect game since 1968 and the second no-hitter in the major leagues this week, defeating the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-0, tonight.
