description: When Rene Lachemann arrived in Seattle last week with his charts, videotape machine and a system of fines and incentives, he wondered if the Mariner players would consider their new manager ''bush league.''

Utah Woman Has Abortion Hours After Losing Appeal
description: A woman who said she feared physical abuse from her estranged husband had an abortion today without his knowledge just hours after a judge ruled that the husband must be told beforehand, in accordance with state law.

title: WILLIAMS INQUIRY COUNSEL NAMED
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics named Robert S. Bennett, a Democrat, today as special counsel for its investigation of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr.

Christopher was unknown to the police who were hunting for the killer or killers of 10 black men, a black teen-ager and a dark-skinned Hispanic man in four cities last year.

title: Trigger Prices On Steel Stable
description: Most trigger prices for United States sales of imported steel will be held to second-quarter levels in the third quarter of this year, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: 3 Unions and Post Reach Wage Accord
description: Local unions of mailers, paper handlers and machinists have reached agreement with The New York Post on an economic package similar to one negotiated earlier with The Daily News and The New York Times, George E. McDonald, president of the mailers local, announced.

title: F.B.I. Director Comments On Possible Point-Shaving
description: An investigation of possible pointshaving activity in two Big Eight Conference basketball games last winter may have aroused unnecessary fears, according to William Webster, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: C.I.A. ACKNOWLEDGES EX-CAMPAIGN OFFICIAL IS PLACED IN KEY POST
description: The Central Intelligence Agency today confirmed that a New Hampshire businessman who had worked on President Reagan's election campaign staff had been chosen to head the agency's directorate of operations, which conducts sensitive covert actions and clandestine intelligence-gathering abroad.

Ullinger, vice president of Crouse Nuclear Energy Services, a construction company in Linfield, Pa., was granted a patent this week for a device that, he says, can bring substantial energy savings to power plants around the country. Mr. Ullinger is in charge of his company's turbine division.

title: JUDGE BARS PAPER FROM PRINTING DATA ON SCHOOL AIDE IN SEX CASE
description: A Superior Court judge here has barred a newspaper from publishing material related to a case involving allegations of sexual harassment on the part of a school official, even though the editors had not decided to use the information and the administrative proceedings on the matter have been completed.

title: Brunei Cuts Oil Price
description: Brunei has told Japanese importers that its crude oil prices for shipment to Japan have been cut by up to $1.40 a barrel, effective today, industry sources said. New prices are $39.60 a barrel for light seria oil, down a dollar, and $37.75 for champion oil, down $1.40, they said. Japan imported 47 million barrels of crude from Brunei in the 1980 fiscal year, ended last March, or 3 percent of its total import needs.

title: No Headline
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, will represent Polish workers at next month's International Labor Organization meeting here, according to Francis Blanchard, director general of the 145-nation agency. It will be the first time that the worker representing a Soviet-bloc country has not been an official of a Government-controlled union, according to a long-time I.L.O. staff member who is now retired.

title: Grand National Semifinals Begin in Manhattan Today
description: For New York players, the Grand National Team Championship reaches its climax at the New York Hilton Hotel this weekend. Semifinal play involving teams originally seeded fifth, sixth, seventh and eighth, an odd circumstance, begins this afternoon, with the final scheduled tomorrow. The winners will continue to zonal playoffs aiming to reach the national quarterfinals in Boston in July.

title: BALLET: IDEALIZED 'DREAM'
description: With its deft storytelling and charming dances, George Balanchine's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' is one of the sweetest spectacles imaginable. But when the New York City Ballet presented the two-act work for the first time this season on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, it was clear that this ''Dream'' is sour as well as sweet in its depiction of the ways of love. In fact, its sour touches prevent it from being cotton candy.

At its premiere three years ago, this abstraction to Hindemith for two couples and an all-male ensemble reminded many people of an awesome machine.

Advancing groups on the New York Stock Exchange ranged from brokerage, airline and electronic issues to the aerospace, aluminum and energy sectors.

title: Lloyd of Giants Healthier, But Will Miss 1981 Season
description: Dan Lloyd, the Giants' linebacker, received mixed news yesterday. He was told by his physician that his cancer treatment is coming along well, but he was also told not to play pro football this year.

title: FOUNDATIONS DISCUSS NEW WAYS TO ACHIEVE GOALS
description: Leaders of the country's philanthropic community, gathered here for 32d Annual Council on Foundations Conference, arrived to bad tidings. The latest figures show that their combined assets have climbed above $41 billion but that inflation had actually reduced the purchasing power of their holdings over the last seven years by 30 percent. The 1,100 participants at the four-day conference which ended yeaterday agreed that requests for assistance have soared. Some estimate that requests had risen by 30 percent; others said that they had doubled. For many, these developments underscore a widespread and what they consider to be an unrealistic expectation among the public and government officials that foundations and corporations will somehow find funds to make up for the expected reductions in Federal spending for a broad range of services. "The gap between the resources available and the sizeof the job is too great," said Richard W. Lyman, president of the Rockefeller Foundation. "It is bad tactics as well as bad thinking to let America at large believe that foundations rolling up their sleeves can take care of what's needed." No 'Gloom and Doom' But others, including Dr. David E. Roger, president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, expressed a more optimistic outlook. "I don't find gloom and doom out there, and I see a positive response. I see a lot of people saying 'yes we can'." The Johnson Foundation, the country's largest in the field of health with $1 billion in assets, spends about $50 million a year on improving care for what it terms the 'underserved population."

In addition, there was Charles Wuorinen's Six Pieces for Violin and Piano (1977), as a kind of reminder of the sort of music Speculum used to espouse more single-mindedly. Finally, there were two commissioned world premieres, Gerald Busby's ''Glyphs'' and David Koblitz's ''Tokens on the Dream Exchange.''

title: BREAKUP OF A COMMUNITY
description: THERE was a time long ago when South African writing, or at least that part of it produced by English-speaking whites, could be viewed as a colonial subspecies of British letters. Growing up gradually alongside this in the past five or six decades, a vigorous literature in the Afrikaans language emerged, distinguished especially for its poets, about whom non-Afrikaners in South Africa as well as in the outside world knew little. And in the 1950's some distinctive black voices began to be heard, only to be smothered by an official persecution, of which censorship was by no means the harshest form. (In South Africa, not just specific writings but the writers themselves -and, consequently, any words they have ever spoken or written - can be ''listed'' and ''banned.'') As the apartheid era unfolded, the experience and orientation of the writers in the various ethnic and racial groups differed so drastically that only literary do-gooders, in their most fatuous moments, were disposed to speak of a South African literature.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Fredrich Cantor's exhibition at the Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street (through May 29), will come as something of a surprise even to people already familiar with his work. For Mr. Cantor is known mainly as a photographer whose pictures of European landscapes are stylized in a romantic manner closely resembling that of certain 19th-century travel photographs, and here he makes his debut as a painter. In contrast to the sepia-toned shadows of the photographs, in which darkness tends to dominate and control the light, the paintings of landcape tend to be sun-drenched. Even the shadows in the paintings tend to be more light-filled than Mr. Cantor's photographs ever are, and there is an obvious effort to confer on every painted image - whether it is a landscape or an interior still life - a degree of clarity and luminosity.

title: THE PICK OF THE CRABAPPLES
description: The limbs of crabapples can weep the found with low spreading branches or cascake downward like a waterstraight toward the sky and widen to form a vase or lollipop shape. Aged picturesque specimens are often 25 to 30 feet tall with branches strong enough to support a swing. Several varieties remain shrubs of 15 feet of less and are ideal for small scale gardens. Crabapples flower from late April into early June depending on the variety. Blossoms may be one-to-two inch singles of doubles in hues of white blush, pink, rose and carmine red. Some deliciously fragrant. Many bear tiny 1/2 to 1 1/2 inch berrylike apples which ripen to brilliant red, rusty-orange or golden-yellow in September cultivated crabapple varieties, some of which are my favorite speing flowering trees. Crabapples, Malus species and hybrids, differ from apples by the size and taste of their fruits. Both are members of the Rose Family. Not all crabapples exhibit the glorious traits for year-round bequty. Some are generally unattractive, flower sparingly and only in alternate years. Fruits can be large and messy when they fall. There are also disease problems. Several crabapple varieties are disease resistant while other are only slightly susceptible. Still other are severely susceptible. The following favorite varieties are special in their flower, fruit, frangrance, color or habit. They are available at quality nurseries and garden centers or from mail-orders sources. All bloom annually; those susceptible to disease are noted.

title:
CAMERA;
SUGGESTIONS FOR TAKING BETTER VACATION SLIDES
description: Many people dread seeing slide shows that consist of vacation pictures taken by friends or relatives - and with good reason. All too often, these shows are long and boring as a result of insufficient planning, haphazard shooting and careless editing. However, interesting slide shows of vacation pictures have been presented by diligent photographers who plan properly, and a slide show that will be interesting to watch can also be put together by almost any photographer capable of using a camera successfully. All you have to do is resist the temptation to shoot endless succession of typical vacation snapshots in which family members or friends are posed next to or in front of some all-too-familiar tourist attractions. Instead, by making an effort to communicate the distinctive character of a particular setting you can shoot vacation pictures that will eventually form a presentation which will inform and entertain a wide range of viewers. The photographic techique of avoiding the obvious and staying away from sterotypes can be successfully applied to practically every vacation picturetaking sequence, but it is even more important that the photographer first realize that not everything that happens in front of the lens will be worth recording on film Being selective in you shooting not only saves time, it also conserves expensive film and cuts down on the amount of work you will have to do during the editing process. Although it has often been said that what separates the professional photographer from the amateur is the greater amount of film the professional uses, it would be more accurate to say that what distinguishes the professional is that he knows when not to shoot.

But obscenity, said Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, is difficult to prove.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 3 incorrectly stated the number of black lawyers who are partners at the nation's 50 largest firms, as tabulated by the National Law Journal. There are 20 partners, out of a total of 171 black lawyers in those firms.

title: FOUR POSSIBLE WAYS OUT OF PUBLIC TV'S CRISIS
description: To Bill McCarter, president of WTTW-TV in Chicago, the financial crisis in public broadcasting is a bracing relief. ''I liken the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cutbacks to that old shaving commercial in which the guy gets slapped in the face and then says, 'Thanks, I needed that,' '' he said. ''We're at a marvelous pivotal moment now. I don't want to be a Pollyanna, but we're enjoying the largest and most enthusiastic audiences in our history. The Government invested in our early development and now we have to make our own way. That's the challenge.''

title: by Shelby Moorman Howatt
description: MY host is ecstatic. ''Isn't it fantastic, the way Coop and Bogart have taken to you?'' he says, his eyes misting at the sight of the two Pekingese heads resting on my lap. ''They're good watchdogs, of course, but see how gentle they are.'' He shrugs and laughs. ''I used to think people who ranted on about their dogs were nuts,'' he says, passing the hors d'oeuvres. ''Now, well ... I guess it's a case of love me, love my dogs. Here, have one while it's hot.''

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Ray Luck, Pianist, Offers Beethoven Sonata
description: Ray Luck, a pianist on the faculty of the Randolph-Macon Women's College in Lynchburg, Va., made his New York debut in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. A native of Guyana, Mr. Luck has studied in London, Paris and Indiana Univeristy, and has had enough performing experience to know where his talents are best applied.

title: Maryland Wins Lacrosse
description: Sandy Lanahan scored two secondhalf goals today to lead Maryland to a 5-3 victory over Ursinus in the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women national lacrosse championship.

title: CITY AWAITING BIDS FOR OUTDOOR CAFE IN BRYANT PARK
description: In an attempt to drive out the drug sellers who congregate there, New York City's Parks Department is asking for bids to put an outdoor cafe on the Bryant Park terrace at the back of the New York Public Library between 40th and 42d Streets.

title: Borriello Paces St. John's To a 4-2 Defeat of Wagner
description: Sebastian Borriello drove in one run with a triple in the fourth inning and another with a single in the sixth yesterday to lead St. John's to a 4-2 victory over Wagner in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference New York-New Jersey baseball tournament at St. John's field in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Tracy Austin's View
description: To the Sports Editor: I'm writing this letter because I'm surprised at all the stories that have been written lately about the offcourt lives of some women tennis players.

title: Reagan Now Oldest President
description: Ronald Reagan today became the oldest President in United States history. Seventy years and 99 days old, Mr. Reagan passed the record set by President Eisenhower, who was a day younger when he left office in 1961. The White House took no official notice of the occasion.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS: OTHER VIEWS IN THE DEBATE
description: styled public school-oriented separationist rather than an educator. His article is pitched at making it more difficult for private schools to exist. He distorts facts about private schools and fails to recognize the value that such schools have to the public at large.

title: Woman Sentenced in Fraud Of Fraternity President
description: A Federal District judge yesterday sentenced a 34-year-old woman to three years in prison for swindling almost $5,000 from the president of a fraternity at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: SHAD FISHING IN THE HUDSON
description: KINGSTON, N.Y. BRILLIANT sunshine, a gentle southwest breeze and a proper tide awaited me on my first attempt to catch Hudson River shad, and although five decades of angling provide some defense against overoptimism, success seemed assured.

title: Ideas and Trends; Law Without Numbers
description: Ignorance of the law is no excuse for not getting into law school, especially since the standardized admissions test has little of the law about it. Too little, according to its critics, who see no correlation between solving algebraic equations or correcting ungrammatical sentences and wrangling with problems of jurisprudence.

title: IT'S OPEC'S TURN TO WORRY OVER OIL SUPPLIES
description: When the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Geneva next week, the cartel will face its toughest challenge since it began dictating oil prices eight years ago. Slackening world demand, growing supplies of oil from other sources and a propensity to convert to other forms of energy have reduced the need for OPEC oil to its lowest level in years.

title:
Art;
REFRESHINGLY HIGH QUALITY MARKS SHOW BY FIVE TOWNS GROUP
description: WOODMERE IN the more than 30 years since its founding, the Five Towns Music and Art Foundation has brought a wide range of cultural activities to the communities of southwestern Nassau County. Classes, workshops, performances, lectures and other events fill its busy calendar, which also includes an annual juried art exhibition, with entries invited from all over the region.

title: Madison Avenue Approach Needed on Dandelions
description: Many Westchesterites will applaud John Chervokas's campaign against dandelions (''Uplifting Campaign Against a Weed,'' April 19), but his coercive, shame-your-neighbor-into-creating-a-golf-green-like lawn, it seems to me, is unworthy of a highly successful advertising executive.

title:
Business Forum;
END THE MORTGAGE GIMMICKRY...
description: O VER the years, the nation's savings institutions have provided the mortgage financing necessary to the development of cities and suburbs around the country. Without them, our real estate developers would have been faced with a void. Without them, apartment houses, onefamily houses, shopping centers, office buildings and industrial parks would never have been built.

title: A Correction
description: An article on public transportation in The Week in Review of May 10 contained a typographical error that exaggerated the prospective percentage increase in fares in the Cleveland area. Officials estimate that the fares could rise as much as 150 percent.

title: Atlanta Getting U.S. Money For Youth Recreation
description: Atlanta will receive Federal money to expand recreation programs this summer to keep children off the streets and safe from the killer or killers of 27 young blacks, Vice President Bush's office says.

title: WILLIS R. BUCK
description: Willis R. Buck, president and general manager of Texaco Oil Trading Division and president of Texaco International Trader Inc., died yesterday at his home in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: The World; Second Inmate Dies In Hunger Strike
description: The hunger strikers in Maze Prison gave up another life last week in their campaign to force the British Government to grant political status to Irish Republican Army prisoners. The second to die - after Robert Sands on May 5 - was Francis Hughes, serving a life sentence for killing a British soldier.

title: PISANI ENTERS WESTCHESTER RACE TO UNSEAT DELBELLO
description: State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle, who has represented southeastern Westchester County in the Legislature since 1966, announced today that he was seeking the Republican nomination for the County Executive post held by Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat.

title: Music Noted in Brief; New York Pro Arte Offers Works of the Youthful
description: Mendelssohn's Symphony for Strings No. 11 in F seemed an example of pure, unabashed, musical play when it was presented by the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Raffael Adler Thursday night in the Abraham Goodman House.

title: 'FIDDLER' AT DARIEN IS A BIT OF SOFT CORE
description: AS surely as you can count on a man in a chef's hat slicing roast beef at the end of a dinner theater buffet line, you can also count on a production of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' turning up. To date, I have seen the show twice at the Coachlight of Nanuet, once at An Evening Dinner Theater in Elmsford; once at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, Conn., and now at the Darien Dinner Theater in Connecticut.

title: DEBATE OVER MOVING OF A POSTAL FACILITY
description: STAMFORD ''IF I'm right, I'm going to holler,'' said Beatrice McCargo. ''If I'm wrong, then I'll shut up.'' Mrs. McCargo believes she is right in saying that plans by the United States Postal Service to build a huge mail-processing facility a block from her home would ruin the quiet environment of the neighborhood, and she has done more than holler.

title: A CALL FOR ACTION ON COUNTY JAIL
description: WESTCHESTER County cannot afford to let the overcrowding at the county jail remain out of control, as it has been over the past year; and there is no longer any excuse for doing so. For the first time in history, we have the means to develop long-term remedies for the many problems of the criminal-justice system, not just for overcrowding alone, through a new mechanism that can make intelligent planning and control possible.

title: Wethersfield, Conn.
description: To the Editor:

title: DON'T FORGET IGUANAS CAN'T FLY
description: DEAR Mom and Dad: Hi! I thought I'd surprise you with a letter for a change instead of a collect call. Hope you're both feeling great and wish I could say the same about myself. But after walking up nine flights of stairs, I feel like Grandma Moses' mother.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary last Sunday stated the rank of John M. Will incorrectly. He retired from the navy as an admiral.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AMERICAN RIVALRY, by Thomas B. Larson. (Norton, $6.95.) A systematic analysis of the economic, political and military competition that went on between Russia and the United States during the three decades after World War II. The author, former chief of the State Department's Division of Research on Soviet and Eastern European Affairs, is not an alarmist, but sees Russian influence somewhat greater by the start of the 21st century.

title: IN A CROWD OF THE FAITHFUL, A TERRORIST STRIKES
description: Among the more than 10,000 pilgrims in St. Peter's Square on Wednesday afternoon was a man who was not on a pilgrimage, but a mission. He had means and motive and sought only an opportunity. It came soon enough. When the open white car carrying Pope John Paul II passed slowly within a few feet of him, opportunity catalyzed means and motive into a deed that resounded worldwide.

title: Shelley Beck Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Shelley Ann Beck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Shelton Beck of Northumberland and Eagles Mere, Pa., to Robert Harder Ryan of New York took place at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Eagles Mere yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Jean Shields of New York and Allamuchy, N.J., and the late Clendenin J. Ryan and a great-grandson of Thomas Fortune Ryan, the financier.

title:
Gardening;
INTENSIVE VEGETABLE PLANTING SAVES SPACE
description: WHEN I was a young boy on a farm, the family vegetable garden was at least an acre in size, and that did not include the corn, potatoes, melons, cucumbers, pumpkins and squash planted in the fields alongside the corn. Although the weeds in the rows were controlled by hoeing and hand-pulling, the garden was so large that the space between the rows was cultivated with an ''eagle claw cultivator.'' This device was pulled by a horse, had five digging shovels and could be adjusted to accommodate the spacing between the rows.

title: At Home
description: MY host is ecstatic. ''Isn't it fantastic, the way Coop and Bogart have taken to you?'' he says, his eyes misting at the sight of the two Pekingese heads resting on my lap. ''They're good watchdogs, of course, but see how gentle they are.'' He shrugs and laughs. ''I used to think people who ranted on about their dogs were nuts,'' he says, passing the hors d'oeuvres. ''Now, well ... I guess it's a case of love me, love my dogs. Here, have one while it's hot.''

title: THIS ONE IS FOR THE HORSEPLAYERS
description: ''You couldn't pay me to go to the Kentucky Derby,'' said Jim Nicholas, one of the first 50 people to pass through the Pimlico turnstiles for the Preakness, just before 9 this morning. ''Churchill Downs is a zoo,'' he said as he hoisted a cooler filled with beer and submarine sandwiches onto his shoulder, ''but Pimlico is a race track.''

title: MORAL FICTIONS
description: THE ART OF LIVING And Other Stories. By John Gardner. Woodcuts by Mary Azarian. Illustrated. 310 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Cable TV Backed In Hockey Playoffs
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson contends that putting hockey teams on cable rather than free TV constitutes economic and geographic discrimination (''Hockey in Need of Don Quixote,'' The New York Times, May 3). He quotes the attorney Ellis Rubin that ''we also have a constitutional right not to be discriminated against.''

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 2 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 6 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 3 4 4 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 4 3 18 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a lost treasure. 5 6 6 REFLEX, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $11.95.) A British jockey copes with blackmail and discovers his own missing past. 6 5 7 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) A journey through that greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all. 7 7 30 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: A STUDY FAILS TO SHOW WHY DEVICE DETACHED FROM IND SUBWAY CAR
description: A Transit Authority investigation of Friday's subway accident at the station at 53d Street and Third Avenue has not yet determined why an electrical device beneath one of the F train cars fell to the tracks, causing the accident, an authority spokesman said yesterday.

title: Another Recollection Of Greystone Station
description: As a daily Greystone Station commuter for the last two and a half years, I enjoyed the opportunity to share in the lore of that station (''Recalling a Genteel Greystone Station,'' April 29). Let me continue the history.

title:
AN ATLAS OF NESTING BIRDS IS IN THE WORKS FOR NEW JERSEY;
SPARTA
description: HUNDREDS of binoculars are being focused on birds in New Jersey these days as observers begin work on the state's first bird-breeding atlas.

title: NAVY SECRETARY SEEKS MORE STRENGTH TO HALT SOVIETS
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. says that he intends to have his service build a warfighting capability superior to that of the Soviet Union.

title: PULLBACK BY HANOI IN CAMBODIA IS SEEN
description: With the onset of the monsoon rains, Vietnamese troops in Cambodia are withdrawing from outlying regions, particularly near the Thai border, to positions closer to their logistical bases, according to Western military and diplomatic sources.

title: STUDY FINDS MIAMI RIOT WAS UNLIKE THOSE OF 60'S
description: The riot that broke out a year ago tomorrow in the Liberty City section of Miami differed dramatically from the racial disturbances of the 1960's, according to a study conducted for the Ford Foundation.

title: The World; Reagan a Co-Signer On Aid to Salvador
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, less inclined than the Administration to give El Salvador's ruling junta a blank check, last week imposed stiff conditions for military aid.

title: Chinese Say They Killed 150 Vietnamese Troops
description: China said today that its forces killed more than 150 invading Vietnamese troops yesterday.

title: CANOEING GAINS AS STATE SPORT
description: CORNWALL ON any good weekend between May and October, traffic on the upper stretch of the Housatonic River is apt to be as heavy as that alongside it - on Route 7, which winds through the river valley for several miles. Provided there is sufficient water, 400 canoes and kayaks nose down sections of the watercourse called by the Indian name that means ''river beyond the mountains.''

title: PARENTS' GROUPS PURGING SCHOOLS OF 'HUMANIST' BOOKS AND CLASSES
description: In Onida, S.D., birth control information has been removed from the high school guidance office, and the word ''evolution'' is no longer uttered in advanced biology. ''Brave New World'' and ''Catcher in the Rye'' have been dropped from classes in literature. The award-winning children's book ''Run Shelley, Run'' has been banned from the library.

title: Marguerite Thomas, Painter, Married to Dr. Frank Jewett
description: In the Pauline A. Hartford Chapel at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday, Marguerite L. Thomas, a painter, was married to Dr. Frank S. Jewett, a psychiatrist and an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. The Rev. William Newell, associate Protestant chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: CAREY COMPLETES ACTION ON BUDGET
description: Governor Carey announced yesterday that he had completed action on the state's $16.6 billion budget, 46 days after the beginning of the state's fiscal year on April 1.

title: BIG BUSINESS'S POLLUTION PROBLEMS SPAWN A NEW BREED OF AUDITORS
description: O N Jan. 21 at 2:52 A.M., two employees of the Owens-Illinois bottlecap plant in Brookville, Pa., were apprehended by state environmental authorities as they dumped toxic waste chemicals at an abandoned site near the plant. The workers were participating in a plantwide cleanup in preparation for a visit by corporate officials later that same day. Yet, Owens-Illinois officials in Toledo insist that the men were acting without the authority or knowledge of company management and in violation of plant procedures for handling waste chemicals.

title: METS SLIDE REACHES 6 IN 9-0 LOSS
description: The New York Mets reeled to their sixth straight defeat tonight when the Los Angeles Dodgers thrashed them, 9-0, behind the six-hit pitching of Burt Hooton.

title: The Birds Of Victory
description: Jan Morris's article ''The Fabulous Beasts of Venice'' (April 19) omits the historical significance of the pigeons in the Piazza di San Marco.

title: SHADOW OF DEATH THE POPE IS A VISIBLE FORCE- AND A VUNERABLE TARGET
description: POPE John Paul II strode onto the world stage in October 1978 and quickly established himself as the most vigorous wielder of papal power in modern times. In keeping with the pattern of his post-Second Vatican Council predecessors, he has wielded that power to affect the course of events in the world at large, rather than just among Catholics.

title: Housen Gains, 1 Up, In Travis
description: Bob Housen of Manasquan River defeated J.P. O'Hara of Winged Foot on the final hole and advanced to the semifinal round of the 71st Travis Memorial golf championship today.

title: Deborah Jane Ward Married to George Foote Lane 3d
description: Deborah Jane Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin W. Ward of Chester, N.J., was married yesterday to George Foote Lane 3d, son of Dr. Lane 2d of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Ada Childers Lane. The Rev. Harry W. Hansen performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Plainfield.

title: SCHOOLS TAKING OVER B.O.C.E.S. PROGRAMS
description: FACED with the rising cost of educating handicapped students at B.O.C.E.S. centers on the Island, many school districts are now attempting to save money by offering the programs themselves.

title: 2-WEEK VISIT YIELDS DECADE OF FRIENDSHIP
description: ON a sunny morning in July of 1968, a group of children from the Fresh Air Fund were getting off a train at the Syosset railroad station when Sue Isaac approached a skinny little boy and glanced at his name tag, which said Charles Howard.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Men's Clothing At 35-40% Off
description: Despite shifts in shopping patterns to suburban strip development, an established store can opt to remain in the same location but join a discount marketing group to keep up with the competition. Frank Martin and Sons Inc., begun in downtown Stamford as a the men's clothing store in 1892, is still in the same ownership and run by a daughter-in-law and a granddaughter. It is part of a larger merchandising group specializing in designer, conventional and traditional styles in sizes up to 50 extra long at prices always 35 or 40 percent off suggested retail prices, sometimes as high as 60 percent.

title: REAGAN SON PRESSES SEARCH FOR CAREER
description: It was a scene from the recent past: Michael Reagan, the elder son of the President, standing on the front lawn of his home in suburban Sherman Oaks here and explaining to a crowd of reporters that he had not done anything wrong.

title: On Language; NO-NO BOO-BOO
description: As a service to Administration spokesmen, here is an upwrap (an upcoming wrap-up) of verbal boo-boos committed by President Reagan and his men in their first hundred-and-whatever days.

title: Ballet Hispanico to Open Spanish Festival
description: Jose Molina will appear as a guest artist with the Ballet Hispanico of New York on May 28 in the opening program of ''Celebration of the Golden Age of Spain,'' a three-day arts festival dedicated to 16thcentury Hispanic culture.

title: HAWORTH HAILS ONE-LANE BRIDGE
description: HAWORTH THE reopening of a single-lane wooden bridge over Conrail's West Shore Line is being celebrated by the residents of this small community in northern Bergen County.

title: The Nation; On Social Security, A Plan to Touch The Untouchable
description: Whether it jumped or was pushed, the Reagan Administration has nevertheless done something no other Administration has dared to. Last week, perhaps for reasons of principle but certainly because of the requirements of budgetary practice, it proposed reducing Social Security benefits for everyone who enters the nation's old-age retirement system after Jan. 1.

title: CONTINENTAL PERSPECTIVES
description: FAREWELL TO EUROPE By Walter Laqueur. 310 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.95.

title: ARE DANCEGOERS SEEING THE REAL PETIPA?
description: On Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater presents a gala in honor of Marius Petipa, one of the most important choreographers in ballet history.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page last Sunday about Nancy Reagan's social secretary, Muffie Brandon, gave the title of her husband, Henry, incorrectly. He is associate editor and chief American correspondent for The Sunday Times of London.

title: CLEANLINESS GAINS GROUND ON SIDEWALK OF NEW YORK
description: Members of a State Assembly committee looking into street sanitation problems held a hearing yesterday on a dirty midtown sidewalk and were told by sanitation officials, community leaders, environmental experts and passers-by that only stepped-up enforcement of the laws and a more conscientious public would result in a cleaner city.

title:
Economic Affairs;
NO GREAT THREAT FROM MILITARY SPENDING
description: A CENTRAL priority of the Reagan Administration is to rebuild America's crumbling defense establishment, economically and psychologically, over the coming years. The military planners are particularly alarmed at estimates by the Central Intelligence Agency that the Soviet Union is outspending the United States by 50 percent on defense.

title: Beverly Johnson Bride of William Jaques
description: Beverly Elga Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Johnson of Far Hills, N.J., was married in the Princeton University Chapel yesterday to William Lovering Jaques of Dedham, Mass., and Vinalhaven, Me., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Jaques of Wenham, Mass., and Boca Grande, Fla. The Rev. Edward S. Gleason, the Rev. Clark Grew and the Rev. Sarah Motley, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at the Episcopal ceremony.

title: The Nation; The Day They Raided Aeroflot
description: It might not have been a ''criminal, barbarous act,'' as a spokesman for the Soviet Union's Washington embassy claimed, when Federal agents delayed the takeoff of a Soviet airliner last week to suddenly seize some electronic cargo. But unless the Administration was attempting to make a diplomatic point - and the White House denied that was the case - it did appear to be a case of overkill by the United States Customs Service.

title: PROPOSAL FOR STUDY OF PLANT SHUTDOWNS
description: FOR Edward SanAngelo, 46, who was laid off two years ago by Uniroyal Inc. in Naugatuck, survival means living on borrowed money and the hope that someday he will find another job.

title: COURT RULES FOR RYE IN DEVELOPMENT SUIT
description: THE town of Rye, challenged by Harrison and Greenwich, Conn., has won the first legal skirmish over a proposed development of offices and conference space south of the Westchester County Airport.

title: REAGAN RESPONDS QUICKLY TO THE WALL STREET SKEPTICS
description: Contemporary economic history repeated itself unexpectedly last week as President Reagan reversed field on the proposal for deep income-tax cuts that he has embraced since the 1980 campaign. No sooner had his aides begun savoring their impressive budget victories on Capitol Hill than they began talking urgently among themselves about having to compromise on their tax program.

title: IRAN SAYS IT PENETRATED IRAQI DEFENSES AT ABADAN
description: Iran said that it broke through Iraqi defenses around the oil city of Abadan today and recaptured a strategic road held by Iraq for more than seven months.

title: MAILBOX
description: To the Sports Editor: Again, the fan pays and suffers. In an effort to have the basketball season shortened, Larry O'Brien expedited the playoffs and championship series and required the players to play every other day.

title: FASTER RAIL SERVICE BETWEEN LONDON AND THE CONTINENT
description: A new program designed to speed travelers between London and four cities in Europe - Paris, Brussels, Amsterdam and Cologne - has been launched by British Rail in conjunction with European railways.

title: Children's Books
description: LITTLE LITTLE By M. E. Kerr. 183 p New York: Harper & Row. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By MARILYN KAYE

title: Alaska Bonanza
description: Alaska's coffers were so bulging with oil and other mineral royalties, that the state announced a treasury giveaway in April 1980.

title: THE SANDWORM SAGA
description: GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE By Frank Herbert. 411 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95.

title: Article 122153 -- No Title
description: A Vermont woman has been awarded $1.3 million in damages for an injury she received in 1978 on the Saw Mill River Parkway when she tried to avoid an animal, lost control of her car and hit a guard rail in Chappaqua, N.Y. The woman, 28-year-old Marian Horton of Danby, Vt., had testified that the rail penetrated the car and severed her left leg below the knee.

title: 2 Inmates Win $6,500 in Jail Suit
description: A Federal judge has approved a jury's award of $6,500 in damages to two inmates who had filed suit over their treatment at the Orange County Jail in Goshen, N.Y. The judge, Abraham D. Sofaer, ruled Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan that $4,000 should go to one of the inmates, Victor Jackson, who had asserted that the jail was negligent in the treatment of his diabetic condition. Judge Sofaer said Charles Meriwether should receive $2,500 on his complaint of inadequate treatment of a gunshot wound. The two prisoners had sought damages of $340,000 and attorneys' fees of $140,000.

title: NEW YORK POLICIES FAULTED IN AUDIT OF GENERAL SERVICES DEPT.
description: The way in which the city buys broom handles, bullets, folding tables and other products should be streamlined to prevent waste and inefficiency, according to a report issued by the City Comptroller's office.

title: CONGRESSIONAL COMMITTEES DIG IN FOR TRENCH WARFARE
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch was upset. ''I chair a committee that I don't think has ever made a cut in its existence,'' the Utah Republican, chairman of the Labor and Human Resources committee, told a House-Senate budget conference last week. ''We're used to adding programs.'' The Senate had nonetheless instructed his committee to approve changes in the law to effect budget cuts totaling $8.8 billion. That means repealing social programs, reducing benefits, tightening eligibility requirements and capping expenditures.

title: AT HOME
description: MY HOST was ecstatic. ''Isn't it fantastic the way that Coop and Bogart have taken to you?'' he said, his eyes misting at the sight of the two Pekinese heads resting on my lap. ''They're good watchdogs, of course, but see how gentle they are.''

title: Eileen Lloyd Smith Wed To Scott Isdale Oakford
description: The marriage of Eileen Lloyd Smith, a sales assistant with the First Boston Corporation in New York, to Scott Isdale Oakford, a credit analyst with the Chemical Bank, took place at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Carleton Lee 3d performed the ceremony.

title: DISPUTE ON ACCESS ROILS GEORGICA POND
description: EAST HAMPTON ON paper, the people of East Hampton Town own Georgica Pond, an ecologically fragile, 290-acre coastal pond surrounded by some of the most expensive real estate on the Island. Along with everything else ''from sea to sea,'' it became theirs in perpetuity back in 1651, when, three years after the town was founded, the original settlers bought the land from the Governors of the New Haven and Connecticut Colonies, who had purchased it from the Indians.

title: Miss Waugh Wed To Stephen Moore
description: Sarah Goodhue Waugh and Stephen Gammons Moore were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., by the Rev. Edward R. Danks.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE upcoming issue of Westchester 60PLUS, the publication distributed to about 100,000 elderly people in the county by the Office for the Aging, will have news of particular interest to older residents of New Rochelle.

title: NEW PRODUCTS
description: Producers of cameras and accessories continue ot produce new products that are of interest to photographers and camera enthusiasts. Here are a few of the latest: The Fujica HD-S "All Weather" CAmera (List $265) is a new concept in compact, lightweight cameras that will be of interest to sports enthusiasts, travelers, and photographers who like to take pictures under any and all weather conditions. This 35mm, autoexposure camera has a built in electronic flash and is completely sealed to protect it against drenching rain, sleet, snow and blowing dust or sand. A big, bright optical finder shows zone-focusing symbols while the camera is at the eye-level viewing postion, making it possible for the photographer to change focus without taking his eye away from the finder. The programmed electronic shutter automatically sets itself for continous speeds of from 1/8th to 1/500th of a second, and a shutter lock prevents accidental shutter release. Although not an underwater camera, the HD-S is completely water-resistant. Built-in 'O' rings and silicone rubber packing around all moving joints keeps out water and dust, while resin/ fiber materials serve to shockproof the camera. All this makes it an ideal instrument for such outdoor sports as swimming, fishing, boating, backpacking, and camping in all kinds of weather. Minolta Auto-Meter III (List $175) is a dual-function exposure meter for measuring both incident and reflected light. Despite the proliferation of cameras with built-in exposure meters, there are conditions which still require hand-held meters for accurate metering of light, and the Auto-Meter III is unlike any hand-held exposure meter now on the market.

title: The World; Berlin Vote Sends Ripples to Bonn
description: The voters, not surprisingly, had local issues on their minds, but last week's election results in West Berlin reverberated throughout West Germany. Attacked from right and left, the scandal-plagued Social Democrats lost control of the Berlin city Parliament for the first time in 27 years.

title: SOMETHING AND OR SOMEONE MUST GIVE- AND VERY SOON
description: Representative James M. Shannon was anxious that no one misinterpret his vote on a relatively modest adjustment in Social Security spending. ''This should not indicate to anybody,'' the Massachusetts Democrat told a House subcommittee last week, ''that I am going to go along with what the President proposed yesterday. I don't like his changes and I don't intend to support them.''

title: U.S. AIDES' UNCERTAINTY ON RULES IS KEEPING THOUSANDS IN ASIA REFUGEE CAMPS
description: United States immigration officials, uncertain of the new legal standard for identifying refugees, have held up the admission of 5,000 to 6,000 people from Indochina who have been stranded for months in refugee camps in Southeast Asia.

title: Other Business; AT G.M., NO MORE MR. NICE GUY
description: DETROIT They are sharpening the ax at General Motors for another round of white collar cutbacks, and the word has gone out from the Fourteenth Floor: This time, no more Mr. Nice Guy. In a sober memorandum to salaried employees in the United States and Canada, G.M.'s vice president for personnel, Stephen H. Fuller, said henceforth layoffs will go by performance evaluations, not seniority.

title: ZOELLER LEADS AFTER A 69-136
description: Fuzzy Zoeller shot a one-under-par 69, despite an ailing back, and took a one-shot lead today in the raindelayed second round of the $300,000 Colonial National Invitation golf tournament.

title: On Addressing Issues in Trials
description: To John Worthley's lament (''Is Legal the Same as Ethical?,'' Opinion Page) that the lawyers in the Joseph M. Margiotta trial were indifferent to the real issue of the case, namely, the ''ethicality'' of both Democrats and Republicans in practicing ''an insurance patronage system'' - and assuming that Mr. Worthley heard all the testimony, the lawyers' arguments, the court's rulings and instructions, and read the documents in evidence and, therefore, is correct in his description of what occurred - I say amen to limiting the trial of Mr. Margiotta to the issue at whether he personally was guilty of violating the particular criminal law sections as charged in the indictment.

title: LIGHTNING FIRES POSE THREAT IN TINDER DRY ROCKIES
description: Colorado's first severe thunderstorm of the season rumbled over the mountains near here last week, filling dry creek beds with a brief but violent cloudburst.

title: FIVE MONTHS IN THE MUSICAL LIFE OF FATS WALLER
description: The mills of the gods could scarcely have ground more slowly than those of RCA Records when they undertook to release ''The Complete Fats Waller.'' When Volume One of this series appeared in 1975 on RCA's Bluebird label, it was part of an ambitious reissue project that involved not only ''Complete'' reissues (''complete'' in the sense that they would include everything the group or performer recorded for RCA) of several major Swing Era big bands but individual albums by lesser bands (George Hall, Richard Himber), by pop singers such as Dick Todd, by jazz groups (Sidney Bechet), by country artists (the Monroe Brothers, the Blue Sky Boys), and by blues (Tampa Red) and Western groups (Bill Boyd and His Cowboy Ramblers).

title: CONSUMER RATES
WITHOUT HOOPLA, AN EXTRAORDINARY SHOW IN PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON SINCE art has become show business, it has predictably adopted the flashy and free-wheeling technique of show business. Artists are idolized as stars, with preposterous myths and legends growing about them, while curators, gallery dealers and museum directors behave like impresarios.

title: Court Curb on Publication Of Principal's Files Dropped
description: A court order barring publication of information from a suspended school principal's personnel file was dropped here today after the educator's attorney said his client no longer needed the prohibition.

title: Royals, on 6-Run 4th, Defeat Red Sox, 7-6
description: Willie Aikens and Hal McRae led a six-run fourth inning with consecutive homers and the Kansas City Royals held on today to score a 7-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: STUDY FINDS AID CUTS THREATENING CITIES WITH FISCAL CRISIS
description: More than half of all cities of more than 10,000 people are spending more for operating expenses than they are taking in, according to a Congressional study, and the sudden drop in Federal aid expected next fall will reduce services further and put more municipal governments ''on the brink of fiscal collapse.''

title: THE SUBURBS: BIG ENOUGH FOR SUBURBS OF THEIR OWN
description: RUTH WOLK, who is 70 years old and still smiling, remembers Woodbridge Township in the years before World War II, when it was just a collection of sleepy villages and farms along U.S. 1 and State Routes 27 and 35.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, MAY 17, 1981
description: International The Saudi royal family's influence with Syria was another strategy taken taken by Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy to the Middle East, in his efforts to prevent a war between Israel and Syria over the Syrian missile emplacements in Lebanon. He went to Riyadh to urge the royal family to help maintain peace in the Middle East. Meanwhile, Syria again refused to remove its missiles from Lebanon's Bekaa Valley, which Israel threatens to destroy. (Page 1, Column 6.) Japan's Foreign Minister resigned as a result of a dispute over the degree of Japanese military cooperation with the United States, in which the Prime Minister is accused by Foreign Ministry officials of taking an ambiguous stand. Prime Minister Zenko Susuki appointed Sunao Sonoda, to succeed Masayoshi Ito. Mr. Sonoda, who was the Health and Welfare Minister in the Susuki Cabinet, was a former Foreign Minister. (1:2.)

title: The Drawbacks Of Cross-Endorsement
description: In the Long Island Journal, it was reported that the Suffolk County Democratic chairman, Dominic J. Baranello, and the Suffolk County Republican chairman, Anthony Prudenti are close to agreement on ''the creation of new judgeships for the county, and a bipartisan split of the judicial spoils.'' It was also stated that ''the solution will likely be that the Democrats and Republicans will split 10 of the judgeships evenly.''

title: SYRACUSE JUDGE FIGHTS CHARGES OF MISCONDUCT ON BENCH
description: A City Court judge disclosed this week that he had been charged by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct with 206 violations of judicial behavior rules. The alleged misconduct includes bias, verbal abuse of defendants and failure to advise defendants of their rights.

title: THE CIVILIZED SOUND OF BARBARA CARROLL
description: BARBARA CARROLL never thought her piano would need a modifier. ''To me, a piano is a piano, but in today's terminology, I have to call it acoustic, as opposed to electronic,'' she said, with amused resignation.

title: THE PITFALLS IN MOVING A CORPORATION
description: FOR nearly two decades suburban towns and cities in Fairfield and Westchester Counties have been wooing industry -especially ''clean'' industry - away from the New York City area. This siren song is still heard today, but few corporate executives even begin to imagine how complex it has become to shift a manufacturing or headquarters facility to the suburbs.

title: FILM-VIDEO SUCCESS AT THE THORPE
description: SPARKILL ''INSTALLATIONS: Films, Video'' involves more than technological magic, contains items that are absolutely fascinating and is altogether worth the trip to the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery, on Route 340.

title: LAWRENCE MANSION PROVES A COSTLY GIFT
description: LAWRENCE WHEN Rock Hall, a Georgian manor house, was deeded to the Town of Hempstead in 1948 for use as a museum, the town inherited not only an 18th-century home on three acres, but also a host of structural problems.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA ARE AT 'THE EDGE OF A PRECIPICE'
description: Just weeks ago, the possiblity of an Arab-Israeli war seemed remote. Egypt was formally at peace with Israel. A relatively weak Jordan was estranged from Syria, and Syria was at odds with Iraq. Iraq's army was mired in a grinding war with Iran. Israeli forces had never been more powerful or more technologically advanced, the Arabs never so deeply divided. It was difficult to imagine how any Arab state could rationally challenge Israel at such a moment, or how Israel could see any urgent threat in an enemy so thoroughly fragmented.

title: OWNERS AND BROKERS MAKING LOWER-FEE HOME SALES
description: Highly competitive marketplace conditions coupled with concerns about inflation are encouraging a number of sellers and brokers to look for alternative ways to market homes without paying a full brokerage fee.

title: About Long Island
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK HER daughter Andrea was going to get nothing but the best, Elsie Kanner vowed long ago. It was going to be easier for Andrea. Mrs. Kanner never had private art instruction as a young girl. She hadn't attended a fashionable artistically oriented school. Because she was married and had three children and taught, she didn't have time to stay home and spend all her time painting or sculpturing.

title: Music Noted in Brief; 'Bamboo Forest,' Fusion Of Jazz and Classical
description: Douglas Ewart is one of the better-known names to have emerged from the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, the newjazz nerve center in Chicago; indeed, he is now chairman of that group. His ''Bamboo Forest,'' an eveninglong collection of pieces, was presented last Thursday for the first of two nights at the Kitchen, and involved two other ''jazz'' musicians - J.D. Parran and Henry Threadgill.

title: Australia Set Back
description: Australia's hopes for making the World Cup soccer tournament were shattered today in a 2-0 qualifying-round loss to New Zealand.

title: Children's Books
description: LESTER'S TURN By Jan Slepian. 139 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By NATALIE BABBITT

title: The 'New' Drinan
description: The word came from the Vatican: ''Politics is the responsibility of laymen, and a priest should be a priest.'' So after 10 years in the House of Representatives, Robert F. Drinan, the liberal Jesuit priest from Massachusetts, gave up his seat last Jan. 1.

title: Hard-Times Town
description: For the second time in four decades, Slick, a once booming Oklahoma oil city of 20,000 residents, appeared down on its fortune. After the oil ran out in the 1940's, Slick shriveled to 171 residents.

title: NEW BUDAPEST CASINO PULLS IN WESTERN CURRENCY
description: A newly opened casino here, Western-equipped and financed, is developing a regular clientele among the non-Hungarian customers who are allowed at the gaming tables and slot machines. "We are quite a new team, people who never worked in places like this," said the manager, 34-year-old Jozsef Somogyi. "In spite of that, we have had no complaints." Installed with the help of Austrian partners at the top of Budpest's Hilton Hotel on the Buda Castle Hill, the casino fers a sweeping view of the of Danube River to anyone looking up from its French roulette tables. Its purpose is to bring in hard Western currency. Business is transacted in West Berman marks at a pace that could instantly wipe out he average Hungarians could afford much gambling in the new casino, were they allowed in Residents of other Soviet-bloc countries are also barred. "For 25 years, we have been fighting against alcoholism in Hungary, bur we have not been successful, "Mr. Somogyi said, "We don't want to get ourselves into a two-front war." So Hungarian gamblers must content themselves, for the time being with horse racing, the national lottery and a national soccer pool. Since its April 25 opening, the Hilton casino has drawn about 200 gamblers a day, officials say, and has pulled in as many as 450 in one day. "Most are from Austria, Yugoslavia, Italy and different Arab countries," Mr. Somogyi said. In its first three weeks, the casino developed a clientele with a nucleus of about 80 seemingly prosperous regulars who, according to Mr. Somogyi, probably" live in Budapest and who prefer the gaming tables to slot machines.

title: G.M. BUCKLES DOWN WITH J'S
description: MARK this down: Thursday is J-day, the day the General really gets serious about the war with Japan. The ''J'' is purely coincidental, of course, standing not for Japan but for the size designation of the new little cars that go on sale four days from now, backed by a General Motors promise that this latest car will be full of world-class quality.

title:
Numismatics;
DEALERS PUT UP A FIGHT
description: Coin dealers throughout the country are joining forces to fight what they regard as excessive regulation by state and local governments. They are doing so in response to the widespread enactment of laws and ordinances which are making the activities of coin and bullion dealers subject to elaborate restrictions.

title: Elsie Wilson, a Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Elsie Dunn Wilson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orme Wilson Jr. of New York, Washington and White Post, Va., was married in New York yesterday to William McIlwaine Thompson Jr., son of Mrs. Thompson of Richmond and the late Rev. Dr. Thompson. The Rev. George W. Wickersham 2d, assisted by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Elizabeth Taylor Is Hospitalized; Play, 'Little Foxes,' Is Suspended
description: Performances of Lillian Hellman's ''The Little Foxes'' were suspended indefinitely yesterday afternoon after its star, Elizabeth Taylor, checked into Lenox Hill Hospital for what might be several days of recuperation from a torn and inflamed rib cartilage.

title: Bobby Unser Grabs Pole for the Indy 500
description: Bobby Unser earned the pole position today for the 65th Indianapolis 500 with a four-lap qualifying run of 200.546 miles per hour at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: No Headline
description: To The Editor:

title: The World; Aid to Angola, Pakistan
description: In other foreign aid votes last week:

title: GREENWICH LOSES DEVELOPMENT ROUND
description: THE Town of Rye, N.Y., challenged by Greenwich and its Westchester neighbor, Harrison, has won the first legal skirmish over a proposed development of offices and conference space south of Westchester County Airport.

title: MICHAEL MAHONEY
description: Question. Dr. Mahoney, you started out as a behavior therapist. What led to your interest in psychoanalysis?

title: No Headline
description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker The Unkindest Cut of All Patrick McDonnell

title: U.S. PRESSES SOUTH AFRICA AIDE ON NAMIBIA
description: A senior State Department official said today that the United States had asked South Africa for a clear ''statement of commitment'' to cooperate in the establishment of independence for South-West Africa.

title: A Footnote On Guide to Fine Living
description: On the Opinion Page, Roseann P. LaManna queried, ''Fine living, where did you go?'' Her superbly conjured article deserves a more appropriate answer than the one given on the 800 number.

title: Bureaucrats
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Teaching Thrift to Bureaucrats'' (March 29), Robert E. Kolson of the University of Chicago proposes to establish a system of monetary incentives to motivate Government employees to eliminate ubiquitous waste and mismanagement. According to his proposals, every Federal employee would receive a percentage of the unspent portion of his agency's authorized budget in addition to his salary and every member of Congress could expect to receive a cash bonus of $1,000 for every $1 billion by which Congressional appropriations fell short of, say, $700 billion.

title: Bridge; DELICATE UNDERPLAY
description: In everyday life those who invent superior products normally give them wide publicity and hope that they will come into general use. But this is not always true of modern weapons systems nor of modern bridge bidding systems, and for the same reason: If it comes to a battle, the side that is better armed will have an advantage.

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC Meredith Monk is best known as a choreographer, but since the late 1960's she has also composed and sung, and her music counts as some of the most interesting on the lower-Manhattan experimental scene. An apparent blend of tribal chanting and minimalist structure, Miss Monk's work usually overlays a simply rocking instrumental base with keening singing.

title: Kyle O'Connor Wed To Thomas Duffy
description: At Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday Kyle O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William O'Connor of Yarmouth Port, Mass., was married to Thomas Michael Duffy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Duffy of Pearl River, N.Y. The Rev. John Wilkinson, chaplain at Iona College, performed the ceremony.

title: Washington; ON TALKING TO THE SOVIETS
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations is just back from Moscow, and so is the Soviet Ambassador to the U.N., Oleg Troyanovsky. They talk from different perspectives, but agree on at least one major impression: that the Soviet leaders are really serious about wanting to talk to the Reagan Administration about their differences.

title: THE INFINITE FLUIDITY OF LANGUAGE
description: EXERCISES IN STYLE By Raymond Queneau. Translated with an introduction by Barbara Wright. 197 pp. New York: A New Directions. Cloth, $12.95; paper, $4.55.

title: COMMUTERS SEEKING TO OBVIATE ROUND 2 OF FARE INCREASES
description: NEWARK THE two-phase, 50 percent fare increase approved last week by NJ Transit will keep the state's commuter rail and bus lines from going bankrupt and, more importantly, will buy time for commuters and state transportation officials to press for additional sources of longrange financing for mass transit.

title: VIETNAM VOICES
description: NAM The Vietnam War in the Words of the Men and Women Who Fought There. By Mark Baker. 324 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95. EVERYTHING WE HAD An Oral History of the Vietnam War by Thirty-three American Soldiers Who Fought It. Edited by Al Santoli. Illustrated. 265 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: Ann M. Heckel, Buyer, Wed to Robert Sommer
description: Ann Mary Heckel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertrand B. Heckel of Dayton, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert Sharp Sommer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nolan B. Sommer of Saddle River, N.J. The Rev. David C. Robisch performed the ceremony at St. Albert the Great Roman Catholic Church in Kettering, Ohio.

title: TURK IS CALLED A PRODUCT OF VIOLENCE IN HIS NATION
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of wounding Pope John Paul II, is a product of the climate of violence that brought Turkey to the brink of a civil war before last September's military takeover.

title: THE TRIUMPH OF COGNITIVE DISSONANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: FAVORITES BEATEN AT BELMONT
description: The fifth running of the Fort Marcy Stakes, a mile-and-a-sixteenth race over the turf at Belmont Park, was run on two fronts yesterday and neither front-runner was ever caught.

title: THE CONTRIBUTIONS OF OLDER STUDENTS ENRICH A CAMPUS
description: THE educational process, both academic and experiential, is being enriched at Westchester Community College, where the learning environment is being expanded by the mature, older students.

title: The World; Kremlin Considered Armed, Dangerous
description: The Reagan Administration continues to sharpen its emphasis on the danger of Soviet military might and aggression. Last week, depicting a Russian bear all the more dangerous because it is wounded, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger tried to win from the NATO allies renewed commitments to increased defense spending and new promises of help in defending Persian Gulf oil sources.

title: HAIG AND RUSSIAN CONFER ON ARMS
description: State Department officials said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had conveyed to the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the NATO decision that Washington should begin talks with Moscow on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: BLACK 'HOMELAND': SHANTIES ON THE VELD
description: Few South Africans have ever heard of this black shantytown in Transvaal, northeast of Pretoria, or of the obscure little state of which it is supposed to be the capital.

title: 'SHIRTLESS ONES' KEEP THE FAITH WITH EVITA PERON
description: She is a legend, the subject of television shows and Broadway musicals, known the world over by her diminitive, Evita. And here, in the country that both bore her and reflects her, she is not dead. Evita Peron lives.

title: HOW AN ISLAND OF DEMOCRACY HAS SURVIVED IN THE AUTOCRATIC WORLD OF
description: MUSIC --------------------------------------------------------------------- Helen Epstein is a writer and professor of journalism at New York University. By HELEN EPSTEIN

title: U.S. Action Will Force Farmers To Hire Own Weather Advisers
description: Farmers in Florida, southern California and Texas will be forced to hire their own weather consultants next winter to predict crop-killing frosts because the Federal Government is eliminating the highly specialized service.

title: 3 CONSERVATIVE DEMOCRATS WARY ON TAX CUT
description: Like most Southern conservatives, Representative Ken Holland backed President Reagan's budget-cutting proposals as they sailed through the House of Representatives. But as Congress takes up the tax bill, the second phase of the President's economic program, the South Carolina Democrat is far more cautious and uncertain.

title: The Nation; List of Victims In Atlanta Grows
description: Whether 17-year-old William Barrett was a victim last week of the killer or killers responsible for Atlanta's awful string of murders was not known. The critical facts, however, were only too clear.

title: WINFIELD'S HITTING IS SILENCING CRITICS
description: The question, with its combination of pride and insecurity, sounds like Mayor Koch's ''How am I doing?'' ''So,'' asks Dave Winfield, ''can I play?'' To date, the answer is a resounding 'yes.' Going into last night's game against Seattle, which the Yankees won, 7-5, Winfield, the latest of the Yankees' million-dollar free agents, was leading the team in several offensive categories, had excelled defensively in left field and as a recent substitute in center field, and was the team's most consistent performer.

title: NEW HEARINGS ASKED ON FORESTS NOMINEE
description: A move is under way among Senate Democrats to try to send the nomination of John B. Crowell Jr. as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture in charge of the United States Forest Service back to the Agriculture Committee when it comes up for debate Tuesday.

title: Kathryn Marie Thoresen Wed
description: Kathryn Marie Thoresen, daughter of Marie Thoresen of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and the late David Thoresen, was married yesterday to Thomas Walker Borland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Borland of Salisbury, N.C. The Rev. William L. Sieburg performed the ceremony at Trinity Lutheran Church in

title: NEW JERSEY'S HISTORIC WATERLOO VILLAGE TURNS BACK THE CLOCK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- IRA HENRY FREEMAN, a former reporter for The Times, is a freelance writer. By IRA HENRY FREEMAN

title: PLEASANT COLONY TURNS IT ON IN STRETCH, WINS PREAKNESS
description: With a final burst of speed in the last few strides, Pleasant Colony added the 106th Preakness today to his Kentucky Derby victory and needs only the Belmont Stakes to become the l2th winner of thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown.

title: NEW ORLEANS MOVES TO CURB MISCONDUCT OF OFFICIALS
description: The New Orleans City Council, at the end of an emotional, 10-hour hearing dominated by allegations of police brutality, voted to establish a new municipal agency to investigate alleged misconduct of city employees, including the police.

title: THE SHAH'S HEALTH: A POLITICAL GAMBLE
description: Lawrence K. Altman, M.D., is the medical correspondent of The Times. By Lawrence K. Altman, M.D. s princes have done since the beginning of kingdoms, the Shah of Iran, from the moment he learned he was seriously ill, chose to treat his illness as much as a matter of state as a medical problem. And from that point of decision by the Shah - a decision to gamble with his health for political ends - flowed a chain of events that dramatically reshaped recent American history and led, all too inevitably, to the 444 days of the hostage crisis.

title: Ideas and Trends; Foundations Cited On Hispanic Grants
description: The logic of philanthropy rarely follows ironbound laws, but two studies of American foundations have discerned a disquieting pattern: Hispanic people, the country's fastest growing minority, have been getting short-shrifted in the granting process. At a news conference attended by Hispanic leaders, the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy last week used these findings to assail foundations.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: REAL SECURITY Restoring American Power in a Dangerous Decade. By Richard J. Barnet. 160 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $10.95.

title: SPRINGTIME IN MOSCOW BRINGS THAT PEPSKI FEELING
description: Russians are wont to have a snatch of verse for most occasions, and when the first thunderstorms of spring swept over Moscow's cupolas and galvanized metal roofs a few days ago the obvious choice was Fyodor Tyutchev's ''I love the thunderstorm in early May when, like a playful child, spring's first thunderclap rumbles in the light blue sky....''

title: RECYCLERS FEAR A PAPER SHORTAGE
description: GARFIELD WHILE New Jersey tries to cope with its ever-growing mounds of garbage, executives in the newspaper-recycling industry are worrying that there may not be enough solid waste to go around.

title: Elizabeth M. Henderson, Photographer, Engaged to Peter B. Hoagland, Sculptor
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Philadelphia and Manchester, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Mason Henderson, to Peter Bush Hoagland, son of Mrs. Stanley M. Cohen of Bridgton, Me., and the late Peter Hoagland. The wedding will take place on Aug. 29 in Manchester.

title: 11 NEW CHARGES FILED AGAINST WESTCHESTER SHERIFF
description: Alfred B. DelBello, the Westchester County Executive, who suspended Sheriff Thomas J. Delaney in February, accused Mr. Delaney yesterday of additional improprieties, including the use of his office to provide special treatment for the singer Engelbert Humperdinck and the improper processing of more than 130 pistol permits.

title: POWER EMERGENCY PLANS FAULTED
description: The nation's electric utility system is ''highly vulnerable'' to major disruption by terrorists or a wartime attack and the Government, despite an investigation after a blackout in New York in 1977, has failed to establish plans to deal with such emergencies, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: Details on 32 Nuclear Accidents With 56 Fatalities Are Released
description: The Pentagon yesterday released details on 32 nuclear accidents that killed at least 56 persons in the last 30 years.

title: SCHROEDER'S 'VALLEY OBSCURED BY CLOUDS'
description: The beginning of Barbet Schroeder's ''The Valley Obscured by Clouds'' finds Viviane (Bulle Ogier) wearing a trim little dress and high heels, traipsing elegantly through the jungle as only a chic Frenchwoman can. The bored wife of a diplomat stationed in Melbourne, she is in New Guinea to buy feathers, which she sells to a Paris boutique.

title: Barbara A. Crunden Married To Jay C. Meyer, a Lawyer
description: Barbara Alison Crunden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren C. Crunden of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Christopher Meyer, son of Ruth T. Meyer and the late Joseph N. Meyer of Cincinnati. The Rev. Earl Pratt performed the ceremony at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT was an afternoon made of memories, some as fragile as the bouquet of lilacs on the porch, others as lasting as the lake on whose shores the cottage perched. Twenty former Girl Scouts, in their 50's and 60's now, and one former Girl Scout leader - their leader - were gathered for the first time in more than 40 years, to share the past and compare notes on the present.

title: ISLANDS FROM SPOIL PROPOSED FOR SOUND
description: KINGS POINT A PROPOSAL to use contaminated sediments dredged from the bottoms of Connecticut harbors as fill to create islands and salt marshes in Long Island Sound will be discussed at a public hearing on Thursday at the United States Merchant Marine Academy.

title: FOR AMERICA, A PAINFUL REAWAKENING
description: Steven R. Weisman is a White House correspondent for The New York Times. By Steven R. Weisman or fourteen and a half months, it was a nightmare that preoccupied the nation, shook its confidence and turned its people upside down with frustration. And yet, though only four months have passed since the hostages were released, it is almost hard now to remember, much less recapture, the frenzy and emotion the crisis brought forth. It is as if the catharsis of the event has temporarily overwhelmed our ability to consider its impact.

title: Vatican Gets First Ambassador From the Islamic Republic of Iran
description: The first Iranian Ambassador to be appointed to the Vatican since Iran became an Islamic republic arrived today to take up his post.

title: FAMILY MATTERS
description: AMERICAN DAD By Tama Janowitz. 264 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $11.95.

title: 2D DEVICE IS FOUND
description: A 20-year-old man was fatally injured yesterday morning when a bomb exploded in a men's room at the Pan American World Airways Terminal at Kennedy International Airport minutes after a warning had been telephoned by a man who said he represented a Puerto Rican independence group.

title: The Region; Finally, the Last Word From Albany
description: One hundred and thirteen days after it was proposed, 42 days after the law says it should have been enacted and six days after everyone thought it would be, a $16.6 billion budget for the fiscal year which began in April was adopted last week by the New York State Legislature. It was hard to find anyone in Albany who thought it was worth the wait.

title: KENNEDY STILL RUNNING AGAINST THE TIDE
description: During his unsuccessful run for the Presidency, Senator Edward M. Kennedy frequently told voters, ''Sometimes it is necessary to sail against the wind, but we must keep the rudder true.'' He is sticking by his word. While other Democratic voices seem muted or tremulous, the Massachusetts Senator is holding to a liberal course with the doggedness that kept him in the race against Jimmy Carter long after it was hopeless.

title: Lea Stops Giants on 4-Hitter
description: Charlie Lea, in his first start for Montreal since pitching a no-hitter last Sunday against San Francisco, stopped the Giants again today with a 5-0 four-hitter as the Expos snapped a four-game losing streak.

title: GOING FOR THE GREEN IN A NEW YORK FASHION SHOOT
description: H eading down Spring Street, Andrea Alberts assesses the props that urban life offers a fashion photographer. ''The red truck, that's great, and I think we can use the yellow Camero. I don't think we can do anything with the lumber here, do you?'' she asks her assistant, Brad Ensminger, who trails slightly behind holding a reflecting board and a bag with 16 rolls of film.

title: VIOLATIONS CITED AT 34 FOOD PLACES
description: New York City's Department of Health has cited 34 food establishments for what it said were violations of the Health Code. It also named six restaurants that reopened after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for failing to do so.
