title: Sound; 'PERSONAL' STEREO BANISHES BLARE
description: Each May our neck of the Berkshire woods swarms with spring-driven fugitives from the city, trekking along the hiking paths, seeking the bucolic. This year, however, we noticed a welcome difference. Those big, blaring portable radios, formerly considered indispensable to the enjoyment of nature, have largely given way to the more discreet kind of on-the-go sound gear. Thanks to the new ''personal'' pocket stereo which plays through earphones rather than loudspeakers, blare is out and sonic privacy is in.

title: MISSING GUARD AT GREEN HAVEN PRISON IS FOUND SLAIN
description: A guard at a maximum-security prison in upstate Dutchess County was found murdered yesterday in a landfill outside the facility, authorities reported.

title: No Headline
description: The ''Ponte Aerea'' (literal translation: ''air bridge''), which I first flew in 1957 between Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro - a one-hour flight on a DC-3 - well may have been the first real shuttle service anywhere. This is a heavily traveled route, service was every hour on the hour, with extra sections when the traffic required it.

title: HASIDIC GROUP REOPENS A BERGMAN NURSING HOME
description: A long-vacant Staten Island nursing home that figured in 1975 investigations as an interest of Bernard Bergman has reopened with state sanction to be operated by a nonprofit Hasidic organization.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Divertimento by Ross Is Given its Premiere
description: New Music for Young Ensembles offered a curious conglomeration of the recent and the not-so-recent at its chamber-music concert in Carnegie Recital Hall last Thursday evening. Otto Luening and Eleanor Steber were on hand to give William J. Ross his award as co-winner of the organization's 1980 competition, and the winning music - Mr. Ross's Divertimento for Flute, Clarinet, Bassoon, Trumpet and Percussion - had its premiere.

title: Isabel Hyde Married to Jerome Jasinowski
description: Isabel Emily Hyde, daughter of Mrs. de La Grange Hyde and Henry B. Hyde of New York, was married yesterday in Washington to Jerome J. Jasinowski, son of Mrs. Estelle Carlson of La Porte, Ind. United States District Court Judge John H. Pratt performed the ceremony at the F Street Club.

title: Main Pitch From Barker Still a Puzzle to Blue Jays
description: Even after the perfect game pitched against them by Cleveland's Len Barker last night, the Toronto hitters could not figure him out. They called his main pitch a slider, but the right-hander said he did not throw a slider in retiring all 27 Blue Jay batters.

title: Dining Out; SENSE OF THE EXOTIC IN NEW HAVEN
description: NEW HAVEN INDIAN restaurants in Connecticut are almost as rare as banyan trees. This makes the discovery of the Taj Mahal in New Haven a double pleasure: first, to find one at all and, second, to discover that it knows its onions - or curries, as the case may be.

title: TORONTO PAPER TRACES DETAILS OF PLOT AGAINST DOMINICA
description: A Toronto newspaper, exploring the recent attempt by Americans to overthrow the Government of the Caribbean island of Dominica, has uncovered a tale of mercenary intrigue, alleged underworld financial backing and some unusual journalistic practices by a Toronto radio station.

title: 2D RESERVOIR SERVING RATIONED JERSEY AREA OVERFLOWING
description: Another of the reservoirs serving rationed residents of northern New Jersey has started to overflow. The spillage began early today at the Oradell Reservoir - one of four owned by the Hackensack Water Company - after a mild shower that followed two days of intense rain last week.

title: GIVE THE BETTORS LEGAL GAMBLING
description: EVERY day of the year, millions of dollars are bet in the United States on a variety of sporting events. Some of it is wagered at race tracks, jai-alai frontons and Nevada's legalized betting parlors. But untold millions more are wagered illegally with thousands of bookmakers in every part of the country.

title: Sally Childs Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Mabon Childs of Pittsburgh and Old Forge, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sally Frazer Childs, to Alexander Tuck Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Walsh of New York and Chappaquidick, Mass.

title: THE DRUG BUSINESS SEES A GOLDEN ERA AHEAD
description: THE Warner-Lambert Company, a major pharmaceutical concern, earned a respectable 13.3 percent on shareholder investment last year, just a shade below the national average for manufacturers of all stripes. But in the exceptionally profitable pharmaceutical industry, it was an also-ran.

title: The Lively Arts; NOVEL CASTS LIGHT ON THE UNGLORIFIED
description: FIRST novels are often ignored, but when one is written by an author, producer and director who seems to have a direct line to the entertainment and political power elite, it is sure to get a splashy sendoff.

title:
Long Island Housing;
MORTGAGE ILLS CREATE A SELLER'S MARKET
description: A FUNNY thing happened on the way to higher mortgage interest rates: Real estate in Nassau County and western Suffolk became a seller's market, according to brokers.

title: PASSIONATE IMPRESSIONIST
description: THE PRESENCE OF FORD MADOX FORD A Memorial Volume of Essays, Poems, and Memoirs. Edited with an Introduction by Sondra J. Stang. Illustrated. 245 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. $20.

title: INDEX
description: International South Africa's tiny black state suffers from 3 overcrowding The "shirtless ones" keep the faith 7 with Evita Peron In Cambodia's monsoon, Vietnamese troops 9 retrenceh I.R.A. supporters urge south to 10 back Belfast hunger strikers Russian urges peaceful solution to 13 missile crisis in Lebanon Accused assailant is product of 18 Turkey's violence before coup Pope's abdominal pains said to diminish 18 Jailed leader of Spanish coup attempt is hero 19 to rightists Government/Politics Navy Secretary sees U.S. strategy 23 deterring Russians New Orleans forms agency to investigate 25 official misconduct Michael Reagan again explaining his 29 troubles Conservative Democrats hint opposition 32 to Kemp-Roth Black Caucus bill sets penalties 43 for rights violators General Fires resulting from lightning 26 pose threat in the Rockies Court fights continue on role of 27 women in Jaycees Around the nation 28 Garwood is found not guilty of sexually 28 molesting a girl Police warn 5 banks to curb false 47 alarms Hasidic group reopening a Bergman 48 nursing home Sailors in New York ports aided by 50 147-year-old institute Industry/Labor President of miners' union rejects 28 companies' new proposal Arts/Entertainment Speculum Musicae at Symphony 57 Space New York's share of arts and humanities 58 grants increases "Bread and Roses" at St. Peter's 60 MacMillan's "Concerto" revived 60 by Ballet Theater Style New French guide to New York 62 City stirs controversy News Analysis Drew Middleton discusses the U.S. Army 11 in Germany

title: Karen Clemens, Writer, Married to Sean Kernan
description: Karen Clemens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Leroy Clemens of Elgin, Ill., was married yesterday in Stony Creek, Conn., to John Devereux Kernan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kernan of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. David Duncomb, chaplain of the Yale Medical School, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: ULSTER'S MAJORITY-BY-GERRYMANDER
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 'LA BAYADERE'
description: Natalia Makarova's staging of the 19th-century Russian extravaganza ''La Bayadere,'' performed last Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is, first of all, enormous fun. And its cast played up that aspect, generally dancing with the kind of sparkling - and enduring - conviction that has become a hallmark of this season. ''La Bayadere'' is crammed, too, with ensemble and solo dances that ingeniously advance the plot and also stand on their own choreographically.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS: OTHER VIEWS IN THE DEBATE
description: SUPERINTENDENT Cande's article ignores two fundamental issues. The first is whether the state or the parents have the right to determine the type of education their children get. Associated with the issue is the constitutional position of the public school system.

title: Leftists Protest in West Berlin
description: Hundreds of leftists, some hurling stones and paint, shouted antimilitary slogans today and carried banners demanding ''Americans Go Home!'' during the annual parade by American, French and British occupation troops. The police arrested 53 demonstrators. The groups urged disarmament and an end to the occupation, in effect since the end of World War II.

title: HOSTELING AFTER 60
description: ''IT'S like a camp,'' Ilse Shafer said. ''You're constantly running from course to course, asking each other if you've read your assignments.''

title: A PUBLIC PERSON
description: JAVITS The Autobiography of a Public Man. By Jacob K. Javits with Rafael Steinberg. Illustrated. 528 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $16.95. By MAURICE CARROLL

title: GRANDPARENTS IN ROLE OF FRESH AIR HOSTS
description: ''I JUST thought that it was about time that older people took in these youngsters,'' Marian Gottlieb said, explaining why she and her husband, Edward, were hosts last summer for a Fresh Air Fund child. ''We wanted to show people that grandparents are also willing to get involved.''

title: Robin Laven, Actress, Bride Of Stewart F. Lane, Producer
description: Robin Laven, daughter of Col. George Laven Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Laven of Hertzalia, Israel, was married yesterday in Rockford, Ill., to Stewart F. Lane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Lane of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Robert Orkand and Rabbi Robert S. Widom of Great Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.

title: The Nation; Back to the Country But Not to the Land
description: Along with an accounting of the population's vital statistics, the 1980 census provided a striking portrait of the United States as a country in motion. According to recently released data and independent analyses of what the numbers mean, the population of rural areas grew faster than that of metropolitan areas for the first time since the census of 1820.

title: AT A BRITISH CLUB, CREAKY DOORS OPEN FOR WOMEN
description: The 145-year-old Reform Club, from which the mythical Phileas Fogg began his 80-day trip around the world, has embarked on a similarly solitary but real-life adventure of its own: it has decided to begin admitting women.

title: EX-POLICEMAN GIVEN 3 TO 9 YEARS FOR HIS PART IN A QUEENS ROBBERY By The Associated Press
description: A former police officer has been sentenced to three to nine years in prison for providing a gun, acting as lookout and driving the getaway car in the robbery of a Queens travel agency in 1979.

title: NEW FRENCH GUIDE TO NEW YORK CITY STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: The new Gault Millau Guide to New York, which came out three weeks ago, has already drawn considerable controversy. Even though it is available only in French, the book has already sold more than 2,000 copies at $19.95 each at the Librarie de France. At the Alliance Francaise it is going for $12 a copy.

title: A GUIDE TO SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVALS
description: ALASKA FESTIVAL - Anchorage, Sept. 8-15.

title: POPE'S DOCTORS SAY RECOVERY CONTINUES
description: Three days after he was felled by an assassin's bullets, Pope John Paul II was still running a slight fever today, and his physicians said they could not say when he would be taken off the critical list.

title: THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM UNDER ASSAULT
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING THE MILITARY ROUTE
description: Drew Middleton is The New York Times's military correspondent. By Drew Middleton fter five months of fruitless negotiations to free the American hostages, Jimmy Carter decided to interrupt the diplomatic approach in favor of direct action. On April 11, 1980, at a meeting of the National Security Council in the White House, he took the decision to ''lance the boil'' of American frustration, as National Security Adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski put it, with a daring rescue raid on the United States Embassy compound in Teheran (see operation map on following pages).

title: HISTORICAL SOCIETY UNVEILS 'ORIGINAL MOON'
description: WHILE poring through the archives of the Hastings Historical Society recently, trustees paid special attention to a large package labeled ''This is the original moon.''

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Gary Klein Performs 6 Debussy Piano Preludes
description: Gary Klein, a pianist from Wyoming who made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, waited until the second half of his program to show his most attractive assets. In six Preludes by Debussy, his nice ear for sound and good musical instincts graced not only the familiar ''La Cathedrale Engloutie,'' but also lesser-known masterpieces such as ''Ondine'' and ''La Puerta del Vino.''

title: Fachion
description: uf7629 SHOWING OFF SUNTANS This is the time of year when store racks are filled with swimsuits for sun worshippers, who any day now will head for beaches, backyards, poolsides and rooftops in quest of tans.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
For Quality Produce And Deli, Turco's
description: The Westchester Department of Consumer Affairs reported a slight drop in April for the 41 market-basket items it surveys at 16 supermarkets, a price pattern that began after January's high. Even so, county residents who developed defensive buying patterns at specialized stores may not go back to former ways.

title: The World; Mitterrand Breaks De Gaulle's Spell On French Voters
description: Franc,cois Mitterrand, an old pro, convinced his countrymen last week that alternance - an alternative -was possible, after 23 years of conservative French Presidents that began with Charles de Gaulle. Mr. Mitterrand, who built the Socialists into France's largest party, from a low of 5 percent of the 1971 vote, exploited seven years of accumulated complaints ranging from President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's haughty style to pocketbook issues, splitting the conservatives and winning a solid 52 percent majority.

title: CLASSIC FIGHT IS ON TO BE U.S. ATTORNEY
description: By States News Service WASHINGTON THE race for New Jersey's next United States Attorney is shaping up as a classic case of political infighting. ''It's a battle over personalites, not over who's going to be the next U.S. Attorney,'' a Congressional observer said last week.

title: HOLLYWOOD'S SNEAKY WAY OF TESTING FILMS
description: DALLAS For the last hour, the seven executives have sat silent and glassy-eyed in front of the television golf match. No one is drinking the beer or eating the sandwiches or taking a shower with the perfumed soap. At 4 P.M. on an afternoon last April, the expensive Dallas hotel room might as well be the Sahara Desert.

title: OIL TECHNOLOGY FROM MIDDLETOWN
description: MIDDLETOWN THE photographs on the office walls show offshore oil wells at work in the Gulf of Mexico and the North Sea, and the reception room's reading matter runs heavily to magazines about the petroleum industry. But there is no mistake. The offices, engineering laboratories, and assembly line of Teleco Oilfield Services Inc. are here, not in Houston.

title: Gayle Garland Wed To W. H. Simpson
description: Gayle Imogen Scott Garland and William Howard Simpson were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Pittsburgh. The Revs.

title: Other Business; DELTA PULLS OUT OF PEANUTS
description: ATLANTA After years of serving peanuts, Delta Air Lines is quietly phasing in pretzels as its standard in-flight snack. The change is certainly against grain for a Georgia-based airline, Bill Berry, a Delta spokesman, acknowledged, but the peanut shortage has come home to the big buyer as well as the small muncher.

title:
Antiques;
SOLID QUALITY AT MODERATE PRICES
description: SHARON THE auction next Saturday of the contents of the home of the late William F. Buckley Sr. will be one of the most spectacular yard sales ever held in Connecticut. Large, peaked-top yellow and white striped tents will be set up on the lawn of Great Elm, the Buckley family estate, for the comfort of the audience. The affair will be catered.

title: PRUDENTIAL PROJECT INCLUDES 'ICE POND'
description: A collaboration between one of the country's largest commercial developers, a leading architectural firm and Princeton University is expected to reduce the energy used by a conventional suburban office building to about one-sixth of what was required prior to the 1973 energy crisis.

title: Theater in Review; 'SLEUTH': A DUEL WITHOUT DAZZEL
description: ROBERT MOSS'S staging of ''Sleuth'' is the final production of Playwrights Horizons at the Theater-in-the-Park in Queens, and it's a pity the exit cannot be grander. For grandiosity - sheer bravado - is what ''Sleuth'' is about.

title: Design; AN ARTFUL RETREAT BY THE MEDITERRANEAN
description: One fine, sunny day in 1930, an elderly gentleman wearing a pincenez and a small mustache burst into a printer's small shop in Cannes, France. ''Maurice Chevalier is singing at a gala and no one can print my program,'' excitedly said the man, an artist.

title: HISTORICAL ANALOGY
description: THE MEETING AT TELGTE By Gunter Grass. Translated by Ralph Manheim. Afterword by Leonard Forster. 147 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

title: Collegiate Chorale Sings Bach Motet and Rossini
description: The Collegiate Chorale sang Bach and Rossini at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening, exhibiting most of the virtues and faults that visit large amateur singing groups. The Collegiate's rich, if somewhat amorphous sound cast a pleasant textural haze over most of the evening, but the contrapuntal delicacies of Bach's motet ''Jesu, Meine Freude'' tended to disappear within the choir's tuttis, and the soporific pacing of Robert Bass, the conductor, slowed the music's momentum.

title: POSTAL AIDE: FACILITY WOULD RUIN STREET
description: STAMFORD ''IF I'm right, I'm going to holler,'' said Beatrice McCargo. ''If I'm wrong, then I'll shut up.'' Mrs. McCargo believes she is right in saying that plans by the United States Postal Service to build a huge mail-processing facility a block from her home would ruin the quiet environment of the neighborhood, and she has done more than holler.

title: Dance View; BARYSHNIKOV'S 'GISELLE'
description: The first of the full-length 19th-century ballets revised by Mikhail Baryshnikov for American Ballet Theater's current season at the Metropolitan Opera House has been ''Giselle'' - a production that will be given again this week with new casts. What is terribly right about this version can be grasped by looking at the picture on this page. The scene is from Act II, where the Wilis - spirits of maidens who died before their wedding day - induct Giselle into their ghostly sisterhood. Yet these Wilis look very different from the ones in Ballet Theater's previous staging of ''Giselle'' by David Blair. They have longer white tutus and each woman, with hair parted in the middle, is a replica of Giselle. What is really new is the entire stance of the corps. This is the famous passage where the corps, in several lines, hops across in traveling arabesques. But now the chest is up, the head is straight instead of bowed, and there is a strong use of the shoulders.

title: Investing; ARE BONDS TODAY'S BEST BUY?
description: T HE bond markets have never been more bewildering than in the last two years. Rapid changes of interest rates, which are now near record high levels, have led to alternating periods of immense profits when yields declined and even greater losses when yields rose again to new highs.

title: AREA ARCHITECTS AND PROJECTS WIN AWARDS
description: Three New York architects and three projects in New York City and State were among this year's winners of the American Institute of Architects honor awards, the profession's highest design recognition in the United States. The awards will be presented this week in Minneapolis and St. Paul at the A.I.A. national convention.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR U.N. ENERGY PARLEY
description: The development of new ways of conserving energy, and of deriving energy from untapped resources through conversion, has given impetus and importance to a United Nations Conference on New And Renewable Sources of Energy to be held in mid-August in Nairobi, the capital of Kenya.

title: MYSTIC RESIDENTS FIND ARCADE UNAMUSING
description: MYSTIC CONTROVERSY is not entirely foreign to this picturesque old whaling port, but it has usually taken on rather mild forms. Some years ago, for example, a mild furor developed over a proposal to establish a boardwalk along the waterfront off Gravel Street, near the stately ''captain's houses'' overlooking the shoreline.

title: CONDITION OF CARDINAL WYSZYNSKI IS SAID TO WORSEN
description: The condition of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who has ruled the Polish Roman Catholic Church as Primate since the Communists came to power, was reported to be failing today. He is said to be afflicted with cancer.

title: FRIENDLY TOWN HOSTS FUFILL THEIR WISH TO SHARE
description: Although they were just eight months out of New York City themselves and work on the house they had built here in Westchester County was not complete, Joe and Pam Provetto and their 5-year-old son, Christian, made room last summer for an 8-year-old Brooklyn child they had never met.

title: Television Week
description: Second Thoughts When the United States Embassy was seized in Iran in late 1979, six Americans escaped from the compound, were hidden by the Canadian ambassador and his staff and then smuggled out of the country. The story will be recounted in ''Escape From Iran: The Canadian Caper,'' on CBS on Sunday evening at 8.

title: Ideas and Trends; IN COLOMBIA, SCIENCE SHOWS SOWS SEEDS OF HOPE FOR THE HUNGRY
description: The grassland spreads for hundreds of miles, its two million acres spilling over from eastern Colombia through Venezuela and into Brazil. The pickup truck rides over the hard red earth as if it were Route 66, though neither roads nor farmers have ever cut into this land. ''One day, it will all be under production,'' Jim Spain told a recent visitor. The tall, Texas-born soil scientist is in a position to do more than dream. He oversees much of the research at this remote experimental station. Located some 300 miles east of Bogota, it is proving to be one of the strongest hopes for reprovisioning the world's dwindling food supply.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
SPRINGTIME HAS RETURNED ONCE MORE TO 'BIG MAGIC'
description: SPRINGTIME has returned to Big Magic. The earth, water and pine smells are back, the bugs are buzzing and anticipation grips you every time you drop your line into the water.

title: COURT FIGHTS CONTINUE ON WOMEN'S ROLE IN JAYCEES
description: In response to a Federal District Court inquiry, the Minnesota Supreme Court held last week that under state law the United States Jaycees were prohibited from excluding people from full membership on the basis of sex.

title: A SPECTACULAR YARD SALE
description: SHARON AT one time the stately old mansion rang with the laughter of 10 children and their steady stream of young guests. But the children grew up - one to become a United States Senator and another, an author, editor and television personality. Most of the children moved away and produced large families of their own.

title: REFORMING THE MARINES
description: A 1976 Brookings Institution study described the Marine Corps as ''a force in search of a mission'' - an accurate description, at that time. United States defense policy was focused on Europe, an area dominated by large-scale land armies where the Marines could make little contribution.

title: Pontiff Sends a Message To 2 Wounded Women
description: Pope John Paul II has sent a personal getwell message to the two women who were wounded in the assassination attempt on the Pontiff, a spokesman for the women said today.

title: WIDOW OF SUN YAT-SEN GIVEN FULL MEMBERSHIP IN PARTY
description: Sun Yatsen's widow, Soong Ching-ling, who is critically ill with leukemia, has been granted full membership in the Chinese Communist Party, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: Other Business; NEW IRISH SUCCESS: LA CREME DE LA CREME
description: The usually conservative liquor business, where products can take up to 30 years to gain a loyal consumer following, is witnessing an explosive growth in cream liqueurs, a category which did not even exist in this country prior to 1979.

title: BILL TORREY: ARCHITECT OF HOCKEY'S BEST TEAM
description: B ILL TORREY resembles the Wizard of Oz as he stands in front of a flashing console during a game at the Nassau Coliseum, his bow tie bobbing madly as he waves his arms and screams, or pounds a table as he oversees other people's lives.

title: STEADY INCREASE IN GAMBLING PROMPTS LAWMAKERS TO HELP THOSE HOOKED ON
description: IT By DICK DAVIES

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
POLE VAULT MEMORIES: THE JOY OF LEAPING MEANT SO MUCH
description: OF all track and field events, perhaps none holds more magical allure than the pole vault. As a youth, vaulting was as dear to me as a cotton blanket is to a baby. And therein lay the problem: I got too wrapped up.

title: Steeds Takes 1,500 In Princeton Track
description: Paul Steeds of Fairleigh Dickinson won the 1,500-meter run today in the Adidas-Princeton Invitational Track Meet and failed to achieve his goal. Matt Centrowitz finished third and made progress toward his goal.

title: MOVE TO QUIT TRISTATE GROUP COULD BE COSTLY
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT'S move to withdraw from the Tristate Regional Planning Commission could end up costing the state more money than it would save.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW ROLE FOR AN OLD ROADHOUSE
description: THERE is a sophisticated little restaurant up in the hills of Passaic County called, of all things, St. Charlie's. The name is the whimsy of the young owners, Charles Nuzzo and his wife, Andrea Carr.

title: WITH A LITTLE PRACTICE, SPRAY PAINT HAS ITS REWARDS
description: TYPE paint spray ''bombs'' can be great timesavers on many small painting and finishing jobs around the house. They cost more than buying paint in bulk and putting it on with a brush, but when only small quantities are required they save a lot of fuss and mess and come in a wide assortment of colors and finishes. They are ideal for spraying carved, grooved or textured materials (such as wicker or wrought iron), as well as for finishing small pieces of furniture, toys and similar objects which would be a nuisance to paint with a brush.

title: No Headline
description: Judging from Tad Szulc's analysis of United States policy toward Cuba, the Reagan Administration is unaware of the multilateral pressures available to support American policy aimed at controlling arms flow and Cuban foreign adventures. Perhaps it has been forgotten that the American ''quarantine'' of Cuba, which threatened to stop Soviet vessels on the high seas in 1962, was made politically secure by careful attention to the legal framework within which such actions can be justified.

title: No Headline
description: Restraining Cuban Foreign Adventures The bottom-line answer to Tad Szulc's brilliant article ''Confronting the Cuban Nemesis'' (April 5) is that the Reagan Administration is dedicated to preserving the balance of power throughout the world. The Administration considers maintaining a balance of power essential to holding the Soviet Union's ambitions in check.

title: The Week in Business; MONEY SUPPLY UP $3.1 BILLION
description: The money supply increased by $3.1 billion in the first week of May, the Federal Reserve said. The gain was less than many economists had expected and as a result, short-term interest rates receded and bond prices gained. Earlier in the week, the prime rate went to 19 1/2 percent at major banks, up from 19 percent. The stock market plunged on the prime rate increase but gained ground throughout the week on hopes that the interest-rate surge was over. The Dow Jones industrial average, rallying Friday, closed at 985.95, with a net gain of 9.55 on the week.

title: ELIZABETH S. HOWE PLANS JUNE NUPTIALS
description: William L. Howe of Lincoln, Neb., and Jean Storm Howe of Millbrook, N.Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Storm Howe, to Rober David Bewkes, son of Darien Conn., and Wauwinet, Natucket, Mass. A late June wedding is planned.

title: DEALING WITH FRANCE, U.S. WILL WIN SOME, LOSE SOME
description: Francois Mitterrand, France's President-elect, has traveled widely, during the Fourth Republic when he held 11 Cabinet posts, and later as an opposition leader. But one of the countries he knows least is the United States. Even when he was in Washington late last year for a meeting of the Socialist International, he didn't see important American politicians or officials.

title:
Gardening;
INTENSIVE VEGETABLE PLANTING SAVES SPACE
description: WHEN I was a young boy on a farm, the family vegetable garden was at least an acre in size, and that did not include the corn, potatoes, melons, cucumbers, pumpkins and squash planted in the fields alongside the corn. Although the weeds in the rows were controlled by hoeing and hand-pulling, the garden was so large that the space between the rows was cultivated with an ''eagle claw cultivator.'' This device was pulled by a horse, had five digging shovels and could be adjusted to accommodate the spacing between the rows.

title: Brooklyn Runner Excels In Events at Schenectady
description: Nigel Gabriel was the big winner today in the 41st annual Eddy Games on the outdoor Linton High School track. The senior from Boys and Girls High in Brooklyn was first in the 440-yard dash and anchored Kangaroo foursomes to victories in the 440- and 880-yard relays.

title: Long Island Journal
description: WHEN lightning struck Sharon's Inn in Montauk early last week, it hit more than just a charming small hotel on a cliff overlooking the Atlantic Ocean. It (and the subsequent fire that leveled the building) destroyed an architectural and historic landmark, too.

title: Ex-P.O.W. to Head Commission
description: President Reagan yesterday appointed James B. Stockdale as chairman of the commission on White House Fellowships. Mr. Stockdale, who retired from the Navy as a Vice Admiral in 1979, spent eight years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam.

title: Nicolys Hesselman Is Bride
description: Nicolys Arden Hesselman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo William Hesselman Jr. of Sea Cliff, L.I., was married yesterday to Vincent Ralph D'Agostino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent F. D'Agostino of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Stark Jones performed the ceremony in the Roslyn (L.I.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Haig Urges U.S. Action To 'Restrain' Russians
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., delivering a commencement address at Hillsdale College here, said today that the United States ''must act to restrain the Soviet Union and its surrogates.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; That's R-e-a-g-a-n
description: Namedropping isn't a crime, except perhaps socially. But Michael Reagan complained last week that he was being treated like a criminal by the news media, all because he dropped a name in a few business letters.

title: UNSUBSIDIZED BUSES FEEL FARE PRESSURES
description: WHEN NJ Transit's new fares take effect at the end of next month, the corporation's 255,000 daily bus commuters will be paying for 71 percent of the cost of their rides, while the 71,000 people who ride the trains each day will have to cover 44 percent of the true price of their tickets.

title: Connecticut Guide; MAD HATTERS
description: ''Theda Bara,'' a hip-length manequin wearing a feathered headress and mantilla, may be worn as a hat. It was designed by John Rohatsch of New York, and it is one of many wacky hats-as-art to be seen in the first juried show at the Farmington Valley Arts Center in Avon today through June 14.

title: THE VERY MODEL OF A MODERN 'CHORUS GIRL'
description: She first appears on stage in leopard skin bikini pants with bongo drums anchored to each hip and three-foot-long green and gold leaves sprouting from her lower back. The top is a flesh-colored bra with jiggling plastic jungle cat's eyes.

title: Comparing Schools For Handicapped Children
description: As the parent of a student at the Eagle Hill School for learningdisabled students, I was dismayed to read the letter to the editor from David Finkelstein, a social worker at the Lowell School, about the possible forthcoming branch of the Eagle Hill School on Long Island.

title:
Architecture View;
INSIGHTS INTO LE CORBUSIER'S GENIUS
description: In a small industrial town in the south of France, the last work of Le Corbusier is rising slowly: the church at St. Pierre de Firminy. The design of the church was completed before the architect's death in 1965, and construction was begun in 1971 by a group of private sponsors. The building is now about 40 feet out of the ground, with two-thirds of its concrete shell in place, and another 60 feet - the rest of the conical tower and dome - still to go. About $2 million has been contributed for the work thus far, with $1 million more needed, which the sponsors are hoping to raise in this country.

title: PAINT USE IS LINKED TO ARTIST'S CANCER
description: A mortality study of artists who devoted lifetimes to working with solvents and pigments that may have contained known or suspected toxic substances has revealed a greater number of deaths than expected from some types of cancer, according to scientists at the National Cancer Institute.

title: Ages of Violence
description: The world is sick, sick, sick. - Anna Pietrangelo, who lives in Rome, near St. Peter's Square.

title: Politics; TRAPPINGS OF AN ACT OF CONGRESS
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly is beginning to act more like Congress every day. Last week a conference committee of the State Senate and House of Representatives put together a package of tax increases, which was passed, to balance the state budget of nearly $3 billion for the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: CONNER IS BUILDING TWO YACHTS FOR CUP
description: Dennis Donner, the America's Cup champion, will seek to defend the cup again in 1983. And to prepare for the onslaught of more than 10 challenger, Meter yacht and select the fastest one for the defender's trials. With a record number of challengers anticipated the competition is rising to a new level of intensity. The lure for the challengers is to Break the longest winning streak in sports -America's 130 year grasp on the cup. And for the defenders, the pressures increase to do everything possible not to be the first to lose it. To this end,Conner's syndicate now becomes the first American effort to invest in two new yachts. The initial budget for the campaign is approximately $3 million. Rear Adm. Sheldon H. Kinney, president of the Maritime College Foundation at Fort Schuyler, which supports the syndicate, said one new yacht is to be designed by Sparkman & Stephens. Under the direction of Olin Stephens S. & S. has designed all five 12-meter cup defenders. The second yacht will be designed by 32-year-old Johan Valentijn, a former S.&S. designer who later designed France 3 and co-designed Australia, the 1980 challenger. Valentijn, who lives in Newport . R.I., intends to give up his Dutch nationality to become an American citizen, since the rules for the cup now require the designer to a national of the country the yacht represents.. George F. Jewett Jr. , of San Francisco, and Edward du Moulin of Sands Point, L.I., will organize and direct the 1983 cup program.

title: Miss Meyers Has 65, Shares Jersey Lead
description: Pat Meyers, who has only one victory in 117 tournaments in her six years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot an eight-under-par 65 today to earn a share of the lead in the second round of the Coca-Cola tournament.

title: Which Way Now for The French Economy
description: PARIS W ITH characteristic impulsiveness, the French business community and financial markets greeted Francois Mitterrand's election last Sunday as next President of France as a dire setback for the French economy. But the outburst of Gallic gloom seems premature and, in the event, may prove unwarranted.

title: Abroad At Home; WHAT KIND OF COUNTRY ARE WE?
description: Secretary of State Haig had a closed meeting last week with the House Foreign Affairs Committee, a general discussion of policy. In the course of it there was an extraordinarily revealing exchange.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: G.O.P. ISSUES VIEWS ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Republican officeholders, plainly troubled by public reaction to President Reagan's proposed cuts in future Social Security benefits, today challenged Democrats to come up with something better, but stopped far short of clear support of the full Administration plan.

title: Contract Agreement Settles Philadelphia Transit Strike
description: Suburban bus and trolley drivers today approved a new two-year contract that includes a 12.5 percent salary increase, settling a 44-day strike that shut down transit service for an estimated 35,000 daily commuters west of Philadelphia.

title: Antiques; QUILTS REVEAL A COMPLEX ART
description: Piecing together the story of quilts stitched in 19th-and early 20th-century America has become a task more complex than anyone suspected when the revival of interest began more than a decade ago. Now, after dozens of exhibitions, it is obvious that at least one more presentation is necessary for a full appreciation of the zenith of this folk art.

title: Belgium Settles Disputes That Threatened Coalition
description: Prime Minister Marc Eyskens of Belgium announced today that his Government had agreed on a set of economic measures and had settled disagreements that threatened to topple his five-week-old center-left coalition.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER When Shelagh Delaney wrote ''A Taste of Honey'' in the late 1950's, she was still in her late teens. Like so many first plays, Miss Delaney's drama was unmistakably autobiographical: It told the story of a teen-aged girl who somehow survives her impoverished, loveless Lancashire childhood with wit and courage.

title: Italian, 17, Is Kidnapped
description: Five armed men wearing masks yesterday kidnapped Alberto Sfinco, 17-year-old son of an agricultural supplier, the police here reported today.

title: Long Islanders; HE GUIDES STUDENTS THROUGH THE LABYRINTHS OF TRANSITION
description: ''ONE end of the spectrum is formal language instruction. The other end is a lecture by a police officer on how to walk the streets without being hurt and what are the normal security precautions one ought to take in the city.

title: Voting by Mail Rated Successful
description: San Diego's special election by mail was so successful that the method should be used in the municipal primary in September, says the San Diego County registrar of voters. Ray Ortiz said the recent mail election, the biggest in the nation's history, cost $200,000 less than one using ballot boxes.

title: Hampshire College
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie G. Rowland Wed To William E. Jacques
description: Leslie Gail Rowland and William Edward Jacques were married yesterday in the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. C. Michael Thornburg.

title: WHAT'S THE BIG ATTRACTION, ANYWAY?
description: WHY are so many people interested in running for Governor of New Jersey this year? Is it because a candidate in the primary, on first raising and spending $50,000 in private contributions, is now eligible (for the first time) to receive public matching funds to assist him in financing his campaign, as a number of politicians, reporters and others recently have alleged? Or are there other reasons why 14 candidates announced for the Democratic nomination and eight for the Republican (plus 11 independents)?

title: ON THE TRAIL OF THE ELUSIVE MOREL
description: THE rites of spring are plentiful. There's Easter and Passover, May Day and Mother's Day, the start of baseball season. But to the 45 members of the Connecticut/Westchester Mycological Association who assembled last weekend, there is only one rite of any significance: the morel hunt.

title: Elizabeth Barrett Fiancee of A. P. Matson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York and Water Mill, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Esther Barrett, to Alexander Paul Matson, son of Prof. and Mrs. Wallace Matson of Berkeley, Calif.

title: At Home
description: MY host is ecstatic. ''Isn't it fantastic, the way Coop and Bogart have taken to you?'' he says, his eyes misting at the sight of the two Pekingese heads resting on my lap. ''They're good watchdogs, of course, but see how gentle they are.'' He shrugs and laughs. ''I used to think people who ranted on about their dogs were nuts,'' he says, passing the hors d'oeuvres. ''Now, well, I guess it's a case of love me, love my dogs. Here, have one while it's hot.''

title: The Region; The City Budget: It's Balanced, It's Provident, It's 1981
description: If politicians have their own version of the old adage about saving, it probably substitutes ''election year'' for ''rainy day.'' Thus few City Hall hands were surprised last week when Mayor Koch proposed a 1982 budget that promised expanded municipal services, no new taxes and yet would be balanced, thanks to a 1981 budget surplus of $243 million.

title: Barbara Gallagher Engaged to Marry Frank Erickson Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gallagher of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Faith Gallagher, to Frank J. Erickson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Erickson of Windham, N.Y., formerly of Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Bossy: Scorer With Touch of an Artiste
description: HE'S a gazelle that gorillas revere, a concert pianist that rock stars envy, a philosopher that hitmen fear. In a sometimes cruel and crashing sport that often resembles a survival of the fittest, Mike Bossy not only survives, but he also flourishes as no other hockey goal-scorer ever has.

title: Starting Up The Shuttle
description: The article on the New York-to-Washington shuttle might have mentioned the civil servant who played a part in its origin (''Winging It to Washington,'' by Francis X. Clines, April 12).

title: BY W. APPLE Jr.
description: Shortly after Italian magistrates began questioning Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turkish fugitive charged with shooting Pope John Paul II on Wednesday, they began to wonder how he got the money, the documents and the skill that enabled him to wander through Europe for more than a year after his escape from a maximum-security prison in Istanbul.

title: Chess; OLD WORLD PLAYERS TRIUMPH IN ARGENTINA
description: Europe scored a convincing 19 1/2-12 1/2 triumph over the Americas in an unofficial double-round match in Mar del Plata, Argentina. The high scorer for Europe was Ulf Andersson of Sweden, with 6-2. He was followed by Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia with 5-3, Bent Larsen of Denmark with 4 1/2-3 1/2, and Lajos Portisch of Hungary with 4-4.

title: The Region; Gun Control Voted - The Hard Way
description: A Connecticut gun control bill, voted out of committee the day after President Reagan was shot, got Senate approval last week after the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II. The measure was passed when a senator who had been against it switched her vote ''in consideration of the violence that has taken place against a man of peace.''

title: 2-Year-Old Survives 6-Story Fall
description: A 2-year-old girl was seriously injured yesterday when she fell from a sixth-story window of an apartment house at 35 Hillside Avenue, near Fort Tryon Park, in northern Manhattan, the police reported. The child, Jasmine DeBellaistre had been left in the care of her 14-year-old brother and she climbed on a bed next to the window and fell out when he went to get her a drink of water, according to detectives at the 34th Precinct.

title: OOTACAMUND, A SPOT FOR A COOL RESPITE IN SOUTHERN INDIA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID TABACOFF, a television news producer for ABC, lives in New York. By DAVID TABACOFF

title: AMID ASH AND MUD, A SPECK OF LIFE RISES AT VOLCANO
description: Seen from the air a year after the volcano erupted with the force of a nuclear explosion, the vast, blasted area on Mount St. Helens remains one of utter devastation, bleak and lifeless as the moon's surface, which it resembles.

title: The Region; A Regional Agency Becoming Less So
description: Nearly two years ago, a task force concluded that the only way to make the Tri-state Regional Planning Commission more effective was to cut the area it serves in half. Since the planners apparently did not agree, Connecticut has decided, in effect, to make a cut itself and get the commission out of the state.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FAIRFIELD County lawmakers have complained for years that the state's legislature never does anything for their part of Connecticut. Many are now saying that this General Assembly is the worst ever for their constituents.

title: ARCHITECT RENOWNED AS DESIGNER OF PRISONS
description: Clarence B. Litchfield, an architect who designed numerous prisons in the United States and abroad, including the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men, died yesterday at his home in Mamaroneck, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: CURB REPEATED FALSE ALARMS, POLICE WARN 5 BANKS
description: Officials of five bank branch offices have been notified that the police will no longer respond to automatic burglar or holdup alarms unless immediate steps are taken to end repeated false alarms, police officials said.

title: Business Conditions; A POOR YEAR FOR POOLS
description: Last year was disappointing for swimming pool builders as high interest rates and shortages of water prompted consumers to spend leisure-time dollars in other ways.

title: 'PENZANCE' AS YOU LIKE IT- 1981 POP OR 1929 TRADITIONAL
description: H0 By PETER G. DAVIS

title: PREPPY-APPROVED LATE BLOOMER RE-ENLISTS
description: WHEN you are returning to school at the age of 37, ''The Official Preppy Handbook'' is no help. Although I live in preppy-approved community and hobnob with friends who love pink, I had hoped that this current best seller would offer me some practical advice on fitting into campus life at a preppy-approved university. Being a late bloomer in life, I was disappointed to find that there was no ''Dear Muffy'' column that I could write to for help.

title: CONNECTICUT STARS IN A FILM FOR PBS
description: THE film begins on an early Connecticut evening. Chopin is heard coming from a dance studio on the second floor of a barn in the town of Washington. From a distance there is a dancer swirling in a white dress through the second-story window.

title: Nancy Aiello Is the Bride Of Joseph Sahid, Lawyer
description: Annunziata Aiello, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Aiello of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph R. Sahid, son of Joseph J. Sahid and the late Helen Sahid of Paterson, N.J. The Rev. Sebastian Weber performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Montclair, N.J.

title: An Oblique Command
description: William Safire quoted President Reagan's excuse for mispronouncing liaison (''Standing Corrected,'' On Language, April 5). Said the President: ''When I was a reserve cavalry officer, the Army called it 'LAY-i-zon,' just like they call 'oblique' 'oblike.'

title:
DINIG OUT;
ON THE WATERFRONT, PORTUGUESE STYLE
description: SINCE its inception four years ago, the Auberge Maxime in North Salem has clearly become one of the most inventive and successful restaurants in the county. The chef-owner, Bernard Le Bris, has developed a classic, interesting basic menu supplemented by six duck specialties and a number of daily offerings suitable to the season.

title: Diana Edkins Wed to Philip Richardson Jr.
description: Diana Maria Edkins, daughter of Mrs. Walter Edkins of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Dr. Edkins, was married yesterday to Philip Morrison Richardson Jr., son of Mrs. Richardson of Boothbay Harbor, Me., and the late Dr. Richardson. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas and Trends; House Panel Votes To Put the Squeeze On Legal Services
description: With the Reagan Administration attacking Federally financed legal aid for the poor, the program's parent organization, the Legal Services Corporation, has been circling its wagons. Last week, a bipartisan cavalry from the House Judiciary Committee came to a rescue of sorts.

title: AN 'INSIDE CONGRESS' TOUR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- RALPH BLUMENTHAL is a reporter for The New York Times. By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

title: DR. GILBERT C. H. STONE
description: Dr. Gilbert C. H. Stone, who had been a professor of chemistry at City College for more than 20 years before retiring in 1964, died Friday at the Amsterdam Nursing Home in Manhattan.

title: New York in Delicate Balance
description: The dizzying contrast between Mayor Koch's prediction of a $240 million surplus in this year's budget and New York City's fiscal condition only six years ago justifies a touch of glee in City Hall these days. But it also should prompt some more cautious questions: What does so rapid a turnaround really say about the city's economy? And what is the long-term prospect for the city's finances?

title:
GARDENING;
INTENSIVE VEGETABLE PLANTING SAVES SPACE
description: WHEN I was a young boy on a farm, the family vegetable garden was at least an acre in size, and that did not include the corn, potatoes, melons, cucumbers, pumpkins and squash planted in the fields alongside the corn. Although the weeds in the rows were controlled by hoeing and hand-pulling, the garden was so large that the space between the rows was cultivated with an ''eagle claw cultivator.'' This device was pulled by a horse, had five digging shovels and could be adjusted to accommodate the spacing between the rows.

title: 2-Day Music Symposium By the Da Capo Players
description: The Da Capo Chamber Players will be sponsoring a two-day symposium on new music at the New School for Social Research on May 29 and 30, 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. each day.

title: Colleen McMahon, Lawyer, Is Married To Frank V. Sica
description: Colleen McMahon, a lawyer with the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, and Frank Vincent Sica, an investment banker with the project-finance group of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles J. Mahoney performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: No Headline
description: I would like to set the record straight about bonsai. Bonsai is an ancient Chinese art which was exported to Japan hundreds of years ago. Bonsai connoisseurs may find the world's oldest bonsai in Taiwan, or in China. WEI WEI C. HUANG, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: SO HOW DID THE PREAKNESS GO? DEPENDS ON HOW YOU FINISHED
description: Depending on where they finished, the trainers and jockeys of the colts in the 106th Preakness sounded afterwards as if they'd been involved in two races. The first race, which included Pleasant Colony, Bold Ego, Paristo and Thirty Eight Pieces, was cleanly run and the best horse won. The second race, among the other nine entrants, was a series of mishaps, rough-riding and inexplicable failures.

title: WHAT WILL 'GARBAGE TAXES' DO FOR THE STATE
description: FEW people mistake garbage collectors for physicists. But New Jersey's garbage collectors would be the first to agree with Sir Isaac Newton that matter is neither created nor destroyed, that it simply changes its form.

description: To the Editor:

title: BURGLARIES INCREASE, BUT ARRESTS FALL AS NEW YORK'S POLICE TRY TO COPE
description: Burglars are reportedly breaking into more New York City homes and apartments than at any time in the city's history, yet burglary arrests have dropped and police officials concede that, because of the lack of manpower, the vast majority of burglaries are not even investigated.

title:
food;
HER CAKES SAY IT WITH FLOWERS
description: CEDARHURST SURROUNDED by pastry bags and bowls of pink, yellow and blue buttercream icing, Eileen Young deftly festoons chocolate and vanilla layer cakes in the back of her father's bake shop. Piping out ''Happy Birthday,'' ''Congratulations'' and ''Best Wishes'' keeps Mrs. Young busy Wednesdays through Sundays at the Cedarhurst Cake Shop, on Cedarhurst Avenue.

title: AT LAST, ACCEPTANCE FOR GARVEY
description: There is money in the bank. There is almost a full house every night, with an average of 46,000 customers in the stadium. There is the best record in the National League. There is even Fernando Valenzuela on the mound every fourth game, creating an international clamor.

description: Joan Mondale, wife of the former Vice President and a leading advocate of the arts in America, will be the commencement speaker at the College of New Rochelle at 3 P.M. next Sunday.

description: Hackensack, N.J.

title: Tradition Still a Part of Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics end their season differently from other National Basketball Association teams. Their tradition is to gather for something Red Auerbach long ago tagged a breakaway dinner.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Prize time. Traditionally, spring is a stormy season in the literary world, a period when awards are handed out for ''the best books'' published during the preceding year, amid heated charges that the wrong books are being honored for the wrong reasons.

title: No Headline
description: You might be interested in knowing about one type of passenger who has benefited greatly from the shuttle service.

title: HOW A SIT-IN TURNED INTO A SIEGE
description: The mountain village of Shemran sits in the the foothills of the Alborz mountains just above the smoggy sprawl of Teheran. Restaurants serving chello kebab, the Iranian national dish of pounded, grilled lamb and rice, cling to the sides of a gorge where a stream runs past a statue of a mountaineer, draped in ropes, pitons and climbing gear. From the village, narrow hiking trails, interspersed with terraced tea houses, run along the stream beds and up the brown, snow-capped mountains. On Fridays, the weekend holiday in Moslem lands, thousands of people, young and old, stroll the paths, seeking a brief refuge from life in the city. Before the revolution, the mountain paths served, too, as meeting places for the clandestine resistance to the Shah, where young people could gather unnoticed and make their plans in low voices.

title: ANTI-SHEIL COALITION FACES TEST
description: STATE SENATOR Walter N. Sheil of Jersey City will now have a chance to test just how solid ''Solidarity'' is. Three of his opponents in last Tuesday's mayoral race in Jersey City joined under that banner to deny Mr. Sheil a clear victory in the election and force him into a runoff.

title: CHINAGLIA IS CHASING A DREAM
description: Giorgio Chinaglia often says privately that the dream of every scorer in soccer is to average a goal a game. His two goals in Tulsa Friday night in a 2-1 overtime victory over the Roughnecks moved him closer to such an accomplishment.

title: JAPAN REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER IN RIFT OVER U.S.
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki appointed Sunao Sonoda to take over as Foreign Minister today after Masayoshi Ito resigned unexpectedly in a dispute over the degree of Japanese military cooperation with the United States.

title: NEW TWISTS IN THE FOREMAN'S WORLD
description: I T has been well over 30 years since Midge Merritt coded capacitors for sorting by dotting them with a colored pen as they came down an assembly line. Nevertheless, she vividly recalls the day her dress was splattered with ink because a supervisor gave her a pen with a defective top.

title: Stars Still Full Of Fight
description: The Minnesota North Stars showed today that they were determined to avoid the playoff ignominy that had been the way of the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Business Conditions; ALL-ENCOMPASSING TV
description: Further evidence of television's pervasive reach into American life comes from the A.C. Nielsen Company in estimates based on recently released 1980 census figures on housing. The data showed that more than 80 million American homes now have TV sets - a 2.7 percent increase from figures compiled as recently as last September, when Nielsen's latest annual survey was taken.

title: Honor Revisited
description: Save some time today for the review of the hostage affair in The Times's Magazine. As Wordsworth said of a higher form of writing, it ''takes its origin from emotion recollected in tranquillity.'' Whatever you felt and were made to feel during those 444 days, did you understand the half of it?

title: Mancini Winner In Boxing
description: Displaying a relentless attack, unbeaten Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini stopped Jorge Morales in the ninth round today to win the North American Boxing Federation lightweight championship.

title: Theater; 'FIDDLER' PLAYS AT DARIEN DINNER THEATER
description: DARIEN AS surely as you can count on a man in a chef's hat at the end of a dinner theater buffet line slicing roast beef, you can also count on a production of ''Fiddler on the Roof'' turning up. The reviewer has seen the show twice at Coachlight of Nanuet, N.Y., once at An Evening Dinner theater in Elmsford, N.Y., once at the Coachlight Dinner Theater in East Windsor, and now at the Darien Dinner Theater.

title: Peter Nagle Weds Patricia R. Herold
description: Patricia Reid Herold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew G. Herold Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Bruce Nagle, son of David A. Nagle of Boonton Township, N.J., and the late Anita Nagle. The Rev. Charles Gross of the Community Church in Mountain Lakes performed the ceremony at the Herold home.

title: HARRISON In bunches, like daffodils going from bud to blossom, hot dogheralding umbrellas are opening up all along suburban roadways.  But unlike their city cousins, they are attached not to pushcarts but to vans.
description: Drawn particuarly to areas in Westchester, Connecticut and on Long Island where clusters of new office buildings provide a ready clientele, they offer a quick, inexpensive alternative to packaged fast food.

title:
Personal Finance;
TIME-SHARING COMES TO VACATIONS
description: V ACATIONS used to be simple - as easy as renting a cottage at the seashore. Now there are such complexities in the leisure world as resort time-sharing - a phrase that summons visions of whirring computers, fast-talking salesmen and smart people always beating you to the best accommodations.
