description: NELLA By John Godey. 341 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $12.95.

title: STAGE: 'BREAD AND ROSES'
description: The Modern Times Theater, in residence at St. Peter's Hall in Chelsea, is a New York descendant of the San Francisco Mime Troupe and shares several of the admirable qualities of the parent company - political awareness, a commitment to correcting social inequities and the use of musical theater as a kind of participatory democracy. This is a theater of exhortation, an indoor adaptation of street theater. Unfortunately, as exemplified by the Modern Times current production, Steve Friedman's ''The Bread and Roses Play,'' the group's sincerity is not always equaled by its theatrical imagination.

title: BILL SETS PENALTIES IN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS
description: The New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus has introduced legislation that would permit people whose civil or human rights are violated to seek money damages from the violators.

title: Vote in Favor Of General TV
description: To the Sports Editor: Many thanks for Dave Anderson's column (''Hockey in Need of Don Quixote''). I live in a noncable, nonpay TV part of Connecticut and I second all of his proposals to reverse the lack of general television coverage of the hockey playoffs.

title: MUSIC: KIRK NUROCK'S NATURAL SOUND SINGERS
description: Kirk Nurock's Natural Sound singers gave some effective revelations about the primal sources of musical activity at the Natural Sound Center on Friday night. ''Successive Rhythm Chants,'' included ''Gung ga kikki ka,'' ''Kukk gaga ging ga'' and ''Whah whah ki ja ga jag,'' along with an overgrowth of animal cries and jungle noises.

title: RECENT HOME SALES
description: Freehold Borough 125 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath town house $69,700 Redwood deck, full basement. Taxes: $1,421 Holmdel 13 Chesnut Ridge Rd. 3-bedroom, 2-bath ranch $85,900 New kitchen, screened porch.

title: Business Conditions; NEW YORK SUBWAY BLUES
description: While the financial woes of New York City's subway system are no secret, the direct and obvious costs of keeping the Metropolitan Transit Association going - higher fares and increased taxes -are only the tip of the iceberg. Benjamin Franklin's axiom that ''time is money'' is hitting individuals and companies in other ways too.

title: Elizabeth Rodie Wed to Leonidas Jones Jr.
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Hartford yesterday, Elizabeth Wilmer Rodie, soprano soloist with the Trinity Choir and a member of the Simsbury (Conn.) Light Opera Company, was married to Leonidas Monroe Jones Jr., a bassoonist and member of the woodwind faculty at the Hartford Conservatory of Music.

title: GETTING A PRIVATE CLUB READY FOR PRO TOUR MEANS CHANGE
description: Created in 1890 at the border of Ridgewood and Glen Rock, N.J., the Ridgewood Country Club moved to its present 260-acre wooded location in Paramus in 1923. There, A.W. Tillinghast designed and built one of his magnificent tracks. This course is comparable to those at Quaker Ridge, Winged Foot and Baltusrol, three other superb Tillinghast courses constructed in the New York metropolitan area during or shortly after World War I.

title: AGREEMENT SEEN ON SHOREHAM PLANT
description: SUFFOLK County officials, who are negotiating with the Long Island Lighting Company over its Shoreham nuclear plant, are apparently nearing agreement on a novel settlement that would avoid an expensive and time-consuming hearing and possibly help clear the way for the granting of a Federal license.

title: Beverly Wolgast Married
description: Beverly Lynn Wolgast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Klehm Wolgast of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Jeffrey Burbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Allen Burbaum of Riviera Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dana Forrest Kennedy performed the ceremony at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Dining Out; BEEF TERIYAKI AND COURTEOUS SERVICE
description: HIDA Steakhouse of Japan comes closer than any other Japanese restaurant on the Island to marrying traditional Japanese food with the popular hibachi-style formula. Several appetizers, such as tempura and sashimi, may be ordered with the hibachi dinners that are prepared and served at grill tables. At a cluster of regular tables in the rear of the dining room, a traditional menu is offered at lunch and dinner. From these tables, you can catch a glimpse of the performing chefs without having to dine on their handiwork.

title: CHEMICAL EXECUTIVES DEFEND THE INDUSTRY
description: STUNG by what they regard as unjustified criticism, spokesmen for the chemical industry in New Jersey defended it in a series of recent interviews.

title: I.R.A. SUPPORTERS URGE SOUTH TO BACK BELFAST STRIKERS
description: Supporters of the Irish Republican Army prisoners who are staging hunger strikes in Belfast's Maze Prison appealed to Dubliners this week to begin lobbying to back the demands for political prisoner status.

title: IN DEFENSE OF PUBLIC TV'S PROGRAMMING
description: To the Editor:

title: SPECIAL U.S. ENVOY SEEKING SAUDI HELP TO AVERT CONFLICT
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, flew to Saudi Arabia today in an effort to salvage his deadlocked peace mission in the Middle East missile crisis.

title: Daphne Clark Milliken Is Bride
description: Daphne Clark Milliken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Minot K. Milliken of New York and Hulls Cove, Me., was married yesterday to Scotson Lindsay Webbe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scotson Webbe of Northfield, Ill. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: IDENTITY CRISES AFFLICT N.J. PRIMARY RACE
description: Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City has a commercial featuring his ''talking'' dog, Henry Hudson. Former Judge Richard McGlynn often arrives at political rallies accompanied by a bagpiper. And Joseph A. (Bo) Sullivan has thrown so many campaign parties that one opponent has accused him of singlehandedly driving up the price of shrimp.

title: Civil Rights Panel Calls for U.S.  To Press College Desegregation
description: The Federal Commission on Civil Rights has recommended that the Government continue to monitor and enforce efforts to desegregate public colleges.

title: ENSIGN CLARK WEDS REBECCA PETERSON
description: The foothills Congregational Church of Los Altos, Calif. was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Rebecca Cecilia Peterson of Los Altos Hills, Calif. and Sargentville, Me. and Harries-Clichy Peterson of San Francisco, to Ens. Edward Schuyler Clark, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wemple Clark of Chevy Chase, Md.

title: TWO REDISTRICTING PROPOSALS FACE HEARING
description: THE adjacent communities of Eastchester and Scarsdale have been represented on the Board of Legislators for about a decade by, respectively, Andrew A. Albanese, a Republican, and Audrey G. Hochberg, a Democrat. Next fall, the two may be running against each other in a combined district that is more Mr. Albanese's than Mrs. Hochberg's.

title: Jamie Chandler Is Bride
description: Jamie Holmes Chandler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Chandler Jr. of Brewer, Me., and Dr. Michael Kenneth Grofik, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Grofik of Dongan Hills, Staten Island, were married yesterday. The Rev. John P. Miller and the Rev. Thomas E. Benson officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Bangor, Me.

title: AMERICA IN CAPTIVITY
description: omehow, the country did not want to ask many questions. The homecoming seemed enough -the joy of the return, the sense of relief, the pride in the conduct of 52 Americans, perhaps the expiation (well, we couldn't get you out but see how happy we are to get you back), certainly the very act of touching hands in celebration, the national sense of community - all that seemed quite enough. And there was a reluctance to let go, even when the yellow ribbons began to look a little dreary in the wintertime.

title: Naumburg to Hold Contest For Violists Next May 8-12
description: An international viola competition will be sponsored by the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation in cooperation with the Atlantic Richfield Foundation next year in New York.

title: POPE IS PATIENT IN AN UNUSUAL HOSPITAL
description: One of the special advantages of Rome's Gemelli Hospital, where Pope John Paul II is being treated for bullet wounds sustained in Wednesday's assassination attempt, is a well-o@rganized intensive care unit with features that differ from those of American hospitals.

title: REAGAN FILLS NUCLEAR POST
description: Washington, may 16(UPI)-President Reagan yesterday nominated Nuzio J. Palladino head of the nuclear engineeting department at Pennsylvania State University, to be chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Mr. Palladino 64 years old, is to replace Joseph Hendrie, the acting chairman. Mr Hendrie, a Republican, will remain a commissioner until his term expires.

title: Gilder's Hymn
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''George Gilder's Hymn To Getting Rich'' (April 26): The days of Andrew Carnegie and Horatio Alger are long past. To say the pursuit of one's own good is a force for social good is highly questionable. Mr. Gilder is making an appeal to the lowest possible denominator in the human condition; to its greed and selfishness. Let's hope we have come far from the days when such an appeal carried weight. BEULAH L. BRUCKHEIM

title: JURY FINDS GARWOOD NOT GUILTY OF CHARGES OF MOLESTING A GIRL, 7
description: A jury of eight men and four women found Pfc. Robert Garwood of the Marine Corps not guilty today on all counts of sexually molesting a 7-year-old girl.

title: 'Silent Spring' Scare
description: After the volcanic eruption of Mount St. Helens in May 1980, one dramatic effect reported within a month was a sudden exodus of birds in areas of eastern Washington where the ash fall was heavy. The ash had wiped out the insects on which the birds fed.

title: PROPOSAL TO CREATE SILT ISLANDS IN SOUND
description: A PROPOSAL to use contaminated sediments dredged from the bottoms of Connecticut harbors as fill to create artificial islands and salt marshes in Long Island Sound, will be discussed at public hearings this week in Connecticut.

title: The Region; Welfare Benefits Raised
description: Although some of them are quick to complain when welfare recipients break the rules, members of the New York State Legislature seem to have at least bent one themselves last week in approving the state's first public assistance increase in seven years.

title: NUMBER OF EVICTIONS IS ON THE RISE
description: ''I'VE been called every name in the book for putting people out of their homes,'' said Seymour Katz, White Plains City Marshal for the past 11 years. ''I've also caught hell for giving tenants a little more time.''

title: Marjorie Lane Wed To Alan Heilbron
description: Marjorie Anne Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford H. Lane of Fairfax, Va., was married yesterday in New York to Alan B. Heilbron, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Heilbron of White Plains. Village Justice John Friedman of Scarsdale, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Westbury Hotel.

title: PAUL WACHTEL
description: FOR several decades, behavior therapists and psychoanalysts have openly warred over the validity of their theories and the effectiveness of their therapies. Recently, however, some psychoanalysts and behaviorists have been surprised to find themselves borrowing ideas and techniques from one another. A growing number of books and scholarly articles attest to the discovery of commonalities; and in San Francisco last month, a handful of psychoanalysts and behavior therapists met to extend the lines of communication.

title: Music View; COMPETITIONS- CHOOSING BETWEEN APOLLO AND DIONYSUS
description: Every year the names change, but the scenario can be depended on to stay pretty much the same. The jury of artists and teachers at the famous musical competition decides, after bitter backstage debate, in favor of Pianist A, a brilliant technician with a firm grasp of many historical styles and a coolly professional approach to performance. However, a few outraged dissidents want it known that they disagree with the majority, insisting that Pianist B, who plays with his emotional thermostat turned all the way up at all times and a flamboyant disdain for convention, is the true winner. Getting these two temperamental types of musical jurist to agree on anything is about as easy as setting up a quiet lunch between an anarchist and a monarchist.

title: Food; SPANISH ACCENTS
description: Of all the world's grains - and ingredients, for that matter - there is probably none more universally popular and essential than rice. Generally, it is used as a side dish, but it also serves as an important component for main dishes in cuisines the world over. Two of the most interesting of these dishes have a Spanish accent. Arroz con pollo, or rice with chicken - as well as a related dish called paella - enjoys an immense popularity in Spain itself and in areas that, at one time or another, have been influenced by the Spanish, notably Caribbean countries such as Puerto Rico, Cuba and the Dominican Republic. The Spanish influence is also evident in jambalaya, that fine Louisiana specialty. Jambalayas can be made with many ingredients, including chicken, shrimp and so on, but rice is the essential thing.

title: CAN THE CITY BE MANAGED? WELL, KOCH KEEPS TRYING
description: Routinely, Mayor Koch looks out the car window as he rides along New York City's streets and jots down in a note pad, say, the location of a crater-like pothole at an intersection. Odds are good that soon the city's Transportation Department will fill that hole.

title: DOCTORS FACING INQUIRIES ON FEES
description: THE state's Board of Medical Examiners has proposed the establishment of committees to review complaints of excessive medical fees and possibly revoke the licenses of those physicians who overcharge.

title: SHOOTING OF POPE 'AFFECTS US MORE'
description: HARTFORD ATTACKS on popes are not new, noted the Archbishop John F. Whealon, head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Hartford, on Wednesday afternoon, when Pope John Paul II was shot at the Vatican. But unlike medieval assassinations, the attack last week ''affects us more, only because it is in our time, and because of modern communication,'' he said.

title: EXHIBITION TRACES COUNTY'S ARCHITECTURE
description: SCARSDALE THE Scarsdale Historical Society sits behind the modest beige-andwhite clapboard facades of the Cudner-Hyatt House (1744) and the 1828 Quaker Meeting House. Nestled in a residential community, the society's home at 937 Post Road is surrounded by domestic architecture - a fitting environment for the current exhibition, ''Three Centuries of Residential Architecture in Westchester.''

title: Casey O'Brien Wed To Clinton Walker
description: Catherine Cooney O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Alfred O'Brien of Fair Haven, N.J., was married there yesterday to Clinton Willard Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Willard Walker of Lloyd Harbor and Quogue, L.I. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity.

title: Editors' Choice
description: THE CHANEYSVILLE INCIDENT, by David Bradley. (Harper & Row, $12.95.) A novel about a young black historian's search for his forebears. AN IMAGINED WORLD, by June Goodfield.

title: TV View; TROUBLE AND WOE, PLUS DISTRACTIONS
description: The ingenuity exhibited in finding personal problems and disorders to explore in made-for-television movies remains inexhaustible. Following a period in which child pornography and runaways were the top attractions, recent weeks have come up with: teen-age pregnancies in the syndicated ''Girl on the Edge of Town''; abandoned children in ''Broken Promise'' on CBS; anorexia nervosa in ABC's ''The Best Little Girl in the World'' and multiple personalities in CBS's ''Five of Me.'' And due this week, rape in ''The Violation of Sarah McDavid,'' on Tuesday, also on CBS, and a teen-ager's identity crisis in ABC's ''Freedom,'' tomorrow evening at 9. Just about the only production to deal with a broader social issue, one involving powerful corporate and government interests, is NBC's ''Bitter Harvest,'' also scheduled for tomorrow evening at 9, which recounts a farmer's investigation into the use of a toxic chemical in animal feeds.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN MACMILLAN 'CONCERTO'
description: Kenneth MacMillan's ''Concerto'' was revived Friday night by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. The British choreographer created the ballet to Dimitri Shostakovich's Concerto No. 2 at the Berlin Opera Ballet in 1960.

title:
On the Isle;
KING OF SPORTS
description: There's more to Falaise than a medieval-style manor house with its costly furnishings and artifacts. The multimillionaire Harry Guggenheim, who built the Gold Coast estate in 1923, was also involved in horse racing -along with publishing, aeronautics and diplomacy - and, as owner of the Cain Hoy Stables and president of the New York Racing Association, he managed to amass an extensive collection of racing memorabilia. Now that the mansion, which Nassau County operates as a museum, is open again for the season, this collection of trophies, paintings, catalogues, books and silks is being featured. Situated in the Sands Point Park and Preserve on Middle Neck Road, Falaise can be visited by guided tour at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Mondays through Wednesdays, and Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 3:30 P.M. Each tour costs $2 a person; parking is an additional $1 a car. For reservations: 883-1612.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A RED BARN FULL OF TREASURES
description: KINGSTON JUST a holler away from busy U.S.1 is the shop of Will Reynolds. The address is 535 Ridge Road, and behind the white-clapboard house are Mr. Reynolds's woodworking shop and a red barn, where he sells the fruits of his labor.

title: Mexican Train
description: o the Editor:

title: Crime
description: Jan Argand, that complicated man who is the Commissioner of the Brabt police, returns in BASE CASE by Julian Rathbone (Pantheon, $9.95). Previously, in ''The Euro-Killers,'' Argand had a case that rested on ecology. Now, recovering from a mental shake-up, he has been sent to the Virtue Islands off the coast of Spain. Argand's job in the Canary - excuse me, Virtue - Islands is to work with security people at a nuclear base that is being built by Americans and that has a great many people up in arms.

title: WHY CARTER ADMITTED THE SHAH
description: Terence Smith, a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times, was the paper's chief White House correspondent during the Iranian crisis. By Terence Smith hen the evening packet of documents from the White House arrived at Camp David that Indian summer weekend, it included a memorandum from Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance that required an immediate Presidential decision. Jimmy Carter could not know it at the time, but that decision would set in train an extraordinary series of events that would preoccupy the nation for the next 15 months and profoundly affect his own future.

title: Margaret Mary Healy Wed
description: Margaret Mary Healy and John Michael Bay were married in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John G. Nolan, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association in New York and president of the Pontifical Mission in the Holy Land. The bride, daughter of Bea Healy of New York and the late Thomas G. Healy, is a health-care marketing consultant. Mr. Bay, son of Mrs. Eugene A. Bay of New York and the late Mr. Bay, is a vice president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.

title: A FAMILY OF 8 HOST TO FRESH AIR CHILD
description: EAST HAMPTON SITTING at the wooden picnic table on the back terrace, while 16-year-old Noel and 6-year-old Patrick played an ill-matched game of one-on-one basketball, Maggie Coolican leaned back and thought about why a couple with six children of their own would want more - at least for two weeks in the summer.

title: WALTZING TO CHAMBER MUSIC
description: Transcriptions, in this era of recordings, are less common than they used to be, but they still have their revelatory fascinations. Two such reworking both involving chamber-orchestra versions of waltz music by composers named Strauss, have surfaced recently on different label from a chamber group called the Ensemble 13 Baden-Baden. On two imported German Harmonia Mundi disks (IC 065-99904/5) the group offers a "salon orchestra version" of the music Richard Strauss provided for the silent film of "Der Rosenkavalier." And the new domestic Pro Arte label has a single disk of waltzes by Johann Strauss transcribed by Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg and Anton Wegern(PAL-1011)

title: Music: Debuts in Review; David Rowland, Oboist, Plays Mozart, Prokofiev
description: Though the oboist David Rowland was accompanied at his debut in Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night by more than a dozen other musicians, he had a clear and impressive musical profile.

title: Connecticut Housing; RULES FOR BOAT DWELLERS ELUDE TOWN
description: ESSEX THE handmade sign taped to the store window read, ''Porthole Pete ... good used boat stuff.'' Inside, barely visible amid a clutter of nautical gear, Ursula Gruber, who runs the small, second-hand shop with her husband, Harris, was sipping black coffee from a blue and white china mug and talking about the problems of life as a boat dweller.

title: STATE PAVES WAY TO TRANSFER A FACILITY FOR RETARDED
description: After months of doubt that a highly specialized but debt-ridden facility for the retarded would be able to continue operating, the State Assembly this week gave final legislative approval to a bill allowing Westchester County to take it over.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are still not in a position to say whether the Pope will live.

title: Reading and Writing; MASTER TEACHER
description: Meyer Schapiro is not among the great teachers portrayed in Joseph Epstein's current book ''Masters'' only because those are posthumous tributes, and Mr. Schapiro, who is now in his 70's, is more alive than most of us. It might be said of a considerable number of New Yorkers that our mothers taught us to walk and talk and Meyer Schapiro taught us to see.

title: CLUB GOES IN SEARCH OF THE ELUSIVE MOREL
description: THE rites of spring are plentiful. There's Easter and Passover, May Day and Mother's Day, the start of baseball season. But to the 45 members of the Connecticut-Westchester Mycological Association who assembled last weekend, there is only one rite of any significance: the morel hunt.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; JAMES CLAVELL
description: While James Clavell was writing ''Shogun'' in the early 1970's, the Emperor of Japan made his first visit to London. ''The British are usually very hospitable, but when he came there was almost no one in the streets at all,'' Mr. Clavell recalled recently. ''It was eerie, and I felt personally very badly. So I wrote him a letter and sent it to the Japanese Embassy, saying I would like to welcome you to my country; one time I would not have, but now I do.''

title: Stockton College's Role In the Community Defined
description: The April 26 article on Stockton State College missed the point entirely, as the reporter unsuccessfully cast about for a ''storyworthy'' conflict.

title: 6 BISHOPS CELEBRATE MASS FOR THE POPE
description: Six New Jersey Catholic bishops concelebrated a mass for Pope John Paul II within minutes of receiving word that he had been shot. The bishops were in New Canaan, Conn., last Wednesday for a day of prayer when news of the assassination attempt was relayed to them.

title: SAILORS IN NEW YORK AREA PORTS AIDED BY 47-YEAR OLD INSTITUTE
description: Charlie Wahrman remembers, oh some 40 years ago, when being a merchant seaman was ''a big deal.'' But now, he adds sadly, nobody pays attention. The romance of ships and sailors has faded. Ports and terminals are sequestered in out-of-the-way places, and even the sea is obscured by the skyscrapers and concrete.

title: Carl A. Muller Of CBS Weds Miss Leidner
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Philadelphia yesterday, Cynthia Ann Leidner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson J. Leidner of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., was married to Carl Anton Muller, son of Theodor Muller of Westport, Conn., and Dorothy Rinaldy Muller of Coos Bay, Ore. The Rev. James A. Trimble performed the ceremony.

title: G.O.P. AID FOR DILLON UNDERCUTS DEMOCRATS
description: DENIS E. DILLON, one of the strongest Democratic vote getters in Nassau County, in effect removed himself from this year's significant county election campaign by accepting last week the Republican endorsement for a third term as district attorney.

title: NEW YORK CAPITOL FINDS
description: The 82-year-old State Capitol, much of which has been altered by neglect, deterioration and the personal tastes of Governors and legislators, is slowly but surely being restored to its original design.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Youth may be wasted on the young, but good training and a reverence for tradition have made the U.S. Terpsichore ballet company a respected one. And on Monday at the Beacon Theater the American Dance Foundation, which sponsors the company and its school, will celebrate in a gala benefit studded with some bright young stars of the ballet and theater.

title: Film View; WHEN READERS CORNER A CRITIC
description: Nightmare: One minute I'm walking up Eighth Avenue at 9 o'clock in the evening, headed toward the bus stop, and the next minute I'm sitting in the back seat of a small, roomy Japanese automobile, a Bloomingdale's shopping bag over my head, speeding toward some unknown destination. Hijacked.

title: Music; A FAIRFIELD CONCERT BY YOUNG AND OLD
description: WHAT will happen tonight when the seasoned musicians of the Ridgefield Orchestra sit alongside the teen-agers who make up the Ridgefield Youth Orchestra? ''If the last nine years are any indication,'' said Charles Spire, supervisor of performing arts for the Ridgefield public schools and the youth symphony conductor, ''absolutely fantastic playing!''

title: Pipe Bomb Found in Dormitory
description: A pipe bomb was discovered this afternoon in a dormitory at the University of Hartford, the police reported. The dormitory was evacuated until it could removed to an open range for detonation. The device was simple enough to have been made by an amateur, the police said.

title: PARK PLAN PENDING SINCE '69 ON BALLOT
description: SOUTH SETAUKET RESIDENTS of the Strathmore Village development here are in conflict over a proposal to build a public park on a 13-acre plot of land within a 63-acre greenbelt surrounding their 700 homes. Sherri Ann Levy, assistant attorney of Brookhaven Town , said that the 63-acre tract south of Route 347 has been held in trust for the district's residents by the town since 1969, when Levitt and Sons built the community.

title: The Region; Peering, Darkly, Into the Farebox
description: Higher fares beget fewer passengers beget higher fares. Though transit officials know from experience that the circle is vicious, two of them indicated last week that without huge subsidies there would be little that they could do to avoid raising fares.

title:
NEW JERSEY HOUSING;
THE BUMPY HISTORY OF SUMMIT PLAZA
description: MORE than 10 years ago, when he was Secretary of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, George Romney predicted that ''by 1980, two-thirds of all housing built in this country will be basically factory-made - either assembled components or complete systems.''

title: Art View; NEIL JENNEY-ELEGANCE WITH A POLITICAL TWIST; BERKELEY, Calif.
description: In an art scene as fast paced and publicity conscious as the present one, where every micro-shift in style is closely monitored by cadres of knowledgeable curators, critics, dealers, collectors and cultural historians on the qui vive for any sign of a significant new talent or a promising trend, museum retrospectives tend to come early to certain artists. Neil Jenney's, for example, has just come at the age of 35. At the University Art Museum on the campus of the University of California, Mark Rosenthal has organized the first comprehensive survey of the painting and sculpture that Mr. Jenney has produced since 1967. It is a show that has much to tell us about the fate of art in a period that saw the radical styles generated by the counter-culture of the 60's swiftly succeeded by the very different artistic strategies of the 70's.

title: UNESCO SAYS IT WILL PERSIST IN EFFORT TO REGULATE PRESS
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will continue in its effort to regulate the news media despite Western fears that it will limit press freedom, the director general, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, said at a conference at this Alpine resort today.

title: Susan C. Samuels Bride of Mark Hochberg
description: Susan Carey Samuels, daughter of Howard J. Samuels and Barbara Christie Samuels of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Mark Stephen Hochberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hochberg of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Sholom.

title: No Headline
description: Indians 1, Blue Jays 0 Indians 2, Blue Jays 1

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Savings and Loan Association of Florida, Miami, has elected Paul E. Wallendorf vice chairman.

title: GIANTS 5, EXPOS 4
description: Jack Clark, batting .198, lashed a single with the bases loaded in the bottom of the 12th to drop the Expos three and onehalf games behind St. Louis in the Eastern Division.

title: TV: 'SHAKESPEARE PLAYS' TACKLES A PROBLEM
description: THE third season of the BBC's comprehensive six-year project, ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' continues this evening with one of the ''problem plays.'' Tonight at 8, ''All's Well That Ends Well'' can be seen on WNET-TV, Channel 13. Like ''Measure for Measure'' and ''Troilus and Cressida,'' the play is filled with dark humors and puzzling motivation, refusing to conform to the inner logic of most other dramas. ''All's Well'' has never been terribly successful on the stage. With Jonathan Miller as executive producer, it works surprisingly well on television.

title: CITY IS SPICED BY BIG BUFFET AND 3 PARADES
description: Marchers moved smartly up Fifth Avenue yesterday in the 14th annual memorial parade for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section, Norwegian-Americans, many in old-country costume, marched. And Manhattan's Ninth Avenue spread its multi-ethnic superbuffet.

title: CAIN IS ABLE
description: By JIM BENAGH Sports World Specials

title: DOCTORS PLAN TO TRANSFER POPE FROM INTENSIVE CARE
description: Pope John Paul II, showing further signs of recovery from surgery for bullet wounds, is expected to be transferred soon from the intensive care unit to a private room at Gemelli Hospital.

title: RATE DROP ENCOURAGES NEW ISSUES
description: More than $700 million of new corporate debt issues are scheduled for sale this week. Analysts say the volume of new issues could increase quickly if interest rates continue to decline, as they did in the final two trading sessions of last week.

title: U.S. PANEL ASKING A BROAD STUDY OF TOXIC AGENTS OF VIETNAM WAR
description: A panel of Government scientists is recommending a broader study of whether the herbicide known as Agent Orange or anything else in the environment of Vietnam harmed the health of American soldiers who served there. The panel said the Defense Department seemed to be unable to determine which soldiers were exposed to the herbicide.

title: Brewery to Remain Open
description: The Pittsburgh Brewing Company, the city's only remaining brewery, has reversed an earlier decision and will remain open. The board of directors took the action last night after members of three unions, which had struck the brewery May 1, voted to accept a contract they had rejected last Thursday.

title: The City; Gas Prices Down
description: Retail gasoline prices fell by an average of 1 cent a gallon in New York City last month - the first monthly decline in prices since last October, the Department of Consumer of Affairs reported. The average prices of all grades of gasoline ranged from a low of $1.484 in Brooklyn and Queens to a high of $1.556 in Manhattan. The price of gasoline has climbed 35 percent since the department began surveying prices in October 1979.

title: CONCERT: BROOKLYN COLLEGE AT 50
description: BROOKLYN COLLEGE staged a musical celebration of its 50th birthday Saturday evening with a look at America in general and its home town in particular. The Brooklyn Dance Theater danced while members of the school's Symphonic Band played Milhaud's ''La Creation du Monde''; Agustin Anievas joined the band as piano soloist in Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue''; and then a stageful of choristers, instrumentalists, and soloists sang, played and spoke their way through the premiere of Robert Starer's ''Voices of Brooklyn,'' a massive setting of prose and poetry about the city.

title: Iran Said to Arrest 10 Jews, Including a Chief Rabbi
description: The chairman of an Iranian immigrants' group in Israel said here today that Iran had arrested 10 Jews in Teheran, including the city's chief rabbi, and charged them with helping to smuggle Jews out of the country

title: Lewis Dominates Southwest Track
description: Carl Lewis, the University of Houston sophomore from Willingboro, N.J., compiled 32 points at the 66th Southwest Conference track and field championships yesterday.

title: DIVERS FIND BODIES OF BROTHERS IN LAKE
description: Police divers found the bodies of two Brewster teen-age brothers in eight feet of water in a private lake here.

title: LATINS STRESS SELF-HELP IN CHARTING A COURSE FOR 80'S
description: Senior economic officals from all the Latin American countries, meeting here under the auspices of the Economic Commission for Latin America, a United Nations agency, have adopted a regional development strategy for the next decade that puts a new stress on self-help.

title: City's Measles Cases Plummet by 94%
description: The incidence of measles in New York City in the first three months of the year plummeted by 94 percent over the same period last year, causing officials to predict that they would meet their goal of eradicating the disease in the city by October 1982.

title: Zoeller Is Winner By 4 Strokes
description: Fuzzy Zoeller played his last two rounds in 68 and 70 today and won the Colonial National Invitation golf tournament by four strokes. It was his first victory since the 1979 Masters.

title: MERRILL LYNCH'S C.M.A. BOOM
description: Four years ago, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith introduced an innovative new product that combined its traditional brokerage margin account with checkwriting and Visa card privileges tied to a money market mutual fund.

title: COWBOYS FLOATING INTO THE 80'S
description: The clear plastic mats lead out of the locker room, past the blue and silver banner that says Cowboys, and into a smaller meeting room where the blackboard is clean. In this room, there is no need for X's and O's. The Dallas Cowboys who voluntarily enter the room climb into the team's new sensory deprivation tank, a white fiberglass box that is eight feet long, four feet wide and four feet high. One by one, they float on their backs in water for an hour at a time in a peaceful world where their minds can be cleared of mistakes and pressures, and then refilled with information that can help win football games.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH WINS 81ST PRO EVENT
description: Kathy Whitworth, the leading money-winner in the history of women's professional golf, moved closer to the $1 million mark today when she beat Alice Ritzman on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff in the Coca-Cola Classic.

title: Sara Hobel Is Married To Andrew D. Gordon
description: At the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue yesterday, Sara Beth Hobel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Hobel of New York, was married to Andrew Douglas Gordon, son of Dr. Malcolm Gordon of New York and Mona Gordon of San Juan, P.R. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated.

title: Activists Mark Riots in Miami
description: Activist groups led a peaceful march through the Liberty City area today to mark the first anniversary of three days of racial riots here that resulted in 18 deaths. Ed Williams, co-chairman of the Citizens Coalition for Racial Justice, said the march by about 50 people was prompted by a 33 percent jobless rate among Dade County blacks and by trials of four young blacks on charges related to the riot slayings.

title: News Analysis
description: After taking 25 minutes to read his 1982 budget message at the start of a news conference the other day, Mayor Koch asked if there were any questions. He got one of the longer moments of silence at City Hall in some time.

title: PUTTING HOSPITALS IN THE MARKETPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer Fans Injured
description: More than 100 people were hurt and 13 were taken to a hospital today when Tottenham Hotspur, the English F.A. Cup winner, paraded its trophy from an open-top bus before a half million fans lining the streets around its White Hart Lane Ground in North London. Hospital spokesmen said the injuries were not serious. Tottenham won the Cup Thursday when it defeated Manchester City, 3-2, at Wembley Stadium in the replay of the game tied, 1-1, on May 9.

title: People
description: * Jordan I. Rosuck named an executive vice president of Grey Advertising.

title: THEY TAKE THE HURDLES OF SIBLING RIVALRY
description: Sibling rivalry is something that many families like to keep under wraps. But one highly visible - and very public - example occurs when two siblings grow up to compete against each other on the highest level of a sport. It is rare, but it happens: Phil and Steve Mahre in skiing, Tom and Dick Van Arsdale in basketball, Phil and Tony Esposito in hockey, Sandy and Gene Mayer in tennis and Gus and Ray Williams in basketball.

title: El Al Office in Istanbul Bombed
description: A bomb shattered windows at the Istanbul office of El Al Israel Airlines last night, the Turkish police said. No one claimed responsibility for the explosion, which caused no injuries.

title: White Sox 9, Rangers 0
description: Ross Baumgarten allowed only four hits in picking up his third victory against four losses.

title: EARNINGS MIXED FOR MAJOR COMPANIES
description: Major corporations showed mixed earnings results in the most recent quarter, according to a New York Times compilation of sales and earnings of 306 companies.

title: ABSCAM AS AN UPDATED VERSION OF 'PARADISE LOST'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW CANADA PROVIDES A LURE FOR MANY N.F.L. PROSPECTS
description: WHEN Harold Daniels, the agent from Los Angeles, suggests that Freeman McNeil might go to Canada if the Jets do not meet the contract demands of his client, the team's first draft choice, his threat has some bite to it because of developments in pro football north of the border.

title: WHITE HOUSE IS PLAYING AN ACTIVE ROLE IN SPECIAL MARYLAND RACE FOR CONGRESS
description: President Reagan is backing a candidate in the first seriously contested Congressional special election since he took office, a candidate he calls ''fully committed to the program for national renewal that this Administration has begun.''

title: 6 Children Die in Louisiana Fire
description: Six children, ranging in age from 3 months to 9 years old, died in a fire yesterday that destroyed their wood frame home, Caddo Parish sheriff's deputies said. Deputy Jerry Henderson said the children's mother had left them while she went to a nearby home to do laundry.

title: Regan Leaves Saudi Arabia
description: United States Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan cut short a three-day visit with Saudi Arabian leaders today and returned to Washington to help defend President Reagan's tax proposals before Congress.

title: Monsieur Henri Wines Seems to Be on the Move
description: There have been no announcements, nothing official, but it appears to be common knowledge among an uncommon few that Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector is the new agency for Monsieur Henri Wines, taking over from Ogilvy & Mather, which had it since 1975.

title: JERSEY CITY STYLE IS KEY TO SMITH'S CAMPAIGNING
description: You can take the candidate out of Hudson County, but can you take Hudson County out of the candidate? That is a time-honored question in New Jersey politics and Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City is well aware of it as he campaigns for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Migrants' Measles Cases In Texas Cause Concern
description: With measles almost eliminated in the United States, public health officials warned yesterday that an outbreak among the children of migrants in southern Texas had the potential to re-infect measles-free areas throughout the nation.

title: Text of declaration, page A14.
description: Representatives of the world's major free news organizations pledged today to fight efforts in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to set up a so-called New World Information Order that would restrict press freedom.

title: METS LOSE SEVENTH STRAIGHT
description: The New York Mets, off to the worst start in their 20-year history, took a 6-1 pounding from the Los Angeles Dodgers today and suffered their seventh straight defeat.

title: PARSONS BEATS HOUSEN IN TRAVIS GOLF FINAL
description: John Parsons, a 38-year-old golf equipment salesman from the Newtown (Conn.) Club ended the two-year reign of Manasquan River's Bob Housen in the Travis Memorial golf championship today.

title: End Run to Guatemala
description: Retired General Vernon Walters, an old hand at military diplomacy, is known for his polished skills as a linguist. But he chose peculiar words last week to explain why the Reagan Administration is considering a resumption of arms aid to Guatemala. During a visit there as Secretary of State Haig's special emissary, General Walters said, deadpan, that Guatemala's Government is defending ''peace and liberty'' and ''constitutional institutions.''

title: Canadian Jet Has Bomb Scare
description: A Canadian-Pacific jumbo jet on its way to Toronto was forced to abort its journey midway across the Atlantic today because of a bomb scare, authorities said. The airliner landed safely in Scotland and more than 400 passengers left the plane.

title: Notes On People; Some Reassuring Words From Mrs. Reagan
description: Nancy Reagan, reasserting her faith in the American character following the attempt on her husband's life, has expressed sympathy for the parents of John W. Hinckley, the young man accused of the shooting.

title: OUTDOORS: STILL WATERS PROVIDE AN ALTERNATE TROUT SITE
description: For centuries, and until very recently, all the books devoted to fly fishing for trout dealth with stream and river angling and ignored lakes and ponds, which are often more rewarding.

title: Clerc Tops Ramirez
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico today, 6-1, 6-2, in the final of the Alitalia tournament.

title: Addenda
description: * Harvard Business Review magazine increasing its circulation rate base 12.5 percent, to 225,000 from 200,000, and its advertising rates 21.5 percent, effective with the January-February issue.

title: SCULPTURE TASTEFUL BLENDING FOR CORPORATION SITE
description: The 145-acre site of the Pepsico world headquarters here is by universal consent a gorgeous piece of real estate.

title: JIM FINIGAN
description: Jim Finigan, a former major-league infielder, was found dead yesterday, apparently from a heart attack.

title: G.M. Executive An Authority On Motivation
description: Alfred S. Warren Jr., 55, vice president of industrial relations of the General Motors Corporation, finds himself much in demand as a speaker and consultant these days.

title: POPE LEAVES HIS BED FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: Pope John Paul II left his bed today for the first time since he was wounded in an assassination attempt on Wednesday, and the hospital's chief physician said it was possible that the Pontiff would be able to leave the hospital in about a month.

title: BALLET THEATER: SNEAK PREVIEW OF JOFFE STAGING FROM 'FILLE'
description: AMERICAN Ballet Theater added a surprise to its Saturday night program at the Metropolitan Opera House by offering the first performance of a pas de deux from ''La Fille Mal Gardee,'' staged by Diana Joffe, a Latvian dancer who has studied in Leningrad and Moscow. This duet was originally scheduled to have its premiere at tomorrow's Petipa gala, so Saturday's performance by Marianna Tcherkassky and Fernando Bujones could be called a sneak preview.

title: TV: 'FREEDOM,' DRAMA OF TWO WOMEN
description: Mare Winningham and Jennifer Warren are two very good reasons to watch ''Freedom'' tonight on ABC-TV, a family drama that is well directed, believable and often touching. These actresses play mother and daughter, locked in one wrenching argument after another before the plot helps them disengage. Libby (Miss Winningham) has such trouble getting along with her mother, Rachel (Miss Warren), a busy divorced journalist with a live-in beau, that it is finally agreed that they separate. California law allows them to draw up an agreement that makes 16-year-old Libby an emancipated child.

title: REAGAN CUT AND PRIVATE PENSIONS
description: President Reagan's proposal to reduce the Social Security benefits paid to workers who retire after the end of this year would have the secondary effect of requiring many companies, under contractual arrangements, to spend more money than they had anticipated on private pensions.

title: 5 Preakness Survivors Hope To Thwart Pleasant Colony
description: Because the dreams in horse racing apparently are more durable and tarnish less easily than others, there will be at least five survivors of the Preakness trying to thwart Pleasant Colony from completing a sweep of the Triple Crown in the Belmont Stakes on June 6.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Winner
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, in nearperfect form, routed Virginia Ruzici of Rumania today, 6-1, 6-1, to win the $100,000 Swiss open women's tournament.

title: Reutemann Captures Belgian Grand Prix
description: Carlos Reutemann of Argentina drove a Williams to victory today in a Belgian Grand Prix that was shortened by rain and marred by an accident on the starting grid.

title: Inmates and Guards Queried on Slaying
description: The police investigating the slaying of a guard at Green Haven Prison said they were questioning inmates and other guards about the death.

title: JERSEY REGISTRATION LAW FOR WASTE HAULERS WIDELY IGNORED
description: Most toxic-waste handlers and regulators in New Jersey are ignoring a state registration law designed to help keep track of companies that haul and dispose of about 720,000 tons of toxic waste a year.

title: Open Government Is Less Government
description: If the Reagan Administration really means to curb the power of Government, one part of it is headed in a curious direction: away from openness. Attorney General Smith appears determined to weaken the Freedom of Information Act, a bulwark of the public's right to know what public servants are up to. He has already signaled the bureaucracy to be more stingy with Government documents and now plans to ''reform'' the act itself. There may well be room for modest changes, but there is no justification for the significant revisions Mr. Smith appears to have in mind.

title: Free Kick in Overtime Downs Cosmos, 3-2
description: Karl-Heinz Granitza converted two well-executed free kicks, the second in overtime, to give the Chicago Sting a 3-2 victory over the Cosmos at Giants Stadium this afternoon before a crowd of 42,385.

title: PIANIST: HUI-YING LIU OFFERS RAVEL'S 'SONATINE'
description: YING LIU was a capable pianist, playing with a certain amount of poise and polish at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. In Ravel's ''Sonatine,'' long, delicate melodies were intelligently punctuated; in Einar Englund's ''Introduzione e Toccata'' and several Liszt selections, Miss Liu had little difficulty with repeated tones and virtuosic figurations.

title: ADMINISTRATION'S PLAN FOR BLOCK GRANTS MEETS RESISTANCE FROM CONGRESSMEN
description: Now that President Reagan has talked Congress into cutting the 1982 budget to his liking, he faces what could be an even tougher Congressional fight to fit his kinds of programs into the confines of that budget.

title: Mass Picketing by Miners Set for Pittsburgh Today
description: By The Associated Press Striking members of the United Mine Workers yesterday pledged mass picketing today at the headquarters of the nation's second largest coal company, in Pittsburgh, while negotiators renewed attempts to reach a new soft-coal contract.

title: Carson Piri Chairman
description: Carroll E. Ebert, 57, recently named chairman and chief executive of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the big Chicago retailer that has diversified in recent years, will preside over the corporation during one of the most turbulent periods in its 127-year history. He succeeded Harold R. Spurway, 62, who retired.

title: SIGNALS OF SOFTNESS
description: The Syrian missile crisis is the first Soviet test of the Reagan Administration's will. The Reagan response to the Kremlin's probe has been dangerously soft.

title: ON A SUNDAY IN BEIRUT, SHELLING AND KILLING CONTINUE
description: Deep in the garbage dump by the Bay of St. George, once the most chic section of Beirut, leftist militiamen have dug in the new 122-millimeter North Korean-made cannon they got from Libya.

title: 2 Aides to Quit in Protest Of Infant-Formula Vote
description: Two high-ranking foreign aid officials said today that they would resign when the Reagan Administration voted in Geneva on Thursday against the adoption of an international code banning the promotion of infant formula.

title: Young & Rubicam Buying Share In a Dutch Agency
description: Speaking of Young & Rubicam, its international operation has acquired ''a significant minority interest'' in Prins, Meiger, Stamenkovits & Van Walbeek, an agency in the Netherlands, where it already owns Y.& R. Koster, which bills $35 million.

title: SLOOP STAJON TAKES EDLU'S GRAND PRIX
description: Stajon, a 40-foot production sloop owned by Dr. John Schinto Jr. of Riverside, Conn., outsailed the custom boats and won the Grand Prix division of the 125-mile Edlu yacht race today on Long Island Sound.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE PRESDENT'S ADDRESS
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of President Reagan's address today at Notre Dame University, as issued by the White House:

title: Mrs. Thatcher Gets a Plea On I.R.A. Hunger Striker
description: The Rev. Brian McCreesh, the brother of an Irish Republican Army hunger striker who is in his 57th day of fasting today, sent a telegram to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher begging her to save his brother's life by making some concessions on the prison issue.

title: Radio Network Profits Off 71%
description: Increased expenses led to a sharp decline in profits for the nation's eight commercial radio networks last year, the Federal Communications Commission has reported.

title: STAGE: 'BROADWAY JUKEBOX,' A REVUE
description: THE subtitle of ''Broadway Jukebox'' - ''A Revue of Great Songs From Forgotten Musicals'' - is only partly accurate. You can hardly call ''House of Flowers,'' ''Candide,'' ''Lute Song'' or ''Do I Hear a Waltz?'' forgotten, certainly not in the sense that ''Hot September,'' ''Weigh In, Way Out'' or ''Fig Leaves Are Falling'' are. Nor are the songs consistently great, despite the inclusion of such familiar pieces as ''Lazy Afternoon,'' ''A Sleepin' Bee'' and ''Here's That Rainy Day.''

title: Yale Heavyweight 8 Triumphs
description: Yale's varsity crew won the heavyweight championship at the Eastern Sprints today on windy Lake Quinsigamond, an accomplishment that followed earlier mishaps to two other Eli boats, the freshman and second varsity.

title: Zimbabwe Getting Chinese Aid
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe left China today, reportedly with a promise of $1 billion in aid, and flew to Japan, where he hoped to obtain additional economic help for his newly independent nation. In Peking, Mr. Mugabe was promised a package of about $1 billion in agricultural and other aid, African diplomatic sources said. The sources said China hoped the aid would help head off Soviet influence in southern Africa.

title: VOICE OF VALENZUELA
description: Two years ago, Jaime Jarrin became the voice of an 18-year-old Mexican pitcher who could not speak English, and it did not seem like anything more than a helpful gesture at the time. Now, the pitcher, Fernando Valenzuela, has become a national celebrity, a youngster who wins every time he pitches for the Los Angeles Dodgers. Valenzuela is swarmed upon by fans, sportswriters and those who would like to share his name on their products.

title: Phillies 6, Padres 3
description: Nino Espinosa (2-3), who had not won a game since April 19, allowed seven hits and worked a complete game as the Phillies stayed a game behind the Cardinals in the Eastern Division. The Phillies scored five runs in the first three innings off Juan Eichleberger (3-2).

title: Maryknoll Order Is Hoping To Return to El Salvador
description: The acting Archbishop of San Salvador, Arturo Rivera y Damas, said today that six United States Maryknoll priests and nuns who left El Salvador early this month expect to return in June if the Government will insure their ''physical integrity.''

title: BALLET: HEATHER WATTS SASHAYS THROUGH 'SQUARE DANCE' DEBUT
description: TWO debuts sparked programs by the New York City Ballet on Friday and Saturday at the New York State Theater. But a good deal more than that went on at each performance.

title: 5 RESERVOIR PROJECTS SOUGHT BY 4-STATE WATER-USE PANEL
description: The four-state commission that controls the use of water from the Delaware River has proposed that two new reservoirs be built and three existing ones enlarged to meet projected demands by the year 2000 within the river's 13,000-square-mile basin.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GRANT. A Biography. By William S. McFeely. 592 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $19.95.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A batter hits a low ball that strikes the pitcher's mound on the fly and then lands in foul territory, between home plate and third, without being touched by a defensive player. What is the ruling?

title: Stock System's Volume at 1.8%
description: A pilot automated stock trading system operated by the Cincinnati Stock Exchange continues to account for only a small share of total trading volume during its third year of operation, a monitoring report by the Securities and Exchange Commission has found.

title: Cardinals 4, Braves 3
description: Appearing in his 700th major-league game, Gaylord Perry gave up four runs in the first inning and suffered his third loss against three victories. The Cardinals (19-9), holding first place in the Eastern Division, struck quickly against 42-year-old Perry, who is eight victories short of 300.

title: The Region; Man Dies as Boat Capsizes on Sound
description: A man died and another was missing after their boat capsized in rough waters on Long Island Sound.

title: TERRORISTS SOUGHT
description: Another bomb - the third within 20 hours - was discovered early yesterday at the Pan American World Airways Terminal at Kennedy International Airport, and investigators were hunting a Puerto Rican terrorist group thought to be responsible for planting all three devices.

title: The City; R-46 Subway Cars Pass an Inspection
description: The Transit Authority's fleet of R-46 subway cars was put back into service after checks were made on an electrical device in the undercarriages of the cars. The inspection was conducted after one such device fell off an IND train on Friday at Third Avenue and 53d Street and caused a fire, delays and minor injuries to 21 passengers.

title: Market Place; A Troubled New Company
description: THE Numex Corporation, which rebuilds metal-cutting machines and produces a limited line of numerically controlled lathes, appears to be the latest casualty of the new-issue wars.

title: INFORMING DOCTORS ON WOMEN
description: O NE of the most frequent medical complaints heard from women in recent years is that many physicians do not know how to give sensitive breast and pelvic examinations. Too often, the women say, their doctors treat them paternalistically or brush aside questions or cause unnecessary pain or, in extreme cases, even talk on the telephone during the examination.

title: Commodities; Limiting Contracts On Futures
description: ONE of the oldest controversies in the commodity market began in 1938, when Congress imposed limits on the number of futures contracts that a speculator may hold. Even then it was considered a strange law because it covered domestic farm products, while exempting so-called '' foreign commodities'' such as sugar, copper and other metals.

title: Israeli Army Holds Arab Suspects In 13 Slayings in the Gaza Strip
description: Israeli security forces announced today that they had arrested a group of suspected Palestinian terrorists in connection with the killings of 13 Arabs and injuries to 22 in shooting and grenade attacks in the Gaza Strip.

title: WHEN A CELEBRITY BECOMES NOTORIOUS
description: Flip Wilson. Roberto Duran. Marilyn Chambers. Anita Bryant. And now Billie Jean King. All these celebrities have found themselves thrust into controversy that subsequently earned them a frown of disapproval from the marketing world in which they had become involved.

title: Increased Spending on Research Urged for Technology Advances
description: The president of the National Academy of Sciences said today that the United States should increase its spending for scientific research or risk falling behind in a second technology-based industrial revolution.

title: Remembering Vietnam
description: Commemorating war dead in art is a rite as old as memory and mourning, so it was inevitable that there would be a competiton for a Vietnam War Memorial in Washington. The winning design, by Maya Ying Lin, a Yale architecture student, is for a low, angled wall inscribed with names, to be built between the Lincoln Memorial and the Washington Monument.

title: Black College Enrollment Has Doubled Since 1970
description: Twice as many blacks are attending college today as a decade ago, the Census Bureau reported today in a study of school enrollment.

title: NEW YORK WINS CHEERS ON LATIN AMERICAN TOUR
description: A small splash of New York surprised Buenos Aires earlier this month, but then that was part of the idea. Roz Ryan of the cast of ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' drew an appreciative crowd when she posed for the cameras in front of the stately Plaza Hotel here.

title: SCHMIDT ASSERTS HE MIGHT RESIGN ON MISSILE ISSUE
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt raised the possibility today of his resignation or the breakup of the Government if groups in his Social Democratic Party do not stop undermining NATO's plan for modernizing its middle-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: Harvard Gets $1 Million For Divinity School Post
description: Harvard University has received a $1 million gift to establish the first endowed chair for Jewish studies at a non-Jewish divinity school in the United States, university officials have announced.

title: THEY SHOOT CHILDREN, DON'T THEY?
description: The principal problem that juvenile justice in this country faces today is massive public indifference. Few of us care to know more about it than what is imposed upon our attention by television news, or newspaper headlines: BOY, 15, ELECTROCUTES WIDOW, 80, IN BATHTUB and JUDGE FREES KILLER KID - MAYOR ANGRY

title: MINCING ON RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ONCE AGAIN, THE ABORTION PUZZLE
description: There is now to be a respite before the Senate tries again to enlighten us about the origins of human life. It's a good thing, too. For in recent hearings on when ''actual human life'' begins, Senator John East and his subcommittee on the Separation of Powers left most of us woefully in the dark.

title: CHARGES BY 2 ASSOCIATES OF REAGAN CHALLENGED BY CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION
description: Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor, in a speech last week to the California Peace Officers Association, accused the American Civil Liberties Union of abetting the nation's criminals.

title: ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: Affirmative action is the latest element of the civil rights legacy to come under assault. Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and chairman of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee that opened hearings this month on affirmative action, has characterized the concept as ''an assault upon America, conceived in lies and fostered with an irresponsibility so extreme as to verge upon the malign.'' The hearings relate to a constitutional amendment proposed by Mr. Hatch to forbid government to make ''distinctions on account of race, color or national origin.''

title: MUSIC: DAVIS'S TORONTONIANS PLAY JANACEK
description: Andrew Davis has been music director of the Toronto Symphony for six seasons, and the relationship between conductor and orchestra appears to be very happy. At least it sounded that way in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Davis has conducted the Toronto musicians frequently in New York in the past, but this concert seemed special, both in the quality of the playing and in the finely judged musical decisions made by the man on the podium.

title: DR. JOSEPH M. LUBITZ
description: Dr. Joseph M. Lubitz, a Milwaukee pathologist who for many years was on the staff of Oconomowoc Memorial Hospital there, died Friday at the hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: BRIDGEPORT YOUTH, 16, CHARGED IN A FIRE FATAL TO SIX
description: A 16-year-old Bridgeport youth has been charged with setting a tenement fire last Thursday that killed a woman and five children and injured 10 others, the police said.

title: BRITAIN'S ROLE AT AILING ICL
description: For more than a decade the British Government and Britain's largest main-frame computer manufacturer, ICL Ltd., have been conducting an on-again, off-again relationship.

title: Vasquez Captures 2 Races in City Meet
description: Louis Vasquez of Brooklyn College, a double winner, was named the most valuable competitor among the men in the City University of New York track and field championships yesterday at Brooklyn.

title: ABSCAM AS AN UPDATED VERSION OF 'PARADISE
description: LOST' To the Editor:

title: Weekly Searches in Atlanta To End to Free Volunteers
description: The weekly searches for evidence in the slayings of 27 young blacks will be stopped next Saturday so volunteers can concentrate on measures to protect Atlanta youngsters, the organizers said today.

title: Escapee Sought for the Slaying of Memphis Officer is Captured
description: An escaped convict wanted for the slaying of a police officer in Memphis and suspected in the killing of a Roman Catholic priest here was arrested early today, the police reported.

title: Gellineau Is Winner In 3 Track Events
description: Lloyd Gellineau of St. John the Baptist won three events yesterday in the Nassau-Suffolk Catholic High School Athletic Association championships at St. Anthony's High School.

title: Ex-Convict Is Ordered to Testify On Meetings With a Fugitive Spy
description: Douglas Wargo, a former convict from San Diego who was quoted in The New York Times as saying that he had met several times with Christopher John Boyce, a fugitive spy, has been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury.

title: Bridge: Ginsberg and Glubok Sides Matched in District Finals
description: Teams led by Martin Ginsberg of New York and Brian Glubok, also of New York, clashed here yesterday in the district final of the Grand National Team Championship. After 16 deals of a scheduled 64, Ginsberg's side trailed Glubok's team by 56 international match points.
