title: Jan Stephenson's 220 Wins Japanese Golf Event by 2
description: Jan Stephenson of Australia won a $69,700 golf tournament here today by two strokes with a one-over-par 76 for a three-round total of 220.

title: AUDIT REPORTS FINANCIAL AID WENT TO 25 CITY U. DROPOUTS
description: Twenty-five students at four community colleges of the City University of New York received a total of more than $24,500 in Federal and state aid and either never attended classes or stopped attending classes soon after the semester started, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in a report yesterday.

title: Study Warns of Impact Of Budget on Charities
description: Contributions to private charitable organizations will have to increase 144 percent over the next four years just to keep pace with inflation and absorb reductions in Federal spending, according to a study by the Urban Institute.

title: Advertising; Compton Returns To Midwest
description: largest in Minneapolis.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TEXT OF CARTER SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech by former President Jimmy Carter to the New York Board of Rabbis last night: We celebrate tonight in the midst of turmoil: War threatens again in a part of the world very close to our hearts. Children in my home state are being murdered and no one knows why. A good and loving man who has sought to foster peace and brotherhood lies wounded by an assassin's bullet. In Northern Ireland, men are starving themselves and they are killing strangers simply because of a difference in religious faith.

title: TAKING ANOTHER LOOK AT THE PROPOSAL TO BURN GARBAGE IN THE BRONX
description: To the Editor:

title: International
description: Britain's two-year economic slide shows signs of having bottomed out, and the nation may even be poised for a modest recovery, according to public and private economists. The latest quarterly report by the Confederation of British Industries was the least gloomy in two years. (Page D1.)

title: CONCENTRATE ON CRIME CONTROL, NOT GUN CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSTAFA MUHAMMAD OUTPOINTED BY SNIPES
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad, the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, added weight to move up to the heavyweight division. But from the way he looked today, losing a dull 10-round split decision in a nontitle bout to Renaldo (Mr.) Snipes, and having his trunks split in the seventh round, maybe he should go on a diet.

title: Cianfrani Endorses Slate In Pennsylvania Primary
description: Henry J. Cianfrani, the former State Senator who served 27 months in Federal prison on mail fraud and racketeering charges, has endorsed a slate of candidates for judgeships in Tuesday's primary and has formed a committee to raise funds to help them.

title: HOPE SEEN FOR BRITISH ECONOMY
description: After nearly two years of decline, the battered British economy appears to have hit bottom and may even be on the verge of a modest recovery, according to Government and private economists here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If ever the great independent colleges and universities like Notre Dame give way to and are replaced by tax-supported institutions, the struggle to preserve academic freedom will have been lost.'' - President Reagan. (B7:2.)

title: GORING UNDERRATED, BUT NOT BY ISLANDERS
description: Butch Goring, whose three goals were essential to the Islanders' victory over the Minnesota North Stars tonight, could not explain precisely what he does to win hockey games.

title: 442.2 Pounds Lifted
description: The Olympic super-heavyweight champion, Sultan Rakhmanov, broke his world record today with a snatch of 442.2 pounds (201 kilograms) during a weight-lifting competition in Novosibirsk, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. Rakhmanov set the previous snatch record of 200.5 kilograms three years ago.

title: Indy's Field Has Surprises
description: Several struggling drivers and a couple of surprises made the 33-car field for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500 during a frantic day of qualifying today.

title: ART FORMS BLOSSOMING IN A GARDEN
description: It took two cranes and three days to lift Arnaldo Pomodoro's ''Triad'' into place here a few weeks ago behind Pepsico's campus-like world headquarters. A cluster of executives watched with awe as the 50-foot-high sculptured columns by the Italian sculptor joined works by Henry Moore, Jacques Lipchitz, Alberto Giacometti and others.

title: Red Smith; Going Home To Belmont
description: IN the evening the Preakness barn at Pimlico was a tranquil spot. The biggest crowd that ever saw a sports event in Maryland, 84,113 immortal souls, had made its way into the darkening streets, and up in the counting house they were checking out the dollars bet: ''Two million, three million, four, four and a half ... that's enough. We'll figure the small change in the morning.''

title: Dutch Official Ends Saudi Visit
description: The Dutch Foreign Minister, Christoph A. van der Klauuw, left Saudi Arabia today after a two-day visit to find out how the European Economic Community can contribute to a Middle East peace settlement, the official Saudi press agency reported.

title: Yankees Defeated By the Mariners, 1-0
description: Gene Michael, the Yankees' rookie manager, was prepared for the second-guessers yesterday, all of them questioning his judgment in pinch-hitting situations in a game the Yankees lost to the Seattle Mariners, 1-0.

title: News Analysis
description: Last week, as the House Agriculture Committee was drafting food stamp legislation, officials of the Reagan Administration argued in favor of placing a strict cap on total expenditures for the program next year.

title: DR. LYNN E. PONTON IS MARRIED TO DR. FREDERIC WALDMAN
description: Dr. Lynn Elisabeth Ponton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grover W. Ponton of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Frederic Waldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Waldman of Chappaqua, N.Y. Mayor Michael Ackerman of Mendham performed the ceremony at the Ponton home.

title: Libya Reportedly Begins Troop Withdrawal in Chad
description: The Libyan press agency said today that Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had begun withdrawing his Soviet-armed troops from neighboring Chad and turning control over to his Chadian ally. No date was announced for the completion of the withdrawal.

title: INTERNATIONAL STAGE FESTIVAL IN TORONTO
description: Canada's largest city is offering a three-weeklong outpouring of international theatrical performances in Onstage '81, the first of what could become an annual event.

title: WHY 'PRIVATE SCHOOLS RETAIN THE FIRE OF
description: EXCELLENCE' To the Editor:

title: Argentina Cites Position on Oil
description: Argentina will continue to look for oil in what it considers its territorial waters despite protests from Britain, according to Telam, the official Argentine press agency.

title: ANDREA JAEGER BEATS MISS AUSTIN IN 3 SETS
description: Andrea Jaeger overcame a slow start to defeat Tracy Austin today, 3-6, 6-3, 7-6, and win the $200,000 Gunze World tennis tournament.

title: No Headline
description: Ofira Navon, the striking 45-year-old wife of Yitzhak Navon, President of Israel, and his partner in a position that is largely ceremonial, displays an intensity that is startling.

title: Randle's Fine Cut
description: Lenny Randle of the Seattle Mariners said his $500 fine was reduced by about half after he talked in New York on Friday with Lee MacPhail, president of the American League. Randle was fined by the league for his part in the brawl between the Mariners and the Oakland A's April 19.

title: O'Neill Cottage Is Open
description: The New London, Conn., cottage that once housed the family of Eugene O'Neill, is open for visits Monday through Friday, from 1 to 4 P.M. The house was dubbed ''Monte Cristo Cottage'' after a stage production of ''The Count of Monte Cristo'' in which O'Neill's father, the actor James O'Neill, appeared. Under the auspices of the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, the Victorian building has been restored and appears as it did when occupied by the family from 1884 to 1920.

title:
Washington Watch;
Flexibility On Tax Cuts WASHINGTON
description: ''THE door is open and the light is on in the hall.'' That's the White House summation, lifted from a popular country and western song, of President Reagan's attitude toward a tax-cut compromise, with Congress still to be convinced of the wisdom of his three-year, thirty-point reduction in tax rates.

title: MARATHON EXPERIENCE
description: Loretta Caliborne started running when she was 14 years old, after doctors told her a foot operation would trouble her for the rest of her life. She told her mother then that running made her feet feel better.

title: George Hammond Retires
description: George Hammond, chairman of Carl Byoir & Associates and once its principle owner, retired formally on Friday, turning the title over to George J. Wood, 62, who already is president and chief executive. Mr. Hammond, 73, has been with the public relations firm since 1932. Since 1978, it has been owned by Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: Director of U.S. Hispanic Group Assails Plan to Import Workers
description: A Reagan Administration plan to import cheap agricultural labor from Mexico amounts to ''legalized slavery'' and must be stopped, according to a top official of the League of United Latin Citizens.

title: VOTING ON ABORTION IS LIGHT IN ITALY
description: Italians started voting today in a referendum on whether to repeal the nation's abortion law, amid speculation on whether the shooting of Pope John Paul II might affect the outcome.

title: Norman Triumphs
description: Greg Norman of Australia won the Martini International golf tournament by one stroke today, firing a 72 for a four-round total of 287. Norman earned a first-place prize of $22,770. Bernhard Langer of West Germany, who shot a final-round 74, was

title: PALMER'S FEAR EASED AS HE BEATS TWINS
description: Last week Jim Palmer of the Orioles, who had won 241 games in 12 years of pitching for Baltimore, said he was ready to give up as a starting pitcher, and operate out of the bullpen. Palmer, 35-year-old right-hander, had split two decisions and was dissatisfied with his stamina.

title: IN ITS NEW HOTEL, AMONGST OYSTERS AND PEONIES, DALLAS SEES A NEW GILDED AGE
description: Early in last night's party, as the men in their dinner jackets and the women in their gowns and jewels sat down to their consomme and turbot and veal and raspberries in chocolate shells, someone said there had not been a gathering like this one since the novel ''Giant.'' No, someone else argued, that image does not fit today's Texas; the party was more like one Jay Gatsby would throw.

title: SPILLANE REDUX
description: ''Most of my mail these days comes on lined looseleaf paper with three holes,'' Mickey Spillane said in describing the new audience he has begun cultivating with the first of a series of adventuredetective books for young people. ''Kids are awfully smart,'' he added with a touch of wonder that made him seem a bit out of character. ''They know an awful lot.''

title: notes On People; A Mother of 11 With Degree of Freedom
description: Mary Striegel knew just what to do at yesterday's graduation exercises at Felician College in Lodi, N.J., and no wonder. Since 1965 Mrs. Striegel had attended 23 similar ceremonies as her 11 children were graduated from grammar school, high school or college.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY FOR 7-5 VICTORY AND 3-0 LEAD
description: The Islanders moved to within one game of winning their second straight Stanley Cup tonight. Overcoming a 3-1 deficit, they defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 7-5, at Metropolitan Center.

title: Index; International
description: Brazil getting nuclear power but the luster is dimmed A2 Latins stress self-help in charting course for '80's A3 Japanese minister assails U.S. for incidents at sea A4 Around the World A5 300,000 Poles attend special mass for Pope A8 Italy halts interrogation ofPope's alleged assailant for one day A8 Voting begins in Italy on whether to repeal abortion law A8 Doctors plan to move Pope from intensive care to private room A9 On a Sunday in Beirut, shelling and killing go on A12 Soviet accuses the U.S. and Israel of trying to blackmail Syria A13 Weinberger concedes that Saudis could misuse Awacs data A15 Government/Politics Panel asks study of all toxic sub- stances used in Vietnam A17 Jersey law requiring data from toxic waste haulers is ignored B2 Excerpts from President's ad- dress at Notre Dame B7 Vote to replace representative draws White House attention B7 Tapes a major part of Govern- ment's case in bribery trial D13 Civil liberties union challenges charges by Reagan associates D13 General Around the Nation A16 Some hiking boots seen as a threat to wilderness trails A16 Dallas holds a party at its new ex- pensive hotel and restaurant A16 In New York City, a day of pa- rades and endless food B3 New Yorkers promote New York in a Latin American tour B5 Industry/Labor Labor federation head assails Reagan's Social Security plan D12 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Reutemann wins Belgain Grand Prix C5

title: Toughman Boxing Brings Controversy
description: In late January Ken Meylan, a 41-year-old father of six, drove from his home in Saginaw, Mich., to Lansing to take part in a Toughman boxing tournament. The Toughman tournaments select 32 men from the ranks of bartenders, bouncers, construction workers, policeman, or farmers like Meylan, as well as attorneys, ministers and assorted all-comers.

title: BRAZIL GETTING A-POWER BUT THE LUSTER HAS DIMMED
description: The countdown is under way at Brazil's first atomic reactor as the country nears what it is calling its ''entry into the nuclear era,'' but the final steps have been a lot less brisk and bold than the initial ones.

title: Ring of Light Victor In Belmont Roseben
description: Ring of Light, getting 19 pounds from the 6-5 favorite Dave's Friend, who carried 132, rallied from last place in a field of eight and won the 37th running of the $55,900 Roseben Handicap by threequarters of a length at Belmont Park yesterday. It was the first loss for Dave's Friend after nine successive victories.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 18, 1981
description: International Israel delayed military action against the Syrian missile emplacements in Lebanon to provide more time for attempts to reach a diplomatic solution. This was decided in a unanimous Cabinet vote that, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said, followed a request for further delay from Philip C. Habib, the American special envoy in the Middle East. The Cabinet communique said that ''diplomatic steps should be exhausted in connection with the situation in Lebanon.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Helmut Schmidt might resign as Chancellor of West Germany if factions in his Social Democratic Party do not withdraw their opposition to NATO's plan to modernize its middle-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe. Besides raising the possibility of his resignation, Mr. Schmidt, in a speech at a party meeting in Bonn, said his coalition Government might break up over the missile issue. (A1:5.)

title: The U.N. Today; May 18, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 11 A.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Royals 5, Red Sox 4
description: The Royals, despite giving up 17 hits, managed to win their second game in a row by rallying for two runs in the ninth to break a 3-3 tie. Dennis Leonard (4-4) yielded 15 hits to the Red Sox, but also made Boston strand a dozen men on base.

title: Adelphi Wins, 17-14, For Lacrosse Title
description: Adelphi University took an eight-goal lead in the first 41 minutes of play, then had to fight off a rally to beat Loyola of Baltimore, 17-14, today and capture the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II lacrosse championship before a crowd of 2,000 at Stiles Field.

title: Culbro Corporation Names President
description: Joseph E. Whitwell, 61 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Culbro Corporation, a consumer products company with interests in such fields as cigars, snack foods and plastics. He succeeds Edgar M. Cullman, 63, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based company.

title: Baseball's Perfect 12
description: SHORTLY after the Cleveland Indians assembled for spring training at Tucson, Ariz., this year, Manager Dave Garcia was watching his pitchers, one by one, back up third base on throws from the outfield. Along the foul line, Len Barker waited for his turn in the drill.

title: THEATER: EQUITY LIBRARY PRESENTS MUSICAL 'RAISIN'
description: ''Raisin,'' the musical version of Lorraine Hansberry's play ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' which was produced on Broadway in 1973, is less a musical in the usual sense than a play with songs. Miss Hansberry's play remains, in the book written by Robert Nemiroff and Charlotte Zaltzberg, the strong core of the production, dominating the music by Judd Woldin and the lyrics by Robert Brittan.

title: MEMBERS OF EX-CONGRESSMEN'S GROUP KEEP DOING WHAT THEY DO BEST
description: Former members of Congress do not go gentle into the night of non-incumbency. They gather and talk against the dying of the light.

title: THREAT OF A SUMMER DROUGHT EASING IN MOST AREAS OF U.S.
description: Spring rains have loosened the grip of a drought that has threatened for a second successive summer to wither crops, increase food prices and deplete urban wells and reservoirs across much of the eastern half of the United States.

title: ACCUSED TURK'S QUESTIONERS GRANT HIM A SINGLE DAY OFF
description: After questioning him for more than 50 hours, the Italian authorities gave the day off today to Mehmet Ali Agca, the 23-year-old Turk who is accused of shooting Pope John Paul II last week.

title: TURKS SAY SUSPECT IN PAPAL ATTACK IS TIED TO RIGHTIST WEB OF INTRIGUE
description: The investigation into the means and motives of Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of shooting Pope John Paul II, has turned attention to the Nationalist Action Party, Turkey's once powerful and broadly based neofascist organization.

title: Carol Golubock Bride of Arthur R. Watson
description: Carol R. Golubock, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Golubock of Kingston, Pa., and New York, was married in Washington yesterday to Arthur Richmond Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. and Donald C. Watson of Dedham, Mass.

title: SOVIET SAYS U.S. AND ISRAELI ATTEMPT TO BLACKMAIL SYRIA
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today that Israel's demand for the removal of Syrian antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon was an attempt at blackmail worked out by Israel and the United States.

title: New Epstein, Raboy Client
description: AFIA Worldwide Insurance, formerly a client of Richard Silver Advertising, has moved in with Epstein, Raboy Inc., bringing $1.2 million in billings. The client sells five companies' casualty and property insurance overseas through 250 offices in 80 cities.

title: AMERICAN-EUROPEAN CROSSROADS
description: Although Europeans, like Americans, are still in the honeymoon phase with President Reagan, some important strains are looming. There is a crossroads ahead, and it will take deliberate new action on both sides to keep the allies moving in the same direction.

title: SQUIRES, JAN ARENZ MARATHON WINNERS
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club set the pace all the way today and pulled away from William DeVoe in the final three miles to win the 45th annual Yonkers Marathon.

title: REDS DEFEAT PIRATES FOR 6TH IN A ROW, 4-3
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers hold a five-and-a-half-game lead in the National League Western Division, but they might not feel secure if they glance back at the second-place Cincinnati Reds.

title: JAIL TERMS URGED FOR GUN CRIMES
description: Republican officeholders today called for more prisons, mandatory jail sentences for crimes involving the use of a gun, the death sentence for ''violent and heinous crimes resulting in death'' and denial of bail to convicted drug dealers.

title: John Henry Wins In Turf Handicap
description: John Henry, ridden by Laffit Pincay, won by three-quarters of a length today in the $200,000 Hollywood Invitational Turf Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: Notes On People; A 'Gunman' in a Courtroom Gets His Wish
description: Since he's been assigned to Brooklyn Criminal Court, Judge Jerome M. Becker has been especially tough on those convicted of violating gun laws.

title: TEXT OF DECLARATION BY INDEPENDENT NEWS ORGANIZATIONS ON FREEDOM OF
description: Following is the text of the Declaration of Talloires, adopted by leaders of independent news organizations from 20 countries at the Voices of Freedom conference:

title: ISRAELI CABINET SAYS IT WILL DELAY MOVE IN LEBANESE CRISIS
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted unanimously today to give more time to diplomatic efforts before resorting to military action against the Syrian antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon. No deadline was mentioned, but the Cabinet communique said that ''diplomatic steps should be exhausted in connection with the situation in Lebanon.''

title: HIKERS' HEAVY BOOTS CALLED A PERIL TO TENDER TRAILS
description: At Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, the rangers have traded their heavy hiking boots for running shoes. ''They're more comfortable and lightweight,'' said Alan Atchison, the chief ranger at the park. ''The only big drawback is that you have to dye them dark brown so they conform to uniform standards.''

title: Angels 7, Tigers 1
description: After 11 seasons in which he won 78 games for the Houston Astros, Ken Forsch is finding the American League a more enjoyable milieu.

title: Reagan Accused of Encouraging Brutal Regimes in Latin America
description: The Reagan Administration is encouraging brutal and corrupt military regimes in the name of stopping terrorism, former Ambassador Robert E. White said today.

title: Craig Virgin First of 27,000 In Bay-to-Breakers Race
description: Craig Virgin, leading 27,000 runners wearing everything from business suits to nothing at all, sprinted today to his second consecutive victory in the 70th annual Bay-to-Breakers race.

title: Honest Tom Takes Jersey Grand Prix
description: Mike Matz rode Honest Tom to victory in the $30,000 added Garden State Grand Prix today, although the mount failed to score a faultless round in the jumpoff.

title: A FILM EXECUTIVE'S TITLE MAY CAMOUFLAGE HIS JOB
description: LOS ANGELES IN Hollywood, title-watching can be exhilarating. ''Vice president has become the cheapest and most dishonest term in the business,'' says one vice president, Robert Dingilian of The Ladd Company. ''Every story editor is a vice president of development now.''

title: Somali President Leaves for U.S.
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre has left for an unexpected visit to the United States, the official Somali news agency said today. It said he left last night for several days of talks aimed at strengthening Somali-American ties. Somali sources close to the situation said without elaboration that he was also making the trip for medical reasons.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. PRESIDENT ASSAILS REAGAN PLAN TO TRIM SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Lane M. Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., yesterday attacked the Reagan Administration's tax cut plan and the proposed reductions in Social Security benefits, saying that the President's mandate to control inflation did not include support for regression in gains made in workers' benefits and social services.

title: REAGAN IS WELCOMED ON NOTRE DAME TRIP, FIRST SINCE SHOOTING
description: President Reagan turned his first trip since he was shot into a sentimental pilgrimage to the setting of one of his first major acting roles. And the warm welcome he received at the University of Notre Dame, despite a strong effort to organize protests against his policies, turned the occasion into a powerful display of the recuperating President's personal popularity.

title: Legislators and Carey Act to Renovate Jails
description: State legislators announced yesterday a bill to renovate New York's 61 county jails and New York City's 17 detention centers.

title: EXPERTS ARE SPLIT OVER MONEY DATA
description: Policy makers in the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meet early this week to take a fresh look at the economy and to decide how much money supply growth is appropriate.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Picks Up A New Hallmark Account
description: Since the ad game is frequently a win-one/lose-one situation, it's no surprise that Ogilvy & Mather should be getting some incoming traffic after losing Monsieur Henri.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JUST ONE MORE, PLEASE

title: Georgia Advances In N.C.A.A. Tennis
description: Georgia, led by its No. 2 singles player, John Mangan, upset third-seeded Pepperdine, 7-2, today to advance to the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's tennis championship.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration has said that it wants to put off until the fall any talk of transferring resources from rich to poor nations.

title: U.S. TO PLAY MORE TAPES AT LOUISIANA BRIBERY TRAIL
description: The bribery trial of Carlos Marcello, a reputed organized crime figure, and four other defendants will enter its eighth week tomorrow with the playing of more tapes that, according to Federal prosecutors, show corruption at high levels of state government.

title: 39 PIANISTS FROM 17 COUNTRIES OPEN 6TH VAN CLIBURN COMPETITION
description: The sixth Van Cliburn Quadrennial International Piano Competition started today, with 39 pianists from 17 countries engaged in the grim process of trying to play one another under the table. They are among the most talented young pianists in the world, and they are playing in a competition that gives the winner greater rewards than any other. In the international hierarchy of piano competitions, several are of

title: Brewers 6, A's 2
description: The Brewers completed a three-game sweep that extended Oakland's losing streak to four games. The A's scored their only two runs in the third inning off Moose Haas (3-2), who allowed only five hits in seven innings before giving way to Jamie Easterly.

title: Notes On People; A Serious Health Problem: When People Bite People
description: People who bite people are possibly the deadliest species of biters, says New York City's Health Commissioner. They are far more dangerous than, say, dogs, according to Commissioner Reinaldo A. Ferrer.

title: Ridley Triumphs
description: Jody Ridley was four laps behind in second place with 21 laps to go when Cale Yarborough, the leader, had engine trouble, giving Ridley his first Winston Cup Grand National victory today in the Mason-Dixon 500 stock car race.

title: Brief Strike at Israeli Radio
description: Israel's state radio went off the air for two hours tonight as a result of a wildcat strike by technicians to push for demands for better pay and working conditions.

title: Excerpts from speech, page B8.
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, speaking last night at a dinner in New York, counseled against withholding criticism of human rights violations in other countries. He also argued that increasing the nation's military strength was no substitute ''for mutually advantageous and properly balanced treaties of arms limitation'' with the Soviet Union.

title:
Notes On People;
A Sea-Shell Distress Call From a Writer
description: An extremely distressed writer and sea-shell collector has issued a call for help in finding the only copy of the picture-and-text layouts for a book she has been working on for five years.

title: Harlequin's Direct Sales Assigned to N.W. Ayer
description: N.W. Ayer has become North American agency for the direct-marketing promotion of the paperback romantic fiction that flows at the rate of six titles a month from Harlequin Enterprises, a worldwide operation based in Don Mills, Ontario.

title: POLES HOLD SPECIAL MASS FOR POPE
description: The tape-recorded voice of Pope John Paul II was played today for a crowd of 300,000 people at an open-air mass in Krakow, where he was once archbishop.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report Friday incorrectly identified Francis M. McDonald. Mr. McDonald is a State's Attorney in Connecticut.

title: Notes ON People; Miss Taylor and the 'Must Go On' Tradition
description: Maureen Stapleton didn't have to be told that the star of ''The Little Foxes'' was too sick to perform Friday night.''I was sitting in my dressing room putting on makeup,'' Miss Stapleton said, ''when someone stopped at the door, and for a split second I didn't know who it was.''

title: Astros 6, Cubs 1
description: The Astros, who won the Western Division title last season, reached the .500 mark for the first time this season as Bob Knepper (4-0) and Frank LaCorte combined on a five-hitter.

title: Must Use New Dean Is Chosen For Teachers College
description: P. Michael Timpane, the director of the National Institute of Education until January, has been appointed dean of Teachers College at Columbia University, the president of the college, Lawrence A. Cremin, announced yesterday.

title: Union Leaders Assail Correction Training
description: Two executives of a union representing prison guards charged that overcrowding of state facilities, inadequate training for correction officers and the lack of a mandatory death penalty for murder of a correction officer were factors that led to the strangulation of Donna Payant, a guard at the Green Haven Correctional Facility in Stormville, N.Y.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: BEFORE the end of the decade, college entrance examinations will be used not to keep students out but to fit them in and give them a better education, and a new testing technology may end what some critics have called the tyranny of multiple-choice questions.

title: THE KETCHIKAN CAPER
description: TheSenate can spare President Reagan from further embarrassment and the country from a disastrous appointment by recommitting today the nomination of John B. Crowell Jr. as Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and Environment.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.50-20.00 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FEDERAL AID SOUGHT FOR SEMICONDUCTORS
description: The American semiconductor industry - fast-growing, prosperous and free of Government control - has stood in stark contrast to some older industries, including steel and automobiles, which have suffered from foreign competition and aging factories. Such factors have forced those industries to seek Government help.

title: Ross Allen, Authority On American Alligator
description: Ross Allen, one of the world's foremost authorities on the American alligator, died last night. He was 73 years old.

title: NADAR PARLEY AIRS LAW FEE COMPLAINTS
description: With hourly fees for senior partners soaring above $200 and annual salaries for 25-year-old fledgling lawyers rising above $40,000 at major Wall Street law firms, rumblings of discontent among corporate clients that must pay law firm bills are beginning to break into the open.

title: COURT BACKS PENSION DEDUCTION
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law allowed private pension plans to reduce a member's pension benefits by the amount of any compensation award received for a jobrelated disability.

title: City Seeks Golf Concessionaire
description: The Parks Department is negotiating with a Chicago management company to turn over three of the city's 13 golf courses for private operation on a concession basis.

title: BRIDGE
description: Four players got the better of six in the district final of the Grand NationaL Tean Championship played at the New York Hilton on Sunday. The winners were Brian Glubok, Michael Rosenberg, John Lowenthal and Phillip Martin all of New York.

title: French Trade Deficit
description: France had a seasonally adjusted trade deficit of 2.18 billion francs in April, or the equivalent of about $393.3 million, down from a shortfall of 3.61 billion francs in March but still above the deficit of 2.04 billion francs recorded in April 1980, the External Trade Ministry said today. On foreign currency exchanges today, the dollar was trading for about 5.5330 francs. The April deficit brought the accumulated shortfall for the first four months of this year to 15.35 billion francs, compared with 16.79 billion francs in the same 1980 period.

title: COURT WIDENS RIGHT OF SUSPECT TO BAR SELF-INCRIMINATION
description: The Supreme Court, ruling in two unrelated murder cases, today significantly expanded the constitutional protection against self-incrimination.

title: Brooklyn Leader Is Choice for Council
description: The Conservative Party's county chairman in Brooklyn, Michael Long, is expected to be recommended as his party's choice to replace Vincent A. Riccio on the City Council, according to City Hall sources. Mr. Riccio, a City Councilman at Large, was convicted of grand larceny last Thursday in Albany.

title: Blazers Hire Lynam
description: Jim Lynam, who coached unheralded St. Joseph's to an upset of De Paul in the second round of the 1981 National Collegiate basketball tournament, was named today an assistant to Jack Ramsey, the Portland Trail Blazers' coach.

title: U.S. and Iran Open Talks On Selecting Arbitrators
description: United States and Iranian negotiators opened talks here today to select three third-party arbitrators to help settle more than $3 billion in financial claims stemming from the 444-day hostage crisis.

title: Business People; Thor Chairman's Plans
description: Harris R. Fender, 64, a Texas oilman who recently acquired 51 percent of the Thor Corporation and thereby became its chairman, is all set to convert it into an oil and gas developer.

title: Peking Asking Recall Of a Dutch Reporter
description: The Chinese Government has asked the Dutch newspaper NRC Handelsblad to recall its Peking correspondent, William van Kemenade, because of unspecified ''inappropriate'' behavior by him and his Taiwanese wife.

title: CHESS
description: Ljubomir Ljubojevic, a Yugoslav grandmaster, won the Colmeia international tourney in Brasilia with a score of 7 1/2 -2 1/2. Second place in the double roundrobin competition went to Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., the United States co-champion, who tallied 7-3. Ulf Andersson, a Swedish grandmaster, took third with 6 1/2-3 1/2.

title: State Notes' Yield Up to 9% Expected
description: New York State's long-delayed spring financing, scheduled to be priced today, should carry a maximum yield of about 9 percent, securities dealers said yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON'S POLICY ON NAMIBIA CLARIFIED
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN ACCUSED OF WRITING THREATS TO REAGAN WAIVES HEARING RIGHT
description: A 22-year-old man who was arrested in Manhattan last month waived his right to a court hearing yesterday and agreed that the Government could send him back to Connecticut to face charges of threatening to kill President Reagan.

title: Soviet to Sell Oil to India
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to sell crude oil and oil products worth $1.37 billion to India this year, the Indian Government said today. The agreement, covering 50,000 barrels a day of crude oil and 2.3 million metric tons of kerosene and diesel oil, was signed in Moscow last week, an official statement said.

title: Private Jobs, Public Needs
description: President Reagan suggests that the private sector will help people who fall through the ''safety net'' of Government aid programs that survive his budget cuts. In New York City, a group led by David Rockefeller pledges to do just that by finding at least 10,000 private-sector summer jobs for teen-agers. The jobs would more than compensate for the anticipated loss of 6,000 Federally funded summer jobs.

title: Israeli Parliament Lifts Immunity Of Minister Accused in Scandal
description: The Israeli Parliament today lifted the immunity of Religious Affairs Minister Aharon Abuhazira to permit the state to try him on charges of embezzlement.

title: Company News; Earnings Are Up At Unilever Group
description: The Unilever Group, the giant British-Dutch food and industrial products concern and the world's largest consumer goods producer, reported yesterday that combined earnings in the first quarter of 1981 rose 19.9 percent, while combined sales increased 15.8 percent.

title: DINKINS WILL OPPOSE STEIN IN PRIMARY RACE FOR BOROUGH PRESIDENT
description: City Clerk David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that he would challenge Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan in a Democratic primary contest that threatens to split the Manhattan Democratic organization just after the election of its new county leader.

title: Trudeau Arrives in Rome for Day
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada arrived in Rome today for a 24-hour working visit. Mr. Trudeau is scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani and Foreign Minister Emilio Colombo to discuss plans for the economic summit meeting of seven major industrialized nations in Ottawa in July.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.613 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.595 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: ITALIAN VOTERS AFFIRM LIBERAL ABORTION LAW BY BETTER THAN 2 TO 1
description: Italian voters today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal for the repeal of a liberal abortion law in spite of a determined campaign by the Roman Catholic Church and an antiabortion movement linked to the governing Christian Democratic Party.

title: JUSTICES PLAN TO DEFINE THE RIGHTS OF RETARDED HELD IN INSTITUTIONS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to define the constitutional rights of mentally retarded people in public institutions.

title: GERMANY FINDS NO EVIDENCE ACCUSED TURK LIVED THERE
description: West German officials said today that there was no evidence that Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of shooting Pope John Paul II, had entered West Germany between the time of his escape from an Istanbul prison in 1979 and his entry into Italy.

title: Postal Service Asks Rule On Scope of Bargaining
description: The Postal Service appealed today to the full membership of the National Labor Relations Board to rule on the service's petition to limit the number of unions that may bargain for a new labor agreement this year.

title: Britain Says Hunger Striker Briefly Considered Eating
description: The British Government said today that a jailed Irish Republican Army member, reported close to death after a 58-day-old hunger strike, had asked for food over the weekend but later changed his mind.

title: DOOMSDAY CHIC
description: McLean, Va. - Anybody who wants to know what is going on in the poor two-thirds of the world keeps getting blitzed with gloomy prophecies. There are the Malthusians (''all those hungry millions are having more babies than we can handle''), and the Marxists (''they'll stay hungry until they overthrow capitalism''), and some academics (''the rich are getting richer and the poor poorer''). It has become a regular latter-day Greek chorus intoning doom.

title: TWO MORE BOMBS FOUND ON EAST SIDE
description: Two small pipe bombs similar to one that killed a man at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday were found yesterday on Manhattan's East Side. Both were safely removed and no one was injured.

title: Polish Accord Is Reached In One of Two Labor Cases
description: Union and Government negotiators reached an agreement today, forestalling a strike threatened for tomorrow in Bialystok.

title: SEVERAL GROUPS VIE IN CLAIMING VIOLENT ATTACKS
description: Half a dozen Puerto Rican groups have claimed responsibility for bombings, armed takeovers and attacks on military installations in the continental United States and Puerto Rico in the last several years.

title: OFFENSIVE DEFENSIVE; Unfair Attack
description: The Presidential counselor, Edwin Meese, was crude and unfair to call the American Civil Liberties Union a ''criminals' lobby'' in a speech last week to the California Peace Officers Association. It was crude to malign the A.C.L.U.'s opposition to legislation it thinks threatens the Bill of Rights.

title: BOSTON PASSES AND CELTICS LOSE THE BALL
description: This beleaguered city had hoped to drown its problems in an afternoon of hero-worship, but in Boston these days sometimes even the heroes won't cooperate.

title: A.C.L.U. SAYS EFFFORTS TO COMBAT TERRORISM HOLD THREAT TO RIGHTS
description: An official of the American Civil Liberties Union asserts that efforts of conservatives ostensibly aimed at combating subversion and terrorism could be transformed into programs to punish political dissent and to erode civil liberties.

title: Justices Refuse to Review Ruling On Libel Suit Against Newspaper
description: The Supreme Court today refused to review a decision that said news organizations could be sued for libel if they relied on oral statements of police officers that were later shown to be erroneous.

title: F.C.C. Change Promised
description: Mark S. Fowler, the 39-year-old broadcasting industry lawyer who was sworn in today as the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, promised a regulatory era free from ''rancor and mistrust'' between the industry and the agency.

title: INSURANCE POOL CANCELS COVERAGE FOR 39 BUILDINGS IN SOTUH BRONX
description: More than $20 million in insurance has been canceled for a complex of 39 renovated buildings in the South Bronx because of what a state-sponsored fire insurance pool for high-risk areas termed noncompliance with recommendations. The pool also disclaimed some liability for past fires in the complex.

title: New Meaning for WNYC
description: Gene Shalit, the NBC movie critic, gave more than a fund-raising pitch when he was asked to say a few taped words on behalf of New York City's radio station, WNYC.

title: U.S. and Japan: Investment Ties
description: Trade relations between the United States and Japan have been strained in recent months as pressures have mounted to curb Japanese auto exports.

title: FORMER C.I.A. OFFICIAL AND RUTGERS PROFESSOR
description: Drexel Godfrey Jr., a former assistant director of the Central Intelligence Agency who taught political science at the Newark campus of Rutgers University, died last Friday of cancer in his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 59 years old.

title: South African Gold Output
description: South African gold output is scheduled at about 670 tons this year, Dennis Etheredge, chairman of the gold division of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, said here today. This compares with 675 tons last year, he said. Last week, Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. said in a report that initial forecasts for 1981 had ranged between 675 and 700 tons.

title: No Headline
description: Regional Water Restrictions New York City

title: Advertising; Media Day Speaker Gives an Adman's View
description: As keynoter of the American Association of Advertising Agencies' Media Day last week at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, Don Johnston, chairman of the association and of the GWT Group, told an interesting tale of the growth of communications as seen through the eyes of an adman.

title: Advertising; Compton Assignments
description: Johnson & Johnson of New Brunswick, N.J., and the Thompson Medical Company of New York, already clients of Compton Advertising, have given additional new product assignments to the agency's domestic operations.

title: SEVERAL HOUSE MEMBERS DISCLOSE ASSETS VALUED AT OVER $1 MILLION
description: Several members of the House of Representatives, including Congressmen from New York, are worth more than $1 million, according to financial disclosure forms released today.

title: Schweiker Says Administration Will Leave Saccharin on Market
description: The artificial sweetener saccharin will be allowed to remain on the market by the Reagan Administration even if Congress does not renew the law that allows its sale, according to Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services.

title: U.S.-JAPANESE BALANCE-OF-PARTNERSHIP DEFICIT
description: To the Editor, Graham Allison and Paul Zigman's May 7 Op-Ed article, ''The U.S.-Japan 'Pie,' '' refers to productive partnership between the United States and Japan and asks, Productivity for whom? Possibly the following points could provide some clues to the answer.

title: Walker, at 29, Seeks New Challenges
description: For eight years, John Walker of New Zealand has been one of the world's great middle-distance runners.

title: Advertising; MCA Gets Standard Brands
description: STANDARD BRANDS is yanking all its food advertising, with total billings of $17 million, out of four major agencies and assigning them all to MCA Advertising.

title: EARLY RETIREMENT PROPOSAL STIRS OPPOSITION
description: President Reagan's proposal to cut Social Security benefits next year for those who choose early retirement has provoked such serious opposition in Congress that it appears unlikely to win approval, at least in its present form.

title: Alberto Jimenez Dead; U.N. Official From Peru
description: Alberto Jimenez de Lucio, a United Nations official who was a former Minister of Industry and Commerce in his native Peru, died of a heart attack Sunday in Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 56 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: CICCARELLI'S FEAT IS DIMMED BY STARS' LOSS
description: Dino Ciccarelli, the 21-year-old Minnesota North Star right wing, is ambivalent about the record he broke last night as his team lost its third straight game to the Islanders in the Stanley Cup final series.

title: American Wounded in Shooting Of Pope Has a Second Operation
description: Ann Odre, the 58-year-old Buffalo, N.Y., woman wounded in the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II, underwent a temporary bypass operaton today to allow her intestines to heal. Mrs. Odre had her spleen removed last Wednesday.

title: NASSAU COMMISSIONER INDICTED IN INQUIRY ON RECYCLING-CENTER CONTRACTS
description: The Nassau County Commissioner of General Services, Francis F. O'Connor, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

title: MIDWEST LOSING TECHNICAL AND INDUSTRIAL TALENT AS JOBS GO TO OTHER AREAS
description: University placement offices, business leaders and economic development experts are beginning to express alarm as some of the Middle West's best technical and industrial talent, motivated by the wane of opportunities and of confidence in the future of the region, slips away to other parts of the country. The migration, they say, will leave the region without the skills to move the old industrial economy into a future dominated by advanced technology and electronics.

title: MICHIGAN VOTES ON TAX BILL TODAY
description: Proposal A, which would cut property taxes in Michigan in half while increasing the sales tax 25 percent, goes before the voters tomorrow, with some opponents saying it goes too far and some saying it does not go far enough.

title: JOHN AND GOSSAGE STOP ROYALS, 2-1
description: This time it was different. This time, Rich Gossage relieved Tommy John in a game against Kansas City, and George Brett did not hit a home run. Of course, Brett wasn't at Yankee Stadium last night, but Gossage was, and this time he preserved a 2-1 victory for John and the Yankees.

title: Noranda B.C. Forest Sale
description: Noranda Mines Ltd. said it had agreed to sell its 28 percent interest in British Columbia Forest Products Ltd. to the Alberta Energy Company for $215 million (Canadian). The transaction is valued at the equivalent of $25 a share for the 8.6 million British Columbia shares that Noranda owns. Noranda said that it would earn an after-tax profit of about $78 million on the sale.
