title: EXXON AND MOBIL TO PAY LESS FOR OIL
description: Following the lead of a number of competitors, the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, the nation's two largest oil companies, have reduced the price they will pay for most types of domestically produced crude oil by $2 a barrel. Exxon's cuts took effect Friday and Mobil's were posted Sunday. The cuts bring prices generally to the $34-to-$36-a-barrel range.

title: Cosmos Are Seeking Wegerle of Rowdies
description: The Cosmos are seeking to obtain Steve Wegerle, a speedy and elusive wing who plays for Tampa Bay. Wegerle, a 28-year-old South African, has been an all-star in the North American Soccer League every year since he joined the Rowdies in 1977. Before the season, he was tied with Vlado Bogicevic of the Cosmos as the league's all-time assist leader with 59.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HERITAGE

title: Giving Voters A Break
description: Why don't the citizens of the world's leading democracy vote? Why did only 53.95 percent of eligible Americans cast ballots in the Presidential election last November? Why, since the modern high of 62.8 percent in the Nixon-Kennedy contest of 1960, has voter turnout dropped in every succeeding Presidential election?

title: Company News; KAISER GERMAN UNIT DEPENDS ON AIRBUS TO SUPPORT GROWTH
description: With orders for the A-310 European Airbus continuing to grow, suppliers to the European aircraft industry are gearing up for better times.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST SPECULATE AS OCCULT BELIFS PERSIST
description: WHEN people believe in the reality of occult phenomena, they believe it deeply and will not yield readily to reason. That, at least, is the suggestion drawn from some recent research with college students.

title: Judge in Desegregation Case Is Overruled in Louisiana
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today that a Federal judge in a desegregation case did not have the authority to force three white girls to remain in the public school system, but the court also criticized a state judge who had attempted to block assignment of the girls.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Aeronca Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 892,883 common shares, of which 809,883 will be sold be certain shareholders.

title: C.I.A. REVISES ESTIMATE, SEES SOVIET AS OIL-INDEPENDENT THROUGH 80'S
description: In a move with potential ramifications for American foreign policy, the Central Intelligence Agency says it has increased its estimates of Soviet oil production. It now predicts that during the 1980's Moscow will still be able to meet its energy needs without having to import petroleum.

title: FUR DESIGNERS HAVE NEW IDEAS ON KEEPING WARM
description: The 1981 fur shows began this week and there is variety enough to keep every woman with a healthy bank balance warm and happy next winter. Despite a rise in prices - good mink, which is the gauge, went up to between $9,000 and $10,000, meaning $1,000 more per coat than last year - furriers show no signs of retrenching.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, MAY 19, 1981
description: International Damascus again was the destination of the American special envoy to the Middle East. Philip C. Habib returned to the Syrian capital for a third round of talks with Syrian leaders aimed at preventing an Israeli-Syrian clash over Syria's missiles in Lebanon. But Mr. Habib, who has spent more than a week shuttling between Israel, Syria, Lebanon and Saudi Arabia, was given a cool welcome by the newspaper of Syria's ruling Baath Party. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Menachem Begin rebuffed U.S. efforts to persuade Saudi Arabia to use its influence with Syria and urge Damascus to back down in its dispute with Israel over the Syrian missile emplacements in Lebanon, which Israel threatens to attack. Mr. Habib reportedly won Saudi Arabia support for his peace mission. Prime Minister Begin ridiculed the suggestion that Saudi Arabia's influence could help ease the Syrian-Israeli confrontation. (A3:1-3.)

title: 16 Electrocuted on Bus in India
description: A bicycle tied to the top of a crowded bus touched a power line today and at least 16 people in the bus died of electric shock, the United News of India reported. Sixteen passengers touching metal parts of the bus died in their seats, while others suffered serious shocks and were admitted to a hospital, the agency said.

title: OHIO BANK PROFITS BY MERRILL TIE
description: ''A lot of people thought we were scoundrels,'' recalls John G. McCoy, vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Banc One Corporation.

title: Advertising; Highwire Magazine Aims at Top Students
description: Next month, National Community Service in Lowell, Mass., will be putting out a new publication called Highwire magazine, which they say will be aimed at the ''opinion leaders and achievers'' in the top half of the nation's 18 million high school students.

title: BRITISH NAVY MINISTER OUT OVER CUTS IN ARMS OUTLAY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today dismissed Keith Speed, Minister of the Navy, for his criticism of the Government's plan to propose defense-spending cuts of $22 billion over the next 10 years. The plan has aroused wide opposition.

title: POLICE CALL TERRORIST PLOT 'REMOTE'
description: Pope John Paul II was moved today from the intensive care unit at Gemelli Hospital to a four-room private suite. The move, which came on the Pontiff's 61st birthday, was a sign of his steady recovery from serious abdominal wounds suffered in an assassination attempt five days ago.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Cup Embodies Merrick's Dreams
description: WAYNE MERRICK'S magnificent obsession has always been with the Stanley Cup itself, never with any of the other old, polished silverware that the National Hockey League presents for individual glory. As a journeyman center, he has always considered the team trophy to be the extent of his dream, a dream that came true.

title: BUTZ REPORTED SET TO ADMIT TAX GUILT
description: Former Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz will plead guilty Friday to a Federal charge of tax evasion, according to a newspaper report.

title: News Analysis
description: He has said it himself: Helmut Schmidt, a source of international envy and admiration a year ago, is a politician in trouble, a man urgently in need of friends. His threat on Sunday to resign over his party's problems with the

title: Suit Filed to Stop Westway Project
description: Groups opposed to the Westway highway project sued in Federal District Court in Manhattan to stop the project on the basis that the recently issued permits for the highway were improperly granted.

title: NUCLEAR AGREEMENT ON JAPAN REPORTED
description: A former United States Ambassador to Japan has confirmed that Japan permits American warships to carry nuclear weapons in and out of Japan under a 21-year-old confidential agreement.

title: REPUBLICANS CONSIDER ENDING ELECTION UNIT
description: Senate Republicans are weighing an effort to abolish or greatly diminish the Federal Election Commission, the watchdog agency established in 1974 after the Watergate scandals.

title: BEGIN RIDICULES IDEA OF SAUDI HELP IN CRISIS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today ridiculed the suggestion that Saudi Arabia could help ease the crisis over Syria's deployment of missiles in Lebanon.

title: Firebomb Injures 32 In a Jersey School
description: A firebomb exploded at Bound Brook High School yesterday, sending 32 students to the hospital and forcing the school to close for the day, the police said.

title: ABHORRANCE OF TERRORISM CAN'T BE SELECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title:
NOTES ON PEOPLE;
College Honors a Village
description: In this season of hundreds of college graduation exercises and the granting of scores of honorary degrees, the story of how two women came to be at Haverford College yesterday to accept honorary degrees stands out.

title: Debt Service Rises in Seoul
description: South Korea's foreign debt servicing will require $25.8 billion during the five years starting this year, the Government's Economic Planning Board estimated in a study released today.

title: Elizabeth Taylor May Return Soon
description: Elizabeth Taylor, star of Lillian Hellman's ''The Little Foxes,'' is expected to return to the play ''before the end of this week,'' according to Zev Bufman. Mr. Bufman, the producer, spoke after meeting yesterday afternoon with Miss Taylor's physicians.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Du Pont Company, Wilmington, Del., has elected to its board Edward Shapiro, co-founder and former chairman of the New England Nuclear Corporation.

title: Credit Markets; BOND PRICES ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Fueled by speculative buying from securities dealers who think that a peak in interest rates is at hand, prices of short- and long-term debt securities rose substantially yesterday and interest rates declined.

title: Five of Eight Inmates Who Fled Prison in Alabama Are Captured
description: Law-enforcement authorities with helicopters and bloodhounds today captured five of eight men who had broken out of Alabama's maximum security prison.

title: CONCERT: THE JULLIARD STRING QUARTET
description: YOU know the story about the country boy and his 20-year-old ax. He bragged that it was as good as new, even though he had replaced the handle six times and the head twice. Well, the Juilliard String Quartet is better than that: it is 35 years old and while most of its parts have been replaced several times, it still has the same head it came with. That, of course, would be the first violinist, Robert Mann, who was a founding member of the quartet in 1946 and who led the Juilliard onstage last night at Carnegie Hall where the group's 35th anniversary was celebrated with the help of an old friend and confederate, Ludwig van Beethoven. Mr. Mann's associates these days are the violinist Earl Carlyss, the violist Samuel Rhodes and the cellist Joel Krosnick.

title: Resch: Islanders Better Than in '80
description: The New York Islanders are a better team without him, Chico Resch said today.

title: HIGH COURT BARS REVIEW OF RULING REMOVING JUDGES
description: The United States Supreme Court today rejected a Brooklyn judge's challenge to a state court order removing him from the bench.

title: REAGANS' BALLET TRIP REFLECTS SECURITY
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, tonight made their first pre-announced appearance at a social function outside the White House since the attempt on Mr. Reagan's life March 30.

title: TOXIC WASTE DISPOSAL: SEARCH FOR THE BEST TECHNOLOGY
description: INTENSIFIES By RICHARD SEVERO

title: Army Helicopter Crash Kills 4
description: An Army helicopter crashed and burned early today on a routine training mission in southeast Alabama, killing all four crewmen aboard. The names of the dead were being withheld pending notification of relatives.

title: Oklahoma and Kansas Are Raked by Tornadoes
description: By The Associated Press Eight tornadoes splintered houses and barns yesterday across Oklahoma and Kansas as a storm surged into the Middle West with violent thunderstorms and floods after leaving 11 inches of snow in the Colorado Rockies.

title: SCIENTIST ENTERED SEMINARY IN '70
description: The Rev. Jeannette R. Piccard, a pioneering high-altitude balloonist with her late husband, the Swiss scientist Jean Piccard, and one of the first American women to be ordained an Episcopal priest, died of cancer Sunday at the Masonic Memorial Hospital in Minneapolis, where she lived. She was 86 years old.

title: U.S. PETITIONS IN TRIS CASE
description: Washington, May 18 (AP) The Justice Department asked a Federal appeals court today to hold a North Carolina company in criminal contempt for alegedlly shipping abroad children's sleepwear treated with the flameretardant Tris.

title: 10 Puerto Rican Terrorists Start Hunger Strike in Illinois Prisons
description: Ten imprisoned Puerto Rican terrorists started a hunger strike today. They said they would not eat until the Government produced Alfredo Mendez, a Puerto Rican nationalist missing from his cell at the Pontiac Correctional Center.

title: Five Youths Escape From Bronx Center
description: A 17-year-old convicted murderer and four other youths yesterday sawed their way out of the Spofford Juvenile Detention Center in the Bronx, officials said.

title: RIGHTS CHOICE SAYS HE'S A 'DO-GOODER,' NOT 'GALAHAD'
description: Ernest W. Lefever, President Reagan's nominee to be Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, described himself today as a ''confirmed do-gooder'' and a ''compassionate realist'' who abhors violations of human rights wherever they occur.

title: G.M. Denies Layoff Report
description: The General Motors Corporation has not set any timetable or quota for white-collar layoffs, despite reports that the auto maker will begin laying off 18,000 salaried employees next month, F. James McDonald, G.M. president, said today.

title: Prof. Erich Correns, 85, An East German Leader
description: Prof. Erich Correns, one of the founders of East Germany, died today, the official press agency reported.

title: Patriots Promise Improved Monday-Night Security
description: The New England Patriots, seeking to avert a ban by community officials of a 9 P.M. start for a nationally televised Monday night game here Sept. 21, promised today to provide security aimed at curbing rowdiness.

title: The Diplomacy of Mothers' Milk
description: The Reagan Administration seems determined to stand alone, if necessary, against 150 countries this week when the World Health Assembly votes on a ''marketing code'' urging restraints in the selling of powdered milk formulas for infants. The sellers are accused of discouraging breast feeding in poor countries, where many women misuse the formulas. The evidence against the manufacturers is largely anecdotal and the campaign against them has been excessive. But there does seem to be a problem.

title: THE SURGEON GENERAL'S PRAGMATIC BOSS
description: While most public and press attention has focused on Dr. C. Everett Koop, an outspoken opponent of abortions whose nomination as Surgeon General is bottled up in Congress, the real responsibility for health and medical policy in the new Administration lies with a low-key administrator from Texas who is widely regarded as a political moderate and pragmatist.

title: BRIEFS
description: * H.F. Ahmanson & Co. and Fidelity Financial Corp. said they had ended talks on the purchase by Ahmanson of some branches and other assets of Fidelity.

title: Mitsui Plant for Qatar
description: The Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding Company said today that it had reached agreement with Qatar to build a petrochemical plant valued at $46 million for the Qatar Petrochemical Company.

title: WANDERING BITS OF GENETIC MATERIAL ARE BLAMED FOR VAST HEALTH HARM
description: THE emergency may be a case of food poisoning, with nausea and great discomfort; a gunshot wound, infected and suddenly resistant to most of the standard antibiotic drugs; or diphtheria, an infectious disease that is uncommon today, but a threat to life when it occurs.

title: Upstate Judges Face Transfers Downstate
description: ALBANY (UPI) - Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke of the State Court of Appeals said he would transfer 28 upstate judges this year to handle a heavy backlog of criminal cases in Suffolk and Westchester Counties.

title: Company News; Angola Oil Venture
description: The Cities Service Company said that it had signed a petroleum exploration and production agreement covering about 1.2 million acres off the coast of Angola. The agreement, with the Angolan National Oil Company, also involves the Marathon Oil Company's Angolan subsidiary and calls for the company to spend $26 million for the first three-year exploration period, Cities Service said.

title: HOUSING STARTS UP 4.2% IN APRIL
description: New housing construction rose 4.2 percent in April, to an annual rate of 1.34 million, continuing a modest recovery from a 27 percent plunge in February to a rate of 1.22 million, the Commerce Department reported today. Starts rose 6.1 percent in March.

title: About Washington For the Speaker, Win Some, Lose Some
description: With his cigar gone cold as his most recent budget battle, the Speaker of the House tapped his desk top for emphasis, talking of Ronald Reagan, telling of the great powers of this new adversary.

title: ART SHOW TO LET RUSSIANS SEE THEIR MODERNISM
description: MOSCOW FOR a half-century, since Stalin decreed Socialist Realism to be the esthetic law of the land, Russians have been allowed no more than a passing glimpse of the great Russian modernist movement that swelled with the revolution and was banished in its aftermath.

title: FAVORED U.S. ROLE IN WORLD COURT
description: Esther Everett Lape, a social scientist and activist who led the unsuccessful battle for United States participation in the World Court in the 1920's and 30's, died Sunday at her home at 447 East 57th Street in Manhattan. She was 100 years old.

title: NAVY SHUTS CUSTODY UNITS ON SHIPS WHILE INQUIRY ON DEATH CONTINUES
description: The Navy's top admiral ordered a temporary closing of all ''correctional custody units'' aboard ship today while an investigation continued into an incident in which a young sailor died.

title: INDY 500 LINEUP ALTERED AFTER SNEVA IS DISQUALIFIED
description: Indianapolis, May 18(UPI)-Stewards for the Indianpolis 500 ordered a lineup change today, declaring that the crew for Jerry Sneva illegally prepared Sneva's car to give him an advantage during qualifying. The ruling, following a 90-minute hearing, reinstated Jerry Karl into the 33rd starting position for Sunday's race.

title: DOCTORS WORLD
description: Pope John Paul II has devoted many hours tending to the sick, comforting the dying, and giving the last rites of the Roman Catholic Church. Last Wednesday, the role was reversed for the Pope, who received the last rites from the Rev. Stanislaw Dziwisz, one of his two private secretaries, in the operating room of Gemelli Hospital here just before he underwent a 5-hour 25-minute operation to repair the severe damage to his bowel created by a bullet that went through his body.

title: BIPARTISAN TAX EFFORT IN CONGRESS
description: An unusual bipartisan effort to write a tax relief bill acceptable to President Reagan began today in a private meeting room a few yards from the Senate chamber.

title: OFFENSIVE DEFENSIVE; Protective Chic
description: It's hard to imagine a more soberly practical product than the bulletproof vest. Yet manufacturers are surpassing practicality by making ''fashion-conscious ballistic apparel.''

title: Transit Report
description: There were 10-minute delays on the 4:30 P.M train to Harrison and the 5:05 to Croton-Harmon and a 15-minute delay on the 5:50 to White Plains. The 5:36 to Glenwood, and the 5:54 shuttle train from Croton-Harmon to Montrose were canceled.

title: VALENZUELA'S STREAK STOPPED AT 8 BY PHILS
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Los Angeles Dodgers' rookie left-hander, suffered his first major league loss tonight in a 4-0 decision to the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Company News; Dutch Raising Stake In Volvo Subsidiary
description: The Dutch Government will increase its interest in Volvo Car BV, the financially ailing Netherlands subsidiary of the Swedish car manufacturer AB Volvo, from the present 45 percent, to 70 percent, according to Interior Minister Hans Wiegel.

title: Punishing The Doctors
description: For years every official voice, including that of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, has been in public agreement that the budget cuts necessitated by the fiscal crisis have hurt the quality of care in the city's municipal hospital system. But two months ago, when the doctors-in-training in that system went on strike against 7 of the 16 city hospitals and two private voluntary ones, the issue got the silent treatment.

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, MAY 19,1981; The Economy
description: The prime lending rate rose to 20 percent from 19 1/2 percent. Led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and Citibank, major banks across the country responded to recent increases in short-term inter-est rates that have raised their own cost of money. Bankers and credit analysts are split on the future course of interest rates. Some see underlying economic trends remaining strong. Others expect money supply growth to slow, easing pressure on rates. (Page D1.)

title: RECENT ART BRINGS RECORD AUCTION PRICES
description: The art-auction season moved into high gear last week with recordbreaking sales of post-World War II art. The highest prices ever paid at auction for dozens of artists included $350,000 bid by Lawrence Rubin of M. Knoedler & Company for Franz Kline's 1960 ''West Brand'' at Sotheby Parke Bernet, and $220,000 for Willem de Kooning's 1977 ''Untitled III'' at Christie's.

title: JOHN S. NOCERA
description: John Stanley Nocera, a former Philadelphia Eagle linebacker, died of lung cancer last night.

title: Japan Exports Of Machinery
description: Japanese machinery exports in the fiscal year 1980 rose 35.8 percent, to a record $91 billion, compared with a rise of 4.7 percent in the fiscal year 1979, to $67 billion, the Japanese Machinery Exporters Association said today.

title: Bush Backs Protection For Whites in Namibia
description: Vice President Bush said today that the United States was committed to independence for South-West Africa but only if the constitutional rights of the white minority there were guaranteed.

title: World Airways Has Profit
description: World Airways, one of the nation's largest charter carriers for commercial and military passengers and cargo, yesterday reported net income for the first quarter of $735,000, or 7 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $11.4 million in the first quarter of 1980. Sales soared to $78.3 million from $27.2 million.

title: France Attempts to Close Nuclear-Export Loopholes
description: France has increased restrictions on the export of nuclear equipment, laser instruments, rockets and other advanced materiel, military officials said today.

title: EMOTIONAL DISORDERS AMONG DOCTORS PROMPT PROGRAMS TO TREAT THEM
description: LAST March 23, Dr. Kenneth Shulman, a prominent New York neurosurgeon, was found dead in his home in Mamaroneck. The day before, according to a medical examiner's report, Dr. Shulman gave himself a lethal intravenous infusion of the powerful muscle relaxer Succinylcholine, ordinarily used only in surgical patients.

title: Company News; Playboy Plans Sale Of Oui Magazine
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said that it was close to selling Oui magazine, the less prosperous companion publication to Playboy. Magazine sources said that the tentative buyer is Goshen Litho Inc., a printing concern owned by Murray Traub, for a price near $1.5 million.

title: Plaintiffs Open Their Attack On Voting System in Mobile
description: Civil rights attorneys, joined by the Justice Department, began trying to prove today that deliberate discrimination was behind the fact that no black person had been elected to Mobile's three-member city commission since 1868.

title: Company News; Cadillac 'J' Car Has $12,131 Base Price
description: The General Motors Corporation said that its new compact Cadillac - the Cimarron - will carry a base price of $12,131 when it is put on sale in dealer showrooms later this week.

title: Product Delay By G.M. Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation is delaying or suspending some of its planned new car models and engines that were originally to have been part of its huge four-year, $40 billion retooling program, according to trade sources.

title: Company News; Bangor Punta Raises Lone Star Holdings
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation, a major producer of building materials, said it had increased its stake in Lone Star Industries to 1,395,000 shares, or 12.8 percent of the total shares outstanding, and that it intended to increase its holdings to more than 25 percent.

title: 80 Haitians Are Detained After Arrival in Florida
description: Immigration officials were holding six Haitians today on smuggling charges and 74 others were being detained at a refugee camp after they were arrested on their arrival here yesterday.

title: Bahrain Minister Dies in Algeria
description: Bahrain's Minister of Education, Sheik Abdul Aziz bin Mohammed al-Khalifa, died today in Algeria, where he was attending a conference of education ministers.

title: CAREY AND KOCH SUPPORT A REGIONAL TRANSIT TAX
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch said today that they had ''reluctantly come to the conclusion'' that the growing deficits of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority would require a new regional tax to stave off sharp service cuts or major fare increases.

title: AGENCY FINDS SLIDES HELPFUL ON ADOPTIONS
description: The designation ''hard to place'' seemed at first glance inappropriate for the 54 children whose saucerlike eyes, sassy stances and alluring grins dominated the color slides shown over the weekend to an audience of prospective adoptive parents.

title: ASSESSMENT OF MAO IS DUE JULY 1
description: Mayor Wang Daohan of Shanghai said today that an official assessment of Mao Zedong will be published July 1 for the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: ARTHUR O'CONNELL, 73, NOMINATED FOR OSCARS FOR SUPPORTING ROLES
description: Arthur O'Connell, twice nominated for an Oscar as supporting actor, died today of Altzheimer's disease, a deadening of the nerve endings of the brain. He was 73 years old.

title: Pulitzer Winner Sued by Alleged Ghostwriter
description: Paul Zindel, author of the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama ''The Effects of Gamma Rays on Man-in-the-Moon Marigolds,'' will have to answer charges in Federal Court in Manhattan that he allegedly hired a young and untried would-be novelist as a ghostwriter.

title: 17 FINALISTS IN PAVAROTTI COMPETITION
description: The Academy of Music, home of the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Opera Company of Philadelphia, often rings to the sound of operatic voices in full cry. But this afternoon was different, as a tenor and 16 sopranos vied to become winners in the finals of the first Luciano Pavarotti International Voice Competition.

title: TV: 'THE VIOLATION OF SARAH MCDAVID'
description: GET yourself a fact and then construct a plot around it. As in numerous other television movies, that is the formula used by ''The Violation of Sarah McDavid,'' on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock this evening.

title: Advertising; Atlantic Monthly's New Publisher
description: Bruce W. Gray, 36-year-old publisher of World Tennis, one of the CBS Publications, will be the new president, publisher and chief operating officer of the venerable Atlantic Monthly magazine, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, its owner for a year, announced yesterday.

title: FOCUS IN JERSEY GOVERNORSHIP RACE SHIFTS TO HUDSON
description: The political maneuvering in Hudson County is attracting considerable attention after last week's elections in Jersey City revealed a startling weakness in the organization headed by Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith and State Senator Walter N. Sheil.

title: 75 Tenants Rescued From Hartford Fire
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - At least 75 people were rescued from a four-story brick apartment house when a three-alarm fire broke out.

title: Two Charged in Slaying Of Officer in Bronx Bar
description: Two Cuban exiles were charged yesterday with the May 4 slaying of an off-duty housing police lieutenant. A third man was charged with illegal possession of a gun.

title: FOUNDATION TO SUPPORT 21 AS 'GENIUSES' FOR 5 YEARS
description: After a secret search that lasted for months, a Chicago foundation yesterday named 21 "exceptionally talented individuals" to receive awards of from $24,000 to $60,000 annually for five years.

title: A LEGISLATIVE HOME FOR ORPHANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Service Union Local Cleared Of Charges and Chief Reinstated
description: The Civil Service Employees Association has lifted its trusteeship of Local 010 and withdrawn charges alleging that the local's president, Joseph Johnson, had made improper expenditures of the union's funds.

title: POPE'S DOCTORS NOTE GAIN BUT STILL EXPRESS CAUTION
description: The superintendent of Gemelli Hospital said today that although Pope John Paul II had been moved out of intensive care his condition was still guarded and that a prognosis about his recovery would not be possible for a few more days.

title: New Framework for N.B.A. Free Agency
description: The telephone conversations going on now between player agents and some National Basketball Association general managers might sound something like this:

title: WITNESS AT BLANTON TRIAL IS INDICTED ON FRAUD CHARGE
description: The Government accused its own chief witness at former Gov. Ray Blanton's extortion trial today of lying when he said he had taken no ''skimmed'' profits from his liquor store, and a Federal grand jury indicted him on charges of conspiracy and fraud.

title: WROTE 'THE TIME OF YOUR LIFE'
description: William Saroyan, whose plays, short stories and novels drew on the Armenian immigrant experience and depicted the variety and romance of American life, died of cancer yesterday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Fresno, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Market Place; Variable-Rate Participations
description: ALTHOUGH the bond market in general has experienced its worst setback in a generation, E.M. Graves & Company has been earning high returns with federally guaranteed variable-rate securities.

title: City Stores to End Chapter 11 Status
description: City Stores Company, the operator of W.& J. Sloane furniture stores, the Maison Blanche department store chain in New Orleans and B. Lowenstein stores in Memphis, said yesterday that the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York had approved its plan for emerging from protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Business People; Aminoil Head's Outlook
description: With the current worldwide glut of petroleum, why has Aminoil USA, a subsidiary of the giant R.J. Reynolds Industries, undertaken a three-year, $5 million pilot project to revitalize its giant Huntington Beach oilfield in southern California?

title: Reagan's Son Still Holds 2 Jobs Amid Controversy
description: President Reagan's son Michael, who stirred a controversy by referring to his father in letters he wrote seeking military contracts, did not resign both his jobs today despite promises to do so because of the furor.

title: 12th-Century Book Sold for $1.46 Million
description: In the world of rare books, some rare books are rarer than others, and the one H. P. Kraus, a New York dealer, picked up in London yesterday was one of the rarest of all.

title: AMERICAN MISSION CRITICIZED IN SYRIA AS TILTING TO ISRAEL
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, flew here today from Saudi Arabia for a third round of discussions with Syrian leaders aimed at preventing an Israeli-Syrian clash over Syrian missiles in Lebanon.

title: JERSEY RELAXING CURBS ON WATER IN MANY TOWNS
description: Rationing of water used inside homes, offices and factories in 94 communities in northern New Jersey ends tomorrow, Paul H. Arbesman, the state's drought coordinator said today.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Which type of glassware will break more easily when hot water is poured into it - thin glass or thick glass?

title: Plastic Trees Lure Birds
description: Ohio State University researchers have devised plastic ''trees'' that can lure insect-eating woodpeckers to forests infested with the spruce budworm, a scourge of timberlands that pesticide programs have had little success in eliminating.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP ONLY 0.6%
description: In a new indication that the national economy is slowing down, the Commerce Department reported today that Americans' personal income and spending rose in April by the smallest percentages since last spring.

title: JAMES S. RAUSCH, 52, BISHOP OF PHOENIX
description: Bishop James S. Rausch, head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Phoenix since 1977 and a former general secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack. He was 52 years old.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: F OR good or bad, the prices of the fall 1981 designer clothes have increased by as much as 25 percent over those for last fall. It is due, in part, to continued increases in the costs of labor and fabric. But the other reason for the increase is that the new, fuller silhouettes - the long, voluminous skirts, the wrap dresses, the fluid coats - naturally require more yardage.

title: EARLY REMIDIAL TEACHING CITED AS SUCCESS
description: SIXTEEN years after the passage of Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, a law that has fundamentally altered attitudes and practices in remedial education, there is a growing body of evidence that early intervention can reverse declines and lead to dramatic increases in the achievement levels of disadvantaged pupils.

title: COAL TALKS RECESS AS NEW DEADLOCK LOOMS
description: Negotiations to end the 53-day strike of 160,000 Eastern and Middle Western coal miners were recessed abruptly by union leaders today after a meeting of less than two hours resulted in what might be a climactic deadlock.

title: GOODMAN IS SOUGHT TO LEAD REPUBLICANS IN MANHATTAN
description: Roy M. Goodman, the liberal Republican who represents Manhattan's East Side in the State Senate, has been offered the Republican chairmanship of New York County by party leaders.

title: A Year's Salute to Ataturk Starts Today, and Koch Joins in Tribute
description: A yearlong celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, who founded the Republic of Turkey and initiated widespread reforms there, will begin in scores of countries and all over the United States today.

title: The U.N. Today; May 19, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: MET SLIDE HITS 8 IN 3-1 LOSS
description: The New York Mets dropped one player, promoted another and switched five others to new roles tonight. But despite all the changes, they suffered a 3-1 defeat from the San Francisco Giants and ran their losing streak to eight games.

title: Too Sweet a Deal for Sugar Growers
description: This may be the year for fiscal austerity, but someone apparently forgot to tell the sugar lobby. Over the objections of the Reagan Administration, the House and Senate Agriculture Committees have adopted rich price-support programs for sugar growers. Either plan could cost the Government hundreds of millions of dollars annually over the next few years, and raise the price of sugar in the supermarket by several cents a pound.

title: Stock Prices Show Slim Gains
description: Stocks edged higher yesterday, despite another half-point increase in the prime rate to 20 percent by major banks - the sort of news that often depresses the market. Growing conjecture on Wall Street that interest rates are near their peak served as a prop to prices.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard WORLD WITHOUT END. By Francine du Plessix Gray. 314 pages. Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: MISCHIEVOUS BILL ON JOINT CUSTODY
description: To the Editor:

title: President Resigns At Katharine Gibbs
description: Lynn D. Salvage, 34 years old, who joined Macmillan Inc. in January 1980 as president and chief executive officer of its Katharine Gibbs School, has resigned. Macmillan, whose headquarters are in New York, announced her resignation in a two-paragraph news release without any explanation.

title: 2 A.I.D. OFFICIALS SAY THEY'LL RESIGN IF U.S. REJECTS BABY-FORMULA CODE
description: Two American officials have said they will resign if the United States votes against a voluntary international code to curtail the marketing of infant formulas in poor nations.

title: IRELAND AND OUR PRESS
description: Whenever the news from Ireland gets especially dismal, British politicians and editorial writers accuse the United States press of distorting it. In making these charges, they are following a custom at least 100 years old.

title: Robert Schrade, Pianist, In Beethoven 'Waldstein'
description: Robert Schrade played the piano with unusual intelligence and sensitivity at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening. His selective ear for detail showed us Beethoven's relentlessly architectural thinking in the ''Waldstein'' Sonata; and in ''Pagodes'' and ''Poissons d'Or'' by Debussy and Ravel's ''Jeux d'Eau,'' the piano managed to glisten yet still retain the clarity of shape so necessary to this music. Scriabin's Sonata No. 5 was exquisitely evil, and a charmingly sentimental Romance by Arensky enjoyed all the performer's sympathy.

title: CONRAIL REFORM PROPOSAL DESIGNED TO SAFEGUARD THE COMMUTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL NEW YORK (NL) - Designated Dave Roberts, pitcher, for assignment. Recalled Greg Harris, pitcher, from Tidewater of the International League.
description: NEW YORK (AL) - Signed Orestes De- s trade, first baseman. BASKETBALL PORTLAND (NBA) - Named Jim Lynam assistant coach.

title: O' NEILL SIGNS BUDGET, BUT WARNS OF FALL SPENDING CUTS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill signed into law today a $2.98 billion budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, but warned that more spending cuts would have to be made in the fall as Congress reduces Federal spending.

title: Johns Hopkins Favored In N.C.A.A. Lacrosse
description: To the surprise of no one, three-time defending champion Johns Hopkins and unbeaten North Carolina have been given the top two seedings for the 11th National Collegiate Division I lacrosse tournament, which opens Wednesday. The N.C.A.A. thus agreed with the weekly coaches' poll of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, in which the nine coaches who took part in the final balloting were unanimous in ranking Johns Hopkins No. 1 and North Carolina No. 2.

title: EX-NURSE SERVED ARMY HOSPITALS IN BURMA
description: Marion A. Buckley, a World War II Army Nurse Corps captain whose 26 months in Burma included service with Merrill's Marauders, died Saturday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside. She was 75 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: Company News; SEARS, PENNEY SURGE IN QUARTER; SALES SHARPLY HIGHER OVER 1980
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J.C. Penney Company, the nation's largest and third-largest retailers, told shareholders at their annual meetings yesterday that net profits surged in the first quarter.

title: Dome Skirts Query In Hudson's Bay Bid
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., which is buying 14 million shares of Conoco Inc. to swap for Conoco's 53 percent interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, sidestepped a Conoco challenge that it be indemnified against any taxes on the transaction but said the offer could be structured so that Conoco would not incur capital gains taxes.

title: CLIBURN CONTEST'S PHASE I HALFWAY POINT
description: Nearly half of the 39 pianists in the Van Cliburn Quadrennial International Voice Competition have gone through Phase I of the preliminaries, and if audience reaction is any judge, the standard so far has been set by the 28-year-old Andre-Michel Schub. The American pianist, who drew No. 17 and thus was the 17th to play, went through 30 minutes of music that encompassed the Baroque style of a Bach partita to the flamboyant virtuosity of the Paganini-Liszt E-flat Etude, with some Beethoven and Schubert in between.

title: INQUIRY IS SET IN COAST DEATH OF EX-MARINE
description: The coroner's office said today that it would try to determine what caused the death of a former Marine who had fired weapons inside a veterans' hospital last March, asserting that he had been poisoned by the herbicide Agent Orange in Vietnam and that nobody cared.

title: SHAWLS IN ALL SIZES: THE LATEST REVIVAL FOR A HARDY PERENNIAL
description: Almost before the first fashions were off the runway in the recent series of fall and winter showings on both sides of the Atlantic, shawls began sprouting on the shoulders of members of the audience. On that intangible network that connects the work of style leaders in all the leading fashion centers, the message had gone out: shawls are back in style.

title: BIG BANKS LIFT PRIME TO 20%
description: Under pressure from sharp increases in short-term interest rates that have raised their own cost of money, many of the nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent, from 19 1/2 percent.

title: CONNORS LOSES FINAL IN FOUR SETS
description: Peter McNamara, in an uncharacteristic turn of form, won the singles final from Jimmy Connors today, then lost the doubles final with his partner Paul McNamee to Hans Gildemeister of Chile and Andreas Gomez of Ecuador at the $200,000 West German open tennis championships. McNamara and McNamee, from Australia, are the Wimbledon doubles champions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This program is probably the best reflection of the rugged individualism exemplified by my father - the risky betting on individual explorers while everybody else is playing it safe on another track.'' - Roderick MacArthur, on awards given by the foundation his father established. (B13:1.)

title: Venezuela Gets U.S. Support For Latin Economic Plan
description: Venezuelan officials said today that they had found support in the Reagan Administration for a multinational economic development program to enhance the stability of democratic governments in the Caribbean and Central America.

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: 1981 results include foreign currency translation losses of 9 cents a shr for the qr and 11 cents a shr for the 9 mos; 1980 results reflect a 2 cents a shr loss for the qr and 4 cents a s gain for the 9 mos from foreign currency translations

title: F.D.A. Approves Sale of Generics
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the sale of three generic drugs yesterday, enacting a policy intended to speed the introduction of cheap copies of drugs developed by research companies. The action followed Federal court rulings that ended fights against the F.D.A. by two research companies, the American Hospital Supply Corporation and the Burroughts Wellcome Company.

title: Starrett Reports Loss of $504,000
description: The Starrett Housing Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had a loss of $504,000 in the first quarter ended March 31, compared with a profit of $39,000 for the corresponding 1980 period.

title: 33 Mexicans Die in Bus Crash
description: Thirty-three people were killed and 15 seriously injured when a bus and a truck collided in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, the police said today.

title: COMMODITIES MARKETS IN THE DOLDRUMS
description: Normally, Benjamin Wong rarely has time to chat during trading hours on New York's Commodity Exchange. His eyes dart from the overhead quote boards to the gold futures trading pit to the stack of order cards he keeps close to his chest. Now and then, he will dash into the pit, shouting and flailing this arms, the normal way of executing orders.

title: BIBBY HURLS 1- HITTER, RETIRING 27 IN A ROW AFTER LEADOFF SINGLE
description: The Pirates' Jim Bibby pitched a one-hitter, retiring 27 straight Atlanta batters after yielding a leadoff single, as Pittsburgh defeated the Braves, 5-0, tonight.

title: BRIE DE MEAUX IN THE UNITED STATES IS RARELY THE REAL THING
description: Last August the French Government decided that several types of Brie could be included in the growing list of cheeses that deserve ''appellation d'origine.'' As in the case of wines, for which the system of ''appellations controlees'' has existed since 1935, the regulation of certain cheeses serves as a guarantee to the consumer that the product was made in a strictly limited region according to particular standards. It also protects producers.

title: SLAUGHTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Eastern, American Reduce Air Fares
description: Eastern Airlines and American Airlines joined a number of other domestic passenger air carriers in lowering their fares and removing travel restrictions to increase traffic during the coming summer months.

title: Article 125593 -- No Title
description: New York State opened its sale of $3.05 billion in short-term notes this morning with a 9.29 percent interest rate from its underwriters. But a few hours later the rate was lowered to 9.187 percent after heavy demand by investors. The note issue, which primarily provides cash for school aid, was fully subscribed by early afternoon.

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
UNITED, ROGERS BID FOR UA-COLUMBIA
description: The United Artists Theater Circuit and a Canadian concern, Rogers Telecommunications Ltd., announced yesterday that they planned to offer about $297 million for all the shares of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc.

title: TELEPROMPTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: -Including extraordinary tax credits of $72,000 for the latest period and $698,000 for the previous period

title: Composers Orchestra Plans 3 Concerts in '81-82
description: The American Composers Orchestra, devoted to contemporary orchestral works, will present three concerts in Alice Tully Hall during the 1981-82 season.

title: SILVERMAN SAYS NBC WILL BE 'COMPETITIVE'
description: In contrast to last year, when he promised that NBC-TV would be in first place in the audience-popularity ratings by Christmas, Fred Silverman, the network's president, promised only that the network's fall schedule would be ''competitive'' when he addressed the annual meeting of NBC affiliates today. Mr. Silverman quipped, ''If I stood up here today and predicted 85 degrees and sunshine for L.A. tomorrow, I know deep down we'd all be snowbound by morning.''

title: QUEENS WILL PLAY RAMAPO IN TOURNEY OPENER TODAY
description: Queens, winner of the City University baseball championship, will meet Ramapo (N. J.) College today in the opener of the National Collegiate Division III Northeast Regional tournament at Eastern Connecticut State College in Willimantic.

title: RONCO TELEPRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
BONN SEEK EARLY U.S. SOVIET MISSILE TALKS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who arrives in Washington tomorrow for three days of talks, will suggest to the Reagan Administration that it advance its schedule for discussions with the Soviet Union on medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe, a Government source said today.

title: ASTRONAUTS SALUTE CREW OF COLUMBIA
description: Legendary American heroes of space travel - Shepard, Glenn, Armstrong, Aldrin, Borman - and 35 other astronauts joined President Reagan today in a salute to the crew of the space shuttle Columbia and their ''victory for the American spirit.''

title: THE FINAL PROTECTOR OF OUR LEGAL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Selected for Assay Post
description: President Reagan today nominated Clifford Barber, an upstate New York lawyer, for Superintendent of the United States Assay Office in New York. Mr. Barber is 63 years old and senior partner of Barber and Gorss of Montgomery, N.Y. He was a delegate to the 1980 Republican Convention in New York. Mr. Reagan also nominated Cecilia Aranda Frantz, Superintendent of the Wilson School District in Phoenix, for director of the National Institute of Handicapped Research.

title: Discoveries; THE PRINCE AND PREPPIES; 1. Charles, the Author
description: There is Prince Charles, H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, and prospective bridegroom. Now meet Prince Charles, author. It seems that when his brothers Prince Andrew and Prince Edward were 9 and 5 years old, the royal family took a cruise on the royal yacht, Brittania. Apparently, even yachts get boring for little boys after a while, so to keep them amused and out of mischief, their big brother wrote them a story about the adventures of an elderly Scotsman. And quite wondrous the adventures are, and frequently very funny. Now ''The Old Man of Lochnagar'' is a book, charmingly illustrated by Sir Hugh Casson and published by Hamish Hamilton, London; you can buy it at Barney's for $12. The proceeds will go to the Prince of Wales Charitable Trust.

title: Vilas Defeats Kirmayr; 5 Americans Win in Italy
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas kept Carlos Kirmayr of Brazil under control in a 6-2, 6-3 victory in the first round of the $200,000 Italian open tennis tournament today, but an unheralded Yugoslav, Marko Ostoja, sprang an upset by ousting 11th-seeded Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 3-6, 6-3, 6-1.

title: I.R.A. MINE KILLS 5 BRITISH SOLDIERS PATROLLING A COUNTRY ROAD IN ULSTER
description: Five British soldiers were killed today in an Irish Republican Army ambush apparently timed to coincide with the imminent death of another prison hunger striker.

title: PANEL CREATES A HISTORIC DISTRICT IN MANHATTAN'S EAST 60'S AND 70'S
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted yesterday to create a historic district on a gilded stretch of Manhattan's East Side that abuts Central Park and forms an architectural evocation of old New York.

title: DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $54,000 tax credit

title: TV: 'THE MUPPETS GO TO THE MOVIES''
description: ONE of television's most durable creations, the Muppets, are popping up on ABC-TV tonight at 8 in an hourlong special of their own. ''The Muppets Go to the Movies'' features, among many other things, Miss Piggy as Dorothy in ''The Wizard of Oz'' and Kermit the Frog in a tribute to Fred Astaire, plus splendidly compatible guest appearances by Lily Tomlin and Dudley Moore.

title: PIANIST: IVO POGORELICH AT CARNEGIE
description: GENUINE individuality is a rare and precious asset in any musical performer. Sometimes it takes an artist a long time to discover his or her own differentness and even longer to put that difference to work in the service of music. Young musicians especially must be allowed considerable room in which to try on personalities and be granted license to abandon them if they happen not to fit, like last year's suit. So let it merely be noted here at the start that Ivo Pogorelich, the 22-year-old Yugoslav pianist who appeared last evening at Carnegie Hall is something of an eccentric in dress and stage manners. He affected a string tie and a shirt with a stand-up collar, and wore his hair in a style that might be called electrified shaggy. He struck dazed postures between numbers (Oh, where am I? Do I wake or sleep?) and in general did what he could to avoid appearing in the least conventional. Never mind, the only real issue in this, his New York debut, was how Mr. Pogorelich played the piano and how well he played music on that piano.

title: Union Camp Plans South Carolina Mill
description: The Union Camp Corporation, a diversified paper, packaging and chemicals concern, announced it would build a $600 million bleached pulp and paper mill near Eastover, S.C. Construction is to start early next year with the mill scheduled for completion in mid-1984, the company said.

title: ZHU DA MING, CHINESE PIANIST, STIRS CLIBURN CONTEST

description: The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation will pay off depositors of the Economy Savings and Loan Association, a Chicago institution that was closed earlier this week by the state authorities for having exhausted its net worth. title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 20, 1981
description: International Syria's President and Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's envoy, had another discussion about the Syrian missiles in Lebanon, which Israel threatens to attack. Mr. Habib gave no details of the talks, saying only that he would continue his mediation efforts, and traveled to Israel for further talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin. The Israeli Cabinet reportedly will meet today to discuss Mr. Habib's proposals. (Page A1, Column 4.) The man accused of shooting the Pope had considered other targets, according to Italian police sources. The suspect, Mehmet Ali Agca, reportedly told Italian magistrates investigating the assassination attempt that he had considered killing the British monarch, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations and Simone Veil, the President of the European Parliament. Meanwhile, the Pope continued to improve and his temperature dropped to 98.6. (A1:1.)

description: Northwest Airlines will adopt a hub and spoke route network to meet stiffening competition and to help the company continue its recovery from recent operating losses, Joseph Lapensky, the company's president, told stockholders at the annual meeting.

description: The United States economy, as measured by the gross national product, grew at a surprising 8.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter of this year, much more rapidly than nearly anyone had anticipated.

description: A dispute between New York City and its largest municipal employees union has raised new questions about the status of ''workfare'' programs in which home-relief recipients work off their monthly financial grants in city jobs.

The City; The Police Blotter

Detectives said more arrests were expected. ... Burglars stole sacred vessels valued at more than $30,000 from St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church at 196-10 Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens. title: An Appraisal
description: A professional team assembled by the American Institute of Architects, which began its annual convention here yesterday, declared Minneapolis and its neighboring city, St. Paul, to be ''one of the nation's highest quality urban environments.''

title: Saudis Cut LPG Price
description: The Saudi Arabian state-run oil company, Petromin, has cut its export price for liquefied petroleum gas to Japan by $40 a ton, to $255, effective immediately, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today. Japan imported 10 million tons of LPG in the fiscal year 1980, 3 percent more than in the previous year, with half of it supplied by Petromin, the ministry said.

title: Retreating From Remedial Education
description: A recent study by the National Institute of Education revealed the discouraging fact that the reasoning ability of 17-year-olds has declined in the last decade. But the study also contains news of striking gains in achievement among 9- and 13-year-old black children and 9-year-olds in poor urban neighborhoods.

title: The Pop Life; SELF-DESTRUCTION? NOT FOR THESE PUNK STARS
description: ''PUNK rock really represents a return to traditional values,'' John Doe of the Los Angeles punk band X asserted recently. That may sound laughable to rock fans who associate punk with safety pins, leather jackets and green hair, but Exene, who is Mr. Doe's wife and shares X's lead vocals with him, contended that these manifestations are a fashion trend and have little to do with punk music. ''The whole point of punk rock is individualism,'' she said, ''not fashion.'' And increasingly, individualism is taking X in musical directions that are alienating some of the group's original hardcore fans. Pure punk, as introduced by the Sex Pistols, the Ramones and a few other mid-70's bands, is fast, hard, loud and relentless. X's music is more subtle.

title: METS SUFFER 9TH LOSS IN ROW, 4-1

title: The Economy
description: The gross national product grew at an 8.4 percent annual rate in the first quarter, up from the 6.5 percent that the Commerce Department reported earlier. First-quarter inflation was also revised upward, prompting some economists to predict further credit-tightening. Some analysts said the report would make it more difficult for the Administration to push through its tax-cut plan. (Page A1.)

title: TAX PROBLEMS FACING COOPERATIVE BUILDINGS WITH STORES

title: The Egg Industry's View

Cold storage eggs, rather than being ''almost all we get in supermarkets,'' are a thing of the past. Cold storage is impractical, expensive and unnecessary. It has not been an industry practice for many years.

title: Retirement Terminated

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Budget Versus Reality
description: FOR the time being, President Reagan has got what he wanted from Congress: a $695.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982. This represents a cut of $43.8 billion below the Carter Administration's proposed budget for that year. But the Reagan budget figures are clearly wrong, even before the first Congressional budget resolution has been printed. Virtually no informed person in Congress or the White House believes that spending in the fiscal year 1982 will be anywhere near that low.

title: BASQUE HOME RULE BECOMING A REALITY

In Lemona, in Vizcaya Province, two Civil Guards were killed when terrorists of the Basque separatist organization, E.T.A., detonated a land mine under their jeep. In Vizcaya and Guipuzcoa Provinces, a score of Basque radicals were accused under harsh antiterrorist legislation of helping E.T.A.

title: Last, Worst Hope for Transit

It looks like a desperate exercise in fig-leaf politics, a way for the legislators to diffuse the blame for painful decisions they know to be unavoidable. But it can also be a constructive step, for the long term as well as for the moment, if the committee is strong enough to force the lawmakers to focus on the main issue.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Agronomics Corp. has decided to triple the capacity of its Myakka citrus fruit concentrating plant in Arcadia, Fla., at an undisclosed cost.

title: TEXAS AIR ICREASES BID FOR CONTINENTAL
description: Frank A. Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, said today that his company was prepared to increase by $1 a share, to $14, its offer for the Continental Air Lines stock that it does not already own. The total value of the revised offer would be approximately $110 million.

title: AN ISRAEL MUSEUM FETE IN THE ANCIENT STYLE
description: Occupied West Bank ON this stark and windy archeological site overlooking the Dead Sea, one hour from and 3,600 feet below Jerusalem, board members of the Israel Museum and their companions gathered recently for a meal that included eggs and apples eaten from clay bowls with wooden spoons in a style associated with the Essenes, who lived here 2,000 years ago. The museum's greatest treasure, the Dead Sea Scrolls, which were found here in 1947, are attributed to a largely monastic sect like the Essenes.

title: Strike Closes Israeli Schools
description: A million Israeli pupils were shut out of classes today by a teachers' strike over wages. The teachers have been demanding pay equal to that of engineers even though they would have to do more work.

title: Kitchen Equipment; FLAN RINGS
description: THE flan ring is a more capable piece of equipment than you might imagine. That's because when you first look at one it's hard to imagine it does anything at all. It is nothing more than a metal ring, usually tinned or stainless steel, several inches in diameter and 5/8 of an inch deep. It looks like something that might hold together a small barrel -but what can it do in cooking?

title: ROSOFF'S LEASE BOUGHT BY O'NEALS
description: Rosoff's restaurant, a fixture on 43d Street east of Times Square for 63 years, closed Monday when the lease on the building that houses it was sold to Michael and Patrick O'Neal, who operate five other restaurants in Manhattan.

title: KETCHIKAN PULP AND THE ASSISTANT AGRICULTURE SECRETARY DESIGNATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Car Sales Up
description: Italian auto sales rose to 668,600 units in the first four months of 1981 from 629,900 in the same period last year, the national car manufacturers association, Anfia, reported today. Sales in April rose to 189,700 from 152,400 in March and 169,900 in April 1980, Anfia's latest delivery figures showed. Imports took 40.25 percent of the market in the first four months, compared with 35.9 percent in the same period of 1980.

title: Cities Service to Sell 2 Nonenergy Units
description: The Cities Service Company, the nation's 19th-largest refiner, said yesterday that it was trying to sell two of its largest nonenergy businesses in order to raise capital for expanded exploration in its more profitable oil and gas operations.

title: CAREY EXPECTED TO NAME PANEL TO STUDY TRANSIT
description: Governor Carey plans to name a panel of at least seven people to study the financial problems of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and recommend ways to resolve them. Most of the panel members will be financiers and executives who dealt with the New York City fiscal crisis in 1975.

title: Arco Cuts Oil Price
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said that it had cut its posted price for crude oil by $2 a barrel in most areas, following an industry pattern of price reductions over the last week. The posted price is the price refiners set for crude oil they purchase. The increases do not affect certain grades of Oklahoma and Wyoming crude oil, the company said.

title: 2 ALABAMA INMATES RECAPTURED
description: Two convicted murderers were recaptured today, leaving only one man at large out of eight maximum-security prisoners who escaped from Holman Prison, the authorities said. Officers said that Olynn Burnett and Gerald Armitage were picked up after tracking dogs found them in a forest three miles north of the prison in southwest Alabama. James R. Straigtz, serving 30 years for grand larceny, burglary and escape, was still at large, prison officials said.

title: The Region; Connecticut House Passes Liquor Bill
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives gave final legislative approval to a bill repealing the state's minimum-markup law on beer and liquor next Jan. 1 and on wine a year later.

title: K mart Net Off 12.6% in Quarter
description: The K mart Corporation yesterday reported a 12.6 percent decline in its net income for the first quarter ended April 29, its sixth consecutive quarterly drop.

title: Agnew Appeals Order to Repay $248,735 to State of Maryland
description: Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has appealed a judge's order that he pay the State of Maryland $248,735 for his role in a kickback scheme, and the appeal will probably be heard in the fall, court papers showed today.

title: MAMAGERS EJECTED AS YANKS DOWN ROYALS
description: Finding new ways to drive Yankee Stadium fans into a frenzy, the Yanks and Royals clawed at each other last night before the New Yorkers, who had trailed by 5-0, finally escaped with a 6-5 victory.

title: Doctor Refuses Cooperation In Study of Hospital Deaths
description: A doctor who treated nearly all the 25 elderly patients who died mysteriously at a small rural hospital has refused to cooperate with officials investigating the deaths, Carl Smith Jr., deputy Riverside County coroner, said today.

title: VAN DUSEN AIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31

title: MUSIC: TAGLIAVINI AS FRITZ
description: AFTER a certain age, opera singers return to the scenes of former triumphs at their own risk. Ferruccio Tagliavini, a popular tenor at the Metropolitan Opera 30 years ago, made a comeback Sunday night in Carnegie Hall singing the title role in Mascagni's ''L'Amico Fritz,'' a concert performance presented by the American Opera Repertory Company. If the results were not an unalloyed triumph, at least Mr. Tagliavini gave his old fans a generous memento of why he had been so esteemed in his heyday.

title: BUDGET CUTS TEST EASYGOING LEGISLATOR
description: With his lopsided smile and easygoing manner, Carl D. Perkins might convey the impression that he is a happy man. But these are not happy days for the durable 68-year-old Representative from the heart of Appalachia.

title: 2 RETAILERS PROFITS RISE
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, New York, operator of Lord & Taylor and 16 other store divisions, said yesterday that it had a 74 percent advance in its net income for the first fiscal quarter, ended May 2, to $4.35 million, or 32 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 19 cents a share, in the comparable 1980 quarter. Sales rose 13.9 percent, to $454.2 million.

title: Schmidt Of Germany
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany comes to Washington this week at a delicate point in the history of the NATO alliance and its relations with the Soviet Union. He may be in political trouble at home but he is a welcome visitor here for several reasons.

title: THAI CUISINE'S RIGHT TIME AND PLACE
description: FEW foreign cuisines introduced to this country in recent years have had so instant and lasting an appeal as that of Thailand, the complex and glittering jewel of a country we used to know as Siam. At least a dozen Thai restaurants in New York, most of which opened within the past four years, continue to flourish, and Thai food stores offering the aromatic and spicy ingredients are beginning to spread throughout the city. As with many other cuisines of Southeast Asia, the Thai recipes rely on spices generally associated with Indian curries and cooking techniques that are primarily Chinese, adding to the mix highly perfumed and often fiery native herbs, grasses and chilies. Arriving on the local scene just as Americans were developing a taste for both hotly seasoned food and lightly cooked vegetable, noodle and rice dishes that included relatively little meat, Thai food won instant popularity. title: Hudson Bay Joins Minorco in U.S. Bid
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said it and the Minerals and Resources Corporation of Bermuda had reached tentative agreement to acquire a privately owned United States coal company for a combination of cash and notes valued at $152 million.

title: CONNECTICUT'S WELFARE RECIPIENTS ARE GIVEN JOBS TO PAY BACK CITIES
description: Frank Carino, head custodian at Washington Junior High School, was waiting in the teachers' lounge for a helper the city welfare office had promised to send. ''The guys on welfare steady are the lazy ones,'' he said. ''The ones who are laid off, temporarily out of work, are good.''

title: 170 BOMB THREATS OR SCARES REPORTED IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The New York City police received more than 170 bomb threats or scares yesterday, forcing the evacuation of several buildings in Manhattan, including the Chrysler Building and the Criminal Courts Building. No bombs were found.

title: FEAR PERVADES MAKESHIFT BEIRUT SHELTER
description: The members of two young families, the Hamouds and the Khalifis, huddled today in the stairwell of the Hamouds' large apartment in Beirut's ravaged Masraa section.

title: Personal Health
description: AVIRGINIA housewife who had befriended some stray cats developed severe leg pains, swollen glands, a persistent high fever, loss of appetite and extreme weakness. She thought she had the flu or mononucleosis, but the doctor figured otherwise.

title: U.C.L.A.-Rutgers Opens Meadowlands College Basketball Dec. 3
description: U.C.L.A. and Rutgers will start college basketball at the new Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands sports complex Dec. 3, opening an 11-game schedule in the 20,100-seat arena, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today.

title: 3-PART K MART PLAN ADOPTED TO RECOVER GROWTH MONENTUM
description: The K mart Corporation has undertaken a three-part strategy aimed at recovering the momentum that had made it retailing's growth leader in the last decade and the one company likely to challenge Sears, Roebuck & Company's hold as America's chain-store leader by 1990.

title: HABIB MEETS ASSAD, CONFERS WITH BEGIN ON MISSILE SOLUTION
description: President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, met here today with President Hafez al-Assad and in Israel tonight with Prime Minister Menachem Begin. Mr. Habib gave no details of the talks, saying only that he would continue his mission aimed at averting an Israeli-Syrian clash.

title: The City; City Bus Driver Sues Over 'Gag' Order
description: A bus driver who has criticized safety conditions on city buses sued the Transit Authority yesterday because he contends that an authority gag order violates his right to free speech. The suit - against the Transit Authority and its president, John D. Simpson -was filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn by the driver, Neil Eisenberg of Staten Island.

title: STAGE: SEXUAL CONFUSION ON 'CLOUD 9'
description: ''CLOUD 9,'' a new comedy by a British writer named Caryl Churchill, may not transport the audience all the way to Cloud 9 - but it surely keeps us on our toes. The evening's subject is sexual confusion, and Miss Churchill has found a theatrical method that is easily as dizzying as her theme. Not only does she examine a cornucopia of sexual permutations - from heterosexual adultery right up to bisexual incest -but she does so with a wild array of dramatic styles and tricks.

title: Elizabeth Robinson Married
description: Elizabeth Binder Robinson, who has completed a year's study in the M.B.A. program at the University of Michigan, was married last Sunday to Steven Paul Schubiner, a student at the Wayne State University Law School. Rabbi Alan W. Miller performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Irwin Jay Robinson, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, and Mrs. Robinson of Riverdale, the Bronx. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Schubiner of Oak Park, Mich.

title: THE ELDERLY ARE COURTED BY MERLINO
description: '' They have had to double the price a senior citizen pays for a prescription to $2,'' State Senator Joseph P. Merlino said, ''but that program is still good.''

title: E. Llwyd Ecclestone, 79; A Residential Developer
description: E. Llwyd Ecclestone Sr., a developer of residential communities on Florida's rich Atlantic Coast, died of cancer Monday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach. He was 79 years old and lived in Lost Tree Village, North Palm Beach.

title: HOUSTON PETERSON, PROFESSOR, DIES
description: Houston Peterson, a professor of philosophy at Rutgers University who conducted a popular series of free lectures at Cooper Union from 1938 to 1946, died yesterday of a heart attack in Dennis, Mass. He was 83 years old and lived at One Washington Square Village in Manhattan.

title: CANNES FESTIVAL BOOMS DESPITE AN AIR OF CRISIS
description: After weeks of rain in Southern France, the clouds vanished and in the best cinematic style, the sun broke through to shine on the 34th Cannes Film Festival, now in full swing here on the Cote d'Azur.

title: ATLANTIC BUYER HALTS PAYMENTS
description: Alleging that he was misled about the financial condition of The Atlantic Monthly, which he purchased it last year, Mortimer Zuckerman has refused to pay five outside stockholders the second installment due under terms of the acquisition agreement.

title: AN ABADAN ROAD CLAIMED BY IRAN IS FOUND STILL EMBATTLED IN WAR
description: An Iranian colonel reported here today that Iraqi and Iranian forces were facing each other across a road that Iran said three days ago had been recaptured.

title: TO SOLVE HOUSING NEEDS: MOBILE HOMES
description: Doomsday predictions about unaffordable housing appear almost daily. In the last quarter of 1980, the median cost of a new site-built home was $80,600 - a pricetag that may make owning a home a perpetually unfulfilled American dream. On the other hand, ''manufactured housing'' - the statutory name that Congress conferred on mobile homes in 1980 and that the industry uses - is the best-kept secret bargain in America. The average cost of a mobile home in 1980 was about $18,500.

description: An anonymous telephone caller, saying that he represented the extreme left-wing Red Army Faction, asserted today that he was responsible for the shooting last week of a West German official. A Justice Ministry official quoted the caller as saying that the Red Army Faction would follow up the murder of Heinz Karry, economics minister in Hesse state, with bomb attacks on airports in Frankfurt and London.

description: -Deliberate, excessive violence on the field and violent reaction in the stands is "one of the greatest threats to the future of spectator sports of every kind, here and abroad," the head of the Miami Dolphins told Congress today. "We must take stern and strict measures for adequate control in each instance," said Joe Robbie, managing general partner of the Miami team.

title: Schieffelin President
description: James P. Kavanagh, 41, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Schieffelin & Company, a New York-based liquor and wine importer and distributor. He succeeds W. Michael Cushman, who died earlier this month at the age of 46.

title: By Peter G. Davis; Chamber: Quintet Of the Americas
description: THE Quintet of the Americas played two world premieres at their concert last night at Hunter College, where the group is in residence. Both pieces were composed especially for the ensemble: Ed Bland's Quintet for Winds and Kathleen St. John's ''The Winds of Aeolus.''

title: Legal Smoke Over the National Forests
description: Today's vote on the nomination of John B. Crowell Jr. to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture for Natural Resources and Environment puts the Senate in a difficult position. The nomination has been controversial from the start. Mr. Crowell has been a highly capable and aggressive general counsel for the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, one of the nation's leading timber companies and the largest single buyer of timber from the national forests. In his new job, he would be in charge of those same forests.

title: YUGOSLAVS CLOSE REGIONAL COLLEGE
description: The government of Yugoslavia's troubled Kosovo Province closed the provincial university and other schools of higher learning today after a demonstration by 1,000 students, who demanded that the province become a republic and unite with neighboring Albania, the press agency Tanyug said.

title: BLACKS TRYING AGAIN IN CRUCIAL VOTE SUIT
description: A crucial legal battle over black voting rights in the South opened this week as a Federal judge began hearing testimony here in a case seeking to determine whether this city's election laws were designed to keep blacks from holding public office.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IF I had to name the greatest revolution in my own taste since I came to America more than 40 years ago, it would probably be my enthusiasm for pasta. At almost every meal when I was a child, we dined on either rice or potatoes or, one of the most basic forms of pasta, noodles. The noodles (which were never referred to as pasta) were always served with any of several kinds of stews or ragouts: veal marengo, which is with tomatoes and mushrooms; chicken in Burgundy wine sauces; rabbit, hunter's style, and so on. But I don't recall ever having spaghetti, which is basic on American menus, and certainly not the more unusual forms of pasta like fettuccine and linguine.

title: A Gesture Can Mean a Lot
description: Americans, Iosif Mendelevich was saying yesterday, underestimate the impact of their symbolic gestures. Mr. Mendelevich, who spent 10 years in a Soviet labor camp, offered his observation during a candlelighting ceremony at New York's City Hall on behalf of Ida Nudel. Miss Nudel, a Soviet Jew, is serving a four-year sentence for hanging a banner from her Moscow window demanding a long-denied exit visa.

title: SOLAR-POWERED PLANE SET A ALTITUDE RECORD IN A COAST TEST FLIGHT
description: Janice Brown, a test pilot, flew a solar-powered airplane to a record 14,300 feet yesterday in preparation for a Paris-to-London flight next month.

title: Technology; Photochemistry: Role of Lasers
description: IT'S getting to be that time of year when people like to settle down on the lawn or beach and engage in a little photochemistry. Getting a tan is one of many photochemical processes - that is, light-induced chemical changes - that are a part of everyday life. Others include photography, in which pictures are produced by lightinduced changes in the chemicals on the film, and photosynthesis, the process by which plants convert sunlight into the sugars they need to survive.
