description: Acknowledging that they risk a ''credibility problem'' as reservoir levels continue to rise, New York City environmental officials said yesterday that they did not plan now to follow New Jersey's lead and ease restrictions on water use.

title: CANADA PERMANENT SOUGHT BY BELZBERGS
description: Management of the Canada Permanent Trust Company said that its board met today to examine a takeover offer by the Belzberg family. No reaction was immediately forthcoming, but at least one securities analyst here advised Canada Permanent shareholders not to rush to tender their shares.

title: CHALLENGES PERIL A STATE RISE OF 15% IN WELFARE BENEFITS
description: As a result of conservative challenges now under study by the Reagan Administration, New York welfare recipients might lose out on part of the full 15 percent increase recently approved in Albany. Those challenges could lead to a cut in food stamps that would offset nearly a third of the forthcoming increase.

title: Continental Air Rejects Merger Bid
description: Directors of Continental Air Lines rejected the $14-a-share merger proposal of Texas International Airlines as inadequate and not in the best interests of Continental and its shareholders.

title: Grambling to Play Here
description: The Whitney M. Young Jr. memorial football game will be held at Yankee Stadium Sept. 5.

title: 2 HARDY SURVIVORS AMID URBAN GROWTH
description: THE 1850 house in Harlem is in the French Second Empire style. The 1840 house on Staten Island is in the English Gothic Revival style. But the most interesting thing about these two houses is their survival while most similar houses throughout the city have been demolished in nearly a century and a half of urban development.

title: Safeway Stores In Mexico Deal
description: Safeway Stores Inc., Oakland, Calif., the nation's largest food supermarket chain, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 49 percent interest in a Mexican food retailer, Casa Ley S.A. of Culiacan, Sinaloa, and would assist the concern in an expansion program in Mexico.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Net loss; yr ago results have been restated for the adoption of LIFO accounting

title: Around the World; Wyszynski, Improved, Plans To Visit the Pope in Rome
description: The health of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, 79-year-old Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has improved so much that he is planning a trip to Rome next month, church officials said today.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO PROMOTE EXPORTS
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that the Reagan Administration wanted to reduce taxation of Americans abroad and encourage establishment of American overseas trading companies as part of a program to stimulate the economy through greater exports.

title: Helpful Hardware; EQUIPMENT FOR EXPANDING CLOSET SPACE
description: ALONG with spring cleaning often comes the task of reorganizing your closet as you switch over from winter to summer clothes. We found some ingenious products to help you gain more closet space and to organize existing space.

title: TAX SOCIAL SECURITY BUT LET US RETIRE AT 65
description: To the Editor:

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Business People; KEMPER FILLS POST IN INSURANCE SECTOR
description: Rudolph F. Landolt, 58 years old, has been named president of the insurance operations of the Kemper Group, made up of the property, casualty and life insurance companies that accounted for 75 percent of Kemper's $2.2 billion in total sales last year. The post at the Long Grove, Ill., corporation, which operates a variety of insurance and financial services companies, had been vacant since the retirement of Maxwell D. Rudgers in 1979.

title: REAGAN'S MELLON SLICES
description: Soon after taking office, Ronald Reagan informed us that the nation is ''in the worst economic mess since the Great Depression.'' It had become fashionable, even before he made his pronouncement, to point out the similarities between the current economic situation and that of the 1930's.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SAUDI ASKS A FREEZE IN PRICE OF OIL
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said yesterday that the kingdom would ask OPEC to freeze prices at their current level through 1982. Sheik Yamani also said the kingdom would ask for moderate price increases thereafter by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Western Wind Stages Vecchi's 'L'Amfiparnaso'
description: Composed in 1594, Orazio Vecchi's ''L'Amfiparnaso'' is a plotless collection of 15 madrigals focusing on the antics of traditional commedia dell'arte types, a 16th-century madcap revue drawing on every vocal form of the period with exhilarating virtuosity. ''L'Amfiparnaso'' was never intended to be staged, but the Western Wind, an a cappella vocal sextet, has joined forces with Jane Stein's company of puppets in a production directed by Stuart White, now on view at The Theater, 428 Lafayette Street, through next Sunday afternoon.

title: TWO U.S. AIDES RESIGN OVER BABY-FORMULA VOTE
description: Two officials of the Agency for International Development in Washington said yesterday that they were resigning in protest against the American vote at the World Health Organization in Geneva opposing the adoption of a code to curtail marketing practices for infant formulas.

title: The Region; Transit Report
description: The 4:30 P.M. train to Harrison was 16 minutes late because an unruly passenger had to be ushered off by the police at the Fordham station.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
7 Arrested in Italy on Lire Outflow
description: Two of Italy's leading financiers, Roberto Calvi and Carlo Bonomi, were arrested today on charges of illegally transferring money abroad. Five other Italian executives were also arrested.

title: G.O.P. MOVING TO ENDORSE KOCH'S BID FOR RE-ELECTION
description: New York City Republicans have began a series of moves that are expected to result next month in the party's first endorsement ever of a Democratic Mayor.

title: ISLANDERS SEE NO HOME EDGE
description: The scene of the National Hockey League championship series shifted today, and so, apparently, did the feelings of the Islanders and the Minnesota North Stars. Having won their first game after losing three in a row, the Stars were delighted to be returning to Nassau Coliseum for tonight's fifth contest. The Islanders were not.

title: SAVINGS AND LOANS OPPOSING CONDITIONS IMPOSED ON MERGERS
description: At a time when the troubled savings and loan industry is consolidating through mergers and acquisitions, conditions in California have been working against the trend.

title: WHAT THE MORMONS THINK OF THE MX
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide
description: A FIRST

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $10,500,000 gain on the sale of certain trademarks

title: ASSAD SUPPORTS HABIB MISSION BUT SEES A BIAS
description: President Hafez al-Assad said today that Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, was ''welcome'' to continue his diplomatic efforts to defuse a crisis between Israel and Syria. But so far, Mr. Assad said in an interview, Mr. Habib has produced no ''specific proposals'' and has only repeated ''Israeli demands that are outside any logic.''

title: Dow Drifts Down 3.15, to 976.86
description: Stocks continued to drift lower yesterday amid uncertainty as to the direction of interest rates and the outlook for President Reagan's proposed tax-cut program. Analysts said the next cue for price movement could come from tomorrow afternoon's report by the Federal Reserve on money supply figures.

title: Critic's Notebook; ILLUSTRATED CLASSIC BOOKS, A NEVER-ENDING QUEST
description: EVERY man has his vice, people say, and mine is that I cannot keep my hands off an illustrated classic. The ones I look for are not the ones that cost the most money, either, though I wouldn't howl aloud if my Christmas stocking turned out to include the poems of Verlaine, illustrated by Bonnard; the poems of Mallarme, illustrated by Matisse, or the poems of C.P. Cavafy, illustrated by David Hockney. The ones I like to find in the antiquarian bookstores are the sleepers - Herodotus illustrated by Edward Bawden, for instance; Thackeray illustrated by Edward Ardizzone, and Tolstoy illustrated by Barnett Freedman.

title: 1,900 Strikers Dismissed
description: Leyland South Africa today dismissed 1,900 strikers at its auto assembly plant here after they ignored an ultimatum to return to work. They walked out Friday, demanding higher wages.

title: Dr. Irving Sheppard, 73, Researcher in Dentistry
description: Dr. Irving M. Sheppard, an expert in dental research and radiography, died yesterday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 73 years old.

title: STUDY SAYS DRUG USE HAS BECOME EVEN MORE LIKE 'NORMAL' COLLEGE LIFE
description: Judging by their academic achievement, participation in activities and career plans, college students who use drugs are ''essentially indistinguishable'' from nonusers, according to a new study by a team of Harvard Medical School researchers.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $895,000 extraordinary gain

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
WASHINGTON
description: ''PULLING weeds, that common garden chore, was the only 'pull' I had in getting the job,'' joked Holly Harmar Shimizu, curator of the year-old National Herb Garden here.

title: BEGIN AND ASSAD CLASH ON LEBANON BUT SAY HABIB SHOULD PRESS EFFORTS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today exchanged sharp public criticism of each other's policies on Lebanon, but both said Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, should continue his efforts to ease the tension between their countries.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A two-alarm fire raged for almost two hours in a vacant four-story factory at 868 Willoughby Street in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section before 70 firefighters brought it under control. Four neighboring buildings were evacuated after the fire was reported, but no injuries were reported. ... Police Officer Peter Kelly of the 66th Precinct in Brooklyn was suspended without pay pending a departmental hearing on charges that he had failed to return a car he leased from a car rental company last January. ... An armed man stole $2,000 from Church's Fried Chicken restaurant at 325 West 125th Street after locking the night manager and two employees in a back room, where they were found by the day manager. ... Two men and a woman robbed a branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank at 3217 Westchester Avenue in the Bronx and escaped with an undetermined amount of cash.

title: BALLET: BARYSHNIKOV'S ALL-PETIPA BILL
description: IF there is any statement of belief that Mikhail Baryshnikov will make this season as American Ballet Theater's new artistic director, it is embodied in the all-Petipa program that the company presented Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: NEW DATA SHOW RICHEST SENATOR IS EITHER HEINZ, DANFORTH OR PELL
description: The richest man in the Senate is either Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, the pickle and ketchup magnate; Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, whose holdings include the Ralston-Purina complex; or Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, who has vast inherited wealth.

title: 'INSIDER' CASE INDICTMENT IS DROPPED
description: A Federal indictment against James Mitchell Newman, a securities trader, was dismissed yesterday. He is one of four men who were accused of profiting on stock trades between 1974 and 1977 by obtaining secret information about corporate merger negotiations from Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision on Tuesday by the Landmarks Preservation Commission to give blanket landmark protection to a 1,044-building chunk of the Upper East Side is the strongest pro-preservation stance the city has taken since it went to the United

title: The New Order Changeth
description: ''The old order changeth, yielding place to new,'' wrote Tennyson, and for a time it appeared that the third world's ambitious ''New Economic Order'' would shame the industrial world's old order into a redistribution of wealth and power.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Rules Out Germ Test As Cause of 1950 Death
description: Army germ warfare tests that spread bacteria throughout the San Francisco Bay area in 1950 did not cause the death of an elderly man whose family had sued the Government, Federal District Judge Samuel Conti ruled today.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: Few men have credited women with as little intelligence, common sense and ability to fend for themselves as have Miss Blakely and other radical feminists. While she purports to promote women's causes, I suspect she has exactly the opposite effect.
description: She does women everywhere a disservice by her assumption that we can be aroused only by cynical propaganda.

title: Advice And Consent
description: The Senate confirmation process is often a humdrum business, not really enlightening. But every once in a while it illuminates a character or an issue so powerfully that we feel again the genius of those who invented the mechanism and wrote it into the Constitution.

title: Business People; INVESTOR RELATIONS CONSULTANT QUITS GEORGESON TO START FIRM
description: After 30 years with Georgeson & Company, the proxy solicitation and investor relations firm, William E. Chatlos, 53, has resigned to open his own investor relations business. The new firm will operate, at least at the outset, from Mr. Chatlos's home in North Caldwell, N.J.

title: Brooks Is Expected To Be Ranger Coach
description: Six months after he agreed to coach the Rangers, only to discover that he would have trouble getting out of a contract in Switzerland, Herb Brooks is expected to agree again tomorrow to take over the team.

title: FLAWED OPPOSITION TO A FOREIGN-WORKER PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Issue of Links to Britain Dominates Ulster Voting
description: In the midst of all its other troubles, Ulster held an election today, and, predictably, the question of its constitutional future was the principal issue.

title: U.S SAYS IT IS ENCOURAGED BY HABIB'S MIDEAST MISSION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was encouraged by statements from Israeli and Syrian leaders that they wanted the mission of the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, to continue, thus allowing more time to avert a conflict.

title: Notes on People; A Triply Rewarding Day for John Guare
description: Yesterday wasn't exactly just one of those days for John Guare.

title: Home Beat; A GUIDE TO DESIGNS BY WOMEN
description: IT started out as a small project. ''We wanted to let the public know that many of the buldings they see every day were designed by women,'' said Linda Yowell, an architect and a member of the Alliance for Women in Architecture, center below.

title: CALNY FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
DANCE: A TERPSICHORE-EUTERPE GALA
description: THE American Dance Foundation held a benefit gala on Monday at the Beacon Theater for U.S. Terpsichore and U.S. Euterpe, its constituent chamber ballet and music companies. Despite the cavernous size of the Beacon, it was more like a party, with song, dance and a little uncategorizable razzmatazz performed by some famous friends, many of whom have passed through the affiliated New York School of Ballet.

title: LEARNING ABOUT LIFE ON THE WILD SIDE
description: Ask a child who has been to the zoo and you will be told that a calf's head is bony and blunt as it thrusts up to scratching fingers, and that nestling a rabbit is like holding the softest pillow in the world.

title: FEDERAL ROLE IS ASSESSED IN AIDING FIGHT ON CRIME
description: Former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell suggested today that Federal assistance to cities experiencing a ''crime disaster'' should be channeled through state governments to insure that all the citizens in a municipal area received help and not simply those who asked for it.

title: JEFFERSON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $631,289 for the latest yr and $72,497 for the previous yr

title: AT GALA, ONLY THE GUEST WAS MISSING
description: ''In Moscow, we have a tradition among humanrights activists that the family of a political prisoner celebrate his birthday in his absence - family, friends, and people who know him perhaps only by reputation,'' said Tanya Yankelovich, stepdaughter of the exiled Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov.

title: EGYPT REPORTS ACCORD ON PEACE FORCE TO PATROL SINAI
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister announced after talks with an American negotiator today that agreement had been reached in principle on the size of a proposed multinational force to be stationed in Sinai after Israel completes its withdrawal.

title: PHOENIX RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Around the World; 2 in Nazi-Camp Trial Deny Responsibility for Deaths
description: Two former guards at Nazi camps denied prosecution charges today that they were each responsible for the murder of 1,000 Jews at a concentration camp in Poland in World War II.

title: BOEING TERMS 2 PILOTS SAFER THAN 3 IN JET CREW
description: Boeing Company officials told a Presidential committee today that a two-pilot cockpit crew would be safer than a three-member crew on advanced airliners that it will start introducing next year. One official said that it might have been a mistake to have designed a conventional three-member crew cockpit in the first place.

title: Pacific Resources
description: Pacific Resources Inc., Honolulu-based petroleum, gas and tanker concern, announced legal action in the Hawaii State Court against David B. Chalmers, president and owner of Coral Petroleum Inc. of Houston; Coral Industries, and subsidiaries of Coral Industries to prevent them from buying additional shares of Pacific Resources' stock. Among other charges, the Hawaii company alleged that Mr. Chalmers had jeopardized its future business opportunities, mainly negotiations for a joint venture with the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, an action that it said violated his fiduciary duties as a Pacific Resources director.

title: SMALL BRITISH JET WINS ITS FIRST ORDER
description: British Aerospace Ltd. has obtained a firm order from a United States airline for a new jet plane that is smaller than any commercial jet now made by American aircraft manufacturers.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $5,600 loss from the sale of assets...C-Includes $72,80 gain from the sale of assets; 1980 results have been restated

title: Vilas, Lendl and Gerulaitis Advance in Italian Tennis
description: Top-seeded Guillermo Vilas led the advance among seeded players into the third round today at the Italian open tennis championships.

title: LIMITED STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
TV Notebook; ABC RESPONDS TO ATTACK ON '20 20' IN CHICAGO
description: A DISPUTE between ABC News and WBBM-TV, the CBS-owned station in Chicago, is turning into an acrimonious battle for credibility. Two news organizations have committed substantial journalistic resources to casting doubt on each other's work.

title: JAZZ: EXPERIMENTS
description: THE Art Ensemble of Chicago called its performances at the Public Theater last Friday and Saturday nights ''great black music,'' which had its elements of chutzpah, but ultimately stuck fairly close to the truth.

title: GERMANS TO FINANCE BOSTON HOSPITAL'S GENE WORK
description: The Massachusetts General Hospital, a teaching and research arm of the Harvard Medical School, has accepted $50 million from an international chemical company to pursue basic research in molecular biology in the next 10 years.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES FLUCTUATE WIDELY
description: Interest rates gyrated widely yesterday as the credit markets continued to be extremely confused about the future of interest rates. While traders and insupply growth was slowing, interest rates remained near record levels in all maturities.

title: 2 GUILTY OF BID TO RIG PENNSYLVANIA LOTTERY
description: Nick Perry, a popular Pittsburgh television personality, and a state offical were convicted in a county court here today of a million-dollar attempt to rig the Pennsylvania lottery.

title: DOCTOR'S RADIO NETWORK TO GO OFF THE AIR MAY 31
description: The Physicians Radio Network, a round-the-clock service sponsored by several giant pharmaceutical companies, will discontinue broadcasts on May 31.

title: AMERICAN ACADEMY MEDALS GIVEN TO COWLEY AND SOYER
description: Malcolm Cowley was awarded a gold medal for belles lettres and criticism and Raphael Soyer was awarded a gold medal for painting, at yesterday's 40th annual awards ceremony of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. Bernard Malamud, the novelist, and Gunther Schuller, the composer, were formally inducted into the 50-member Academy.

title: A.T.& T. SETS VIDEO STANDARDS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday specified the electronic characteristics it wants in systems using phone lines to display printed and graphic information on home television sets.

title: Nadler & Larimer Acquires 14-Year-Old Agency
description: Nadler & Larimer, which has about $50 million in billings, has acquired 14-year-old David, Oksner & Mitchneck, billing at least $7 million from such clients as Consolidated Cigar, Johnson & Higgins insurance, Avis Car Leasing and Restaurant Associates.

title: DEATH OF PAINTERS IN L.I. TOWER BRINGS OSHA CHARGE
description: Investigators for the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration said yesterday that they were citing a painting contractor, two of whose workers died last month while painting the interior of a Long Island water tower, for violations of Federal regulations.

title: STUDY SAYS PRICE RISES IN '80 OUTSPED RAISES FOR NEW YORK WORKERS
description: The regional office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday released the last in a series of annual municipalgovernment wage surveys that began in 1970. It disclosed that pay increases for New York City employees were less than half of the rise in the Consumer Price Index for the year that ended May 1980.

title: POLISH DEBT ENMESHES THE WEST
description: In banking there is a saying that if a bank lends you less than a million dollars the bank has leverage over you, but if it lends you more than a million dollars you have leverage over the bank.

title: BIG BOARD AIDE CITES HIGH TAXES
description: William C. Freund, chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange, told Congress today that, even with enactment of President Reagan's proposed 3-year, 30-point cut in tax rates, investment income in the United States would still be taxed far more heavily than in West Germany and Japan.

title: HOW TO CHOOSE AN AIR-CONDITIONER
description: ''ABOVE-AVERAGE temperatures for the next 90 days,'' forecasts the National Weather Service. The Old Farmer's Almanac, however, predicts that June and July will be wetter and cooler than usual, followed by an August that ''drizzles, mizzles; sun sizzles.'' (Do not bother looking up ''mizzles'' in the dictionary. ''We'll make up any word to make a rhyme,'' said the Almanac's editor, Judson Hale.)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express has named James C. Winfrey Jr. vice presidentsystems planning.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
EXECUTIVE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes $1.2 million gain from the sale of property...C-Net

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
LEGAL SCHOLARS ASSAIL LEGISLATION TO CURB POWER OF FEDERAL COURTS
description: A group of bills that would strip Federal courts of power to enforce Supreme Court interpretations of the Constitution on several issues came under fire today from four prominent constitutional scholars testifying before a Senate subcommittee.

title: Electric Boat Layoffs
description: Some 300 workers at the Electric Boat shipyard will be laid off on Friday because of a light workload and a lack of new submarine contracts, company officials said today. Two weeks ago, the shipyard laid off about 100 workers, but most of them got jobs elsewhere in the yard, the company said. The shipyard has blamed the Navy for its labor problems after the Navy earlier this year gave a $1 million contract for fast-attack nuclear submarines to a Virginia competitor.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My house is heated with hot water and the boiler has two valves in the cold water line leading to it. One is an automatic feed that supplies water when needed, and I believe the other is a safety that is supposed to release water when the system is overfilled. During the past year, about half a pail of water has come out of this safety valve every day while the furnace is running. I have lived here for 10 years, but never had this problem before. Do you have any suggestions? -S.P.T., Yonkers, N.Y.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS EASED BRIBERY ACT
description: The Administration today proposed a significant relaxation of the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which was intended to prevent American companies from bribing foreign officials. The Administration argued that the existing legislation was making it difficult for the United States to compete in foreign markets.

title: THEATER: 'MR. SLOANE' IS REVIVED
description: JOE ORTON'S first full-length play, ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' is a blissfully perverse comedy of bad manners, in which everyone is entirely motivated by self-interest. After three acts of sexual power play and a case of homicide, one of the characters calmly observes, ''Well, it's been a pleasant morning.'' With Orton, the grotesque is regarded as pleasant, immorality as an accepted mode of behavior and delirium as the root of domestic comedy.

title: Hers
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks, it will be written by Patricia O'Toole, a writer and a consulting editor on Savvy magazine.

title: Notes on People; Miss Hepburn Speaks Her Mind on Compromises
description: Looking back on her life, Katharine Hepburn said, she realizes that ''I compromised all the time,'' even when it came to deciding whether she would start wearing trousers, for which she became famous.

title: Around the Nation; Four Doctors Investigated In Coast Hospital Deaths
description: Four doctors are being investigated for possible negligence and incompetence in the deaths of more than two dozen elderly patients a two rural hospitals, Art Kanady, investigator for the state Board of Medical Quality Assurance, said today. He said no report would be filed on the unnamed doctors until laboratory tests were completed early next month.

title: DESIGNER FURS: COLORS, PATTERNS AND FLICKERS OF GOLD
description: THE second installment of fur showings got off to a smashing start with furs from the house of Alixandre. With four designers in its stable -Viola Sylbert, Perry Ellis, Jeffrey Banks and Yves Saint Laurent - Alixandre presented lots of new ideas.

title: GENERAL TO RETIRE IN SPLIT OVER FORCE
description: Gen. Volney Warner, the top general in the United States Readiness Command, said today that he planned to retire because of a ''lack of support'' by the Joint Chiefs of Staff in his unsuccessful fight against creation of a separate Rapid Deployment Force command with headquarters in the United States.

title: News of Music; ROCHBERG FINISHING HIS FIRST OPERA
description: GEORGE ROCHBERG is putting the finishing touches on his first opera, ''The Confidence Man,'' based on Herman Melville's book of the same name. The world premiere will take place on July 31, 1982, at the Santa Fe Opera, and as soon as the work is safely launched, Mr. Rochberg plans to get right down to work on another opera.

title: Nobody's Always Perfect
description: Len Barker of the Cleveland Indians, making his first start since pitching a perfect game against the Blue Jays last Friday, lost to the Seattle Mariners , 3-1, tonight.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Conrail Seeks Surcharges
description: Conrail said today that it wanted to impose $2.7 million in surcharges to cut losses on freight lines in six states scheduled to be abandoned.

title: Air-Fare War Grows Wider
description: The summer air-fare war intensified yesterday as United Airlines and Trans World Airlines matched deep discounts on transcontinental fares announced earlier this week by Eastern Airlines and American Airlines.

title: POP: A DIFFERENT JOHNNIE RAY
description: JOHNNIE RAY has dried the tears that helped carry him to stardom as he agonized his way through ''Cry'' and ''The Little White Cloud That Cried'' almost 30 years ago. In his stand at Marty's, which continues through next week, he has replaced the weeping, hair-tearing approach of those days with a kind of boyish vulnerability, which is underlined by the awkward, arm-flailing gestures that also accompanied his crying jags.

title: Rohm and Haas
description: The Rohm and Haas Company said that it had filed a complaint with the International Trade Commission against the Danish Sugar Corporation Ltd. on behalf of its Romicon subsidiary, charging unfair import practices.

title: Coach's Words Give Inspiration to Stars
description: While losing three straight games to the Islanders in the Stanley Cup final, the Minnesota North Stars had listened to various precepts of the hockey wisdom of Glen Sonmor, their coach. None worked.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ELSIE LUKER DRUKKER
description: Elsie Luker Drukker, the widow of Dow H. Drukker Sr., a banker, publisher and former member of Congress from New Jersey, died Monday at her residence in Lake Wales, Fla.

title: Harris Corp. Wins Argentina Contract
description: The Harris Corporation said that it had won an international competition to design and build in Argentina what it called the world's largest domestic satellite communications system. The initial contract is valued at $30 million.

title: HOUSE VOTES $695 BILLION BUDGET WITH SHARP RISE IN MILITARY LINE
description: The House today approved a $695.5 billion budget for the fiscal year 1982 as Congress neared completion of the first stage of a process authorizing a sharp increase in military spending and a curtailment of most social programs.

title: Stokely-Van Camp Stake to Canadian
description: David J. Hennigar, a Canadian investor from Halifax, Nova Scotia, has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that he has purchased a 6.3 percent interest in Stokely-Van Camp Inc., a manufacturer of canned and frozen foods.

title: 'HEAVEN'S GATE' TRIES AGAIN AT CANNES
description: Did Michael Cimino see a tree he liked on the way to the studio and have it dug up and sent to him for $100,000? Did he throw a party to celebrate the shooting of the first million feet of film for ''Heaven's Gate''? Maybe yes and maybe no, but these are the kinds of questions that are occupying a great deal of time here at the 34th International Film Festival.

title: Michael Reagan's Father's Problem
description: Billy Carter was not the first Presidential relative to embarrass the White House, and President Reagan's son Michael, caught dropping his father's name in letters soliciting military contracts, won't be the last. In fact, the most surprising aspect of the Michael Reagan affair is that it occurred so soon after the protracted Billy Carter mess.

title: Home Improvement; NEW TYPE OF WATER HEATER CAN YIELD ENERGY SAVINGS
description: IN nine out of 10 homes in the United States, the second biggest consumer of energy - after space heating or central air-conditioning - is the hot water heater. Anything, therefore, that promises to reduce the amount of energy consumed in making hot water is bound to interest homeowners, as well as utility companies and many Federal, state and private energy-conservation authorities.

title: AT AUCTION, WALLETS WERE CLOSE TO THE VEST
description: The million-dollar art auctions that took place Monday and Tuesday at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, resulted in great disappointments. But last night's sale at Sotheby Parke Bernet was a major success, with a total of $6.8 million.

title: The City; Victim of Car Crash Awarded $4 Million
description: A Brooklyn jury awarded $8 million in damages - later reduced by the judge in the case to $4 million - to a man whose legs were crushed by a 1973 Chevrolet Malibu with a defective accelerator, according to United Press International.

title: BOMB SCARE KEEPS HOLD FOR 5TH DAY
description: The rash of unfounded bomb threats and false reports of bombs continued yesterday in New York City as investigators reported no substantial progress in their efforts to find those responsible for Saturday's fatal blast at Kennedy International Airport.

title: U.S. Aide Sees No Proof Of G.I.'s Jailed in Laos
description: Amid reports here that the Government had financed and sent a secret force of mercenaries into Laos this month looking for Americans imprisoned in a jungle camp, a top Pentagon spokesman said tonight that ''there was no convincing evidence of the Americans' having been there.''

title: VW Plans Layoffs In Pennsylvania
description: Volkswagen said that it will lay off 5,700 workers at its Westmoreland County assembly plant for one week beginning June 1 because of the slumping auto market.

title: NEW HOME FOR STUDIO MUSEUM
description: The Studio Museum in Harlem marked the commencement of renovation and construction on its future home yesterday. Some 200 guests, many of whom represented the museum's supporters in the corporate, public and foundation worlds, attended.

title: MSI DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $105,000 for the and $988,000 for the yr and $615,000 loss for the qr and yr on disposal of discontinued operations...C-After $168,000 net fore currency translation loss

title: REAGAN'S SON MICHAEL RESIGNS SALES POSITION IN AVIATION CONCERN
description: President Reagan's son Michael, who caused a furor by using his father's name in letters seeking business for an airplane and missile parts manufacturer, resigned from the company today.

title: 2,000 EXPECTED AT FUNERAL FOR SLAIN GUARD AT PRISON
description: New York State's Commissioner of Correctional Services today ordered that the 23,000 inmates in 33 state prisons be locked in their cells all day tomorrow so that guards can attend the funeral in Dannemora of a slain corrections officer.

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Knicks Get Cavs' Smith
description: Randy Smith, whom the Cleveland Cavaliers tried to trade last season, became a Knick yesterday. In an apparent effort to patch up backcourt weaknesses that surfaced in their two-game playoff elimination by the Chicago Bulls, the Knicks obtained Smith in a trade for their first-round choice in the college basketball draft June 9.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr ago shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted for th purchase of 100,000 shrs in Jan 1980 and a subsequent 3-for-1 s split paid Mar 10, 1980

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. Deports 3 Cuban Refugees Who Came Through Costa Rica
description: The Federal Government has deported a family of three Cuban refugees who arrived illegally in this country from Costa Rica last February.

title: Dow and Saudi Basic In Chemical Venture
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that it had reached a final agreement with the Saudi Basic Industries Corporation, the Saudi Arabian state-owned petrochemical company, to form a joint venture to build a $1.5 billion petrochemical facility at the Jubail Industrial complex in the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Navarrete Takes Title
description: Rolando Navarrete of Honolulu scored a unanimous 12-round decision over Johnny Sato Tuesday night and became the North American Boxing Federation junior lightweight champion.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Two Choral Groups Offer Rossini 'Messe Solennelle'
description: Rossini gave the best commentary on his ''Petite Messe Solennelle,'' which was performed by the Metropolitan Singers and the Greek Choral Society, directed by Dino Anagnost in Avery Fisher Hall Sunday night. On the final manuscript page, Rossini wrote:

title: 8 DOCTORS AT SENATE HEARING CRITICIZE ANTI-ABORTION BILL
description: A group of prominent doctors and geneticists, opposing legislation that would make abortion illegal, today criticized attempts by Congress to define when human life begins.

title: Woman Dies in Army Training
description: A 23-year-old woman who had completed all but one week of Army basic training died after experiencing difficulty in breathing after a two-mile run at Fort Jackson this morning. Preliminary autopsy results indicated that Pvt. Pamelia F. Johnson of Hillsborough, N.C., died of arrhythmia, an irregularity of the heartbeat, according to a post spokesman. She had passed all medical requirements and had no previous record of medical complaints at the fort, the spokesman said.

title: NEW ZOO PUTS CHILDREN IN ANIMALS' PLACES
description: A spectacular new Children's Zoo, where children can burrow like prairie dogs in underground tunnels or perch like birds on platforms high in the trees, will open tomorrow at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Central Soya Ending Farm Supply Link
description: The Central Soya Company of Fort Wayne, Ind., said it would divest itself of its remaining 12 farm supply operations in Missouri, Indiana, Kentucky, Ohio, Alabama, Nebraska, Wisconsin and Tennessee.

title: Jersey Nuclear Plant Licensed
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has awarded a full-power operating license to a New Jersey nuclear plant operated by Public Service Electric and Gas Company, joint owner with the Philadelphia Electric Company.

title: Around the World; Police in South Korea Battle Students in 2d Day of Protest
description: The police battled hundreds of stone-throwing students for a second day today after an anti-Government demonstration marking the anniversary of South Korea's most violent uprising.

title: No Strings
description: Once upon a time the children of America, and some adults, gathered weekly around the television set to watch ''The Millionaire.'' The opening was always the same - a very rich man, as anonymous as the Angels' Charlie, would hand a henchman a check for $1 million and tell him to deliver it to Mr. and Mrs. XYZ.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL TO ASK FOR REPEAL OF 1978 SPECIAL PROSECUTORS' LAW
description: The Reagan Administration is expected to call tomorrow for repeal of those portions of a 1978 law that require the appointment of special prosecutors to investigate criminal allegations against high-ranking Federal officials in the executive branch.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in December

title: Business People; COMPATIBILITY STRESSED IN CABLE BID BY ROGERS
description: To hear Edward Rogers tell it, there couldn't be a more perfect fit. When the founder and owner of Rogers Telecommunication Ltd. eyes UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., a major United States cable television concern, he says he sees a management team and a cable network with the quality and compatibility to propel his Toronto-based concern right to the top of the quickly expanding cable business.

title: PAGE PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Western economies need a pause.'' - Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani. (D1:6.)

title: STREET AWAKENING FROM '67 DETROIT RIOT
description: Twelfth Street is going to get a supermarket at last, an event that ranks above even new housing on the agenda for progress in the life of this notorious thoroughfare.

title: SPENCER SENT TO A'S
description: Several hours after trading Jim Spencer and Tom Underwood to the Oakland A's for Dave Revering, a left-handed first baseman with a .282 career average, the Yankees completed a three-game sweep of the Kansas City Royals last night with a 5-4 11th-inning victory.

title: Swiss Watch Maker Gets Credit
description: Societe Suisse pour l'Industrie Horlogere, watch maker and marketer of Omega and Tissot brands, said today that Swiss banks had agreed to provide $150 million in credit, a move aimed at keeping Switzerland's secondlargest watch maker in business after heavy losses last year.

title: ARTS AGENCIES TOLD NEW CUTS LOOM
description: Officials of the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities have learned that the Office of Management and Budget may recommend to President Reagan cuts of roughly $32 million and $26 million, respectively, from their fiscal 1981 budgets, already approved by Congress. Pending a decision by the President based on its recommendations, the Office of Management and Budget has temporarily frozen appropriations for the third quarter of the fiscal year for the endowments.

title: Marine Midland Sets Restructuring
description: The Marine Midland Bank, the nation's 13th- largest bank, announced a major restructuring designed to facilitate atttainment of what it called ''its strategic objectives for accelerated profitable growth in the 1980's.''

title: Carey's Transit Panel Will Meet Tomorrow
description: Governor Carey today completed the naming of his transit advisory panel and said it would hold its first meeting on Friday in New York City.

title: City Police Data Show Major Crime Up 11.9%
description: The total number of reported major crimes in New York City during the first three months of this year showed an 11.9 percent increase over the same period in 1980, which was the worst year of crime in the city's history.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after $9,900 loss from settlement of a lawsuit

title: By Sports of The Times; A Champagne Toast to Vintage Hockey
description: CHAMPAGNE is always associated with the Stanley Cup, hockey's glamorous goblet. But when a team wins it, as the Islanders could do tonight at the Nassau Coliseum for the second consecutive year, the cup is usually filled with a relatively inexpensive brand. No sense spilling good stuff for the photographers.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including pretax deductions of $4,592,000 for the latest 6 mo and $749,000 for the previous 6 mos; yr ago qr and 6 mos net in include a gain on the sale of an interest in a company operatio to 40 cents a shr

title: XOIL ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
The Editorial Notebook; SOCIAL SECURITY'S WHITE LIES
description: ''Old people are being thrown to the sharks,'' asserted Jacob Ossofsky of the National Council on Aging. House Speaker Tip O'Neill called the effort ''despicable'' and ''a breach of faith,'' hoping that no Congressman would be ''stonehearted enough'' to vote for it. The object of their wrath is President Reagan's proposal to slash tens of billions from Social Security expenditures over the next few years.

title: CAYMAN ISLANDS REINSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Comparable figures are not available since the company just completed its first qr as a public company

title: Plucknett's Record No Path to Glory
description: Ben Plucknett is a big man in several ways. Start with his size - 6 feet 7 inches and 305 pounds. Add the athletic ability that enabled him to set a world record of 233 feet 7 inches in the discus throw last Saturday at Modesto, Calif.

title: Let's Pretend There's a Lebanon
description: Having painted themselves into a corner in Lebanon, Syria and Israel seem alternately appreciative and contemptuous of America's mediation. For a time, they appeared dangerously close to believing that the United States needed peace even more than they. That brought a useful warning that Washington feels no requirement to get paint on its shoes.

title: INSTEAD OF MISSILES
description: We are headed for serious trouble that we have had before: in our dealings with our European friends on the size and shape of NATO's nuclear umbrella. The difficulties recently were papered over once again in a North Atlantic Treaty Organization statement, but beneath the paper they are steadily growing. Meanwhile, the evolution of our own strategic nuclear procurement is about to offer a solution vastly better than the one the allied negotiators have been discussing. Will the Administration seize its chance?

title: COMPLEX PLANNED ATOP PATERSON'S GARRET MOUNTAIN
description: Plans for a $110 million luxury apartment and office complex atop Garret Mountain in this Passaic County city were announced today by Mayor Lawrence F. Kramer and Garret Heights Associates, the developer.

title: Around the World; 150 Peasants in Honduras Said to Seize Agrarian Office
description: Residents of Comayagua, 62 miles north of this capital city, said today that more than 150 dissident peasants armed with machetes had seized the local National Agrarian Institute and were holding its employees hostage inside the building.

title: Lawyer Sentenced for Theft
description: A 61-year-old Syosset lawyer who admitted stealing $42,500 in funds entrusted to him by clients was sentenced today to one to three years in prison. The sentence was imposed by Judge Alfred Samenga of Nassau County Court on the lawyer, Robert Connolly, who specialized in laws governing liquor licenses. Mr. Connolly was disbarred when he pleaded guilty March 23.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Express Co. announced a joint venture with Banco Bamerindus and Banco Economico, both of Brazil, to establish a new company to market an American Express Cruzeiro Card throughout Brazil. * A-T-O Inc. changed its name to Figgie International Inc.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Chicago Rail Service
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad Company said yesterday that it will seek approval on June 1 to suspend all commuter operations in the Chicago area a week later.

title: SYRACUSE POLICE TRIAL HAS BITTER FINISH
description: For eight months, this community of 170,000 residents has been preoccupied with the death of 49-year-old Raul Mora, who collapsed during a struggle with four police officers.

title: Advertising; Chipwich Destined for Grocers
description: A QUALITY confection product sold by attractive and uniformed vendors from clean, well-tended carts? Why that sounds like the Good Humor of yesteryear. It also sounds like the new Chipwich Inc.

title: Bridge: An Expert Missed the Boat In a Recent Cavendish Deal
description: One of the experts in the Cavendish Club's recent invitational pair championship missed the right line of play on the diagramed deal. Readers who wish to test themselves should cover the East-West hands and make a plan. The contract is six spades and the lead is a trump.

title: DATA CARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
Interim Successor Chosen At McCann-Erickson
description: After James K. Agnew, president of the domestic operation of McCann-Erickson, leaves the company this summer Willard C. Mackey Jr., worldwide president and chief executive, will not only temporarily assume that job, but also Mr. Agnew's newer additional post of chairman of the executive committee worldwide, Mr. Mackey said, when asked, yesterday.

title: Harvester Reports $79.2 Million Loss
description: The International Harvester Company, one of the nation's leading producers of farm equipment and trucks, announced yesterday that its loss for the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, narrowed to $79.2 million, from $257.2 million in the similar quarter a year ago.

title: EXTENSION AT BUS TERMINAL CELEBRATED
description: The people who are rebuilding and expanding the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue took time off from their labors yesterday morning to celebrate the completion of a major extension of the terminal from 41st to 42d Street.

title: EAST GERMANS MAKE SEVERE ATTACK ON POLISH PARTY
description: Two months before Polish Communists are to gather at a party congress to discuss the difficult issues that divide their country, the East German Communists are bluntly warning them that confidence is running out in the Poles' ability to find a political solution to their problems.

title: News Analysis
description: The Government of Japan has recently run into a series of mishaps, disputes and embarrassing disclosures - all unrelated but forming a pattern of difficulty for Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki - and the question is how seriously these affect the relationship with the United States.

title: ADMINISTRATION STUDYING NEW PLAN ON BOLSTERING INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES
description: The Reagan Administration has redrafted its proposal to expand the authority of intelligence agencies in a manner that retains some of the safeguards for civil liberties that would have been eliminated in a previous draft.

title: TV: ANOTHER AGATHA CHRISTIE MYSTERY
description: THE Mobil Showcase Network is taking another fling, tonight at 8 on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, at an Agatha Christie mystery. Produced for London Weekend Television, ''Why Didn't They Ask Evans?'' is far too long, coming in at three hours, but it is considerably more successful than last month's ''The Seven Dials Mystery,'' which finally expired beneath a mound of Miss Christie's notorious red herrings.

title: COSMOS LOSE, 2-1, TO BELGIANS
description: Anderlecht of Belgium, one of Europe's best soccer teams in recent years, defeated the Cosmos, 2-1, at Giants Stadium tonight before a crowd of 30,512.

title: Gretzky Seeks New Pact As Best Paid in League
description: Wayne Gretzky says he wants to be the best-paid player in the National Hockey League, but the Edmonton Oilers' owner, Peter Pocklington, will not say if he is willing to oblige his 20-year-old star.

title: HANDCRAFTED WOOD FURNITURE ON L.I.Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors.
description: HANDMADE furniture, both traditional and sculptural styles, will be offered by a new gallery in East Hampton, L.I. The Pritam & Eames Gallery will open next Monday, showing pieces from 30 craftsmen in woodworking.

title: FOREST CHIEF GAINS SENATE'S APPROVAL
description: John B. Crowell Jr., former general counsel of the Lousiana-Pacific Corporation, one of the largest users of timber from national forests, was easily confirmed as an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture today after Senate Democrats failed to return his nomination to committee for further hearings.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Apogee Enterprises is offering 400,000 common shares at $15.50 a share through a Dean Witter Reynolds underwriting group.

title: SLOW START FOR A NEW EXCHANGE
description: The exterior of the building is painted a mellow yellow, except for the Corinthian columns and the arched lintels, which are trimmed in white. Under a dome with murals depicting the economic life of the city sits an ornate room where the pace of actvity is as slow as a local drawl.

title: Litco Signs Pact For Its Takeover
description: Litco Bankcorporation of New York Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement under which a subsidiary of Banca Commerciale Italiana of Milan, Italy, as previously announced, will acquire all of Litco's outstanding common stock.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Bronx Ensemble Plays Music of Bronx Composers
description: In honor of Bronx Week, the Bronx Arts Ensemble brought its native music to the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night. Bronx Borough President Stanley Simon was honored with a plaque.

title: The City
description: A fire on the top floor of Public School 98, at 512 West 212th Street, forced the removal of 1,200 youngsters from the five-story building.

title: TRANSTECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
VETO BY DELBELLO SEEN
description: Westchester County's Republican-controlled Board of Legislators approved a reapportionment plan redrawing the board's district lines. The measure faces an almost certain veto by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, a Democrat.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: Traded Jim Spencer, first baseman, and Tom Under- wood, pitcher, to Oakland A's for Dave Revering, first baseman; Mike Patterson, outfielder, and Chuck Dougherty, pitcher. Assigned Pat- terson to Columbus of Interna- tional League and Dougherty to Fort Lauderdale of Florida State League.

title: Military Analysis
description: The North Atlantic alliance, despite reassuring words from its foreign and defense ministers, is in a seriously deteriorating military situation.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 11
Writing Reportedly Authenticated In Mormon Blessing Document
description: A document in which Joseph Smith Jr., the founder of the Mormon Church, designated his son as his successor as church leader has been authenticated by handwriting experts, according to officials of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: ADVANCED COMPUTER TECHNIQUES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
ELIZABETH K. TAYLOR
description: Elizabeth K. Taylor, retired director of the Riverside School in Manhattan, died Tuesday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. Mrs. Taylor, who lived in Old Saybrook, Conn., was 73 years old.

title: Music Noted in Brief; M.I.T. Studio Presents Computer-Music Program
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology might seem an ideal place for science and composition to meet. And indeed the institute's Experimental Music Studio under Barry Vercoe's direction has seemingly contributed considerably to the technology and the critical literature of computer music.

title: Vice Adm. Joseph J. McClelland; Headed Coast Guard Pacific Area
description: Vice Adm. Joseph J. McClelland, who retired in 1976 as commander of the United States Coast Guard's Pacific Area, died Sunday at 64 years old.

title: Concert to Benefit WNYC-FM
description: A benefit concert for radio station WNYC-FM will be held in Carnegie Hall next Wednesday.

description: B-Including $648,000 tax credit and $1,210,000 extraordinary gain from the settlement of debt...C-Including $240,000 tax cre

description: Net earnings for both periods include gains realized from the sale of real estate not used in operations equivalent to 3 cent a shr in 1981 and 8 cents a shr in 1980

title: PROGRESSIVE INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $120,000 extraordinary gain

title: IN EL SALVADOR, NO ESCAPE FROM THE HORRORS OF WAR
description: A resident was talking about what it's like to live in El Salvador these days. ''A secretary who works here was with her mother when a truck backfired,'' he said. ''She instantly pushed her to the ground and threw herself on top of her. They were in Detroit.''

title: Market Place; New Wrinkle At Option Fund
description: IN the past, mutual funds investing in stock options had limited appeal. They provided relatively good income, but money market funds often did better, and the option funds' capital gains potential was limited.

title: G.&W. Buys Stock
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 846,800 shares, or 5.9 percent, of the stock of J.P. Stevens and Company Inc. G.& W. said it had paid about $13.6 million for the stock. The shares were purchased between March 24 and May 15 on the New York Stock Exchange for investment purposes, it said.

title: E.E.C. Duties On U.S. Goods
description: The European Common Market, acting in advance of trade talks with the United States this week, announced two new measures today to counter alleged American dumping.

title: THIRD I.R.A. HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN PRISON NEAR BELFAST
description: Raymond McCreesh, one of the Irish Republican Army hunger strikers in the Maze Prison near Belfast, died this morning at the beginning of his 61st day without food.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Pandit Pran Nath Sings Two Morning Ragas
description: Listening to Pandit Pran Nath sing two morning Ragas on Sunday morning at the Dia Art Foundation was a remarkable experience. The Indian religious and musical works, combining improvisation with ancient traditional forms, created subtly shaped worlds, enclosing the listener.

title: TRUST ACT GIVES IT REASONABLE CONCESSIONS, N.F.L. ARGUES IN SUIT
description: The National Football League opened its defense of a Federal antitrust suit today by asserting that professional football was entitled to reasonable concessions under the Sherman Antitrust Act, which forbids agreements between business enterprises that restrain competition.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes gains from sale of real estate and discontinued oper Operating results include those of Ayr-Way Stores acquired late

title: 30,000 Mourners in Jamaica View Body of Marley in National Arena
description: More than 30,000 people today viewed the body of the 38-year-old reggae star Bob Marley - a guitar by his side and a Bible in his hand - and the police had to fire tear gas to prevent fans from disrupting long lines of mourners.

title: PRICING COMPROMISE BETWEEN CONSUMER GROUPS AND SUPERMARKETS REACHED IN ALBANY
description: New York's consumers will still find price stickers, in addition to computer hash marks, on the goods they buy in stores under an agreement announced by legislative leaders today.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. IS A DISSENTER AS U.N. AGENCY VOTES BABY-FORMULA CODE
description: The United States voted in the World Health Organization today against the adoption of a voluntary code that would ban promotion of infant formulas that could discourage breast feeding.

title: MAY, ALLIED, DAYTON ALSO GAIN
description: Federated Department Stores, the nationwide chain that is the parent of Abraham & Straus and Bloomingdale's, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter of 1981 surged 53.6 percent as sales increased 14.4 percent.

title: GISCARD GETS EMOTIONAL FAREWELL ON LAST DAY AS FRENCH PRESIDENT
description: Hundreds of youths chanting ''Come back soon!'' bade an emotional farewell today to the outgoing President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, and thousands of Parisians flocked to see his last official act.

title: Philbro-Cocoa Link
description: Phibro Corporation officials said the company was close to acquiring the Cocoa Merchants Group Ltd., a major London-based cocoa trading concern. The officials declined to specify the purchase price beyond saying it would be substantially more than $10 million. Phibro formerly was the Philipp Brothers unit of the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation.

title: CRIB-INJURED CHILD GETS MULTIMILLION SETTLEMENT
description: The manufacturers of a child's sailor suit and crib have agreed to pay up to $10 million to settle a suit filed by the parents of a now brain-damaged baby who choked on a clothing cord tangled on his crib.

title: ULSTER'S FEARFUL PROTESTANT MAJORITY AND WHY THE ARMY STAYS THERE
description: To the Editor:

title: BERVEN CARPETS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
RED SOX TRIUMPH BY 5-3, SENDING A'S TO THEIR 7TH STRAIGHT DEFEAT
description: Rick Miller of Boston broke a tie with a tworun, two-out single in the seventh inning tonight as the Red Sox extended the Oakland A's losing streak to seven straight games with a 5-3 victory.

title: Missiles on Barges
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 21, 1981
description: International The United States voted against the adoption of a code by the World Health Organization that would ban all promotion of infant formulas that could discourage mothers from breast-feeding. The measure was adopted in a committee of the whole by 93 votes to 3 with 9 abstentions. The measure was strongly opposed by the baby food industry, but activists charged that the code is needed to protect infants in third world countries from the dangers of bottle-feeding.(Page A1,Column 3.) The leaders of Israel and Syria exchanged sharp public criticism of each other's policies, but both said Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, should continue his efforts to ease the tension between them. The Israeli Cabinet decided to continue diplomatic efforts toward a peaceful solution of the missile crisis in Lebanon. President Hafez al-Assad of Syria accused Israel of making demands that are ''outside any logic.'' Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel called the Syrian President's remarks ''extremist,'' but said his country would not attack Syrian forces unless provoked. (A1:4-5.)

title: Notes on People; Editorial Cartoonists' Group Cites 2 From Abroad
description: A young Uruguayan who is in prison and a Polish survivor of Auschwitz are the recipients of the Association of American Editorial Cartoonists' first annual Distinguished Foreign Cartoonist Awards.

title: Buyers See Economic Rise
description: Although expecting little improvement this month, the nation's purchasing managers believe the economy will get better through the rest of the year, a new survey indicated yesterday.

title: Fund Liquidity Worries I.M.F.
description: The liquidity of the International Monetary Fund will come under increasing strain from about mid-1982, according to I.M.F. staff estimates made public today.

title: THURSDAY, MAY 21, 1981; The Economy
description: The Administration proposed easing the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which was intended to prevent American companies from bribing foreign officials. Trade Representative Bill Brock argued that it was making it difficult for United States companies to compete abroad. The Administration would end the S.E.C.'s enforcement power and certain accounting requirements. (Page A1.)

title: The Region; False Alarm Routs 50 at Stouffer's Inn
description: More than 50 guests were routed from their beds early yesterday by a malfunctioning fire alarm at Stouffer's Inn, where a flash fire last December killed 26 persons.

title: Around the Nation; Wildcat Strike Halts Puget Sound Ferry Fleet
description: A wildcat walkout shut down the nation's largest ferry fleet and forced about 45,000 commuters to catch ''mosquito fleet'' charter boats or drive some 75 miles around Puget Sound to get to work today.

title: SEATRAIN LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $10.9 million for the qr and $171,570,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $3,543, income from discontinued operations and $700,000 charge from th reversal of a tax credit...D-Net income including $12,177,000 i from discontinued operations and $400,000 tax credit; yr ago re have been restated for capitalizaton of leases under F.A.S.B. title: ARMS SCANDAL IS CHARGED IN COSTA RICA
description: A congressional committee here has charged that some of the weapons that entered this country from Cuba in 1979 to help overthrow the Somoza regime in Nicaragua were subsequently sold illegally by Costa Rican officials for smuggling to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: ROCK: RUSH, CANADA POWER TRIO
description: IN its seven-year recording career, the Canadian power trio Rush has grown in popularity to the point that today it ranks as one of the 10 best-selling North-American rock groups. But judging from its sold-out Madison Square Garden concert on Monday, Rush's success has less to do with music than with teen-age ritual.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Van Cliburn Inter- national Competition in some editions yesterday incorrectly named the pian- ist who withdrew because of tendinitis. It was Chan Hee Kim.

title: HAIG CANCELS PLAN TO VISIT TOKYO ON HIS TRIP TO ASIA NEXT MONTH
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has canceled plans to visit Japan on a trip to Asia next month. Mr. Haig's first stop was to have been Tokyo about June 12, but he will now visit only Peking, Manila and New Zealand.

title: 12 Western States Seek Control Of 554 Million Acres of U.S. Land
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Representative James D. Santini, Democrat of Nevada, introduced legislation in Congress today that would give 12 Western states some 554 million acres of Federal lands.

title: THEATER: CRAIG LUCAS'S 'MISSING PERSONS'
description: ''MISSING PERSONS,'' at the Production Company, is of interest for two reasons. Its star is that excellent actor Richard Backus, and its author is Craig Lucas, the co-star and co-creator of the current Stephen Sondheim show, ''Marry Me a Little.'' As it happens, these points of interest quickly prove to be academic. ''Missing Persons'' is thin stuff and a poor showcase for Mr. Backus's talents.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard SOLVENCY. The Price of Survival. An Essay on American Foreign Policy. By James Chace. 115 pages. Random House. $9.95. REAL SECURITY. Restoring American Power in a Dangerous Decade. By Rich- ard J. Barnet. 127 pages. Simon and Schuster. $10.95.

title: REAGAN SEEKS ALLIES TO AVERT ALTERATION OF ECONOMIC PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration has promised to mute its criticism of the Federal Reserve System's monetary policies and has stepped up its pressure on Democrats for a compromise tax program as part of a broad effort to win final approval of President Reagan's economic recovery program before it runs out of political momentum.

title: ELIZABETH R. OTIS
description: Elizabeth R. Otis, a co-founder in 1928 of McIntosh and Otis, the literary agency, died yesterday at her home in New York. She was 80 years old.

title: METS BEAT GIANTS, END SLIDE AT NINE
description: They had to go 10 innings to do it, but the New York Mets finally ended their nine-game losing streak today when they defeated the San Francisco Giants, 4-3.

title: Mother's Day Message
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Mary Kay Blakely's Mother's Day column on violent games of manhood (''Hers,'' May 7) moved me more than any treatise on Mother's Day I have ever read.

title: FOR SUMMER, FURNISHINGS TO GO, AND SOME NEW TWISTS
description: YOU'VE been waiting months for this moment: The sun is shining, the temperature is rising and, if you are like many city dwellers, summer has just caught you by surprise again.

title: MILITANT VIEWS AMONG TURKS TROUBLE BONN
description: Unconfirmed reports that Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk seized in the shooting of Pope John Paul II, lived among Turkish workers in West Germany after his escape from prison have focused attention on a spread of militancy among the Turks in West Germany. In public, Bonn officials have affirmed that no evidence has appeared to indicate that Mr. Agca was ever in West Germany.

description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: WOODWORKING TIPS
description: ''Woodworking Without Electricity,'' Craft Students League, 610 Lexington Avenue, near 53d Street.

Amherst Coal Takeover Near
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, a major chemicals, oil, gas and coal producer of Dallas, said it had definitively agreed to acquire all outstanding shares of the Amherst Coal Company of Charleston, W.Va., in exchange for some 6.2 million shares of Diamond Shamrock common stock valued at about $204 million.

title: MARYLAND VOTE CALLED RESPONSE TO THREAT OF SOCIAL SECURITY CUTS
description: Leaders in both political parties read national significance, especially unhappiness over proposed Social Security cuts, into yesterday's victory by Steny H. Hoyer, a Maryland Democrat, in a special election to the House.

title: No Headline
description: The obituary of the reggae singer Bob Marley on May 12 incorrectly described the origin of the Rastafarian religious movement. It is not ascribed to any one person and is generally considered to have evolved in Jamaica in the early 1930's.

title: DISCORD AMONG ARGENTINE JEWS OVER REGIME FLARES ANEW IN U.S.
description: Long-standing differences among Argentine Jews about the nature of anti-Semitic violence in their country and how to respond to it emerged again yesterday at a meeting in Manhattan.

title: STRIKE AT BRITISH FORD IS SYMPTOMATIC
description: Even the participants might not have recognized it as such, but a classic example of one key aspect of the controversial economic policies known as Thatcherization was on display this week at the strike-bound Ford Motor Company plant on the outskirts of this worn industrial city.

title: ...BUT ROAD REPAIRS MAY SLOW RUSH TO BEACHES OR BOSKY DELLS
description: Forget June 21. No matter what the calendar says about its being the first day of summer, the season in the New York City area really begins this afternoon as millions leave for their first trips to beaches and country lanes.

title: M-G-M to Buy United Artists
description: Transamerica Corporation's board approved the sale the company's United Artists subsidiary to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. for $380 million, the companies announced today.

title: Brezhnev Arrives in Caucasus
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, arrived today in Tbilisi, capital of the Caucasian Republic of Georgia, to a welcome of brass bands and roses for the 60th anniversary of Georgia's incorporation into the Soviet state.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices On Office Systems
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which until three years ago seldom cut prices, said that its general systems division, based in Atlanta, was offering volume-purchase discounts of 6 to 15 percent on major components of its 5520 distributed data system and its 5280 administrative system. The two systems are widely used in offices.

title: Yankee Justice
description: A rhubarb involving New York Yankees, Kansas City Royals and umpires the other night had everyone in sharp disagreement over the justice of baseball. Some were even moved to philosophize about a sport that's sterner than life. Even in the cold real world, a judge will often forgive a citizen who has innocently relied on a Government ruling later found mistaken. But for a while at Yankee Stadium, it seemed that rough justice, not equity, might rule.

title: Two in Lottery Scheme Dismissed on Conviction
description: A state lottery official and a television host were discharged from their jobs today after they were convicted last night of rigging the Pennsylvania Daily Number drawing on April 24, 1980.

title: HISPANIC VOTE GAINS AS DEBATE ON RIGHTS ACT SWIRLS
description: McALLEN, Tex. - Dominga Sausedo was nervous as she walked from her cramped house to the neighborhood school a few blocks away. For the first time in the 48 years since she was born here in Texas, Mrs. Sausedo was on her way to vote.

title: McNeil Unlikely To Go to Canada
description: The Winnipeg Blue Bombers of the Canadian League are unlikely to make an offer to lure Freeman McNeil, the Jets' top draft choice, the Blue Bombers' general manager said yesterday.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1981
description: International A withdrawal of the nomination of Ernest W. Lefever as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs has been requested by Senator Charles H. Percy, the Chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, according to Administration and Congressional officials. Aides to the Senator reported that Mr. Percy told White House officials that Mr. Lefever might ''hurt the foreign policy goals'' of the Administration. (Page A1,Column 1.) Syrian missiles must be removed not only from Lebanon but also from Syrian territory near the Lebanese border, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said in a television interview. The broadening of demands by the Israeli leader, which included the demand that Syria not fire antiaircraft missles from its own territory at Israeli planes over Lebanon, was expected to complicate efforts to resolve the conflict. (A1:4.)

title: ART: CHANCE TO COMPARE DEMUTH AND GUGLIELMI
description: THAT shows by Charles Demuth (1885-1935) and O. Louis Guglielmi (1906-1956) should be running concurrently is a happy, if not amazing coincidence. Both are small but bright stars in a firmament that is now undergoing re-examination and, though the two artists were poles apart temperamentally, Demuth did exert some influence on Guglielmi. The Demuth exhibition, on view through May 30 at the Salander O'Reilly Galleries (20 East 80th Street) consists of 68 watercolors and drawings dating from 1907 to 1934. Most come from the artist's estate, as it was bequeathed to his companion and friend, Robert Locher.

title: HIGHER TAXES TO FINANCE M.T.A. SUGGESTED BY SENATOR IN ALBANY ,
description: The chairman of the Transportation Committee of the Republican-controlled State Senate recommended today that, to finance public transportation, the state increase the sales tax in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority region by 1 cent and place a surcharge on New York City's real-property tax on commercial buildings.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Chinese Leader to Visit Nepal
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China will visit Nepal for three days beginning June 4, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Around the Nation; 8 Held for Conspiracy To Bomb N.A.A.C.P. Center
description: Eight people from three states were arrested today in an alleged conspiracy by Ku Klux Klan members to bomb the Maryland headquarters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Federal agents said.

title: MACY NET CLIMBED 89% IN 3D QUARTER
description: R.H. Macy & Company, one of the nation's leading department store chains, reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 soared 89 percent as sales climbed 17.3 percent.

title: WAS RIMSKY A SALIERI TO MUSSORGSKY?
description: New York's current fascination with Antonio Salieri and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart takes a new turn this weekend and next when the Theater Opera Music Institute presents eight performances of Rimsky-Korsakov's one-act opera, ''Mozart and Salieri.'' The strange confluence of Salieri, the successful mediocrity, and Mozart, the struggling god-child, is now a familiar one - how Salieri, through jealousy, poisons Mozart, if not in fact, at least indirectly through intrigue and manipulation.

title: Gerulaitis Upset by Pecci In Italian Open, 6-2, 6-4
description: In today's major upset, Victor Pecci of Paraguay eliminated fourth-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-2, 6-4, to move into the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Italian open.

title: Bridge: Eastern Regional Title Play Will Get Under Way Today
description: One of the oldest and most prestigious tournaments in the game is the Eastern Regional Championships, which begin at the New York Hilton Hotel today. The schedule is: Today - Men's and women's pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; speedball Swiss teams, midnight. Tomorrow - Goldman open pairs (two flights), 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; newcomers lecture by Edgar Kaplan, 6:15 P.M.; expert post-mortem show, 11 P.M. Sunday - Flight B Swiss teams and Goldman open pairs Flight A final, 1 P.M. and 7 P.M.; Swiss teams, 11:30 P.M.

title: ROYAL DUTCH SHELL POSTS A 53.7% DROP IN EARNINGS
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that high crude oil costs, coupled with slumping prices for refined products, helped drive down net income 53.7 percent for the first quarter of 1981.

title: SMOKING WARNINGS CALLED INEFFECTIVE
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission, after five years of study, has determined that the current warnings against smoking that appear on cigarette packages and in advertisements are not effective and that a new warning system may be necessary.

title: BEGIN WIDENS TERMS FOR SYRIAN PULLOUT OF BORDER MISSILES
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today broadened his public demands on Syria, declaring that its recently deployed antiaircraft missiles must be removed not only from Lebanon but also from Syrian territory adjacent to the Lebanese border.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Apr 30
CABLE TV PAYS ITS WAY, PANEL IS TOLD
description: Thomas Wheeler, president of the National Cable Television Association, defended his industry's growth under the copyright laws. Testifying before a House panel today, he said no changes in the laws were required.

title: BIPARTISAN MOVE TO LOWER TAXES SAID TO ADVANCE
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and the Democratic majority leader in the House of Representatives, Jim Wright, held out the possibility today of making compromises that might permit agreement on a bipartisan tax bill.

title: THE PITCHING PRIME OF BERT BLYLEVEN OF INDIANS
description: At one point last season, Bert Blyleven, aged 29 and earning a half-million dollars a year throwing baseballs for the Pittsburgh Pirates, quit, and went home to Villa Park, Calif., where for 10 days, by his own account, he painted his daughter's playhouse, pulled weeds in his back yard and read the want ads.

title: 2 Publishers Firm On Cablevision Bid
description: Dow Jones & Company and Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said that they did not plan to change their $80-a-share bid for UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. despite the new $90-a-share proposal put forth by Rogers Telecommunications Ltd. and United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc.

title: TV Weekend; FURTHER 'SCRUPLES,' ART AND 'A BET ON HUMANITY'
description: THIS weekend's most delectable trash treat has to be ''Scruples,'' the made-for-television movie on ABC tonight at 9. It is a continuation of the story that made a lot of dollars for Judith Krantz in the form of a best-selling novel and a television miniseries. The credits note that the new venture is ''based upon characters from the book by Judith Krantz.'' Someone, somewhere, is obviously hoping for a regular weekly series in the soap-opera manner of ''Dallas'' or ''Dynasty.''
