title: WINNER OF THE WOODY-ALLEN-KINDRED-SOUL CONTEST
description: ''I WAS the smallest kid in the fourth grade, and my teacher cast me as the Giant in 'Jack and the Beanstalk.' I got out on stage and got my first laugh and that was it.'' Brian Backer grinned, remembering the beginnings of an acting career that is still budding.

title: WELFARE RECIPIENTS FIND THAT PATH TO HELP OFTEN BEGINS AT END OF LONG LINE
description: Leaning against a grimy wall in the reception area of the Melrose Income Maintenance Center, Andrea Thomas gazed out at some of the 1,800 clients who come to the center each week for help in dealing with poverty.

title: Pop Jazz; JOHNNIE RAY IS BACK AT EAST SIDE CLUB
description: ''I'M not really a singer,'' Johnnie Ray was saying. ''What I'm about is communication. I leave singing to the Tony Bennetts. I'm an actor set to music and lyrics. Acting is what I started out to do. Then I made records, none of which I can stand.''

title: A BIT OF BALI IS IN TOWN TO DANCE
description: This weekend, the Asia Society's new headquarters at 725 Park Avenue will become a little bit of Bali transplanted in the New World.

title: Notes on People; McCracken Rejects Operatic Storm Drenched in Realism
description: James McCracken, the opera tenor, has gone to great lengths for his art. But, he said Wednesday, at this point in his life he draws the line, notably when called on to risk his health.

title: PUBLISHING: ALEX HALEY REPAYS AN OLD FRIEND
description: IN a couple of months, Alex Haley expects to present Doubleday with the manuscript of his new book, ''Search,'' the account of how he came to write the phenomenonally successful ''Roots.'' Yet he recently devoted two days to a succession of television and radio interviews, not to plug his own books but to publicize ''The Playboy Interview'' (Playboy Press), edited by G. Barry Golson.

title: AT THE DALTON SCHOOL, MYSTERY OF A BURIED TREASURE
description: ''One night I went to sleep,'' whispered Kit Williams, sitting crosslegged on top of a table, hunched over and peering down from under his brows at the band of open-mouthed sixth-graders beneath him, ''and when I woke up I was not sure whether I was a man who went to sleep and awoke a leprechaun or a leprechaun who went to sleep and awoke a man, but all I know is my shoes keep getting greener and greener.''

title: 3,000 LEAVE PRISONS FOR GUARD'S RITES
description: Three thousand guards and other New York State prison personnel took time off to attend a funeral in upstate Dannemora yesterday for a slain guard, but the prisons, operating with reduced staffs and curtailed activities, were reported peaceful.

title: Around The Nation; McDonnell Douglas Wary Of 3-Member Cockpit Crew
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation told a Presidential panel today that putting an ''unnecessary'' third crew member in the cockpit of its new DC-9 Super 80 airliner could decrease the safety of the plane's operation.

title: Newspaper Seeks a Wage Freeze
description: Joseph Pulitzer Jr., editor and publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, has asked the newspaper's 11 unions, whose contracts will expire on Aug. 30, for a two-year freeze on wage increases. The newspaper reported today that Mr. Pulitzer cited ''severe financial strain over the past 40 months.'' Union representatives said the paper's financial status must be verified by an auditing concern experienced in newspaper operations.

title: HARRY H. VAUGHAN, MAJOR GENERAL WHO WAS AN AIDE TO TRUMAN,DIES
description: Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, whose actions as confidant and aide-de-camp to President Truman a generation ago led to a series of national uproars, died here yesterday at DeWitt Army Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: Restaurants; Endless variety from land of the Hakka.
description: ALTHOUGH we paid six visits to the Home Village Restaurant on Mott Street in Chinatown and tried some 40 dishes, including several that were not on the menu, this review probably should be marked ''To be continued.'' That's because the 40 dishes represent only 20 percent of a menu listing 185 dishes as well as 15 or more available for special house dinners.

title: Nu-West Acquires Cities Service Stake
description: Nu-West Group Ltd., a diversified Canadian real estate development concern, said today that it had purchased a 6.3 percent stake in the Cities Service Company, the integrated oil and copper-mining company, for $249.5 million.

title: AMDAHL IS STILL GUESSING RIGHT
description: For the second time in its meteoric 10-year history, the Amdahl Corporation, a small manufacturer of large-scale computers, is profiting from its ability to second-guess the huge International Business Machines Corporation.

title: ISLANDERS CAPTURE THEIR 2D STRAIGHT STANLEY CUP
description: With Butch Goring leading the way, the Islanders captured their second successive Stanley Cup by defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 5-1, at Nassau Coliseum tonight. Goring scored two goals and was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player in the playoffs.

title: Errichetti Indicted In 2d Bribery Case
description: Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti of Camden, N.J., who was convicted of bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam inquiry into political corruption, was indicted on allegations stemming from an inquiry into bribes on federally subsidized sewer projects.

title: RISING INTEREST RATES SEND STOCKS LOWER
description: The stock market, continuing to react to rising interest rates, edged down yesterday in more active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout most of the session, closed down 0.27 point, to 976.59. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outscored advances by 816 to 705.

description: The companies project an aura of innocence because they make food for babies. But for years, consumer groups have hounded them, calling them baby killers and mounting boycotts of Nestle, the leader in the sector.

THE EARLY FRIDAY GETAWAYS DAWN WITH BIG HOLIDAY...
description: Drawn to nature, thousands of New Yorkers are about to renew the summer custom of leaving work early on Friday afternoons. Gripped by lethargy, normally productive members of the labor force will find themselves not at their work stations, but behind the wheels of automobiles heading for retreats. Thousands more will say they are going to lunch and simply disappear. Many will be found swimming off Long Island or New Jersey or on the beaches.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; THE BRONX FOR YOUNG NATURALISTS
description: Young visitors to the Bronx Zoo this weekend can do more than stand back and watch the animals. They can venture into a burrow to see how prairie dogs live, or crawl inside a big snail shell to find out how snails get around. There is even the nest of a black-crowned night heron to climb into. The exhibitions are part of the new Children's Zoo, a three-acre tract of marsh and woodland where some 110 animals live in settings close to their natural habitats. Raccoons make their home along the bank of a stream, with their natural neighbors the black-crowned heron living close by. The zoo also contains an area for visitors to pet and feed goats, rabbits, pigs, chicks, lambs, geese and snakes to their heart's content. The Children's Zoo is open daily 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and costs 80 cents for children, 70 cents for adults. But be warned; adults must be accompanied by a child. Information: 933-1759.

title: Bristol-Myers Gains Interferon Licenses
description: Interferon Sciences of New Brunswick, N.J., said that it had signed a research, licensing and supply agreement with the Bristol-Myers Company and had granted it an option for other unspecified interferon technologies.

title: INFANT-FORMULA CODE IS FORMALLY APPROVED
description: The World Health Organization formally approved a code today that calls for a ban on the advertising and promotion of baby formulas as substitutes for breast-feeding.

title: SECOND TIME IS SWEETER FOR MANY ISLANDER FANS
description: What happened tonight had happened once before, but that only made Long Islanders more jubilant as they celebrated the 5-1 victory that renewed the New York Islanders' lease on the Stanley Cup for a second straight year.

title: BEYOND 96-0
description: How did it come to pass that a Republican Administration that came to office in January promising at most some modest cuts and efficiencies in Government spending ended up in May proposing such devastating cuts in the Social Security system that a Republican-dominated Senate voted 96-0 to reject the entire proposal?

title: 4 KILLED IN EAST HARLEM AS CAR HITS A STORE
description: Three men and a teen-age girl were crushed to death late yesterday afternoon by a speeding car that careered out of control onto the sidewalk along Second Avenue near 103d Street in East Harlem and smashed into a neighborhood delicatessen, the police said.

title: YIELDS UP IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Perturbed by signs that the Federal Reserve is determined to keep a tight rein on bank reserves and the nation's money supply, the credit markets retreated yesterday, and yields rose for both shortand long-term securities.

title: SENATE PASSES NEW ABORTION AID CURB
description: In the midst of granting approval to a $695.5 billion budget plan sought for the fiscal year 1982 by President Reagan, the Senate today changed its focus to abortions and voted more stringent restrictions on Federal payments for abortions for the indigent.

title: WASHINGTON ; The Evening Hours; ARCHITECTS IN CAPITAL
description: W HAT do architects talk about at candlelit tables gleaming with crystal as white-gloved waiters serve up fingerbowls and champagne? Buildings.

title: AUCTIONED FOR $5.3 MILLION
description: A Pablo Picasso ''Self Portrait: Yo'' sold last night for $5.3 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a Picasso and a 20th-century artist, making it the fourth most expensive picture ever sold at public sale. The bidding was spirited and swift between the buyer, Wendell Cherry, president of a hospital chain based in Louisville, Ky., and others who were bidding over the telephone to agents of the house in the room at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at East 76th Street.

title: Times Declares Dividend
description: The New York Times Company declared its regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share yesterday on its class A and class B common shares, payable June 26 to holders of record June 5. The company also declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.375 a share on its 5 1/2 percent cumulative prior preference stock, payable July 1 to holders of record June 5. The dividends were unchanged from the previous quarter.

title: WARDS ISLAND IS THE WRONG HAVEN FOR HOMELESS WARDS OF NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson Cruises Resume
description: The passenger ship Dayliner begins the Hudson River Day Line's 118th season of cruises up the river tomorrow at 10 A.M. at Pier 81, at the foot of West 41st Street.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD DOWN 1.8 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 1.8 million shares in the month ended May 15, to 73.1 million. The short interest for last year totaled 47 million shares.

title: 'FOUR SEASONS,' A HYMN TO ORDINARINESS
description: ''THE FOUR SEASONS'' is a fond, generous movie about characters who might have easily lent themselves to satire. Alan Alda, who wrote and directed the film and fits comfortably into its balanced cast, shapes the material almost as if he were offering a toast. A group of middle-aged, middle-class principals vacation together on the four occasions to which the title refers. They cook and trade quips and have heart-to-heart talks by the dozen. They use these holidays for celebrating the status quo, and for applauding their own continuing affection for one another.

title: Portuguese Banking Bill
description: The Portuguese Parliament approved a bill to allow the opening of private banks and insurance companies for the first time since both sectors were nationalized in 1975.

title: STARS APPEAR ON SMALL STAGES TO STRETCH THEIR TALENTS
description: ACTORS frequently talk about challenging themselves; some actors even do something about it, and when they do, it is often away from Broadway. With skyrocketing costs and the resultant increase in the timidity of producers, Off Broadway and Off Off Broadway continue to attract those actors, many of them with established reputations, who want to test their mettle and extend their range in classics as well as unusual new plays, in monologues as well as in collaborative performance pieces.

title: CALIFORNIA ALLEGES MORTGAGE FRAUD
description: California officials, alleging fraud, have opened an assault on a large group of home mortgage brokerage firms that have offered unusually high rates of return on investments in second or third mortgages.

title: CAREER DIPLOMAT IS EXPECTED TO BE ENVOY TO CHINA
description: President Reagan is expected to name Arthur W. Hummel Jr., a Chinese-speaking career Foreign Service officer, as the next American ambassador to China, Administration officials said today.

title: Woodlawn Walking Tour
description: A walk through Woodlawn Cemetery, created in 1863 to serve northern New York City and Westchester County, will be led Sunday by Lloyd Ultan, an associate professor of history at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: Aoki, Japan's Top Golfer, Brings Skills to Pro Tour
description: At 38, says Isao Aoki, ''I'm not too young.'' So Aoki, Japan's leading golf professional in four of the last five years, has opened a new phase of his career, playing the PGA Tour as a regular.

title: U.S. SENT TWO PATROLS INTO LAOS IN QUEST OF G.I.'S THOUGHT TO BE CAPTIVES
description: The Reagan Administration sent at least two long-range patrols into Laos in response to what a high-ranking official called ''tantalizing hints'' that American prisoners of war were still alive in that country, Administration officials said today.

title: Reunion Day in Bronx
description: The streets of the ''Little Italy'' section of the Bronx will be filled with music, food and special events tomorrow at the third Family Reunion Day, sponsored by the Arthur Avenue and 187th Street Merchants Association.

title: BUCKLEY, OUTLINING REAGAN POLICY, CALLS ARMS SALES ABROAD 'VITAL' TOOL
description: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley declared today that sales of American weapons abroad ''complement and supplement our own defense efforts and serve as a vital and constructive instrument of American foreign policy.''

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt GENERATION WITHOUT MEMORY. A Jewish Journey in Christian America. By Anne Roiphe. 221 pages. Linden/ Simon & Schuster. $11.95.

title: SENATE PANEL URGES INQUIRY ON NEW TEAMSTER HEAD
description: After receiving a report that called Roy L. Williams, interim president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, ''an organized crime mole,'' a Senate subcommittee recommended today that the Labor Department determine whether he was suitable for high office in the nation's largest union. The panel questioned his suitability because he declined to answer its questions last year about his alleged connections with organized crime.

title: Assets of Money Funds Extend Decline
description: The total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined by $256.2 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: EQUITY PACT IS REACHED ON PIPELINE
description: Pipeline companies and gas producers have worked out an equity-sharing arrangement for the projected Alaska natural gas pipeline as an important preliminary step to obtain billions of dollars in financing on United States and Canadian money markets, it was announced today.

title: RUTGERS GIVES HONORARY DEGREE TO EXILED SCIENTIST
description: The Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov was awarded an honorary doctorate of science in absentia today at Rutgers University's 215th commencement.

title: Stamford Advocate Picks Editor
description: Kenneth H. Brief has been named executive editor of The Advocate of Stamford and Greenwich Time, Jay Shaw, the publisher, announced today. Mr. Brief, 42 years old, is now assistant managing editor-administration for Newsday on Long Island.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
YOUTHFUL NORTH STARS SURE THEY'LL BE BACK
description: When the Minnesota North Stars finished shaking hands with the Islanders after losing the Stanley Cup final tonight, they stomped quietly to their dressing room, only to find it locked.

title: 'OUTLAND,' CONNERY ON JUPITER'S FRONTIER
description: ''NOT many people here have both oars in the water,'' says flinty Dr. Marian Lazarus (Frances Sternhagen), to Bill O'Niel (Sean Connery), the newly arrived Federal district marshal who has been assigned to the remote mining camp to maintain law and order. Doc Lazarus is no easier on herself, being aware that the kind of physicians who take jobs in remote mining camps usually are, as she puts it, one step ahead of a malpractice suit.

title: PRAGMATIC FRENCH PREMIER
description: ''Facts are stubborn,'' Pierre Mauroy told the Socialist Party congress assembled at Metz in 1979 to thrash out the leadership battle between Francois Mitterrand and his young challenger, Michel Rocard.

title: The Region; Transit Report
description: Most trains ran close to schedule yesterday morning, but six trains experienced delays of between six and 14 minutes. The 7:59 A.M. from Long Beach arrived in Pennsylvania Station 14 minutes late because of a backup of other trains in front of it.

title: PIZZA INN (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
Topics; STYLES, IMPORTED AND DOMESTIC TRIUMPH; Triumph
description: It always seemed to be a sign of enduring youth when the obituaries were still of movie stars we had never heard of and cars we had only heard of. In that light, age must be advancing fast, for now there has been an obituary of a car some of us used to own.

title: ROTHMANS OF PALL MALL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $5,263,000 gain on the sale of Carling O'Keefe trade marks in Southern Africa

title: Brooks's Agent To Meet Patrick
description: Herb Brooks, who is reported to be close to becoming the Rangers' coach, will be represented by his agent, Art Kaminsky, in a meeting scheduled for today with Craig Patrick, the team's operations director.

title: Husky Ends Talks On Conoco Holdings
description: Husky Oil Ltd. said that its talks with Conoco Inc. on the possible purchase of Conoco's holdings of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company had ended without agreement.

title: TURK EXPRESSES NO SORROW ON POPE AS HE IS TRANSFERRED TO ROME JAIL
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the 23-year-old Turkish militant accused of attempting to murder Pope John Paul II last week, gave no sign of contrition today as his police interrogation ended and he was moved to a civil prison.

title: Grain Storage Elevator Explodes, Injuring Five Men, Two Critically
description: Grain dust apparently ignited by either a welder's torch or an electric motor exploded in a grain elevator today, injuring five men, two of them critically, fire officials said. The explosion at about 3 P.M. destroyed the 50-foottall Inola Farm Elevator.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES NEGOTIATING A PLAN ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: President Reagan proposed tonight that Congressional leaders of both parties meet with his representative ''to launch a bipartisan effort to save Social Security.''

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
THE POINTER SISTERS AT THE SAVOY
description: THE Pointer Sisters, who appeared at the Savoy last Saturday, exemplify pop professionalism so overpolished that it undercuts the expressive power of their music. Technically, this black female trio is made up of note-perfect vocal harmonists who sing in a variety of styles.

title: Brady Leaving Room for Therapy
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, is making twice-daily trips from his hospital room for physical therapy and ''remains in good condition,'' his doctors said today. The 40-year-old press secretary is concentrating on improving his balance and ''enhancing the motor function'' of his left leg at the exercise sessions in the physical therapy department of George Washington University Medical Center, the doctors said in a report released by the White House.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Apr 18
FRIDAY, MAY 22, 1981; The Economy
description: Administration and Congressional leaders offered compromise proposals for a bipartisan bill to cut income taxes. Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and House Majority Leader Jim Wright said the Administration wanted a bill that mainstream Democrats could support. (Page A1.) President Reagan asked Congressional leaders to meet with Secretary of Health and Human Resources Richard S. Schweiker ''to save Social Security.'' The Senate on Wednesday rejected two major parts of the Reagan plan to cut benefits. (A1.)

title: Index; International
description: With pride and music, Jamaicans bury Bob Marley A2 W.H.O. formally approves baby- formula code A2 Fourth Irish nationalist hunger striker dies in Ulster A3 Irish Parliament is dissolved and elections are called A3 Around the World A5 Discord among Argentine Jews flares anew in U.S. A6 Text of Mitterrand's inaugural address A10 Pope's accused attacker exhibits no contrition A10 Buckley, outlining Reagan policy, terms arms sales ''vital'' A12 Government/Politics Smith criticizes law on independent special prosecutor A14 Hispanic vote gains as debate on act swirls A15 Senators hear conflicting views on abortion law A16 Yonkers County Executive says he'll seek a third term B2 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Under Federal law, Memorial Day will be observed Monday. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; other rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets - Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Sunday schedule; Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedule. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: Fresh Start for France?
description: Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist leader, was inaugurated today as the 21st President of France. But there was no ceremonial precedent, and public wonderment at each invention of the day added to the sense that something quite new was happening.

title: MITTERRAND TAKES OFFICE AS PRESIDENT
description: Francois Mitterrand took office today as the first Socialist to wield the strong presidential powers of France's Fifth Republic.

title: The Region; U.S. Files an Appeal On Margiotta Retrial
description: The Federal Government laid the groundwork for the retrial on Aug. 3 of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican leader, as it filed an appeal in Brooklyn for a reversal of several actions by the judge in the first trial.

title: Campbell Soup's Net Down 12.4%
description: The Campbell Soup Company reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended May 3 dropped 12.4 percent, to $29.7 million, or 92 cents a share, from $33.9 million, or $1.03 a share, in the fiscal quarter a year earlier.

title: Yankees Are Expected to Give Revering Plenty of Swing Time
description: When Dave Revering, the Yankees' new left-handed-hitting first baseman, arrived at the Stadium during the eighth inning of Wednesday night's extra-inning victory over the Kansas City Royals, Gene Michael had no time for elaborate words of welcome. ''I haven't met you yet,'' the manager said, ''but you're hitting.''

title: ROCK'S NEW WOMEN ARE GOING IT ALONE
description: WOMEN have been singing rock-and-roll since rock-and-roll began, but recently they have been invading what was previously considered a male preserve, wielding electric guitars and basses, and forming or creatively directing their own rock bands in dramatically increasing numbers. They have been acting on what the rock guitarist, singer and songwriter Joan Jett has called ''a secret desire to play sweaty rock-and-roll.'' They're not even dressing up the way earlier rock singers used to, just wearing the kind of clothes they wear on the street, as most male rock musicians do.

title: The Company Mr. Casey Keeps
description: A certain skepticism is in order when the intelligence brotherhood complains that amateurs are taking over the Central Intelligence Agency. The Bay of Pigs wasn't exactly an amateur production, save in its humiliating outcome. Nor were the abortive attempts to assassinate Fidel Castro in the 1960's. But in the matter of Max Hugel, a New Hampshire businessman now turned spymaster, the consternation among old C.I.A. hands is surely understandable.

title: Commonwealth Oil Has New Chairman
description: Last August, C. Howard Hardesty Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, said: ''I set out to bring the company out of bankruptcy. I'll be disappointed if I don't.

title: REAGAN LETTER ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Following is the text of the letter sent by President Reagan today to Congressional leaders on Social Security legislation:

title: The Awful Odds on Casino Gambling
description: Having long supported casino gambling for New York, Attorney General Robert Abrams revealed his change of mind with the care and vigor of a turncoat. The result is a most readable, precise and persuasive refutation of the widespread belief that the state can let casinos operate without imperiling the community and government's integrity.

title: SOUTHLAND FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including realized investment gains of $77,000 for the latest first qr and $46,000 for the previous first qr

title: Holmes Accuses Ex-Manager of Deception
description: Larry Holmes's longtime trainer and manager, Richie Giachetti, taped more than Holmes's hands, Holmes said yesterday in explaining why he dismissed Giachetti last month, shortly before a title defense against Trevor Berbick.

title: BRIEFS
description: Alco-Gravure, a printing unit of Macmillan Inc., has been sold to Alco Gravure Industries, a newly formed, employee-controlled company, for $25 million.

title: Extortion Bid Charged In the Patz Boy's Case
description: A Long Island man was charged yesterday with attempting to extort $2,500 from the father of Etan Patz, a Manhattan boy missing for two years, by implying he could guarantee the safety of the child.

title: Notes on People; First the du Ponts, Now the Astors
description: When his first book, ''The Du Pont Family,'' was published two years ago, John D. Gates seemed to have hit on a sure-fire formula for success. His first wife had been a du Pont and his research was aided by his family connection.

title: Suddenly, Sutton Is Camera Shy
description: NBC was forced to scrap a supposedly topsecret project when a newspaper reporter and photographer showed up for a film session featuring Don Sutton, the Houston Astros' pitcher, wearing a ski mask and demonstrating how to throw illegal pitches, something major league hitters have long suspected.

title: St. John's Wins, Spoils Yale No-Hitter
description: An unearned run on a steal of home in the 12th inning gave St. John's a 1-0 victory over Yale today in the first round of the Northeast regional of the National Collegiate tournament. Ron Darling had pitched a tournament-record 11 hitless innings for the Elis before Steve Scafa led off the 12th with a single, then stole second, third and home.

title: REAGAN SEEKS TO ASSURE SCHMIDT U.S. INTEREST RATES WILL FALL SOON
description: President Reagan told Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today that American interest rates would soon fall after Mr. Reagan's economic program was put in place.

title: Baseball Talks Hotter; Progress Invisible
description: Although representatives of major league baseball players and club owners have accelerated the frequency of their negotiating sessions, they seem to be making no progress toward a settlement that could head off a players strike scheduled to begin next Friday.

title: Architectural Firm Picks New President
description: N. David O'Malley, 42, has been named president and chief executive officer of Welton Becket Associates, a major architectural and engineering firm based in Los Angeles. He succeeds MacDonald Becket, 52, a nephew of the founder, who became chairman.

title: Rozelle Testifies At Trial
description: Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, denied today that the Los Angeles Rams' owner, Georgia Frontiere, had ever expressed fear of competition if the Oakland Raiders were allowed to move to Los Angeles.

title: Notes on People; Autograph Seeker Drops Suit Against Reggie Jackson
description: A $150,000 damage suit against Reggie Jackson was withdrawn in Civil Court in Manhattan yesterday, and Mr. Jackson's lawyer immediately claimed victory for all celebrities who are targets of autograph seekers.

title: INTERIOR CHIEF ORDERS STRIP-MINE OVERSEERS TO REDUCE OPERATION
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt disclosed a plan today to ''realign'' the United States Office of Surface Mining, which oversees the coal states in carrying out Federal-state strip-mine regulations.

title: SENATORS HEAR CONFLICTING VIEWS OVER PLAN TO PROHIBIT ABORTIONS
description: Legal authorities and Congressional figures clashed today over the constitutional implications of a bill that seeks to ban abortion and decree that all human life starts at conception.

title: DAVID DRISCOLL
description: David Driscoll, who established the news and special events department of radio station WOR before World War II and then served as its correspondent, died in Southold, L.I., on May 8.

title: THEATER: COLLEEN DEWHURST DIRECTS 'NED AND JACK'
description: IN her first time out as a director, Colleen Dewhurst has made a smart move. She's chosen to stage a play that taps right into the kind of theater she knows best as an actress. Indeed, Sheldon Rosen's ''Ned and Jack,'' which opened at the Hudson Guild last night, is a drama about theater people. More to the point, it is about the theater people of Eugene O'Neill's day - people O'Neill might have written about and in a sense did. If Miss De@whurst hadn't directed ''Ned and Jack,'' she would have had to figure out a way to act in it.

title: East-West Trade Gets China Tabloid Account
description: East-West Trade Publications here in New York has been named to solicit advertising worldwide for International Trade News, a tabloid circulated only in China, according to Louis F. Sharpe, president of East-West Trade. He said the Chinese had ended a 20-year ban on advertising in the country's only official foreign trade newspaper.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
DOES SPECIAL TYPE WIN PIANO CONTESTS?
description: Six smart young pianists who are jousting one another here in the sixth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, sat in a circle yesterday, talking about competitions in general and the Van Cliburn in particular. All are superb pianists, and three of them - at least, in this observer's private score card - would appear to be inevitably destined for the semifinals that start on Sunday. A fourth may have knocked himself out yesterday. He had an awful afternoon, as can happen to anybody but which can be fatal in a competition. Will the jury shoot him down, or will it gloss over the unhappy lapse from form in light of the artist's undeniable talent and charisma? We will know in a few days.

title: PRIVATE REPORT RECOMMENDS U.S. EXPAND EMBARGO ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: A private study of American policy choices in southern Africa recommends that the United States maintain an arms and investment embargo on South Africa until the black majority in that country obtains ''an effective share in political power.''

title: 'BUSTIN' LOOSE' STARS RICHARD PRYOR GONE SOFTY
description: ONLY the incomparable Richard Pryor could make a comedy as determinedly, aggressively sentimental as ''Bustin' Loose,'' which is about eight needy orphans and a $15,000 mortgage that's due, and still get an R-rating. Vulgar language is the reason, but because vulgar language is a basic part of the Pryor comedy method, one longs for his every assault on genteelism in ''Bustin' Loose,'' a film that would otherwise be painful.

title: TALKS IN COAL STRIKE ARE RESUMING TODAY
description: Sam M. Church Jr., president of the United Mine Workers, issued a harsh attack today on his coal industry counterpart but at the same time said negotiations to end the 56-dayold miners' strike would resume tomorrow.

title: G.M. 'J' Car Models Displayed by Dealers
description: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest car manufacturer, rolled out its $5 billion line of ''J'' cars today, confident that they will put a dent in Japanese imports.

title: Notes on People; Cordiality Reigns as Cohen and Merrick Meet
description: At a cocktail party Alexander H. Cohen gave at the Players Club on Wednesday, a clutch of still and television photographers rushed toward the entrance when David Merrick ambled in. That's because of the oft-reported ''feud'' between Mr. Cohen and Mr. Merrick, both longtime Broadway producers.

title: ESQUIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $89,000 loss for the qr and $6,226,000 gain for the yr from discontinued operations

title: Charter Terminating Alaska Oil Venture
description: The Charter Oil Company announced that its 93 percent owned joint venture, the Alaska Oil Company, planned to terminate its royalty crude oil contract with the State of Alaska because Charter could not secure $2 billion in financing for an oil refinery in Alaska.

title: Caramoor and Boscobel Are Open for Visiting
description: The scenic New York estates of Caramoor in Katonah and Boscobel in Garrison-on-Hudson are open for visits. Caramoor, built in the 1930's by the lawyer and banker Walter Tower Rosen, contains his collection of early European and Chinese art and furniture.

title: A FOURTH HUNGER STRIKER DIES IN ULSTER
description: Patrick O'Hara, the fourth of the Irish nationalist hunger strikers, died at the Maze Prison near here last night, after 61 days without food.

title: AS MEDICAL MALPRACTICE INSURANCE GROWS COSTLIER
description: To the Editor:

title: German Technology Show
description: A bicycle from 1817 and an 1883 experimental model of a Daimler gasoline engine are among the devices on display in an exhibition of 19th-century German technology at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 83d Street.

title: TEXT OF ADDRESS BY MITTERRAND
description: Following is the text of President Francois Mitterrand's inaugural address, as translated by Reuters:

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 31
Mr.  Lefever's Colors
description: Here are excerpts from an exchange on Monday between Chairman Charles Percy of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and Ernest Lefever, President Reagan's nominee for Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs:

title: Around the World; Zimbabwe Says Disarming Of Ex-Rebels Is Complete
description: Zimbabwe has completed the disarming of dissident former guerrillas, Emerson Munangagwa, a Cabinet minister in charge of security, said today.

title: Reader's Digest Gives Go To Families Magazine
description: The board of the Reader's Digest Association, whose magazine is the worldwide best seller, has given the ''go'' signal to its Families magazine, which has had two test issues.

title: Books: People in Crises
description: By Anatole Broyard WHERE THE JACKALS HOWL AND OTHER STORIES. By Amos Oz. 217 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: Market Place; Issue of Airline Control
description: LAWYERS are experts at saying what a listener wants to hear. Consider the two letters written at different times by lawyers for Continental Air Lines in connection with its proposed employees' stock ownership trust that would own 51 percent of the airline's shares.

title: Magazine on House Design
description: DENIS AND CHRISTINE CONNIFF SHEAHAN were both in publishing - he on the writing and editing sides and she, art direction and design - before they opened an ad agency in Remsenburg, L.I., called Sheahan & Conniff, which specializes in real estate development.

title: DELBELLO SAYS HE'LL SEEK 3D TERM AS WESTCHESTER'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Alfred B. DelBello, the Executive of Westchester County, returned to the city of his political origins today to announce that he would seek a third four-year term in the county's top post.

title: FILM: 'FAN,' A LAUREN BACALL THRILLER
description: ''THE FAN,'' a suspense-thriller of rather unfortunate timeliness, has several terrific things going for it, and they're all named Lauren Bacall.

title: HONDA MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: Shr earnings are per American shrs each of which is equal to 10 shrs of Honda common stock; shr earnings also reflect a 10 percent common stock distribution made on Sept 1; results were translated at the rate of 210 yen equals $1, the approxima exchange rate on Feb 27

title: Broadway; A new theatrical unit aiming for Broadway with a new musical.
description: the promotion of events, television, a model agency. International Management has just formed IMG Theatrical, which will take a new musical, ''American Heroes,'' into workshop performances next month and, if all goes well, open it on Broadway in October. The director is Tom O'Horgan, and the workshop will be held in Michael Bennett's studio downtown. Already this is promising.

title: HAMILTON BROTHERS PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $1,210,000 gain on the sale of securities

title: PERCY SAID TO URGE NEW RIGHTS CHOICE
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has asked the White House to withdraw the nomination of Ernest W. Lefever as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, according to Administration officials and Congressional aides.

title: Around the Nation; Witness Testifies Blanton Never Ordered Licensing
description: A former member of the Alcoholic Beverage Commission testified today that he had never been told how to vote on the licensing of liquor stores by either former Gov. Ray Blanton or by Mr. Blanton's special assistant, Clyde Edd Hood Jr.

title: Around the World; 30 Priests in South Korea End 3-Day Hunger Strike
description: Thirty Roman Catholic priests ended a three-day hunger strike today after the authorities promised to accept their demands for the release of 23 people jailed for involvement in last year's violent Kwangju uprising, a Catholic official said.

title: 'IMPROPER CHANNELS'
description: THE best part of ''Improper Channels'' is a slight craziness around the fringes, although at the center of this comedy there's not much going on. Alan Arkin and Mariette Hartley, appealing though none too well matched, play a couple who lose custody of their child through a bureaucratic mishap. It's an accident, really, so the story doesn't exactly have villains. But it does have a social worker who declares, ''I think everybody in this country has the right to be helped,'' and an administrator who keeps diplomas from the Arthur Murray dance academy prominently on his wall.

title: Chief Executive Named At L'Oreal's U.S. Unit
description: Lindsay H. Owen-Jones, 35, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Cosmair Inc., the United States licensee of L'Oreal, a large French cosmetics company. He succeeds Jean Caste, 51, who became president and chief executive of the Nestle Company, an American subsidiary of the giant Swiss Nestle organization, which owns a minority interest in L'Oreal.

title: DURHAM GETS 4 HITS AS CUBS STOP REDS
description: Leon Durham hit a three-run homer, a double and two singles today and Randy Martz pitched a seven-hitter to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 5-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: CONCERT: COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA
description: THE American Composers Orchestra concert Monday night at Alice Tully Hall confirmed its status as one of the country's most important musical institutions - one that offers a refreshingly wide stylistic range of new orchestral music in top-notch performances.

title: CABARET: SONGS BY JANE HARVEY
description: JANE HARVEY, whose singing career began with Benny Goodman's orchestra in the 1940's, indicated at Freddie's last weekend that she is, after all those years, still uncertain about her direction as a singer.

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: B-Including $140,766 or 6 cents a shr nonrecurring income

title: MEDCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $85,448 extraordinary tax credit

title: BEVARE! BEVARE! IT'S LUGOSI
description: ''GLEN OR GLENDA,'' which opens today at the Quad Cinema, is a half-mad old movie Paramount hasn't so much rescued as disinterred. It isn't quite a camp classic, although it's dreadful enough to have a certain comic appeal. ''Glen or Glenda'' is also a film of great conviction in its way, and that tends to interfere with the fun. Edward Wood, who made the film in 1952, appears to have genuinely believed that the world was an unfair place because women got to wear all the lounging pajamas. Here, in 67 minutes punctuated by occasional bewildering shrieks from Bela Lugosi, he made his case.

title: Around the World; Five Polish Factory Workers Are Reported to Begin a Fast
description: Dissident sources said today that five workers had begun a hunger strike at a factory in Sosnowiec in the heavily industrialized south to protest the imprisonment of political prisoners.

title: BOMB FOUND ON TRUCK AT U.N. GARAGE
description: A live pipe bomb was found taped to the chassis of a private garbage truck entering the United Nations garage yesterday. The bomb was found a little more than an hour after a telephone caller warned the police that six bombs had been placed in the ''basement'' of the United Nations complex in mid-Manhattan.

title: F.C.C. Delays TV Rate Rises
description: In a victory for the major television networks, the Federal Communications Commission told the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today that it was not convinced that the utility's proposed restructuring of its TV transmission service rates was reasonable.

title: F.C.C. Weighs Appeal by RKO
description: The Federal Communications Commission today took under advisement a request by lawyers for RKO General Inc. that the agency reconsider its decision to strip the company of valuable television stations in Boston, New York and Los Angeles.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $35,000 loss for the qr and $9,894,000 gain for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-After losses of $28,385, for the qr and $28,486,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued oper and a charge covering losses on receivables and liabilities ass from the former Wisconsin Steel division

title: UNION AIDE IS INDICTED IN BROOKLYN
description: An official of a teamsters' union based on Long Island was indicted yesterday on Federal racketeering and extortion charges. The official, Harry Gross, was accused of having illegally demanded and received two automobiles valued at a total of $19,000 from two construction organizations and a $2,500 payment from a third. Mr. Gross is a business agent of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: DRUG CASE LINKS HAITIAN TO A PLOT FOR A REVOLUTION
description: A Federal indictment charged a Haitian physician and six other men yesterday with conducting a conspiracy to manufacture and sell ''$100 million worth of synthetic cocaine.''

title: Topics; STYLES, IMPORTED AND DOMESTIC; Success Story
description: There was a time not long ago when Newport, Rhode Island, seemed the perfect setting for someone who shared Graham Greene's sense of the seedy. But soon after the Navy moved out, in 1973, the exposed brick wall/ spinach salad lobby moved in.

title: BERTRAM GELLER
description: Bertram Geller, the president of a women's shoe company, died Monday at his home in Cedarhurst, L.I. He was 64 years old. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis; three sons, Joseph of Cambridge, Mass.; Michael of New York City, and Alan of Austin, Tex., and four grandchildren.

title: Changes at Ziff Corp.
description: There were several changes yesterday at the Ziff Corporation, where Philip B. Korsant, 37, was named executive vice president and Richard P. Friese, Albert S. Traina and Kenneth Koppel became, respectively, president of Ziff-Davis Publishing, president of the Consumer Magazine division and president of the Business Publications division.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Auctions; Refound Corot leads art sales.
description: AFTER three record-breaking weeks of art auctions, the sales continue next week with European and American 19th-century paintings, American Impressionists and 20th-century works. The mostdiscussed painting of the hundreds to be dispersed is Jean Baptiste Corot's ''The Meditation,'' a work from the 1860's. This pensive study of Emma Dobigny, one of the artist's favorite models, will be auctioned in a two-part sale of 320 paintings beginning next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. in Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street.

title: GOLD MEDALLION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $118,000 for latest first qr and $60,000 for the previous first qr

title: CUP, M.V.P. TROPHY HELP SOOTHE GORING
description: In the swirl of champagne that bubbled through the Islanders' locker room tonight, Butch Goring acknowledged his surprise at having been selected the winner of the Conn Smythe Trophy as the most valuable player of the entire Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: 2 PSYCHOLOGISTS TESTIFY CRIMMINS HAS VERBAL LEARNING DISABILITIES
description: Two psychologists - one who tested Craig S. Crimmins when he was 13 years old and another who tested him earlier this month - testified yesterday that he had a long history of learning disabilities.

title: Female Recruit Dies in Run
description: Preliminary autopsy reports indicate that an irregular heartbeat may have been the cause of the death of a 23-year-old female Army recruit, Pvt. Pamelia F. Johnson of Hillsborough, N.C., who complained of difficulty in breathing on a two-mile run at Fort Jackson. Private Johnson died Wednesday. Lois Duke of the Fort Jackson public information office said Miss Johnson had one week of basic training left to serve.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
CENTURY OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
'DEATH HUNT' PITS BRONSON AGAINST MARVIN
description: ''DEATH HUNT,'' which opens at the Criterion Center and other theaters today, is reportedly based on a true story that happened in the Yukon Territory in 1931: a fur trapper named Albert Johnson, an eccentric loner, having been accused of murder, attempted to flee through the Arctic Circle wilderness to sanctuary in Alaska, pursued by authorities led by Sgt. Edgar Millen of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

title: Topics; STYLES, IMPORTED AND DOMESTIC CROISSANTERIES; Croissanteries
description: Imagine this scene. You and a friend are lunching together. One of you -the one who buys bottled water -wants quiche, salad and a glass of regional red.

title: Ted Bates Name Change
description: Ted Bates & Company, 40-year-old consumer goods agency giant, is changing its name to Ted Bates Worldwide, joining the other agencies seeking a multinational image through a name change. Bates is entitled, however, since it does have 68 offices in 31 countries in its international group, as well as five big domestic subsidiaries.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Last Angry Week for Baseball
description: AS Ray Grebey must have known they would, the baseball players have rejected the only bargaining gesture made by their employers in more than a year. The deadline for a strike by the 26 major league teams is one week away, and ''I have never seen the players so angry,'' says the head of their union, Marvin Miller.

title: ALBANY PANEL TO WEIGH BILL ON CULT-MEMBER GUARDIANS
description: Legislation allowing the courts to name temporary guardians for people in religious cults was defeated this week in Connecticut, but a similar measure goes before a New York State Assembly committee next week.

title: Measles Found to Have Infected Vaccinated Teen-Agers in Texas
description: With a epidimic here apparently nearing an end, the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta have been asked to find out why 42 percent of El Paso's 180 recent measles victims had been immunized since 1968 with a vaccine that should have been effective, according to Dr. Bernard Rosenblum of the El Paso City-County Health Unit.

title: SMITH OPPOSES A SPECIAL PROSECUTOR FOR INVESTIGATIONS OF U.S.  OFFICIALS
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that Congress should repeal the law requiring the appointment of an independent special prosecutor to investigate allegations against any of more than 200 high-ranking Federal officials.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Policy And the G.N.P.
description: THE upward surge in the gross national product during this year's first quarter was so dramatic that it forced a change in the perception of the state of the economy and a reappraisal of the Administration's fiscal and monetary policies.

title: NEW YORKER GETS TOP PRESBYTERIAN JOB
description: A New York City clergyman has been elected to the top office in the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., a 2.4-million member denomination that has its national headquarters here.

title: Los Angeles Agency Gains Tyco Account
description: Scott Lancaster Mills Atha, a Los Angeles agency, has been named to the Tyco Industries toy account and has changed its name by adding Jackman in the middle.

title:
MORALITY IN MAKING POLICY;
PHILADELPHIA - Our ethical systems are irrelevant, inconsistent, and ineffective as tools of consensus in policy making. A confluence of historical factors has produced this disorder in the moral dimension of policy formation. Judeo-Christian morality is ill-suited as a guideline in dealing with increasingly complex problems. In addition, the utilitarianism that pervades policy generates a stream of dissenters who consider social choices unjust.  The utilitarian principle of promoting the greatest good for the greatest number is a political slogan that is rarely a useful tool of policy. And so, the moral regimes propose, and the moral minorities, through obstruction and indifference, dispose.
description: The policymaker's role is to reconcile technical and moral judgments. He confronts three major categories of moral posture. A large segment of the public, the religionists, is hostile to the policymaker because his policy rubs against their religious sentiments. The ethic of a second segment, the utilitarian situationalists, comprises assessing contemplated behavior in terms of probable benefits and costs; the extent to which the situationalists tolerate costs varies inversely with the proximity to themselves of those who bear the costs. The third group, which lacks a structured moral system, is the narcissists. They affect policy because of the policymaker's inability to count on them for its effective execution. Their behavior is summarized by the dictum: If it makes you feel good, do it, unless the action creates intolerable costs to the doer. The narcissists have the least sense of moral obligation - a requisite for the effective operation of a society.

title: STAGE: 'SEMMELWEISS,' STORY OF A MEDICAL HERO
description: Howard Sackler's ''Semmelweiss'' is a chilling drama of one man's crusade, madness and martrydom. It is a medical adventure story set in 19th-century Vienna that confronts urgent and eternal issues - an altruistic hero struggling helplessly against a corrupt system, idealism subverted by pragmatism. The play poses the question: is there no alternative to the hypocrisy of compromise and the futility of a powerless individual? Under the direction of Edwin Sherin at the Hartman Theater Company, four years after its premiere at the Buffalo's Studio Arena Theater and three years after a Broadway-bound production closed in Washington, ''Semmelweiss'' remains a drama with dimension, sagacity and moral fervor.

title: MODERNIST SHOW MOVES MET FIRMLY INTO ART OF 20TH CENTURY
description: THE exhibition called ''An American Choice: The Muriel Kallis Steinberg Newman Collection,'' which opened yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is something of a milestone in the history of that august institution. It certainly marks a change for the better in the history of the museum's troubled attempts to acquire a significant collection of modernist art. For this show gives us our first public look at a Chicago collection that is renowned for its fine examples of the New York School, and the collection itself - which also includes examples of modern European art and primitive sculpture - is a promised gift to the museum. It will thus form an important part of the museum's future holdings in 20th-century art and may very well serve as a stimulus for bringing other modernist collections to the Met.

title: A GOOD RESTAURANT SHOULDN'T SERVE 'WRONG' DISHES
description: ''Oh, well. You didn't order the right things. You ate all the wrong dishes!'' This is the comment I often get when I report unfavorably on a highly recommended restaurant. The idea that a restaurant serving a number of ''wrong'' dishes can still be considered good is inexplicable, yet it is not without its advocates or, at least, its apologists. That a generally lackluster or even poor restaurant consistently produces one or two isolated masterpieces - sports, as it were - is common and understandable. In such cases recommendations will usually say, ''Look, everything at that place is pretty bad except. ...''

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 10, 1981; The Economy
description: Producer prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in December for finished goods. At the end of 1980, that index was 11.7 percent higher than at the end of 1979 - a bit better than the 12.6 percent rise in 1979. Food prices fell in December, but advances for energy, capital equipment and other goods more than offset the drop, the Labor Department reported. ''It's not comforting at all,'' commented Arnold Shindler, a senior economist at Bankers Trust. (Page 1.)
