description: Next year is Haydn's 250th birthday, and considering his reputation - most people would probably include him in a short list of the world's greatest composers - the occasion does not seem to have excited much interest among performing organizations. Haydn remains an indispensable staple of any healthy musical diet, but in our concert life, he usually appears as an appetizer to the main course, a Romantic-age symphony, sonata or string quartet. Rarely is he accorded the spotlight, and the comfortable image of harmless old Papa Haydn, whose safe-and-sane scores clear the air for more important matters, dies hard.

title: First U.S. Yacht in Global Race
description: Neil Bergt grew up in Anchorage and went to work as a milkman. He saved enough money toting milk bottles to buy a small plane and begin a career as a bush pilot, flying to the most remote areas of Alaska.

title: Kent Daiber Weds Elizabeth Ackerley
description: Elizabeth Allyn Ackerley and Kent Edwin Daiber were married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ronald Lafferty. Julia Allyson Ackerley, the bride's sister, was maid of honor.

title: Index; International
description: Economy is key factor for both rebels and junta in El Salvador 3 Greek Cypriots hold parliamen- tary elections today 3 Around the World 4 U.S. and Greece said to approach compromise on bases and aid 6 Coalition plans break down in West Berlin 10 Poland investigating former Pre- mier 11 Oil ministers gather in Geneva for meeting on prices 12 Turks says Europeans aren't cooperating in Agca case 15 Government/Politics Panel to urge Reagan to grant am- nesty to illegal aliens 18 Support facilities at Reagan ranch are temporary, aides say 19 G.A.O. report on Tombigbee hailed by both sides 20 Amtrak plans side ventures to res- cue rail network 21 Environmental quality unit plans active role 22 Senator attacks Carey plan for more power to name judges 34 Queens G.O.P. endorses Esposito for Mayor 35 Albany Notes: Legislature and Carey trading blame 38 General Harvard's Hasty Pudding Club faces economic problems 17 Searchers come in greater num- bers in Atlanta to hunt for clues 23 Around the Nation 24 High-rise complex planned on West 96th St. 29 Summer of protests planned by antiwar coalition 30 Prison uprisings in Nevada and Michigan quelled by officers 31 Contents of Buckley family's 30- room mansion go on the block 32 Magicians discuss tricks of trade at Manhattan convention 33 New York seeks to update its his- torical makers 42 Industry/Labor Sanitation agency and union disa- gree over new truck 41 Arts/Entertainment Music: Debuts in Review 45 Theater for the New City stages Kroetz's ''Farmyard'' 46 James Taylor in high spirits at the Savoy 46 ''Women in Tune,'' revue at the Theater off Park 46 Darci Kistler dances in ''Who Cares?'' 46 Patricia McBride and Tomasson dance ''Scotch Symphony'' 46 Van Cliburn jury picks 12 semi- finialists 47 Abbey Lincoln sings at the Village Vanguard 47 Dancers and Musicians from Bali perform at Asia House 47 Style Their camouflage draws the eye 48 Help from ''aunts'' in England 48

title: WHEN A VIRTUOSO AND HIS CELLO TAKE TO THE ROAD
description: Logan Airport, Boston. Destination Detroit. Flight attendant: ''Welcome aboard, sir. Wouldn't you like to check that object through?''

title: Health Code Violations Found in 55 Food Places
description: New York City's Department of Health has cited 55 food establishments for violations of the city's Health Code. In addition, three establishments corrected earlier violations and two were closed for failing to do so.

title: Spring City in 3-Way Tie For Lead at Devon Show
description: Spring City, owned by the B. K. L. Stables of Manlius, N. Y., and handled by Dan Langan, pulled into a tie for the lead in the race for the junior jumper championship by winning the touches and time class today at the Devon horse show.
To the Editor:

title: KAVALEK TRIUMPHS, IN THE CAPABLANCA MANNER
description: Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Reston, Va., triumphed in the International West German championship in Bochum with a convincing 12-3 score. Trailing him by 1 1/2 points came Vlastimil Hort, a Czech grandmaster, who served as Robert Hubner's second in the Candidate's Matches.

title:
Art;
THE ART OF NORTH CAROLINA: SURPRISES IN STORE
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP A VERY interesting exhibition, ''The Art of North Carolina,'' is on display at the E.R. Squibb Art Gallery, and I am quite willing to bet that the show, which ends next Sunday, will be a surprise to most viewers.

title: A restored house is beginning to look more like a second home for beneficiary of Fresh Air project
description: GLEN GARDNER ROLLING farmland surrounding this Hunterdon County community is only about a two-hour drive from the aging tenements and factories of Long Island City, but it seems like a world away.

title: Soviet Parliament to Convene
description: The Supreme Soviet, or Parliament, will convene in regular session on June 23, the Government announced today.

title: No Headline
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES Americans currently have a consuming passion for books about getting into good physical shape.

title: Bond Funds
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Lessons From a Bond Fund'' (May 10) and the table accompanying it, we feel the table is misleading. Although the Babson Tax-Free Income Fund was legally in existence on March 31, 1980, it had virtually no money in it and was not operational.

title: The World In Summary; REPORT ON S.AFRICA TAKES A TOUGH LINE
description: The Reagan Administration said it would ''read with interest'' a 456-page study published last week by 11 prominent Americans proposing a freeze on United States investment in South Africa to persuade its whites to share power with its black majority.

title: GREEK CYPRIOT VOTE TODAY SHOWS RIFTS
description: In the soft night air of the Akhna pine forest, the Greek Cypriot opposition leader, Glafkos Clerides, gave his oath to the gathering of several hundred Greek Cypriot refugees ''to keep fighting until you can go home.''

title: BALLET DARCI KISTLER SOLO
description: Darci Kistler is one of the New York City Ballet's chief attractions at the New York State Theater this season. Young, touchingly spunky and possessed of an apparently unlimited fund of technical daring, Miss Kistler, still in her teens, has risen to the challenge of the major roles that have been assigned her in such quick succession and has brought something of her own to each. On Thursday, however, she ran into problems that probably only maturity will overcome. Miss Kistler certainly can dance. But her performance in ''Who Cares?'', George Balanchine's effervescent celebration of George Gershwin's songs, suggests that she can't yet prance.

title: Who's on First?
description: To the Editor:

title: St. John's Wins 2 in Tourney
description: St. John's won a doubleheader today in college baseball's Northeast regional tournament at Yale Field, forcing an extra game against Maine here tomorrow. The winner will qualify for the College World Series at Omaha May 30.

title: Paterson Arts Official Corrects a Quotation
description: I was grateful to see the article by Terence Ripmaster (''Cutting Arts Budgets Is a Mistake,'' May 10), and I totally agree with his opinions. But I must add a correction.

title: Nancy Stephen, Actress, Wed
description: Nancy Jane Stephens, a television and screen actress, was married yesterday in Los Angeles to Richard L. Rosenthal Jr., president of Whitewater Films Inc. Superior Court Judge Isabel Cohen performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: THE PICTURE ON SILVER
description: The price of silver has long since come down the roller coaster which took it to a peak of $50 an ounce in early 1980. Silver averaged $13 an ounce in this year's first quarter this year and has currently slipped under $11.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; Court Fills In Some Blanks in 'Miranda' Rights
description: The waters of ambiguity have run deep beneath Supreme Court pronouncements on the rights of suspects to remain silent and to have a lawyer present during police interrogations. When it spelled out those constitutional guarantees in its 1966 Miranda decision, the Court left open several questions of when and where they obtain. Last week, in two unrelated cases, the Court gave answers, significantly extending protections against self-incrimination.

title: COURTS EXPERIMENT TO HASTEN JUSTICE
description: IN UNION COUNTY, every citizen is entitled to his day in court, even if the ''day'' is at night. In Camden County, anyone summoned for jury duty is assured that his days are numbered, for, unless called for a trial, no one is required to put in more than one day's service.

title: Ann L. Thomas Married To Lieut. Douglas Porter
description: Ann Louise Thomas, an architect with the San Diego firm of Salerno/ Livingston and Partners, and Lieut. (jg.) Douglas Carlton Porter, U.S.N., were married yesterday in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is no more danger to his life.'' - Dr. Francesco Crucitti, on Pope John Paul II. (14:6.)

title: Cary Bacon Bride Of Paul Winslow, A Ph.D. Candidate
description: At St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Cary Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Michael Bacon Jr. of Greenwich, was married to Paul A. Winslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Winslow of East Weymouth, Mass. The Rev. Thomas P. Guinan performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Thomas F.X. Hoar, director of campus ministry at St. Michael's College in Winooski, Vt., which the bride attended and from which her husband graduated cum laude.

title: Katherine Clifford Bride of Randolph Cates
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Joseph of Arimathea in Elmsford, N.Y., yesterday, Katherine B. Clifford was married to Randolph E. Cates by the Rev. Donald Cutler.

title: A SURPRISINGLY STRONG FIRST QUARTER
description: The economy grew at a surprisingly strong rate in the first quarter, the Government said. Revising previously reported figures, it said the Gross National Product had bounded ahead at an 8.4 percent annual rate. The old estimate was 6.5 percent.

title: MEDIATOR IS PESSIMISTIC AS BASEBALL IMPASSE CONTINUES
description: Baseball moved a day closer to a strike yesterday, with negotiators for club owners and players resolving nothing in a 90-minute bargaining session, then recessing until Tuesday. Barring an unexpected, drastic change in position by either side on the freeagent compensation issue or a Federal Court injunction, the players are expected to strike after Thursday night's games.

title: Headliners; The President's Scientist
description: The scientific comment on Dr. George A. Keyworth's selection as White House science adviser last week seemed to dwell on what he isn't rather than what he is.

title: What's the Moral In Campanis Tale?
description: To the Sports Editor: George Vecsey's Mother's Day column, ''Seeds of Success From Watermelon'' (The New York Times, May 9) wasn't long enough. It left me up in the air.

title: CHILDREN GET LESSONS IN HANDLING FEELINGS
description: PORT CHESTER ''EVERYONE has feelings,'' Jean Merkle was telling her third grade class at the John F. Kennedy School here. ''Feelings are where?'' ''Inside,'' answered John Smith. ''That's right,'' Mrs. Merkle said. ''Someone may not show them; feelings are inside whether they are expressed or not.'' She went to the blackboard to compose a ''feelings list,'' calling on the youngsters for suggestions. One of them offered ''frustrated.'' ''What does that mean?'' Mrs. Merkle asked. ''When you try real hard and you can't do it,'' answered Marcos Morales. They went on: important, surprised, upset, angry, embarrassed, excited, disappointed and proud, ''like when you're in a race and you win something,'' said John.

title: Dancing With Jacques d'Amboise
description: I salute Jacques d'Amboise for the time, love and talent he expends on the children he instructs (''The Pied Piper of Dance,'' by Barbara Gelb, April 12). As a principal of an urban school, I see too many children whose broken spirits prevent them from excelling. Mr. d'Amboise brings success, positive attention and self-pride to children who might never have felt these emotions. Could you imagine the impact if more artists like Jacques d'Amboise were willing to devote their time and talent to our children? PETER J. SALZANO JR., Paterson, N.J.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Braves 7, Padres 6
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Rufino Linares singled in Rafael Ramirez from second base with one out in the 11th inning for the winning run. With one out, Ramirez hit a double to left field off Gary Lucas (3-5). After Bill Nahorodony, a pinch-hitter, was intentionally walked, Linares singled to right to make Rick Camp, (4-1) the winner.

title: SUSANNE S. STERN ENGAGED TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hart Rice of New York and Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rice's daughter, Suzanne S. Stern, to Peter W. Kunhardt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Bradish Kunhardt Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BERMUDA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JUDITH WADSON is a reporter for The Royal Gazette in Hamilton. By JUDITH WADSON

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: The Region In Summary; CULTS AND PARENTS A VOLATILE MIXTURE
description: When is an abrupt change of ''basic values and life styles'' the result of an ''indoctrinational thought-reform process'' and when is it a sign of faith? That was the theological and legal question posed by legislative proposals in New York and Connecticut to give parents and others the right to temporarily remove cult members from their sects.

title: Miss Colhoun And J.W. Taft Plan Wedding
description: The engagement of Susan Forbes Colhoun to James William Taft of Pacific Palisades, Calif., has been announced by Damaris Deere Wiman Colhoun of New York and Sun Valley, Idaho, and Richard Newbold Colhoun of Tarpon Springs, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Shirley Peterson Taft and Leroy Taft, both of Pacific Palisades.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: JUNE HAVOC TO LEAD IN DAY OF DANCING
description: WILTON TO June Havoc, dancing was once a survival mechanism, a means to a meal. Today, it is sharing and having fun. The actress, author and director, who endured dance marathon contests for thousands of hours in dingy halls during the Depression, is staging a ''dance in the streets'' this afternoon in Cannon Crossing, her enclave of restored shops in the Cannondale section of Wilton, about two miles north of Wilton Center on Route 7. She said she has invited ''everyone in the state'' and will be sending in the clowns ''to mix with the people.'' The event is scheduled to last from noon until 5 P.M., but under Miss Havoc's direction, it may last longer.

title: The Region In Summary; A PLAN TO PRESERVE WITHOUT FREEZING
description: Preserving the architectural quality of a neighborhood and protecting its commercial vitality are often opposite ends. In designating a 1,044-building chunk of Manhattan's Upper East Side as a historic district last week, New York's Landmarks Preservation Commission took pains to reach one goal without obstructing the other.

title: Polish Cardinal Has a Relapse
description: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the ailing Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, has taken a turn for the worse, the press agency P.A.P. said today. Quoting a church communique, the agency said that he was in ''very serious'' condition and that his health had deteriorated since the last official statement, on May 14. Earlier this week, church sources reported an improvement in his condition.

title: Philip Wins IC4A Long Jump on Final 25-11
description: Anthony Philip of Seton Hall was having a frustrating time today in the long-jump competition of the 105th annual IC4A outdoor track and field track championships.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Islanders' Decision
description: FOR all the glorious moments of their second consecutive Stanley Cup championship, perhaps the Islanders' most significant tableau occurred as Denis Potvin relaxed with his teammates at the National Hockey League's annual playoff luncheon last Monday in Bloomington, Minn.

title: Favored Day Care Takes Meadowlands Trot Race
description: Day Care, one of the leading eligibles for the Hambletonian, scored a half-length victory in the second round of the Weequahic Park trotting series at the Meadowlands last night.

title: WHY NOBODY CALLS YOU BACK ANYMORE
description: W E live in an on-line society that continually changes its many established business habits. Nowhere is this more evident than in the apparent deterioration in business manners. Good manners, in fact, seem no longer to exist as a sound administrative practice. Despite the bland use of such terms as ''Have a nice day,'' management seems to have taken a slightly less than chivalrous view toward what was once deemed accepted business behavior. To wit:

title: WHY WASN'T WILLIAMS SUSPICIOUS?  an Arab sheik
description: BY NOW, I would think, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. recognizes that he should have pursued some of the suspicions he must have had during the several months he was dealing with the men who later turned out to be Abscam undercover agents and asked a few questions.

title: About Long Island
description: OCEANSIDE THE two men who shared Room 201 of B-2, a postsurgical ward of South Nassau Communities Hospital, watched the evening's passing parade, and the paraders looked in on them. One's door is almost always open so that nurses and doctors can look in and get in and out quickly, if they have to.

title: MUSICIANS OF THE FUTURE DISCUSS LIFE AND ART
description: Sometimes Gary Schwartz wonders if he has what it takes to become a professional trumpeter. ''Some people have a natural ability with the instrument,'' said the 20-year-old Juilliard student. ''Those are the people I hate. I have to sweat and sweat and sweat. I can be doing everything right, I mean everything - my tongue, my breathing - and I still can't get those high notes.''

title: Thousands Attend Funeral Of Ulster Hunger Striker
description: Thousands of supporters of the Irish Republican Army crowded into the village of Camlough today for the funeral of Raymond McCreesh, one of two Irish hunger strikers who died last week.

title: THROUGH THE WRINGER AT GOODYEAR
description: IN the annals of management, the downsizing of General Motors cars is recognized as a classic decision. It was a fundamental and wrenching move, but the auto maker's resources and capital enabled it to muscle its way through a difficult time. Now, although the company is by no means out of the woods, G.M. is wellpositioned to make the most of recovery while its competitors are in deeper trouble.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; FUROR OVER BABY FORMULAS-WHERE, WHEN AND HOW
description: One hundred and eighteen lands - from tiny, dirt-poor African states to rich, Western European giants, from the Communist bloc to right-wing Latin American regimes - joined last week in Geneva under the auspices of the World Health Organization to approve a voluntary international code. The purpose: to curtail the promotion of artifical milk mixes for infants as a life-threatening hazard. The lone negative vote was cast by the United States, which found itself in the unenviable position of opposing what seemed a ''mother and apple pie'' issue -the health and well-being of babies.

title: Miss Wiener, a Lawyer, Wed to Steven Goldstein
description: Margaret Whitney Wiener, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, and Steven Laine Goldstein, a sports reporter for The Daily News, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Larchmont, N.Y. Village Court Judge Joseph P. Clifford performed the ceremony.

title: PROGRAM ON ALIENS OFFERED TO REAGAN
description: A Cabinet-level advisory committee has tentatively decided to recommend that President Reagan back a program of amnesty for about one million illegal aliens along with improving enforcement of the immigration laws, penalizing employers for hiring illegal aliens and permitting a limited number of Mexicans to work legally in the United States under an experimental program.

title: Dr. G. S. O'Connor Weds Karen Paul
description: Karen Lynn Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Paul of St. James, L.I., was married in Washington yesterday to Dr. Gerard Stephen O'Connor, son of Gloria O'Connor of Roanoke, Va., and John S. O'Connor of Hazlet, N.J. The Rev. James English performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, Georgetown.

title: Margaret deRosset McLean Married to David G. Gordon
description: Margaret deRosset McLean and David Gerald Gordon, a partner in G.X. Clarke & Company, a government-securities firm in New York, were married yesterday.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I have read with intense sympathy the ''expressions of abhorrence'' coming from ''eminent writers, philosophers and theologians'' on the shooting of the Pope: ''I don't understand. I just don't understand,'' is the universal tenor of all their statements (news article May 14).

title: Elizabeth A. Smith Is Married to Douglas L. Crawford
description: Elizabeth A. Smith, daughter of Mrs. Wayne C. Smith of Punta Gorda, Fla., and the late Mr. Smith, and Douglas L. Crawford were married yesterday in Atlanta. Canon David M. Chamberlain performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Cathedral.

title: The Nation In Summary; THE ADMINISTRATION DECIDES TO KEEP ITS COMRADES IN ARMS
description: Near the end of ''Major Barbara,'' Andrew Undershaft the munitions man is asked: ''What on earth is the true faith of the armorer?'' His answer is: ''To give arms to all men who offer an honest price for them, without repsect of person or principles...If you good people prefer preaching and shirking to buying my weapons and fighting the rascals, don't blame me. I can make cannons: I cannot make courage or convictions.''

title: The Nation In Summary; SENATE RESTRICTS ABORTION FUNDS
description: Even before Election Day, when Republicans were put in charge, the Senate had become increasingly receptive to restrictions on the right of women to obtain Federally financed abortions.

title: Patients and Humiliation
description: In his description of advantages offered by the Humiliation Relief Bureau, Russell Baker neglects to list the services that could be provided for patients in hospitals and physicians' offices (''Facing Humiliation,'' Sunday Observer, April 12). How wonderful it would be to hire a trained professional to explain the emergent nature of one's ailment to a receptionist who insists that ''Doctor's busy.'' How productively we might use the time we now spend sitting in hospital reception rooms or waiting near telephones for doctors to call. CAROL H. DEDOV, Philadelphia

title: No Headline
description: On LanguageBy William Safire Cut a Deal Kimble Mead

title: AN UNDERCURRENT OF HOPE APPEARS IN LEBANON TALKS
description: The fuse kept burning in Lebanon last week, but the focus of efforts to prevent a blowup seemed to widen from narrow military issues - Syrian SAM-6 missiles and Israeli overflights - to broader possibilities for repairing the shattered nation. Even as shelling in Beirut struck the United States Embassy compound, where President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, was staying, there were hints that diplomacy in an enlarged context might avert war between Syria and Israel.

title: David Rockefeller, in China, Says Peking Retains Open-Door Policy
description: David Rockefeller, chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, said today that China remained committed to an opendoor policy despite its economic cutbacks.

title: TRADITIONAL MENU IN GLITTERY SETTING
description: DARIEN DARIEN'S new restaurant, Twin Faces East, advertises itself as ''a restaurant plus.'' It took two visits to discover what that ''plus'' was - a huge ballroom in the back of the restaurant. It is a commentary on the building's good acoustics that we spent our first evening in the dining room nearest the bar without being aware of the disco-rock goings-on in the rear room that leads off the same bar. Well-modulated soft music is piped into each dining room, so that the sounds in the ballroom are insulated from diners. The name, Twin Faces East, comes from the fact that the owners are twin brothers, Dick and Bob Babian, and the restaurant is in the East.

title: Westchester Journal
description: IT was toward the end of a fund-raising dinner for Carl A. Vergari just over a week ago, and the District Attorney, who is running for re-election, paused to consider his response to the roasting he had just received.

title: TRIMMED ENVIRONMENTAL UNIT PLANS BUSINESS LINK
description: The weakened Council on Environmental Quality will play an active, if limited, role on policy issues and will be more accessible than in the past to the business community, according to A.Alan Hill, who has been picked by President Reagan to be its chairman.

title: The Nation In Summary; REVISIONS SOUGHT IN BRIBERY LAW
description: Bribes may be bad, but forbidding United States firms to make under-the-table payments overseas is unrealistic, the White House has concluded. Administration witnesses at a Senate hearing last week said substantial portions of the 1977 Foreign Corrupt Practices Act should be revised because they amount to an unreasonable imposition on American companies.

title: ITALIAN ELITE EMBROILED IN A SCANDAL
description: Italy's Justice Minister, Adolfo Sarti, resigned today following reports linking him to a powerful, secret Masonic lodge that has been implicated in a variety of criminal activities.

title: Lucy S. Patterson Bride Of Robert C. Stanley 3d
description: Lucy Sudler Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stuart Patterson 2d of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Crooks Stanley 3d, son of Mrs. Nancy Knothe Stanley of Delray Beach, Fla., and Robert Crooks Stanley Jr. of Red Bank, N.J. The Rev. Carl Dietrich Reimers performed the ceremony in the Miller Chapel at the Princeton Theological Seminary.

title: Patricia Gay, Writer, Wed
description: Patricia Gay, a magazine and film scriptwriter, was married yesterday to John Kluge, president of Metromedia Inc. Terence Cardinal Cooke performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Auxiliary Bishop Theodore E. McCarrick assisted. The bride, daughter of Edmund C. Rose and Mrs. Sylvia Maria Rose, both of London, has been married and divorced. Mr. Kluge has a daughter and a son by a previous marriage, which also ended in divorce.

title: RURAL TIME BOMB
description: LETTTERS FROM THE COUNTRY By Carol Bly. 184 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE New Jersey State Lottery reached two milestones in recent weeks: $1 billion in prizes to its customers and $2 billion in gross sales since it was instituted in 1970. Most of the prize money was awarded to the winners of the daily ''Pick-It'' game, which began in May 1975.

title: VIEW FROM THE MILL ON BASEBALL STRIKE
description: I WORK in the Basic Oxygen Furnace Department of Republic Steel in Warren, Ohio. As a steelworker and a baseball fan, I am of two minds about the impending strike by major league baseball players.

title: 600 MINI-INVENTORS SHOW OFF INGENUITY
description: year-old resident of Middletown, looked at the world around him and found it lacking. And so he invented the Toothbrush With Toothpaste.

title: 'AUNTS' IN BUSINESS OF HELPING
description: Packing a panda to Pamplona? Seeking a witness for your impromptu marriage? Few tasks are beyond the scope of Universal Aunts, a battalion of 18-to-80-year-olds whose slogan ''Anything for anyone at any time'' has propelled them, in many people's eyes, into the ranks of British institutions.

title:
TELEVISION;
THE CRUCIBLE OF BREAKING NEWS
description: Within the span of only a few weeks, television news was severely tested on two breaking stories of international significance: the attempted assassinations of President Ronald Reagan and Pope John Paul II. These were not news events in the manner of space shots or historic journeys or a royal marriage. Such events generally follow tight and tidy schedules. They can be followed and reported, for the most part, with the precision found in a scripted movie. The breaking news story is a decidedly messy affair, especially in the first hours. It takes time for the giant networks of electronic apparatus to gear up to full working strength. Then, the on-air correspondents are forced to juggle conflicting reports, rumors and speculations. The worst that can happen did when, during the Reagan story, all three networks were verifying an erroneous report that James S. Brady, the President's press secretary, had died. Stung by subsequent criticism, television news was noticeably more cautious in covering the shooting of the Pope.

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: Under Federal law, Memorial Day will be observed tomorrow. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; other rules in effect.

title: GREECE AND U.S. CALLED NEAR TO AN ACCORD ON BASES
description: Greek and American diplomats negotiating an accord on American bases and economic and military aid are approaching a compromise that may enable them to sign an agreement next month.

title: JACQUELINE HEYMAN TO BE WED JULY 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kerry Heyman of New York, Water Mill, L.I. and Miami have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jacqueline Kerry Heyman, to Stephen Clark Snowden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Snowden of Lexington, Ky.

title: Home Clinic; OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSE: LATEX OF OIL?
description: AT this time of year, most homeowners have a long list of chores to do around the outside of the house. For many, painting the exterior is probably at or near the top of that list. Although it normally does not come up every year, (painting usually is needed at four- to six-year intervals) it is one of the larger and most expensive maintenance chores for the average homeowner. So it is not surprising that a large percentage of the mail received here at this time of year concerns the selection of exterior paints.

title: Juantorena and Leonard In Coast Track Meet
description: Ten track stars from Cuba, including Alberto Juantorena, Silvio Leonard and Alejandro Casanas, all Olympic medalists, are expected to compete in the Brooks Invitational meet at the University of California on June 13.

title: NOW TO SEE IF CORPORATE IDEAS WORK FOR TRANSIT
description: There is probably no other municipal service in New York that provokes emotions so intense as the mass transit system. Managment and workers of the New York City Transit Authority have been criticized so often for the near collapse of the system that many of them believe, in the words of one well-connected transit official, ''It's better not to do anything than risk messing up.''

title: MAN SEIZED IN SHOOTING OF OFFICER
description: A 35-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with attempted murder in the shooting of an off-duty policeman Friday evening, the police said.

title: Politics
description: IT WAS a busy week for Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith of Jersey City. Not only did he have to continually squelch rumors that he was thinking of quitting the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor, but he reportedly had to prevent State Senator Walter N. Sheil from going over the wall.

title:
CAMERA;
AUTOMATIC FOCUSING: IS IT FOR EVERYONE?
AN EXPERIMENT IN CONTRAST
description: he ice chest was square and old-fashioned, fabricated from silvery aluminum in a time before everything was made of plastic, and beads of perspiration ran down its sides and dripped into the sand as we toted it among the dunes searching for a secluded spot for a picnic. It was early in the season and the beach was cool and quiet, with only the rhythmic crash of the waves breaking the silence.

title: QUEENS G.O.P, NAMES ESPOSITO ITS MAYORAL CANDIDATE
description: Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens Village was endorsed by the Queens Republican organization yesterday as its candidate for Mayor, and as a result emerged as Mayor Koch's principal challenger in the G.O.P. primary.

title: Judge Orders Legal Briefs In Dallas Integration Suit
description: After four weeks of testimony in a school integretion suit, a Federal judge yesterday told attorneys to submit additional legal briefs by June 29, indicating that a decision was at least a month away.

title: Astros 5, Giants 3
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Cesar Cedeno and Alan Ashby drove in two runs each and Bobby Sprowl drove in one to pace Houston. The Astros took an early lead in the first when Terry Puhl drew a leadoff walk, stole second, was sacrificed to third by Craig Reynolds and scored on Cedeno's sacrifice fly.

title: WILL TROOPERS FOLLOW O'NEILL'S LEADER?
description: For years the Connecticut state police force was almost sacrosanct. Commissioners, named to four-year terms, could be removed only ''for cause.'' They did not brook second-guessing, even by the governors who appointed them.

title: STAGE: 'FARMYARD' LOOKS AT ELEMENTAL HUMANITY
description: The people who inhabit Franz Xaver Kroetz's compulsively fascinating ''Farmyard'' (at the Theater for the New City) are inarticulate peasants who are unable to understand or explain their actions. Some of the events of their lives are grotesque to the point of seeming bestial; at times, the characters behave like dumb animals, and there are sounds of livestock in the background to remind us of the environment. There is a humanity here, but of the most elemental nature.

title: Connecticut Guide; Yale-Harvard Regatta
description: Because of increased interest in the annual Yale-Harvard Regatta, said to be the oldest event of its kind in the nation, weekend packages have been devised for the 117th competition, to be held on the Thames River in New London next Sunday afternoon.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Put Lift in Your Life; Get on Your Toes
description: Capezio Dance-Theater Shops represent a family known for dance footwear since 1887. They also carry men's, women's and children's dancing supplies and theatrical makeup. Deliveries permitting, there will be new leotard and shoe styles, fabrics and colors in the Stamford store in time to help celebrate, without the champagne, the move of the Westchester branch to a larger location at 420 Mamaroneck Avenue in White Plains on Wednesday.

title: ROTH'S COMPLAINT
description: ZUCKERMAN UNBOUND By Philip Roth. 225 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95.

title: DANCE: BALINESE TROUPE BRINGS COLOR AND MAGIC
description: Last Thursday night's performance by the Dancers and Musicians of Bali at the Asia Society's handsome new headquarters was both colorful and magical.

title: Deborah DeTurk Bride of Leonard Amato
description: At the Wilton (Conn.) Congregational Church yesterday, Deborah Suzanne DeTurk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. DeTurk of Wilton, was married to Leonard D. Amato, son of Emma Amato of Plainedge, L.I. The Rev. Zenek Bednar performed the ceremony.

title:
Antiques;
HUNTING GROUND FOR HOUSE MUSEUMS
description: GRANBY AMONG the crowds of collectors and the curious who spend their weekends visiting Connecticut's outdoor antiques markets often can be found curators of New England house-museums. More often than not they are searching for the odd piece in which the average buyer may have little interest - antique containers and utensils, the sometime rather homely furnishings that once were common to 18th-century households.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; Foundation Buys; Time for Geniuses
description: Twenty-one individuals, already gifted with proven talent in science, the arts or the humanities, last week became doubly gifted as the first winners in a unique program of awards of the John D. and Catherine MacArthur Foundation of Chicago. Ranging from $24,000 to $60,000 annually for five years, the awards are intended to give creative freedom to ''exceptionally talented individuals,'' in the hope, the foundation said, that they will produce ''discoveries or other significant contributions to society.''

title: HARVARD'S HASTY PUDDING CLUB FACES HARD TIMES
description: A century ago, young Harvard men with such surnames as Lowell and Cabot centered their social lives and dining schedules on the Hasty Pudding Club, the nation's oldest student society.

title: Mount Palomar
description: To the Editor:

title: Sophie M. S. Gorek Married To Thomas Widdell Wynne
description: Sophie Marie Simone Gorek, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edmond A. Gorek of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Widdell Wynne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald T. Wynne Jr. of Cleveland. The Rev. David Stewart Hoag performed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Drug Smuggling Shift Seen From Florida to Texas
description: Drug smugglers are increasingly shifting their operations to the Texas coast to escape an increase in Coast Guard patrols off Florida, a Government report said today.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC It may be a bit early for summertime music, but the time is obviously just right for a spring music festival, and three of them are getting under way in New York this week. The first is the New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' series in Avery Fisher Hall, beginning on Wednesday and running through June 9. While cynics might say that virtually every other Philharmonic concert celebrates the Romantic Era, at least these special programs will offer some offbeat music; on Friday night, for instance, James Galway will play rarities for flute and orchestra by Reinecke and Doppler.

title: PERFORMING ARTS USED AS AID TO LEARNING
description: ''I KNEW the streets backwards,'' Mark Keith was saying. ''I'd seen people fighting and I'd never seen anything else to go to. Then I found this.''

title: Politics; MORE THAN A CHANGE OF PLACE
description: ''TIP O'NEILL hasn't got the power that Stanley Fink has,'' said one of the Island's three new members of the House of Representatives, Representative Raymond J. McGrath of the Fourth District in southwestern Nassau County.

title: FOR THE CLASH, MUSIC IS PART OF THE MESSAGE
description: Debra Rae Cohen writes frequently about rock music. By DEBRA RAE COHEN

title: CONRAIL SAFETY PLAN BEGINS
description: WHITE PLAINS AREVISED training program for Conrail railroad tower operators - the employees who man the levers that control the movement of the trains - has been put into effect by railroad in the aftermath of the Dobbs Ferry collision last November that injured more than 100 people.

title: SUFFOLK DEBATES LILCO EVACUATION PLAN
description: SHOREHAM BEFORE the Shoreham nuclear power plant can begin operations, Suffolk County must prepare an emergency evacuation plan for the 130,000 people who live within 10 miles of the facility. However, both proponents and opponents of nuclear energy say such a plan is unnecessary - the proponents because it will never be used, the opponents because it will never work.

title: SINGER: A MATURE ABBEY LINCOLN
description: When Abbey Lincoln first came to prominence 20 years ago she had a vocal quality that was strikingly similar to Billie Holiday's, along with a fresh beauty that was much like that of the young Miss Holiday. Miss Lincoln, who will be at the Village Vanguard through today, has matured into a handsome and gracefully assured woman while, on some songs, her voice has taken on the grainy, almost grating sound that Miss Holiday had in the later stages of her career.

title: Claudia Antonelli, Harpist, Plays Pescetti and Glinka
description: An excellent young harpist from Italy, Claudia Antonelli, made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday evening. Miss Antonelli may have seemed frail and a little awkward on stage, but she played with strong-fingered aggressiveness and an energetic sense of momentum throughout.

title: IN ARGENTINA, IT TAKES 3 TO TANGO (INFLATION)
description: Before me is another article on inflation in my country. The reporter notes that in Buenos Aires: ''The daily newspaper costs 60 cents. A cup of coffee in an ordinary coffee shop costs $1. Rents for a two-bedroom apartment in areas equivalent to Manhattan's Upper East and West Sides begin at $2,000 a month.''

title: ANNANDALE, Va. - In May 1980, President Carter welcomed the Cuban ''boat people'' with open arms. But now, in May 1981, President Reagan's interagency Task Force on Immigration and Refugee Policy may recommend that boats carrying Haitians be intercepted in international waters. In the intervening year, the United States' desire to live up to its tradition of welcome and to honor a United Nations treaty to which it is a party has confronted a fear that this country has become vulnerable to repeated inundations by masses of deprived peoples.
description: Two fundamentally conflicting attitudes are at the heart of the immigration issue: the instinct to protect what we have achieved, and the equally strong impulse to preserve our heritage as history's most open and successful multi-cultural society.

title: THE COST OF CUTTING TRISTATE TIES
description: THE State of Connecticut is considering action that would end the state's 20-year cooperation with New York and New Jersey on shared urban problems. Connecticut's contribution of $140,000 to the Tristate Regional Planning Commission has been deleted from the state budget. The General Assembly now has before it a bill that would prevent state funding of Tristate from any source.

title: THEIR CAMOFLAGE DRAWS THE EYE
description: From time to time, designers get carried away with war clothes. Only in peacetime, of course. Uniforms aren't fashionable when you have to wear them.

title: BATTERED AND DIVIDED ARMY MIRRORS LEBANESE CIVIL CRISIS
description: a daily microcosm of the anarchy, aggression and sheer piggishness that have torn this land apart -is frequently interrupted by military vehicles, not surprisingly in a country that currently supports some 43 distinct armies.

title: Reagan Picks Nominee For Marines' No. 2 Post
description: President Reagan today nominated Lieut. Gen. Paul X. Kelley of the Marine Corps, head of Rapid Deployment Joint Task Force, to be assistant commandant and chief of staff, the No. 2 post in the corps.

title: The Region In Summary; LIFE AT THE BRIM RETURNS TO N.J.
description: Nobody went thirsty, but for eight months northern New Jersey residents lived with the strictest water-use curbs in the tristate area. However, heavy May rains brought a ''dramatic, astounding'' recovery in reservoir levels, officials said, and last week water restrictions were substantially relaxed in the 94 North Jersey communities that had been hardest hit by the drought.

title: City Council Schedules 6 Meetings This Week
description: The City Council and its committees have scheduled six meetings this week. They are: TUESDAY - City Council and Board of Estimate, joint hearing on citywide projects and allotment of revenue-sharing funds, auditorium, 1 Police Plaza, 10 A.M.

title: FIGHT ON BUDGET ENDS QUIETLY
description: HARTFORD IN some ways, the appearances were more important than the substance during the General Assembly's long struggle to put together a budget and tax package to keep the state government running in the fiscal year starting July 1.

title:
On the Isle;
SUMMER ACTIVITIES BEGINNING ON THE ISLE
description: READY or not, Long Islanders must welcome summer in this weekend. Memorial Day, after all, is the signal. And to celebrate the calendar, they can engage in some bouts of ethnic food-sampling and fair-going, watch the sheep being sheered at Old Bethpage Village, meander through the historic streets of Cold Spring Harbor or take their youngsters through a museum children's room to see how 19thcentury children lived and played. In other words, as the Island prepares to do its summer thing, the variety promises to be, well, varied, indeed.

title: UTILITY WORKING WITH CUSTOMERS TO CONSERVE
description: BERLIN IF you heat your home or water with electricity or natural gas from Northeast Utilities, the company wants to give you $100. Northeast and its subsidiaries, Connecticut Light and Power Company and Hartford Electric Light Company, want to hand out cash - along with information and encouragement - to qualifying customers as part of a new conservation program. While environmental and consumer critics say the company's program channels far too much money into new generating capacity and not enough into conservation, it is clear that Northeast is trying to develop a new relationship with its customers.

title:
Gardening;
VARIETY FOR THE HOME VEGETABLE GARDEN
description: IN recent years, there has been a significant increase in the number of home gardeners in the United States. Although the growth has tapered off somewhat since its peak in 1975, it has been estimated that as many as six million new gardening households cropped up last year, bringing the total to 46 percent of all households. Much of this increase has been in vegetable gardening.

title: POP: SISTER SLEDGE SINGS
description: Although Sister Sledge, a quartet from Philadelphia, is best known for its disco hits, ''He's the Greatest Dancer'' and ''We Are Family,'' its vocal abilities aren't limited to unison chanting. At Radio City Music Hall last Thursday, the four sisters sang in front of a full orchestra, demonstrating skill at part-singing and the potential to adopt a much more wide-ranging musical approach than the group's albums have indicated.

title: DON KING'S BUSINESS GOES ON
description: For several months, Don King had been privately telling friends he feared he would have to change his business address to a Federal prison.

title: MINORITIES ASSAIL SUFFOLK REDISTRICTING
description: AS the Suffolk County Legislature prepares to vote on Tuesday on a reapportionment plan that would affect the re-election of four incumbents in November, Hispanic and black leaders assailed the proposal as gerrymandering against minority representation.

title: INDIAN PT. REACTOR UNDERGOING FINAL START UP TESTS
description: After the longest shutdown in its eightyear history, Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant is undergoing final tests, and utility officials have expressed hope that service will be restored by the end of this month.

title: Abroad at Home; COTTON MATHER POLITICS
description: One of the important elements in Ronald Reagan's election was right-wing fervor on social and religious issues. The Moral Majority and other groups roused a lot of voters with their calls to end abortion, put prayer back in the schools and resist the women's movement as a threat to the family.

title: AN UNCOMMON DRAMATIST PREPARES HER NEW WORK
description: In her first successful play - ''Uncommon Women and Others,'' which was produced by the Phoenix Theater and later televised by PBS - Wendy Wasserstein presented a satiric portrait of life in a women's college at a time, scarcely more than a decade ago, when the curriculum for young ladies included instruction in the art of ''Gracious Living'' and the necessity of marrying well. The play - which was hailed by a number of critics for its pungent dialogue and wryly witty observations - focused on five young women struggling with the tensions of changing social and sexual mores as well as the traditional pressures that still exert a strong influence on their lives.

title: The World In Summary; MITTERRAND CLAIMS THE MIDDLE GROUND
description: Making every gesture count toward next month's parliamentary elections, President Francois Mitterrand moved into the Elysee Palace last week and reassured Frenchmen of his moderate intentions. ''I wish to convince, not to vanquish,'' he vowed.

title: VAN CLIBURN PIANO JURY SELECTS 12 SEMIFINALISTS
description: After two hours of deliberation, aided by a computer, the jury of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition last night selected 12 pianists to compete in the semifinals. They are:

title: Notes; AFRICAN TOURS THAT EMPHASIZE CULTURE
description: Four travel and study programs in Africa that emphasize meeting writers and artists and visiting institutions of learning as well as traditional sightseeing are being offered this summer by the American Forum for International Study, an organization founded in 1968 to encourage cultural exploration of Africa.

title: EX-CONGRESSMEN: NEW LIVES OF FUN AND PROFIT
description: Former Representative William H. Harsha of Ohio, who retired last year as ranking Republican on the Public Works and Transportation Committee, opened a Washington consulting firm that caters to airline companies, trucking firms and other transportation matters his committee handled. Former Representative Robert Duncan, an Oregon Democrat who lost his primary, was recruited to open a Washington office for a hometown law firm. Former Senator Gaylord Nelson, the Wisconsin Democrat defeated in his re-election bid, has signed on as executive director and chief lobbyist for the Wilderness Society, a Washington-based environmentalist group.

title: POP: JAMES TAYLOR IN HIGH SPIRITS
description: James Taylor was in high spirits when he opened an eight-night run on Broadway on Thursday night at the Savoy Theater. In fact, for a performer who has often been considered quiet and introspective, he was a positive live wire. He joked with the audience, he told stories about a pet pig, and he danced to the rhythms of his rock band. But anyone who has seen Mr. Taylor in the last few years knows that the singer and songwriter whose early hits set the tone for much of the 1970's most placid-sounding soft rock has been rocking harder and, apparently, enjoying it more. His performance was a continuation and a celebration of the process.

title: THE SPIRIT IN WORDS
description: STORYTELLER By Leslie Marmon Silko. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York: Seaver Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Bonnie Raymond and Andrew Nathan to Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Fisher of New York and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Fisher's daughter, Bonnie Lynn Raymond, to Andrew Jonathan Nathan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Nathan of North Woodmere, L.I.

title: SINGING THE SEMICONDUCTOR BLUES
description: A S the Government ponders legislation designed to revitalize American industry, it is being hit with demands from a somewhat unexpected quarter - the United States semiconductor industry.

title: HAIL TO A HORNE OF PLENTY
description: One of the 6,000 things I like about Lena Horne is that she didn't rush her new entertainment onto Broadway in time to qualify for a Tony nomination. The deadline for Tony nominations came along just before mid-month, and, as you may remember, half a dozen enterprises began an unseemly push and shove to see which could get themselves booked into theaters, reviewed in the next day's papers, and otherwise fully certified before midnight struck and this season's fancy-dress ball was declared over.

title: Elisabeth Luce Is Bride on L. I.
description: Elisabeth Root Luce and John J. Hagenbuch were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony.

title: TURKS ASSAIL ALLIES IN POPE'S SHOOTING
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit urged foreign security forces today, particularly those of West Germany, to cooperate with Turkey in investigating the European connections of Mehmet Ali Agca, who is accused of shooting Pope John Paul II.

title: Royals Beat Twins, Stop Shutout Streak
description: Willie Wilson lined a two-out single to left field in the bottom of the 15th inning to score Dan Garcia from third base and give the Kansas City Royals a 1-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: LEARNING TO BE A PREPPY AT 37
description: WHEN you are returning to school at the age of 37, ''The Official Preppy Handbook'' is no help at all. Although I live in preppy-approved Rye and hobnob with friends who love pink and green, I had hoped that this current best seller would offer me some practical advice on fitting into campus life. A late bloomer, I was disappointed to find that there was no ''Dear Muffy'' column that I could write to for help.

title: 45,000 OWNERS ACCEPT DEAL ON RATES
description: About 4,500 home owners across the country have taken advantage of a program that the Federal National Mortgage Association initiated in March to provide mortgage financing at below-market interest rates.

title: Shepherd Is Easy Winner In Mello Yello 300 Miler
description: Morgan Shepherd, the reigning Late Model Sportsman champion, raced to an easy victory today in the Mello Yello 300 before a crowd of 64,000 at Charlotte Motor Speedway.

title: From Kemp-Roth to 'Let's Make a Deal'
description: Surprise. For months they denied they would ever utter the words, but last week Administration officials conceded that maybe there's nothing sacred about Kemp-Roth after all. And some leaders of the Democratic House allowed that perhaps their one-year-or-nothing stance had a little give in it.

title: Jane Schurman Is Married to John Womer
description: Jane D. Schurman and John Clark Womer were married yesterday in the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Christopher J. Emerson performed the ceremony.

title: BLACKS HAVE YET TO GAIN CITY OFFICE
description: For civil rights advocates, it has not been the best of times. Attorney General William French Smith's declaration last week that the Justice Department would no longer vigorously pursue busing as a remedy for school segregation and his rejection of quotas to correct job discrimination, was, in a way, just another confirmation for many that while the gains of the past quarter century may not be reversed, progress will, at the least, be slowed.

title: HEAT OVER LEFEVER'S NOMINATION BRINGS SOME SENATORS TO A BOIL
description: No one thought it would be easy. But the confirmation hearings last week of Ernest W. Lefever, Assistant Secretary of State-designate for Human Rights, proved far tougher than even the most pessimistic Administration officials had predicted.

title: Panel Seeks Required Bylines
description: A bill requiring bylines for all newspaper articles and editorials has received the backing of the Massachusetts Legislature's Judiciary Committee. Although enactment appeared doubtful, no dissenters were listed on the committee report that was released Thursday.

title: Bestiary
description: To the Business Editor: Concerning the wittily informative piece, ''A Zoo in Every Shirt Drawer'' (May 10), with its bestiary of contemporary sport shirts, the description of the great French tennis champion, Rene Lacoste, needs some clarification.

title: WANTED: NEW ENGINEERS
description: As the college commencements play out the spring season, fresh evidence of what a degree is worth on today's job market is coming out. As in past years, new graduates with degrees in technical fields get more pay than those who majored in the liberal arts.

title: Mugabe Begins Visit to Pakistan
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe arrived today for a four-day visit. The African leader met with President Zia ul-Haq soon after his arrival, and the first round of talks was said to have focused on the Middle East and other problems of the African-Asian region.

title: GROWING UP IN AMES
description: BLOOMING A Small-Town Girlhood. By Susan Allen Toth. 211 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $10.95.

title: Community Homes For the Retarded
description: Unfortunately, the rosy picture painted of the community residence program for the mentally retarded (''When the Retarded Live as a Family,'' May 3) is far from the truth. The article reflects the ideal hostel, but in practice the Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities (O.M.R.D.D.) has dramatically departed from the original model.

title: AN ABLE DIRECTOR OF C.I.A. OPERATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIWAR COALITION PLANS PROTESTS ON DIVERSE INTERESTS
description: A summer of demonstrations is being planned by a coalition of organizations dedicated to such diverse interests as preventing a resumption of the draft, promoting the rights of male and female homosexuals, shutting down nuclear power plants and effecting racial and sexual equality.

title: PHYSICIST AWARDED 'GENIUS' PRIZE FINDS REALITY IN INVISIBLE WORLD
description: Most people would presumably be elated if someone dropped $128,000 into their laps. Dr. Stephen Wolfram is politely appreciative of the fact that he was so favored, but beyond that he tends to regard the news of the windfall as an intrusion on his consuming preoccupation: trying to figure out how the universe works.

title: OPEC MINISTERS GATHER IN GENEVA FOR KEY MEETING
description: Oil ministers began arriving here today for one of the most critical meetings of the Organizations of Petroleum Exporting Countries since the cartel began setting prices nearly eight years ago.

title: One Plus One Offers String Chamber Rarities
description: One Plus One is the name of the duo that Elisabeth Perry and Alexander Balanescu have formed to play music for two violins or for violin and viola. The name may be dreary, but the performances were not.

title: KATHLEEN HOWLAND FIANCEE
description: Kathleen Ann Howland and John I. Leahy will be married June 13 in the Roman Catholic Church Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Bernardsville, N.J. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Howland's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Howland of Beminster, N.J. Mr. Leahy is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Leahy of Timonium, Md.

title: 2 HELD FOR PLOT IN '76 BLAST AT MERRILL LYNCH BUILDING
description: Two Texans have been arrested on charges of sending corporations and individuals more than 130 extortion letters, several of which contained bombs, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. One of the bombs they allegedly mailed exploded, injuring four people in a Merrill Lynch mailroom in New York City in 1976.

title:
Dining Out;
WHEN THE SITE CAN BE A PROBLEM
description: FRANK LaBATE opened El Meson de Espana two years ago with three strikes against him. The site was the biggest problem because diners looking for a Spanish or Portuguese restaurant usually head for Newark's Ironbound section rather than North Newark.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: It was a scene right out of the 1960's: the commencement speaker delivering his speech while much of his audience wore white arm bands and about 50 students turned their backs during his address. But this was not the 1960's; it was earlier this month at American University. And the protest was not against one of the architects of the Vietnam War but against George Gilder, author of the best-selling ''Wealth and Poverty,'' a blueprint for ''supply-side'' economics.

title: SCULPTORS WHO TRIUMPH IN BRONZE
description: Two of the most impressive SoHo exhibitions to be seen in New York just now are exhibitions of new sculpture - Bryan Hunt's at the Blum Helman Gallery, 20 West 57th Street (through June 6), and William Crozier's at Xavier Fourcade, Inc., 36 East 75th Street (through June 20). These are artists very different from each other in style, sensibility and background. For one thing, Mr. Hunt's sculpture is more or less abstract, whereas Mr. Crozier's is emphatically - one might even say passionately - representational. Yet despite their divergent loyalties, these exhibitions do, nonetheless, have something interesting in common. Both may be said to take a very traditional view of the medium they employ, and the medium itself - cast bronze - has long been regarded as embodying the very essence of sculptural tradition.

title: Article 129449 -- No Title
description: A Federal program created seven years ago, in part to help preserve deteriorating but occupied big city apartment buildings by insuring money for their rehabilitation, is finally scheduled to gets its first test. It will come in two pilot projects in New York City, one in Brooklyn's Flatbush section and the other in the northwest Bronx that includes a portion of the South Bronx along the Grand Concourse.

title: NEW YORK JUDGE SEEKS ONE SET OF PROCEDURES FOR STATE'S CITY COURTS
description: New York State's chief administrative judge, Herbert B. Evans, says he will recommend unified procedures for the state's 64 City Courts, based on the results of a two-year study in the Ninth Judicial District of Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange and Dutchess Counties.

title: BALLET: MIDDLE GROUND OF 'SCOTCH SYMPHONY'
description: Friday night's all-Balanchine program with the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater began with the recently revived Mendelssohn ''Scotch Symphony,'' one of the company's occasional pieces that prove so enduring so often.

title: Post Stays Undefeated In Softball Title Tourney
description: C.W. Post of Long Island remained unbeaten in the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division II softball championship with two victories over California schools yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: My 12-year-old son, Brandon, is in his second year of the National Dance Institute program at school, and is also in Jacques d'Amboise's ''SWAT team.'' At every opportunity, Brandon goes into his room to listen and choreograph dance routines to all kinds of music (jazz, ballet, rock or disco).

title: Herzog's Cards Are Extremists
description: Whitey Herzog, who traded 23 players in one week last winter, conceded today that he was both the manager and general manager of baseball's team of extremes, the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: an encampment that he finds mean-spirited, narrow-minded, divisive, immature and disruptive. A well-researched, well-written, gossipy book that, perhaps of necessity, is not definitive.

title: GLOVES COME OFF IN STRUGGLE WITH UNESCO
description: After a period of relatively polite diplomacy, the battle for control of the worldwide flow of information heated up last week. Private news organizations and Western governments, which equivocated for a decade, went on the attack against Soviet bloc and third world demands for a ''new world information order.'' They said it would legitimize state control of the news and empower the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to regulate the flow of information. As Rosemary Righter, a British expert, said last week, ''The false truce in the long campaign for international regulation of the press is over.''

title: The World In Summary; KENNAN: ARE WE NUCLEAR LEMMINGS?
description: Actually getting rid of nuclear weapons has rarely, if ever, been on the table at United States-Soviet arms control negotiations, as critics from all points of the ideological compass have noted. Underlining the point last week, George F. Kennan, author of the post-World War II policy of ''containing'' Soviet expansionism and Ambassador to Moscow (1952-53), called for ''an immediate across-theboard reduction by 50 percent'' of the nuclear arsenals held by the superpowers.

title: 6 Rebels Are Sentenced to Death For Bombings in Angolan Enclave
description: Six members of a guerrilla organization seeking independence for the oil-producing enclave of Cabinda have been sentenced to death by an Angolan court, the official Angolan press agency said today.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: I read Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past'' for the first time while I was in the Army. Detached from duty while waiting to go to a special training school, I would disappear every morning after reveille and read in the library at Camp Edwards, Mass., until 10 P.M. With time out only for lunch and supper, it took me two weeks to go through its more than 3,000 pages. The world of Proust's novel and life on an Army post would seem to be at antithetical poles of civilization, and that was why I chose him.

title: STADLER, LOSING 3-SHOT MARGIN, IS TIED FOR LEAD BY ARCHER, KITE
description: Double bogeys on the 14th and 15th holes cost Craig Stadler his three-stroke advantage today, putting him in a tie for the lead with George Archer and Tom Kite after three rounds of the $300,000 Memorial golf tournament.

title: Art; SCULPTURE THAT HAS A VERY DIFFERENT LOOK
description: ROSLYN A PROFUSION of art is being produced these days, much of it technically adept and esthetically competent. Unfortunately, it does not go beyond that. It does not possess that special mark of originality or that touch of imagination and individual flair that sets it apart as a distinctive experience. What it has in know-how and craftsmanship, it lacks in profundity.

title: Broncos' Pick Defies Scouts With Agility
description: Pro football's spring-weekend minicamps for rookies are designed to introduce to the coaches the players of whom the personnel department thought highly enough to draft.

title: OF ITME OF TALENT: THE GROWTH OF BURT LANCASTER
description: Good actors are at the mercy of so many forces over which they have no control that it takes a while to get the full measure of them, especially those who, unlike Tracy or Cagney or Fonda, do not immediately display particular, idiosyncratic quality. However, because of the nature of films, which do not necessarily require that an actor be good to be successful, a film actor, including the overnight star, has time to learn, to grow into the role that was made originally his by the cut of a jaw or the reflection of a personality seen only by the camera.

title: Art Sampler
description: PHOTOGRAPHS of landscapes and buildings have their own beauties, but they rarely have the compassionate warmth that photographs of people have.

title: HONORING THOSE WHO MAKE THIS DAY A MEMORABLE ONE
description: I HAVE stood among thousands and viewed spectacular sights parading on Fifth Avenue. I have witnessed wonders no city except New York could host. But Memorial Day is a small-town day. It is a day for families and friends and quiet feelings that would be lost in the tumult along the Queen of Avenues. On Memorial Day, it is the small town that wears the crown. On this day, she is the spirit, the sparkle, the soul.

title: Reagan Starts Over; On Social Security
description: ''There's nobody set in concrete or wedded to any particular part of that package,'' Social Security Commissioner John Svahn said soothingly of the Administration's proposals to cut benefits in the nation's old-age pension program. The Senate was not soothed.

title: AN EW SUPPLY OF BALLET CLASSICS
description: One man's classic may be another man's potboiler. Is every 19thcentury ballet that is revived today - or its excerpt - to be considered a classic? In popular ballet parlance, the classics are defined as the great 19th-century ballets, usually full-evening length, that have survived in current repertories. This category would include ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' ''Swan Lake,'' ''Giselle,'' ''The Nutcracker,'' ''Coppelia,'' and ''La Sylphide.'' The Russians would add at least ''Don Quixote,'' ''Le Corsaire,'' ''La Bayadere,'' ''Raymonda,'' and one-act excerpts from ballets such as ''Paquita.''

title: CARTER BUDGET CASTS A LONG SHADOW
description: It began as Jimmy Carter's campaign budget, was revised and delayed in the interests of Congressional selfpreservation and now it bears the imprint of Ronald Reagan. It happened last week, when the lawmakers finally adopted a ''final'' $661.3 billion budget for the current fiscal year, which began seven months ago. Once tenuously balanced, the budget now has a $58 billion deficit; experts predict that before the year is out the spending figure and deficit will climb by at least $5 billion more.

title: PUTTING MORE 'BACKBONE' INTO MEASURING COST EFFECTIVENESS
description: A few days ago, the Office of Management and Budget told the Food and Drug Administration to condense 610 proposed regulations on the safe use of medical devices into a single ''generic'' set of principles, pared down a new Internal Revenue Service reporting form for certain trusts and disapproved a Fish and Wildlife Service proposal to permit only steel buckshot, not lead, in proposed nontoxic waterfowl zones. All this is evidence of the Administration's drive to shrink Government regulation, managed by the Office of Management and Budget and led by James C. Miller 3d, an assistant budget director and executive director of the Presidential Task Force for Regulatory Relief. He discussed the deregulation campaign with Edward Cowan, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times. Excerpts from the interview follow.

title: FARE INCREASE FOR L.I.R.R. CALLED 'INEVITABLE'
description: AS the Long Island Rail Road wrestles with the problem of getting its cars' air-conditioning working properly for summer weather, political leaders and transit officials agree that a fare increase this summer or fall is ''inevitable.''

title: Deborah Boxer Is Bride Of David M. R. Minchin
description: The marriage of Deborah Brand Boxer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Boxer of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., to David Michael Richard Minchin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry R. Minchin of Yarmouth, Isle of Wight, England, took place yesterday. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title:
Food;
WHERE CHEER IS A PART OF THE RECIPE
description: MASSAPEQUA ''THIS sure beats sitting in front of the boob tube on Saturday night,'' said Bob Ruchman as he attempted to slice some zucchini - a task he hadn't tried since his Army days, 20 years ago. As he hacked away at the vegetables, seven other men busily grated cheese, minced garlic, marinated skewers of meat, separated eggs and melted chocolate for the dinner they were preparing for their wives on a recent Saturday night at Kitchen Time, in a one-story, white brick building here.

title: Record College Gift
description: What happens when a small, quiet liberal-arts college in the farmlands of northwestern Iowa gets the largest per capita gift in the history of American philanthropy? The recipient, Buena Vista College in Storm Lake, got $18 million in May 1980, equal to $13,846 for each of the 950 full-time and 350 part-time students. The donor, who requested anonymity, stipulated that the college raise $9 million on its own over six years as a condition of the donation.

title: INVENTOR STILL BUSY AT AGE 90
description: CRANBURY LOUIS LIONEL SCHACHT has been using both his head and his brash self-confidence to solve problems since he and the century were young. And at the age of 90, he shows few signs of slowing down.

title: DISCLOSE DETAILS OF MEDICAL CARE
description: Doctors treating Pope John Paul II said today that he was out of danger and should recover fully from his gunshot wounds within 60 days.

title: Sicily
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDENER FINDS A 'BETTER WAY'
description: OLD FIELD ''I THOUGHT to myself there had to be a better way,'' was how Mel Bartholomew put it. He was talking about a solution to the problems and frustrations of some 100 gardeners who, under his tutelage, planted crops in a community garden three summers ago at the Setauket-Smithtown Environmental Center.

title: JANET GUTHRIE'S FRUSTRATING SEARCH FOR ANOTHER INDY RIDE
description: FOUR years ago, I became the first woman to compete in the Indianapolis 500. It was the last race sent off by Tony Hulman, the track's longtime owner who died that winter. Although I was in the race, Hulman had threatened to go ahead and use the historic words, ''Gentlemen start your engines.'' He said it was the mechanics who actually started the engines. But Kay Bignotti, wife of the master mechanic George Bignotti, and a USAC mechanic in her own right, volunteered to start my engine.

title: BORIS SAGAL, 58, MOVIE DIRECTOR, DIES AFTER A HELICOPTER ACCIDENT
description: Boris Sagal, a film director whose most recent movie credits included the ABC television miniseries ''Masada,'' died Friday at a hospital in Portland, Ore., of injuries he suffered five hours earlier after being struck by a helicopter blade. Mr. Sagal was 58 years old.

title: ECONOMY IS KEY FOR BOTH SIDES IN SALVADOR CONFLICT
description: Political and military developments in El Salvador have reached a shaky equilibrium, but a plunging economy threatens to sunder even that relative stability.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEW TRANSIT TRACK FORSEEN
description: NEWARK AFEDERAL Railroad Administration study of NJ Transit's Seashore Division, formerly the Pennsylvania-Reading Seashore Lines, indicates that the old railroad, after substantial capital improvements, should see boom days again.

title: Reforming Nassau's Insurance Practices
description: The article ''Controversy on Insurance Leads to Cuts in Nassau Fees'' (May 3) points to the fact that Nassau's insurance with outside agencies has shrunk considerably since the mid-1970's, when the fee-splitting practice was revealed by the State Investigations Commission. Although it is a fact that premiums have been reduced considerably, this relates more to the general trend of selfinsurance for municipalities, rather than to any political reawakening by the Purcell administration.

description: A van containing costumes and props belonging to a visiting Philippine dance company was stolen in Elmhurst, Queens, Friday night.

title: 3-2 LOSS TO DIPLOMATS IS COSMOS' 2D IN ROW
description: The Washington Diplomats scored three goals early in the game and held on for a 3-2 victory tonight over the Cosmos at RFK Stadium.

title: Karen Van Name Emery Bride of Stephen Lynch
description: Karen Van Name Emery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Rathbone Emery of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Henry Lynch, son of Mrs. Henry Williams Lynch of Centreville, Mass., and the late Mr. Lynch. The Rev. Dr. Gerald S. Mills performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J. He was assisted by the Rev. Stephen F. Duffy, a Roman Catholic priest of the Christian Brothers Academy in Lincroft, N.J.

description: The French franc is sliding. Money is leaving the country. Last week, the new Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, announced a series of controls to stop that.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Senate, seconding the House, has put further restrictions on Federal funding for abortions for the poor. Medicaid payments for ending pregnancies resulting from rape or incest were struck down; now only those poor whose lives are at stake are eligible.

title: Topics; NOT FOR CHILDREN ONLY; Instructive Shrinkage
description: Once dubbed the Livingston Hilton because of its capacious hospitality to bureaucrats, the headquarters of New York's Board of Education has been sensibly shrunk to boarding house size.

description: WHEN Steven Mitchell Sack of Oceanside was a small boy, he often took to the road with his father, Bernard, who was a commission salesman in the women's apparel industry.

title: REALTY BOARD GIVES NEW IDEAS ON POLICY
description: The Real Estate Board of New York has issued a series of recommendations to alleviate pressures on New York City's job base from a dual housing and commercial space crisis.

description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker The Ages of Man Patrick McDonnell

description: BASIN AND RANGE, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A master journalist studies the geology of the North American continent in the company of scientists.

description: Northeastern's varsity heavyweight crew took its fourth consecutive Burk Cup today, completing the 2,000-meter course on the Charles River in 5 minutes 54 seconds to beat Pennsylvania.

Mitchell. The Rev. R. Craig Burlington performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: GAME WARDEN WINS HER POLICE CREDENTIALS
description: LAKEWOOD NO ONE gave Jo Ann Frier any special treatment during her 10 weeks at the Ocean County Police Academy here, and that is just the way she wanted it. She took every course, squeezed through every push-up and shot at every target that the 30 other students - all but one of them men - had to do.

title: MONEY AND JOBS FOR SOUTH JERSEY
description: THOUSANDS of new jobs and millions of payroll dollars could be pumped into New Jersey's economy by the development of a major foodprocessing and distribution center in South Jersey.
