description: President Reagan and his senior national security advisers, concerned about Soviet and Cuban inroads in the Caribbean and Central America, are considering a long-term approach for providing major economic, political and military assistance to countries there, Administration officials said today.

title: VIEWING THE VISUAL ARTS
description: YOU CAN'T KEEP A GOOD WOMAN DOWN By Alice Walker. 167 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.95.

title: CREATING A DYNASTY IN THE PHILIPINES
description: use this Henry Kamm is The New York Times's chief Asian diplomatic correspondent. By Henry Kamm arxists would say that the ''objective conditions'' for revolution exist in abundance in the Philippines. The country's leader - who began his first term 16 years ago under a constitutional limitation of two four-year mandates -and his relatives and friends flaunt their great wealth while the gap between them and the vast majority of the impoverished grows. Many bishops, priests and nuns in this profoundly priests and nuns in this profoundly Roman Catholic nation of 47 million people denounce the regime and are sympathetic to its opponents; the bulk of the politically aware elite is openly disaffected, and scattered groups of insurgents have tied down much of the armed forces in prolonged combat.

title: Westchester Guide; HOLIDAY IN PIERMONT
description: Piermont will celebrate an old-fashioned Memorial Day tomorrow. The parade will start at 10 A.M. in front of St. John's Church, wind down Piermont Avenue and disperse in Kane Park, where a brief service will be held at 11 A.M.

title: Scotland Defeats England On a Penalty Kick, 1 to 0
description: John Robertson scored a penalty goal to give Scotland a 1-0 victory over England today in a British championship soccer match.

title: SENATOR ASSAILS CAREY'S PLAN FOR APPOINTING JUDGES
description: Governor Carey's proposal to expand his powers to appoint judges was attacked this week by a Republican State Senator who said that all but two of Mr. Carey's new judicial appointees to date were Democrats.

title: THE SOUND OF SUMMER IS MUSIC, MUSIC, MUSIC
description: In the summer of 1927 the late Robert A. Simon, who was the first music critic of The New Yorker, wrote an article on New York summer music for The New York Times. In those days things seemed blessedly simple. All the big musical organizations shut their doors. The musicians fended for themselves or played in rural festivals. Rich people moved out to Long Island or to Newport. Music critics toured the European summer festivals or retired to the country for monthslong summer vacations.

title: STUDY ON WATERWAY PLEASES BOTH SIDES
description: Both sides in a Congressional battle over the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway in Alabama have taken heart from a General Accounting Office report on the huge project of locks and dams.

title: The Turtle Collector
description: Marilyn Bethany might have mentioned the collectors who acquired their collections through gifts from friends (''Stalking the Wild Collector,'' Home Design, April 26.) I am the owner of pet turtles, and people frequently send me gifts, using the turtles as inspiration. I have turtle planters, turtle needlepoint, a turtle ceramic garden seat, turtle candlesticks, a gold turtle charm, turtle rings, a turtle belt buckle, turtle salt and pepper shakers, an Indian bead turtle, a clock in a turtle, a pair of erotic turtles and a turtleneck sweater with turtles on it. ANN MITCHELL, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: Bouvier Is Best in Show In Jersey 2d Year in Row
description: A 100-pound Bouvier des Flandres, Ch. Beaucrest Ruffian, who was best in show at the Monmouth County Kennel Club fixture last year, was named again today, lifting his total of major awards to 21.

title: U.S. Ties Shake; Suzuki Government
description: ''Alliance'' is too strong a word for some Japanese to describe their country's relationship with the United States, Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki has discovered - as have Reagan Administration strategists seeking a big increase in Japan's military strength. Mr. Suzuki's promise in Washington this month to beef up defense, several mishaps by the United States Navy in Japanese waters and disclosures that American ships carrying nuclear weapons have docked in Japan all contributed to a grave crisis for the Suzuki Government and a wave of anti-American feeling.

title: RIGHTISTS SEIZE BANK AND HOLD CAPTIVES IN BARCELONA RAID
description: About 25 heavily armed men seized the Barcelona headquarters of a major bank yesterday, took more than 200 people hostage, and demanded the release of four officers imprisoned for their involvement in an unsuccessful military coup three months ago.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE GREEN FLAG IS POISED FOR LYME ROCK ROAD RACES
description: SALISBURY IN the spring, some people's fancies turn to racing cars, a fact clearly demonstrated each fourth Monday in May in the usually quiet northwestern Connecticut village of Lyme Rock. Close to 25,000 fans are expected at Lyme Rock Park tomorrow to watch the races on a 1.53-mile course.

title: THREE ROOKIES AT INDY CARRY FAMILIAR NAMES
description: INDIANAPOLIS TWENTY years ago, the three boys were much too young to understand what happens each May at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Scott Brayton was 2 years old in May 1961, when the Indianapolis 500 celebrated its golden anniversary, and Geoff Brabham and Tony Lee Bettenhausen both were 9. Their fathers were race drivers. Their families were racing families. For as long as they can remember, there was never any other way of life.

title: HIGH-RISE COMPLEX PLANNED ON W. 96TH
description: A 30-story luxury apartment complex has been proposed for a blockfront on the Upper West Side where a fenced-in community garden now grows.

title: The Nation In Summary; TOP TEAMSTER IS INDICTED, FOR A START
description: ''The Government hasn't proved anything on me,'' Roy L. Williams boasted shortly before he was named to fill the term of the late Frank E. Fitzsimmons as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Maybe so, but that hasn't stopped the Justice Department from trying.

title: NEW MIX-UP CENTERS ON RYE AND CHURCH LAND
description: THE question of what will become of the 23-acre United Methodist Church property on the Long Island Sound in Rye, which appeared on its way to resolution, is caught up in a new round of confusion.

title: The Region In Summary; FATAL BOMBING BRINGS ECHOES OF THE F.A.L.N.
description: Terrorism in the name of Puerto Rican independence was thought to have been dealt a crippling blow when 10 alleged members of the F.A.L.N. were sentenced to long prison terms in Chicago last year. But the bombing at New York's Kennedy International Airport that killed a man last weekend and the subsequent discovery of five similar bombs at the airport and in the city seemed to confirm that a new and no less violent group had taken up the cause.

title: Rahal, Point Leader, Loses Ride
description: The Indianapolis 500 isn't the only major motor sports event this weekend. The Coca-Cola 400, the sixth round in America's most important road racing series, the Camel G.T., is being held tomorrow at Lime Rock Park in Connecticut. And it appears that the leader in season's point standing, Bobby Rahal, won't have a car to drive.

description: The following is the district-by-district breakdown of state public school aid provided by the 1981-82 budget enacted by the New York State Legislature earlier this month:

title: AMTRAK PINS HOPES ON NEW ENTERPRISES
description: Amtrak, whose Federal subsidy seems certain to fall more than $100 million short of what the system says it needs to maintain its national rail network next year, is considering branching into other fields to raise enough money to stay afloat.

title: SHARING NEW FREEDOM
description: THE visiting American poet, in his capacity as an item of cultural exchange, is put up in Poznan's official tourist hotel. In the lobby, members of the semi-legal Rural Solidarity are meeting in small workshop-sized groups. Many of them look the way farmers are expected to look: big, determined-seeming men of various ages in bulky dress-up clothes, and wearing green ''Solidarnosc'' pins on their lapels. A fair number of women also attend. There is something odd and unfamiliar about the intensity of these committee meetings; there don't seem to be any glazed expressions, smirks, finger twiddling. Nobody is staring at the ceiling or at his shoes. People are talking with a concentration that confirms a sense one gets from the literary people in Warsaw and Krakow, or from the way people date time as ''before August'' or ''since August'': These beefy, passionately debating farmers are sharing the heady atmosphere of successful revolt and new freedom. However brief it may turn out to be, and however complex its causes and meanings, this new freedom is also shared by the poets, translators, editors, screenwriters I meet. And it began, amazingly enough, with a proletarian uprising in the ship-yards of Gdansk in August.

title: David Lewis Dead at 71; Key Socialist in Canada
description: David Lewis, former leader of Canada's New Democratic Party and one of the country's most prominent and respected socialists, died today of leukemia in the Ottawa Civic Hospital.

title: Pecci, Clerc Reach Italian Tennis Final
description: Victor Pecci of Paraguay upset top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 7-6, 6-4, 7-6, today and reached the final of the $200,000 Italian open tennis championships. The grueling claycourt match lasted three and one-half hours.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Del Parkinson of Idaho Presents a Piano Program
description: Negotiating most of the difficulties of such works as Lizst's ''Dante'' Sonata, Stravinsky's ''Trois Mouvements de Petrouchka'' and Rachmaninoff's second Sonata, as Del Parkinson did in his debut Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, is no small accomplishment. The Idaho pianist, with advanced degrees from Indiana University and Juilliard, relished the physical expanse of the works, along with their demanding climaxes.

title: Brooklyn Man, 47, Shot At I N D Subway Station
description: A 47-year-old Brooklyn man was shot in the head and critically wounded early yesterday at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas after he stopped to help another man down to a subway station, the transit police said.

title: U.S. HOUSING SERVICE FOR ELDERLY VIEWED AS IN PERIL UNDER REAGAN
description: A program to provide meals and other assistance to keep older people out of hospitals and nursing homes is threatened by the Reagan Administration's proposed budget cuts, according to members of the House Select Committee on Aging.

title: Bossy's Father Dies
description: Borden Bossy, 60-year-old father of Mike Bossy, the right wing of the Stanley Cup champion New York Islanders, died today of a heart attack suffered while at the wheel of his car.

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN FARE WITH EMPHASIZED DECOR
description: COMPARED with some honeymoon palaces in the Poconos or catering establishments on the Island, La Romantica in Copiague is almost subdued. Still, it does not let the romantic scene go to waste.

title: SINGLE AT MIDLIFE
description: Andree Brooks is a housing columnist for the Connecticut section of The New York Times. By Andree Brooks In a white, Colonial-style house in prosperous New Canaan, Conn., half-hidden behind tall trees at the far end of a quiet cul-de-sac, lives Vicky Papson, a dark-haired, jovial woman in her late 30's. Mrs. Papson, once married to a pediatrician, is the only divorced woman on her block - a solo passenger in a suburban society conceived and built for the tandem ride.

title: Washington Eight Takes Women's Collegiate Title
description: Washington captured the national women's collegiate rowing title today, holding off strong challenges by Boston University and Yale.

title: DEATH, THE INVISIBLE PASSENGER, GOT OUT JUST IN TIME
description: IT WAS 13 degrees that January day. Snow had fallen the night before, covering the icy roads and sidewalks. Nothing had melted in the bitter cold.

title: Hempstead Supported As Site of Arts Center
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; CONNECTICUT GETS A NEW BUDGET-QUIETLY
description: Although it was three months in the making, Connecticut's $2.98 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning in July crossed Gov. William A. O'Neill's desk last week without much fanfare and, apparently, without many fans. ''It was one of those signings,'' said one legislator, ''where nobody wants to keep the pens.''

title: COLORADO TOWN LOOKS TO BETTER DAYS, WITH A GERMAN BUS FACTORY
description: What with the dry summers and the grasshopper infestation getting worse each year and all the young people leaving town to look for jobs in Denver or Colorado Springs, times have not been easy here.

title: WHITE HOUSE LEARNING THE LIMITS OF PRESIDENT'S MANDATE
description: For the first time since taking office, President Reagan and his main advisers have suffered a painful lesson in the political limits of the President's popularity and his mandate.

title: MISS KHALFOUNI IN BALLET THEATER 'GISELLE'
description: Dominique Khalfouni was a leading young ballerina of the Paris Opera Ballet, a special favorite with youthful audiences, when she resigned last year to join Roland Petit's Ballet National de Marseilles.

title: CHINESE-AMERICAN, JAILED BY PEKING, STAYS AFTER RELEASE
description: ''Are you crazy?'' shouted the chief of China's largest concentration camp to the American professor of fluid mechanics, a former Marine Corps intelligence officer, when he discovered him writing a manuscript. ''Do you expect to teach again? You will leave this camp only in a small wooden box.''

title: DANCE: POMARE TROUPE BACK WITH 3 NEW WORKS
description: The Eleo Pomare Dance Company hasn't been seen in New York in a fully produced stage performance for several seasons. Last week, it danced at Symphony Space, and a program of six old and new dances presented Friday provided a welcome return to Mr. Pomare's modern dance, so recognizable for its intense theatricality and strong viewpoint, developed as it has been during 23 years of choreographing.

title: ISRAELI OFFICIAL IS CLEARED OF GRAFT BUT NOW FACES TRIAL FOR LARCENY
description: A court in Jerusalem acquitted Israel's Minister for Religious Affairs today of charges that he accepted kickbacks from religious educational institutions, but denounced his moral standards in dispensing grants from his ministry.

title: TAP SHOES IS VICTOR IN PETER PAN STAKES
description: Banner Gala, a speedy filly being pointed toward the Belmont Stakes, was scratched from the Peter Pan Stakes yesterday for having inadvertently been medicated with a pain-killer, according to a steward for the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Haitian Laborers Say Argument Preceded Fatal Florida Collision
description: The Florida Highway Patrol investigated reports today that the occupants of a van had an argument over money shortly before their vehicle collided with another van, killing three Haitian farmworkers and injuring 19 other persons.

title: Man Kills Woman, Hurls Baby 6 Floors
description: A New Jersey man stabbed a woman to death, threw his baby out the window of a sixth-floor apartment on Staten Island and then jumped from the apartment himself, the police reported.

title: Flooded Valleys in Montana Face Forecast of More Rain
description: Floodwaters receded today in western Montana, but hundreds of people were still stranded by high water or were unable to return to their flooded homes.

title: F.C.C. Waives Import Rule
description: The Federal Communications Commission, in a move it hopes will be temporary, is dropping one of its key enforcement efforts intended to insure that electronic equipment imported into the United States cannot cause harmful interference.

title: BASEBALL IMPASSE: MANY SIDES TO STORY
description: Major League baseball's 650 players could lose about $600,000 a day in salaries if they strike starting with Friday's games, but the Cleveland Indians could lose approximately $1 million if they can't play their four-game series with the Yankees starting Friday.

title: BREWERS DEFEAT RED SOX TWICE
description: Cecil Cooper's homer capped a four-run rally in the eighth inning as the Brewers defeated the Boston Red Sox, 10-7, to complete a sweep of their doubleheader yesterday in Milwaukee. The Brewers rallied after the Red Sox had scored six runs in the top of the eighth to take a 7-6 lead.

title: Kennedy Attacks Plan For Arms Sales to Arabs
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, speaking in New York, sharply attacked the Reagan Administration yesterday for embarking on what he called ''the most extensive rearmament of the enemies of Israel in modern times.''

title: BOBBY UNSER WINS INDY 500 MARRED BY CRASHES, FIRES
description: The danger of fire, which has been said to be a fear of the past at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, returned here today. The anger and annoyance of controversy, which had never left, lingered in the garage area.

title: Youth in Trunk Dies in Car Crash
description: A 17-year-old youth who hid in the trunk of a car, apparently to avoid paying $3.50 to attend a drive-in theater, died when the car was struck in the rear and caught fire. The state highway patrol said that a car driven by John Duvall, 20 years old, was waiting last night for a drive-in south of Elyria when it was hit. The collision ruptured the car's gas tank and ignited a fire, trapping John Rundle in the trunk.

title: MONDAY, MAY 25, 1981; The Economy
description: Large losses are forcing the reshaping of savings institutions, and the changes are expected to have a wide impact on future mortgages and home ownership. Mortgages are expected to be risky, rising and falling with interest rates, and thrift institutions could become more like banks and brokerage houses. (Page A1.)

title: MUSIC: RIMSKY'S 'MOZART' OPERA
description: Each age has the Mozart it deserves. Ours - in summer festivals and on Broadway - has an unearthly genius that is the air-conditioned cure for a sweaty, crude life.

title: Flights From Morristown Set
description: A commuter airline has announced it will begin scheduled service June 1 from Morristown Airport to Boston, Newark and Newburgh, N.Y. The airline - Air Vectors Airways, based at Stewart Airport in Newburgh - has also applied for landing rights at Dulles International Airport near Washington, according to James Aspin, company president. Air Vectors will operate its Morristown flights with eight-passenger Piper Navajo Chieftains mornings and afternoons each weekday and once on Sunday, he said.

title: PERSIAN GULF STATES HOLD 2D SESSION
description: Foreign Ministers of six Persian Gulf nations held another session today to prepare for the start of tomorrow's summit meeting inaugurating a regional council on development and security.

title: COSMOS ARE LOSING GAMES AND PLAYERS
description: This is a bad time for the Cosmos. They have suffered three straight losses. Several of their players have been ineffective in recent games and three of their most consistent performers, Ricky Davis, Angelo DiBernardo and Seninho, have been sidelined by injuries.

title: MYSTIQUE OF SUMMER ROMANCE
description: T HERE was Seymour on the Jersey shore, Norman in Greece, Ben on the Cape and somewhere in between a tour guide whose name she no longer remembers. ''I was in love with each of them for five minutes,'' says a freelance photographer named Pearl West. ''I never saw them again, of course, except for Ben, who I bumped into at a party. We talked about getting together for drinks but he never called and I was relieved. A summer romance is a summer romance.''

title: From Capra to Wesleyan With Appreciation
description: In Middletown, Conn., Wesleyan University has received a gift of his memorabilia and working documents from Frank Capra, one of the giants of the movie industry, who turned 84 last Monday.

title: ONE NATION'S CRIMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: SIX ARE HONORED WITH DOCTORATES FROM FORDHAM
description: More than 3,000 graduates were awarded degrees at an outdoor commencement ceremony yesterday on Fordham University's Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.

title: 'SUPERMAN II' PREDICTED AS SUMMER'S HIT MOVIE
description: ''Superman II'' will be the overwhelming boxoffice hit of the summer, according to Hollywood expectations and at least one ''mildly scientific'' poll.

title: Beth Heiden Takes Bike Race in Japan
description: Beth Heiden of the United States won the women's 30-kilometer event today at the 1981 Karuizawa international cycling competition, beating a field of 35 women, including four other Americans, by almost two minutes.

title: Hospital at Indy Speedway Has Busy Day
description: The scene at the small hospital near the garage area of the Indianapolis 500 race track was one of hectic precision during today's race.

title: A HOSPITAL MESSAGE FROM THE POPE OFFERS COMFORT TO FELLOW SUFFERERS
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a brief but emotional noon address today from the Rome hospital where he is recovering from gunshot wounds.

title: Where Chastity Is Not Virtuous
description: Liberals are not the only ones capable of mischief in the name of good intentions. It is time to apply the same standard to conservative doctrine. Who, after all, opposes the values of the ''pro-family'' movement? Who denies the desirability of a society freed from abortion, broken families and pregnant teen-agers? But lofty aspirations do not justify programs that do more harm than good.

title: Division III Lacrosse Is Won by Hobart
description: Jeff Knaus and Bill Sitterly drove home three goals apiece today to lead Hobart College to the National Collegiate Division III lacrosse championship with a 10-8 victory over Cortland State.

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: Under Federal law, Memorial Day will be observed today. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; Sunday rules in effect.

title: JIM HARTUNG SCORES GYMNASTICS TRIPLE
description: Jim Hartung of Nebraska won three events last night in the United States Gymnastics Federation national men's championships, then watched 16-year-old Chris Riegel, Bart Conner of Oklahoma and Peter Vidmar of U.C.L.A. join him as gold medalists.

title: SWISS RACING DRIVER IS KILLED IN A CRASH
description: Herbert Mueller, a Swiss race driver, died after his Porsche 908 crashed during a race today at the Nuernbergring track near here.

title: Carol Lawson Wed To Dr. D. S. Arick
description: Carol Lawson, a reporter on the cultural-news staff of The New York Times, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel S. Arick, an otolaryngologist. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: Hitler Cantata Goes Back to a Poet's Days on Saipan
description: He had just returned from Pacific duty as a ''dusty sailor'' - a land-based Navy yeoman at a Saipan replacement depot - when W. D. Snodgrass began thinking deeply in 1946 about the war in Europe and the meaning of the Nazi leadership. Spurred by Hugh Trevor-Roper's ''The Last Days of Hitler'' - ''nobody had ever given us such insight into the Japanese leaders,'' Mr. Snodgrass said yesterday -he began the first of ''10 or 15 versions'' of a play based on that book while still at the University of Iowa.

title: U.N. FARM AGENCY SCRAPING FOR MONEY
description: The prevailing mood of antagonism toward foreign aid, as toward social programs of all kinds, has created serious financial problems for a $1 billion international agency dedicated to agricultural development in poor countries.

title: PRESIDENT CHOPS WOOD AND DOES PAPER WORK
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, spent another day at their ranch in the Santa Ynez Mountains near here, receiving no visitors and using the opportunity to catch up on paperwork.

title: Czech Woman Wins
description: Regina Marsikova of Czechoslovakia defeated Ivanna Madruga of Argentina, 6-2, 6-1, today to win the $100,000 Berlin Grand Prix women's tennis tournament.

title: Mishap at Drag Strip
description: An auto being used to start a dragster with electrical jumper cables in the pit area of a drag racing strip bolted out of control late last night, striking six vehicles and injuring 10 persons, Kenosha County authorities said. The auto was not a dragster or other type of racing vehicle, officials said.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THREE LEVELS OF TIME. By Harold T.P. Hayes. 236 pages. Dutton. $13.50.

title: University and Its Center In Reagan Economics Rift
description: The University of Southern California has severed its relationship with an on-campus research center founded by the industrialist Justin Dart, a major supporter of President Reagan, because university officials say the center's advocacy approach is inappropriate to an academic setting.

title: 5 AMERICAN BANKERS THREATENED
description: Four armed men described as ''leftist extremists'' hijacked a Turkish airliner carrying 110 passengers and crew members yesterday and diverted it to Bulgaria.

title: Georgette Jasen Married To Dr. Max Van Gilder
description: The marriage of Georgette Jasen, a reporter with The Wall Street Journal's New York bureau, to Dr. Max Van Gilder, a pediatrician and medical director of the Segundo Ruiz Belvis Neighborhood Family Care Center in the Bronx, took place yesterday in the Meeting Hall of the New York Society for Ethical Culture. The Rev. Mary Forell of St. Matthew's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Jersey City and Rabbi Abraham Krantz performed the ceremony.

title: Card-Sending Thief Back in Jersey Cell
description: TRENTON (AP) - A convicted armed robber who officials said had been sending snide postcards to prosecutors since he escaped from prison 16 months ago was back in a cell here.

title: Rangers 5, Mariners 3
description: Jim Sundberg had three hits and drove in two runs as the Rangers got 13 hits to complete the sweep of a three-game series.

title: Scott Shines in 3-1 Met Triumph
description: Like a man counting his blessings after hard times, Joe Torre ticked off the fortunes of his New York Mets today after they had gone 10 innings to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 3-1.

title: MCCORMACK IS FIRST IN NUTLEY BIKE RACE
description: Alan McCormack, a member of the 1976 Irish Olympic team, defeated Ed Slaughter of Kensington, Md., by one and one-half lengths in a stirring finish to win the annual Motobecane Tour of Nutley 100-kilometer bicycle race today.

title: Panov Premiere June 27
description: The world premiere of ''War and Peace,'' a full-evening ballet by Valery Panov, will take place June 27. It will be performed by the Berlin Opera Ballet in Berlin. Based on the Tolstoy novel and set to a collage of music by Tchaikovsky, the 36-scene ballet will star Galina Panova, Frank Augustyn and Mr. Panov, in the dual roles of Prince Andre and Napoleon. Mr. Panov's ''The Idiot'' was created for the company in June 1979.

title: Barry Rosen to Get a Medal From Brooklyn College
description: There have been many happy returns for the former American hostages in Iran since their release, and perhaps more than most for Barry Rosen of Brooklyn, the embassy press attache, who was the only New Yorker among them.

title: YANK ROOKIES LOOM LARGE
description: ONCE they were unfamiliar names acquired by the Yankees from the Texas Rangers in two package deals - Dave Righetti in the trade for Sparky Lyle shortly after the 1978 season, Gene Nelson in a trade for Mickey Rivers during the 1979 season. But in the fallout yesterday from an eruption by George Steinbrenner, the principal owner, that many other Yankees have been playing ''embarrassing baseball,'' the two rookie pitchers loom as the difference for the team this season, especially with Tommy John now bothered by a lower back ailment.

title: YALE'S 280TH COMMENCEMENT HONORS 13
description: Yale University bestowed 3,002 undergraduate, graduate and advanced degrees on this year's graduates today. Thousands of parents and friends gathered in bright sunshine as the 1,236 seniors of the class of '81, Yale College's 280th, waited to receive their diplomas.

title: Gina Martone Mearns Wed To Dr. Anthony M. Barrera
description: Gina Martone Mearns, daughter of Carolina Mearns of Weehawken, N.J., and the late Robert E. Mearns, was married yesterday to Dr. Anthony Michael Barrera, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alberto Barrera of Niantic, Conn. The Rev. Paul Viale performed the ceremony at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Union City, N.J.

title: Bibby Wins With Arm and Bat
description: Jim Bibby never listens to good advice, but seems to get good results, anyway. Harvey Haddix, the pitching coach of the Pittsburgh Pirates, keeps telling Bibby that the secret to winning is ''pitch a shutout and hit one out of the park.''

title: BOBBY ALLISON'S BUICK WINS
description: Bobby Allison, whose younger brother, Donnie, was injured in an accident earlier in the race, won the World 600 Grand National stock car race today from Harry Gant. Bobby Allison took control on the 275th lap, and drove his Buick across the finish line 8.2 seconds ahead of Gant's Chevrolet.

title: 35 ACRES OF PARADISE TURN INTO A TOXIC WASTE NIGHTMARE FOR A WISCONSIN MAN
description: To Walter Rondini, it seemed like a chance to own a piece of paradise: 35 thickly wooded acres of wetland, 20 miles from town, abundant with deer, raccoons and other wilderness critters, and all for a paltry $6,000.

title: OIL OFFICIALS FOCUS ON SAUDI ROLE
description: Oil ministers representing several key OPEC members called today for a freeze in oil prices and substantial reductions in crude oil output.

title: Cheryl Aronoff Is Married
description: Cheryl Aronoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Aronoff of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in Englewood, N.J., to Richard Heller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Heller of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg performed the ceremony.

title: ECONOMY'S VIGOR STIRS QUESTIONS
description: The economy's surprising strength in the first quarter is prompting economists to question a durable tenet of economic policy: that extremely high interest rates will slow business activity quickly.

title: SALVADORAN BUSINESS IS NOT FOR THE TIMID
description: For the businessman bored with the daily routine, El Salvador presents some entrepreneurial challenges. Warehouses and factories are favorite targets of guerrilla firebombings, trucks are regularly hijacked, stores are looted and workers are intimidated from showing up for the job. Extortion payments known as ''war taxes'' can be demanded by both sides, a curfew limits double-shift production, public utilities are erratic, credit and insurance no longer exist, customers demand cash in advance and owners and managers are subject to kidnapping, assassination or simply the unnerving threat of both.

title: Robert Scheidlinger Weds Miss Aurbach
description: Jacquelyn J. Aurbach, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Aurbach of Amherst, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Westbury Hotel in Manhattan to Robert Steven Scheidlinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Scheidlinger of Freeport, L.I. Rabbi Neil Gillman performed the ceremony.

title: Post Defeated Twice In Softball Tourney
description: Joanne English won three games today as California State-Sacramento captured the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division II softball championship at Dill Field.

title: THE EUROPEAN EXPERIENCE GUIDES THE CITY'S WASTE-TO-ENERGY PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Frank Scherschel, Photographer For Life Magazine, Is Dead at 74
description: Frank J. Scherschel, a staff photographer for Life magazine who covered World War II in Europe, including the liberation of Paris, and in the Pacific, died Saturday in St. Mary's Hospital in Madison, Wis. Mr. Scherschel, a resident of Baraboo, Wis., was 74 years old.

title: Dr. R.P. Weissberg Weds Dr. Stephanie Wright
description: Dr. Stephanie Wright was married in Rochester yesterday to Dr. Roger Paul Weissberg. Rabbi Rosalind Gold performed the ceremony at the University Club.

title: CABARET: LAURIE BEECHMAN
description: Laurie Beechman is a black-haired, button-eyed pixie with such tremendous resources of energy that Saturday she sang a matinee and evening performance of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' on Broadway and then ran over to the New Room at O'@Neal's, the Avenue of the Americas at West 57th Street, and did two relentlessly slam-bang solo performances.

title: In the Shadow of Segesta
description: It was inspired after the Civil War by the immense and bitter losses of the Blue and the Gray and intended then to encourage survivors to visit battlefields and decorate village graves. The modern Memorial Day evokes a response of much older and more complicated origins.

title: VETERANS' GROUPS SEEK ACTION ON AGENT ORANGE RISKS
description: Representatives of 25 veterans' and environmental groups convened here this holiday weekend to seek Federal action on illnesses they say are caused by Agent Orange, a defoliant used in the Vietnam War.

title: WHITE IS BICYCLE WINNER AGAIN
description: At 6 o'clock yesterday morning, David White was a little tired. Except for a one-minute break just after midnight to slip into a long-sleeved racing jersey to keep from getting a chill, he had been bicycling round Central Park for 17 uninterrupted hours. Only 400 of the 9,500 cyclists who had entered the 10th Annual Pepsi Challenge Bicycle Marathon were with him on the road. Most of the park lights had been turned out an hour earlier and White's sleeked-down racing bike had neither headlights nor reflectors to cut through the lonely darkness.

title: Justice Burger Asks Aid For Inmates and Guards
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today called for mandatory educational and vocational programs for prison inmates and the establishment of a ''national academy'' for prison guards.

title: MAXWELL J. PROUJANSKY
description: Maxwell J. Proujansky, president of Basch Advertising of Manhattan, died Friday of a heart attack while driving near Muttontown, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Baldwin, L.I.

title: Carol D. Bahoric Is Married To Myron Meisel, Film Critic
description: Carol Dorothy Bahoric of Los Angeles, daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Bozidar Bahoric of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Myron Meisel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Meisel of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at La Bibliotheque, a Manhattan resturant.

title: Tigers 8, Orioles 2, Tigers 5, Orioles 3
description: The Orioles, the leaders of the Eastern Division, saw their lead cut to one game over Cleveland as they dropped a doubleheader to the Tigers.

title: 19 Win in Contest Held by Pavarotti
description: Nineteen singers were named last night winners of a contest conducted here by Luciano Pavarotti, the Metropolitan Opera tenor. During the last year, 500 opera singers from all over the world were screened in preliminary audtions.

title: Steinbrenner Angry As Yanks Lose, 12-5
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, watched his team's pitching and defense crumble yesterday in a 12-5 loss to the Cleveland Indians and said he was embarrassed that 53,874 spectators ''paid hard-earned dough to see that fiasco.''

title: TV: LOST WOMEN ARTISTS FROM MUSEUM TO SCREEN
description: Thanks to the monumental ''Women Artists, 1550-1950'' exhibition, put together by the art historians Linda Nochlin and Ann Sutherland Harris five years ago for the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, we have a new perspective on women artists of the past. Whatever their place in the so-called ''mainstream'' of art, the names Artemisia Gentileschi, Angelica Kauffmann, Elizabeth Vigee Lebrun and even Rosa Bonheur no longer seem hopelessly out of context when mentioned with those of their male counterparts.

title: 15 Guatemalans Found Slain, Including a Journalist
description: The body of journalist kidnapped May 1 was among 15 murder victims found yesterday near the town of Cuilapa, 39 miles southeast of here, officials reported. They said it appeared that all of the victims had been tortured before they were slain.

title: CHEAP U.S. ALUMINUM HURTS JAPAN
description: By MIKE THARP

title: PRO AGENTS PLAY THE RECRUITING GAME
description: There were letters and telegrams and, of course, long-distance telephone calls. Sometimes, the calls came so frequently, one after another, that Kelly Tripucka hardly had time to change clothes in his room.

title: ST. JOHN'S BOWS, 15-0, AS MAINE ADVANCES
description: The St. John's baseball team, which had scored 33 runs in two games yesterday, got none today and lost the final game of the Northeast Regional college tournament to Maine, 15-0.

title: NATO ALLIANCE: ADVANTAGES THAT ARE NOT EXPLOITED
description: The North Atlantic military alliance, with 200 million more people than the nations of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, a huge advantage in gross national product and more advanced industrial and technical resources, is trying to restore the military balance in Europe. Military leaders, politicians and civil servants associated with NATO agree that, in view of the basic strengths of the two alliances, the present imbalance indicts Western leaders, parliaments and people.

title: MINNESOTA CURBING 'HEADSHOPS'
description: Giving a minor tobacco will carry a more severe penalty than giving him marijuana, under a bill signed last week by Gov. Albert H. Quie.

title: LIKE IT OR NOT, NUCLEAR WEAPONS SERVE A PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIDGE
description: The second and final day of the prestigious Goldman open pair championship at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday began with two out-of-town players in the lead.

title: Chebor, Juskus Star As IC4A Meet Ends
description: Solomon Chebor of Fairleigh Dickinson University won one title, the 3,000-meter steeplechase, and almost a second, and Mike Juskus of Glassboro State, who was more concerned about the impending arrival of his first child, broke a meet record.

title: Veterans Continue Protests And Seek Reagan Response
description: Two small groups of Vietnam veterans vowed today to continue a hunger strike and a sit-in until President Reagan responds to their demands for better treatment for veterans.

title: HOOKED
description: Everybody wants to catch a fish. That's my belief. And I think it's too bad that most people never have caught one.

title: CONTROLLING AGENTS IS NOT EASY
description: What does it take to be a good professional sports agent? ''I think you need a thorough understanding of the collective bargaining agreements, the grievance procedures and how the salary system works,'' William Weston, a professor at the University of Baltimore Law School, said. ''You can't just go in and negotiate with some general managers; you need a good understanding of tax laws, which very few lawyers have. Guys jump into this business for the wrong reason. There are an awful lot of them who can't get good jobs, jump in as agents and don't know what they're doing.''

title: BALLET: GELSEY KIRKLAND DANCES AS GUEST OF EGLEVSKY TROUPE
description: FRIDAY night's appearances by Gelsey Kirkland and Christopher Aponte with the Eglevsky Ballet Company in Hempstead, L.I., caused an observer's thoughts to turn to the whole problem of guest stars. Essentially, their performances at Hofstra University's John Cranford Adams Playhouse raised one big question: when guest stars are imported, what should they dance?

title: HORSES THAT PULL BUGGIES
description: H ALFWAY up the drive to Norman Woolworth's house in New Canaan, Conn., a sign reads, ''Whoa,'' which is a command Stanley Dancer occasionally gives to French Chef and Smokin Yankee.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INSIDE

title: PROPOSED REFERRAL CENTER FOR HOMELESS DISTURBS WEST SIDE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: In an effort to deal with the thousands of vagrants and former mental patients who roam the streets of Manhattan's West Side, the city is planning to establish its first referral center for homeless people, at 88th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: POLISH FILM JUST MAKES IT TO CANNES FOR SHOWING
description: It was in the best tradition of the film world. Tension was high, fingers were crossed and everyone was waiting - not for the cavalry to arrive in the last reel, but for the newest film of the noted Polish director Andrzej Wajda to arrive here.

title: 3 WOMEN OF 'GENIUS' TELL OF ROAD THEY TOOK
description: To be publicly labeled a genius would seem to guarantee neither comfort nor privacy, but three women so dubbed last week and given five-year grants to indulge their particular talents appear to be wearing their identities with considerable ease.

title: Royals 6, Twins 4
description: The Royals, the American League pennant winners last season, finally escaped last place in the Western Division with their 11th victory in 33 games, dropping the Twins into the lowest position. The Royals rallied for five runs in the seventh after trailing by 4-1 to reward Rich Gale (2-3) with the victory.

title: 5 AT WABC-TV ASKED TO RESIGN IN AN INQUIRY INTO BOGUS-LETTERS USE
description: Five employees of WABC-TV, including the program director, the station's executive producer and a reporter, Ellen Fleysher, have been asked to resign as a result of the use of bogus letters on local viewer-participation programs.

title: Times Book Review Gets Award
description: The Irita Van Doren Book Award was presented yesterday to The New York Times Book Review ''for its many contributions to the cause of the book as an instrument of culture in American life.''

title: GOLDIN URGES CAREY ACT ON TRANSIT
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin of New York City called on Governor Carey to seek an emergency meeting with Governor Byrne of New Jersey and Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut to develop a regional plan to deal with mass transit.

title: 15 Are Exposed to Radiation In Nuclear Mishap in Japan
description: Fifteen workers were exposed to radiation Friday night when three tons of radioactive water overflowed at a nuclear power plant in Fukui State in western Japan, it was reported today.

title: VIETNAM GOES ON
description: Officially, the Vietnam War is over, but it still goes on in American minds. The battle lines are so ingrained that we play out the old conflicts without noticing the consequences. Some of the war's after-effects are obvious.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS OFF
description: The rise in orders of machine tools in March did not continue into April. Orders last month declined 10.8 percent to the lower levels of the last nine months.

title: POTTER'S FIELD: AISLE OF THE DEAD
description: ''And the chief priests took the silver pieces, and said, It is not lawful for to put them into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.

title: FERGUS TAKES MEMORIAL GOLF
description: Keith Fergus, one of the most consistent young players on the PGA Tour, carried off a seemingly impossible shot from the back lip of a fairway bunker on the 18th hole today to save par and win the Memorial Tournament by one stroke. His closest pursuer, Jack Renner, thought Fergus was facing a certain doublebogey, but Fergus said later, ''I felt I could make the shot.''

title: 3 L.I. Youths Seized In Fire at School
description: Three Glen Cove youths were arrested and charged with setting a fire at the Glen Cove Middle School, causing an estimated $250 in damages, the Nassau County police said.

title: ISRAEL PREMIER SAYS SOVIET ADVISERS JOIN SYRIANS IN LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin charged today that Soviet military advisers were accompanying Syrian Army units into Lebanon.

title: AFTER CRASH, STREET REGAINS ITS RHYTHM
description: The browsing and bargaining and buying that is the rhythm of Sunday on the Lower East Side was shattered yesterday morning by the automobile that careered into the Sunday crowds, injuring 27 people.

title: BODY OF BLACK MALE IN 20'S IS FOUND IN ATLANTA RIVER
description: The body of a black man in his late 20's was found today in the Chattahoochee River, and authorities said the victim o apparently had not been reported missing to the police.

title: SPANISH COMMANDOS STORM BANK, FREE HOSTAGES AND SEIZE GUNMEN
description: Police commandos assaulted a bank headquarters here last night held by right-wing terrorists and freed several scores of hostages. One terrorist was reported to have been killed.

title: WILLOWBROOK'S GOALS STILL UNMET 6 YEARS AFTER ORDER FOR REFORMS
description: In 1975 a Federal judge ordered the state to clean up the Willowbrook State School on Staten Island, then the world's largest treatment center for the mentally retarded.

title: Mayotte Captures N.C.A.A. Crown
description: Tim Mayotte found the range in the second set with his spinning serve and went on to win the National Collegiate singles title with a 6-7, 6-3, 6-3 victory over Jimmy Gurfein today.

title: OFFER TO BIRDSONG TOO HIGH, KINGS SAY
description: The Kings say they have not seen the deal Otis Birdsong, their free-agent guard, has made with the Cleveland Cavaliers, but Kansas City officials say the $1 million a year for five years Birdsong has reportedly been offered is too much.

title: REAGAN'S WRONG MOVES
description: Many conservatives voted for Ronald Reagan to cut out the sleazy conflicts of interest of the Carter days, to guard against the power abuses of the 60's and early 70's, to give investors confidence that corporate bribery was not concealed in public statements, and to reverse the Big Government intrusion into private lives that began in the New Deal. Mr. Reagan has shown his first signs of failing on those four counts.

title: ARMS NEGOTIATORS COME ARMED AGAINST CONTROLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Grant by U.S. Returned In Back-Reagan Move
description: John M. Thompson Jr., president of the Tile Council of America Inc., has returned a $225,000 grant to the Government, saying he hoped his action would inspire others to support President Reagan's economic program.

title: M.I.T. Graduates Find Diploma Worth Dollars
description: Lynn Radlauer, class president at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that when she told her father of her 11 job offers and her final choice and salary, ''he said, 'You're not worth that much.' ''

title: A Tense Quiet Is Reported At 3 Prisons After Riots
description: United Press International Hostile quiet prevailed yesterday at prisons in Michigan and Nevada where riots in which more than 30 people were injured last week were quelled by special police teams and prison guards.

title: Teen-Agers Accused In Hempstead Rape
description: Two Hempstead teen-agers were arrested and charged with the rape, sodomy and robbery of a 28-year-old woman here, according to the Nassau County police.

title: Caroline Parker Bride of Vincent Andrus Jr.
description: Caroline Scott Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Parker of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Saviour's Episcopal Church to Vincent Dyckman Andrus Jr. of Cody, Wyo. He is the son of Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Andrus.

title: Sondra Holtzman Bride Of Douglas Alan Phillips
description: Sondra Holtzman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Holtzman of New Canaan, Conn., was married in the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Douglas Alan Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. Phillips of Lafayette, Calif.

title: NEW TRADE IN GOLD FUTURES
description: THE powerful 104-year-old London Metal Exchange, in an apparent recognition of the role that futures contracts play in pricing gold, will begin trading futures in the metal for the first time on Sept. 7. Should the venture succeed, the exchange is expected to add a market in silver futures.

title: GEORGE JESSEL, COMEDIAN AND TOASTMASTER, DIES AT 83
description: George Jessel, the vaudeville comedian and actor who became known as the ''toastmaster general of the United States,'' died of a heart attack last night while at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center for tests. He was 83 years old.

title: Magic Carpet
description: When Texas Stadium decided to replace its 10-year-old artificial field with Texas Turf last July, there was a question of what to do with the old three-eighths inch Tartan Turf - all 98,000 square feet of it - which was mounted on a five-eighths inch pad.

title: U.S. ATTORNEY ASSESSES HIS YEAR ON JOB
description: Narcotics, organized crime and white-collar crime are the main targets of John S. Martin Jr., who has just completed one year as the United States Attorney in Manhattan.

title: Missile Crisis Is Said to Hamper Europe's Mideast Peace Efforts
description: The Common Market's envoy to the Middle East said today that the Israeli-Syrian dispute over missiles in Lebanon was hampering European efforts to bring peace to the region.

title: TRAIL OF MEHMET ALI AGCA: 6 YEARS OF NEOFASCIST TIES
description: For at least six years, Mehmet Ali Agca, the man accused of shooting Pope John Paul II, has been associated with a xenophobic, fanatically nationalist, neofascist network steeped in violence - the National Action Party of his native Turkey and its satellite groups there and elsewhere in Europe.

title: ANOTHER MODEST PROPOSAL
description: Northern Ireland is a disgrace to the European Community and the whole Western world. To be sure, worse things are going on in other countries, for example Lebanon and Uganda. But their trials stem from very different circumstances, beyond ordinary citizens' control.

title: A's 6, Blue Jays 5 A's 5, Blue Jays 0
description: Tony Armas, who had not hit a home run since May 7, hit one in each game for the A's.

title: Bold Type Bad Style For Jersey Doctors
description: Hundreds of New Jersey physicians may be violating a rule of the State Board of Medical Examiners that says doctors may not put their names in boldface in the Yellow Pages.

title: TOWN SEEKING PROFITS IN LIFE OF JESSE JAMES
description: ''Site of first daylight bank holdup in the United States,'' says the inscription on the bronze plaque on the two-story brick building just northeast of the town square here. ''Attributed to Jesse James gang.''

title: Is Borg on Decline? French Open May Tell
description: Discounting his surprising elimination from tournaments this year in Toronto, Brussels, Milan and Monte Carlo, Bjorn Borg was busy the other day quelling recent suggestions that he had reached the limits of his tennis brilliance.

title: DEBATES SPIRITED AS 21 IN JERSEY SEEK OUT VOTERS
description: Five Democrats from the cluster of candidates for Governor of New Jersey met in a Manhattan television studio yesterday, as the campaign entered its last full week, and joined in criticism of some of the absentees.

title: Ailing but Energetic Minister Looks to Future
description: It was 20 years ago in Greenwich Village, where the turbulently innovative 1960's had already been born in the 1950's, that the Rev. Al Carmines was brought by the Rev. Howard R. Moody to Judson Memorial Church as his assistant pastor.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, MAY 25, 1981
description: International Soviet advisers are entering Lebanon accompanying large Syrian Army units, Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel suggested. Mr. Begin made the charge in a fleeting remark in a speech to a convention of Israeli building contractors in Tel Aviv. It was the first time that Israel had accused Soviet advisers of being inside Lebanon. Mr. Begin's office had earlier disclosed that it gave Lebanese Christians a secret commitment as early as 1978 of protection against air attacks by the Syrians. (Page A1, Column 6.) Spanish police commandos rescued several scores of hostages when they assaulted a bank headquarters and reportedly killed one of the gunmen who had held the building for 36 hours. According to officials, not one of the hostages, who had initially numbered more than 200, was wounded in the attack. (A1:3-4.)

title: MISS HITE GETS FIRST TRIUMPH ON TOUR
description: Kathy Hite scored a one-stroke victory over JoAnne Carner today in the $125,000 Corning Classic. It was her first triumph on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: Lucas Avery Alden, 69; A Financial Consultant
description: Lucas Avery Alden, a financial consultant and former vice president of W. R. Grace & Company, died Saturday at the Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital, after a long illness. Mr. Alden, who was 69 years old, was a resident of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS RESHAPING OPERATIONS IN FACE OF BIG LOSSES
description: The nation's savings institutions, which have financed American home buying since the Depression, are experiencing unparalleled losses brought on by a combination of high interest rates and deregulatory moves that are changing the shape of the industry.

title: Good for the Bench
description: In a time of turmoil over the role of the courts, it is a relief to see the names Senator D'Amato has proposed to the Justice Department for appointment to the Federal bench in New York. They are accomplished, moderate lawyers and include a distinguished law dean, Joseph McLaughlin of Fordham.

title: A SEVERE CASE OF 'GENERAL HOSPITAL' HITS HARVARD
description: The '' 'General Hospital' Weekend'' at Harvard University was billed as an educational experience. On Saturday morning, three stars of the popular soap opera, Anthony Geary (Luke Spencer), Jacklyn Zeman (Bobbie Spencer, his sister) and Norma Connolly (Aunt Ruby, their guardian) analyzed their craft and performed forthcoming ''General Hospital'' scenes before some 175 students. But the atmosphere of the weekend recalled not an ivory tower but Shea Stadium during the Beatles' concert in August, 1965.

title: Barbara Jean Merle Wed
description: Barbara Jean Merle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Merle of Yonkers, was married there yesterday to Edward N. Wendolski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Wendolski, also of Yonkers. The Rev. Eugene A. Kosinik performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Casimir. Mrs. Wendolski expects to graduate June 6 from Pace University. Her husband, a business representative with the New York Telephone Company in White Plains, is an alumnus of Mercy College.

title: TV: BALANCHINE'S 'SPELLBOUND CHILD'
description: Dance is viewed from two angles on public television: ''Dance in America'' is presenting George Balanchine's latest version of ''The Spellbound Child,'' and a choreographer's methods are documented in ''Martha Clarke: Light and Dark.''

title: Fewer Juveniles Held in Custody In Private Facilities, Study Finds
description: The number of youths held in privately operated juvenile custody facilities has been declining, a Justice Department study reported today.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS REAGAN ON RIGHTS
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, speaking to the 30th graduating class at Brandeis University, today criticized the Reagan Administration's human rights policies abroad.

title: BOOKSELLERS MEETING IN A LOW-KEYED CONVENTION
description: One book publisher here is giving away a capuchin monkey, another invited delegates to attend an autograph session for an 11-year-old horse, and tomorrow two booksellers will be married in a civil ceremony at the Hyatt-Regency Hotel to help celebrate a line of paperback romance novels.

title: Counselors Sought At Summer Camps
description: ''Hundreds'' of jobs for summer camp counselors remain registered with the Camp Unit, New York State Job Service, 247 West 54th Street, and its upstate and Long Island offices, according to Louise Dankberg, supervisor.

title: TRAINING RETARDED CALLS FOR PAINSTAKING PATIENCE
description: At the dining room table of a pleasant, two-story house on the grounds of the Staten Island Developmental Center, a young man of 26 was the center of attention. He had been given a suit and tie to wear for the occasion, which took place in mid-afternoon. The ceremony clearly pleased him, and six people sat regarding him with friendly interest, asking questions about his welfare and what he had learned since they saw him last.

title: Miss Zimmerman Wed To Dr. Arnold J. Levine
description: Patricia Alta Zimmerman, a financial analyst on the corporate planning staff of the TransWorld Corporation in New York, was married in Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to Dr. Arnold Jan Levine, an ophthalmologist in practice in Manhattan. Rabbi Malcolm Thomson performed the ceremony at the Innis Arden Golf Club.

title: IN ULSTER, 5 'SIMPLE DEMANDS' DEFY SIMPLE SOLUTION
description: In a letter to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher the other day, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who has great influence in Ireland, beseeched her once again to institute ''real measures of prison reform'' that would end the hunger strikes that have taken four lives at the Maze Prison here this month.

title: Miss Taylor Honored for 'Foxes'
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who made her Broadway debut in ''The Little Foxes,'' will receive an award Thursday at the presentation of the 37th Theater World Awards. The awards are given annually to outstanding new talent in Broadway and Off Broadway productions.

title: DISCLOSURE OF TWO FABRICATED ARTICLES CAUSES PAPERS TO RE-EXAMINE THEIR RULES
description: Many American newspapers, distressed by the idea that The Washington Post and The Daily News of New York had each printed a fabricated article, and concerned about their own reputations, say they are setting new rules and re-emphasizing existing rules to reduce the potential for fraud or misrepresentation.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A batter bunts the ball and then drops his bat in fair territory as he dashes toward first base. The bunt has a lot of backspin and the catcher, thinking it will go foul, lets the ball roll. It is finally stopped by the bat in fair ground as the batter reaches first base safely. Is it a single or is it interference?

title: VIGIL AGAIN CAPTURES CLEVELAND MARATHON
description: Charles Vigil of Alamosa, Colo., took the lead with 14 miles to go today and scored his second straight victory in the Cleveland Marathon.

title: Loughlin Girls Win Outdoor Track Title
description: Bishop Loughlin made it a sweep of Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor and outdoor track titles yesterday when it won the girls' outdoor championship at St. John's University.

title: FED'S CONCERN ABOUT INTEREST RATES
description: WASHINGTON THE latest decline in the money supply, a $2.2 billion drop in the basic measurement M1-B reported Friday, appears to be taking some heat off the Federal Reserve Board.

title: HALSTON'S HARD SELL FOR 'PRESTIGE' ACCOUNT
description: ''I wanted to formulate a fragrance never experienced before - a totally original fragrance.'' On that note, ''Halston Night,'' a ''strong, direct, alluring'' and, at $125-an-ounce, decidedly expensive perfume, was introduced last month by Halston, the designer, with a little help from his friends: Norton Simon Inc., the conglomerate that acquired his fashion business in 1973; International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., the New York laboratory that formulates scents for some of the most glamorous - and unglamorous - products in the world, and a host of experts in public relations, advertising and other areas involved in the selling of scent.

title: White Sox 10, Angels 2
description: The White Sox rapped 13 hits off Geoff Zahn (5-5) and Luis Sanchez to win their fourth straight. In sweeping a three-game series from California, the White Sox collected 34 runs and 45 hits.

title: Deborah Grolnick Married to Prof. Frederick Godwin
description: Deborah Ellen Grolnick was married to Frederick H. Godwin yesterday at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Simon A. Grolnick, in Great Neck, L.I. Village Justice Nicholas F. O'Shea of Williston, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: 27 HURT AS STOLEN CAR CHASED BY POLICE HITS CROWD
description: Twenty-seven persons were injured yesterday when a stolen auto being chased by a police car on the Lower East Side careened into Orchard Street and plowed into shoppers at an unbarricaded pedestrian mall. One of those injured was listed in critical condition.

title: Some Progress Is Hinted In Coal Strike Negotiations
description: Intensive negotiations to end the coal strike ended today with union and industry representatives planning to resume them tomorrow in an effort to reach agreement on job security provisions in a new three-year contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Syrians have 3,600 tanks concentrated with Soviet advisers who go togehter with Syrian units into Lebanon.'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. (A1:6.)

title: JAZZ VIBROPHONE: GARY BURTON
description: The excellent jazz vibraphonist Gary Burton has rarely worked with a horn player before, but the latest addition of his quartet, which played at the Bottom Line during the weekend, includes the talented alto saxophonist Jim Odgren. The other members of the quartet, which have just released an album on ECM, are the bassist Steve Swallow and the drummer Mike Hyman.

title: A GOOD SPOT TO BEAT THE HEAT AND AVOID THE CROWDS
description: Under the boardwalk at Coney Island, Monica Morales, 2, found the perfect place to enjoy a bottle of cool juice without the worry that someone would kick sand in it. New Yorkers who remained in town flocked to city beaches, parks and pools as the temperatures on the middle day of the long Memorial Day weekend climbed to 86 degrees.

title: Mitterrand and Schmidt Call for Military Balance
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany met for three and a half hours today and agreed that the West should work to restore military balance in Europe while pursuing arms control talks with Moscow, West German sources said.

title: Juventus Captures Italian Soccer Title
description: Juventus of Turin won its 19th Italian soccer championship today by defeating Fiorentina, 1-0.

title: A FACELIFT FOR CAREY MANSION
description: You can take your shoes off in Governor Carey's mansion. It's that kind of place. And in the second-floor sports room, leaning back in a studded red leather chair, you might want to raise a mug of ale to the New York Islanders, Pele, Reggie Jackson or one of the other sports heroes whose photos adorn the walls.

title: Authorities Link 2 To Murder at Attica
description: Authorities investigating the stabbing death of a 27-year-old inmate at the state prison here said yesterday that they had two suspects, according to the state police.

title: TAKING CARE OF THE TRADE CENTER'S MIRO TAPESTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Mang First in Spain
description: Toni Mang of West Germany, the world champion, took another step toward his second 250cc motorcycling title today by winning the 31st Spanish Grand Prix at Jarama, near here. Mang won easily once he passed the early leader, Carlos Lavado of Venezuela.

title: THE CASE FOR 'THE PEOPLE V. JEAN HARRIS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Munich Rain Delay
description: The final match in the Bavarian international tennis tournament between Christophe Roger-Vasselin of France and Chris Lewis of New Zealand, scheduled for today, was postponed until tomorrow because of rain.

title: FEARS OVER REDUCED SOCIAL SECURITY AFFLICT ELDERLY
description: Gregory Kaplan sat in the small, orderly apartment, the gnarled hands that once held the brushes of an artist trembling scarcely more than his lips as he fearfully contemplated tomorrows scalloped with uncertainties.

title: KEEP THE MA BELL CASE JUDICIAL, NOT POLITICAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Debate Evokes Heated Schweiker Reply
description: Health and Human Services Secretary Richard S. Schweiker, in a heated exchange about the Reagan Administration's polices on abortion, said today that he had difficulty understanding ''why we can get all wrought up about tadpoles and not unborn kids.''

title: NEW MANAGERS HOPE TO RETURN SPARKLE AND CROWDS TO PLAYLAND
description: Playland opened its 1981 season this weekend under new management, and with a musical bang, as Westchester County and the Marriott Corporation joined in an effort to revitalize what has long been considered the prototype of the family amusement park.

title: Clerc Defeats Pecci, Wins Italian Open
description: Jose-Luis Clerc of Argentina defeated Victor Pecci of Paraguay, 6-3, 6-4, 6-0 today to win the $200,000 Italian Open.

title: Prisoner at Rikers Hangs Himself in Cell
description: A Brooklyn man awaiting trial hanged himself with his belt in the Rikers Island complex, a Corrections Department spokesman said.

title: QUALITY CIRCLES AID PRODUCTIVITY
description: ''It's such a fragile thing,'' said Howard M. Love, the chairman of the National Steel Corporation, cupping his hands as if to protect a newly sprouted seedling. ''You've got to encourage it with all the sunlight and fresh air to make it grow.''

title: Italian Minister Refuses To Resign in Scandal
description: Labor Minister Franco Foschi said today he would not resign in Italy's deepening scandal over alleged espionage and other criminal activities by a secret Masonic lodge.

title: DOWN HOME OLYMPIAD HELD FOR SECOND TIME
description: -Checkers, tobacco-spitting, marbleshooting skillet-throwing are all events in this town's three-day olympiad, first held last year when the United States boycotted the 1980 Olympics in the Soviet Union to protest that country's intervention in Afghanistan.

title: Around the Nation; TALKS HELD IN COAL STRIKE WITH LITTLE PROGRESS NOTED
description: Coal industry and union bargainers met for three hours today trying to resolve differences over job security. The president of the United Mine Workers, Sam M. Church Jr., said little progress was made.

title: No Headline
description: Donnie Allison's condition was upgraded from guarded to ''unsatisfactory but stable'' today.

title: U.S. DISCLOSES ACCIDENTS INVOLVING NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: A Pentagon study has disclosed five previously unreported accidents with nuclear weapons, including one incident involving a submarine. In three of the accidents, the nuclear weapons were not recovered.

title: Market Place; Savin's Key To the World
description: THE Savin Corporation, the aggressive office copier company that has placed more machines in the United States market in the last three years than both the Xerox Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation combined, will soon compete directly in the world market.

title: No Headline
description: Brian Redman powered his Lola T-600 to a four-lap victory in the Camel GT Coca Cola 400 at the Lime Rock track today.

title: ONGAIS HAS MORE SURGERY
description: Doctors repaired a six-inch tear today in the diaphragm of Danny Ongais, the race driver injured in a crash during yesterday's Indianapolis 500.

title: 6 Persian Gulf Countries Sign Cooperation Treaty
description: The heads of state of six countries in the Persian Gulf area signed an agreement today to form a Gulf Cooperation Council despite differences on defense policy.

title: DANCE: 'LASER SCULPTURE'
description: THERE wasn't anything impressively sculptural, danced or laserlighted about ''Laser Sculpture Dance,'' a brief collaborative project presented Saturday at a Duane Street loft theater. The bodies of the three female dancers did assume the sculptured look that most bodies do in dance.

title: The City;
description: New York City could be a ''treeless waste'' by the year 2012 if it doesn't do something to protect its trees, the president of the city's Parks warned.

title: AMERICANS TELL OF A WILD MELEE AS HOSTAGES ATTACKED TERRORISTS
description: Haggard and exhausted after his two-day ordeal, John H. Bernson, a 34-year-old Citibank vice president from Chappaqua, N.Y., smiled at his fellow American ex-hostages tonight and murmured, ''I'm delighted to be alive.''

title: 2 Quarterly Supplements Scheduled by Esquire
description: Esquire magazine will be introducing a pair of quarterly supplements later this year that will cover film and music.

title: THEATER: 'GETHSEMANE' PERFORMED AT SPECTRUM
description: LATE in Harvey Perr's ''Gethsemane Springs,'' at the Spectrum Theater, one of the play's many long-winded characters compares the evening to ''A Day at the Races,'' ''without the Marx Brothers, in French, without subtitles.'' Does that sound boring? ''Gethsemane Springs'' defines boredom. It is ''Rules of the Game'' without Renoir, ''The Cherry Orchard'' without Chekhov. The play begins with a character announcing: ''There are no silver birches. I ache for plain talk. I ache for silver birches and plain talk.'' Skip the silver birches.

title: Jerseyan Held on Coast For Smuggling of Heroin
description: A New Jersey restaurant owner was arrested yesterday for attempting to smuggle more than nine pounds of Southeast Asian heroin, worth an estimated $9.5 million, through customs in the false bottom of a suitcase, officials said.

title: Psychiatric and Physical Ills
description: Unrecognized medical diseases may produce or worsen psychiatric symptoms. Identifying and treating the physical ailments may prevent unnecessary psychiatric hospitalization.

title: Congress Should Cut the Cards
description: Attorney General William French Smith assails the special prosecutor law as unnecessary, wasteful, unfair - and even unconstitutional. Only a Congress with no memory at all could possibly agree. This law is essential to public confidence in Government. It needs fine-tuning, not watering down or repeal.

title: The Mayor Has Gone Fission
description: Edward I. Koch, a Democrat, will soon be endorsed for re-election by the Republicans and will thus become the first Mayor of New York City to have the backing of both major parties. Aside from remarks by the handful of minor-party and splinter-group opposition candidates who have surfaced, none of whom has a serious chance of winning, few questions have been raised about the prospect of merging the two major political points of view.

title: SHAH'S DOCTOR AND JOURNAL SETTLE LIBEL SUIT OUT OF COURT
description: A libel suit against the journal Science by Dr. Benjamin H. Kean, over his purported role in the admission of the late Shah of Iran to the United States, has been settled out of court.

title: BOOMING NANTUCKET TO TEST MODEST CRIMP IN ITS SUCCESS
description: Things are going to be a little different here this summer. The streets will still be, as ever, quaint and bustling, the traffic will still be horrible, the air will still be brisk and salty and the island will still be magnificent in its splendid isolation from the real world.

title: Sears Tower in Chicago Is Scaled by Stunt Man
description: A 25-year-old stunt man dressed in a bright blue-and-orange Spiderman outfit today climbed the west face of the Sears Tower, the world's tallest building.

title: Consumer Group Calls for Inquiry On Recreational Vehicles' Safety
description: The Center for Auto Safety, a publicly financed consumer group, said today that it had petitioned California officials to investigate the safety and quality of recreational vehicles.

title: TANNING PARLORS FADE FROM FRANCHISE SCENE
description: ''It was too much blue sky,'' said Fred Tippen, president of Wonder Tan, an Atlanta-based company, when asked what happened to all those tanning parlors. ''Everybody thought it was easy money.''

title: Social Security, After the Fall
description: ''None of us can afford to underestimate the seriousness of the problem .... This should be the time for statesmanship of the highest order.'' - President Reagan, May 21

title: Around the World; Salvador Junta Clears Area For an Attack on Guerrillas
description: Government sources said today that about 800 people living in Chalatenango Province near the Honduran border had been evacuated from their homes in preparation for a major army attack on guerrillas.

title: EDUCATION
description: IT used to be that you became a dancer by toiling away with unlimited hope and very limited money in the small private studios that dot New York. If you were lucky, you were accepted for advanced training at a school attached to a major company and gained a kind of inside track on employment.

title: COST EFFECTIVENESS OF CAT SCANNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVING A 'BOTTLE BILL'
description: For nearly a decade returnable-container legislation, which would require a deposit on beer and soda bottles and cans, has been bottled up in committee in the New York State Senate and Assembly.

title: FILM: OLIVEIRA'S 'ARMOR DE PERDICAO'
description: MANOEL de OLIVEIRA'S ''Amor de Perdi,cao'' (''Doomed Love''), which opens today at the Public Theater, takes a stately 270 minutes to unfold. But until the last half-hour or so, this tale of ill-fated love in 19th-century Portugal holds the attention in a near deathgrip.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: IN response to reports of widespread cheating, student leaders have launched efforts to repair the tarnished image of campus ethics. A spot check of colleges from coast to coast showed that honor codes are being tightened, enforcement made more effective and penalties more realistic and equitable.

title: A Collision Course
description: No doubt George F. Kennan will be widely considered Quixotic for calling attention at this time to the ''collision course'' on which he believes the nuclear superpowers are embarked, and for urging the immediate reduction by 50 percent of American and Soviet nuclear arsenals.

title: MERCEDES EXECUTIVE TO HEAD U.S. IMPORTER
description: Walter Bodack, a 51-year-old automotive executive, has been appointed president of Mercedes Benz of North America, the American importer and distributor for Daimler-Benz of West Germany. He succeeds Werner F. Jessen, 60, who resigned.

title: SHELL'S SUCCESS IN OIL BIDDING
description: This is a story of high-stakes corporate gambling by tight-lipped men in well-tailored suits. The stakes run into hundreds of millions of dollars. Promising ''playing cards'' are given the names of women, cocktails or automobile parts to mask their identities. Bagmen with access to very big money roam the city.

title: RECALLING SOME GROUND RULES FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor One things seems to have been forgotten in the furor of illadvised tinkering with Social Security. Attempts to answer the funding problems of old-age benefits by forcing workers to continue to work until age 65 and beyond completely ignores the issue of job opportunity.

title: The City; Five Struck by Car Are Still in Hospital
description: Five persons remained hospitalized yesterday with injuries received when a stolen automobile plowed into a crowd of shoppers on Orchard Street on the Lower East Side on Sunday.

title: MODERN PRODUCTION METHODS TROUBLE ISRAEL'S KIBBUTZIM
description: On the 70th anniversary of Degania Aleph, Israel's first kibbutz, or communal settlement, Allan Shapiro, a member, reflected on the controversies that preoccupied its founders at the turn of this century.

title: Californian to Eleven Stitches
description: Eleven Stitches held off Temperence Hill in the stretch to win the $342,600 Californian by a head at Hollywood Park today.

title: 2 Baez Concerts Banned in Brazilian Cities; 2 Joan Baez Concects Banned in Brazilian Cities
description: Joan Baez, the folk singer, was prevented from giving a concert in Brazil Saturday night for the second straight night.

title: Bridge: Jones and Zirker Hold Lead To Win 53d Goldman Pairs
description: A distinguished event that has been captured by some of the most colorful characters in the history of the game was won in New York City on Sunday night by two quiet but determined young men who are building solid reputations. The event, the Goldman Pairs, has been won by such figures as Oswald Jacoby, Sidney Lenz, David Burnstine, Harry Fishbein, Helen Sobel, Charles Goren, Alfred Sheinwold, Edgar Kaplan, Tobias Stone and Alvin Roth.

title: Lewis B. Patten, Author, Dies; Wrote More Than 100 Westerns
description: Lewis B. Patten, a writer of westerns, has died at his home here. He was 66 years old. Mr. Patten, awarded the Golden Saddleman's Award by the Western Writers of America in 1979 for his collected work, wrote more than 100 novels.

title: Dollar Mixed; Gold Declines
description: The dollar was mixed against major European currencies in slow trading today. The price of gold declined slightly in Zurich.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International An Israeli drone was shot down in the vicinity of the Lebanese border by missiles fired from Syrian territory. It was at least the third Israeli pilotless craft that has been shot down since Syria moved missiles into Lebanon nearly four weeks ago. Page A1, Column 6. Moscow denied Israel's contention that Soviet advisers were accompanying Syrian army units into Lebanon. Responding to a statement by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, the press agency Tass said that "there have been no Soviet advisers whatsoever in Lebanon, nor are there any now." A3:4-6.

title: MISSILES FROM SYRIA DOWN ISRAELI DRONE: BEGIN MAKES OFFER
description: Missiles fired from inside Syria brought down another pilotless Israeli reconnaissance aircraft in the vicinity of the Lebanese-Syrian border today. It was at least the third such aircraft shot down since Syria moved missiles into Lebanon nearly four weeks ago.

title: TUESDAY, MAY 26, 1981; Energy
description: Saudi Arabia said it would raise its $32-a-barrel oil price if other OPEC members lowered theirs. But at the cartel's semiannual ministerial meeting in Geneva, the other 12 members, which charge $36 to $41 a barrel, rejected the proposal to unify its pricing structure. Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, said he did not want to discuss production cuts at this meeting, cuts that the other countries contend are the key issue and essential to preventing further downward pressure on the prices of crude oil. (Page A1.)

title: POPE, MAKING PROGRESS, PHONES AILING CARDINAL
description: Pope John Paul II, who is said to be making further progress, ate a light lunch today and telephoned his ailing mentor, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.

title: Around the World; Bolivian Ex-Colonel Fails In 2d Coup in 2 Weeks
description: A former colonel who seized the city of Cochabamba this morning for his second try at a coup in two weeks gave up at the end of the day and ordered his troops back to their barracks, the Bolivian Army's general command said.

title: GUATEMALA'S WAR ON ITS DEMOCRATIC FORCES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE LOST NEW YORKANS
description: THE setting sun stretched a shadow of the Great Obelisk across the silent wasteland, and Professor Timur, head of the New Ulan Bator University expedition, uncorked a celebratory bottle of fermented mare's milk. Professional acclaim seemed finally about to shine upon a career of pedagogic mediocrity, and Timur could hardly wait to savor it.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WOMEN OF MUSIC

title: BALL LIGHTNING NOW SEEMS MORE FACT THAN FICTION
description: o'-the-wisps and ball lightning - all have been snubbed by science as the imaginings of undisciplined minds. But ball lightning, at least, seems finally to have won a wide measure of scientific recognition as a physical reality.
