title: CONGRESS AIMS TO CUT U.S. CREDIT
description: In handing President Reagan a resounding budget victory, both the House of Representatives and the Senate also acted in accordance with the President's wishes to check the rapid growth of Federal borrowing, which many economists consider a major contributor to the rise in interest rates.

title: Tax Rise Lifts British Inflation
description: Britain's traditional measure of annual inflation dropped slightly in April, but higher taxes pushed the cost of living sharply higher, the Government said Friday.

title: 1980 CENSUS FINDS SHARP DECLINE IN SIZE OF AMERICAN HOUSEHOLDS
description: The size of the American household has declined sharply since 1970 because large numbers of people are living alone and there are fewer children per family, according to 1980 census figures released today.

title: The Region; 23 L.I. Firemen Hurt In Nine-Hour Blaze
description: Seven businesses in a Hicksville, L.I., shopping center were destroyed and 23 firefighters were injured in a nine-hour fire early yesterday.

title: MRS. GANDHI URGES MAJOR EFFORT TO COMBAT SURGE IN POPULATION
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi called today for a more vigorous national effort to curb runaway population growth, which she described as ''shocking.''

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED
description: A tourist from Colorado was seriously wounded today when he was stabbed in the chest, apparently without provocation, in front of a gift shop in the visitors' lounge here.

title: Cosmos Defeat Tornado
description: Roberto Cabanas scored four goals today to lead the Cosmos to a 5-1 victory over the Dallas Tornado at Giants Stadium.

title: Chicago Dance Festival To Run From June 25 to 28
description: The International Dance Festival of Chicago will celebrate its fifth anniversary with five programs at Chicago's Civic Opera House from June 25 through June 28. The festival, which will include vocal and instrumental music, will feature programs set to music by Bartok, Bizet, Saint-Saens, Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev and Faure.

title: A BLEAK MOOD PERVADES F.T.C.
description: Michael Pertschuk riffled through some papers on his office coffee table for the two latest labels editorial writers have attached to the Federal Trade Commission. ''The cowering puppy,'' read one. ''The 92-pound weakling,'' stated the other.

title: CITY'S AIR CLEANER THAN IN 1960'S BUT POLLUTION LEVEL IS UNKNOWN
description: In the 1960's, when New York had a critical air-pollution problem, Mayor John V. Lindsay always drew laughs from audiences around the country with the line, ''I never trust air I can't see.''

title: Black Guerrillas in South Africa Stage Attacks Near Three Cities
description: Black guerrillas attacked a police station and railroad lines outside three cities today as white South Africans prepared to celebrate the country's 20th anniversary as a republic.

title: OBSERVERS SAY NEPTUNE MAY HAVE THIRD MOON
description: A ''lucky'' observation led to the spotting of an object near Neptune that may turn out to be the planet's third moon, astronomers at the University of Arizona said.

title: Dodgers 7, Braves 1
description: ATLANTA (UPI) - Steve Garvey drove in three runs with a two-run homer and a single as Burt Hooton of Los Angeles got his seventh victory without a loss. Garvey singled in one of three Dodger runs in the first inning and hit his fifth homer of the year in the fifth inning. He also doubled and scored on a sacrifice fly in the ninth inning.

title: WASHINGTON RALLY MARKS ATLANTA MURDERS
description: The 30 missing or murdered black children and young adults in Atlanta were the cause for a rally at the Lincoln Memorial today and, in the words of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, are the basis for a ''new unity, a new power and a new determination'' in the fight for civil rights.

title: SMITHSONIAN UNCOVERS INTRICATE RELATIONSHIPS AMONG ANTS IN THE WILD
description: The outlanders climbed atop the plastic disk that lay on the forest floor and moved their anvil-shaped heads from side to side. They seemed to be watching the dangerous larger animals feeding in the center of the disk. Waiting until the coast seemed clear, the smaller intruders darted toward a morsel of food dropped by one of the big creatures. They quickly covered it with soil, camouflaging it from the larger animals. That evening, when it was safe, the smaller animals returned to their hidden food treasure and carried it off to their home.

title: CITY BALLET: JOSEPH DUELL IN 'WALPURGISNACHT' DEBUT
description: IF you were a devil, how would you go about tempting a man who adored beautiful women? Well, you might begin by showing him a whole corps de ballet of beautiful women.

title: HERB LUBALIN, GRAPHIC DESIGNER FOR PUBLICATIONS AND ADVERTISING
description: Herb Lubalin, a graphic designer who won wide recognition for his innovations in advertising, publications and books, died Sunday at New York University Hospital. He was 63 years old and had homes in Greenwich Village and Millerton, N.Y.

title: Pollution Spending To Increase 9%
description: American business plans to spend $10 billion on pollution control equipment this year, a modest 9 percent increase over 1980, according to a survey released yesterday by the McGraw-Hill Publications Company.

title: Howard Swenson, 78, Architect, Consultant
description: Howard W. Swenson, a New York architect who had been associated with Philip Johnson and I.M. Pei in construction and restoration projects, died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday night at Long Island College Hospital. He lived in Brooklyn.

title: E.E.C. Warned subsidies
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, warned the European Economic Community today that if its members continued to subsidize exports of manufactured goods and farm products, the Reagan Administration might retaliate.

title: TAKING A LEAF FROM FRANCE'S ELECTORAL BOOK
description: To the Editor:

title: Presbyterians Agree With Pastor On Confidentiality of Counseling
description: Presbyterian representatives today strongly defended a pastor who has been cited for contempt of court for refusing to divulge what was told him in private counseling.

title: Around The World; French Communist Leader Asks for Representation
description: Georges Marchais, the leader of France's Communist Party, met today with President Francois Mitterrand and asked for representation in the Government after next month's parliamentary elections.

title: Chess: Original Opening Positions Are Not Always Successful
description: It is impossible to be forever successful in creating original opening positions, even for someone as inventive as the Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen. Yet he never seems to have any regrets about the occasional failure he has to stomach from time to time.

title: Summing Triumphs at $75.20
description: Summing took the lead with a quarter of a mile to go and scored an upset in the $167,300 Pennsylvania Derby at Keystone today.

title: COMMUNISTS LEAD IN CYPRUS VOTE
description: With election results almost complete, the Communist party appeared certain today to become the strongest single group in the Cyprus Parliament.

title: Around the Nation
description: Federal agents have solved a counterfeiting scheme that operated in the basement of an Arkansas farmhouse and circulated at least $1.5 million in bogus $100 and $20 bills, the Secret Service said today.

title: KNOWN AS 'TOASTMASTER GENERAL'
description: George Jessel, the comedian who gained fame on the vaudeville stages of the nation, went on to stardom on Broadway and in Hollywood, and in recent decades was known as ''the toastmaster general of the United States,'', died of a heart attack Sunday night at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center in California at the age of 83. His most famous appearance was in the title role of the 1925 hit play, ''The Jazz Singer.''

title: Around the Nation; Body Found in Santa Cruz Linked to Trailside Killings
description: The authorities used dental charts today to identify the remains of Heather Scaggs, missing co-worker of David Joseph Carpenter, who is charged in one of eight trailside slayings in Northern California.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: The National Association of Purchasing Management has been publishing a monthly business survey for the last 50 years, missing only four months during World War II.

title: SSC&B Campaign For Heineken to Begin
description: The first ad campaign for Heineken beer from SSC&B will begin to run in magazines next month. The ads will be big pictures of frosty, beaded bottles and glasses of the No. 1-selling import with the simple quote in smallish type, ''Come to think of it, I'll have a Heineken,'' which sounds like something less than 100 percent conviction.

title: Jordanian King Visits Moscow
description: King Hussein left today for Moscow on the first state visit by the Jordanian ruler to the Soviet Union in more than five years.

title: ROY BROWN, A PIONEER ROCK SINGER
description: Roy Brown, the blues singer who wrote and recorded ''Good Rocking Tonight'' in 1947 and originated a style that influenced Elvis Presley, Jackie Wilson, James Brown, and other leading rock and soul vocalists, died of heart failure yesterday at Pacoima Lutheran Memorial Hospital, near his home in the San Fernando Valley just outside Los Angeles. He was 56 years old.

title: ROSA PONSELLE, DRAMATIC SOPRANO DIES
description: Rosa Ponselle, indisputably one of the greatest operatic talents this country has ever produced, died of a heart attack yesterday in her Baltimore mansion, Villa Pace, at the age of 84. She had suffered several strokes in recent years and was confined to a wheelchair.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DAD. By William Wharton. 449 pages. Knopf. 12.95.

title: MAXIM SHOSTAKOVICH PLAYS OVERTURE TO A NEW LIFE
description: At 8 o'clock tonight Maxim Shostakovich gave the downbeat on his father's ''Festive Overture'' at an occasion that that could hardly be more symbolic in spotlighting his defection from the Soviet Union.

title: Advertising Campbell Switching To B.& S.
description: BACKER & SPIELVOGEL has struck again. The agency with the fastest growth record in the history of the business has now become the national agency for Campbell Soup's line of condensed soup, the good old red and white cans, the ''Mm-mm, good'' American institution.

title: HIGHWAY DEATHS RISE AS SMALL AUTOMOBILES AND SPEEDING INCREASE
description: The number of Americans dying in automobile accidents is increasing again after falling sharply when the national 55-mile-per-hour speed limit was imposed, and safety authorities are warning that as drivers shift to smaller cars the rise in the death toll will accelerate.

title: About New York; SOLDIERS OF LONG AGO AND WOMEN THEY LEFT BEHIND
description: The central event of Holmes's life occurred on a warm autumn morning in 1944, when a man came to the door of her apartment with a telegram. Every American woman knew what a telegram meant in 1944, and so, before she had opened the yellow envelope, Mrs. Holmes broke down. She knew without words on paper that her 19-year-old son had been killed at old son had been killed at Guadalcanal.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: L AST week was the perfect week to be in Washington for three days. The moon was full. The District, as it is called, was leafy, warm and dry. Hundreds of people were playing softball on the newly cut grass around the monuments. And there were enough transcultural functions, subtle alchemical mixtures of East Coast, West Coast and Washington sensibilities, to help one gauge the Reagan Impact, as it has been called, on Washington society.

title: Fox Films' TV Buy
description: The 20th Century-Fox Films operation is putting $10 million into advertising during the ABC-TV Network coverage of the 1984 Winter and Summer Olympic Games. It will be the exclusive film company advertiser and the network says it is the biggest TV buy ever made by a movie maker. The Entertainment division of J. Walter Thompson made the buy.

title: The Editorial Notebook; GETTING TOGETHER ON DEADLY FORCE
description: ''If a policeman needs to defend his life, the use of force is permissible, but if he is chasing a suspect, he has no right to shoot the man.''

title: Around The Nation; 3 Held in Nashville in Plot To Bomb a Synagogue
description: Federal agents arrested three persons today for allegedly attempting to plant dynamite at a synagogue, and a newspaper reported that officials had uncovered a conspiracy by Ku Klux Klan members to destroy Jewish property.

title: ANDRETTI IS AWARDED INDIANAPOLIS VICTORY ON PENALTY TO UNSER
description: Mario Andretti was declared the winner of the Indianapolis 500 this morning as Bobby Unser, who had crossed the finish line in first place almost 17 hours before, became the first driver ever to have an Indianapolis victory voided by the officials.

title: The Region
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Three fires that broke out within a six-hour period gave Newark firemen one of their ''busiest nights in years,'' a fire official said. Sixty-nine persons were driven from their homes by the fires, some of which may have been set.

title: The Region; Search of Cells Finds Weapons at Attica
description: A number of ''homemade'' weapons were found in a search of prisoners' cells at the State Correctional Facility at Attica, prison officials said. The search followed the stabbing death Saturday of an inmate at the maximum-security prison.

title: WABC-TV STAFF SPLIT OVER OUSTER OF 5 EMPLOYEES
description: The two-month investigation that led to the forced resignations of five employees at WABC-TV was conducted by a private law firm hired specifically to look into allegations that letters used on some viewer-participation programs were fabricated, officials and employees of the station said yesterday.

title: A Jetliner With One Engine Out Makes Safe Landing at Kennedy
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner, carrying 92 passengers and a crew of 12, enroute to San Juan, P.R., was forced to return to Kennedy International Airport last night after one of its engines had to be shut down when it developed a malfunction and began to leak fuel, according to the Federal Aviation Administration duty officer at the airport.

title: Mobil May Drill Sable Island Well
description: Mobil Oil Canada Ltd. said today that it may drill another exploratory well near Sable Island, off the Nova Scotia coast, before making a hard estimate of natural gas reserves there.

title: Notes On People; Fortune Society Director Looks at Other Side
description: The longtime executive director of the Fortune Society, David Rothenberg, works with ex-convicts to help them return to society and is a crusader for improvements in the criminal justice system.

title: Notes On People; Quartet, and Helpers, Ready for Anything
description: The widely traveled LaSalle Quartet left last week for an extended tour of Japan, Australia and Europe, equipped with an entourage that should make things go smoothly. It has its own secretary-translator, a psychiatrist, an art historian and a travel agent.

title: 10 ARE DEAD AND EIGHT ARE MISSING AFTER FLOODS SWEEP TEXAS CAPITAL
description: Flash floods turned gentle streams into torrents that swept through Texas's capital early today, killing 10 persons, leaving eight others missing and carving a path of destruction that looked like ''a week of hurricanes.''

title: SMALL PUBLISHERS REAP PROFITS BY SPECIALIZING
description: The Georgia World Congress Center here is a bibliophile's delight, jammed as it is with nearly 1,500 booths proclaiming the fall wares of some 1,000 publishers. As a general rule, the larger and more successful publishers have the biggest and most noticeable displays.

title: ORIOLES ROUT GUIDRY AND YANKS, 10-1
description: A day after George Steinbrenner, the team's owner, had threatened that there would be ''hell to pay,'' the Yankees lost their second straight humiliating game tonight, this time by 10-1 to the first-place Baltimore Orioles.

title: AIR-BAG RULING IS STILL DISPUTED BY CAR MAKERS
description: When the Reagan Administration decided to postpone for at least a year a federal measure that large cars be equipped with air bags or some other form of passive restraint, it effectively extended the run of one of the longest-playing disputes between the Government and the automobile industry.

title: ONE MORE JOINS ATLANTA LIST OF SLAIN AND MISSING BLACKS
description: The number of Atlanta's missing and murdered young blacks rose to 29 today, as a new case was given to the special police task force investigating the string of unsolved crimes over the last 22 months.

title: RECALLING SOME GROUND RULES FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: BOND SELLING POINT: SLOWING INFLATION
description: Comparing inflation and bond yields has long been a standard tool of economists, but the practice has now been adopted by bond salesmen eager to show their products in the best possible light.

title: News Analysis
description: In informal discussions over the past week, Congressional tax experts have been outlining a tax-relief bill that they say would satisfy the seemingly conflicting requirements of the Reagan Administration and the House Democratic leadership.

title: MOST OF NEW ISSUES ARE TAX EXEMPT
description: Few corporate bond issues are scheduled in this holiday-shortened week, although there are several new tax-exempt offerings. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimated the week's volume at only $213 million for corporate issues and $844 million for tax-exempt issues.

title: RESERVED FOR BUSES
description: Beginning today, in yet another New York City experiment to reduce auto congestion and encourage the use of mass transit, two lanes of Madison Avenue will be reserved for buses for five busy hours on weekday afternoons.

title: PIANIST: OREN PLAYS PROGRAM TO MAKE AN AUDIENCE THINK
description: BENJAMIN OREN's recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Sunday afternoon had a slightly didactic air, which is perhaps not surprising in a pianist known for his lecture-recitals. Mr. Oren, who is on the faculty of the Rubin Academy of Music in Jerusalem, did not speak on this occasion, but his program was obviously intended to make an audience think.

title: TORTURE ON TV?
description: I had requested the meeting with Jacobo Timerman, Argentine newspaper editor and publisher in exile, to discuss his ''disappearance,'' imprisonment, and torture by the military junta as a possible subject for a television documentary. His book, ''Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number,'' had just been published. He sits in a windowed office at the publisher's 21st floor headquarters overlooking midtown Manhattan.

title: Notes On People; 10 POUNDS OF RESISTANCE
description: Once again, Julia Child said yesterday, she has fallen victim to an occupational hazard common in her line of work. The television ''French chef'' got fat again, she said, sampling all that good food she whips up, and she has had to go on a diet.

title: News Analysis
description: For the first time since last October, the Democrats had a good week. The most important event in their unaccustomed political prosperity was embarrassing the Reagan Administration and its Republican allies over proposed Social Security reductions, but the most important element in that success, and in others, was coordination among Democrats. In the fight against Social Security cutbacks, in a special election to the House in a suburban Maryland district and in their efforts to raise questions about an Administration nominee before the Senate, the Democrats worked together more than they usually do, looking almost Republican at times in their ability to function effectively in a minority role.

title: NO ADVISERS IN LEBANON, MOSCOW SAYS
description: The Soviet Union today rejected the Israeli contention that Soviet advisers were accompanying Syrian Army units into Lebanon.

title: PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED AT DATA ELECTRONICS INC.
description: Jack H. King, 47, has joined Data Electronics Inc., a manufacturer of digital drives for tape cartridges and related systems, as president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Hal Georgens, 58, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the San Diego company.

title: AVANT-GARDE 'NINE BELLS' PLAYED
description: MUSICAL phraseology is usually an expression of something physical in the performer - the stretch of the fingers, the capacity of the lungs or the speed of the hand. Tom Johnson's ''Nine Bells'' at the Susan Caldwell Gallery on Friday evening was measured instead by quickness of foot and breadth of stride.

title: TURKISH CRIME SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Marshall Wins 800 Meters In Eastern States Meet
description: John Marshall of Plainfield (N.J.) High School took the 800-meter run in 1 minute 53 seconds, and Mike Morris won the 100-meter dash in 10.3 seconds yesterday in the 15th annual Eastern States schoolboy outdoor track and field championships at St. John's University.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Mets' Tolerant Approach
description: OVER in the Bronx, volcanic ash was still falling after another eruption by Mount Steinbrenner even though the Yankees were a game and a half out of first place going into last night's game in Baltimore. But in Flushing, all was serene even though the Mets already were 12 games out of first place before yesterday's 13-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: The City; Legislator Assails Transit Inspections
description: Assemblyman John C. Dearie of the Bronx said the city's buses and subway cars were unsafe because the same people who did the repairing also inspected the quality of the repairs, according to United Press International.

title: Notes On People; A Government Expert
description: Only days after he left the Vice Presidency, Walter F. Mondale found two excellent ways to keep his name and presence before the public.

title: Crowsnest Trio Dancing At Public Through Sunday
description: Crowsnest, the modern-dance trio headed by Martha Clarke with Felix Blaska and Robert Barnett, will appear in its first New York season today through Sunday at the Public/Newman Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Highlighting the engagement will be the American premiere of ''It Don't Mean a Thing'' and dances set to scores by Crumb, Mendelssohn and Schubert.

title: MEN ARE DISCOVERING THE FACIAL
description: While women have been knocking down sexism in traditionally male bastions, men have been invading areas formerly sacred to women. In the 60's, when men let their hair grow and found they were not satisfied with barbers, they turned up at beauty salons and asked to be styled, rather than clipped. These days, one isn't surprised to find a man happily stretched out in the hushed cubicle of a facial salon with a half-inch of goo on his face. Both facial salons and cosmetics counters are reporting that more and more of their customers are men, while dermatologists are treating men for acne and other skin problems, as well as doing hair transplants.

title: The U.N. Today; May 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Bush Places Wreath At Arlington Cemetery
description: Vice President Bush today laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery and called on ''all Americans to look within themselves and offer a moment of prayer for those who have made the supreme sacrifice.''

title: RECALLING SOME GROUND RULES FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDIS OFFER TO LIFT OIL PRICE IF OTHERS IN OPEC CUT THEIRS
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the oil minister of Saudi Arabia, offered today to raise the price of Saudi crude from the present low of $32 a barrel if other oil producers would lower theirs.

title: SPAIN SEIZES 3 RIGHT-WING LEADERS AFTER BANK RAID
description: A major investigation of rightist groups was opened here today in connection with the seizure of a bank headquarters that ended last night when police commandos stormed the building and freed some 70 hostages.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Why do onions make us cry?

title: CUBAN WINS BY KNOCKOUT
description: -Emilio Ruiz of Cuba knocked out Monoa Betuely of Papua, New Guinea, today in the featherweight division of the first President Ferdinand Marcos international amateur boxing tournament. Ruiz dropped Betuely three times before scoring a knockout at 1:50 of the first round on the second day of the 22-nation tournament.

title: JERSEY'S CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR FOLLOW VOTERS TO HOLIDAY OUTINGS
description: Candidates for governor of New Jersey campaigned where the people were this holiday weekend, marching in parades, eating picnic snacks and strolling on boardwalks.

title: SIX SUBSCRIPTION SERIES SET FOR GOODMAN HOUSE
description: The Abraham Goodman House will present six subsciption series in its newly named and partly redesigned Merkin Concert Hall.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Abbott Laboratories named John G. Kringel president of the Sorenson Research Company.

title: Stein Sets Pinch-Hit Record
description: Bill Stein, setting an American League record with his seventh consecutive pinch-hit, singled home the winning run in the ninth inning to give the Texas Rangers a 4-3 victory tonight over the Minnesota Twins.

title: Dance Student Wins Award
description: Wanda Dryer, a dance student at Brooklyn College, has won the first Dancemagazine Scholarship Award for technical excellence, one of only two such scholarships being given this year. The $1,000 scholarship was awarded to the 22-year-old junior, a resident of Flatbush, on the basis of her performance at the American Dance Festival Association's Northeast Regional Festival held in January in Philadelphia.

title: HIJACKERS OF TURKISH JET OVERPOWERED IN BULGARIA AND 91 HOSTAGES FREED
description: Turkey, saying that it had shown that terrorism must be ''confronted decisively,'' announced today that four terrorists who yesterday hijacked a Turkish airliner to Bulgaria had been captured and all of the hostages freed.

title: STATE TO ALLOT $3.6 MILLION FOR CETA JOBS PROGRAM
description: Governor Carey, warning that 25,000 workers in the state would soon lose their jobs because of reductions in federally financed job programs, announced yesterday that the state would spend $3.6 million in an ''emergency effort'' to train those workers and help them find new jobs.

title: Lear Siegler Contract
description: Lear Sigler Inc. has been awarded a $6.8 million contract by the Naval Air Systems Command to produce 34 tactical navigation systems for the Navy's P-3B aircraft. The contract, announced on Friday, is an extension of an earlier production agreement to provide the tactical navigation systems, which are designed to monitor foreign submarine activity.

title: Greeks Start Producing Oil and Gas
description: Greece began producing its own oil and natural gas today from a field in the Aegean Sea estimated to hold nine million metric tons, or about 70 million barrels, and given a life of about 15 years.

title: CLIBURN RECALLS '58 EVENT AS PIANO SEMIFINALS START
description: The semifinals of the Van Cliburn Piano Competition got under way yesterday afternoon, and the luck of the draw had Edward Newman of Gaithersburg, Md., playing first - the Schumann Piano Quintet with the Tokyo Quartet. In this phase of the competition, each of the 12 pianists gives a solo recital of about an hour's duration and play a piano quintet. The daily programs alternate recital with quintet.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE HAS NEW CHAIRMAN
description: Emory Williams, 69 years old, has been elected chairman of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation, the holding company whose subsidiaries include the financially troubled Chicago, Milwaukee, St Paul & Pacific Railroad. Effective June 1, he will succeed Donald F. Hunter, 50, who resigned his post at the Chicago-based company to concentrate on his law practice in Minnesota.

title: HIGHWAY DEATHS RISE AS SMALL AUTOMOBILES INCREASE
description: The number of Americans dying in automobile accidents is increasing again after falling sharply when the national 55-mile-per-hour speed limit was imposed, and safety authorities are warning that as drivers increasingly shift to smaller cars the rise in the death toll will accelerate.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Florida Driver Shoots 4
description: A motorist careened his car around Key Biscayne beach yesterday, causing a picnicking family to object.

title: 2 POLISH OFFICIALS OF GIEREK PERIOD CALLED SUICIDES
description: Two former ministers in the regime of Edward Gierek, the Communist Party leader who was ousted in September, have committed suicide, the official Polish press agency said today.

title: Accounts Moving To Other Agencies
description: On the account-movement scene there is news from Triton Advertising, Marsteller and from Lois Pitts Gershon. Triton, which is at 15 West 44th St., has gained the account of Tuscan Dairy Farms in Union, N.J. They make the yogurt pops.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If our clients don't want to buy our crude at $36, they can go elsewhere.'' -Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's oil minister, rejecting Saudi Arabia's offer to raise its oil prices if other producers lowered theirs. (A1:4.)

title: Two Teen-Agers Are Fatally Shot In a State Forest in Connecticut
description: Two teen-agers were found shot to death yesterday in a thickly wooded area of Cockaponset State Forest, the state police reported.

title: REDFORD'S NEXT PROJECT, ANOTHER FAMILY TRAGEDY
description: LOS ANGELES AFTER winning an Academy Award for ''Ordinary People,'' his first movie as a director, Robert Redford has finally decided on his next project, a similar family tragedy. Mr. Redford is developing and intends to direct ''Sweetsir,'' a novel about a battered wife by Helen Yglesias.

title: WINTER OLYMPICS ENDING ITS DEFICIT IN LAKE PLACID
description: Fifteen months after the end of the 1980 Winter Olympics, the flags of 37 nations still flutter in the breeze between the arena built for the games and the speed-skating oval where Eric Heiden won five gold medals.

title: Article 132617 -- No Title
description: Genuine Risk, winner of the 1980 Kentucky Derby, was beaten as the odds-on favorite at Belmont yesterday in a race that stole some of the attention from Fappiano's victory in the $142,750 Metropolitan Mile.

title: LIFE SIZE BRONZE HORSES AND CHARIOTS FOUND IN CHINESE TOMD
description: The continuing excavation of the tomb of China's first emperor, which startled the archeological world in 1974 with the discovery of the ruler's life-size pottery army, has yielded another spectacular find: two full-scale bronze chariots drawn by life-size bronze horses and driven by bronze charioteers.

title: Time for a New Surgeon General
description: Initially, the nomination of Dr. C. Everett Koop to be Surgeon General, the head of the Public Health Service, had been stalled on a technicality. He was, under present law, seven months too old for the job.

title: Around the World; Japan Says It Won't Bar The Carrier Midway
description: The Japanese Government, under attack in Parliament for allowing nuclear-armed American ships to enter Japanese waters, today rejected a demand by the opposition that the aircraft carrier Midway be banned from returning to its home port here.

title:
Notes on People;
Elizabeth Taylor Returns, and Show Goes On
description: Elizabeth Taylor was reported to be ''feeling fine'' when she went on stage last night when she went on to perform her starring role in the hit drama ''The Little Foxes,'' before a sold-out house at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: U.S. LAWYERS FRUSTRATED IN SAUDI ARABIA
description: Burt & Taylor, a small but sophisticated Massachusetts law firm, established a branch practice in Saudi Arabia in 1978. As one of the partners acknowledged, the firm was looking for bigger business.

title: 6 SHOOTINGS IN BROOKLYN THIS YEAR LINKED TO SNIPER
description: Six persons have been wounded over the last four months by an unknown sniper operating from the upper floors of a middle-income apartment building in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: Mazzilli and Kingman Pace 13-3 Victory
description: The Mets returned home yesterday after a punishing trip west, startled 20,469 fans in Shea Stadium by scoring eight runs in the first two innings, and kept barreling to a 13-3 pounding of the World Series champion Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Notes On People; A Mayor Plans to Run Long After Election
description: Appointees of Richard Hillman, Mayor-elect of Annapolis, Md., had better be in good physical shape, or be prepared to get that way. The 38-year-old Mr. Hillman, who was elected Mayor of Maryland's capital city last week, is a jogging enthusiast and he said he intends to combine his passion for the sport with his official duties.

title: Economic Adviser Named
description: President Reagan today nominated Jerry L. Jordan, a university dean and former banker, as a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Jordan is dean of the Robert O. Anderson School of Management at the University of New Mexico and is also senior vice president and chief economist at the Pittsburgh National Bank. He previously worked at the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis and, in the early 1970's, served as a consultant to the West German central bank in Frankfurt.

title: Hearst's Country Living To Become a Monthly
description: Hearst Magazines, firm believers in the slow-but-sure system of magazine introduction, will add a new monthly magazine to its roster in February.

title: Around the Nation; Boston Archdiocese to Aid Its Conscientious Objectors
description: The Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, saying it wanted to insure the legal rights of its members, announced today that it would keep files for young people who might later seek status as conscientious objectors in a military draft.

title: Around The World; Ex-Bolivian Commander Tries 2d Coup in 2 Weeks
description: A former military commander who escaped from prison after leading an attempted coup in Cochabamba two weeks ago undertook another coup in Cochabamba today and called for the resignation of the leader of Bolivia's military junta, Gen. Luis Garcia Meza.

title: POP: MILLIE JACKSON SINGS AND SAYS THE UNSAYABLE
description: rated language and racial epithets, have become more important than her music. Miss Jackson has adopted Richard Pryor's method of saying the unsayable, on both sexual and racial matters.

title: IN BEIRUT, A ROUND OF GOLF AND VALIUM
description: ''It's a pity you couldn't have come visiting yesterday,'' Afif Boulos was saying. ''We had a group of 20 or so over to sing English madrigals.'' As he spoke, a few random gunshots could be heard coming from a side street, a sound as commonplace here as a car backfiring.

title: ELLEN BURYSTN: 'I'D RATHER SEE A PLAY'
description: Donald Sutherland was seen having lunch at the pool at the Majestic Hotel here on Saturday. Goldie Hawn was observed at one of the famous restaurants. Neither star has a film in contention here.

title: CURT FLOOD FINDS HIS NICHE
description: ''I'm no martyr,'' Curt Flood was saying. ''All the martyrs in history are dead.'' To the 3,000 boys and girls in the Young America Baseball program across the bay in Oakland, he is the First Commissioner of the sandlot leagues, the man who shows films of Rod Carew and brings Joe Morgan around.

title: SOLOMON IS OUSTED
description: Bjorn Borg, playing his first match in six weeks, had little trouble with Jose Lopez Maseo today in the first round of the $600,000 French open tennis championships at Roland Garros Stadium. Intermittent rain kept officials rolling tarpaulins on and off the courts.

title: Tyco-Fisher Link
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc., which has an 8.9 percent interest in the Fisher Scientific Company, informed the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing last Friday that it planned to acquire ''a significant stock position'' in Fisher. Tyco, which produces fire protection systems, said it did not yet have any intention of seeking control of Fisher but said that if it decided to do so it would disclose that fact in an S.E.C. filing. Tyco said its subsidiary, the AMBG Corporation, had paid nearly $16 million to purchase 465,198 shares of Fisher, which makes laboratory apparatus.

title: POP: GARY U.S. BONDS AT RITZ
description: WERE it not for Bruce Springsteen, Gary U.S. Bonds, the Virginiaborn rock-and-roll singer, who enjoyed several big hits in the early 60's, would not have been at the Ritz on Friday. Mr. Springsteen, whose lighter material often recalls Mr. Bonds's hits, discovered him performing in a New Jersey club recently and rescued him from obscurity, when their friendship turned into a studio collaboration.

title: Bendix Plans to Buy A Stake in Maxwell
description: The Bendix Corporation said it had signed an agreement to purchase 250,000 shares of the common stock of Maxwell Laboratories Inc. at $13 a share, or a total of $3.25 million.

title: RANGERS 2, TWINS 1
description: -Pat Putnam hit a bases-empty homer in the second inning, and Mario Mendoza singled home a run in the fourth to lead Texas past Minnesota.

title: COLUMBIA ASKS BARNARD FOR RISE IN COEDUCATION
description: Columbia College, the Ivy League's only remaining all-male college, will soon begin accepting women unless Barnard College, its sister institution, agrees to more coeducation.

title: Amnesty Body Marks Anniversary By Denouncing Rights Violations
description: Amnesty International marked its 20th anniversary today with a sweeping condemnation of ''torture, murder, abduction and imprisonment'' of political prisoners by scores of countries.

title: Park Slope Man, 77, Is Accused Of Fatally Knifing Roommate, 64
description: A 77-year-old man fatally stabbed his 64-year-old roommate last night in a dispute over who ate the food in the refrigerator in their apartment in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES UP BY 9.8%
description: The nation's three largest auto manufacturers today reported an increase in sales of 9.8 percent over last year in the May 11-20 selling period, but analysts were not encouraged by the increase.

title: ROME EVERY Tuesday and Friday, Giovanna Conti trundles her old-fashioned shopping cart, a bulging basketwork container on two wheels, to the outdoor market on the Via Triofale near her home and fills it with potatoes, fresh vegetables and fruit.  On top of these she will often put two or three eggs that the peasant woman who sells them - only to select customers - swears are just hours old.
description: "This morning, Signora Giovanna, they were still warm," she says. Each fresh egg from the countryside around the Italian capital costs 20 cents. Supermarkets offer imported eggs from Bulgaria at $1.20 a dozen, but Mrs. Conti never buys them.

title: FEELING SAFE UNDER PROTECTION OF WOMEN
description: AWEALTHY European businessman arrives at Kennedy International Airport, where he is warmly greeted by a fashionable young woman. Linking arms, the pair disappear into a waiting limousine that carries them to the Regency Hotel. What is the woman's relationship to the businessman? 1) wife; 2) girlfriend 3) secretary; 4) bodyguard.

title: ARCO IS CHARGED WITH INFLATING COSTS
description: -The Department of Energy said that it had charged the Atlantic Richfield Company with inflating its foreign oil costs by $167 million between 1973-81.

title: NEW PHASE SEEN
description: Two Soviet astronauts piloted their Soyuz-T 4 spacecraft to a soft landing in Central Asia yesterday for the successful conclusion of the final mission to the Earth-orbiting Salyut 6 space station, which for nearly four years has been the sturdy base for record-setting tests of human endurance and the centerpiece of the Russian space program.

title: SYRIA, LONG ISOLATED, IS REGAINING ARABS' SUPPORT IN THE MISSILE CRISIS
description: Syria, long isolated in the Arab world, has won the backing of Saudi Arabia and other Arab League members in its confrontation with Israel over Syrian missiles in Lebanon. But the Saudis are widely believed to be trying to find a face-saving way out of the crisis.

title: TOP JOB FILLED AT SYNTEX BEAUTY CARE
description: James N. Wilson, 37, has been appointed president of Syntex Beauty Care, a unit of the Syntex Corporation that produces hair and skin care products. He succeeds Alvin Hartley, 50, who resigned but who will be a consultant to the Los Angeles-based company.

title: Gas Pipeline Accord Is Set
description: A major stumbling block to construction of the 2,769-mile Alaska natural gas pipeline has been overcome, but the difficult task of attracting bank financing remains, officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday reporting the marriage of Dr. Arnold Jan Levine incorrectly identified the bride. She was Felicia Alta Zimmerman.

title: WITH SONGS AND STATISTICS, LOBBYISTS ASK CITY FOR AID
description: Armed with statistical analyses and small children singing ''God Bless America'' on cue, a long line of civic groups, lobbyists and concerned individuals went before the City Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday to plead for more money for schools, parks and libraries.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Don Had looked forward to his retirement and the many fishing trips it would make possible. But he wasn't prepared for his wife's reaction when he tried to put his retirement plan into action. "I don't want to go fishing, and I'm not going to be a camp cook," she told him.

title: GERMANS LINK P.L.O. TO DOMESTIC TERROR
description: Senior West German security officials possess ''clear indications'' that a number of fugitive members of left-wing West German terrorist groups are hiding under the protection of the Palestine Liberation Organization in areas it controls in Lebanon.

title: STRIKES DISRUPT BRITISH FLIGHTS
description: Trans-Atlantic flights to and from Britain were disrupted again today when air traffic controllers staged new strikes as part on an 11-week pay dispute.

title: 'Long Day's Journey' Closing
description: Joseph Papp's production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' will close Sunday evening after 87 performances at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. Directed by Geraldine Fitzgerald, the play features Gloria Foster, Earle Hyman, Thommie Blackwell, Peter Francis-James and Samantha McKoy. It opened on March 3 at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street, and moved to the Public Theater on March 18.

title: LANSING HEARS DETROIT PLEA FOR FISCAL RESCUE PLAN
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit and his financial advisers traveled to the State Capitol today to plead for a fiscal rescue package in the wake of last week's defeat of a measure on state property tax relief.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CertainTeed Corporation, Valley Forge, Pa., has elected to its board Jacques Chevenard, president of the insulation division of Saint-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson of France.

title: LOMAK PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Mrs. Lloyd Scores, Nastase Pulls Upset
description: Chris Evert Lloyd said she was obliged to win her first-round match at the French open today because her parents and sister were coming from Florida later in the week to watch her play.

title: GRETE WAITZ READY FOR TOUGHEST MILE
description: Grete Waitz says she thinks the L'eggs Mini Marathon Saturday morning in Central Park will be a tough race, ''the first competitive Mini I've been in.''

title: SOLDIER, HELD IN 3 BUFFALO SLAYINGS, IS INDICTED IN A MANHATTAN MURDER
description: A 25-year-old Army private already under indictment in the fatal shooting of three black men in Buffalo was indicted yesterday in the murder of a dark-skinned Hispanic man, one of four men stabbed to death on Dec. 22 in mid-Manhattan.

title: ITALY'S CABINET QUITS AS MASONIC SCANDAL RUPTURES COALITION
description: The Cabinet of Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani resigned today as a result of the revelation that hundreds of highranking officials were members of a secret Masonic lodge.

title: PLAN IS DISCLOSED FOR OFFICE TOWER AT TRADE CENTER
description: Detailed plans for a 43-story office tower in lower Manhattan - the seventh and final building of the World Trade Center complex - were disclosed yesterday by the Port Authority.

title: RULING BY JUDGE MAY BLOCK TRIAL IN A MURDER CASE
description: Angel Claudio, a 16-year-old Brooklyn youth, admitted to the Queens District Attorney that he had killed Stephen Zwickert, a high school honors student who was shot as he was returning home from a prom last year on May 15. In fact, days after the killing, Angel Claudio got in touch with a private lawyer and through him, arranged to surrender.

title: MITTERRAND PLANS TO ASSURE ARABS FRANCE WILL CONTINUE ARMS SALES
description: President Francois Mitterrand plans to send special envoys to Arab countries to assure them about France's Middle East policy, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today.

title: On Medical Age
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: If I have failed to come up with a medical age, it is because I can't make head or tail out of the plus or minus Health Inventory (Personal Health, May 13). Because of confusion and/or ignorance, I will now either add or subtract (plus or minus) to my Life Style Inventory. This raises my age to 123.7, or lowers it to 3.7. I am staggering under the realization that I am either an exceptionally precocious toddler, or dead.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 27
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in Oct 1980

title: EXOTIC PORTS ON 5TH AVE.; 1. In a Make-Believe Bazaar
description: If you're hunting for a special gift you might check out the area called Port of Call at Bergdorf's, which is rather like browsing through an Eastern bazaar. Only better, because Miriam Marshall, who selects its jewelry, bags and objets, frequently redesigns or refinishes the things she finds in India, Thailand, the Philippines or China. One of her treasures is an evening bag shaped like a large bean and paved with chips of old mother-of-pearl ($250). The bag was made in India, but the brass frame was polished here and was given a new clasp to replace its flimsier original one. Another fascinating bag is a hand-crocheted pouch covered with tiny shells, whose handle is a large, ivory-colored bracelet ($65). The shop sells all sorts of accessories, from an $8 bracelet to a $30,000 necklace.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $456,000 for the qr and $902,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $36,000 for the qr and $276,000 for the 6 mos

title: TURKEY ASKING BULGARIA FOR EXTRADITION OF HIJACKERS
description: Turkey will ask for the extradition of four terrorists who hijacked a Turkish airliner to Bulgaria on Sunday, it was announced here today.

title: SYRIAN-SOVIET FRIENDSHIP IS ON PAPER, NOT STREETS
description: Most days of the week, hundreds of Western tourists and businessmen flock to the bazaar here. But no Russians go there; they are under orders to stay away from public places because of the hostility that Soviet citizens have encountered in this country.

title: Expos Defeat Cards, 4-3
description: Tim Raines and Warren Cromartie hit twoout run-scoring singles in the seventh inning tonight to lead the Montreal Expos to a 4-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Flights Abroad Offer Fare Cuts
description: A new Civil Aeronautics Board survey shows that most United States airlines are substantially discounting their fares on international flights in both the Atlantic and Pacific markets. Results of the survey, taken every other month, were released today.

title: Bridge: Reisinger Player Proves 88 Is Young for a Competitor
description: In the first round of Reisinger Knockout Team play at the New York Hilton Hotel on Monday, a sprightly 88-year-old named Jay Feigus became the oldest man ever to defeat a strong team on such an occasion.

title: CROWLEY CLOUTS 2
description: Manager Gene Michael's reluctance to call on a depleted bullpen, and Reggie Jackson's tentative defense cost the Yankees tonight as they lost to the Orioles, 6-4, at Memorial Stadium.

title: TALKS ON BROOKS ARE CONTINUING
description: Craig Patrick, the Rangers' operations director, and Herb Brooks's lawyer spoke yesterday about the Ranger coaching job, but nothing was resolved, according to the lawyer, Art Kaminsky.

title: ATLANTA SAFETY COMMISSIONER SAYS SELECTION OF VICTIMS ISN'T RANDOM
description: The young black victims of the unsolved abductions and murders here are probably being selectively chosen, Lee Patrick Brown, the Atlanta Commissioner of Public Safety, strongly implied today.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income after $1,890,350 writeoff on excess of investments over assets acquired

title: STRANGE HOSPITAL DEATHS RAISE QUERIES IN CALIFORNIA DESERT TOWN
description: ''It's a mystery, all right. But other than going slower past the cemetery when they were doing the exhumations, I haven't noticed things are too much different, day to day,'' said Penny Brechtel, executive secretary of the Perris Valley Chamber of Commerce.

title: Philippines' Plan For Debt Outlined
description: The Philippines plans to borrow between $400 million and $500 million this year, Jaime Laya, a governor of the nation's central bank, said at a news conference here today.

title: GREASE FOR THE GANDER
description: Having managed to convey the impression that they are against mother's milk, down on orphans and fairly relaxed about torture conducted by friends of American foreign policy, the Reagan people are now trying to restore bribery's good name.

title: STAGE: 'TROUBLE' AT ARK
description: MARISA GIOFFRE'S ''Trouble'' at the Ark Theater Company is an Italian-American family play that is as porous as ricotta cheese. It seems to soak up everything - saucy comic situations from scores of other comedies - but some of it is worth savoring.

title: UNITED ASBESTOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Way to Save Set-Aside Contracts
description: A valued Federal program aimed at helping small minority businesses become competitive is on the endangered species list. The section 8(a) ''set-aside'' program, as it is called, makes Government contracts available for such firms without formal bidding. But what began as a helping hand became a permanent crutch or, worse, a cover for cheating. Congress last year gave the Small Business Administration until June 1 to correct the flaws. To its credit, the Reagan Administration seems committed to the overhaul; it could save the set-aside program.

title: Walkout Ends At British Ford
description: Nearly 10,000 workers at the Ford Motor Company's largest auto plant in Britain returned to work today, ending a 15-day wildcat strike.

title: State Police Recruits in New York Help in Arrest of 21 in 8 Drug Raids
description: A score of state police recruits drawn from their training academy here took part in a ''field exercise'' accompanied by senior officers that resulted in the arrests of 21 suspected dealers in marijuana and cocaine.

title: RED SMITHSports of The Times; A Lesson From History for Baseball
description: NDERSTAND in the first place that baseball 'law' is illegal, contrary to civil law, in direct violation of the Federal laws regulating combines and the blacklist, and in principle, directly in defiance of the Constitution and the Rights of Man.''

title: SONG: LEON REDBONE AND GUITAR
description: THE singer and guitarist Leon Redbone, who performed two special Memorial Day sets at the Lone Star Cafe, is an American pop archivist whose repertory consists mostly of pre-World War II songs. Mr. Redbone doesn't just dig up the past, he embodies it, by dressing himself in the clothes of an oldtime traveling minstrel and singing in a voice that is a stylistic composite of early Southern blues and vaudeville performers.

title: FOREIGNERS FIGHTING IN A UNIT OF SOUTH AFRICAN ARMY
description: In response to allegations of atrocities, South Africa has furnished informat on about a battalion made up mainly of foreigners that it has been using for raids into Angola against the guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization.

title: HOW CLEAN ARE FOOD CARTS?
description: Most carts selling food carry licenses issued by the New York City Department of Health, and their vendors have permits. Carts are inspected with varying frequencies.

title: WEST GERMAN PARLIAMENT SUPPORTS NATO PLAN ON MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt reported to Parliament today on his recent trip to Washington and afterward his governing coalition won legislative approval for a NATO decision to deploy new nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: 2 Leaders of Move Organization Held for Trial in Explosives Case
description: Vincent Leaphart Africa, whom the authorities describe as the founder of Move, a group that describes itself as revolutionary, was held in $750,000 bail today for trial on Federal charges of conspiring to manufacture and possess explosives.

title: TOWARD INFLATION PROOF INVESTMENT SPURS
description: The Editor: Your May 5 editorial ''Real Depreciation, Real Inflation'' supports the proposition that the entire depreciation allowance should come in the year of investment. I agree.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After $2 million writeoff of securities in relation to the sale of its Vilas Furniture division; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: The Time It Takes to Cook
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In his article ('Convenience' Food: Better (And Cheaper) When Made at Home, May 20) Bryan Miller has indeed correctly claimed that some of his suggested recipes can be prepared in 15 to 20 minutes.

title: Moderate Quake Hits Coast
description: A moderate earthquake jarred the northern California coast today, giving residents a predawn wake-up call but causing no damage. The University of California-Berkeley seismographic station said the temblor was measured at 4.5 on the Richter scale and occurred at 4:41 A.M.

title: The U.N. Today; May 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: INDEPENDENT POLITICAL GROUPS' CLASH ON TRUTH IN ADS HINTS AT 1982 ISSUE
description: In what apparently portends a running battle over a key issue in next year's election campaign, the National Conservative Political Action Committee and Democrats for the 80's have clashed over honesty in political advertising.

title: Fluor Unit Contract
description: The Fluor Corporation said that its Fluor Canada Ltd. unit had won a contract to design and construct an ethylene-glycol plant for Union Carbide Canada Ltd. at Prentiss, Alberta.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Around the World; Bolivian Leader Promises To Step Down on Aug. 6
description: President Luis Garcia Meza, his authority eroded by two military revolts in as many weeks, announced today that he would relinquish his office Aug. 6 and appealed to the armed forces to unite behind him and help choose his successor by July 17.

title: Accounts
description: * The New York City Fire Department to Smith/Greenland as its volunteer agency.

title: Prepare Early to Retire, New State Guide Urges
description: The state has published a new guide urging New Yorkers to start preparing for retirement decades before they turn 65, it was announced today.

title: GEORGE, KEYNES, REAGAN, RABBIT AND HAT
description: In the 1870's, a young newspaper editor named Henry George walked the streets of San Francisco lamenting the paradoxical economic mayhem that lay all around him. Why should people starve for lack of work in the very shadow of industries that were closing because people didn't have enough money to buy their goods? In 1879, he published his classic, ''Progress and Poverty,'' to try to supply an answer.

title: Esmark and Purex To Discuss Merger
description: Purex Industries Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to discuss a merger with Esmark Inc. in exchange for a guarantee from Esmark that it not purchase any additional Purex shares for the next three months.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Action Corporation has delayed until next week the offering of 700,000 common shares with warrants.

title: ALBERTA NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
WINE TALK
description: ERNEST AND JULIO GALLO have accomplished almost everything that can be accomplished in the wine trade. Their E.& J. Gallo Winery in Modesto, Calif., is the largest wine-making operation in the world, churning out some 52 million cases a year - a million a week - of red, white, rose, fortified, fruit-flavored, sparkling and sweet wines. Their products are denigrated by connoisseurs, who wince at the sight of screw caps and such redundant names as ''chablis blanc,'' but no one gainsays the Gallos' extraordinary success.

title: The Region; Water Rate Increases Approved in Albany
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Public Service Commission announced that it had granted rate increases to two water companies. The action means that almost 150,000 customers will pay about 20 percent more than before.

title: DILLARD DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
ALBANY BILL SEEKS TO CUT SIZE OF MALPRACTICE AWARDS
description: Convinced that New York State is headed toward a medical crisis if malpractice insurance rates continue to rise, the chairmen of the State Senate and Assembly Health Committees are trying to push through legislation aimed at reducing the size of malpractice-suit awards.

title: SERVICE FRACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Feb

title: CONNECTICUT POLICE RESTRUCTURED
description: The Connecticut State Police, in an effort to become more responsive to residents and municipal police departments, are reorganizing to give regional commanders more authority, officials announced today.

title: 2 IN JUSTICE DEPT. URGED SPECIAL PROSECUTOR FOR INQUIRY ON VESCO-WHITE HOUSE TIE
description: Two senior officials of the Justice Department strongly recommended the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate allegations that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, tried to bribe White House officials in the Carter Administration, according to newly released Government documents. But no special prosecutor was appointed.

title: BYRNE ENDORSES DEGNAN IN RACE TO SUCCEED HIM
description: Governor Byrne, as expected, today endorsed John J. Degnan, his former Attorney General, in the Democratic primary for Governor on June 2, calling him the ''most electable'' candidate.

title: SPOLETO U.S.A.: MUST IT BRING ART TO THE PEOPLE?
description: CHARLESTON, S.C. PALMETTOS line the streets of Charleston, planted firmly in front of the huge mansions of the plantation era; the elegant homes, with their long screened piazzas and narrow lush gardens, angle toward the harbor to catch the sea breezes. But Charleston has not come by its survival easily. It has withstood the end of the cotton and indigo trades, the attacks by the British during the Revolution and the Yankees during the Civil War, and long years of municipal poverty.

title: COAL BOOM SENDS MILE-LONG TRAINS ACROSS COLORADO, ROILING SMALL-TOWN LIFE
description: The trains don't stop here anymore. They just roll right on through, bound for power plants in Texas and Oklahoma with their cargo of Wyoming coal.

title: KAPOK TREE INNS CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Apr 12
REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
A YEAR AFTER KOREAN UPRISING, CHUN'S GRIP IS FIRM
description: A year after the civil insurrection in Kwangju and despite recent minor demonstrations, President Chun Doo Hwan appears to have consolidated his grip on power, according to Western diplomats.

title: 2 Die in Crash of Navy Copter
description: Two crewmen died today in the crash of Navy helicopter from Patuxent Naval Air Test Center at a crossroads town in St. Mary's County.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

title: THE PLEASURES OF OUTDOOR EATING
description: ''EATING out'' suddenly has new meaning in New York. It takes only a week or two of sunshine and gentle weather before parks, squares, streets and avenues blossom with bouquets of striped umbrellas that shade the food carts dispensing an international menu of hot and cold temptations.

title: MINERS THREATEN TO BREAK OFF TALKS
description: The chief negotiator for the United Mine Workers rejected a new coal industry contract package today and threatened to break off further talks if the offer was not improved at another meeting scheduled to start at noon tomorrow.

title: Auto Output Rises in Japan
description: Japan's production of motor vehicles totaled 991,367 units in April, up 2.7 percent from a year before, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association reported today. It was a record for April.

title: CORNELIUS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $126,000 extraordinary credit for the qr and 6 mos and $569,000 for the 6 mos from cumulative effect of an account change

title: Famous Father Helps Out
description: When officials of the Dalton School were planning a benefit concert featuring student performers, they decided it would be a good idea to get one of the Dalton parents to join the concert and offer an educational critique of the students.

title: MODERN MERCHANDISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Conoco Loses Bid To Thwart Dome
description: A Federal judge today denied a request for a preliminary injunction to prevent a Canadian oil company from pursuing a possible takeover of Conoco Inc.

title: WELL-KEPT SECRET IN PHOENIX AND SCOTTSDALE
description: PHOENIX BEFORE visiting here recently, I had heard of a restaurant, called Vincent's, spoken of in the most grandiloquent manner. The chef, I was told, had been trained at Maxim's in Paris and later worked at a restaurant in the Middle West. After numerous phone calls and inquiries at my hotel, I decided that if the restaurant existed, it must be the best kept secret in this sprawling, lively town. The telephone operator could give me no clue.

title: Jessel Service on Coast Today
description: A service for George Jessel will be held today at 1 P.M. in the Hillside Memorial Park Chapel, 6001 Centinela Avenue, Los Angeles. Milton Berle will deliver the eulogy. The 83-year-old comedian and actor died of a heart attack Sunday night in the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. Mr. Jessel will be entombed in Hillside Memorial Park.

title: A's McLaughlin Hit by Line Drive
description: Bo McLaughlin, an Oakland A's relief pitcher, was struck in the face by a line drive hit by Chicago's Harold Baines in the eighth inning of tonight's game against the White Sox.

title: Pray Silence for 'The Chief'
description: The Chief Justice of the United States is probably the most private Federal official in the nation, passing judgment on judicial cases from the secrecy of his chambers on Capitol Hill. But the present presiding officer of that temple, Warren E. Burger of Minnesota, is a little different.

title: BOOKSELLERS: ON COSTS, RIGHTS AND FATE
description: It has been hard to find a bookseller or publisher who hasn't complained that this year's convention of the American Booksellers' Association has been quieter than most, and the official tally bears that out. Attendance was only about 12,581, down sharply from the 16,000 who showed up last year in Chicago, and the number of booksellers was down from 5,800 in 1980 to 3,900 this year.

title: IRE FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
SUPREME COURT BARS LOUISIANA'S GAS TAX
description: In a ruling with significant financial implications for Northeastern energy consumers, the Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Louisiana tax on natural gas that is extracted from the Gulf of Mexico and processed in Louisiana.

title: MORE ARRESTS EXPECTED IN KLAN PLOT
description: A dozen members of a Ku Klux Klan faction may be charged in a plot to bomb a synagogue, a television tower and Jewish businesses, the authorities said today.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
NATO'S INCOMPLETE 'DIRECTORATE'
description: To the Editor:

title: WABC-TC REPORT ON ITS INQUIRY INTO FABRICATIONS IS SENT TO F.C.C.
description: TV filed with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday a report on its investigation into fabrications on several of its shows. The situation led last weekend to the forced resignation of five high-ranking station employees, and letters of ''admonition'' to 10 others.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City jumped 65 cents to a record high of $103.86 in the two-week period from May 11 to May 22, according to the market basket survey of the Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers spent $94.09 in the same period last year.

title: INDIAN POINT GOES BACK IN OPERATION AS ABRAMS CALLS FOR CON ED REBATE
description: Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant had returned to service. The plant had been shut down since Oct. 17.

title: NOISE CONTROL LOSES ITS PRIORITY, AND EXPERT SEES HIS JOB VANISH
description: They will make Charles Elkins move out of his office before long. They will take away his 143-member staff, his subscription to Sound and Vibration magazine and the desk where he keeps his ear protectors. They have already begun revoking some of the Federal regulations he worked to enact, including one that limits the noise of garbage trucks.

title: Westvaco
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a leading producer of paper, packaging and chemicals, announced that net income in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1981 ended April 30 increased 15.6 percent, to $25.1 million, or 98 cents a share, from $21.7 million, or 86 cents a share, in the second fiscal quarter of 1980.

title: DUTCH VOTERS SEND MIXED SIGNAL ON MISSILES
description: Dutch voters appeared tonight to have delivered a mixed verdict in a general election on the deployment of American nuclear missiles in the Netherlands.

title: POLAROID'S STOCK RISES ON RUMORS
description: The Polaroid Corporation's stock price rose sharply yesterday in anticipation of today's introduction of a new instant camera and film, apparently because of the belief among some investors that it might involve a revolutionary advance, such as the use of 35-millimeter film.

title: Around the World; Greece Protests to Turkey On Incident in Aegean
description: The Greek Government today delivered a formal protest to Turkey over alleged harassment of Greek warships by Turkish fighter planes in the eastern Aegean Sea in an area it said was just inside Greek territorial waters.

title: DEVELOPED HIGH YIELDING GRAINS
description: Dr. Sterling Wortman, a plant geneticist who was a leader in the Green Revolution, which sought to fight famine in poor regions of the world by developing high-yielding ''miracle grains,'' died of cancer yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Alaska's Oil Reserves
description: The Alaska Oil and Gas Conservation Commission said today that the state's eight oilfields contained an estimated 8 billion barrels of oil on Jan. 1, with 92.5 percent of these reserves in the Prudhoe Bay field. Alaska's 24 natural gas fields were estimated to contain 32.85 billion cubic feet.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 1981
description: International A milestone in Soviet space missions was apparently marked. Two Soviet astronauts landed their Soyuz spacecraft in Central Asia after making the final mission to the Earth-orbiting Salyut 6 space station. A more sophisticated space station is expected to replace the Salyut 6, which has been the base for Moscow's record-setting tests of human endurance for nearly four years. (Page A1, Column 1.) Italy's Cabinet resigned after the four parties in the coalition could not agree on how to deal with a major scandal. Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani, a Christian Democrat, stepped down after the coalition disagreed on how to cope with the revelation that hundreds of top officials had belonged to a secret Masonic lodge. (A1:2.)

title: Russians License A Kloeckner Plant
description: Kloeckner Humboldt Deutz A.G., a diversified West German metals and engineering concern, said it had signed a licensing agreement with the Soviet Government for annual production of up to 25,000 Deutz air-cooled diesel engines in the Soviet Union. It said in a statement that under the agreement it would help the Russians produce Deutz model 413 engines.

title: SUMMER OFFICE JOBS FOR YOUTHS
description: WITH the end of the college term approaching, students are thinking about summer work. Many have already lined up jobs as lifeguards, camp counselors, gardeners, supermarket clerks, department store salesmen, bank tellers, waiters, bartenders, brokerage firm clerks, temporary policemen at resorts, carpenters and many other occupations.

title: A Glittering Prize for the Battery
description: After 15 years of false starts and failures, construction is about to begin on Battery Park City. The joint announcement last week by the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Canadian developers, Olympia and York, signaled a dramatic addition to the Lower Manhattan skyline. The development leadership that finally brought the project to the brink of reality bodes well not only for lower Manhattan but also for Times Square, where a similar undertaking is in the works.

title: US SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
GAP STORES INC, THE reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
NEW AMERICAN FARE
description: American Airlines said it would introduce a systemwide "Amerifare" that limits the cost of round-trip travel on any of its domestic flights to $179 one way. American's special summer fare, which cuts regular coach fares by 35 to 63 percent, matches similar $179 caps announced last week by Eastern and Trans World Airlines for domestic travel. The Amerifare is effective June 1 to Sept. 15 in any market where the round-trip Super Saver fare would be greater than $358, or $179 each way.

Track Duel in London
description: Craig Virgin of the United States, the world cross-country champion, will take on Steve Ovett of Britain, the world mile and 1,500-meter record-holder, in the 3,000-meter run at a Crystal Palace track and field meet June 3. Stanley Floyd, ranked No.1 in the world at 100 meters, and Charles Oliver, the 400-meter runner, are also on the United States team announced today.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including investment gains of $119,712 for the latest first qr and $22,581 for the previous first qr

title: LIBERALS CHOOSE MRS. CODD OF S. I. TO OPPOSE KOCH
description: Liberal Party leaders were scheduled last night to select City Councilwoman Mary T. Codd of Staten Island as their candidate for mayor.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Harvard beets are beets that have been cooked and are served in a sweet-sour sauce. Some people make them with sugar and water thickened with cornstarch to which vinegar is added. Is this recipe authentic? Some cookbooks say that the original never contained water but only vinegar. What is the origin of the name?

title: JOHN FORD JR., REVIVED DETROIT SYMPHONY IN '51
description: John B. Ford Jr., who was credited with reviving the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in 1951 and who served as its director for 30 years, died at his Grosse Pointe Park home on Sunday. He was 84 years old.

title: BEING CREATIVE WHEN A PICNIC IMPULSE HITS
description: AT this time of year the impulse to picnic is almost irresistible - whether it's at the beach, in the park, at baseball games, tennis matches, open-air music festivals or simply in backyards or on rooftops. And there is a particular sense of well-being that comes from digging into creative, enticing picnic fare instead of those typical lunch-box assortments of tuna fish or peanut butter sandwiches.

title: DOW GAINS BY 12.24 ON OPEC NEWS
description: Stocks rallied sharply late yesterday on news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to freeze oil prices at current levels. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 12.24 points, with virtually all of the advance occurring in the final hour, to finish at 983.96.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $35,394 gain on the sale of equipment

title: EQUITY'S LICENSING OF AGENTS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Actors Equity's 50-year-old system for licensing and regulating theatrical agents is immune from suit under the Federal antitrust laws.

title: Around the Nation; Fiery Explosion Injures 17 At Refinery in New Mexico
description: Leaking propane and butane gases ignited and exploded at a refinery today, sending flames 100 feet into the air and injuring 17 men, two of them seriously.

title: TO BE ABLE TO REASON IN TOMORROW'S WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: GOODPASTER JOINS WEST POINT '81
description: Lieut. Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, the Superintendent of the United States Military Academy, was made an honorary member of the graduating class of 1981 tonight because, as Cadet Mark Hogan, the class president, said, ''He came in with us, and he's going out with us.''

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30

title: FRANCE SUPPORTS NEW MEASURES AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA
description: A United Nations-sponsored conference here that is studying sanctions against South Africa has been buoyed by the support of the new Socialist Government of France.

title: A GROUP'S FATE WHEN ITS STAR GOES SOLO
description: THE flowerings and flounderings of the most popular rock groups have become signs and portents by which the most epochal generational changes can be divined. When the Beatles arrived in the early 60's, so did new fashions, new ideas, the heady optimism of a new decade. When the group broke up at the end of the 60's, that event signaled the end of an era. One could argue that the 70's, the mellow ''me'' decade, were brought to an end just as decisively by the arrival of punk and new-wave rock.

title: FRANKLIN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: Net income figures are from securities transactions

title: Credit Card At Bache
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. announced yesterday an agreement with the American Express Company to offer a cash management type of account under which clients will receive an American Express gold card.

title: SUMMER COOKING CLASSES: A LIST OF WHAT'S AVAILABLE
description: Fortunately for those interested in learning to cook, not all schools will be out for the late spring and summer. Although most schools will be closed until the fall, those listed below will offer classes. Their exact schedules and prices should be checked by telephone. All schools except for Greek Cooking and Baking were reviewed in the Living Section on Sept. 10, 1980; descriptions here are taken from that review. Donna Adams Cooking Classes, 445 East 86th Street, 831-8864.

title: The City; Club's Owner Gets Deadline on Fine
description: Charles A. Vincent, who owned Vincent's Place, a now defunct Harlem nightclub and restaurant, was ordered to pay a $5,000 fine within a week or serve a one-year prison term for failing to remit more than $100,000 in Federal withholding and Social Security tax payments.
