description: By Anatole Broyard JULY'S PEOPLE. By Nadine Gordimer. 159 pages. Viking. $10.95.

title: The Real Loisaida
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In the article by Moira Hodgson (''New French Guide to New York Stirs Controversy,'' May 17), a question was raised about the name ''Loisaida'' as used in the Gault Millau Guide to New York for ''a section of the Manhattan map between FDR Drive and Avenue D.''

title: YOUNG MANAGEMENT OF FRENCH GAUMONT BUILDS MEDIA GIANT
description: SUR-SEINE, France, May 26 - As the Cannes Film Festival draws to a close, Gaumont, France's largest entertainment company, has, as usual, the biggest battalion on the Cannes battlefront. Yet the Gaumont name is written in tiny letters on its billboards, and its executives meet in a secluded villa removed from the festival limelight.

title: MULTIPLE CHOICE ON IMMIGRATION
description: What does a good conservative think Government should do about immigration of workers from Mexico: (a) Keep them out. America should be for Americans, or at least immigration should be balanced among different countries. (b) Keep them out. We don't need any more people to create social problems and soak up scarce social welfare dollars. Even the temporarily legal have a way of becoming the permanently illegal. (c) Letthem in, to discipline the domestic labor force and provide workers for the stoop labor that American simply won't do. (d) Let them in. We need to please Mexico, whose oil is all-important.

title: Soviet Will Buy Canadian Grain
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to buy a minimum of 25 million metric tons of Canadian grain over the next five years in a transaction worth at least $5 billion, the Canadian Government announced today.

title: Steel Production Down
description: Steel production fell to 2.585 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1.1 percent from the previous week's 2.613 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: QADDAFI OPPOSITION IS GETTING STRONGER
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's campaign of repression at home and support of terrorism abroad have created a growing opposition to his regime. It includes key aides who helped in his coup in 1969 but have since defected.

title: IDEAL TOY GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Joseph C. Winkler has been elected president of the Ideal Toy Corporation. He succeeds Lionel A. Weintraub, who remains chairman and chief executive officer of the big toy company with headquarters in Hollis, Queens.

title: 'RENTAL WEEKEND' SHOPPING' GROUP EFFORT
description: WESTHAMPTON, L.I. LINDA NOVEMBER was not too frantic as she cornered Ina Garten in a corner of the Barefoot Contessa on Main Street here last Saturday. It was just that she wanted to make sure that she had enough bran muffins and blueberries and croissants for Sunday's breakfast and that Miss Garten had put aside the fixings for Monday's lunch.

title: PHILIP W. BARBER, 78, A WRITER, DRAMATIST AND TEACHER AT YALE
description: Philip W. Barber, a dramatist, writer and public-relations consultant, died of cancer May 8 at the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 78 years old and lived in Becket, Mass.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IHAVE not the least recollection of when I first sampled that Proven,cale dish called ratatouille, but I suspect that it must have been in my childhood. Or at least it was a dish that resembled ratatouille.

title: 9 Yachting Challenges Accepted
description: Nine challenges for the America's Cup, a record number, have been accepted by the New York Yacht Club for 1983, and a 10th has been accepted provisionally.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
American Motors And Chiat/Day End Tie
description: American Motors and Chiat/Day are ending their 14-year relationship. The Los Angeles-based agency, through its subsidiary, Chiat/Day/ Hoefer in San Francisco and Detroit, has been handling the advertising for A.M.C.'s cars and Jeeps outside the United States and Canada.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
KING HUSSEIN, IN MOSCOW, ENDORSES BREZHNEV'S CALL FOR MIDEAST PARLEY
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived to a warm reception here today and expressed his support for the expanding Soviet drive to hold an international conference on the Middle East.

title: SPAIN UNCOVERS POSSIBLE PLOT AGAINST KING
description: The police in Barcelona have reportedly uncovered evidence of a possible plot to assassinate King Juan Carlos. According to well-placed police sources, the interrogation of terrorists captured Sunday night in the headquarters of the Banco Central in Barcelona after a 36-hour siege has led to the discovery of a 75-foot-long tunnel under the parade route that the King is scheduled to follow when he presides over Armed Forces Day in the city Sunday. The police, however, were unsure of the intended use of the tunnel.

title: New Evidence Reported In Murder of U.S. Nuns
description: The F.B.I. has matched a fingerprint from the van used by four American churchwomen killed in El Salvador last December with one from one of six Salvadoran national guardsmen held on suspicion of committing the murders, a State Department official said today.

title: SOMETHING NEW FROM ZENITH
description: THE Zenith Radio Corporation is about to offer a television receiver that the innovative Japanese might envy. Zenith officials are in Las Vegas, Nev., today to demonstrate the new device. It is a projection television set with a screen area that is said to be twice as large as today's 25-inch direct-view sets.

title: POWER INDUSTRY SEEKING FINANCING ABROAD
description: The American utility industry, which needs some $100 billion for construction in the next five years, is preparing a campaign that it hopes will lead to a vast expansion in the amount of capital it raises from overseas lenders, including the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency.

title: Ban on Raider Move Defended by Rozelle
description: Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, today gave jurors an emotional defense of the league's decision to bar the Oakland Raiders from moving to Los Angeles.

title: FED'S POLICY: IS IT FLAWED?;  IS the effort of the Federal Reserve to check inflation by holding down the rate of money supply growth a wrongheaded policy that actually destabilizes the economy by forcing up interest rates and accelerating velocity, the rate at which the money supply turns over?
description: This is the issue dramatized by the startling results of this year's first quarter when real gross national product climbed at an annual rate of 8.4 percent and nominal G.N.P. (total national output unadjusted for inflation) soared at a near-record rate of 19.3 percent, while the narrowly defined monetary aggregates scarcely grew.

title: Record Savings Outflow Noted
description: The nation's beleaguered savings and loan associations reported a record outflow of $4.63 billion last month, almost double the mark set only a month earlier, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: No Headline
description: PRESIDENTIAL FUNERAL IN ECUADOR: Oswaldo Hurtado Larrea, right, Ecuador's new President, bearing coffin of late President Jaime Roldos Aguilera at funeral in Quito. Mr. Roldos, his wife, and other Government officials were killed in plane crash. From left are Mrs. Hurtado and Leon Roldos Aguilera, late President's brother.

title: METS MAKE 5 ERRORS AND BOW TO PHILS, 7-5
description: In one way, the revival of the Mets continued last night in Shea Stadium: They ripped into undefeated Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies with four runs in their first turn at bat.

title: Shared Antitrust Penalty Barred
description: The Supreme Court today resolved, at least temporarily, a major controversy in the field of antitrust law by ruling unanimously that a defendant in an antitrust case has no right to require other companies to share the cost of an unfavorable verdict.

title: WRITERS GO PUBLIC, FOR LOVE RATHER THAN LUCRE
description: This is the man who is going to introduce you. He says, 'Could you tell me the names of the books you have written ...' This is the lady who is giving a party for you After the poetry reading. She says, 'I hope you don't mind, but I have carefully avoided inviting Any beautiful, attractive farouche young women, But the Vicar of Dunstable is coming, Who is over here this year on an exchange program, And the Calvinist Spiritual Chorus

title: POLICE SCANDAL IN PORTLAND, ORE., LEADS TO SHAKE-UP OF NARCOTICS SQUAD AND CONVICTION OF AN EX OFFICER
description: A police scandal spawned in the torrent of cash from the illegal narcotics trade is running its course behind this city's lovely facade of blooming late-spring flowers and rainwashed, sun-dried streets.

description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $798,00 for the qr and $1,135,000 for the yr...C-Including $123,000 tax

description: BASEBALL

title: Day's Grace on Licenses
description: Driver licenses and vehicle registrations due to expire on Sunday, May 31, will automatically be extended for a day, Leslie G. Foschio, the State Motor Vehicles Commissioner, said today.

title: L.I. Baby Gets a Head Start on His Brother
description: Cheryl Goldstein made it to the hospital in time to give birth to a 5-pound son yesterday morning, but it was touch and go for the Dix Hills, L.I., woman. The trip to the hospital was delayed while Mrs. Goldstein gave birth to a 4-pound, 11-ounce son in the back seat of the family station wagon.

title: The City; Harlem Man Gets Deadline on Fine
description: Charles A. Vincent, a 53-year-old Harlem businessman and the former owner of Vincent's Place, a nightclub and restaurant, was ordered to pay a $5,000 fine within a week or serve a one-year prison term for failing to remit more than $100,000 in Federal withholding and Social Security tax payments.

title: Princess Margriet to Help Boost Colonial Spirit
description: Princess Margriet of the Netherlnds, the Canadian-born third daughter of former Queen Juliana, will be setting foot on the original acreage of Nieuw Amsterdam this week with her husband, Pieter van Vollenhoven.

title: THE OLD IMAGERY OF WAR IS OUTDATED
description: Government policies are often sophisticated expressions of fairly simple underlying images. In some cases, these images are useful guides; in others -national security is one - the images do not truly fit changing realities, and mislead us. Yesterday's realism is becoming tomorrow's dream world.

title: Reagan Names Miamian
description: Jose Manuel Casanova, a Cuban-born Miami businessman, has been named by President Reagan to serve as executive director of the Inter-American Development Bank, Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, announced today. Mr. Casanova, 50 years old, owns a Miami export concern and has been chief executive of a Miami area bank. He was a businessman in his native Cuba before establishing permanent residence in the south Florida city in 1964. The post requires Senate confirmation.

title: Reassessing Radiation
description: Thirty-six years after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, a quiet debate has erupted over the radiation damage they caused to human beings. The subject is of more than academic interest. Survivors of the blasts form a pool of humans wholly exposed to radiation, and estimates of the effects of radiation on all of us have largely depended on their experience.

title: 'A CELTIC TRIOLOGY'
description: KATHLEEN DOWDEY'S ''A Celtic Trilogy'' is a like a tapestry on which the colors have run together. The film is more a series of impressions than it is a documentary, and its images flow into one another almost arbitrarily. The mood isn't random, though; it's dreamy, guided by a private vision of which Miss Dowdey seems in full command. Her film is by no means clear or illuminating. But she displays a poetic free-associating spirit that governs the selection of its images, if not the order with which they have been put together.

title: Bauer Is Winner of Central Park Bike Race
description: Steve Bauer of Fenwick, Ontario, turned in a sustained sprint in the closing yards in Central Park yesterday and captured the 50-mile third event in the 10-event Lowenbrau Grand Prix cycling series.

title: The Region; 2 Men Badly Burned In Power Station Fire
description: Two workers were severely burned yesterday when a flash fire broke out at a power substation of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, utility officials said.

title: COMPLEX MOTIVES BY SAUDIS INDICATED
description: Is Saudi Arabia the altruist of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, putting the interests of the Western world at the forefront of its considerations? Or is it acting out of selfinterest?

title: TV MORAL MONITORS TO PRESS SPONSORS
description: In a few more weeks, a coalition of organizations seeking to stamp out moral corruption is going to implore consumers to boycott some companies' products for a full year, while urging them to buy the goods of other makers.

title: J. Walter Thompson In Cable TV Deal
description: Leaping right into the center of the cable TV maelstrom, J. Walter Thompson U.S.A. has got itself a deal with the Adams-Russell Company, which operates a 52-channel, two-way cable system in Peabody, Mass., with 8,000 subscribers.

title: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 2
Renault Output Down
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, France's state-owned auto maker, reported today that its worldwide vehicle production in the first quarter fell 9.2 percent, to 516,186 units, from the level of a year earlier. Sales outside France fell 14.8 percent, to 263,575 units.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30

title: Tosco Says Official Aided Developer in Bid
description: The Tosco Corporation filed suit today against a Denver land developer, contending that he used a romantic relationship with a state official to obtain private Tosco documents helpful to his bid to take over Tosco.

title: EUROBLEND WINES WORRY GEMRANS
description: LONDON The bottle of white wine in an English wine bar looked quintessentially German: Teutonic names on the label in black-lettered gothic type and a picture of jolly men in lederhosen carousing in a Rhineland tavern. But the small print said otherwise.

title: THE THINGS TO TAKE ALONG
description: Unless picnicking is a regular activity in the household, with special gear set aside and ready, gathering picnic utensils is likely to be a last-minute rush to the closest hardware, grocery or stationery store - or making due with leftovers from children's birthday parties. And the picnic will be consumed off thin, absorbent paper plates with flimsy utensils, the wine sipped from inadequate paper cups.

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
THE ONLY FEASIBLE MX DEPLOYMENT PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRESTONE POSTS NET OF $27 MILLION
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, buoyed by strong gains from its tire operations in North America, reported yesterday that it had net income of $27 million in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1981, in contrast to a loss of $52 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 10.5 percent, the company said.

title: MELLON ALSO BUYING THE MAINE CENTRAL
description: Timothy Mellon, an heir to the family fortune of the Pittsburgh Mellons, has made an offer on his second railroad in two months. The 38-year-old son of Paul Mellon signed a purchase agreement with the United States Filter Corporation on Saturday to buy the Maine Central Railroad.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SYMPATHY FOR WOMEN

title: FOREIGN INVESTMENT RISING IN NEW YORK OFFICE PROPERTY
description: ''The Europeans feel that when a deal is offered in Europe it has already been shopped in the United States,'' said W. Allen Churchill, a vice president of the European American Bank.

title: Caldor Tie Approved
description: A merger of Caldor Inc. into the Associated Dry Goods Corporation in a $313 million cash-and-securities transaction was approved by shareholders of both companies, the retailers announced. Associated operates 162 department stores nationwide, including the chain of Lord & Taylor stores. Caldor operates 63 discount stores in the Northeast.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
LIBERAL LOBBYISTS DWINDLING IN CAPITAL
description: They used to crowd the corridors of Congress, earnest young veterans of the Peace Corps and the protest years, lobbying for programs to help the hungry and the homeless. Often they won, and the rising budgets of the Federal Government, and of their own organizations, reflected their success.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Motortech Magazine To Be Sent Free to 150,000
description: Magazine publishers rent lists of names of people who buy from direct marketers to use for their subscription solicitations. Time Inc. used subscription lists of Time's magazines to try to sell its Time-Life Books.

title: COURT SETS ASIDE RULE REQUIRING TRANSIT TO ADAPT TO HANDICAPPED
description: In a victory for impoverished transit systems across the nation, and especially in New York City, the United States Court of Appeals for the Districtof Columbia today set aside a set of Federal rules requiring cities to make transit facilities accessible to handicapped riders.

title: JOHN J. REYNOLDS SR., 78, A BROKER FOR REAL ESTATE TRANSFERS IN CITY
description: John J. Reynolds Sr., a New York City real estate broker for more than six decades and the longtime adviser on property transactions for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died yesterday at Westchester Square Hospital in the Bronx after a long illness. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PLAYERS UPHELD ON DATA REQUEST
description: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board moved into the dispute between baseball's club owners and players yesterday, issuing a complaint against the owners that could have far-reaching impact on a settlement of the free-agent compensation dispute.

title: Around the World; Pole Beaten by Russians, Union Branch Reports
description: A district branch of the independent labor union Solidarity said today that Soviet soldiers stationed in Poland had beaten a Polish ambulance mechanic and that the military authorities of both countries were investigating.

title: STATE POLICE QUELL 2D RIOT IN 5 DAYS BY INMATES AT A PRISON IN MICHIGAN
description: Up to 1,000 inmates, many armed with makeshift clubs, rioted for nine and a half hours today at Southern Michigan Prison, taking over a cell block and setting fire to prefabricated dormitories.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TOWARD INFLATION PROOF INVESTMENT SPURS
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; Transit Report
description: Switch trouble last night resulted in 10-minute delays on all RR express trains from Astoria, Queens, along with delays of 10 to 15 minutes on all southbound trains to Kennedy International Airport and on A trains to Far Rockaway.

title: LORAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to mar 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to include Frequency Sources Inc, acquired in August 1980 on a pooling-of-interests

title: RETAILERS AND THE THEFT PROBLEM
description: American retailers are finding that the rate of merchandise theft continues to soar despite efforts to stem the flow of disappearing goods.

title: IS HUNT FOR GENIUS A MALE PRESERVE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Transit Officials Reject Fare Rise in Chicago Area
description: Directors of the area's financially troubled mass transit system today rejected a proposed 12.5 percent fare increase and the elimination of weekend service, which had been suggested to avert a June 1 shutdown.

title: 3 LAWYERS GET $10 MILLION IN WINNING CASE FOR INDIANS
description: Three Washington lawyers have been awarded a record $10,595,943 in fees for their work on behalf of eight Sioux tribes in obtaining more than 10 times that amount from the Government for its seizure of South Dakota's Black Hills in 1877.

title: Pro-West Cyprus Party Cuts Communists' Lead
description: A late surge by the pro-Western party of Glafkos Clerides has prevented hard-line Communists from dominating politics in the Greek-Cypriot sector of Cyprus, official election results showed today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Columbia College will become a coeducational institution. The only issue is whether this will be accomplished unilaterally or in collaboration with Barnard.

title: GOVERNOR CALLS MEDICAID FIRST LEGISLATIVE PRIORITY
description: Governor Carey said today he planned to make the proposed state takeover of local Medicaid costs his ''primary focus'' for the remainder of the legislative session.

title: CHRYSLER, PEUGEOT IN ACCORD
description: In a move that could eventually lead to some form of a merger, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it and Peugeot, the French auto maker, had agreed to jointly produce a subcompact car in the United States, probably by late 1985.

title: THE BASIC KNIVES
description: IWAS leafing through a knife manufacturer's catalogue the other day and noticed that there were 36 different knives lined up proudly, each pronouncing its own usefulness. In this column too, I think, I may have left the impression that to be a good cook one needs 10 or 20 knives. Of course, that is not so.

title: NEW SALVADOR MEDIATION EFFORT BEGINS
description: Just a month after a proposal for outside mediation was rejected by the Salvadoran junta, a new international effort has started to bring the warring factions in El Salvador to the bargaining table.

title: Around the World; Publishers' Group Attacks Moves to Regulate News
description: Newspaper publishers from more than 20 countries have called on Unesco and other international bodies to abandon ''attempts at regulating news content and formulating rules for the press.''

title: WEDNESDAY, MAY 27, 1981; Energy
description: An OPEC majority agreed to freeze oil prices and cut production by at least 10 percent, but Saudi Arabia, the biggest producer, refused to lift prices from its $32-a-barrel level or restrict output. OPEC's 12 other members will hold their crude oil prices to $36 to $41 a barrel until December, when another pricing meeting is scheduled, and reduce output by 1.5 million barrels daily in an attempt to offset the present worldwide oil glut. (Page A1.)

title: Marathon Sets Entry Deadline
description: Entry form requests for the 12th New York City Marathon must be postmarked no earlier than next Tuesday, according to Fred Lebow, director of the race, which will be held Oct. 25.

title: NEW YORK AIR'S CHIEF
description: Neal F. Meehan, the 40-year-old president of New York Air, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Frank A. Lorenzo, 41, who continues as chairman of the airline.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TV: 'CUBAN ODYSSEY,' REFUGEE DRAMA
description: ACQUIRED by Public Broadcasting Service's ''World'' series, ''Against Wind and Tide: A Cuban Odyssey'' can be seen on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 9 o'clock. This is part of the story - the not always pleasant part -of the more than 120,000 Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's regime in the spring and summer of last year. The refugees are seen as the victims in this country of confused immigration policies and election-year politics.

title: Palace Invites 2,500 to Wedding, and Says It's 'Too Few'
description: There will be rejoicing in some high places and fretting in others in the next few days, when the mail comes in. Buckingham Palace announced yesterday that about 2,500 people around the world had been sent invitations to the July 29 wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer.

title: U.S. STEEL ROLLS BACK PRICE RISE TO MATCH BETHLEHEM'S INCREASE
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it was notifying its customers that it was rolling back its price increases announced only two weeks ago to the lower levels set last week by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: INTEREST RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday, although traders said the bulk of the most recent drop occurred suddenly late Friday after the Federal Reserve announced a larger-than-expected $2.2 billion decline in the nation's money supply.

title: CROWLEY MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $220,103 investment tax credit; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting method required by F.A.S.B. Standard No 43

title: Brazil Raises Coffee Tax
description: Brazil raised its export taxes on both green and instant coffee today.

title: Communique by OPEC
description: Following is the text of the communique issued in English tonight by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at the end of a two-day meeting of OPEC oil ministers:

title: Unser Appeal to Delay Outcome
description: Roger Penske today affirmed his intention to appeal Bobby Unser's drop to second place in the Indianapolis 500 and Unser admitted he had passed several cars in the race. But the finish, most controversial in the race's history, might not be resolved for another month.

title: Big Bank Plans Variable Rate Note
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the holding company for New York's third-largest bank of the same name, announced yesterday plans to issue $100 million of variable rate notes with a minimum denomination of $1,000 that makes the issue affordable for small, individual investors.

title: DIFFERENT BREED AT MCA
description: MCA Advertising, which won all of the Standard Brands foods business from five of the country's leading ad agencies last week, may also create and place advertising as the others do, but there its resemblance to other shops ends. It is truly a breed apart.

title: JUSTICES, TO REVIEW RULING IN EX-GREEN BERET'S CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether to reinstate the overturned murder conviction of Dr. Jeffrey R. MacDonald, the former Green Beret captain who was found guilty in 1979 for the 1970 murders of his wife and two daughters.

title: Around the Nation; Searchers in Texas Hunt For 4 Missing in Flooding
description: Firefighters searched Lake Austin today for four persons missing and presumed dead after a violent storm unleashed floodwaters that killed 10 others and left a trail of destruction through the state capital.

title: People
description: * Marianne Howatson, a senior vice president, named associate publisher of all Penthouse publications, and Jay Remer, a vice president, named advertising director of Penthouse magazine.

title: METHOD TO DESTROY TOXIC PCB'S IS TENTATIVELY APPROVED BY U.S.
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that it had given preliminary approval to a new process for destroying a significant amount of the toxic PCB compounds found in electrical transformers.

title: DISTRICTING IS WALKING ON THIN ICE
description: Nothing elevates the blood pressure of politicians quite like redistricting. The decennial process, now under way in the City Council, has produced its share of shouting, arm waving and purple faces.

title: OPEC NATIONS FREEZE OIL PRICES AND AGREE ON PRODUCTION CUTS
description: Faced with Saudi Arabia's refusal to increase its oil prices or cut back its huge production, the other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided tonight to freeze prices at current levels and to cut production to reduce the world's oversupply of oil.

title: Cavaliers Sign Edwards, Free Agent From Pacers
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers, apparently willing to spend to shore up their sagging fortunes, say they have come to terms with James Edwards, the free-agent center from the Indiana Pacers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amoco Minerals Co., a unit of Standard Oil (Indiana), said it would seek a buyer for its 63 percent interest in Cyprus Anvil Mining Corp., a Canadian lead, zinc and silver producer.

title: A Convalescent Duck
description: A duck that received nationwide attention because it was apparently able to fly and swim normally with a three-foot arrow piercing its breast has been grounded by a Humane Society official named Dart Anthony.

title: U.S. AIDES DISMISS BEGIN'S CHARGE ABOUT SOVIET ADVISERS IN LEBANON
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had no information to support Prime Minister Menachem Begin's statement that the Soviet Union had military advisers with the Syrian troops in Lebanon.

title: Blackjack-Wager Rule Reconsidered in Jersey
description: The New Jersey Casino Control Commission is reconsidering its blackjack ''surrender'' rule, which allows players to give up half their wager if they fear they have a losing hand.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Sales of Existing Homes Rose 6% in April
description: Sales of existing single-family houses recovered a bit in April after falling for six straight months, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Advertising; The New Chairman For A.A.F.
description: PATRICIA J. MARTIN, the first woman chairman of the American Advertising Federation, who takes office June 8, is arriving at a time when that grass roots organization is becoming more important to the advertising industry than it has ever been.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The era of self-doubt is over. We've stopped looking at our warts and rediscovered how much there is to love in this blessed land.''

title: SUFFOLK COMMISSIONER IS INDICTED FOR PERJURY IN KICKBACKS INQUIRY
description: The Suffolk County Labor Commissioner has been indicted on charges that he lied to a county grand jury when he said he did not take kickbacks totaling more than $70,000 for contracts his office awarded under the Federally financed Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: NEGOTIATORS IN COAL STRIKE TALKS REPORT THEY ARE CLOSE TO AN AGREEMENT
description: Negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the major Eastern and Middle Western coal operators said tonight that they had nearly reached agreement on a new contract that could end the 62-day strike of 160,000 miners.

title: Cecil Taylor at the Public
description: Cecil Taylor, the jazz pianist and composer, will appear at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, tomorrow and Saturday at 10:30 P.M. with a new version of his Unit.

title: REAGAN RECALLS HIS SPECIAL ENVOY FROM MIDDLE EAST FOR CONSULTATION
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, was returning from the Middle East for consultations on what the United States should do next in trying to avert an Israeli-Syrian clash over the stationing of Syrian missiles in Lebanon.

title: Acton Is Cleared To Drop Food Units
description: The Acton Corporation said its directors have approved in principle a plan that would spin off its food business during the fourth quarter and leave the company with only its communications operations.

title: Around the World; Nestle Said to Have Paid For Rights Nominee's List
description: Ernest W. Lefever, the Administration's nominee to become Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, used a mailing list paid for by the Nestle Corporation to distribute an article favoring the sale of infant formula to poor nations, it was disclosed today.

title: Fredric Warburg Dies; Published Orwell Books
description: Fredric Warburg, the British publisher who backed George Orwell's ''Animal Farm'' when other publishing houses rejected it, has died in University College Hospital at the age of 82, his family announced today.

title: THE WRONGS THAT JOINT CUSTODY RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: MARSHALL FIELD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Around the nation; Arkansas Law on Teaching Of Creation Is Challenged
description: A dozen clergymen joined teachers, parents and six organizations today in filing suit to overturn a state law that requires public schools teaching evolution to give equal treatment to the idea that the universe and man were created instantly.

title: Alberta to Cut Oil Flow Again
description: The province of Alberta will reduce oil production by 60,000 barrels a day on June 1, bringing the total cutback this year to 120,000 barrels daily, federal and provincial sources said today.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting chan

title: Farm Loan Unit Raises Its Rates
description: The Farmers Home Administration said today that it was raising the interest rates on most of its loans by one-quarter to one and three-quarters points, effective Saturday.

title: Canadian Gas Transport Is Cleared
description: The Northern Border Pipeline Company of Omaha said it had received authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to transport additional volumes of Canadian natural gas and to build and operate a second compressor station in McIntosh County, N.D.

title: TRANS-WESTERN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
C.I.A. ENDS FORMAL BACKGROUND BRIEFINGS FOR PRESS
description: As part of an effort to tighten security and reduce the visibility of the Central Intelligence Agency, William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, has ended a longstanding policy of formally briefing reporters about nonclassified subjects.

title: Hewlett-Packard's New Technology
description: A new machine that uses electron beams instead of light to etch circuits on silicon chips, the basic component of computers, has been developed by the Hewlett-Packard Company.

title: Gardening; ZEROING IN ON THE MOST PERSISTANT WEEDS
description: WEEDS are just about the most exasperating plants that gardeners have to contend with. They seem to pop up everywhere and even when they are hoed or pulled out, they return.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
POLISH 'MAN OF IRON' WINS TOP HONORS AT CANNES
description: ''Man of Iron,'' a Polish film inspired by the workers' uprising last summer that brought sweeping changes in Poland's Communist society, won top honors today at the 34th Cannes Film Festival.

title: Notes On people; Fast-Learning Miamian, 12, to Enter N.Y.U. in Fall
description: When Stephen Baccus begins his freshman year at New York University in the fall, he'll be the youngest student at the university since at least 1900, and officials said yesterday that they suspected he might be the youngest

title: THE 'CRIMES' AND PUNISHMENT OF JURI KUKK
description: To the Editor:

title: STREET SCENE
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENTISTS CONFIRM METHANE FIND
description: Evidence that methane gas of nonbiological origin is seeping from the ocean floor in a region of the East Pacific Rise more than 2,800 miles south of the area where a similar discovery was made in 1979 has been reported by scientists from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Alcan Smelter Put Off
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said today that it had postponed indefinitely plans to build a 300,000-ton-a-year smelter in Queensland, Australia. The company said Government approval for the third stage of its expansion of the Kurri Kurri smelter in New South Wales, to 150,000 tons from 90,000 tons, had been slow in coming, so it decided to delay a decision on the Queensland facility to avoid having two construction projects under way in Australia simultaneously.

title: Net Off Sharply At J.P. Stevens
description: J.P. Stevens & Company, a diversified textile producer, reported yesterday that second-quarter profits plunged more than 56 percent from the like period a year ago, in part because of continued high interest costs.

title: Neighbors Rise to Aid A Threatened Family
description: Aided by cheering neighbors armed with baseball bats and rakes, the police arrested a man today accused of harassing a family and breaking into their home four times in the last month.

title: RIPLEY CO reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
News Analysis
description: Even on the morning after, it was difficult to be certain, but yesterday's Dutch general election appeared to have made it highly unlikely that cruise missiles would ever be deployed on the soil of the Netherlands.

title: BACK TO 'INORDINATE FEAR OF COMMUNISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: G.S.A. Chief Sworn
description: Gerald P. Carmen, promising to ''open the windows and let the sun shine in,'' was sworn in yesterday as administrator of the General Services Administration.

title: Airline Talks On Losses Set
description: The world's major international airlines with the exception of United States carriers will convene in emergency session next week to discuss growing financial losses, it was announced today.

title: Panafax Offers Advanced Printer
description: The Panafax Corporation introduced what it says is the first facsimile machine that can print information sent from computers and word processors as well as from other facsimile machines.

title: BILL TO LIMIT 'OFFENSIVE' CABLE TV PROGRAMS INTRODUCED IN ALBANY
description: Legislation that would give cable television companies the power to refuse to broadcast ''patently offensive'' sexually explicit or violent programs on their channels was introduced here today.

title: Shoemaker Wins No. 8,000
description: Bill Shoemaker won his 8,000th race today, and then won three more, including the $53,500 Happy Issue Stakes at Hollywood Park. He captured the first race with War Allied and the stakes with Gam Bey.

title: BLANTON DENIES GUILT ON KICKBACKS
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton testified today that he expected members of the Tennessee Alcoholic Beverage Commission to ''help his friends'' when he was in office, but he denied ever telling the commission to approve any specific liquor licenses.

title: News Analysis
description: The semiannual meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries adjourned last night, but the final communique may not have been the last word.

title: 14 KILLED, 3 OTHER PLANES WRECKED
description: A Marine electronic combat aircraft crashed on the flight deck of the carrier Nimitz off the northern coast of Florida late last night and plowed forward, erupting into a ball of fire that killed 14 men, destroyed three fighters and damaged 16 other aircraft.

title: WATER CURBS EASED FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: With New York City's upstate reservoirs at their highest levels in nearly a year, the Koch administration yesterday relaxed its water restrictions. Warm-weather activities such as watering lawns and filling private swimming pools will now be permitted.

title: HOPE SCHARY, LEADER IN TEXTILES DESIGNING AND WOMEN'S RIGHTS
description: Hope Skillman Schary, a textile designer and a leader in the women's rights movement, died at her home in New Milford, Conn., last Saturday. She had recently returned from a meeting in Brussels of the International Council of Women, of which she was vice president. Mrs. Schary, who was 73 years old, also maintained a home in Manhattan.

title: Saudi Friendship, and Its Limits
description: OPEC Freezes Oil Prices Through 1981 ... Saudi Arabia Refuses to Cut Exports. There is good news from Geneva, but some contend that it arises only because Saudi Arabia is on our side. There is a serious split in the oil cartel, they observe; by fighting for stable prices and high production, Saudi Arabia is showing the industrialized importers that it is a trustworthy friend.

title: Around the World; Khomeini Seems to Criticize Bani-Sadr in Sharp Speech
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned feuding Iranian officials today to halt their grab for power.

title: The Region; Westchester to Add Hydroelectric Plant
description: Ground was broken here for one of several small-scale hydroelectric power plants designed to help reduce both the cost of electricity and New York State's dependence on foreign oil.

title: Technology; Customizing Silicon Chips
description: IF any companies should have happy customers, they are the makers of integrated circuits, who have continually offered silicon chips with more and more computing power for lower and lower prices. Yet their customers have not always been satisfied.

title: 7 DIE, INCLUDING 6 CHILDREN, IN JERSEY CITY TENEMENT FIRE
description: Seven persons, including a mother and her four children and two teen-agers from another family, died tonight when a fire that started in a mattress swept through the top floor of a four-story brick tenement near the city's waterfront.

title: LEBANON'S BECOME NONVALID
description: Whether by blunder or carefully calculated step, early this month the United States legitimized Israeli raids into Lebanon when President Reagan praised Prime Minister Menachem Begin's restraint in the face of the introduction of Syrian missiles and urged additional time for diplomatic efforts to resolve the problem.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
OFFSHORE OIL LEASE SALE IS BLOCKED
description: A judge today granted an injunction sought by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California to block the Department of the Interior from selling 32 oil- lease tracts off the coast of central California.

title: Embassy Wives
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Lynn Rosellini's ''The Plight of the Embassy Wife'' (April 29) suggests that ''salaries, pensions and other benefits'' are ''unheard of.'' The fact is that the Foreign Service Act of 1980 was signed into law in December of that year by President Carter. It provides that ''unless otherwise expressly provided by any spousal agreement or court order...a former spouse of a participant or former participant (in the Foreign Service) is entitled to an annuity.''

title: DOME TO BUY 22 MILLION CONOCO SHARES TENDERED
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said early today that it had been offered an estimated 53 million shares of Conoco Inc. under a tender offer and that it would buy 22 million of them at $65 a share.

title: Red Sox Snap Blyleven's Streak at Six With 10-5 Rout of Indians
description: Rick Miller's three-run homer highlighted a six-run fourth inning, Dwight Evans also knocked in three runs and Jim Rice added a pair of homers to power the Boston Red Sox to a 10-5 rout of the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Around the nation; Senate Panel to Get Data On Teamsters' Interim Head
description: A Federal prosecutor said today that he would submit to the Senate Select Committee on Ethics evidence in a bribery case involving Roy L. Williams, interim head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: MIGUEL DE CAPRILLES, EX-DEAN OF N.Y.U. LAW SCHOOL
description: Dr. Miguel de Capriles, a former dean of the New York University School of Law and one of the world's leading authorities on fencing, died on Sunday at the Ralph Davies Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 75 years old.

title: G.M. Diesel Unit In Mexico Accord
description: The General Motors Corporation said its Detroit Diesel Allison division had agreed to join with a Mexican company to build heavyduty diesel engines at a new plant in Aguascalientes, Mexico.

title: WORLD'S BIGGEST DUMP FOR GARBAGE JUST A MONUMENTAL PROBLEM ON S. I.
description: Operating night and day, six days a week, the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, the world's biggest garbage dump, is the final resting place for the 10,000 tons of domestic garbage produced daily by three million New Yorkers.

title: VOLUME UP
description: The stock market's ''OPEC rally'' gained momentum yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average sharply higher in stepped-up trading. Airline, brokerage and bank issues spearheaded the general advance.

title: Arkansas Insurer In Talks on Sale
description: Negotiations are under way to sell the National Old Line Insurance Company, the largest life insurance company based in Arkansas, for about $144 million.

title: Critic's Notebook; PROTECTING THE KIDDIES ON BOTH SIDES OF FOOTLIGHTS
description: I have been thinking of the kiddies lately, mainly because a recent matinee took me right back to the ambience - a word I didn't know at the time - of my childhood. For this particular matinee, hordes of kiddies had been bused into town from heaven knows what suburban school to attend a preview of a new musical, ''Copperfield,'' and it very quickly became plain that they'd done precious little theatergoing prior to that Saturday afternoon.

title: ACADEMY
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's commencement address yesterday at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: CONGRESS NARROWS GAP ON A TAX BILL
description: The Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Bob Dole, and the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Dan Rostenkowski, said today that they had narrowed their differences over a tax-relief bill and that the next concession had to come from President Reagan.

title: Getty Unit to Add Energy Fuels Co.
description: The Getty Oil Company, a major integrated oil producer, and the Centurion Investment Company announced that a Getty subsidiary would acquire the Energy Fuels Corporation, a subsidiary of Centurion, for approximately $70 million. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: REPORTING LED TO A PULITZER PRIZE
description: Martin O. Waldron, chief of the Trenton bureau of The New York Times, whose investigative reporting for The St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times led to a Pulitzer Prize for public service for the newspaper, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: Reagan's Son Accuses Press of Harassing Him
description: President Reagan's son Michael says he quit his job with a small southern California military contractor last week because, ''with the press investigating every contract they got, they would have gone bankrupt.''

title: RENT CONTROL'S FLAWS AS A SUBSIDY PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allied Telephone Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of 325,000 common shares through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.

title: ARRIVING WASHINGTON WIVES: MOVING AND SETTLING IN
description: WASHINGTON THEY all have secure phones, which means no one can listen in while they're talking to their carpenters. And they all have something called Signal, a government screening/answering service that connects their new homes to the White House so that they or their husbands can be reached at a moment's notice. They also have two or three functions to attend each day, often followed by black-tie events at night, and the responsibility of organizing their homes and the lives of their families without losing sight of their own needs.

title: Reds 3, Giants 2
description: CINCINNATI (UPI) - Dave Collins drove in a run and scored another, and Mario Soto limited the Giants to eight hits in a game delayed almost two and a half hours by rain. Soto worked a complete game, striking out seven.

title: Around the nation; Oak Ridge Radiation Leak Prompts Evacuation of 125
description: About 125 workers were evacuated from a uranium enrichment plant for two hours today when low-level radioactive uranium hexafluoride leaked from a compression cell, officials said.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, MAY 28, 1981; The Economy
description: Differences over a tax-relief bill have been narrowed, said Bob Dole, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and Dan Rostenkowski, the Democratic chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. They indicated the next concession had to come from President Reagan. Mr. Rostenkowski said disagreements remained over such issues as the across-the-board rate cuts favored by the Administration. (Page A1.)

description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of the LIFO accounting method; the 1981 6 mos net income reflects 14 cents a shr foreign currency translation loss

title: The City; 3 Accused of Fraud
description: Three Bronx residents were indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that they fraudulently obtained more than $100,000 in payments under the Guaranteed Student Loan Program.

title: Nassau County Officer Convicted Of Assaulting L.I. Motorist in '79
description: A Nassau County police officer has been convicted of assaulting a motorist who had been stopped after an auto chase in November 1979.

title: Plaques to Mark Road Ex-Hostages Traveled
description: The route in New York state traveled by the freed American hostages after their return from Iran will now be known as Freedom Road, as a result of a bill signed into law by Governor Carey.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Marley Holders Approve Asset Sale
description: The Marley Company, which produces cooling towers and heating and air-conditioning equipment, said its shareholders had approved a plan to sell most of its assets to an investor group formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts and Company, an investment banking group, for more than $325 million.

title: L.I. SCHOOL DISTRICT SUES TO BLOCK CUT IN U.S. AID
description: School officials in two New York State communities sued yesterday to prevent a proposed sharp cutback in the Federal program that compensates localities for educating children of military people and Federal employees.

title: Californian Is Named by Reagan As New Ambassador to Austria
description: President Reagan named Theodore E. Cummings, a 73-year-old Austrian-born California businessman, to be Ambassador to Austria today.

title: White Plains Democrat Plans to Run for Mayor
description: County Legislator Carolyn Whittle, a Democrat, said today that she would seek her party's nomination to run for mayor of White Plains.

title: MIA DILLON, BOB GUNTON WIN DERWENT AWARDS
description: Mia Dillon, who won praise for her performances in Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart'' at the Manhattan Theater Club and in Hugh Leonard's ''Summer'' at the Hudson Guild, and Bob Gunton, who accomplished the unlikely feat of portraying 21 of the 22 characters in Amlin Gray's ''How I Got That Story'' at the Second Stage, were named the winners yesterday of the 37th annual Clarence Derwent Awards.

title: KOCH'S SUPPORT BY REPUBLICANS NOW IN DANGER
description: The expected Republican support for the re-election of Mayor Koch was threatened yesterday. Brooklyn Republican leaders openly questioned whether they could reject the mayoral candidacy of their fellow Republican, Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens, in favor of the Democratic Mayor.

description: It used to be that to make big money in stocks on Wall Street, a person had to know how to sell - not understand -them. That may no longer be true.

description: * Atlantic Richfield Company, Los Angeles, has elected Harrison C. Jamison and William A. Keeler senior vice presidents and O. Glenn Simpson vice president.

They were appointed to 10-year terms.

description: Crop analysts said today that the full extent of the damage to wheat fields in central Kansas from the frost of May 9 and 10 may not be known until harvest, but it is likely that yields will be reduced.

title: A's Pitcher Hit by a Drive Suffers Broken Cheekbone
description: Bo McLaughlin, the Oakland A's pitcher who was struck in the face by a line drive off the bat of Chicago's Harold Baines, was reported in excellent condition today at Merritt Hospital.

title: Bridge: Most of Top Teams Survive Second Round in Reisinger
description: Almost all the top-ranked players survived to last night's quarterfinals in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the Beverly East Club in Manhattan. The pairings, by captain, were: Brian Glubok vs. Tom Smith; Kathie Wei vs. John Solodar; Bart Bramley vs. John Suozzo, and Phillip Martin vs. Alan Greenberg.

title: The City; 22 on School Bus Injured in Accident
description: Twenty-one children and a school matron were injured when a school bus hit a pole after its rear axle fell off in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, United Press International reported.

title: MINT: THE BASICS OF AN EXTREMELY MULTIFARIOUS HERB
description: THERE'S many a mint to be planted. Gardeners are rarely satisfied with just one kind. The assortment of leaf colors and subtle differences in flavors have been charming their way into gardens for centuries.

title: Advertising; Two College Students Win Ad Campaign Awards
description: Michele Moyer and Stephen Cowles, both college students in Pennslvania, have won the McCaffrey & McCall Creative Advertising Challenge, beating out 232 other undergradutes from 81 colleges in the Eastern part of the country with advertising campaigns for their individual colleges.

title: PRODUCTIVITY UP AT 4.3% ANNUAL RATE
description: United States business productivity in the first quarter rose at a 4.3 percent annual rate, its largest gain in three and a half years, the Government said in a report today that revised an earlier estimate of 3.9 percent.

title: REAGAN VOWS U.S. WILL PRESS EFFORT TO BUILD DEFENSES
description: President Reagan, asserting that the United States' ''era of self-doubt is over,'' today promised a continuing defense buildup that would not use treaties as a substitute for military hardware.

title: Bond Flood Poised For Drop in Rates
description: While high interest rates are discouraging many corporations and foreign governments that want to sell bonds in the United States, a potential logjam is forming in anticipation of the day when rates are lower and buyers are more plentiful.

SILVER SHAKY ON WORRY ABOUT HUNTS
description: Silver prices came under severe pressure again yesterday, tumbling at one point to $10.26 an ounce, within pennies of the low of $10.20 reached during the ''Silver Thursday'' market debacle of March 27, 1980. But prices recovered almost 20 cents in a late rally.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, MAY 28, 1981
description: International Philip C. Habib was recalled to Washington for consultations on what the United States should do next in seeking to avert an Israeli-Syrian clash over Syria's stationing of antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon. Mr. Habib, the special American envoy, has been in the Middle East for three weeks. Officials said that the main diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis were being left to Saudi Arabia until Mr. Habib returned to the region, probably late next week. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Israel pledged to back further efforts to solve its differences with Lebanon peacefully, but Prime Minister Menachem Begin charged that Syria had mobilized reserves and increased the deployment of missiles in Syria in apparent preparation for battle. (A3:3-6.)

title: CONSOLIDATED CANADIAN FARADAY LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MUSIC: VON DOHNANYI LEADS
description: THE word Romantic means so many different things in so many different contexts and to so many different people that it would be hard to get a panel of estheticians to agree on even a vague definition. But musicians would certainly line up behind the idea that the works of Weber, Mendelssohn and Schubert fall comfortably inside any Romantic boundaries that might be drawn. No arguments, then, about the program with which the New York Philharmonic inaugurated the spring series that it calls ''The Romantic Era.'' Last night's concert at Avery Fisher Hall began, most aptly, with Weber (the ''Euryanthe'' Overture), moved on to Mendelssohn (the Violin Concerto) and closed most resoundingly with Schubert (the ''Great'' C Major Symphony).

title: TIRELESS TROUBLE-SHOOTER FOR THE U.S.
description: When Philip C. Habib was selected to try to head off an Israeli-Syrian clash over Syria's missiles in Lebanon, White House and State Department officials were attracted by his past record as a negotiator in one seemingly insoluble problem after another.

title: REAGAN AIDE'S SON HAILED BY THE CHIEF
description: Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor and one of his closest aides, does not often accompany his chief on trips such as the one made today to the United States Military Aacademy, but this one was different.

title: 36 Parties in Israeli Vote June 30
description: Voters in the Israeli elections June 30 will choose among a record number of 36 parties.

title: Notes on People; Healing the Sick: From Medicine Man to Medical School
description: There is a world of difference between ancient African folk treatment and modern American medicine, but to Kofi Atta-Mensah there is a singular similarity: Both, he noted yesterday, use accumulated wisdom to heal the sick.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
The City; Extradition Upheld In Hong Kong Case
description: A Federal appeals court ruled that a youth living in Brooklyn could be extradited to Hong Kong to face charges that he committed two robberies at knifepoint in 1980, when he was 16 years old.

title: 76ERS' ERVING IS CHOSEN N.B.A.'S MOST VALUABLE PLAYER
description: Julius Erving, the Philadelphia 76ers' forward, was selected as the National Basketball Association's most valuable player today. He is the first player not a center to win the award in 17 years. Oscar Robertson, a guard for the Cincinnati Royals, won it for the 1963-64 season.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida refused to confirm a Western Air Lines statement that Air Florida has acquired 500,000 Western shares, or a 4 percent interest.

title: MSGR. L.J. CAHILL, 70, HARLEM CHURCH PASTOR ACTIVE IN COMMUNITY
description: Msgr. Lawrence J. Cahill, pastor of Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church on West 142d Street in Harlem, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack in the church rectory.

title: Albertson's Net Rises
description: Albertson's Inc., a supermarket chain with units in the West and Southeast, said today that earnings for the 13 weeks ended April 30 rose 15 percent, to $10.2 million, or 66 cents a share, from $8.9 million, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent, to $813.8 million from $714.5 million.

title: FEDERAL PROSECUTORS REJECT PLEA BARGAIN FOR HINCKLEY
description: Justice Department officials said today that lawyers for John W. Hinckley Jr. had tried unsuccessfully to negotiate a plea bargain for their client, who is accused of shooting President Reagan here on March 30.

title: THE CALENDAR OF EVENTS
description: Biblical Garden Day, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Am- sterdam Avenue.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect information provided by the New York State Insurance Department, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday on medical malpractice suits gave an erroneous total for cash awards in the last five and a half years. The correct amount is $45 million.

title: Business People; New President of Todd To Stress Ship Repair
description: Hans K. Schaefer, 45, has been elected president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, effective July 15. He will succeed Arthur W. Stout Jr., 60, who is taking early retirement. J.T. Gilbride, 65, continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the New Yorkbased company.

title: Smaller Investors Buying Issues; But Institutions Remain Wary
description: Purchases in the credit markets by individuals continued at a heavy pace yesterday, while large institutions remained wary of buying notes and bonds, securities dealers said..

title: BRITONS TALKING OF EVEN A RADICAL SOLUTION IN ULSTER
description: Although the hunger strikers in Northern Ireland have not persuaded the British Government to grant their demands for the status of political prisoners, they have certainly achieved another of the goals of the Irish Republican Army organizers - the stimulation of a new debate about the future of the troubled province.

title: Helpful Hardware; UNUSUAL SHELF BRACKETS
description: SCORES of styles and types of shelf brackets are available. Most hardware stores sell a no-nonsense aluminum bracket-and-standard system, and there are also attractive decorative styles to suit any decor. We have found some unusual and attractive shelf brackets that do not use unsightly standards for mounting.

title: AS HOUSTON'S AMENITIES BOOM, ITS SERVICES DECAY
description: It burst upon the national stage in the 1960's as Space City U.S.A., the gleaming new metropolis of the Southwest, home of the astronauts, site of the Astrodome, citadel of medical wizardry. By the end of the 1970's, it had advanced to world class as the capital of a potent, hard-muscled global energy industry. Some called it Super City, others the City of the Future.

title: SOVIET SUSPENDS MANNED FLIGHTS AS SPACE PRIORITIES ARE CHANGED
description: Soviet space officials said yesterday that they planned no more manned flights for several months at least, and perhaps a year, but that they would keep the Salyut 6 space station orbiting the earth for use in unmanned scientific and technical experiments.

title: The City; Full Con Ed Bill Cut To Begin in July
description: The full impact of a 10 percent reduction in fuel-adjustment charges for Consolidated Edison electric customers resulting from the return to operation of the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant will be recorded in bills rendered after mid-July, the company said.

title: BOONE IN THICK OF IT ALL
description: Robert Raymond Boone, a onetime baseball brat, is a 33-year-old catcher for the Philadelphia Phillies who won academic honors in psychology at Stanford before deciding that he wanted to be a ballplayer more than he wanted to be a doctor.

title: GERMANS MAY BUY PART OF ASHLAND COAL
description: The Ashland Oil Company said yesterday that final negotiations were under way to sell 25 percent of its wholly owned subsidiary, Ashland Coal Inc., for $102.5 million to Saarbergwerke A.G. of West Germany.

title: Home Improvement; AIR-CONDITIONER COST CAN BE CUT
description: THE arrival of warm weather means there will soon be days and nights when simply opening a window in the hope of catching a cool breeze will not be enough and air-conditioners will be turned on. Because of the high cost of energy, many people will undoubtedly hesitate to use them, although not when sweltering weather really arrives.

title: The City; Suit Contends Drug Left Baby Disfigured
description: A Queens couple filed a $363 million lawsuit against a national pharmaceutical company, charging that its widely marketed pregnancy drug, Bendectin, had left their newborn daughter ''horribly disfigured and malformed.''

title: BEGIN VOWS PEACEFUL EFFORT BUT SAYS SYRIA MOBILIZES
description: As the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, left for consultations in Washington, Prime Menachem Begin said today that Israel would support further efforts for a peaceful solution of the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon. But he charged that Syria had mobilized reserves and increased the deployment of missiles on its territory in apparent preparation for battle.

title: Hers; A CHILD HAS HER FIRST BRUSH WITH 'CRIME'
description: ICOMMITTED my first white-collar crime in second grade. Like many white-collar criminals, I persist in believing that I acted for an honorable cause and that the lessons crime taught me were not necessarily the ones society would have me learn.

title: A Savings Bank Bill in Time ...
description: LOCK IN 16 PERCENT INTEREST! WE'RE BETTER THAN THE MONEY MARKET FUNDS! The latest advertising blitz by savings banks and savings and loans should bring cheer to inflation-battered savers. But savings industry executives aren't smiling. High interest rates are pushing hundreds of so-called ''thrift'' institutions toward insolvency. Their best hope now -other than a sharp drop in interest rates - is legislation to give Federal regulators broad powers to arrange mergers with commercial banks.

title: FORD'S GERMAN UNIT LOSES $255.6 MILLION
description: Fordwerke A.G., the Ford Motor Company's West German unit that has traditionally been one of Ford's most profitable divisions, said today that it lost $255.6 million last year, its first deficit since 1974.

description: The Lone Star Steel Company said it had developed a new family of steel, oil and gas well casings that resist hydrogen sulfide corrosion and the high pressures and temperatures of deep wells.

title: AGREEMENT TO EXPAND CELL SPACE AT OSSINING IS REACHED IN ALBANY
description: Governor Carey announced agreement with the legislative leaders today on a plan to spend $24.6 million to expand the century-old Ossining Correctional Facility by 596 beds.

title: POLAROID INTRODUCES NEW CAMERA AND FILM
description: The Polaroid Corporation yesterday introduced a new ''system'' - two instant cameras and a high-speed color film - incorporating major refinements in its existing instant photography technology. Analysts described the products as ''evolutionary rather than revolutionary'' but important enough to stimulate the $2 billion amateur photography market.

title: U.N. GAVE $432,000 TO THE FOREIGN PRESS TO PUBLISH ITS VIEWS
description: The United Nations has acknowledged giving subsidies of $432,000 to 15 foreign newspapers for supplements promoting the organization's view on aid to the third world.

description: and Turpan Sanders, a just-opened SoHo store is one of them. The owners, David Sanders and Gregory Turpan, have filled a 3,000-square-foot space with an imaginative and intelligent selection of home fur-nishings.''

title: MENOTTI: IS HE THE 'LAST SAVAGE' IN WORLDS OF ARTS AND FINANCE?
description: CHARLESTON, S.C. IN Gian Carlo Menotti's opera ''The Last Savage,'' which is being presented this week and next at the Spoleto U.S.A. Festival here, Kitty Scattergood, the spoiled, bitchy daughter of a Chicago millionaire, travels to India in search of a living specimen of prehistoric man. She cages him, takes him back to Chicago, brandishes a whip, civilizes him and dresses him in a purple velvet jacket. At a garish party, attended by religious leaders, artists and businessmen, decorated with a mock version of the sculpture in New York's Avery Fisher Hall, she introduces him to the worlds of finance and the arts.

title: Executives Move Up At Superior Oil
description: Fred C. Ackman, 50 years old, took over yesterday as president of the Superior Oil Corporation at the organizational meeting of the board of directors. He succeeds Joseph E. Reid, 52, who became chairman of the exploration and production concern, while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: METS BEAT PHILLIES, 3-1, ON ZACHRY'S 6-HITTER
description: The Mets got back on the revival trail last night when Pat Zachry stopped the Philadelphia Phillies, 3-1, for the team's fifth victory in seven starts since burrowing out of a nine-game losing streak.

title: U.S. MOVES TO REVOKE CITIZENSHIP OF SUSPECT IN EICHMANN PROGRAM
description: The Justice Department moved today to revoke the citizenship of a 71-year-old California man on the ground that he had concealed his activity as a Nazi who helped Adolf Eichmann plan the persecution of Jews.

title: MOST CANDIDATES FOR BYRNE'S POST ATTACK CAP LAW
description: The New Jersey law that puts a cap on increases in spending by local governments was criticized today, with varying degrees of vehemence, by most of the candidates for Governor.

title: NEWS MEDIA FIND IT HARD TO COVER JERSEY PRIMARY
description: New Jersey's June 2 gubernatorial primary is frustrating reporters and confounding editors who say they do not quite know how to cover a race among 21 candidates with their flood of forums, position papers, rallies, news conferences and strategic maneuvers.

title: Shoppers Renew Interest in Used Cars; Sticker Prices Of New Autos Revive Market
description: With the price of the average new car approaching $10,000, shoppers recovering from ''showroom shock'' are finding themselves on the used-car lots more frequently these days.

title: Capital Cities Buys Georgia FM Station
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. of New York has agreed to purchase WBIE, a country music FM radio station, for $7.5 million, a spokesman for the sellers said.

title: Fire Destroys Police Warehouse
description: A fire of suspicious origin at Mitchel Field late last night destroyed a warehouse containing spare parts and equipment for Nassau County's fleet of police cars. The police said an inventory must be done to determine the amount of the loss.

title: The New Haynsworth
description: In the summer of 1979, a human rights activist organizing the ''Internatonal Sakharov Hearings'' asked Senator Edward Kennedy to lend his name and prestige to the advisory board: such sponsorship would help pressure the Russians to stop harassing their foremost dissident.

title: Award Against Bell Overturned by Panel
description: A jury award of $16.5 million in an antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was nullified yesterday by a three-judge Federal appeals panel.

The store, after inspecting it, said the problem was due to moisture seeping up through the concrete slab floor. Since then the condition has gotten worse, so we have to replace the flooring. What is safe to put down, assuming there is a moisture condition that is actually causing this problem? - Mrs. N.B., Woodland Hills, Calif.

description: The defense rested its case yesterday in the murder trial of Craig S. Crimmins after having presented 19 witnesses. The prosecution then immediately began calling rebuttal witnesses to counter testimony given earlier by two psychologists and a psychiatriast who reported their findings about Mr. Crimmins's intelligence and susceptibility to suggestion.

title: STEELMAKERS OPTIMISTIC DESPITE SOFTENING ORDERS
description: Some steel executives who gathered at their annual convention here said yesterday that orders for steel have begun to soften, but they do not yet foresee a repetition of the sharp drop that occurred last May.

title: Saroyan Memorial Monday
description: A memorial for William Saroyan will be held Monday at 7 P.M. at St. Vartan Armenian Cathedral, Second Avenue and 35th Street.

title: PROTESTS PUNCTUATE SOUTH AFRICA FETES
description: A large bomb ripped through an army recruiting station in downtown Durban early today and riot policemen stormed onto a university campus here as South Africa celebrated 20 years as a republic.

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Deere's Net Drops 2.4% in Quarter
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment and a major manufacturer of construction machinery, said yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 slipped 2.4 percent as sales fell 4.5 percent.

title: JUNK THE B-1 - AGAIN
description: Old bombers never die - they just hang on until a new Administration comes into office. The B-1 is coming back in a new version four years after it was shelved by President Carter. The Reagan Administration has resurrected the plane as a symbol of a commitment to a stronger America and as as a corrective to what what it considers was a weakness in Jimmy Carter's defense policy.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN IN MERGER ACCORD
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company, the country's leading producer of sewing patterns, and NCC Energy Ltd. of London, England, announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle to combine the two companies in a share-exchange transaction with an estimated worth of more than $85 million.
