description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHICAGO TRANSIT SYSTEM EXHAUSTS FUNDS, RAISING THREAT OF A SHUTDOWN
description: The Regional Transportation Authority, which has repeatedly warned since mid-March that it was about to run out of funds, used up the last of its money today.

title: Notes on People; Joan Crawford Defended as 'Very Warm'
description: Just about everyone's heard about Christina Crawford's sometimes horrendous account of Life With Mother, Joan Crawford, through the best-selling book ''Mommie Dearest.''

title: Royals 8, Mariners 5
description: SEATTLE (AP) - A three-run homer by Willie Aikens highlighted a four-run first inning for Kansas City. Paul Splittorff (1-4) worked the first six and a third innings and yielded all of Seattle's runs, but left with a 7-5 lead.

title: Advertising; Advertising Magazine Scheduled for This Fall
description: Lawrence Dobrow closed up Lawrence Dobrow & Associates and left Washington after 25 years in the agency business there. Now he is going to edit a magazine of his own creation.

title: TV: SHORTAGE OF NURSES STUDIED BY CBS REPORTS
description: A CRITICAL shortage of nurses in the nation's hospitals is the subject of ''Nurse, Where Are You?,'' this evening's ''CBS Reports'' documentary at 10 o'clock. Produced by Judy Towers Reemtsma and reported by Marlene Sanders, the hour focuses on the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia, finding this widely respected facility no exception to the general shortage pattern.

title: News of Music; A FEAST OF OPERA AWAITS TV VIEWERS
description: OPERA fans have much to anticipate when the fall television season gets under way -a far cry from the days, not so long ago, when opera on the home screen was considered television box-office poison. The turning point came with the first ''Live From the Met'' telecast over the Public Broadcasting Service on March 15, 1977, a ''La Boheme'' with Renata Scotto and Luciano Pavarotti that attracted an unprecedented 7,655,000 viewers. Since then, opera has become an increasingly important ingredient in PBS's programming, and the 1981-82 lineup promises more than ever.

title: SECRET SERVICE GUARDING EMPTY REAGAN HOUSE
description: Neither President Reagan nor his wife, Nancy, has been to the couple's $1.9 million Pacific Palisades home since it went on sale in January, but taxpayers still pay for roundthe-clock Secret Service surveillance.

title: EXPERIMENTING WITH INDOOR FABRIC TENTS
description: THEY look simple enough - one a smooth, curved shape that rises mysteriously overhead in a lower Manhattan loft; another a curtained bedchamber topped by a conical ''hat.'' They are interior tents by a group of architects who since 1971 have established themselves as pioneers in a relatively unexplored field of design - fabric structures.

title: CHANCELLOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GREATWEST HOSPITALS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Business People; Coke Selects President For Food-Wines Group
description: Ira C. Herbert, 53, has been named president of the newly formed foods and wine group of the Coca-Cola Company, effective July 1. In addition, he was appointed director of corporate marketing at the Atlanta-based company.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
MURDER VICTIM IN QUEENS IDENTIFIED AS CRIME FIGURE
description: A murder victim found in a vacant Queens lot on Sunday was identified yesterday as Alphonse Indelicato, a reputed captain' in the organized crime ''family'' once headed by Carmine Galante. Mr. Galante was shot to death nearly two years ago.

title: Design Notebook; DOING CONCEPTUAL FURNITURE AS PLAY
description: ARCHITECTS have always been intrigued - and in some cases obsessed - by the problem of furniture design. Part of this comes from a desire, sometimes admitted, sometimes unconscious, to control every aspect of the physical environment, from the largest structure to the smallest objet.

title: The Region; Brush Fire Disrupts Service on L.I.R.R.
description: Volunteer firefighters battled a stubborn brush fire near the Long Island Rail Road station here for more than three hours before bringing it under control.

title: WATERBED BECOMES A SLEEPING FIXTURE
description: THAT curious and somewhat exotic vestige of the 1960's, the waterbed, currently ebbing and flowing in its second decade, has emerged, despite occasional opposition to it, as a very big business indeed in these early days of the 1980's.

title: BEAUTY CONCERN WILL LEAVE CITY FOR NORTH JERSEY
description: Helena Rubinstein Inc., which has had its headquarters in New York since 1914, has decided to move out. Both the executive offices, now at 300 Park Avenue, and the manufacturing plant in East Hills, L.I., will be moved this summer to the Hartz Mountain industrial complex in Secaucus, N.J., along with at least 150 employees.

title: Convicted Man in Yorkshire Case Faces Questions on Old Murders
description: Peter Sutcliffe, who is already facing life in prison after his conviction in the ''Yorkshire Ripper'' case, will be questioned about unsolved murders and attacks dating back more than 10 years, the police said.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
LABOR BOARD STARTS LEGAL MOVES AIMED AT POSTPONING STRIKE
description: Lawyers for the National Labor Relations Board will go into Federal District Court in New York today to begin a series of legal moves that could postpone until late in the season a strike threatened by major league baseball players to begin tomorrow.

title: YANKS LOSE IN NINTH AS GOSSAGE FAILS, 6-5
description: Not even Rich Gossage, pitching for the first time in eight days, could rescue the Yankees tonight or derail the Baltimore Orioles as they completed a three-game sweep with a 6-5 ninth-inning victory.

title: Article 134375 -- No Title
description: A Superior Court jury yesterday awarded $2.25 million in the case of a 15-year-old Greenwich girl who became retarded as a result of complications during surgery at Greenwich Hospital seven years ago.

title: Ford Lifting Output
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was increasing production at its Dearborn assembly plant to accommodate increased sales of its Mustang and Capri models and will call about 600 employees back to work from indefinite layoff on June 1. Ford said the assembly line speed will be increased to turn out 68 cars an hour instead of the current 52 an hour.

title: Gerulaitis Is Ousted By Ycaza
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, last year's runner-up, was upset by Ecuador's Ricardo Ycaza today and became the third seeded American to fall in the first round of the $600,000 French open tennis championships.

title: Around the world; Tass Attacks Schmidt View On U.S. and Arms Talks
description: The official press agency Tass sharply attacked Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today, dismissing as false his statement that the United States truly desired nuclear arms negotiations.

title: PEUGOT: A GIANT IN TROUBLE
description: Peugeot, the French auto maker that announced yesterday that it would jointly develop a new car for the American market with Chrysler, used to be considered the prissy spinster of the French auto industry. It was rich, proper and dull, qualities that clearly reflected its descent from the 19th-century steel corset stay maker who founded it.

title: MADRID TALKS ON HELSINKI ACCORDS SHOW SCANT PROGRESS
description: Now almost three months beyond its original date for closing, the conference here reviewing the Helsinki accords on security and cooperation in Europe may continue for many more weeks with little to show for its labors.

title: PASSING L.I.R.R. TRAIN KILLS YOUTH ON TRESTLE NEAR DOUGLASTON STOP
description: A 13-year-old boy was killed yesterday on a Long Island Rail Road trestle in Douglaston, Queens, the same place a 14-year-old girl was killed in April 1980.

title: THE WRONGS THAT JOINT CUSTODY RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CON IS IN AND CONSCIENCE IS OUT
description: WHEN the Indianapolis 500 officials took down Bobby Unser's number and declared Mario Andretti the winner of Sunday's automobile race, the issue was not so much that Bobby Unser had cheated as it was that he had been caught cheating. When the yellow caution light is on at Indianapolis, a driver is not supposed to pass other cars. Bobby Unser passed ''eight or nine'' cars, according to Tom Binford, the chief steward. Bobby Unser plans to appeal that ruling, charging that Mario Andretti passed cars, too.

title: Around the World; Doctor Says Pope Will Lose Some Movement in Finger
description: Pope John Paul II will permanently lose some movement in his left index finger, which was struck by a bullet in the assassination attempt two weeks ago, a doctor treating him said today.

title: Market Place; How Brokers View Berkey
description: BERKEY PHOTO INC. drew major support on Wall Street a couple of years ago when the Federal District Court in Manhattan awarded the company $87 million in its antitrust action against the Eastman Kodak Company. Berkey had accused Kodak of trying to monopolize film processing and other aspects of the photography business.

title: Going Out Guide
description: LOOKING BACK

title: Rozelle Defends Status of Pro Sports as Monopolies
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League Commissioner, said today that the league is a natural monopoly.

title: HARTFORD VOTES SECOND GUN-CONTROL BILL
description: Connecticut's State Senate late last night unanimously approved a bill mandating a five-year prison sentence for persons convicted of using firearms while committing most felonies.

title:
Notes on People;
Grateful Fan of Lena Horne Expresses His Thanks
description: From the moment Lena Horne opened her one-woman show at the Nederlander Theater May 12, adoring critics started bemoaning the fact that the opening was too late to make Miss Horne eligible for a Tony Award nomination. So did a Horne fan named George Andrews.

title: PARKING REGULATIONS
description: Because of the Feast of the Ascen- sion, alternate-side parking is sus- pended today. All other rules are in ef- fect.

title: GOLFER'S 7-YEAR DROUGHT OVER
description: Kathy Hite was earning $290 a week through her first 12 golf tournaments on the tour this year, which is just about enough to pay a caddy.

title: Liverpool Triumphs, 1-0, In European Cup Final
description: A goal by Alan Kennedy with nine minutes remaining gave Liverpool a 1-0 victory over Real Madrid in the European Cup final tonight.

title: Mr. Habib Shows The Way
description: The pause in Philip Habib's Middle East shuttle is a moment to say a word about a man who earns the diplomatic accolade: professional. Whether in the end he will succeed in defusing the Syrian missile crisis is still a question. But we know enough to see that Ambassador Habib is giving a classic performance in the difficult role of the mediator.

title: MASONRY DREW MOZART AND WASHINGTON
description: As a quasi-religious society whose members swear fealty to the lodge and each other, Freemasonry has often attracted the wrath of governments and churches.

title: Around the nation; Austin, Tex., Flood Damage Is Estimated at $20 Million
description: Mayor Carole McClellan said today that Austin would seek a Presidential disaster declaration to repair property ravaged by bloods that struck the Texas capital Sunday night, killing at least 10 persons and causing at least $20 million in damage.

title: ELECTRONICS EXECUTIVE IN TULSA IS SLAIN AT COUNTRY CLUB
description: Roger Wheeler, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Telex Corporation, was shot to death yesterday in his automobile at an exclusive country club in Tulsa, Okla., shortly after he finished a round of golf there, the police reported. He was 55 years old.

title: Advertising; Graber & Cohn Acquires New Officer and Account
description: George M. Klas, a 39-year-old Australian, had worked for Unilever in England and Down Under before coming to the United States to be an account man at Ogilvy & Mather and Doyle Dane Bernbach, and then at Bozell & Jacobs, where he had the Renfield Importers account.

title: SONY, PHILIPS PRESENT DIGITAL DISK PLAYERS
description: Prototypes of tiny machines that play high-quality digital records about the diameter of a grapefruit were demonstrated yesterday by the Sony Corporation and the North American Philips Corporation.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
PUBLISHING: BOSS MAKES AUTHOR'S CAUSE HIS OWN
description: MANY authors owe large debts to their editors and their publicists, but rarely is an author taken in hand by the chief of the company himself. Yet that is what has happened in the case of Jacobo Timerman, author of ''Prisoner Without a Name, Cell Without a Number,'' who has received considerable personal attention from Robert L. Bernstein, chairman and chief executive officer of Random House.

title: Lucy Niblack Lyle Wed to Whitney Tower
description: Lucy Niblack Lyle was married in St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday to Whitney Tower. The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony.

title: At the Movies; Good days in the life of a screenwriter.
description: ON May 20, John Guare, the playwright, married Adele Chatfield-Taylor, picked up $1,000 and a medal - the Award of Merit - from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, and flew away for a monthlong holiday in Britain.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change from FIFO to LIFO accounting

title: NURSERY SCHOOL REUNION: KUDOS AND KAZOOS
description: Lisa (Bunny) Birnbach, a model student at the 92d Street Y Nursery School, graduated with the class of '61 and grew up to write a best seller called ''The Official Preppy Handbook.'' Harris (Buzzie) Baumgold, class of '51, who once tried to steal some finger paints (and was caught red-handed), grew up and went into the diamond business. But what brought Gene Shalit to the nursery school reunion when, by his admission, he was expelled from nursery school?

title: THE NEW JERSEY HANDICAP
description: Confusing is the best word for New Jersey's gubernatorial primaries, in which 21 candidates - 13 Democrats and 8 Republicans - seek nomination next Tuesday. The absurdly crowded field is the result of a bizarre experiment in campaign finance ''reform,'' which offered public money for almost any candidate. But that is a topic for another day. It is time to try to spot the real contenders in the race.

title: Kirk Billings, 65, Dies; Friend of the Kennedys
description: Kirk LeMoyne Billings, a retired advertising executive and a friend of President John F. Kennedy, died Wednesday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 65 years old.

description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; HOT AND COLD TERRORISTS
description: The structure and implications of terrorism in Europe are changing. Foreboding undertones provoke memories of the terrible 1930's and require clear, cool reaction. The U.S. is not yet directly involved. But it is of the greatest importance not to be carried away by emotional charges and counter-charges of Soviet master plots that unnerve.

title: Auctions; Disappointing paintings sale.
description: THE auction of 19th-century European paintings at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street, produced some surprises yesterday, when works of which much had been expected did not sell or sold for surprisingly low prices. Others, however, particularly three horse paintings by Sir Alfred Munnings, brought two to three times their estimates. The expected star of the sale was Jean Baptiste Corot's ''The Meditation,'' but it did not find a buyer during the auction, although negotiations continued afterward. This pensive 1860's study of Emma Dobigny, one of the artist's favorite models, surfaced this year, when the person who had inherited the painting sent a photograph of it to Sotheby's.

title: No Headline
description: Books: Robust Survivor By John Leonard THE PARIS REVIEW. 25th Anniversary Double Issue. 420 pages. Paris Review/ Eastern News Company. Paper, $10.

title: Fighting Inflation With Crossed Fingers
description: Ten years ago this summer, when prices were rising at a shocking rate of 5 percent a year, President Nixon stunned the nation by imposing the first peacetime wage-price controls in history. Now, news that prices last month were rising at roughly the same 5 percent rate is viewed by some as the beginning of the end of the war on inflation.

title: Business People; Ex-Head of Korvettes Settles Suit on Salary
description: David Brous, the fast-talking, skilled home-furnishings merchant who served as president of Korvettes Inc. for seven years before resigning in May 1979, has settled a suit for unpaid salary that he filed against the once-prosperous and now nearly defunct retail chain.

title: TRINITY RESOURCES LTD

RED SMITH;
If You Can't Win, Relax
description: WHERE a baseball strike had seemed almost inevitable at the start of this week, it now appears that the club owners will back away from their demand for compensation for players lost to free agency and eliminate the only reason for the players to walk out. No guarantee goes with this prediction. It is simply a gut feeling based on past performances.

title: MAKING ADJUSTMENTS TO THE BRIBERY ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO BILLS SIGNED ON GUN CONTROL FOR CONNECTICUT
description: Two gun-control bills that will go into effect Oct. 1 were signed into law today by Gov. William A. O'Neill. One mandates a five-year prison sentence for using a firearm while committing a serious crime and the other requires a one-year term for carrying a handgun without a permit.

title: BYRNE URGES 3 TO GIVE UP THEIR GUBERNATORIAL QUEST
description: Governor Byrne has privately urged at least three liberal-leaning candidates in the Democratic gubernatorial primary for Govenor to drop out of the race in favor of his candidate, John J. Degnan, the former state attorney general, a spokesman said tonight.

title: RELIGION BECOMES POLITICAL BATTLEGROUND IN NICARAGUA
description: ''Christ is here,'' Tomas Borge Martinez, the Sandinist Interior Minister, told a crowd one recent Sunday with a Jesuit priest standing pointedly at his side. ''Those who say He is coming want to justify the counterrevolution. Christ has never left the heart of the Nicaraguan people.''

title: Taylor, Young Sign Giants Contracts
description: Lawrence Taylor, the University of North Carolina linebacker, has signed a contract with the Giants. General Manager George Young announced today that the Giants had signed nine players selected in last month's National Football League draft. Among them were Taylor, the Giants' first-round choice, and Dave Young, the Purdue tight end picked in the second round. George Young said he expected no difficulties signing the five remaining draftees.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Restored Lenn Sakata, infielder, to the roster from the disabled list and sent Bob Bonner, infielder, to Rochester of the International League.  CALIFORNIA (AL) - Dismissed Jim Fregosi as manager and named Gene Mauch to replace him. Placed Doug Rau, pitcher, on the disabled list and restored Dave Frost, pitcher, to the roster.

title: PLENTIFUL GAS AT STABLE PRICES PREDICTED FOR NEW YORK AREA THIS SUMMER
description: Gasoline is expected to be plentiful in the New York metropolitan area this summer, with prices fairly stable in contrast to the usual seasonal increases.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks Planned
description: For the first time since the curtailment on grain sales to the Soviet Union was imposed last year, United States and Russian officials will conduct formal talks next month on new grain sales.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES DROP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates dropped sharply yesterday, and the Treasury was able to sell new 13 7/8 percent, five-year, five-month notes at an average rate of 13.95 percent, well below the 14.6 percent yield that was estimated earlier in the week.

title: Around The Nation; Coast Prosecutors Seek To Extend Sirhan Term
description: City prosecutors here will try to extend the prison term of Sirhan B. Sirhan, the slayer of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, beyond his release date of September 1984, a spokesman said here today.

title: Data Relay System Announced by G.E.
description: The General Electric Company announced a new system that can beam data from one building to another within a close range using highfrequency microwaves.

title: No Headline
description: Associated Press ANTI-GOVERNMENT DEMONSTRATION IN KOREA: Student demonstrators fleeing from police after breaking through roadblock on the Seoul National University cam-pus. It was the second day of their rock-throwing clashes with riot police. The students were demanding the resignation of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea.

title: France's Socialists Cancel Plans For a Nuclear Station in Brittany
description: The French Government, making good a campaign promise by President Francois Mitterrand, said today that it was abandoning plans to build a nuclear power plant at Plogoff in Brittany.

title: Around the Nation; Judge in Chicago Rejects Bid To Continue Transit System
description: As another suburban bus line announced plans to close, a Circuit Court judge refused today to order the penniless Regional Transportation Authority to keep mass transit systems running in northeastern Illinois. Officials of the Chicago Transit Authority, which depends on the regional transit agency for funds, predicted that a shutdown of the city's system could come as early as June 6.

title: O'NEILL VOWS TO PRESS FIGHT TO RESTORE BUDGET FUNDS FOR SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, today stepped up his campaign to alter the Federal budget by vowing to press for Democratic proposals to restore funds for social programs now facing severe slashes under the proposed budget adopted last week by Congress.

title: The Region; Private Now Faces 2 Assault Charges
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Joseph G. Christopher, a 25-year-old white Army private charged with slaying three black men in the Buffalo area and a dark-skinned Hispanic man in Manhattan, was indicted yesterday in knife attacks on two other black men in Buffalo.

title: BLOCK GRANTS FOR EDUCATION IN JEOPARDY
description: President Reagan's plans for consolidating Federal spending for education into block grants to states and localities began unraveling in Congress today, with key members of his own party expressing strong reservations about the proposal.

description: Every era needs its own taboos, its own pornography. What is the pornography of modern America? Certainly not sex, not in a time when the most explicit devices and images are available over the counter or the television cable. But if our pornography is not sex, then what is?

description: After hinting yesterday that Gene Michael's job might be in jeopardy, George Steinbrenner said today that he would stick with Michael as manager of the Yankees and made some changes in the coaching staff and one roster move.

description: The total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $104.6 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

description: Sherwood & Schneider, the Della Femina, Travisano & Partners subsidiary whose principals were previously principals of KSW&G, yesterday got its first account since its formation on May 1.

description: Israeli jets struck at Palestinian guerrilla encampments today in wide-ranging raids along the Mediterranean coast and also reportedly in the southeast of Lebanon.

title: Dr. Charles N. Ford, 91; A Civic Figure in Harlem
description: Dr. Charles N. Ford, a dental surgeon in Harlem for 30 years and a leader in business and community activities there, died last Friday at his home in Massapequa, L.I. He was 91 years old.

title: MUSICAL BRIDGE TO ISLAM
description: The greatest musical traditions, Western or non-Western, have combined the esoteric and the popular. If a piece of music is too unashamedly popular, it is usually deficient in spiritual depth. If it is too refined and intellectual, it may lack humanistic resonance. At 7:30 Sunday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, a particularly enticing blend of the refined and the earthy will be on view when the Sabri Brothers ensemble from Pakistan appears for a three-hour concert that will blend the refined and the earthy.

title: CHASE CUTS PRIME RATE TO 20%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday cut its prime lending rate to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, but many economists and analysts were reluctant to interpret the move as the start of a long-term drop in interest rates.

title: The City; 2 Officers Accused Of Cocaine-Dealing
description: Twenty-three persons, including two city police officers and two former officers, were indicted in connection with an alleged ring importing about $3 million worth of cocaine a year from Peru, according to the United States Attorney, Edward R. Korman.

description: It was elegantly hushed the other night in the French Consulate, where Robert Ricci was showing his Paris couture collection to 300 guests.

description: Frank C. Lanza, 49, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Loral Corporation, a big defense producer. As president, he succeeds Bernard L. Schwartz, 55, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, which has its headquarters in New York.

description: Government forces today reported killing 20 Communist rebels and wounding several in a monthlong operation in the south. Seven Government fighters were killed and 106 rebels surrendered.

The waiter brought it and I took out a notebook from the pocket of the coat and a pencil and started to write. Hemingway, ''A Moveable Feast''

title: Texas Flood Toll Rises to 12
description: Fire Department squads searching Lake Austin today found two bodies missing since the weekend flooding, bringing the number of dead to 12. Two other persons were still listed as missing and a Fire Department spokesman said the search would continue.

title: Brady Has Pneumonia; Doctor Sees Little Peril
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, has developed pneumonia, but a doctor said today that it was a ''highly manageable'' infection in his left lung and could be treated successfully with antibiotics.

description: After 12 years in office, District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn said yesterday that he would not seek re-election in November, and he vigorously endorsed his executive assistant, Norman Rosen, as his successor. Meanwhile, istrict Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said he intended to seek re-election.

title: Pop Jazz; THE BLOOM HAS FADED AT SMALL ROCK CLUBS
description: THE proliferation of new rock clubs that has been one of the most significant developments in New York's rock subculture during recent years has ground to a halt. Hurrah, which became the city's first successful ''rock disco'' in 1978, closed last week, and the Rock Lounge and the 80's closed recently as well. In the last year Tier 3, Danceteria, Heat and a number of other clubs shut their doors. Maxwell's in Hoboken, a favorite of many Manhattan rock bands and fans and of visiting groups from as far away as the West Coast and Britain, is closing on July 4, though it may reopen one night a week in the fall.

title: PRINCIPALS TO FACE FINES OVER LACK OF PUPIL SHOTS

title: 'HAUNTING OF JULIA' FRAZZLES MIA FARROW
description: IN ''The Haunting of Julia,'' which opens today at the Coronet, Mia Farrow appears as she's never appeared before. She plays a frail, neurasthenic, terrified creature who moves into a dark and spooky dwelling. Granted, that sounds as if it might not be much of a stretch. But this time, Miss Farrow does something new: she develops rusty-brownish coloring, because ''The Haunting of Julia'' has been sitting on the shelf for a while. The film stock has begun to fade, thus giving the movie its only touch of novelty.

description: The caretaker Government of Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani suspended five high-ranking officials today pending an investigation of reports that they belonged to an illegally secret Masonic lodge.

title: DANCE: A BIRD, A PLANE? NO ... IT'S CROWSNEST
description: THE first odd thing about Crows-nest, which opened in its New York debut season Tuesday at the Public/Newman Theater, is its name. Does it refer to a ship's lookout perch? Or to a nest found on the farm where the company was formed three years ago? Could Martha Clarke, Felix Blaska and Robert Barnett, the collective's three participants, be raven dance-creatures, glossy of feather and very keen - and somewhat malevolent - of eye?

title: The Evening hours
description: I might as well have been Quebec. In fact, on Wednesday evening part of the Waldorf-Astoria was the Commonwealth, North American division. There were maple trees and potted live pines, trucked down from Canada for the occasion; rows of Royal Canadian Mounted Policemen; quilted piper bands piping ''Scotland the Brave'' and all of Canada's provincial flags arrayed in front of, around and in the hotel's grand ballroom for the ''Salute to Canada,'' sponsored by the women's committee of the American Cancer Society.

title: LEADING INDICATORS UP 0.4% IN APRIL
description: The Government index that is intended to forecast economic trends climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. The rise in the index of leading economic indicators was the second straight following three monthly declines.

title: DOW UP 1.11 AFTER A LATE RALLY
description: A late rally rescued a lethargic stock market yesterday, although energy-related issues remained under selling pressure. While the performance lacked the dynamic gains of Tuesday and Wednesday, it marked the third straight session when prices turned notably stronger in the final hour.

title: Economic Scene; An Opportunity For Reagan
description: THE Greeks thought the most important attribute of a military commander was to be lucky, and that goes for economic policy makers as well. Thus far, President Reagan seems to have the luck of the Irish. He has just had a big helping hand in his inflation fight from, of all people, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: STAGE: RICHARDSON STARS IN STOREY'S 'EARLY DAYS'
description: David Storey's ''Early Days'' is less a play than an acting exercise. It was written expressly for its principal player and is designed, above all else, to show off that actor's full range of gifts. As the performer in question happens to be Ralph Richardson, who can complain? Mr. Storey writes very well for his star - he plays him like a Stradivarius - and Mr. Richardson abundantly returns the favor. In ''Early Days'' we hear all his high notes, all his low notes - and all that beautiful, tremulous poetry in between.

description: Ballistics tests on three .22-caliber rifles have determined none is the weapon a sniper used to wound six persons from the upper floors of a Brooklyn building, the police said yesterday.

title: ART: THE IMPASTO WORLD OF WALTER DARBY BANNARD
description: ARTISTS have been mixing their paint with ''alien'' substances for most of the 20th century. But it has taken the invention of plastics to make the practice widespread and, while in earlier times the use of additives sometimes denoted the material poverty of the artist, the reverse is true today. Pigment now is as likely to be combined with body-building compounds as it is with mere oil and turpentine, and the texture of a canvas can resemble practically anything from a hooked rug to junk food. The ''process'' movement of the 1960's greatly encouraged the trend by giving a new twist to the old notion of ''truth to materials.'' Similarly, the very style of Color-Field painting was to a great extent determined by the synthetic paints employed. It was logical, therefore, that such representatives of the movement as Jules Olitski and Walter Darby Bannard should have continued experimenting with new materials.

description: The Uruguayan military Government has been badly shaken by a scandal that has led to the resignation of a number of senior officers and delayed moves to return to democracy.

description: The President of the ruling junta of El Salvador today rejected a new proposal by the Socialist International to mediate in the leftist-rightist conflict on the ground that it would be ''an act of intervention.

title: The City; Bronx Bus Garage Approved by Board
description: The Board of Estimate voted, 6 to 5, to approve the construction of a bus-maintenance garage near Co-Op City in the Bronx to the accompaniment of shouts from 150 angry spectators, according to United Press International.

title: CITY PUPILS' READING SCORES IMPROVE
description: The reading scores of public-school pupils in New York City have exceeded the national average for the first time in the 12 years that the citywide test has been given.

title: ART: MERIDA, A FATHER OF MEXICAN MODERNISM
description: ALTHOUGH he was born in Guatemala, Carlos Merida, who will be 90 this year, has long been regarded as a father of modern Mexican art. Like the late Diego Rivera, he has made a large contribution to the Mexican mural movement, but with a difference: his murals, which adorn public buildings in several Latin American countries, are abstract and entirely devoid of social content. Of part-Spanish, part-Mayan ancestry, Mr. Merida also helped bring about a revival of interest in the Indian art forms of his native country, using them himself as a basis for the abstract art that is his main concern.

BASEBALL STRIKE OFF AS PLAYERS, OWNERS EXTEND DEADLINE
description: Major league baseball players will not strike today. The strike, if there is one, could come as early as next Thursday or as late as June 1, 1982.

title: ANGELS DISMISS FREGOSI AND NAME MAUCH
description: The California Angels dismissed Jim Fregosi as manager today and named Gene Mauch, former manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, Montreal Expos and Minnesota Twins, to replace him.

description: New London, Conn., may be best known these days for its submarines base, but this weekend the emphasis will be on the oared craft in the 117th annual Yale-Harvard Regatta.

description: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, Archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw and Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, spent three decades in a struggle with secular authority and left the Polish church far more powerful than before.

description: Bo McLaughlin is scheduled to undergo surgery tomorrow to repair damage suffered when he was hit in the face by a line drive, officials at Merritt Hospital said today.

description: Government officials are reviewing what they call ''questionable'' federally financed volunteer projects under the Vista program to determine if they should be suspended because of political activities, the director of such programs, Thomas Pauken, said yesterday.

title: Around the World; U.N. Defends Payments For Favorable News Articles
description: The senior United Nations information official today defended payments to newspapers for articles favorable to the organization, saying that $432,000 distributed among 15 newspapers in various countries was simply to reimburse the companies for the amount of newsprint used to publish the material.

title: Divesting Move By Swarthmore
description: The Swarthmore College Board of Managers announced today that it had divested itself of nearly $2.4 million worth of stock in corporations that deal with South Africa.

title: ABUNDANT PORTUGUESE RESIDENTS ELUDE THE SOUTH AFRICAN CENSUS
description: South African authorities are well known for numbering and tabulating the various population groups in this country on the basis of race and ethnic origins. But one group that is conspicuously large and growing, the Portuguese, appears to have eluded the official tabulators.

title: THE GOLDEN AGE OF SPAIN CELEBRATED IN THEATER, DANCE AND ART
description: SPAIN'S greatest outpouring of literature and drama occurred in the 16th and 17th centuries: El Siglo de Oro, or the Golden Age, was the epoch of Spain's premiere novelist, Cervantes, and of its pre-eminent playwrights, Lope de Vega and Pedro Calderon de la Barca. This weekend, on the 300th anniversary of Calderon's death, three of New York's leading Hispanic cultural institutions - the Museo del Barrio, the Ballet Hispanico and the Intar Hispanic-American Theater0- begins ''The Golden Age of Spain,'' an arts festival that spans two cultures and the heart of Manhattan from 42d Street to 104th Street.

title: FOR MRS. D'AMATO, IT'S COMPUTERS, NOT POLITICS
description: Five months after her husband was sworn in as a United States Senator - a job his wife says he wanted at least since they began dating more than 25 years ago -Penelope D'Amato has achieved a long-held ambition of her own. She has earned an advanced technical degree, which she says she wanted ever since the youngest of their four children started school several years ago.

title: MARTHA BACON, POET AND NOVELIST, TEACHER AT RHODE ISLAND COLLEGE
description: Martha Bacon, a poet and teacher, died of cancer in Providence, R.I., on Tuesday. She was 64 years old. She was associate professor of English at Rhode Island College at her death.

title: India's Rails Test for Alcohol
description: The Railway Ministry has ordered engineers of diesel and electric trains to have Breathalyzer tests ''so that no driver steps onto the footplate of his locomotive after consuming alcohol.'' The ministry said in a statement that the tests would be extended to steam-driven locomotive engineers, railroad guards and other employees.

title: Extradition Pacts Go to Senate
description: President Reagan today sent to the Senate for ratification treaties of extradition with Colombia and the Netherlands, saying that they would ''make a significant contribution to international cooperation in law enforcement.''

title: TENTATIVE COAL ACCORD IS REACHED
description: A tentative contract agreement was reached early today by negotiators representing soft-coal miners and coal industry operators. If approved by the union's bargaining council and then the rank and file, the accord would end a 64-day strike by Eastern and Middle Western miners.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 26
'POLYESTER,' AN OFFBEAT COMEDY
description: JOHN WATERS has done more to make tubby transvestites a staple of the cinema than any other director working today. He has also made a number of films, among them ''Pink Flamingoes'' and ''Desperate Living,'' that even at the level of plot synopsis would leave large segments of an audience grossly offended.

title: FIVE AMERICANS AND A CHINESE REACH FINALS IN CLIBURN PIANO COMPETITION
description: Six pianists, all males, five of them Americans and one from China, were chosen last night as the finalists of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. They are the survivors of the 39 pianists from 17 countries who started competing on May 17 for the richest prize that any musical competition in the world has to offer - a $12,000 cash award, a recording contract and two years of solo and concerto appearances in the United States, Europe and the Far East.

title: FREED SOVIET JEW FOUND PRISON TEST OF HIS FAITH

description: DOME PETROLEUM LTD. of Canada appears to have gained some headway in its plan to acquire the majority interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, the prize in a bitterly contested battle between Dome and Conoco Inc.

description: To the Editor:

title: Harper Pronounced Healthy

title: MONUMENTAL, INTIMATE AND BASICALLY BACH
description: THIS year's Basically Bach festival will widen in ambition by becoming a little smaller. The grand presentations of this annual late-spring event will remain as before - beginning with tomorrow's performance of the B minor Mass and ending next Saturday, June 6, with the Charpentier Te Deum and Vivaldi's G minor Magnificat, both at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: A DOWNSIDE-UP LOOK AT HOW NEW YORK TICKS
description: New Yorkers grow up on legends about what lies below the ground they walk on. Dinosaurs are said to be buried in a corner of Central Park. Some people say glittery-eyed alligators roam the city's sewers. And whole confederations of tramps are said to celebrate their rituals in vast, neglected chambers beneath midtown hotels. But what really lies below the surface of the city will be explored in ''A Mole's Eye View,'' a four-hour tour sponsored by the 92d Street Y that begins this morning at 11:15 in front of 316 East 63d Street.

title: Esmark Earnings Up 62.3% in Period
description: Esmark Inc., a diversified consumer and industrial products company based in Chicago, reported yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter rose 62.3 percent on an increase in revenues of 16.6 percent.

title: Energywatch
description: MAY 22 Crude oil stocks dipped to 405.7 million barrels. Experts say the decline reflects increased refinery output and reduced imports.

title: THEATER: MARATHON OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: SHEL SILVERSTEIN has taken the second oldest story in the world, ''The Lady or the Tiger,'' and turned it into a cynical satire of our acquisitive, amoral society. This play by the noted cartoonist and children's author is the highlight of the first round of ''Marathon 1981,'' the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual festival of one-act plays. ''The Lady or the Tiger'' gives center stage to Richard Dreyfuss, offering a malicious comic portrait of an irredeemably ambitious television producer who will do, say or promise anything if it will raise his ratings.

title: Ratelle Ends 20-Year Playing Career

title: Time Inc. to Raise Satellite Capacity

title: CHINA'S PROSPECTS
description: Dreyer CORAL GABLES, Fla. - An often-postponed meeting of the Central Committee of China's Communist Party will now, it appears, be held in mid-June. Lengthy delays in scheduling it have reflected deep-seated disagreements within the elite over the country's problems. At issue has been the degree to which the central leadership can loosen social and economic reins without losing control of the society and its economy.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; CECIL TAYLOR UNIT AT THE PUBLIC THEATER
description: Cecil Taylor, the pianist, who has been an influential figure in jazz for more than 20 years, has been attracting particular interest in recent years as a composer. He has been commissioned to write and perform music for the Munich Symphony and the Brooklyn Philharmonia as well as for Mikhail Baryshnikov and for the Alvin Ailey dance company. Tonight and tomorrow at 10:30 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, he will make his only group appearance in New York City this year as he introduces a new version of his Unit. It includes two young players new to the group - William Parker on bass and Rashid Bakr on drums - as well as a veteran of the Unit, Jimmy Lyons on alto sax. Tickets are $7.50. Information: 598-7150.
