Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MINNESOTA RAG. By Fred W. Friendly. 243 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $12.95.

title: CITY INVITES BIDS ON BUS SHELTERS AS DISPUTE REMAINS UNRESOLVED
description: New York City has begun advertising for bidders on a contract to maintain shelters at bus stops, James F. Capalino, the Commissioner of General Services, said yesterday.

title: Notes on People; Brademas Tells Law School Graduates: We Need You
description: Take the word of a law school dropout, Dr. John Brademas, president-designate of New York University, what this country needs is a lot of lawyers to play active roles in the legislative process.

title: Fred Meyer Inc. Bids For Founder's Stock
description: Directors of Fred Meyer Inc. have tentatively approved a plan for the Northwest merchandising chain to buy company stock owned by the estate of Fred G. Meyer.

title: Around the World; Ukrainian Jewish Activist Said to Get a 3-Year Term
description: A Ukrainian Jewish activist, Vladimir Kislik, has been sentenced to three years in a labor camp after being convicted of malicious hooliganism in Kiev, dissident sources said today.

title: STRONG DEFENDER OF POLISH CHURCH
description: Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, died of stomach cancer early today. He was 79 years old.

title: MRS. THATCHER PAYS 9-HOUR ULSTER VISIT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made a nine-hour visit to Northern Ireland today in a gesture of concern over the recent political turmoil there.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON STANDARDS FOR TWO-MAN SANITATION TRUCKS
description: A productivity dispute between New York City and the sanitationmen's union that led to a work slowdown by some of the crews on the new two-man trucks has ended in an agreement on monitoring performance standards.

title: LITERARY GIANTS IN MS. AND CARICATURE
description: THE Pierpont Morgan Library, which can usually be counted on to provide a glimpse of something rare, interesting and beautiful in its special exhibitions, has fetched up from its vast storehouse of autograph manuscript materials an astonishing survey called ''British Literary Manuscripts, 1800-1914.'' The cast of characters represented in this exhibition is pretty remarkable. Jane Austen and Sir Walter Scott, Charles Dickens and William Makepeace Thackeray, William Wordsworth, Thomas Babington Macaulay and Samuel Taylor Coleridge are all in it, and - among authors from the other end of the period under review - so are Willlam Butler Yeats, James Joyce, H.G. Wells, Max Beerbohm and D.H. Lawrence.

title: COURAGE OF CREW IN CRASH PRAISED
description: The aircraft carrier Nimitz steamed home to a somber reunion of crew and families today, and officers told a tale of courage when a Marine aircraft crashed and plowed through men and machines on the flight deck before exploding in a ball of fire Tuesday night.

title: A Foul Wind For Mariners
description: Lenny Randle of the Seattle Mariners says he did not blow a baseball into foul territory against the Kansas City Royals last night. But that's the way the umpires wound up seeing it, and the ruling went against Randle - and the Mariners.

title: Around The Nation; Strength and Skill Hinted In Killer of Atlanta Blacks
description: The strangulations of increasingly older blacks since a baffling string of slayings began here may indicate that their killer was ''very strong'' or had ''some kind of special training'' in assault techniques, a medical examiner said today.

title: WASTE CONCERN PRESIDENT IN JERSEY DENIES MOB TIE
description: Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New Jersey state police told a House subcommittee hearing today that one of the nation's largest waste disposal companies had participated in an illegal system of territorial allocation of customers mediated by organized crime in New Jersey.

title: MASSEY NARROWS DEFICIT
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the multinational manufacturer of farm and industrial machinery, reported today that it lost $8 million in the second quarter of the current fiscal year, a sharp improvement from the $81.4 million first-quarter loss.

title: Lacking a Pact, Dome Bought Stock it Sought
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. almost canceled at the last minute an offer to buy 22 million shares of Conoco Inc. directly from stockholders for $1.43 billion, Dome insiders said yesterday.

title: Advent Files Plan Under Chapter 11
description: The Advent Corporation, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since March, said that it had filed a proposed plan of reorganization with the United States Bankruptcy Court. The company makes high fidelity audio components and home video products.

title: Borg Advances In Paris
description: Bjorn Borg of Sweden, seeking a record sixth victory in the French Open tennis championships, defeated Cassio Motta of Brazil 6-1, 7-5, 6-0, in the rain today and advanced to the third round.

title: Around The Nation; Swarthmore Divests Itself Of Stock in 3 Corporations
description: The Swarthmore College board of managers today divested itself of nearly $2.4 million in stock from corporations that deal with South Africa, saying American concerns should be ''responsible agents for progressive social change in South Africa.''

title: DR. MAURICE H. FLEYSHER
description: Dr. Maurice Henry Fleysher, an industrial chemist for 38 years and then a cancer researcher for 18 more, died Wednesday at Buffalo General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: COMMONWEALTH THEATRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
RECITAL: GILLIAN WEIR, ORGANIST
description: IN 1978, the New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists created an International Performer of the Year Award ''to recognize excellence in organ performance and to increase public awareness of the organ and its performers.'' Previous recipients have been Robert Noehren and Catharine Crozier.

title: Notes on People; Billy Carter Moving On to Alabama
description: The best-known resident of Plains, Ga., Jimmy Carter, has returned to his hometown, but Plains's second-best-known son, Billy Carter, is leaving to accept a job in Haleyville, Ala.

title: American League; Brewers 7, Tigers 1
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI) - Roy Howell hit a grand slam home run and Ted Simmons added a two-run shot to pace Milwaukee. The victory was the Brewers' 11th in their last 14 games.

title: Income Ceiling for Food Stamps Will Be Raised by 13% on July 1
description: Income ceilings for food stamp recipients will raised by 13 percent on July 1 to $360 a month for a single person to account for rising prices, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BROOKS & PERKINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Eisenhower Aide Picked As Ambassador to Italy
description: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Maxwell M. Rabb, secretary to the Eisenhower Cabinet, to be Ambassador to Italy.

title: OIL WIDENS TRADE GAP FOR APRIL
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit, pushed by newly rising figures for oil imports, grew to $3.46 billion in April, the Commerce Department reported today. A department analyst said, however, that the oil statistics could be misleading.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, MAY 29, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan criticized Wall Street, charging that the financial community had focused excessively on credit market conditions and that it had failed to understand his economic program. The remarks were seen as a sign of frustration over the recent disarray in financial markets and the resulting pressure on the Administration to compromise its position on tax cuts. (A1.) Wall Street's reaction was mixed. (D4.) In Washington, the Administration and Congressional Democrats continued negotiations on tax-cut legislation, without notable success. (D4.)

title: COALITION IN HOUSE IS HINTED
description: After another round of negotiations with the Administration, House Democratic leaders reported today that substantial differences remained over the size and shape of a taxrelief bill.

title: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $297,000 or 27 cents a sha for the quarter and $627,000, or 58 cents a share, for the year C-Including extraordinary credits of $116,000, or 11 cents a sh for the quarter and $217,000, or 20 cents a share, for the year

title: A Pulitzer Prize-Winning Weekly Is Offered for Sale in an Editorial
description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning Point Reyes Light is for sale for $135,000, its owners have announced in a page 1 editorial.

title: Restaurants; Two cuisines with Latin accents.
description: IF there is no consistently excellent Mexican restaurant in the city, there are at least several places that offer a few wellprepared specialties of that ethnic kitchen. For almost 30 years, El Charro on Charles Street in Greenwich Village has had a loyal coterie that has come to rely on certain dishes. The setting is friendly, convivial and rustically Mexican, the prices are low to moderate, and if you pick your way carefully among menu choices, you can leave well satisfied.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * American Agronomics Corp. said that shareholders of record June 8 would be entitled to purchase one share of a spinoff, American Agronomics Cattle Corp., for each four shares of American Agronomics stock.

title: Real Estate; How Jersey Homes Site Kept Going
description: BRIELLE, N.J. THE vocabulary of housing is narrow, so it is hardly surprising that the term ''condominium town houses'' tells nothing about the look of a community of new homes.

title: Solomon Debt Plan Approved by Court
description: The Sam Solomon Company, a Charlestonbased retail chain that filed for protection under Federal bankruptcy laws in August 1980, said a plan of reorganization providing for 100 percent repayment of its debts had been approved by a Federal Bankruptcy Court.

title: SLAIN TELEX CHIEF'S VAST EMPIRE
description: Oil companies, jai alai and the Telex Corporation. This was the business world of Roger M. Wheeler until he was shot to death on Wednesday as he left a country club in Tulsa, Okla.

title: LACANA MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Region; Essex Jail Inmates Stage a Protest
description: Prisoners in a section of the Essex County Jail refused for about two hours to return to their cells in a protest.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, MAY 29, 1981
description: International Israel jets swept over Lebanon and destroyed what a military spokesman described as a complex of Libyan antiaircraft missile batteries guarding Palestinian guerrilla positions south of Beirut. The spokesman said that the attack was made after missiles had been fired at Israeli reconnaissance planes. (Page A1 Column 6.) Reports from around Lebanon contrasted with Israel's announcement that its planes had destroyed missile batteries at only one encampment. Jets from Israel struck at Palestinian guerrilla camps in wide-ranging raids along Lebanon's Mediterranean coast and also reportedly in the southeastern part of the country. (A10:1-4.)

title: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for the latest third quarter reflect a nonrecurring cha equal to 9 cents a share Year-ago 9 months results include a $1,369,000 non-tax deductible charge Year-ago results reflect a change to the LIFO accounting method

title: SALVATORE M. DE STEFANO
description: Salvatore Mario de Stefano, a concert harpist and composer, died May 18 at St. Clare's Hospital.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AB Volvo, the Swedish car, bus and truck manufacturer, has elected to its board James W. Walter, chairman and chief executive officer of the Jim Walter Corporation.

title: MUSIC: AMERICAN PHILHARMONIC
description: FOR the last 80 years, Bruckner's Ninth Symphony has been accepted and frequently performed as the composer left it at his death in 1896, an incomplete torso in three movements. Realizing that he probably would not live to compose the finale, Bruckner once suggested that his Te Deum, written in 1884, might serve as an appropriate conclusion -obviously a makeshift solution despite a few thematic references common to both works.

title: Business People; Mutual of New York Selects a President
description: Henry S. Romaine, 47 years old, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Mutual of New York, the nation's 12thlargest life insurance company, effective on Monday. He will succeed Robert U. Shallenberger, 64, who will retire.

title: Extent of Offer by Its Holders Stuns Conoco
description: When Conoco's founder, E.W. Marland, struck oil 70 years ago on land belonging to a Cherokee Indian named Willie Cries-for-War, Mr. Marland could have little imagined what his company would one day become.

title: U.S. May Return Nazi Art to West Germany
description: A collection of Nazi art seized by United States troops after World War II may be returned to West Germany, but an Army art curator said that four watercolors by Hitler most likely will stay in this country.

title: CABLE TV TALKS OPEN ON COAST TODAY
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California will deliver the keynote address at the opening of the National Cable Television Convention here tomorrow. Mark Fowler, the new chairman of the Federal Communicatons Commission, will use the forum on Sunday to make his first major policy address. No fewer than two dozen Congressmen and state legislators are scheduled to appear on panels discussing the issues surrounding cable television.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: In a move that might spell an end to the efforts of two major publishers to acquire UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc., the cable company announced yesterday that it had begun negotiations on a higher bid from United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. and Rogers Telecommunications Ltd.

title: A $3.05 BILLION ISSUE MEANS HARD WORK FOR AN UNDERWRITER
description: Robert Mascatello, the 29-year-old supervisor of the underwriting operations unit at Merrill Lynch, was nervously pacing the hallway of the firm's concourse-level accounting offices yesterday. In front of him was a row of windows where clerks were preparing to receive checks totaling $3.05 billion from banks and securities firms throughout the country.

title: Players See Hope After Briefing
description: Twenty-five players were briefed for two and a half hours last night on the agreement that delayed the baseball strike, then voted unanimously to renew their strike authorization for the future.

title: WHAT THE WHITE HOUSE THINKS ABOUT CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED PRESBYTERIAN GROUP RESOLVES ISSUE THAT THREATENED MERGER PLANS
description: Presbyterians have reworded a question asked of candidates for ordination after a dispute generated by a minister who seemed reluctant to affirm the deity of Jesus.

title: Braves 9, Dodgers 4
description: ATLANTA (AP) - Gaylord Perry moved closer to 300 victories and hit a two-run single in a seven-run rally that chased Fernando Valenzuela.

title: Soviet Admiral, G.I. Levchenko; Stormed Winter Palace in 1917
description: Adm. Gordei I. Levchenko, who took part in the storming of the Winter Palace in the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution and went on to become commander of the Soviet Baltic Fl eet, has died, the military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda reported today.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to LIFO accounting method and certain other accounting changes

title: Threats to Reagan Brother Cited
description: A Los Angeles woman has been arrested on charges of making threats against Neil Reagan, President Reagan's brother, the San Diego County Sheriff's Department said today. Raisa Borisova, 62 years old, was arrested Tuesday night inside the garage at the home of Neil Reagan, 72.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have never found Wall Street a source of good economic advice.'' -President Reagan. (A1:4.)

title: Newton, Cook Tied for Lead
description: Bethesda,Md., May 28-Jack Newton, and Australian who is a regular on the American tour, and John Cook tied today for the first-round lead of the Kemper open at 65, five under par.

title: Around The Nation; Hinson Pleads No Contest To Oral Sodomy Charge
description: Former Representative Jon C. Hinson of Mississippi today pleaded no contest in District of Columbia Superior Court to a charge of attempted oral sodomy involving a Library of Congress employee in a House office building restroom last February.

title: Chrysler Outlook Is Termed 'Good'
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which lost $1.7 billion in 1980, has a ''good shot'' at breaking even in the April-June quarter, according to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige.

title: EASED STAND HINTED ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Reagan Administration indicated for the first time today that it was willing to consider using general tax revenues to help rescue the Social Security System from the threat of insolvency.

title: BENCH FRACTURES AN ANKLE
description: Johnny Bench, the Cincinnati Reds' catcher-first baseman, suffered a fractured left ankle today in the Reds' 7-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants. Bench was carried off the field in the seventh inning on a stretcher after sliding into second base in an attempt to break up a double play.

title: BERT J. LIPPMAN
description: Bert J. Lippman, founder and president of General Art Associates, died Wednesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital of a heart attack.

title: A CRITIC'S-EYE VIEW OF THE SIX FINALISTS
description: Following are the finalists in the Van Cliburn Competition, with their ages, hometowns, the pianos they used and a brief critical evaluation by Harold C. Schonberg: Zhu Daming, 29, China, Bosendorfer: ... his instincts are remarkably sure and he learns with incredible speed. He has a blazing technique, draws a resonant sound from the piano, and approaches music in a very serious manner.

title: IN THE WAKE OF FRANCOIS MITTERRAND'S VICTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: AT COLUMBIA GRAMMAR, AN ERA ENDS
description: In Headmaster James W. Stern's pine-paneled office at Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School - popping out rosily amid old etchings, team trophies, wry cartoons and student artwork - a Valentine from the current kindergarten class reads, ''Thank you for setting up the school.''

title: Oilers Waive Jack Tatum
description: The Houston Oilers waived Jack Tatum, a former all-pro defensive back, today and signed Mike Renfro to a multiyear contract.

title: TV Weekend; ORDEAL OF AN ARGENTINE PUBLISHER
description: TONIGHT at 9, WNET-Channel 13's ''Bill Moyers' Journal'' continues its recent run of absorbing conversations with an hour titled ''The Ordeal of Jacobo Timerman.'' Mr. Timerman is the former Argentine newspaper publisher who was jailed and tortured by Argentina's military regime, then stripped of his citizenship. His description of the experience was published in The New Yorker and then as a book.

title: NEW PANEL, FAMILIAR TRANSIT REPORT
description: Governor Carey's advisory panel on transit issued its initial report tonight, but provided none of the proposed solutions Mr. Carey had promised when he appointed it last week.

title: Five Charged in Beating Of Refugees From Cuba
description: A supervisor at the Immigration and Naturalization Service and four detention officers were indicted yesterday, charged with beating and abusing Cuban refugees at Fort Chaffee, Ark., last fall.

title: Broadway; 'Dream Girls,' new Michael Bennett musical, due in fall.
description: ''DREAM GIRLS,'' a new Michael Bennett musical, will open at the Winter Garden on Nov. 8. Actually, Mr. Bennett is only the director and co-choreographer, but any musical he is involved with will be identified as a Michael Bennett musical. (Similarly, there are Hal Prince musicals, except when Mr. Prince works with Stephen Sondheim; then they are Prince-Sondheim musicals.) Meanwhile, ''Dream Girls'' will have a book and lyrics by Tom Eyen, who wrote ''The Dirtiest Show in Town'' and ''Women Behind Bars,'' and music by Henry Krieger, who once wrote for television's ''Captain Kangaroo'' and then moved on to pop.

title: The Harbor on 103d St.
description: For those who like the history of New York Harbor but don't want to get their feet wet, a visit to the Museum of the City of New York this weekend may be in order. Two galleries of the museum, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, have been transformed into a wharf, complete with weathered walkway, harbor sounds and lilting sea chanteys.

title: Caramoor Festival Will Open on June 27; Caramoor Festival Will Open June 27
description: The 1981 Caramoor Festival, on the Caramoor estate near Katonah, in Westchester County, will open June 27 with a Mozart concert in the Venetian Theater. James Conlon will conduct, and the program will offer two symphonies, Nos. 34 and 38, and the Piano Concerto No. 23 in A with Misha Dichter as soloist.

title: PREVOR-MAYRSOHN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results reflect a $37,847 extraordinary loss on the sa of an investment

title: CONESCO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Terrell Industries Ltd a newly formed subsidiary

title: Tass Assails Reagan Talks With Wife of Dissident
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass today described President Reagan's meeting yesterday with the wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, as interference in Moscow's internal affairs.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,800 for the quarter and $23,100 for the year...C-Including tax credits of $20,200 for the Quarter and $215,300 for the year Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in March

title: Bartok Memorabilia On View at Carnegie Hall
description: An exhibition of Bartok memorabilia including manuscripts, letters and photographs is being shown at Carnegie Hall during the period of the hall's Festival Concerts.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, MAY 30, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan invited Democratic Congressional leaders to the White House for a ''last chance'' meeting Monday on a tax compromise, White House officials disclosed. He will decide afterward whether to begin a national publicity campaign to win public support for his plan to cut income taxes, they added. (Page 1.)

title: Soviet Aide Ends Visit to Britain
description: The Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, Vladimir N. Sushkov, today ended a weeklong official visit to Britain, the first by a Soviet minister in the nearly two years since Soviet troops intervened in Afghanistan. A joint communique said both countries would seek ways to expand economic and commercial relations.

title: FRANK ALTSCHUL, A BANKER AND NOTED PHILANTHROPIST
description: Frank Altschul, an investment banker who was a senior partner at Lazard Freres & Company until 1945 and chairman of General Investors Corporation Inc. until his retirement in 1961, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 94 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Since the early 1800's, the United States Supreme Court has reigned virtually unchallenged by Congress and the President as the ultimate authority in interpreting and enforcing the Constitution.

title: Prisoners Moved From Essex Jail
description: Corrections officials moved 33 prisoners from the Essex County Jail to state facilities today and promised to work with inmates to ease tensions that sparked a disturbance at the jail on Thursday.

title: Bus Line in Chicago Area Plans to Suspend Service
description: The largest private bus company in the Chicago area said today that it would suspend service by midnight, and others threatened to shut down within the next few days as the regional mass transit network moved closer to collapse.

title: WOODWARD & LOTHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
P.E.N. American Center Gives Translation Awards
description: The P.E.N. American Center has presented its annual awards for the most distinguished translations into English of books published here. John E. Woods received the $1,000 P.E.N. prize, donated by the Book-of-the-Month Club, for Arno Schmidt's ''Evening Edged in Gold,'' published by Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, translated from the German.

title: Jail Guards End Pay Protest
description: Middlesex County jail guards who had called in sick to protest delayed cost-of-living raises returned to work today after Gov. Edward J. King signed a bill providing $1.7 million for the pay increases.

title: Asarco Completes Share Repurchase
description: Asarco Inc. said it had completed the purchase of all of its shares held by the Bendix Corporation by buying 1.78 million common shares for approximately $103 million.

title: N.B.A. Unit Recommends Steps to Halt Zone Defense
description: The National Basketball Association's rules and competition committee recommended today that the rule on the prohibited zone defenses be clarified.

title: FILMWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.6 million for quarter and $1.5 million for the year...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $526,000 for the quarter and $6.9 million for the year and extraordinary gains of $408,000 for th quarter and $1.6 million for the year...D-Net income

title: HANOI REPORTS FINDING THE REMAINS OF 3 U.S. AIRMEN
description: Vietnam announced today that it had found the remains of three United States airmen missing since the Vietnam War.

title: News Analysis
description: There is a brief time, between the promises of the campaign and the long haul of trying to make a mark on reality, when a new Government has a moment to present itself. This is done through its appointments, its first measures, usually symbolic, and its first words. These, in different ways, are all signs. Through them the Government says what it would like to be, as opposed to its campaign version of what it thinks the voters would like it to be or what reality will compel it to be in the future.

title: Life Term Given in Drug Case
description: A Trenton man was sentenced to life in prison today for trying to distribute more than a half-pound of heroin and cocaine. The man, Warren A. Leverett, 32 years old, was convicted last March of the possession of 147 envelopes of heroin and cocaine with intent to distribute.

title: GOT GOOD MATH GENES?
description: Why can't Janey do calculus? Is it because she's a girl and was born with bad ''math genes''? That's the disquieting interpretation being given to new research done at The Johns Hopkins University.

title: Three Held in Recovery of Items From Thefts at the Smithsonian
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has recovered four items stolen in the last year from the Smithsonian Institution, among them a valuable silver pen used by John Hay to sign the 1898 Treaty of Paris, the Smithsonian said today.

title: Wobbly Spain
description: Whenever political violence occurs in Spain, there is heard a familiar, complacent theory: The Spanish are by nature immoderate, too deeply divided by doctrinal and regional passions to sustain a democracy. As evidence this year, pessimists point to the brief seizure of Parliament by right-wing Civil Guards, the bloody renewal of Basque terrorism, the recent seizure of a Barcelona bank, presumably by rightists, and now an apparent plot to kill the King.

title: 60'S ACTIVISM STILL STRONG IN ALBANY BISHOP
description: The spirit of the 1960's is alive and well here, and living in the Bishop's residence. And the man who occupies the residence is doing what he can to keep that spirit alive in a more forbidding building a few blocks down the street, the State Capitol.

title: WAS LIBRARY OF CONGRESS OFFICIAL
description: David Chambers Mearns, a writer and humorist whose career at the Library of Congress spanned 58 years, died in Alexandria, Va., on May 21 after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: POP: THE CLASH, QUARTET
description: The title of ''the world's greatest rock band'' has been applied to the Clash by many critics who see the English rock quartet's roughand-ready anthems as the culmunation of the rock-as-revolution tradition that was born in the late 60's. On Thursday, at the first of eight sold-out performances at Bond's International Casino, they demonstrated that fervent, critical adulation and some commercial success haven't diluted their intransigence.

title: DOCUMENTS LINK NAMIBIA SOLUTION TO BETTER U.S. TIES TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The United States will work to end South Africa's isolation if that nation cooperates in achieving an internationally acceptable settlement for the independence of South-West Africa, according to purported State Department documents made available today.

title: ACCESSORY LINE BY LIZ CLAIBORNE
description: As fashionable women know, accessories are every bit as important as clothes themselves. A good leather bag or belt can make a whole outfit look expensive. The right scarf can update last year's dress. One of the women who's very aware of what accessories can do to pull together a look is Liz Claiborne, the designer. She feels so strongly, in fact, that she resisted all efforts to get her to+esign accessories until she could do everything with one company. Most designers license one company to make scarves with their names, another to make gloves, another to do bags, and so on. Not Miss Claiborne. Kayser-Roth is producing her scarves, belts, gloves, hats and handbags. Everything relates to her sportswear line. The same colors, fabrics, weaves and textures are used so that her customer can dress in Liz Claiborne from the top of her head to the hem of her skirt or trousers. No stockings or shoes bear her label yet, but give her time. This fall is only her second season designing accessories.

title: COBB RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Sports of The Times; From Jock to Belle
description: SHE had a date to a prom in another city. In the evening she would come home from badminton practice and transform herself from jock to belle of the prom, parading through the living room in the frilly pink Mary McFadden gown she had discovered on a marked-down rack at Syms.

title: ROMAN CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-Including $95,000 tax credit

title: Odd Doings in Ork
description: The producer of the ''Mork and Mindy'' situation comedy on ABC television, Garry Marshall, told a college audience in Salt Lake City that the two title characters of the show will marry next season.

title: 28 ARE INJURED IN A BRAWL AT STATE PRISON IN COMSTOCK
description: A late-morning exercise period ended in a brawl between guards and prisoners today at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility. Two guards were admitted to hospitals and 26 inmates and guards suffered minor injuries.

title: POLAND SAYS ARTICLES BY AMERICAN CONCOCTED TALES OF 'UNDERGROUND'
description: The Polish Foreign Ministry and the Solidarity trade union have denounced as a fabrication articles by an American who visited Poland four months ago.

title: Financial Times Plans Layoff of 200
description: The financially troubled Financial Times has announced plans to reduce its staff of 1,900 by 200 people over the coming year after losing $210,000 last year.

title: HARBOR YIELDS BOTH GLITTER AND LITTER
description: Live artillery shells, a dead sea turtle half the size of a Volkswagen Beetle, a drowned giraffe, antique crockery, pocketbooks, chemical sludge, raw sewage and about 5,000 cords of driftwood a year -the waters of New York Harbor yield a strange and eclectic bounty.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.2 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced late yesterday that the nation's money supply declined $1.2 billion in the week ended May 20, and for the second consecutive week the drop in money supply caused shortand long-term interest rates to drop sharply.

title: Carey Is Drawing Up Plan To Save Glen Grand Prix
description: Governor Carey is putting together a $2 million state plan to save the 1981 Watkins Glen Grand Prix auto race, his aides confirmed today.

title:
Patents;
New Device Discourages Smoking
description: WASHINGTON A clinical psychologist in Plymouth, Mass., has patented an antismoking device. It infuses cigarettes with a substance carrying an unpleasant odor that discourages smoking.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 25
description: Results are for 53 weeks for the latest year and 52 weeks for t previous year

title: Albania Denies Role in Bombing
description: Albanian newspapers said today that Albania's Deputy Foreign Affairs Minister, Reis Malile, had rejected Yugoslavia's accusation that Albania was involved in the bombing of the Yugoslav Embassy in Tirana last week. Mr. Malile reportedly summoned Yugoslavia's Ambassador in Tirana, Branko Komatina, and told him, ''We have never attacked, nor will we ever attack, the Yugoslav Embassy in Tirana.''

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
RECORD SET FOR U.S. IMPRESSIONIST
description: William Merritt Chase's ''Gravesend Bay'' yesterday sold for $820,000, an auction record for an American Impressionist painting and for the artist. The 1888 canvas showing a woman and two children on the shore of the bay was purchased by John Parkerson, a Houston dealer, who went on to make other record-breaking purchases in the sale at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries.

title: Rozelle Ends Testimony At N.F.L. Antitrust Trial
description: After a week of testimony, Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League left the witness stand in a Federal antitrust trial today, stressing his view that fan support is crucial to the league's success.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: B-After $4.4 million loss from discontinued operations

title: Unit of Baldwin Buys S.& H. Shares
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said that a subsidiary had bought 9,500 shares of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company common stock at $34 a share on the open market, the final such stock purchase before consummation of a merger of the two companies.

title: SYLVIA KNOX BINGHAM
description: Sylvia Knox Bingham, a longtime Connecticut civic leader, died Thursday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn. She was 74 years old and lived in Salem, Conn.

title: U.S. SEEMS TO RIDE OUT THE COAL STRIKE
description: There is no question that the coal strike has hurt: Miners have lost more than $50 million a week in wages, the economies of the Eastern coal states have been badly hammered and the nation's secondquarter economic growth may have been held down as much as 1.5 percentage points.

title: Linda Phillips Married To Thomas P. Spollen
description: Linda Howe Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Phillips of Concord and Dennis, Mass., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Thomas P. Spollen, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Spollen of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Henry Mancel performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Joan Joyce Enjoys Moments of Glory
description: Joan Joyce, the 40-year-old professional athlete who is best known as a softball player, held the lead in a golf tournament for the first time in her life today even though it was only for eight holes of the $125,000 Golden Lights event at the Stanwich Club.

title: FREDERICK SCHUMAN SCHOLAR, DIES AT 77
description: Dr. Frederick Lewis Schuman, a specialist on Nazi Germany and Soviet affairs who taught political science at Williams College for 32 years, died on May 19 in Portland, Ore., where he had been living with a son. He was 77 years old.

title: POPULARITY OF WINES UNLEASHES GROWTH PAINS IN CALIFORNIA VALLEY
description: The Napa Valley, perhaps America's premier source of premium table wines and certainly a stunning, largely unspoiled region reminiscent of rural France, is experiencing a sudden popularity that is straining its resources.

title: WHY THE VOTERS AREN'T VOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING TO ACCEPT FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILTY
description: The language of finance is still new to many women, and they are just beginning to speak it with some fluency. In the past, women may have been responsible for paying household bills, but that was often as far as their financial acumen was stretched, either by family design or their own desire. Certainly many were not given to chatting with friends about Treasury notes, bonds and money market funds, as many husbands and fathers were.

title: U.S. Tightens Farm Disaster Aid
description: The Agriculture Department announced changes in regulations today to tighten administration of its emergency lending to farmers who suffer damage from natural disasters.

title: Ailey Dancers to Tour 5 Latin American Cities
description: Philip Morris International will sponsor the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in a five-city tour of Latin America, from Monday to July 7. The company will visit Mexico City; Bogota, Colombia; Santiago, Chile; Buenos Aires, and Rio de Janeiro.

description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: DEREK WALCOTT'S 'PANTOMIME,' IN WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON To wrap up its 30th-anniversary season, Arena Stage is offering audiences an admirably eclectic diet of theater. The company's main auditorium, the Arena, is occupied by a new production of ''God Bless You, Mr. Rosewater,'' the musical adaptation of Kurt Vonnegut's novel. In the small, 180-seat Old Vat Room, the first local production of David Mamet's ''American Buffalo'' is in unlikely repertory with the imported cabaret ''Banjo Dancing.'' And then, in the medium-sized Kreeger, one finds the exotic piece de resistance: ''Pantomime,'' a 1978 play by the Trinidadian writer Derek Walcott.

title: AMERICA FOR SALE
description: Contemporary American culture is the closest thing there is to a universal world culture. While the Coca-Cola logo may be the most prominent symbol of this phenomenon, it is only the beginning.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Yr to April 30
TIMES COMPANY VOICES REGRET OVER 2 ARTICLES FROM SUBSIDIARY
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that Harley Lippman's articles about Poland ''appear to be of questionable accuracy,'' and it expressed regret over their publication. But Mr. Lippman defended them as ''truthful in their entirety'' and contended that Solidarity, the independent Polish labor union, had disavowed them out of fear that they might be used to discredit it.

title: F.C.C. SAYS JERSEY TV NEWS SHOW IS EXEMPT FROM EQUAL-TIME RULE
description: The Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that the New Jersey Nightly News television broadcast was a news program and thus it did not have to give equal time to all candidates in the gubernatorial primary next Tuesday.

title:
Patents;
Inflatable Boat Developed To Carry One Person
description: A mini-boat that can be inflated to carry one person has been invented for the Navy. George P. Gillespie, a project engineer at the Naval Air Development Center in Warminster, Pa., was granted patent 4,268,930 this week.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago sales have been reclassified to include royalty income

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to May 10
Bridge: The Wei and Martin Teams Near Finals of the Reisinger
description: Teams led by Kathie Wei and Phillip Martin seemed headed for the Reisinger knockout finals when semifinal play resumed last night at the Beverly East Club here.

title: About New York; COUNTING THE TINY DEVILS THAT FOUL THE WATER AT BEACHES
description: Water is in Ron Schliessman's blood. It was not always so. His initial efforts in the public health line consisted of flushing out rats, and the landlords who housed them, in residential buildings in Harlem. And his vocation is not always grand. Much of his time is spent scrutinizing ordinary tap water, water that people insist is green, or tastes like vinegar, or has feathers in it, or is being laced with arsenic by a disgruntled superintendent.

title: 2 COOL REFRESHERS FOR SUMMER HEAT
description: In recent years, it has become much easier to find great and rare wines in New York than to come across properly prepared iced tea or iced coffee. Plebeian in appeal and relatively low-priced, those all-American summer coolers do not have the status to command the careful attention they deserve, either from restaurateurs or home cooks.

title: Pen Sovan Is Elected Leader Of Cambodia's Ruling Party
description: Cambodia's ruling People's Revolutionary Party ended a four-day congress in Phnom Penh today after electing Defense Minister Pen Sovan as Secretary General, the Cambodian press agency S.P.K. reported.

title: SOFT-DRINK WARS HEATING UP
description: Suddenly it's summer, and those athletic young men and women who peddle soft drinks in television ads have traded their jogging suits for swimwear and are now sipping on the beach. As the weather warms up, so does the rivalry - never too cool in recent years - between Coca-Cola and its longtime rival, Pepsico.

title: Bid on Hudson's Bay Reported Rebuffed
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. of Toronto made an offer to purchase Conoco Inc.'s 53 percent interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company and was rebuffed, according to unconfirmed reports from Canada.

title: POP SHOPPES INTERNATIONAL (CANADIAN CO) reports earnings for Qtr to March
description: B-Net income including $29,600 tax credit

title: Fujitsu Presents 2 New Computers
description: Fujitsu Ltd., Japan's leading computer manufacturer, announced the development of two computers it says have the world's largest memory capacity and fastest data-processing speed.

title: Fogel Appointed Director Of National Symphony
description: Leonard Silverstein, president of the National Symphony's board, has announced that Henry Fogel, manager of the New York Philharmonic, would assume the duties of the executive director of the orchestra in mid-July.

title: PRYOR AND ALDA PROVING STARS STILL SELL MOVIES
description: The lesson of the Memorial Day weekend at movie box offices is that stars still sell movies. In this case, the stars are slightly surprising ones - Richard Pryor and Alan Alda. Mr. Pryor's ''Bustin' Loose'' opened in 725 theaters for a five-day gross of nearly $7 million. ''Four Seasons,'' written and directed by and starring Mr. Alda, opened in 600 theaters to five-day sales of nearly $6 million.

title: REAGAN PLAN WOULD AID TROUBLED SAVINGS UNITS
description: Under a plan prepared by the Treasury Department, the Reagan Administration would provide temporary letters of credit to ailing thrift institutions caught in a profit squeeze caused by high interest rates.

title: No Headline
NEW YORKERS UNITED IN A WALLET'S RETRIEVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: SINDONA DENIES FINANCIAL LINK WITH MASON IN ITALY
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier jailed in New York for his role in the collapse of the Franklin National Bank, has told an Italian parliamentary commission that he had good relations with Licio Gelli, the head of an illegally secret Masonic lodge, but that Mr. Gelli had nothing to do with his financial activities.

title: The City; Guardian Angels Get City Recognition
description: The Guardian Angels, the volunteer youth group whose subway patrols have produced mixed feelings among the public and officials, won official recognition yesterday from New York City.

title: BAKER AND HOME FOLKS SWAP VIEWS AND CHATTER
description: Home for a week, the Senator talks in the country way, standing with his hands in his pockets to deliver an in-person accounting of ''a brief overview of the situation in Washington'' to a sizable gathering of the Smoky Mountain elite here in upper eastern Tennessee.

title: CRITON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: B-Including $344,000 income from discontinued operations

title: NAUMBURG VIOLIN WINNER NAMED
description: Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg won the 1981 Walter W. Naumburg International Violin Competition, after seven finalists competed at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The prize includes a $3,000 award, two concerts at Alice Tully Hall, a recording with the Musical Heritage Society and orchestra appearances and recitals around the country.

title: EXECUTIVE DIRECTORS AT 3 HOSPITALS WILL BE REPLACED BY CITY AGENCY
description: The executive directors of three city hospitals - Harlem, Cumberland and Elmhurst - are being replaced, the president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation disclosed yesterday.

title: Spot Commodity Index Is Ended
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, is being discontinued with the figures for the week ended last Tuesday. The decision, announced late last year, resulted from budgetary constraints, the bureau said. It also said that the information in the index was available from private sources.

title: BANGLADESH REPORTS DEATH OF PRESIDENT ZIAUR RAHMAN
description: President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh was killed today in the southern city of Chittagong, the Bangladesh radio reported. He was 45.

title: BONN OFFICIAL SEES WELFARE CUTS AHEAD
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, addressing the national convention of his Free Democratic Party, asserted today that cuts in West Germany's social welfare budget were unavoidable, a position that could lead to conflict with his Social Democratic partners in the governing coalition.

title: Minimarathon Draws 5,500
description: Jacqueline Dixon, winner of the first minimarathon in Central Park in 1972, has been invited back as a guest spectator today for the 10th running of the 10,000-meter race. She was first among 78 competitors in the time of 37 minutes 1 second.

title: SQUEEZE ON BRAND-GAS DEALERS
description: Sy Kasper's Texaco station on Queens Boulevard sells one of the best-known gasolines in the United States on a traffic-packed thoroughfare that would be the envy of any dealer.

title: Financier Is Guilty of Fraud In Peking Man Case
description: Christopher G. Janus, the financier who set out in 1972 to find the fossilized bones of the Peking Man, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today of defrauding two banks to obtain loans for a movie project about his search for the prehistoric creature.

title: DANCE: ANNUAL CONCERT BY PERFORMING ARTS
description: As one might expect of an institution that offers ballet, modern dance, character dance, ethnic dance and jazz, the annual dance concerts of the School of Performing Arts tend to be varied. Thursday night's concert by the senior class, plus a few juniors, at Norman Thomas High School was unusually varied. Lasting almost three hours, it was also unusually long. Audiences could get eyestrain from watching so much dancing. Yet it did indicate that the school's dance department, headed by Lydia Joel, gives students sound training in many forms.

title: I.R.A. Hunger Strikers Seek Seats in Irish Parliament
description: Four Irish Republican Army hunger strikers and five other I.R.A. prisoners in Belfast's Maze prison will run in elections June 11 for seats in the Irish Parliament, their supporters announced today.

title: EXPOS BEAT PIRATES FOR 4TH STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: Scott Sanderson combined with Bill Lee on a six-hitter tonight in pitching the Montreal Expos to a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates for their fourth straight victory.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY PRESS FOR QUICK TRANSIT ACTION
description: The leaders of the Legislature, frustrated by a delay in proposals from Governor Carey's transit advisory panel, called today for immediate action to begin rebuilding New York City's transportation system and to forestall big fare increases.

title: Oregon Pardons for 56 Urged
description: District Attorney Michael Schrunk said today that he would ask Gov. Victor L. Atiyeh to pardon 56 persons because of improper behavior by the narcotics officers who arrested them. An investigation confirmed earlier indications that officers planted drugs on suspects, lied to obtain search warrants and stole property from people who were arrested, Mr. Schrunk told a news conference.

title: Buses Run Again in The Hague
description: Streetcars and buses resumed operation here today after a 21-day strike that left the city without any public transport, union officials said.

title: OPPOSITION PRESSES TRUDEAU TO RELEASE CARTEL STUDY
description: Canada's leading opposition party renewed demands today in Parliament that the Government make public an official report that the Progressive Conservatives believe will buttress their charge that the Canadian Government operated outside its own antitrust laws when it helped set up an international cartel to rig uranium prices starting in 1972.

title: AGM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Dr. Charles N. Ford, 91; A Civic Figure in Harlem
description: Dr. Charles N. Ford, a dental surgeon in Harlem for 30 years and a leader in business and community activities there, died May 22 at his home in Massapequa, L.I. He was 91 years old.

title: The Associated Press
description: A Queens couple accused of stealing thousands of dollars in Government checks from mental patients in their care were sentenced yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn to three years' probation on plea-bargained charges of tampering with the mail.

title: APARTHEID FIGHT IS URGED
description: Participants at a conference on United States policy in South Africa this week heard demands for stiff new legal measures and direct action, including consumer boycotts, to force American companies to promote social change and to end racial discrimination in that country.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, MAY 30, 1981
description: International A negotiated end to the Middle East crisis is ''achievable,'' said Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, on his return from three weeks of negotiations in the Middle East. But he cautioned Syria and Israel against building up combat forces near the Lebanese border. Mr. Habib said he would return to the region next week. (Page 1, Col.1.) Heavy artillery and rocket exchanges erupted between Lebanese Christian militiamen in Zahle, 30 miles east of Beirut, and Syrian forces, sending the town's 200,000 people back to underground bomb shelters. (1:2.)

title:
Patents;
Fuel Additives Made From Vegetable Oils
description: Fuel and lubricant additives derived from vegetable oils were patented this week for the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla.

title: Royal Graduation
description: Among some 400 graduates who will receive degrees at Amherst College in Massachusetts tomorrow will be one Albert Grimaldi.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The Soviet Union's Soyuz-T 4 spacecraft concluded the final manned mission to the Salyut 6 space station, which has orbited the Earth for nearly four years.

title: BALLET: SYDNEY COMPANY PERFORMS 'SHEHERAZADE'
description: Things picked up brightly with Australia's Sydney Dance Company at the City Center Thursday night on a far stronger second program. The stunning use of decor was still evident -especially in the gorgeous new ''Sheherazade.'' The difference was in the choreography, with a bill that had plenty of meat as well as range.

description: Books of The Times Re-doing Donne By ANATOLE BROYARD JOHN DONNE: LIFE, MIND AND ART. By John Carey. 303 pages. Oxford Univer- sity Press. $19.95.

description: With four fledgling cable-television networks producing and acquiring high-quality programs here, the competition among them is to carve out an audience in what they all agree is a limited universe.

A Memorable Night in a Mozart Landmark
description: Tonight the baritone Sherrill Milnes will be singing in ''La Traviata'' with the touring Metropolitan Opera company in Detroit's Masonic Temple, but he said in New York yesterday that he'll probably still be thinking about where he performed last Sunday.

title: Koch Is on Helicopter Forced Down in Croton
description: A helicopter carrying Mayor Koch back to New York City from a criminal-justice meeting was forced to make an emergency landing at about 10:15 last night because of bad weather, the police said. There were no injuries.

title: COMPUTER PROCESSOR EXPANDS RAPIDLY
description: The odds are one in twenty that your next paycheck was processed by a company in Clifton, N.J., called Automatic Data Processing Inc., or A.D.P., the country's largest payroll-processing concern.

title: CENSUS FINDS FEWER BLACKS IN HARLEM
description: In the last decade, the number of blacks living in and near Harlem has decreased sharply, but the black population has increased in many other Manhattan neighborhoods, according to 1980 census figures.

title: A New French Minister To Visit U.S. in a Week
description: The State Department announced today that France's new Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, would visit Washington next week.

title: DEMOCRATS INVITED BY REAGAN TO TALKS ON TAX COMPROMISE
description: President Reagan has invited Democratic Congressional leaders to the White House on Monday for a ''last chance'' meeting on a tax compromise White House officials said today.

title: CAMPAIGN FOR ROE OR FACE A FINE, JERSEY UNION INSTRUCTS MEMBERS
description: Aides of Representative James J. Florio today released copies of a letter from labor supporters of one of his rivals for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, Representative Robert A. Roe, urging 2,000 union members to campaign actively for Mr. Roe or face a $50 fine.

title: Armored in Ignorance
description: For many parents, this country is a scary place. Being frightened is, of course, a concomitant of parenthood, but the reasons for fear appear to have multiplied.

title: DOUBTS ON 1982 FAIR IN TENNESSEE INVOLVE SIZE, QUALITY AND MONEY
description: On the spring morning of May 1 next year, the 1982 version of a world's fair is scheduled to open in this industrial and university city in the lower Appalachians of East Tennessee.

News Analysis
description: The scores on the mathematics test released this week by the New York City public school system indicate that youngsters here seem to have the same difficulty as those around the country: they have trouble applying the basic skills they learn in the lower grades to solving problems in the higher grades.

title: MCENROE WINS
description: Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe, the top-rated contenders for Bjorn Borg's French open tennis crown, advanced to the third round today.

title: Judge Dismisses 4 Charges For Blanton Co-Defendant
description: A Federal judge today dismissed an extortion charge and three of nine mail fraud counts against former Gov. Ray Blanton's campaign manager as testimony ended in their liquor license conspiracy trial.

title: UNSER APPEAL TO BE HEARD BY PANEL ON THURSDAY
description: A board will be set up by the United States Auto Club to hear Bobby Unser's appeal on the results of the Indianapolis 500 race, according to Dick King, head of USAC.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Conrail Dismisses 3 Ticket Sellers
description: Three ticket sellers at Conrail's ticket office in Grand Central Terminal have been dismissed and a fourth has been forced to retire and pay $4,500 in restitution after the discovery of a ticket-selling scheme at the commuter line.

description: The company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: F.A.A. WARNS CONTROLLERS ABOUT THREATENED STRIKE
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration has asked that air traffic controllers be notified that a threatened walkout would be illegal and could lead to dismissals and he has requested that lists of candidates for ''these high-paying controller jobs'' be updated.

title: Dreams Of Dimes And Palms
description: It becomes increasingly obvious that very few Americans can afford to grow old anymore. What with inflation eroding your nest egg, impending crackdown on Social Security and so on, old age has become a luxury for the few.

title: POLICE OFFICER INDICTED IN KILLING OF MAN, 22, IN OFF-DUTY SHOOTING
description: A grand jury in the Bronx indicted a police officer yesterday for criminally negligent homicide in the shooting of a 22-year-old Yonkers man in Van Cortlandt Park last March 28.

title: METS GET EXPO'S VALENTINE; YANKEES DEFEAT INDIANS, 5-2
description: The Mets showed some power at bat in a 6-1 victory last night over the Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium. And they added additional hitting strength when by acquiring Ellis Valentine from the Montreal Expos.

title: Exxon's Annual 'Energy Outlook'
description: American demand for foreign oil will reach a peak in the next 10 years, then drop to less than half of its current level by 2000, an Exxon USA report said.

title: ESPOSITO ASSERTS HE WILL REMAIN IN MAYORAL RACE
description: Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens said yesterday that he would remain in the race for the Republican mayoral nomination and would reject any Republican efforts to persuade him to drop out and pave the way for the G.O.P. nomination of Mayor Koch.

title: THE SUGAR INDUSTRY HAS TAKEN ITS LUMPS
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; Selecting A Credit Card
description: WHAT'S the best credit card deal for the average American? The answer lies in the use made of the card. Each type - the bank card, the retail charge card, oil company card and travel-and-entertainment card - offers a specific use and thus a distinct advantage. But trying to substitute one for the other can be troublesome, if not unproductive.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for 6 mo to April 30
description: Corrected from Thursday's editions

title: Michael Defends Decisions
description: Manager Gene Michael returned here this afternoon, looking weary after an overnight trip to Florida to meet with George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner. In the aftermath of strong criticism by Steinbrenner, Michael found out that he still was the Yankee manager.

title: MISSILE OFFICER IS HELD IN UNAUTHORIZED VISITS TO THE SOVIET EMBASSY
description: The Air Force tonight arrested one of its missile-launching officers at an air base in Kansas and charged him with making three unauthorized visits to the Soviet Union's Embassy here.

title: Big Chance for Those at 'Edge of the Spotlight'
description: Until he won stardom in 1970 in the ''The Rothschilds'' on Broadway, life for Hal Linden was, in his own words, ''one failure after another.''

title: YANKS DEFEAT INDIANS, 5-2
description: The Yankees rallied round their beleaguered manager tonight and beat the Indians, 5-2, in Cleveland Stadium, which was packed with 65,311 spectators. The victory ended a fourgame Yankee losing streak and might have ended for a time the weeklong criticism of the team from its principal owner, George Steinbrenner.

title: Abdicating On Transit
description: We are told there is a transit crisis and the day of judgment is upon us. The oracles who bring this message are telling the truth, but to be fair to history and to the unfortunates who suffer daily in the subway's menacing depths and on other collapsing forms of public transport in the region, the emergency has been with us for some time. The practice of ignoring it has been polished into an honored political tradition here, where one of the prime measurements of an officeholder's success is the length of time he can put off needed but unpopular fare increases.

title: ENTERTAINING OF 2 F.D.A. AIDES SCRUTINIZED
description: A small Maryland company that produces solutions used to clean soft contact lenses spent approximately $9,000 over five years to entertain two Government regulators whose decisions affected the industry as a whole and the company in particular, Congressional investigators testified today.

title: CABLE-TV OPERATORS AT CONVENTION VIEWING 'ADULT' PROGRAMS WITH WARY EYE
description: At a booth for a new ''adult'' cable network conceived by Penthouse magazine, two centerfold ''pets'' autograph glossy pictures of themselves, while a company executive hastens to explain that the service will not be focused simply on sex but will also include discussion and topical programs.

title: MANAGER PATIENT WITH CUBS
description: Just tell Manager Joe Amalfitano the good news. He already knows the bad news - that his Chicago Cubs, who started a weekend series against the Mets here last night, have the worst record in baseball.

title: Nimiitz to Return to Sea And Resume Flights Today
description: The aircraft carrier Nimitz will return to sea tomorrow and resume night landing exercises despite the crash Tuesday night off the Florida coast of a Marine Corps plane that killed 14 servicemen and injured 48 others, Navy officials said today.

title: Morocco Holds Elections
description: Morocco held parliamentary elections today in the southern part of the former Spanish Sahara that it annexed in 1979. Morocco took over the area after Mauritania withdrew under a peace agreement with Algerian-backed guerrillas who have been fighting for the independence of the area since 1976. The inhabitants of the sparsely populated territory were due to elect three deputies to the Moroccan Parliament for the first time since they came under Moroccan rule.

title: MINERS' COUNCIL VOTES TO ACCEPT NEW COAL PACT
description: Leaders of the United Mine Workers today approved a proposed agreement to end a strike by 160,000 coal miners, quickly accepting the terms negotiated with the mine operators early this morning.

title: AT AGE 50, DAVIS BACON IS STILL A SOUND SOURCE OF INDUSTRIAL STABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: The experts say everybody needs a will, men and women alike. ''Married women have traditionally thought they did not need a will,'' said Margaret Tyre, a Rye, N.Y., lawyer who spends nearly a third of her time writing wills. ''Women haven't felt they had assets to disburse, but the equitable distribution divorce law means they do.''

title: Stock Prices Retreat; Dow Is Off by 2.50
description: With energy issues still under pressure, stock prices moved lower yesterday to record their only loss of the week. Also, for the first time this week, the market failed to stage a final-hour rally.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES OFFER CITY TRANSIT FUND ADVICE
description: Senior White House officials have suggested that New York City and New York State consider tapping the city's budget surplus or trading in the Westway for mass-transit funds to strengthen their case for more Federal transit assistance, an aide to President Reagan said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE

description: WEATHER conditions should have stabilized sufficiently in the last week for tender vegetables and annuals to be planted out without danger of stunting from cold exposure. Tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, squash and cucumber planted at this time will often surpass those planted earlier in growth and production. Zinnias and tall marigolds may also be planted out. However, they often do better if the seed is sown directly. Scatter the seeds three inches apart in the row, then thin to a six- to eight-inch spacing after germination.

title: HOW HAIG IS RECASTING HIS IMAGE
description: Leslie H. Gelb is The Times's national security correspondent, based in the Washington bureau. He served as a senior official in the State Department from January 1977 to July 1979. By Leslie H. Gelb The late-afternoon sun barely penetrated the sedate office, with its wood-paneled walls and Colonial-style furniture, as the Secretary of State mused on America's situation in the world. ''I think we've got more going for us,'' he said during the course of a 90-minute interview, ''than we've had historically in the last 30 years.'' The ''beleaguered'' Russian leaders, he added, must understand that ''there are hopes for arms control, hopes for the West to assist them in solving their dilemmas in the economic and agricultural spheres.'' Of course, there would be a price - ''some reining in of what has been a hemorrhaging of risk-taking.''

title:
Dining Out;
SAVORING THE RHINELAND IN RED BANK

Housed in a narrow two-story building opposite the local railrad station, this charming little restaurant has been serving the typical robust fare of Germany for 11 years. Patrons should be forewarned, however, that portions here are either dauntingly large or solidly satisfying, depending upon one's approach to dining.

title: IN THE TIME OF 'ALL THE KING'S MEN'
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, ''All the King's Men'' was published. With any event in your life, you know more after 35 years than after one. True, you may know less in some ways. Time does not necessarily improve memory. But in the course of time, strange odds and ends - or even fundamental facts not recognized in the noonday sun -may, out of blank idleness of a later mind, rise up, trailing God knows what, like a half-rotten log disturbed in a creek bed trailing algae, patched with moss, clung to by some strange, snail-like creatures, with a rusty length of barbed wire still nailed to it. What rises so gratuitously out of the deep of time may be a set of relationships and connections of which you had been unaware when things were fresh. The unconscious thing may, years later, become startlingly conscious, seemingly by accident. That is why it is always hard to say precisely when and how a book - or anything else - ''began.''

title:
COMMENT;
NEW YORK'S JOB LAG
description: T HE limited nature of the city's economic revival is mirrored in the labor markets. Although the unemployment rate in 1980 was basically unchanged in New York City while rising sharply in the rest of the country, joblessness continued to be much higher in the city. The stability of the city's jobless rate was largely the result of a reduction of the size of the city's labor force and not because its job market was substantially stronger than the nation's. Indeed, if the city's labor force had grown in 1980 at the same rate as the nation's, all other things being the same, the city's unemployment rate would have risen to 10.9 percent instread of remaining unchanged at 8.6 percent.

title: Taxes
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Letters - Tax Shelters'' (May 10) a New York attorney named Gerald J. Robinson writes yet another attack against ''abusive tax shelters.'' After praising the Internal Revenue Service for its valiant efforts to ''finger'' these deals, he rhetorically asks why abusive tax shelters continue to thrive, and concludes that the chief cause lies in the fact that investors have little to lose, i.e., that they have a good chance of getting away with exorbitant deductions, and receive only slight penalties if caught.

title:
Art;
DAYS OF WINE AND NUDES
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON MANY galleries in the Hamptons are beginning the summer season with group shows featuring a broad selection of works by regional artists. One of the largest and most diverse is Elaine Benson's ''The Subject Is Wine,'' on view through June 9. Actually, the wine theme is only the jumping-off point for most of the works, which range from luscious studies of grapes by Richard Karwoski and Paul Hodges to Helen Hoie's collages of wine labels and a subtle color abstraction in shades of burgundy red by Sydney Butchkes.

title: Dining Out; A PROVOCATIVE BACKDROP

Just as oceanfront or riverbank imparts a pleasurable excitement of discovery and a promise of adventure, so, too, does the inland equivalent, the airport dining room, offer a piquant and pleasurable aura of activity, of going places.
