description: ''I USED to tell my children that this case would see them through college,'' Marvin J. Sonosky, a Washington Indian lawyer, recalled last week. ''Now maybe it will see my grandchildren through college.''

title: CYPRUS MOVES TOWARD NEW EFFORT AT FEDERAL STATE
description: Cyprus is moving slowly toward another attempt to establish a federal state, and the results of last weekend's Greek Cypriots' parliamentary elections are being interpreted as possibly providing some impetus.

title: WARSAW SLOGAN SAYS IT ALL NOW 'LET POLAND BE POLAND'
description: To many politicians in the West, ''Finlandization'' is a nightmare; it means the threat of encroachment by the Soviet Union upon the nations of Western Europe.

title: ROSSMAN, ONCE A CHAMPION, IS STILL TOILING IN A FLEABAG GYM
description: In the city where he was christened Michael DePiano, Mike Rossman will have his 50th professional fight tomorrow, and if he wins, perhaps another shot at the light-heavyweight title. But the former champion was seeing more than the lions and tigers who shared the dusty, cluttered makeshift gym with him.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: FREDDY'S BOOK, by John Gardner. (Ballantine, $2.95.) Professor Winesap visits old Professor Agaard in his Charles Addams-ish house and during the night hears the story that the professor's giant son has written. That mythical tale is about the conflict between good and evil in a fabulous 16th-century Scandinavian kingdom. An entertaining novel within a novel, and a challenging exercise in literary game playing.

title: GOING ABROAD FOR STOCKS
description: The search for higher returns and portfolio diversification is sending an increasingly large number of investment dollars out of the United States. A study by Richard K. Abrams and Donald V. Kimball, economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, shows that sales and purchases of foreign equities rose to a total of $18 billion in 1980, up from $2 billion 10 years earlier.

title: A 'SYMPHONY' WITH 24 MOVEMENTS...
description: WE are a musical family, but we are not always harmonious. Our teen-age son, Sam, plays the electric guitar, I play the harp and my husband, Fred, plays the remote-control television channel selector.

title: Sara Marshall, H.T. Gibson Jr.  Set Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Patterson Marshall of Bronxville, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sara Puryear Marshall, to Henry Taylor Gibson Jr., son of Mrs. Peter Van Dyke Berg of New Canaan, Conn., and the late Mr. Gibson of Bedford, N.Y. A June 27 wedding is planned.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: ART There are not many painters around who are genuinely amusing, but William N. Copley - an American artist long associated with the Surrealist movement in Paris - is one of them. The mini-retrospective currently devoted to his work at the Brooks Jackson Gallery, 52 East 57th Street (through June 13) gives us a chance to sample some of the work he has been producing since the 1950's, and the result is a show that is often very funny and often very bawdy.

title: LOW TURNOUT EXPECTED IN 21-CANDIDATE PRIMARY
description: TRENTON COME Tuesday, New Jersey's experiment with the public financing of primary elections will be over, with fewer voters than four years ago expected to go to the polls to pick nominees for Governor from among 13 Democrats and eight Republicans.

title: Jet Run Is Jumping In Peak Form at 13
description: Less than four years ago, when Mike Matz first climbed aboard Jet Run, he knew he had a winner. ''You didn't have to know too much about jumping horses to come to that conclusion,'' Matz said last week. ''Jet Run had a great record before I ever saw him. It was just a matter of keeping him going.''

title: A JOURNEY TO PAST AND PRESENT IN BOISE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DWIGHT JENSEN is a writer who lives in Boise, Idaho. By DWIGHT JENSEN

title: Diana M. Carulli, Artist, Bride of Robert Dunlap ,
description: Diana Marina Carulli, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Stella Carulli and the late Mr. Carulli, was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University to Robert Dunlap. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Calhoun and the Rev. Richard M. Spierling.

title: Elderly Drivers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY LUNCHROOMS GO FANCY
description: Once relegated to basements and left-over spaces, employee eating facilities are being given greater prominence in many new office buildings in the city and the suburbs.

title: HIGHER ARSON RATE REFLECTS THE TIMES
description: AN unemployed man burns his gas-guzzling automobile rather than try to keep up with finance payments and buy gasoline he can no longer afford. A store owner, hard-pressed to pay his suppliers, sets fire to his shop. A teen-ager is charged with arson for setting a fire at a garden apartment, whether for a thrill or because someone paid him to do it.

title: NEW JUDGES ASSIGNED
description: JUSTICE professionals are optimistic that a new plan to temporarily transfer upstate judges to Westchester will reduce a dramatically increased backlog of felony indictments by the end of the year.

title: THE WILD PLACES OF KAUAI
description: Hawaii is not all high-rise hotels and beach-front condominiums. My wife, Beatrice, and I found a wilderness of mountains and forests, a canyon and sheer sea cliffs, in the interior and on the northwest coast of Kauai. This region is a haven for nature lovers, hikers, campers and bird-watchers. There is no golf, tennis, surfing or shopping. Trout fishing - as well as hunting of wild goats, wild pigs and pheasants - is permitted. But the principal activity is absorbing the beauty and solitude of a tropical wilderness.

title: Nina Davis Fiancee Of Harry Pollock,
description: Mr. and Mrs. William S. Davis Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Riker Davis, to Harry Winslow Pollock, son of Mr. and Mrs. H.E.D. Pollock of Cambridge, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: 'NO"EL' CAPTURES COWARD'S GLITTER
description: ''NOEL'' has nothing to do with Christmas and everything to do with the late Sir Noel Coward, playwright, actor, composer and lyricist. The source for this production is ''Cowardy Custard,'' a British hit of a few seasons back at London's Mermaid Theater. Ned Sherrin, probably best-known on this side of the Atlantic for his Public Broadcasting Service series ''Song by Song,'' has adapted and directed the version now at the Goodspeed Opera House.

title: Letters; WHAT MUST HUMAN LIFE DO TO PROVE PERSONHOOD?
description: To the Editor:

title: NO LEADERS EMERGE IN JERSEY'S PRIMARY
description: The 21 candidates and their campaign themes, page 30. By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

title: BANNING A TEXTBOOK
description: In March, the Alabama State Board of Education, after meeting with of Education, after meeting with Gov. Fob James, removed from the approved list of school texts several books, including ''Unfinished Journey: A World History,'' which has been used in secondary schools across the country. This decision followed a public hearing of the State Textbook Committee at which a parental group complained that the social-studies text promoted secular-humanist values. Elsewhere in America, parents' groups are insisting that schools purge materials that they consider antifamily, anti-American, and anti-God. The were taped under the authority of the the State Board of Education. Following are excerpts of the text and objections raised by critics, whose comments are taken verbatim from the tapes.TEXT

title: IT'S STILL NO SALE AT THE TRADE CENTER
description: It should all be splendidly simple. After years of disagreements, haggles and disputes, everyone finally seems to agree that the World Trade Center should be sold. Governor Carey and a panel of businessmen he appointed to study the question think so. Officials of the Port Authority, which owns the complex, and their panel think so. Mayor Koch concurs, as does Governor Byrne of New Jersey; even the developer, who last week announced plans for the seventh and last building in the Trade Center complex, says he has no problem with it.

title: OTHER BUSINESS
description: ''June'' still means brides, and a great many brides, before they trip down the aisle, have already made the trek to Brooklyn. There, behind a mundane storefront at 82d Street in the Bay Ridge section, is I. Kleinfeld & Son, which is a kind of a Cinderella compared to its regal competitors on Fifth Avenue or the Upper East Side.

title: FISHING FLEET'S RENAISSANCE
description: STONINGTON CONNECTICUT'S only commercial fishing fleet, which was all but defunct a few years ago, is slowly recovering its vigor at its home port here. Supplementing the small wooden day-boats that have been the fleet's mainstay since World War II, several local fishermen have bought $500,000 steel draggers capable of working the rich Georges Bank area for a week at a time.

title: Music Noted in Brief; 'Fixed Do: Movable Sol' Creates Tonic Center
description: The evenings of music put on by the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Centre Street seem more eager to avoid the public than to court it. Indeed, these regular gatherings of composers and newmusic followers at a third-floor loft in SoHo are informal exchanges of ideas rather than the usual player-audience experience.

title: Hilary Anne Schultheis Wed
description: The marriage of Hilary Anne Schultheis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Schultheis of Manhasset and Shelter Island, L.I., to Lawerence A. Marusi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Marusi of Manhasset, took place yesterday at the Schultheis home on Shelter Island. The Rev. Frank Johnston of Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset performed the ceremony. Dr. Schultheis is a physician.

title: TWO ICONS OF ROCK MUSIC
description: Only a handful of rock musicians have become genuine icons - larger-than-life symbolic figures whose personal triumphs and vicissitudes seem to mirror the ups and downs of rock as a whole, and sometimes of the society that nurtures it. Often, rock icons become the objects of personality cults that tend to overshadow their musical accomplishments. They are the reigning deities of the recording industry; their name on a record is enough to sell it, contents notwithstanding. They can get away with a lot, and frequently they do.

title: CENSUS FINDS MORE BLACKS LIVING IN SUBURBS OF NATION'S LARGE CITIES
description: Blacks have increased in numbers and as a percentage of the total population in the suburbs of most large cities over the last decade, but at the same time whites were moving on to virtually all-white areas of new growth and prosperity, either in the suburban rings or outside the metropolitan areas.

title: The Nation; SOCIAL SECURITY--SEEKING MEANS FOR ENDS TO MEET
description: LIKE all strict constructionists of the nation's pay-as-you-go oldage trust fund and like most public officials who are fond of calling themselves fiscally prudent, members of the Reagan Administration have shuddered at proposals to shore up Social Security with general tax revenues. Until, that is, last week, when in Congressional testimony both Health and Human Services Secretary Richard S. Schweiker and budget director David A. Stockman promised to give the idea another look.

title: DANCE
description: Among those active in the current tap dance revival have been Jane Goldberg and her mentor, Charles ''Cookie'' Cook. This week, they take to the boards with something of a musical of their own called ''Old, New, Borrowed and Bluesy.''

title: 6-DAY EARLY MUSIC FESTIVAL IN BOSTON
description: There has always been a sense of community about early-music performers, but that community has been made palpable this week at the first Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition. The events, which began Tuesday and continue through Sunday, have brought thousands of instrument makers, musicians, critics and early-music lovers together in one smoothly organized, inventively planned arena.

title: Frank C. Dougherty
description: PEACEKEEPERS IN LEBANON: Irish members of a United Nations battalion in southern Lebanon survey the fields below from a hilltop emplacement. Their outpost is a short distance from Haddata, a Christian enclave. Yesterday, Libya said that four of its soldiers died last week in Israeli raids while acting as ''volunteers'' in Lebanon.

title: CITY DEFENDS SUPERVISION OF COURT LOCKUP DESPITE SUIT
description: Although a jury has awarded a man $350,000 in a suit against the city for a sexual assault that he suffered in a lockup at Manhattan Criminal Court, city officials say they have not changed the way people awaiting arraignment are supervised.

title: PATIENTS WAIT, BUT IS KNOWLEDGE RIPE FOR HUMAN GENE THERAPY
description: The 21-year-old woman has ''gargoyle'' features, short stature and multiple bone deformities that have led to several fractures. In addition, she has hormone deficiencies and chronic heart failure. Her life expectancy today is only about two more years and she is too intelligent to have many illusions about the future.

title: CBS WINS APPEAL ON TRANSCRIPTS OF TV PROGRAM SOUGHT IN A TRIAL
description: A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia has ruled that the defendants in a multimillion-dollar fraud trial may not have the full transcripts and tapes of interviews used in preparing a CBS ''60 Minutes'' television broadcast about fast-food franchises.

title:
Gardening;
IT'S TIME FOR SPRAYING AND FERTILIZING
description: WEATHER conditions should have stabilized sufficiently in the last week for tender vegetables and annuals to be planted out without danger of stunting from cold exposure. Tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, squash and cucumber planted at this time will often surpass those planted earlier in growth and production. Zinnias and tall marigolds may also be planted out. However, they often do better if the seed is sown directly. Scatter the seeds three inches apart in the row, then thin to a six- to eight-inch spacing after germination.

title: WEICKER MINIMIZES G.O.P. VISIT
description: SENATOR Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who is up for re-election next year and who has talked at various times about running for Governor, running again for the Senate, running as an independent and running again as a Republican, seemed to be doing some fence-mending last week with Connecticut Republicans.

title: GOVERNING THE CAPITAL
description: Blacks did not ride in the backs of buses in Washington 25 years ago, or ever. Local transportation was never segregated.

title: 200 DISPLAYS AT FLEA MARKET trunk, Queen Anne Spanish-foot chair
description: RIDGEFIELD THIS season, more good-looking turn-of-the-19th-century candlestands and small tables and more early New England side chairs seem to be coming out of storage to be offered on the open market than have been available at the same time for several years past. As a result, buyers have a wider selection from which to choose and prices are bound to be more competitive.

title: Dining Out; CONTINENTAL FARE IN VICTORIAN STYLE
description: AFTER a hiatus of several years, the cozy Victorian dining rooms of the Maidstone Arms in East Hampton are welcoming guests for dinner. Last season the owners experimented with serving simple cold suppers. In the fall they engaged a regular chef, Morris Weintraub, who devised an a la carte menu that is best described as Continental.

title: TALE OF ATLANTIC CITY HOTEL THAT TRIED TO BE A CASINO
description: The landmark Ritz Hotel is open for business on the Boardwalk, but without a casino and without the remodeling and expansion that had been planned for it.

title: Sunday Observer But Will It Sell?
description: I am writing a best seller. At first it was about dieting. ''If you want to sell best of all, write a diet book,'' everybody said. I titled it, ''The Smoke Your Way Down to a Skeleton Diet Book.''

title: Vivian Barnett Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Samuel Barnett of Irvington, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Vivian Barnett, to Jacob Toporek, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Toporek of Union, N.J. An August wedding is planned. Miss Barnett, daughter also of the late Mr. Barnett, is a teacher in Irvington. Her fiance is appointments counsel to Governor Byrne.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Sly Sarah In her 1976 screenplay for ''The Incredible Sarah,'' which starred Glenda Jackson as Sarah Bernhardt, Ruth Wolff wasn't able to include ''absolutely wonderful material'' about the American tours that the French actress made between 1880 and 1918. And so she wrote ''Sarah in America.'' The virtually one-character play ran last February at the Kennedy Center in Washington, starring Lilli Palmer. Now, it can be seen on Channel 13 on Wednesday at 9 P.M., again with Miss Palmer.

title: Gabriel Captures 2 Finals
description: Nigel Gabriel had a busy and productive afternoon at the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championships yesterday. On a hot, humid day, Gabriel, a senior at Boys and Girls High School, raced seven times in the preliminaries and finals of the 100- and 400-meter dashes and the 400-meter relay. Not once did anyone beat him to the finish line.

title: Theater; 'NOEL' CAPTURES COWARD
description: ''NOEL'' has nothing to do with Christmas and everything to do with the late Sir Noel Coward, playwright, actor, composer and lyricist. The source for this production is ''Cowardy Custard,'' a British hit of a few seasons back at London's Mermaid Theater. Ned Sherrin, probably best-known on this side of the Atlantic for his Public Broadcasting Service series, ''Song by Song,'' has adapted and directed the version now at the Goodspeed Opera House.

title: Design; A SOLID STATEMENT WITH STONE
description: For designers who revamp high-rise city apartments, one mandate has become increasingly common: to create distinctive and luxurious dwellings out of spaces that have little beyond their location and availability to justify their astronomical prices.

title: Music; A PROGRESS REPORT ON 3 CULTURAL TESTS
description: ALL too often, today's top story becomes tomorrow's forgotten news. For that reason, I'm delighted to be able to update information about three experiments in Westchester culture that have been reported earlier in this column. Since they are still developing, it may be too soon to speak of happy endings; but happy growings, absolutely.

title: Kilmer Sees a Future In Summer Football
description: The American Football Association is often described as the Bill Kilmer League, which cannot be entirely fair because the A.F.A. has been around since 1977. But this is its first season with Kilmer, the former professional quarterback, as its commissioner and with its first two franchises in majorleague cities, Chicago and Dallas.

title: AT 16, SHE LOOKS BEYOND THE CAMERA
description: SHE'S 16 years old. She likes roller skating and junk food. She hates homework and ''people who are stuffy and phony.'' From that account Lisanne Falk, who will graduate from Long Beach High School three weeks from today, seems to be a typical teen-ager. From all appearances, she is an atypical achiever - at the top of her class (an advanced ''A'' student who is getting out of high school a year early) and at the top of her career (a high-powered model who earns $1,500 ''for a full day's work'' and $150 by the hour).

title: Connecticut Journal
description: CONNECTICUT'S House of Representatives usually is a noisy place, with dozens of conversations going on at the same time. But it quieted down quickly when Representative Robert C. Sorensen, Democrat of Meriden, rose to support a measure to allow the use of marijuana in selected medical cases. And legislators turned silent when Mr. Sorensen revealed that he had cancer and is undergoing chemotherapy.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Worst Team in Baseball
description: THE worst team in baseball is in New York and it isn't the Mets or Yankees or even an expansion team like Seattle or Toronto. It is the Chicago Cubs, who have been working down toward this distinction for 105 years. When they arrived in Chez Shea Friday they had 9 victories and 31 defeats for a winning percentage of .225.

title: Westchester Housing; HOW TO ASSESS YOUR ASSESSMENTS
description: IF you wonder whether your property tax is higher than your neighbor's, the next two weeks is the time to find out. The new assessments will be announced tomorrow in all Westchester towns - which include the villages -and in Mount Vernon, New Rochelle and Rye.

title: Officer Shoots Man in Robbery
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer shot a man during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: M.F. Hurworth Weds Joan Fry
description: The Unitarian Church of All Souls was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Joan Francis Fry, daughter of Mrs. Joseph L. Noble of Rochester, to Michael Frederick Hurworth, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Ernest Hurworth of Nottingham, England.

title: Yonkers Boycott Put Off
description: A threatened boycott of races at Yonkers Raceway was delayed for at least a week today by the harness horsemen. Del Insko, president of the Standardbred Owners Association of New York, was granted the extra time in order to permit the State Legislature to consider an amendment to a bill involving increased purses for both Roosevelt and Yonkers.

title: Golf Title to Commans
description: Ron Commans of Southern California took advantage of Jay Don Blake's troubles on the final nine holes today and won the National Collegiate golf championship. Commans shot a final 69 to beat Blake of Utah State and Ed Luethke of Fresno State by a shot with a four-round total of 283. Brigham Young took the team title.

title: HOW A COW PASTURE BECOMES A DREAM
description: MAPLE, Ontario Q UESTION: How do you get 2.7 million people to pay $32.5 million to visat Elmer McKinnon's old cow pasture on the outskirts of Toronto? Answer: You spend a decade planning, and two years building, a $122 million amusement park, complete with its own mountain, four roller coasters and a cast of familiar cartoon characters.

title: Tax-Cut Negotiators Get Heat Treatment
description: All income taxes are not created equal. Neither are all tax cuts. With three-way bargaining on how unequal this year's cuts should be still bogged down last week, the Administration decided to remind Congressional Democrats that some tax-cut writers are more equal than others.

title: SOVIET FOLLOWS MIDEAST POLICY RICH IN RISKS AND REWARDS
description: MOSCOW IT took Moscow more than two weeks after Syria moved antiaircraft missiles into Lebanon to tell the Soviet public that a ''dangerous and complicated'' situation was developing in the Middle East. And it wasn't until last week, before a visiting King Hussein of Jordan, that the Soviet Union pledged to ''firmly support'' the Syrians. It may have been just another case of sluggish bureaucratic reflexes, but more likely, the slow responses suggested caution in handling an issue rich in potential advantages and risks for the Kremlin.

title: 'BILLY BALL' IN WEST HAVEN
description: WEST HAVEN NOT many people envied David Goldstein when he became the owner of a minor league baseball franchise here last year. For one thing, the New York Yankees had just moved their Double-A franchise, the West Haven Yankees, to Nashville, even though the team had drawn 71,000 spectators in 1979 while winning the Eastern League pennant for the third time in four years. For another, the team Mr. Goldstein bought, the West Haven Whitecaps, a farm club of the Oakland A's, had finished last in the league the previous two seasons while playing in Waterbury.

title: COMPETITION PROMPTS ELDERLY TO STRIVE
description: BRIDGEPORT WHAT makes Sammy run? Sam Jaffe, 65 years old, says too many retired men just sit around all day. So he and a lot of other older men - and some older women, too - used to run nearly every day for fun, health and just to feel and look a lot better.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Testing the Police
description: Asserting that police work ''is always changing, like law or medicine,'' Chief David Couper in Madison, Wis., proposed a year ago to run the first police department in the country with mandatory performance standards. By

title: The Nation In Summary; Lefever, the Man; They Love to Bait
description: Ernest W. Lefever, a State Department nominee with an undiplomatic bent for verbal combat, is due for a rematch on Capitol Hill this week. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, whose members have apparently already decided that he is unfit to serve as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, wants him back for more questioning.

title: SUNDAY, MAY 31, 1981
description: International The President of Bangladesh was killed and a state of emergency was declared by Vice President Abdus Sattar, who assumed the duties of Acting President. Dacca radio said that a little-known group was responsible for the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, who was visiting Chittagong, an area in which foes of his Government have been active. Rebels announced over the radio from Chittagong that they were taking over the Government, but officials in Dacca said that they were still in control. (Page 1, Col.6.)

title: INTREPID FILMMAKERS RE-CREATE AN ARCTIC TRAGEDY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Cowie is a London-based critic with a special interest in Scandinavian films. By PETER COWIE KALIX, Sweden

title: A TAX ON EARNED INCOME?  IT IT ALREADY ON THE BOOKS
description: THOSE legislators who recently predicted that Connecticut would someday have an income tax remind one of the psychic who predicted the attempt on the President's life shortly after it occurred. The tax is here, now.

title: BAILEY
description: Ralph E. Bailey, chairman of Conoco, the nation's ninth largest oil company, suffered a bit of an embarassment last week.

title: Headliners; Gold in Those Hills
description: Even as legal fees go, the $10.6 million awarded last week to Arthur Lazarus Jr. and two colleagues in a Sioux Indian land claim case seems high - until one considers they might have made more working for the Cleveland Indians. They took over an almost moribund case in 1956, pursued it for almost 25 years and finally won a settlement of $106 million, compensation for the Government's seizure of South Dakota's Black Hills in 1877.

title: HOUSE WITH BOOKCASE
description: The current report from Leisureading, Inc., sole purveyors of books for all summer rental houses and cottages in the Northeast: 1947 edition of Reader's Digest Condensed Books still top of the line ... ''Lust for Life'' (coverless model) in second, an ear ahead of ''The Murder of Roger Ackroyd'' ... Only newcomer to Top Five, up from 14, ''The Summer of '42'' ... ''My Life and Loves,'' still in fifth. Rounding out the Big Fifteen: ''War and Peace'' (Garnett trans., special paperback model, missing pp. 117-166), Fodor's Guide to England (1968), ''Orlando,'' ''The Agony and the Ecstasy'' (No. 4 last year), ''All the President's Men,'' ''Beloved Infidel,'' ''A Thurber Carnival,'' ''The Prisoner of Love'' (pressed wild phlox included), ''The Right Stuff'' (first year on the list, paper edition, available in pre-waterlogged model, choice of fresh or salt), ''The Bull from the Sea.''

title: YOUNG COMPOSERS START ON A HIGH NOTE
description: AVRAHAM STERNKLAR and Herbert Feldman are 50 and 49 years old, respectively. Jennifer Bilfield and Bruce Edelstein are 16 and 15. What the four have in common is music: the Long Island Composers Alliance, in particular, and today at 2 P.M., when the two teenagers hear their compositions performed at Coe Hall in Oyster Bay by other talented young musicians, it will be because Mr. Sternklar, Mr. Feldman and their fellow members ov the alliance think it's important to encourage young people to get involved in both the performing and writing of contemporary music.

title:
About Westchester;
Lynne Ames
description: MOUNTAINOUS biceps, segmented abdominal muscles, backs and legs rippling with snake-like veins and bulges - the body built look takes some getting used to, even on a man. On a woman, especially a woman devoid of fat and clad in the skimpiest of bathing suits, it can be downright startling.

title:
Camera;
PUTTING THE MOON INTO YOUR NIGHTTIME SCENICS
ENVIRONMENT POLICY STILL BEING PLANNED
description: With the sale of oil and gas leases on 81 tracts off the coast of central California, the Reagan Administraton has completed its first major environmental action since taking office last January.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CALIFORNIA WINE COUNTRY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the New York Times bureau in Los Angeles. By ROBERT LINDSEY

title: BRIDGEPORT U.S. STOP IN INTERNATIONAL RACE
description: AFTER next month, about 200 aviators from 15 countries may forever remember Bridgeport as ''the city that is halfway to Paris.'' Those adventurous men and women in their abbreviated flying machines will make the run from Paris to Bridgeport and back as participants in Air Transat, the first trans-Atlantic air race ever, according to its sponsors.

title: CAN A RELIGIOUS SOAP OPERA FIND AN AUDIENCE?
description: Beginning tomorrow, ''Another Life'' a 30-minute, five-day-a-week soap opera will make its debut on 63 stations around the country, including WPIX/Channel 11 in New York, where it will be shown at 12:30 P.M.

title: Solo Stars Attempt 2-Person Ocean Sail
description: To race a sailboat 3,000 miles across an ocean requires a combination of skill, perseverance and money. To win, one needs all this and luck.

title: MEXICAN COKE RAP
description: THE ULTIMATE GOOD LUCK By Richard Ford. 201 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $9.95.

title: Crafts
description: CRAFT courses in New Jersey this summer are scheduled everywhere from the shore and the countryside to the city and suburbs. Following is a sampling of some schools and centers where these courses are available:

title: PRIVATE COLLEGES TRYING TO COUNTER LOSS OF RESOURCES
description: HIGHER education in Connecticut remains a growth industry, but like corporate executives concerned over an unstable market, educators are looking to the future with a sense of uncertainty and a belief that adjustments must be made.

title: FRINGE BENEFITS ON THE TAX BLOCK
description: W ITH inflation pushing more people into higher tax brackets, the Government is finding that a larger number of taxpayers are being attracted to fringe benefits that are beyond the reach of the Internal Revenue Service. Although the law considers all noncash benefits to be taxable income unless they are specifically exempted by the tax code, historically such perquisites as bargain air fares for airline employees and free tuition for children of university professors have not been taxed.

title: Lydia Buckley Wed To George Whipple
description: Lydia Alice Buckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Buckley of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday in Aspen, Colo., to George Stephenson Whipple, son of Mr. and Mrs. Taggart Whipple of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Robert James Babb, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Aspen, performed the ceremony at the Prince of Peace Chapel.

title: Troops and Police Quell Disorder in Londonderry
description: Demonstrators threw rocks and gasoline bombs in Londonderry today, and Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary announced that he had banned scheduled marches by Roman Catholics and Protestants.

title: Swiss Takes Cycling Stage
description: Daniel Gisiger, a Swiss cyclist, won the 15th stage of the Tour of Italy race today, edging Giancarlo Casiraghi of Italy in a two-man final sprint.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: THE TRAUMATIC EFFECTS OF DIVORCE ON GRANDPARENTS
description: GRANDPARENTS experience trauma when they first hear about the divorce of their adult child. The shock is intensified when the adult child does not have custody of the children and when the divorce involves the only set of grandchildren. The impact is also greater when the divorced children live nearby. So says a group of 15 grandparents of divorced families that met recently for 12 sessions at the Scarsdale Family Counseling Service.

title: THEATER: NEW CAST FOR 'THAT STORY' AT THE FOLGER
description: When Amlin Gray's ''How I Got That Story'' was produced in New York last December by the Second Stage, the play was, perhaps, somewhat overshadowed by its marathon star turn. ''Story'' is about a naive reporter who travels to cover a war in mythical Amboland (read Vietnam), and Bob Gunton, cast as the Historical Event, enacted all 21 characters the reporter meets on his assignment. By effortlessly assuming identities ranging from American pilots to Asian women, Mr. Gunton scored a dazzling personal triumph. Last week, he received the Clarence Derwent Award for his performance.

title: JOHN deC. BLONDEL
description: John deC. Blondel, president of Blondel & Sons Fuel Oil in Montclair, N.J., died Friday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 72 years old and a life-long resident of Montclair.

title: Future Events Galas Inside and Out
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Celebrity Gala June 3 - Take a performance of the hit musical ''One Mo' Time,'' at the Village Gate. Throw in extra entertainers (Roberta Flack, Ruby Dee and more), plus a few literary figures (Norman Mailer and Toni Morrison). Top it off with a raffle-auction (Robert DeNiro, for example, will put his boxing gloves from the film ''Raging Bull'' on the block), along with a couple of jazz bands, an open bar and buffet supper and you have a gala benefit for the ''Books Behind Bars '' P.E.N. program that schedules lectures and writing workshops for inmates and distributes carefully selected donated books to prison libraries. Tickets, $75 from 924-6780.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: BASIN AND RANGE, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $10.95.) A master journalist studies the geology of the North American continent in the company of scientists.

title: Richard Bourgeois Weds Pauline Dora
description: Pauline Perigord Dora and Richard Pierre Bourgeois were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. The Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Zimbabwe Mine Seizure Doubted
description: Zimbabwe's year-old Socialist Government will not nationalize the nation's mines, Mining Minister Maurice Nyamgumbo was quoted as saying today in The Herald, a Salisbury daily. ''Nationalization for the sake of it is a form of racism, and we don't want it,'' he said. The Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions had urged the Government to seize the mines, most of which are owned by British, American and South African companies.

title: The Nation In Summary; CONSERVATIVES' SOCIAL AGENDA IS REFUSING TO REMAIN HIDDEN
description: The cover of the current issue of Conservative Digest, a political journal of the right, depicts the Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., standing under a huge wave labeled ''social issues.'' The headline reads: ''Howard Baker Bucks the Tide.''

title: A Grandmother Asks Who Has Abandoned Whom
description: A recent article asked the question, ''Where have all the grandparents gone?'' Let me answer for millions: we haven't ''gone'' at all. We are here in Bronxville, Mount Vernon, Pelham, New Rochelle, Scarsdale, and points east, west, north and south, ad infinitum.

title: 9 DEAD, 12 SAVED
description: Twelve survivors of a mysterious marine accident in the Pacific Ocean have been rescued after they saw nine shipmates die while the boat drifted helplessly for two months, the Coast Guard here reported today.

title: NEW PROD FOR READING TEACHERS
description: FIVE years ago, in his book ''Why Johnny Can't Read,'' Rudolf Flesch expressed concern about the nationwide decline in children's reading ability and criticized the way reading was taught in the United States. Instead of having children memorize individual words, Dr. Flesch wrote, the phonics method should be used, teaching the sound of each letter.

title: MR. MOORE'S NEW GAUGE OF JOBS
description: In spite of unpredictable economic performance thus far this year, the unemployment rate has remained relatively steady at around 7.5 percent, far above acceptable levels but below what some economists had feared might occur. According to a new index, which is designed to anticipate changes in employment, conditions may even be a bit better than they already appear.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: This FICTION Last Weeks Week Week On List 1 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, 1 4 $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random 2 8 House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 3 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald.36 (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 4 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. 4 6 (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 5 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random 11 32 House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 6 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, 9 9 $15.95.) A journey through that greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all. 7 TAR BABY, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $11.95.) 6 7 A black fable of race and eroticism set on a Caribbean island. 8 REFLEX, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $11.95.) 5 8 A British jockey copes with blackmail and discovers his own missing past. 9 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams.

title: 76ers' President Leaving
description: Lou Scheinfeld, president of the Philadelphia 76ers, will be leaving the team by Monday, the team owner, F. Eugene Dixon Jr., has announced. Scheinfeld came to the 76ers in January 1980.

title: Marcie Tennen, Crystal Buyer, Married to Seth D. Petok
description: Marcie Ellen Tennen, daughter of Harvey F. Tennen, a retired Municipal Court judge of Huntington Woods, Mich., and Mrs. Tennen of Franklin, Mich., was married in New York last night to Seth David Petok, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Petok of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: RIGHT next door to its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant, the Consolidated Edison Company is conducting experiments in heating water with solar energy. ''We're quite aware of the fact that we have to be knowledgeable about alternate sources of energy,'' said Martin Gitten, a Con Ed spokesman. ''We have to put solar energy in real-use situations so we can gain a real knowledge of how much costs will be, how much backup and maintenance is needed.''

title: Behind the Best Sellers; FRANK HERBERT
description: If inside of every journalist at least one book is struggling to get out, Frank Herbert has far exceeded his allotment. The bestselling ''God Emperor of Dune,'' the fourth novel in Mr. Herbert's Dune series, is his 24th book in the past 25 years, and he wrote many of his books while holding down full-time jobs on seven newspapers from Glendale, Calif. to Seattle.

title: CHINESE VISITOR LEARNS OF LAWS AND U.S. WAYS
description: A most unsettling thing happened one night while Shen Shiao-ming was studying at her carrel at the law library of Southern Methodist University.

title: MARTIN IS SUSPENDED FOR BUMPING UMPIRE
description: Billy Martin, whose conduct this season as manager of the firstplace Oakland A's has been uncharacteristically demure, reverted to form Friday night in Toronto. After a run-in with the umpire Terry Cooney, Martin was ejected, and yesterday he was suspended indefintely and fined an unspecified amount by Lee MacPhail, president of the American League.

title: Pamela Sheard And a Lawyer Wed in Darien
description: The marriage of Pamela Carol Sheard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Sheard of Darien, Conn., to William G. McGuinness 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. McGuinness Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., took place at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Walter H. Taylor.

title: LITERATURE AND LUCRE
description: IN America - perhaps precisely because among us commerce is officially more honored than art - our eminent writers have not typically spoken with equal candor on the subject of literature and lucre. Certainly, the great novelists of the mid 19th century, celebrated in F.O. Matthiessen's ''The American Renaissance'' and D.H. Lawrence's ''Studies in Classic American Literature,'' have chosen self-pity over irony or frankness in talking about their relationship to the marketplace. The classic statement is Melville's, ''Dollars damn me ... all my books are botches. ...'' And implicit in this melancholy cry from the heart is a belief, as strong and pertinacious as any myth by which we live, that the authentic writer is neither drawn to nor confirmed in his vocation by the hope of marketplace success, the dream of becoming rich and famous; but can only be seduced by lucre, led to betray or prostitute his talent.

title: Film View; WHEN DIE-HARD FANS GET CARRIED AWAY
description: The man wore long sideburns and sunglasses with Elvis's name sculptured into the frames. The woman with him had on a denim shirt displaying a full-color Elvis portrait, obviously homemade. They carried a cassette player with a tape of Elvis's hits, and while they waited she showed him copies of a mimeographed newsletter for Elvis's fans. They were in line to see ''This Is Elvis,'' a film combining interviews, concert footage, home movies and patently phony scenes in which Elvis Presley is impersonated by actors who barely look like him.

title: CONDOMINIUM CONVERSIONS TIED TO STRESS IN ELDERLY
description: Elderly residents of rental apartments suffer serious emotional and physical disturbances when they are advised, often with little warning, that their buildings are being converted into condominiums, a study by the University of Miami has concluded.

title: Art View; AT LAST, A MAJOR PISSARRO EXHIBITION; BOSTON
description: Of all the great painters who banded together under the banner of Impressionism, Camille Pissarro (1830-1903) has proved to be the most elusive. Even today, when Impressionism is universally beloved by public and connoisseurs alike, Pissarro alone remains something of a conundrum - an artist easy enough to admire in isolated examples, but very difficult to keep clearly in focus as a whole. Despite his unquestioned historical position, he has never really emerged as a very distinct - much less a glamorous or popular - figure.

title:
Architecture View;
A STYLE CRYSTALLIZED IN THE NEW FOGG DESIGN
description: The creative processes in architecture have less to do with the muses of inspiration than with the painstaking resolution of site, program, structure and plan. That procedure can be understood fairly easily; what is less clear are the esthetic and cultural impulses that account for those very personal decisions that give the solution its specific shape and style.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
WHY ARE REAL-ESTATE ADS SO BLEH?
description: SOMEWHERE ALONG MADISON AVE. ONE of the many questions in the housing industry that perplexes me is this: Why is real-estate advertising so boring? The issue is so controversial that not one professional involved in the field has ever agreed to discuss it for attribution.

title: City Hall Notes
description: OR COULD BE GOOD By CLYDE HABERMAN City Hall Notes

title:
Numismatics;
NEW U.S. TREASURER WILL BE MORE ACTIVE
description: From a numismatic standpoint the United States treasurer ranks among the nation's most important public officials since his or her signature appears on our paper money. But, in a practical sense, the post has had relatively little clout in recent years. In fact, at times it has seemed largely ceremonial in nature.

title: Where Are the Pickets Of Yesteryear
description: Organized labor - 20 million strong, possessed of billions of dollars, celebrating what the A.F.L.-C.I.O. calls the 100th anniversary of the union movement - has become an oddly quiescent giant in a wildly changing world.

title: France Moves to Insure Limitations on Wiretaps
description: The French Government announced today that it was taking steps to insure that official wiretaps would be used only in cases involving national security or in certain cases involving professional criminals.

title: EQUITY FOR PALESTINIANS
description: The West Bank of the Jordan River, together with the Gaza Strip, has been under military occupation by Israel since 1967. United Nations Resolution 242, accepted by Israel, calls for the West Bank and Gaza to be relinquished by Israel when peace and security are realized for the nations of the area.

title: Digging Into History
description: Where were all the urban archeologists between 1970 and 1975 when the historical Delaware riverfront, at the foot of Philadelphia's Society Hill, was being bulldozed away to make room for Interstate 95 (''Digging Up Our Urban Past,'' by Claudia Lorber, April 12)?

title: Westchester Guide; FAMILY-STYLE COLUMBUSES
description: The Westchester Sports Car Club, founded in 1949 and claiming to be the second oldest in the country (Sports Car Club of America is the first), will be the host to a family-style road rally starting at 7:30 P.M. Saturday from the Elmsford Bowling Lanes, in Elmsford.

title: LABORS OF LOVE ON BEHALF OF VICTOR HERBERT'S OPERETTAS
description: For Victor Herbert fans, it is that time of year again - the Bel Canto opera's annual June revival of a Herbert operetta. This year's offering is ''Princess Pat,'' which receives four performances at the Senator Wagner Junior High School auditorium this weekend, the latest in a series of fascinating Herbert resuscitations that began in 1976 with ''Babette'' and has continued with ''Sweethearts'' in 1977, ''The Red Mill'' in 1978 and 1979, and last year's ''The Debutante.''

title: CATHY REYNOLD'S 213 LEADING BY 2 IN GOLF
description: Cathy Reynolds has not won a tournament in her three years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, and until today she never held the lead by herself at the conclusion of a round.

title: RADIOACTIVITY CLEANUP TO START
description: MIDDLESEX FOR the occupants of six homes in this Middlesex County community, June will not bring lawn-mowing, barbecues or gardening. Instead, their properties will be surrounded by eight-foot-high plywood fences, trees and other vegetation will be stripped away by workmen wearing protective coveralls and radiation badges and the soil in their yards will be dug up and hauled away.

title:
Antiques;
THE LURE OF MATAWAN'S MAIN ST.
description: MATAWAN THIS old Monmouth County town lies between Lake Lefferts and Lake Matawan, which provide not only pretty vistas but also boating areas. Although Matawan is surrounded by a network of highways, it maintains its old-fashioned flavor because of, among other things, its century-old (and more) houses. One of these houses - it is at 277 Main Street - started life as a farmhouse. It then became a plumber's shop, and then a butcher store, but for the last 30 years it has been the antiques shop that its owner, Elizabeth Welstead, calls Through the Years.

title: William Malcolm Sutherland Marries Kathryn J. Loomis
description: Kathryn Joan Loomis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Loomis of Toledo, Ohio, was married yesterday in Gambier, Ohio, to William Malcolm Sutherland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wallace Sutherland Jr. of Mount Lebanon, Pa. The Rev. David C. Waltz, a Presbyterian minister of South Williamsport, Pa., performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit, a nondenominational chapel on the campus of Kenyon College.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Capezio Has Leotards And Dance Footwear
description: Capezio Dance-Theater Shops, to use the official name, represent a family known for dance footwear since 1887, and the retail outlets also carry men's, women's and children's dance supplies and theatrical makeup. Capezio recently reopened in White Plains with a champagne reception in a more spacious location at 420 Mamaroneck Avenue. Capezio, which also has a store in Stamford, displays the latest in leotard styles and colors and the most up-to-date character and jazz shoe fashions.

title: Letters; SHORTCHANGED BY THE SWING OF THE PENDULUM
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 CUBAN EXILES ACQUITTED AT RETRIAL OF LETELIER MURDER
description: Two anti-Castro Cuban exiles whose murder convictions were overturned last year were acquitted today in their retrial on charges of assassinating former Ambassador Orlando Letelier of Chile on a Washington street in 1976.

title: THE WOMEN OF ULSTER ARE SURVIVING--TO MOURN
description: At the funeral of Robert Sands, the first of four Irish Republican Army hunger strikers to die this month, his parish priest described what an ordeal the 66-day fast had been for the family, especially for Rosaleen Sands, Mr. Sands' mother. The Rev. Liam Mullan said he had advised Mrs. Sands to stay away from the prison hospital where her son was dying, to spare herself, but that she insisted on visiting him every day. ''The Blessed Virgin Mary stayed with her son until the end, 'and I want to do that too,' '' Father Mullan quoted Mrs. Sands as explaining.

title: OSPREYS RESPONDING TO STATE'S EFFORTS
description: LACEY TOWNSHIP THE osprey, a handsome and graceful fish hawk, has responded favorably to a state program to restore endangered species, and next year probably will be removed from the endangered list.

title: By Sports of The Times; Satchel Paige Finally Looks Back
description: SATCHEL PAIGE was on location in Hattiesburg, Miss., for a few days last year when the TV movie of his life was being filmed. He has a cameo role at the beginning and again at the end of ''Don't Look Back,'' which will be shown tonight on the ABC network. The title was derived from one of his memorable commandments of life.

title: K.C. Harris Weds Lesley Gorog
description: Lesley Anne Gorog, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Gorog of McLean, Va., and Dayton, Ohio, was married in Dayton yesterday to Kenneth Carl Harris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl August Harris of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Joseph Goetz performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Angels.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; Is Safety a Price Of Better Mileage?
description: Whether the milk pitcher hits the rock or the rock hits the pitcher, it's generally bad for the pitcher. So it seems with highway accidents and small automobiles. Recent statistics indicate that though compacts and subcompacts account for 38 percent of cars on the road, they were involved in 55 percent of all fatal crashes.

title: TOWN FIGHTS PLAN FOR TOXIC WASTE TREATMENT PLANT
description: The 3,500 residents of this rural town north of Syracuse are opposed to becoming ''New York's chemical dump,'' which is how they view the state's proposal to build a treatment plant for hazardous waste at a 2,800-acre site on Lake Ontario.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Eleanor Earle Is Wed to Mark Mascheroni
description: Eleanor Forbes Earle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Earle 2d of Haverford, Pa., and Narragansett, R.I., was married yesterday to Mark Mascheroni, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mascheroni of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. James Carpenter performed the Episcopal cermony at the Earle home in Narragansett.

title: INDUSTRY'S WOES HURTING MIDWEST'S QUALITY OF LIFE
description: Youngstown's Little League will begin its season a month late this year. Detroit's symphony orchestra will not make it to Carnegie Hall next season. The Toledo Zoo Museum has closed its doors. The money isn't there anymore.

title: Recalling Von Cramm
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to clarify a point mentioned in an article about homosexuality in the sports world (The New York Times, May 12).

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; Columbia to Go Coed Regardless
description: ''Columbia College will become a coeducational institution,'' Michael I. Sovern, Columbia University's president, said last week. ''The only issue is whether this will be accomplished unilaterally or in collaboration with Barnard.

title: TAIWAN KIN INVITED TO SOONG SERVICES
description: China today offered Taiwan's official airline permission to land special flights in Peking and Shanghai next week so that Taiwan-based relatives and friends of Soong Ching-ling could attend her funeral and burial services. Taiwan is expected to ignore the offer.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED BY HEALTH DEPT. OVER CODE VIOLATIONS
description: In its weekly report, the New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of 25 food establishments found to been in violation of the health codes.

title: Mrs. Waitz Captures Third Minimarathon
description: Grete Waitz won her third consecutive L'eggs minimarathon in Central Park yesterday and remained undefeated in six races here - three New York City Marathons and three at 10,000 meters.

title: Faith Taylor Has Wedding
description: Faith Hutchinson Taylor and Theodore Loomis Sullivan were married yesterday in St. Bede's Chapel in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Farmakis of the Northampton (Mass.)

title: WHY WE LOSE OUR BEST BRAINS TO OTHER STATES
description: ABOUT $1.3 billion leaves New Jersey each year because the state does not provide sufficient opportunities and resources for higher education, according to Laurence H. Falk, a state research economist.

title: BALANCHINE AND COMPANY SALUTE TCHAIKOVSKY
description: Observe George Balanchine in communion with a dancer. It is mystical, which Balanchine denies. It is reverential, which he does not necessarily deny, although it is highly unlikely he will acknowledge it, either. Instead, he will deplore the mysticism, ignore the reverence, and compare a choreographer to, say, a plumber. ''Everyone says art is great,'' Balanchine declares. ''They talk about soul. So, what is soul? Show me what soul is. Art is what you make with your hands.''

title: LUXURY RAIL SERVICE TO CASINOS PLANNED
description: ATLANTIC CITY APLAN to increase commuter train service between this resort city and Philadelphia and provide luxury parlor cars for casino customers may get a three-year trial run.

title: HELEN CAROL GREENE
description: Helen Carol Greene, assistant director of public relations for Cartier, died of hepatitis Thursday at New York University Medical Center.

title: Controversy Over Referee Cancels Tate-Ballard Bout
description: The promoter of the scheduled 10-round heavyweight fight between John Tate, the former World Boxing Association champion, and Jody Ballard, booked for June 10 in Tampa, Fla., says he is canceling the bout because of a disagreement over who would referee.

title: Kathleen Tracy, Law Student, Wed To Peter O'Flinn
description: The Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathleen Tracy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., to Peter Russell O'Flinn, son of Mrs. Russell W. O'Flinn of Brooklyn, and the late Mr. O'Flinn. The Rev. James Haggarty performed the ceremony.

title: Chinese Arrest Killer of a Panda
description: A Chinese peasant has been arrested for killing a giant panda, China's most prized animal, in a Shaanxi Province nature preserve, a Chinese magazine reported today. It said Chao Tzuyu, a local militia leader, killed the 200-pound panda last January while hunting in the nature preserve with an automatic rifle. Chinese experts say only about 1,000 of the giant pandas, which are protected by law, are still living.

title: Swiss Set Back England In World Cup Qualifying
description: Switzerland scored twice in two minutes and scored a stunning 2-1 victory over England in a World Cup European soccer qualifying match yesterday in Basel, Switzerland.

title: METS LOSE
description: The Chicago Cubs, with the worst record in major league baseball, did not follow form yesterday afternoon. The Cubs rapped 16 hits and walloped the Mets, 10-3, before 11,504 fans at Shea Stadium. The Mets, who had won six of their last eight games, were out of contention after a seven-run fourth inning in which the Cubs sent 12 batters to the plate.

title: Fire Kills 2 San Quentin Inmates
description: Two inmates in San Quentin prison's protective custody unit burned to death in their cell today after a blanket was set on fire, prison officials said. The state Fire Marshal's office began investigating what caused the fire to burn so intensely that it sealed the cell door shut to would-be rescuers. Prison officials said that inmates had set several fires since a lockdown Thursday for a weapons search, but that the others had been extinguished without any injuries and with little damage.

title: No Headline
description: CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) - Hagley's Nest, a Canadian-bred son of Hagley, wore down Top Avenger in the stretch to score by 1 1/4 lengths in the $114,100 Sheridan Stakes at Arlington Park today. Television Studio, who will run in the Belmont Stakes, was third, four lengths back in the mile race for 3-year-olds.

title: SOVIET SAID TO EASE ITS VIEWS ON TERROR
description: Recent reports and discussion among students of terrorism suggest on the basis of fragmentary clues that an ideological gap betwen the Soviet Union and international terrorists is being bridged.

title: Weaver Told to Fight Tillis for Title
description: Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Associaton heavyweight champion, must sign to fight James (Quick) Tillis by June 30 or be stripped of his title, the W.B.A. ruled yesterday in Philadelphia. Tillis has a 20-0 record and is the No. 3 contender in the W.B.A. rankings.

title: No Time to Waste Water
description: Mayor Koch promises sprays on some hydrants on hot summer days. He will also let New York's homeowners fill swimming pools and water lawns three times a week. These minor bends in the city's strong line against water waste should not be taken to mean the drought's end. If summer rainfall is low and consumption high, the Mayor will promptly turn off the sprays and let lawns turn yellow. All other drought precautions, therefore, should remain in force.

title: CENSUS FINDS MORE BLACK LIVING IN SUBURBS OF NATION'S LARGE CITIES
description: Blacks have increased in numbers and as a percentage of the total population in the suburbs of most large cities over the last decade, but at the same time whites were moving on to virtually all-white areas of new growth and prosperity, either in the suburban rings or outside the metropolitan areas.

title: Nevada Senate Defeats Bill To Shut Bordello Near Reno
description: A bill to outlaw the Mustang Ranch brothel near Reno was defeated by a 11-to-9 vote today in the Nevada Senate.

title: ISLIP OBJECTS TO SEWER TAX WITHOUT PIPE
description: ISLIP ''WE'RE not objecting to the fact that Suffolk County has the right to collect a sewer tax, but we do object when there is no sewer pipe in the ground running in front of our property,'' said Stephen Jones, Commissioner of Planning for the Town of Islip.

title: Notes; FOR THEME-PARK VISITORS, NEW LOCATIONS AND NEW RIDES
description: Here is some good news for travelers who like theme parks. At least one new park is scheduled to open this summer, another has completed a major expansion and several others have added new attractions, including roller coasters and rides described as white-water adventures.

title: Spigner Bowling Winner
description: Needing nine pins on his final shot to win, Bill Spigner of Chicago came through with a strike to defeat Mark Williams, 237-235, in the final of the $95,000 City of Roses open bowling tournament today.

title: Hotels
description: To the Business Editor: I would like to point out certain major inaccuracies in your article, ''King David Hotel in Jerusalem Faces Invasion by U.S. Chains'' (April 7).

title: Miss Rinaldi, 14, Scores Upset
description: The other day Rosie Casals, a veteran, was eliminated by 19-year-old Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia at the French open tennis championships. Afterward Miss Casals expressed admiration for the way t- exuberant crop of youngsters, particularly Americans, had developed the ground stroke into a deadly weapon.

title: STUDIOS GROWING TO MEET CITY FILM INDUSTRY SURGE
description: New York City, a center of movie-making and television feature production in earlier years, has been experiencing a resurgence of the industry. To accommodate the growth, there has been a a critically needed expansion of studio facilities.

title: Italian Government Toppled by Scandal
description: Even in a country where scandal sometimes seems to approach an art form, the drama that brought down Italy's Government last week was epic. It started with Propaganda Due, a shadowy Masonic lodge headed by Licio Gelli, a fugitive businessman and loyal Mussolini Fascist, who allegedly combined underworld ties with dreams of a right-wing coup. His lodge membership list encoiled 3 Cabinet ministers, 30 generals, 8 admirals, 43 members of Parliament and hundreds of other prominent Italians, some also suspected of illicit activities.

title: Mutch Rides Holy Smoke To Working Hunter Title
description: Hugh Mutch rode Holy Smoke to the regular working hunter championship at the Devon Horse Show today although the gray gelding could do no better than finish second in the final class, the stake.

title: Leisure; A 30- ACRE GARDEN OF WILD FLOWERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John A. Lynch is a professional writer and freelance nature photographer. By JOHN A. LYNCH

title: SPENDING BY POLITICAL GROUPS
description: The following chart shows the 12 political action committees that spent the most money in 1979-1980, according to the Federal Election Commission.
