title: Elisabeth Witte Wed to William McIntire 3d
description: Elisabeth Witte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Hoyt Witte of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married in Bedford, N.Y., yesterday to William Tredick McIntire 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McIntire 2d of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Daniel Miner performed the ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: The Region In Summary; Fusion Candidacy Begins to Fizzle
description: Barring re-election by acclamation, perhaps nothing would please Mayor Koch more than to add the Republican endorsement to his own party's blessing in the upcoming campaign. But that consummation, which had seemed probable, was seriously endangered by the forces of party loyalty last week.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: The World In Summary; Saudis and OPEC Come to a Draw; Consumers Win
description: A buyers' market in oil, or what passes for one these days, seems likely to hold a while longer as a result of last week's OPEC meeting in Geneva. Cartel members agreed to freeze prices through 1981 and to cut production by about 10 percent - enough to reduce, but not eliminate, the worldwide glut of nearly 3 million barrels a day.

title: METHODISTS PONDER SALE OF 1842 CHURCH
description: MEMBERS of the Huntington-Cold Spring Harbor United Methodist Church will meet after Sunday services next week to decide whether to sell - for use as a business - one of the Island's oldest Methodist churches, a building that has been used as a church since it was built in 1842.

title: CHARLIE BROWN AND ME: OPTIMISM AND A BASEBALL HABIT
description: In the copious literature of baseball there is no book that I like any better than ''Sandlot P anuts,'' a collection of the daily and Sunday comic strips by Charles M. Schulz chronicling the efforts of Charlie Brown to manage his team to at least an occasional victory. Technically it is a work of fiction. It is also the story of my life.

title: 2 Adults and Baby Boy Killed in Oswego Blaze
description: Three persons, including a 19-month old boy, were killed when fire swept through their home at about 3 A.M. today, fire officials said. Three other children and an adult guest escaped after being alerted by a smoke alarm.

title:
Gardening;
IT'S TIME FOR SPRAYING AND FERTILIZING
description: WEATHER conditions should have stabilized sufficiently in the last week for tender vegetables and annuals to be planted out without danger of stunting from cold exposure. Tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, squash and cucumber planted at this time will often surpass those planted earlier in growth and production. Zinnias and tall marigolds may also be planted out. However, they often do better if the seed is sown directly. Scatter the seeds three inches apart in the row, then thin to a six- to eight-inch spacing after germination.

title: New Jersey Guide; HUNGARIAN FESTIVAL
description: On Saturday, from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M., New Brunswick will be the scene of the sixth annual Hungarian Festival around Mindszenty Square.

title: PUTTING TOGETHER THE CAMP TRUNK
description: FOR parents of camp-bound youngsters, this time of year has a special significance - it's the season to shop for and pack the camp trunk.

title: Letters; HIPPOCRATIC ADVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Bank Caper Is Bad For Spain's Nerves
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo at first couldn't or wouldn't say exactly who was behind the takeover of the Banco Central headquarters in Barcelona last week. In its way, this uncertainty was almost as damaging to Spain's insecure democracy - undermined by terrorism from the Basques and left and right - as if the bank caper had succeeded.

title: The Region In Summary; Aid and Comfort On Reading Scores
description: Ever since they were begun 12 years ago, citywide reading tests have provided ready ammunition for critics of the New York City school system. Each year the results showed that the average city student could not read as well as the average student elsewhere.

title: Art; TRENTON: OFFBEAT WATERCOLORS
description: TRENTON IT IS rumored that clearinghouses exist in certain parts of the country and that their sole function is to produce works of art. Whether the rumors are true or not cannot be determined at this time, but much of the art we see in galleries and museums resembles a clearinghouse product.

title: The Nation In Summary; Coal Miners Get A New, Improved Contract Offer
description: The United Mine Workers got a new tentative agreement with the soft coal industry last week and Sam M. Church Jr., the union's president, exuded optimism over prospects for rank-and-file ratification. But the same Sam Church had predicted ratification of a tentative contract reached in March, just before the 160,000 miners went on what now has become a 66-day strike.

title: Barbara Thatcher, Banker, Wed
description: Barbara Riddell Thatcher and Alan Peabody Donaldson were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE APOLOGIZES TO PROFESSOR FOR 1954 DISMISSAL
description: Nearly 27 years ago, in the waning months of the McCarthy era, Reed College dismissed Prof. Stanley W. Moore because he refused to discuss his Marxist beliefs. Twelve years ago, in the name of academic freedom, students and members of the faculty began a campaign to reinstate the professor, whose field is philosophy.

title:
Long Island Housing;
HOME SWEET BOAT
description: LIKE many other young couples planning to get married, James Johnston and Leslie Janes had a problem: how to find a house they could afford.

title: AFFORDABLE HOUSING CAN BE BUILT
description: NEVER in the world of housing has there been so little to satisfy the demands of so many. Yet, houses do not have to remain unbuilt in record numbers and Americans with below-average incomes do not have to reconcile themselves to a houseless future.

title: Lutherans Name Pastor For the Citicorp Complex
description: A former pastor of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod who is now dean of Christ Seminary-Seminex in St. Louis has been nominated for pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church at the Citicorp Tower in midtown Manhattan.

title: VALENTINE: METS' NEW MYSTERY
description: Ellis Valentine drove his $40,000 Mercedes down the Northway yesterday from Montreal to New York, where he will join the Mets today as one of the mystery men of baseball: an outfielder with a puzzling past but with superstar potential.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: THE following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1980. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from the Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: Doctors Say Pope Improves And Seems Less Fatigued
description: Doctors treating Pope John Paul II said today that his condition had clearly improved further and that he appeared less fatigued.

title: SETTING A NEW COURSE FOR MUSEUM
description: YONKERS IF a good fund-raiser is one who makes people want to give rather than feel constrained to do so, Peter Langlykke must be among the best. During a recent conversation, the new director of the Hudson River Museum inspired a listener to think, if only momentarily, of making an unsolicited contribution.

title: RED SOX STAGE RALLY TO BEAT BREWERS, 7-6
description: Dave Stapleton singled home Jim Rice from third base in the 10th inning today to give the Boston Red Sox a 7-6 comeback victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Seoul General Gets 5-Year Term For Taking Money From Students
description: A South Korean court today sentenced a retired three-star general and war hero to five years in prison for embezzlement.

title: Kathleen Corsale Bride Of Kenneth D'Appolonia
description: Kathleen Corsale and Kenneth J. D'Appolonia were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Arduino d'Apollonia,the bridegroom's maternal uncle, and Rev. Carl Hinrichsen officiated.

title: TOXIC-WASTE ROUTES REMAIN AN ISSUE
description: FOR years, Westchester County has imposed strict regulations on the transportation and disposal of septic-tank waste and refuse by private haulers. Trucks have to be in good mechanical shape, the disposal site approved and records kept of what is being hauled over what routes and where.

title: BASEBALL'S ADVERSARIES IN HOLDING PATTERN
description: On Dec. 8, 1980, Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, addressed the opening sessio of the game's annual winter meetings in Dallas. He welcomed the participants, he greeted visiting baseball officials from Japan, he sadly noted the retirement of Sadaharu Oh.

title: 'ADJUSTABLE' MORTGAGES FIND ACCEPTANCE, LENDERS SAY
description: With interest rates in the metropolitan area continuing to drift upward, adjustable-rate mortgages are gaining acceptance with lending institutions and a skeptical public.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is to such totalitarian states and the kinds of punishment they mete out that we doom people to return, if we accept and carry to its logical conclusion the I.N.S. action. In my view, this Administration does not wish to be seen as contributing to the creation of that kind of tragedy.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., in a letter urging reversal of an immigration policy limiting the entry of Indochinese refugees. (13:5.)

title: About Long Island
description: SINCE my mother taught me that this was the brake and that was the gas and I'd really better know the difference, many automobiles have come into my life by many routes, but only our new (new?) blue (blue?) 1968 Oldsmobile Delmont sedan came into my life out of someone else's.

title: ARLENE ALDA: LIFE AS A FEMINIST'S WIFE
description: Arlene Weiss of the Bronx seemed to have all the tickets: She graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Hunter College, won a Fulbright scholarship so she could study music in Europe, and then joined the Houston Symphony as assistant first clarinetist under the direction of Leopold Stokowski.

title: A DESIGNER HIS ART
description: BATTISTA FARINA, nicknamed Pinin, began styling automobile bodies not long after there were chassis to put them on. His son, Sergio, now head of the manufacturing and design firm called Pininfarina, has commemorated the company's long history with a series of designs that are being exhibited through June 14 in ''Carrozzeria Italiana,'' an examination of the Italian coachbuilder's art at Pasadena, Calif. Here, in response to questions, are his comments on the state of that art today.

title: DREISER RESTORED
description: SISTER CARRIE By Theodore Dreiser. The Pennsylvania Edition. Historical Editors: John C. Berkey and Alice M. Winters. Textual Editor: James L.W. West III. General Editor: Neda M. Westlake. 679 pp. Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $12.95.

title: Mary Mangini Is Married
description: St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary Henderson Mangini, daughter of Jerome John Mangini and the late Suzanne Scheffer Mangini, to William Tyler Saunders, son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Saunders.

title: Connecticut Guide; THE FLAMBOYANT WHISTLER
description: The portrait of his mother that made James McNeill Whistler famous gives no indication of the flamboyant character of the artist, and indeed ''looks nothing like her,'' in the painter's own words. The real J.M. Whistler, his amorous adventures in Paris and London, his wit, extravagant clothes and brash way of life have been brought to the stage by Lawrence and Maggie Williams, two Connecticut writers whose play ''I, James McNeill Whistler'' may be seen at the Hartford Stage Company, 50 Church Street, through June 28.

title:
On the Isle;
FAIR WEATHER
description: If this is almost June, can fair weather be far away? Of course not. So starting today, when the Three Village Historical Society holds its annual Colonial Fair, the Island will be abuzz with enough outdoor festivities to gladden the heart of any aficionado.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; Mrs. Gandhi Again Urging Birth Control
description: The continued growth in India's abundant natural resource, people, moved Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to vehemence last week. Addressing a conference of members of Parliament, she called new statistics ''shocking.''

title: BALLET: REMEMBERING A RIVAL FROM THE 40'S
description: Ballet history takes strange twists and turns. Back in the 1940's, Ballet Theater (as American Ballet Theater was then known) and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo were America's leading touring companies, and they were fierce rivals. Then the Ballet Russe disbanded, history twisted and turned, and on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, American Ballet Theater offered a program consisting entirely of works associated with the Ballet Russe of the 40's.

title: COMPUTERS TURN ARTISTIC AND THE ARTISTS LIKE IT
description: In a dimly lit room with cinderblock walls at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, organ keyboards are connected to computer terminals that display musical notes on their screens. There, musicians are using computers to create and shape sounds never before heard.

title: LOUISIANA, TEAMING WITH ALLIGATORS, LOOKS TO HUNTING AS ANSWER
description: According to state wildlife officials and beleaguered landowners, Louisiana is up to its subdivisions in alligators.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Nancy Boston, Pianist, Performs a Haydn Sonata
description: There is a good deal to be said for the bracingly direct and unmannered approach to the piano that Nancy Boston cultivated at her debut recital in the Abraham Goodman house on Wednesday night. Miss Boston, who has studied at Lawrence University in Wisconsin and at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, has strong, accurate fingers and a forthright manner that made everything she played sound crisp, fresh and unaffected.

title: Elizabeth C. Greene Married To Kenneth R. Nowakowski
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Cooke Greene to Kenneth R. Nowakowski took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Music Noted in Brief
description: Music  Noted in Brief Contemporary Works From German Repertory

title: FRENCH COMMUNISTS SCRAMBLING TO REGAIN PRESTIGE
description: Derailed after 40 years of regarding itself as the locomotive of the French left, the Communist Party is facing legislative elections next month that are likely to reduce its 86-seat contingent in the National Assembly by approximately half.

title: Follow-Up on the News; New Florida Termite
description: It was a condominium in Hallandale, Fla., with a spectacular ocean view. And then the residents learned that the building was infested with the world's worst termites.

title: The Nation In Summary; Only the Murders Add Up in Atlanta
description: Last week brought a new victim; Nathaniel Cater, 27 years old. Like five others, his body was found in the Chattahoochee River; like at least 16 others, he apparently died by asphyxiation; like five others, he was an adult said to have been slightly retarded.

title: Music View; FINGERPRINTS OF THE GREAT COMPOSERS
description: A musical score is like one of those maps that the host draws to guide you to his party in the country. (When you come to the second Safeway, turn left until you see the basket and cheese store, then drive 22 1/2 miles on a dirt road to the antiques shop ....) Even the most party-hardened driver can lose his way in the exurban labyrinth unless he has learned to interpret the host's idiosyncratic way of giving directions. The same is true of any musical score, but particularly those written in centuries before our own. Until our own century it was the rare score that offered what we would regard now as the bare minimum of navigational instructions.

title: RUSTY TRAWLER TO LEAD BATTLE AGAINST WHALE HUNTS
description: The rusty old trawler called the Sea Shepherd 2 is rocking peacefully at her slip at this Potomac River port while a crew of young men and women scrapes and paints her.

title: Bridge; NOT QUITE WARMED UP
description: From the angle of the player and the publicist, organized bridge in North America suffers from a major weakness that few perceive: There are virtually no representative opportunities. A handful of players earn the right to play in world championships; and when they arrive to do so, it is often the first occasion on which they have not been playing simply for themselves.

title: DANCE: NEW CASTS IN BALLET THEATER'S REPERTORY
description: For balletomanes who adore new casts in familiar works, American Ballet Theater's current season must be a thoroughgoing delight. There were many new casts on view at the company's Wednesday matinee and evening presentations at the Metropolitan Opera House and their performances ranged from the promising to the disappointing.

title: Social Security
description: To the Business Editor: I read ''Cut Retirement Costs'' (May 24) by Rudolph G. Penner with mounting indignation. Professor Penner states, ''I find it hard to see why Social Security benefits should remain sacrosanct when recipients typically receive more income than those on welfare whose benefits are being cut by the Reagan budget.''

title: POP MUSIC
description: Floyd Tillman, who will be at the Lone Star Cafe, 61 Fifth Avenue, on Thursday, is a pioneer of Southwestern honky-tonk music and the writer of several enduring country-music classics, including ''Slipping Around,'' ''It Makes No Difference Now'' and the unforgettable ''Cold War'' (recently revived by John Pline.) Mr. Tillman, who was born in Oklahoma and grew up in Texas, first attracted attention in the 1930's as an exceptional electrical guitarist, playing in the company of western swing and honky-tonk artists like Moon Mullican and Ted Daffan, author of ''Born to Lose.'' The guitar occupied most of Mr. Tillman's attention from the mid 30's until around 1949, when he began writing and recording - in a relaxed baritone - his own honky-tonk hits.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook Salaries and Trades Top Menu
description: The new rule for signing free agents, called the right of first refusal, gave the National Basketball Association general managers and coaches a new game to play last week at their annual summer meetings. Mitch Kupchak, the Washington Bullets free agent, was the main topic.

title: Realty News
description: Third Avenue Several major leases have been signed at 875 Third Avenue, the 29-story office under construction on the east side of the avenue between 52d and 53d Streets.

title: ACTING PRESIDENT OF BANGLADESH WELL VERSED IN LAW AND POLITICS
description: Abdus Sattar, who became Acting President of Bangladesh yesterday after the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, is a mild-mannered man, well versed in law and politics.

title: An Alternative Exists For Bilingual Programs
description: In an Opinion Page article on April 12, the president of an urbanarea Board of Education attacked the country's bilingual-education program. However, he never mentioned a perfectly viable solution that already exists: The English as a Second Language program.

title: Rochelle A. Stackhouse Wed to Peter G. Ferriby
description: At the Church in the Manger (United Church of Christ) in Bethlehem, Pa., yesterday, Rochelle Ann Stackhouse, a member of the class of '82 at the Princeton Theological Seminary, was married to Peter Gavin Ferriby, who received a Master of Divinity degree from Princeton Theological last year. The Rev. Charles W. Long performed the ceremony.

title: The Region In Summary; Gun Laws Signed, With Reservations, In Connecticut
description: Gun controls haven't been very popular in Connecticut, nor were they expected to be this year. But no one expected a President and a Pope to be shot, either.

title: A VOLCANO'S FIERY LABORATORY
description: David Ritchie is a graduate student in biology at the University of Massachusetts. His book, ''The Ring of Fire,'' about earthquake and volcanic activity in the Pacific, will be published in August by Atheneum. By David Ritchie One of the most spectacular natural disasters in United States history took place just over a year ago, when a formerly serene volcanic peak in the state of Washington - Mount St. Helens - erupted on the morning of May 18, 1980.

title: DETAILED RECORDS LINK 500 IN ITALY TO MASONIC UNIT
description: Parliament has received records reportedly showing that about 500 Italians paid membership dues to a Masonic lodge that is at the center of a scandal that brought down the Government this week.

title: Cynthia Carter, Editor, Bride of Shirley Edward Ayres
description: Cynthia Austin Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Owen Carter Jr. of Wassaic, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Shirley Edward Ayres, son of Mrs. James Ernest Ayres of Farmville, Va., and the late Mr. Ayres. The Rev. Sydney N. Craig, rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kent, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Carter home.

title: NEW U.S. ENVOY ARRIVES QUIETLY IN SAN SALVADOR
description: The new United States Ambassador to El Salvador, Deane R. Hinton, has arrived here and presented his credentials to the embattled Government in a ceremony that was virtually closed to the press.

title: Molly Hegarty, Lawyer, Wed to Richard Colombo
description: Mary Meade Hegarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hegarty of Greenwich, Conn., was married at home yesterday to Richard Colombo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Colombo of Kenley, England. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest of Riverside, Conn., performed the ceremony.

Rabbi Roy Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism performed the ceremony.

title: D.J. Shannon Weds Alice Ely
description: The marriage of Alice Ely to Daniel Joseph Shannon took place yesterday at St. Thomas Aquinas Roman Catholic Church in Indianapolis. The Rev. Martin Peter performed the ceremony. The bride, director of creative services for Progressive Grocer magazine, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Ely of Indianapolis. Mr. Shannon, son of Joan Shannon of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., is an account executive at Cunningham & Walsh, advertising agency.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: OPEC failed to establish a uniform price for oil at its meeting last week in Geneva, and some analysts think that the price of gasoline will fall several cents a gallon as a result. Saudi Arabia refused to raise its $32-a-barrel price or cut production. A majority of the oil nations agreed to reduce output by at least 10 percent and hold their crude oil prices to $36 to $41 a barrel.

title: Dr. Jay Clark Buckey Jr.  Weds Sarah W. Masters
description: At Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, N.J., yesterday Sarah Woodroffe Masters and Dr. Jay Clark Buckey Jr., who graduated in 1977 from Cornell University, were married by the Rev. William Strain.

title: MORMONS HONOR SHUTTLE ASTRONAUTS
description: Many people had come to Temple Square an hour and a half early just to be sure of a seat, and when the ceremony at last began, Elder Neal A. Maxwell advised the 6,000 in attendance that on this one occasion it would be appropriate for them to break the solemnity of the tabernacle and applaud.

title: Schmidt Gets Backing of Coalition Partners for Stand on Missiles

description: Shelves were restocked today at two grocery stores where employees found extortion notes demanding $160,000 and saying that jars of pickles and tomato sauce had been spiked with hydrochloric acid.

Long Island Journal
description: AS ''a courtesy'' to the New York Islanders hockey team, construction was delayed on the 391-room, 10-story hotel at Mitchel Field until a day after the team had won the Stanley Cup.

Loehr, a Democrat who had criticized him for the city's fiscal difficulties, for a ''headline hunting'' public style and for his constant bickering with the City Council.

description: Reworking the Budget

description: This farming town 50 miles west of Dublin is familiar to most of the Irish as the site of the country's first turf-burning power station, erected in 1950.

description: The marriage of Lisa Pelikan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pelikan of Paris and Washington, to Robert Harper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Harper of New Monmouth, N.J., took place in Stony Point, N.Y., yesterday. title: Pastore, Reds Top Dodgers
description: George Foster drove in three runs today, two of them with his 11th homer of the season, and Frank Pastore posted his first victory since April 24 as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 9-1.

title: Medicaid Stall in Albany
description: Normally, June in Albany means deadly inaction because the Legislature has adjourned and gone home. This year, it promises to mean costly inaction on the critical issue of Medicaid, because Governor Carey is refusing to talk seriously about it with anyone who does not already agree with him.

title: BEWARE OF REAGAN'S MILITARY SPENDING
description: H AVING started the debate about the economic impact of President Reagan's military spending in the New York Review of Books last month, let me respond to the points made by the economic defenders of the Reagan military budget.

title: Foster Grandparents, Mutual Love and Respect
description: I agree with the authors of the book ''Grandparents/Grandchildren'' (''Authors Find Grandparents to Be Valuable Resource for Children,'' May 10) that ''children need their grandparents, the only adults with an uncritical, loving and long-lasting relationship.'' As stated in the article, grandparents, for many reasons, are not as available as they were for previous generations.

title: MONTCLAIR TROUPE AWAITS CURTAIN
description: MONTCLAIR ''INEVER had the typical parent hassle about entering the theater,'' said W. Scott MacConnell. ''I was an apprentice at 13, acted when I was in college and worked throughout the East and South before I came here.''

title: MUST NEW JERSEY PAY THE PIPER BECAUSE IT PAYS THE CANDIDATES?
description: PRIMARIES have a habit of confounding even seasoned political pros, and with a field of 21 candidates, Tuesday's gubernatorial contests in New Jersey are an especially hard call. Nevertheless, the consensus is that among Democrats, Representative James J. Florio is in front, but just barely. Representative Robert A. Roe, popular with labor in a state with a large labor vote, and former Attorney General John J. Degnan, who was endorsed last week by Governor Byrne, could give him trouble. Mr. Byrne also asked Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark, Ann Klein, the former state human services commissioner, Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith of Jersey City and Assemblywoman Barbara W. McConnell to pull out of the race and clear the way for Mr. Degnan. None did.

title: 2 STAR SOVIET SINGERS ARE OUT IN COLD
description: Alla Ioshpe was a Jewish girl from Moscow. Stakhan Rakhimov was a Moslem boy from Uzbekistan. They met in the final of a nationwide student singing competition, shared the first prize, fell in love, were married and began singing together.

title: RETHINKING LIBERALISM
description: New Haven - For liberals, this is a time for reflection, an unaccustomed respite from the thought-impoverishing responsibilities of power. Although unregenerate defenders of hallowed dogma remain, more-thoughtful liberals wish to reassess their alternative to Reaganism. They have repaired to the academy, ''think tanks,'' and the private sector, eager to fashion a creed suitable to today's zeitgeist. Once they roost, what next?

title: NEW YORK POLICE WILL QUESTION 2 IN BOMB INQUIRY
description: Two men suspected of membership in a Puerto Rican terrorist group were arrested in a Chicago suburb Friday and will be questioned by New York City detectives in connection with unsolved bombings in New York.

title: A PUSHCART MOTIF IN A 5TH AVENUE SHOP
description: Fifth Avenue, for all its glamour, has long been home to discounters, stores purporting to be going out of business and street peddlers, side-by-side with some of the world's most elegant emporiums. Starting tomorrow at noon, it will also be home to Job Lot Trading-The Pushcart, which has been selling reduced-price liquidated merchandise in the Wall Street area for more than 30 years.

title: OLEAN MARKING ITS CENTENNIAL AS A FRESH AIR TOWN
description: On a hot summer day in 1885, a group of nervous couples waited anxiously in the steamy lobby of the Erie Railway depot in Olean, N.Y., for the arrival of 46 children from New York City.

description: "I am not a very technically oriented person, but I find myself constantly confronted with technical problems in my buildings," said Charles Solberg.

description: GREAT NECK IRVING SIEGEL wants very much to keep his advertising and marketing business in Great Neck, where it has been for 21 years. But he may face an uphill battle in doing so.

description: To the Editor:

title: RESTORATION REVEALS MICHANGELO'S GIFTS
description: ROME Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel, which are some of the most important works of art in the world, are being cleaned. The 12-year, $3-million project, which has been underway for several months, has already produced evidence that Vatican scholars triumphantly contend makes possible a new evaluation of the master artist as a painter. Michelangelo's frescoes in the famous chapel include the monumental ''Last Judgment'' on the huge altar wall, the even more gigantic depiction of the origins of the universe that covers the entire huge ceiling and 14 more modest lunettes depicting the ancestors of Jesus. So far the restorers have finished one lunette and started work on a second. The result is startling. The restored lunette, on the entrance wall, is bursting with colors. The figures have become so three-dimensional they fairly jump out of the wall. The part of the adjoining lunette that has not yet been cleaned is dark and dull by comparison and its figures are shadowy against a dim background.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: In its earliest days, dance photography was a matter of carefully posed pictures that captured, at best, the still and contemplative moments of the dance. Nowadays, with fast films and fast cameras, photographers can freeze action in mid-air, as Martha Swope did with Edward Villella when he would make that breathtaking leap in the ballet ''The Prodigal Son,'' enabling the viewer to contemplate aspects of movement that the unaided eye cannot see. Yet, some of today's most evocative dance photographs are still of the motionless sort.

title: Lefever: Why It Matters
description: Two weeks ago in this space I mentioned a Soviet physicist, Vladimir Kislik: not a famous dissident, just a man who for eight years had been trying to emigrate to Israel. description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Dick Ruthven scattered nine hits, and Dick Davis drove in five runs, two with his first National League homer, for the Phillies.

title: History
description: Wars between Moslems and Hindus have been erupting on the subcontinent for centuries. In the 12th century Moslem invaders brought Islam to Bengal, which is now part of Bangladesh, and the Moslem rulers remained until the British arrived in the 18th century. In 1947, predominantly Hindu India won independence from Britain and a separate Moslem state, Pakistan, was created in two parts divided by 1,000 miles of Indian territory. With power centered in West Pakistan, the more populous East Pakistan demanded greater economic benefits and political change. Rioting broke out in the East in 1968. In 1970 the separatists in the East won a majority in the National Assembly and called for more independence, but Assembly sessions were postponed by Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, who was then President. Rioting in the East erupted into civil war and Bangladesh was declared independent, forcing the resignation of Mr. Yahya Khan. Sheik Mujibur Rahman, a leader of the Bengali nationalists in the East, became Prime Minister but was killed in a 1975 coup. His successor was also deposed, and Maj. Gen. Ziaur Rahman, who was assassinated yesterday, became the martial law leader in 1976 and President

description: To: Jonathan Burpee Burpee Seed Company Warminster, Pa. ... 18991 Dear Mr. Burpee: Last winter in your seed catalogue, you wished me ''best wishes for a productive, happy gardening year,'' and invited me to report on my progress.

title: The World In Summary; Dutch Vote Casts Doubt on Missiles
description: Last week's Dutch election produced no clear winner, but there was at least one likely loser - a plan to station 48 United States cruise missiles in the Netherlands under North Atlantic Treaty Organization auspices. Dutch refusal could be pivotal because acceptance of the new intermediate-range missiles was already in doubt in larger West European countries.

description: Scientists at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health have warned the Reagan Administration that it should impose unusual safeguards in the engineering and construction of prospective coal liquefaction plants to limit ''serious health and safety hazards'' that the agency says are inherent in the process.

description: THE WORLD OF DONALD EVANS By Willy Eisenhart. Illustrated. 173 pp. New York: A Harlin Quist Book. Distributed by Dial/Delacorte. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $16.95. title: ENVIRONMENTALISM IN THE 80'S
description: THE environmental movement in New Jersey, having fought for and won many protective laws long before other states acted, has settled down to a quieter, but perhaps more intense, routine.

title: TARRYTOWN CENTER EXPANDING ITS SCOPE
description: TARRYTOWN E STABLISHED 16 years ago as a private campus for a few corporations, the Tarrytown House Executive Conference Center gained a reputation as a cultural and intellectual center when Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, helped form what came to be known as the Tarrytown Group. Under the chairmanship of Dr. Mead, who died Nov 15, 1978. The 26-acre Mary Duke Biddle estate was a favorite weekend retreat for a small group of friends, who met informally to explore life's problems.

title: Long Islanders; PROFESSOR OF ENGLISH, STUDENT OF LAW
description: LOOK on the list of faculty members at Hofstra University and you will find the name of Richard B. Sypher of Hempstead. He is an associate professor of English.

title: NO LETUP IN PROPAGANDA WAR ON NATIONALIST ISLES OFF CHINA COAST
description: The first thing to strike a visitor's eye as he alights from the military plane are two huge signs that proclaim in bold white Chinese characters on a flaming red background, ''Recover the Chinese Mainland'' and ''Destroy the Communists.''

title: Annual Benefit
description: The Hudson River Museum, which has faced financial difficulties recently, is seeking to raise $30,000 during its fourth annual benefit, which will be held June 12, from 7 P.M. until midnight in the museum's courtyard.

title: Quito Ratifies Break in Ties With Linguistics Institute
description: Ecuador today ratified a decision, signed by President Jaime Roldos Aguilera before his death last Sunday in a plane crash, to end the contract here of the Summer Institute of Linguistics within a year. The institute, based in Huntington, Calif., works in a number of Latin American countries, translating the Bible into local dialects.

title: CONSERVATIVE POLITICAL COMMITTEE EVOKES BOTH FEAR AND ADORATION
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee, which got more attention and spent more money on politics in 1979 and 1980 than any other political action group, typifies a critically important new force in American politics, nurtured by the growth of direct-mail technology and developments in campaign finance laws.

description: CUSTOM By HENRY TANNER

title: Zimbabwe to Control Press Unit
description: Zimbabwe is gaining control of its national press agency from South Africa. The South African Press Association said today that it would transfer ownership of the press agency to the Salisbury authorities by June 30 because its directors "decided it would be right for the ownership of Zimbabwe's domestic news agency to be in Zimbabwean hands."

title: Monaco Grand Prix Uses Laser to Enforce Rules
description: Laser technology is being used at the 39th Monaco Grand Prix to enforce a rule that has produced anger in some teams and drivers.

title: BANGLADESH LEADER IS SHOT AND KILLED IN A COUP ATTEMPT
description: President Ziaur Rahman of Bangladesh was shot and killed in the port city of Chittagong early today and a broadcast by the Dacca radio said a little-known opposition group was responsible for the assassination.

title: ZIAUR RAHMAN WAS STRICT LEADER WHO TRIED TO GIVE NATION DIRECTION
description: When Maj. Gen. Ziaur Rahman seized power in Bangladesh six years ago, he was hailed as the strict leader that the struggling nation needed.

title: Article 138122 -- No Title
description: A British company and several unidentified British investors have offered to buy a luxury cooperative apartment building on Park Avenue for $32 million, according to several residents and others familiar with the proposal.

title: CITY PLAN FOR GARBAGE-FUELED PLANT DRAWS ANGER OF BROOKLYN RESIDENTS
description: New York City's plan to build a steam plant that would burn 3,000 tons of garbage a day in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard has prompted borough residents to begin voicing fear, suspicion and opposition.

Keenan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Keenan of Rutland, Vt. The Rev. John Ames and the Rev. Francis Lavelle performed the ceremony.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ATHIA HARDT contributes to The New York Times from Phoenix. By ATHIA HARDT

title: Follow-Up on the News; Legal Marijuana
description: With minutely defined use - mainly to relieve nausea in cancer patients and to hold down the eye pressure of persons with glaucoma - marijuana became a medical drug by law in New York State in July 1980. The action followed similar laws in 23 other states.

title: Match the Hatch Wins, Surviving Inquiry
description: Kenny Skinner had mixed success in his only two rides at Belmont Park yesterday. Skinner, who is 25 years old and comes from Edinburgh, Scotland, won the first $100,000 stakes race of his career with Match the Hatch in the $113,600 Edgemere Handciap on the turf. But he had to survive a stewards' inquiry to do it.

title: INDUSTRIAL NEIGHBOR'S NOISE BRINGS COMPLAINTS ON W. 15TH
description: Residents of several buildings on West 15th Street have complained to the city about a ''new and unusual'' noise coming from a printing business in the former Port Authority building across the street.

title: Caroline Wheelwright Bride Of Thomas Sylvester Carroll
description: Caroline Eschauzier Wheelwright and Thomas Sylvester Carroll were married yesterday at the bridegroom's home in New Canaan, Conn.

title: OLD BOOKSTORES: A CHAPTER ENDS
description: Book Row needs an epitaph, says Walter Goldwater, who has been in business there for close to 50 years. ''As a book center, the street is gone,'' he said. ''Somebody dies, somebody becomes moribund, somebody moves to Florida. Most of us never made a substantial living anyway.''

title: Charles Robb a Candidate For Governor of Virginia
description: Lieut. Gov. Charles S. Robb, son-in-law of the late President Lyndon B. Johnson, was nominated today by Virginia Democrats to run for governor this year.

title: Stage View; YES, IT'S TONY AWARD TIME, BUT MEANWHILE, OFF BROADWAY...
description: A week from tonight, Broadway's finest will parade before a national television audience in the annual Tony Awards ceremony. These rites are always entertaining - even when they try too hard to parrot the silliness of routine prime-time variety specials - and, this year, at least, the show will serve as a reasonable summation of the Broadway season. One might quarrel with a few peculiar omissions among the Tony candidates - a Maria Tucci here, a Derek Jacobi there - but, overall, the best plays, musicals, revivals and performances have been nominated for prizes. Some of them have been thrilling, too. At the very least, this Broadway season is to be cherished for such productions as ''Amadeus,'' ''Fifth of July,'' ''A Lesson From Aloes,'' ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and ''Sophisticated Ladies.''

title: ALBANY PANEL EXPECTED TO ENDORSE MRS. POOLER AS A UTILITY REGULATOR
description: Despite the strong objections of utility companies, the State Senate Energy Committee is expected to recommend next week the confirmation of Rosemary S. Pooler to the Public Service Commission, according to the committee's chairman, Senator Dale M. Volker.

title: WHEN AMWAY OPPORTUNITY KNOCKS
description: TORRINGTON, Conn. ''H ELLO, Matthew, my name is Lucy Lubus, and I own my own business,'' said the woman who, unsolicited, telephoned my home one evening recently. An odd way to open a conversation with a stranger, I thought, but it kept me listening.

title: Antiques; TEDDY BEARS BASK IN COLLECTORS' AFFECTION
description: It's a bullish year for teddy bears. Books on the subject are proliferating and the market for period bears is booming. Be they straw- or foam-stuffed, hump-backed or straight, boasting eyes of black shoe buttons or bright, shining glass, and wearing a thick coat of angora plush or a thin skin which is balding in spots, these teddies are eagerly sought by a growing band of collectors.

title: U.S. EARTHQUAKE AID FOR ITALY IS SLOWED
description: Last November's earthquake in southern Italy, which killed 3,000 people and demolished 365 villages, has generated $85 million in relief aid from the United States. But the money is beginning to arrive only after extensive bureaucratic delays.

title: The Region In Summary; Light and Shadow At Indian Point
description: It's no Three Mile Island by a long shot, but Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear plant has never lacked its share of critics, especially after a 112,000 gallon leak forced it out of service in October. Last week, as the company finally switched the reactor back on, public officials demanded that the utility pay at least part of the cost of the shutdown.

title: COAL STRIKERS' CHIEF GIRDS TO SELL PACT
description: Sam M. Church Jr., president of the United Mine Workers, is to set out tomorrow on a six-day tour of the Eastern coal fields in yet another effort to second-guess the militantly independent, antimanagement feelings of thousands of striking Appalachian coal miners.

description: Mario Andretti spoke almost as if he would have preferred second place to a victory with an asterisk behind it.

title: Ideas & Trends In Summary; On the Average, Baby No Longer Makes Three
description: The nuclear family seems to be splitting into ever smaller particles. According to 1980 census figures released last week, the size of American households has declined sharply since 1970 - a drop caused by a lower birth rate and by the record numbers of adults living alone.

title: Manners
description: To the Business Editor: The timing was exquisite! Not 10 minutes before noticing and reading ''Why Nobody Calls You Back Anymore'' (May 24) by Robert K. Otterbourg, I was remarking that I had fruitlessly tried to contact an executive through both his secretary and his wife. The purpose was to convey information of some value to him.

description: Responding to a sudden increase in companies planning to use gene-splicing techniques to manufacture medical and industrial products, Boston and several surrounding communities have passed or drafted ordinances to regulate the industry on the local level.

description: IS it possible for a dual-career couple to find happiness in marriage, raise a family and simultaneously continue to prosper in their chosen fields? If so, what are the ingredients for success?

description: The decision of Eugene Gold not to seek another term as Brooklyn District Attorney has set off a scramble to succeed him that involves at least five persons, according to politicians and courthouse sources.

description: The Reagan Administration, in trouble with Congress over its Social Security and tax-cut plans and yet to enunciate an overall foreign policy, last week played the cards it's confident are strong. One is the President's popularity - two out of three Americans rate him favorably, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

description: To the Editor:

title: LITCHFIELD HILLS SEEN FROM TOWERS
description: THE traveler to northwestern Connecticut who is willing to get off the beaten track can visit two ''modestly ancient'' round towers that are well worth the challenging climb along woodland paths that lead to them. Situated on mountaintops, both offer fine vantage points for panoramic views of the countryside.

title: The Nation In Summary; Mexican Workers: Second Thoughts
description: Last fall, candidate Ronald Reagan said he favored an open-ended program to allow Mexicans into the United States as temporary workers. Last week, an advisory panel said that President Reagan should be content with a two-year experiment limited to 50,000 workers a year.

title: Mimi Dolph and Steven Michael Adkins Are Married
description: Mary Early Dolph, daughter of Mrs. Thomas P. Ford of New York and Madison, Conn., and Edward Clark Dolph of Boston, was married yesterday to Steven Michael Adkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Steven Adkins Jr. of Easton, Conn. description: To the Editor:

title: Reading and Writing; LIFE STORY
description: In the recently published ''Singled Out,'' a book of social and sexual etiquette for the divorced man, Richard Schickel urges him to ''bring a little shaping art to bear'' on the story of his former marriage when he tells it to a new friend.

title: WHITE PLAINS LIBRARY TO BE HOST TO CIRCUS
description: A CIRCUS is coming to the White Plains Public Library, complete with clowns and puppets, a juggler and mimes. The occasion is the White Plains Arts Festival, and as part of the celebration the library is conducting a children's street carnival next Saturday, from 2 to 4 P.M.

title: Practical Travaler; AIR, RAIL, BUS OR CAR? CHOOSING IN THE NORTHEAST CORRIDOR
description: Never before has the Northeast Corridor offered as many travel options as it does today. Although prices in general have been rising, competitive pressures have recently created a number of substantial bargains, especially for travel by air.

title: EATING DISORDERS OF YOUTHS EXPLORED
description: AT midnight, while the rest of the family slept, 17-year-old Maggie tiptoed into the kitchen for a ''snack.'' There she consumed a half gallon of ice cream, a quarter of a chocolate cake, two candy bars and a box of cookies she had hidden for the occasion. Then, feeling uncomfortably full, depressed and disgusted with herself for the uncontrollable eating, she forced herself to throw up.

title:
Speaking Personally;
PICKING UP THE DETRITUS OF A LIFE
description: SUDDENLY, you were hit with the feeling that his life was laid out there, in bits and pieces, on the garbage dump in front of the newly sold mountain lodge, waiting for the scavenger truck to pick it up.

title: By Peter G. Davis; Music: Debuts in Review; Steven Hartman Displays Clarinet in Many Settings
description: For his debut recital in the Abraham Goodman House last Sunday night, Steven Hartman chose an intelligent and enjoyable program that displayed the clarinet in a variety of settings. There was Brahms's Sonata in F minor (Op. 120, No. 1), the obligatory repertory classic; Bassi's Concert Fantasia on ''Rigoletto,'' a virtuoso showpiece; Kenneth Higgins's Sonata, a score composed for the occasion, and finally a chamber work, Mozart's Trio in E flat (K. 498).

title: Chess; THE GAMBIT GAMBLE
description: A gambit is almost always a stern test, even if it is not entirely correct. The threats and positional pressure it generates may not in the final analysis fully compensate for the material sacrificed, but the defender must play from a cramped formation and this is conducive to error.

title: AMERICAN MODERN HAS BEEN THRIVING IN FRANCE
description: Lois Draegin is dance editor of Soho News. By LOIS DRAEGIN

title: LIGHTING UP THE COSMOS
description: Diane Ackerman, the author of two collections of poetry and a prose memoir, is currently at work on a novel about the soccer world. By Diane Ackerman Near the goal, head sunk deep into his shoulders as he sprints, Giorgio Chinaglia takes the ball, dribbles it around a thatch of red shirts and, sliding between two defenders, belts it at 70 miles an hour into the netted calm of the goal. Raising his fists in triumph, Chinaglia gallops around the pitch, leaping as if lovesick into the arms of his teammate Andranik Eskandarian, leaping to the hypnotic boom of the New York Cosmos fans, thousands of whom are on their feet, booing him, as usual.

title: YANKS WIN, 1-0
description: On his second day on the job, Clyde King, the Yankees' new pitching coach, faced his first setback today when Ron Guidry took himself out of a game just before it began.

title: DELAY ON MARGIOTTA COULD AFFECT ELECTION
description: WHILE the retrial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican leader, on charges of mail fraud and extortion is scheduled for August, any delay could cause problems for the Nassau G.O.P. organization.

title: ...CAN BE PRELUDE TO 'THE SOUNDS OF SILENCE'
description: TRUE or false: With the temporary demise of a family's favorite diversion, television, members of the household rediscover the art of conversation, renew their interests in things intellectual, become reacquainted and develop into a loving, interreacting familial unit.

title: DELIGHTFUL HUBBELL, 'THE MEAL TICKET'
description: To the Sports Editor: I read with interest Dave Anderson's column (The New York Times, May 10) ''Original Carl Hubbellito.''

title: Sound; AN AMPLIFIER THAT GILDS THE LILY
description: Not wishing to frustrate budget-bound readers, this column rarely focuses on blatantly expensive equipment. Occasional exceptions are called for when a) the item is so good as to be attractive despite its price, and b) when the design breaks new technical ground in a manner which in itself is news. Both conditions are met by Sansui's latest entry in the top ranks of audio - the Model AU-D11 amplifier.

title:
Construction Update;
UNFOLDING HOUSES
description: Since Shanni Homes, renamed Shanni International, sold and erected its first unfolding home in West Keansburg, New Jersey last year it has not erected another.

title: Charger Owner Better
description: Eugene Klein, owner of the San Diego Chargers, was listed in satisfactory condition today after having been stricken with a heart attack. He was hospitalized after having testified in the National Football League-Oakland Raiders trial here two days ago. He has been transferred to Cedar-Sinai Medical Center to be closer to his home, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Politics; GOVERNOR PRESSED BY THE PRESS
description: HARTFORD A LONG time ago a young reporter for a now-defunct New York City newspaper rushed back to the office and wrote a story that began as follows:

title: WHAT IS BASEBALL'S MEANING AND ITS EFFECT ON AMERICA
description: WARS couldn't stop major league baseball, the Depression couldn't stop major league baseball; it seems the only thing that could is major league baseball itself. By the very threat of the players' strike, the idea that the great stadia would be empty this summer - and the crack of bat against ball merely an echo in the mind - gives pause to reflect on baseball and its meaning in the warp and woof of life.

title: Warsaw Pact Leader Is Visiting Poland
description: Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, Soviet Commander in Chief of the Warsaw Pact military alliance, made an unannounced visit to Poland today for a meeting with Stanislaw Kania, the Communist Party leader, and Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, according to the official press agency.

title: Dining Out; STYLISH SIMPLICITY FACING THE PARK
description: HARTFORD WITH its many downtown renovations of recent years, Hartford deserves as many attractive restaurants as it can get. Fortunately, in Hubbard's Park it has a stylish one indeed.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Susanne Shapiro, Baroque Harpsichordist
description: Susanne Shapiro, who teaches and plays the harpsichord at Indiana University and at schools on the West Coast, paid the Abraham Goodman House a visit Thursday evening, offering music that pretty well defined the beginnings and ends of the Baroque era. Her program seemed to celebrate this age's constant straining for originality - from the wild-eyed iconoclastic harmonic textures of Giovanni Picchi's Pass'e mezzo to Bach's equally wild but awesomely surefooted Sarabande in the G minor English Suite.

title: TURKISH TALES
description: SEAGULL By Yashar Kemal. Translated by Thilda Kemal. 250 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $11.95.

title: Security Is Tight in Spanish City For Visit by King and His Family
description: Sharpshooters watched from rooftops and uniformed and plainclothes police patrolled the streets today on the second day of King Juan Carlos's visit to Barcelona for Spain's annual military celebrations.

title: ABOUT PUBLIC TV'S CRISIS
description: The following letters have been received in response to a recent twopart series of articles examining ''the crisis of confidence'' surrounding public television. The first article by Desmond Smith, which appeared on May 10, asserted that the Public Broadcasting Service had lost governmental support largely as a result of having become ''elitist.'' The second article by Tony Schwartz, which appeared on May 17, explored possible future directions for public television.

title: DIGGING INTO HISTORY
description: Claudia Lorber neglected to mention industrial archeology. In addition to answering questions about the process of industrialization, industrial archeology can tell us a great deal about the daily lives of our grandfathers and grandmothers and about otherwise anonymous sweatshop laborers, who are as much a part of our history as our more famous and articulate ancestors. CAROL POH MILLER Society for Industrial Archeology

title: The Devious Path Out of Lebanon
description: A good diplomat does not turn his back on a crisis unless he's sure it won't explode. Nor does he stop talking to the belligerents unless he thinks his absence might actually help. And Philip Habib, who flew home last week ''to report'' on three weeks of bargaining in Syria and Israel, is a very good diplomat.

title: Letters; On Blueprints
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 KILLED AS A COPTER CRASHES IN FOG IN WESTCHESTER COUNTY
description: A corporate helicopter evidently seeking to make an emergency landing in a thick fog crashed last night on a front lawn in this Westchester County community, killing the two persons aboard the aircraft.

description: THE newer double-hung, factory-assembled windows have built-in spring-type or friction balances that are virtually trouble-free, as well as efficient weather-stripping, but older windows with sash weights and cords are often prone to stick.

description: The period 1790-1830 was a crucial one for the growth of the kind of German Romantic opera that reached its culmination in the works of Richard Wagner. But as several seemingly disparate record releases suggest, that genesis was neither so simple nor so simply nationalistic as Wagner and his partisans later believed.

title: CATFISH LOOKING BEYOND THE SOUTH
description: misunderstood, much-slandered, whiskered item, is generally known as something Southerners eat, Northerners throw back in the lake and Westerners would not recognize if they fell over it.

title: Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Talk
description: The summer of '81. The 13 weeks between now and Labor Day are traditionally the happiest time of the year for paperback publishers, for then cash registers keep ringing as Americans buy books to take along with them to read at the shore or the lake. What are the prospects for the trade this year? We discussed the question with a number of buyers for wholesalers and bookstore chains, whose business it is to watch the fluctuations of the public's tastes.

description: John Kenneth Galbraith is Paul M. Warburg Professor of Economics Emeritus at Harvard University. His most recent book is ''A life in Our Time.'' By John Kenneth Galbraith

The program will include Louie White's ''Sursum corda,'' which Mr. de Tar commissioned for the 150th anniversary of the Church of the Ascension in 1977, and the premiere of Alan Fletcher's Psalm 26.

title: POLICY THAT LIMITS INDOCHINA REFUGEES IS REVERSED BY U.S.
description: At the urging of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Attorney General William French Smith has reversed a new policy that the State Department asserted was threatening to undercut the six-year program of admitting Indochinese refugees to this country.

title: MEETING THE CHALENGES OF MAKING SPORTS SUCCEEDS IN NEW YORK STATE
description: The following article is excerpted from Thoughts on Sports, Public Policy Questions on Sports in New York State, a report issued by the New York State Senate Committee on Corporations, Authorites and Commissions, Senator John R. Dunne, chairman.

title: Opera, Texas Style
description: Deborah Trustman's article, ''Opera from the Heart of Texas'' (May 3), was the fairminded and articulate examination of Houston Grand Opera that we have all been waiting for. However, in suggesting that ''elaborate productions, with big stars'' are being produced ''at the expense of David Gockley's original policy of support for younger singers,'' Miss Trustman seems ignorant of the casting problems peculiar to opera.

title: WHY DIDN'T REAGAN SIMPLY KILL SYNFUELS?
description: P RESIDENT REAGAN'S decision, apparently upon the advice of David A. Stockman, his budget director, to keep Jimmy Carter's Synthetic Fuels Corporation, stands out as a glaring anomaly and as a potential threat to his Administration's ability to claim (as it must) that all sectors are being treated equitably in the effort to reduce the impact of government. This decision is even more curious when one examines the history of this program and the views regarding a government synfuels effort that such officials as Mr. Stockman have expressed before.

title: Hard-Coal Miners Accept Contract
description: Miners of hard coal ratified a proposed contract today, ending a 30-day strike that began with their rejection of an earlier offer.

title: The Nimitz Returns to Sea; Faces More Night Landings
description: The nuclear carrier Nimitz returned to sea today, planning an immediate resumption of night landings such as the one that resulted in a fiery jet crash that killed 14 fliers and sailors and injured 48 others.

title: U.S. Peace Envoy Gets a Rest, but Palestinians Don't
description: Philip C. Habib's break from Middle East diplomacy last week left Palestinian forces nervous and for good reason. Israel's commitment not to take out Syrian missile sites in Lebanon while hope remained for their peaceful removal never extended to the Palestinians. Less than 24 hours after Mr. Habib left Jerusalem, Israeli jet fighters struck at guerrilla positions up and down the Lebanese coast.

title: Letters; Neighborhood Transition
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; GOING FOR THE GOLD; Competition
description: COMPETITION It's not just colleges that have trouble keeping professionalism out of amateur sports. We see by The Wall Street Journal that some top corporations are accused of "rising fanaticism" in their approach to an event known as the Corporate Cup Relays.

title:
Construction Update;
DUNBAR RENOVATION
description: The Dunbar Apartments in Harlem may become a cooperative again. The New York Bank for Savings, which holds the mortgage, and Webb & Brooker, the managing agents, are proposing to renovate the 536 garden apartments under the Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation program.

title: Economics of Nuclear Energy
description: Anthony Parisi implies that nuclear-powered electricity would not be competitive if there were a free-market economy (''Hard Times for Nuclear Power,'' April 12). In this, we believe he is wrong.

title:
Stamps;
RACHEL CARSON IS PICTURED ON NEW 17-CENT ISSUE
description: Rachel Carson was a quiet scientist who became the apostle of the preservation of nature. She was a leader in the fight against indiscriminate destruction by man and touched off a still-continuing national and international effort to protect the environment. The books she wrote in espousing her cause made her one of the best-selling authors of the 1950's.

title: A LAGGARD RECOVERY
description: Although most analysts have been surprised at the economy's ability to withstand high interest rates, the recovery from last year's recession has thus far been weaker than any of its post-war predecessors.

title: Stage View; SASSY PARODY AND DEAD-END DRAMA
description: The first half of Caryl Churchill's ''Cloud 9'' takes place in the Africa of 1880, a time when confusion and Queen Victoria seem to have reigned simultaneously. The confusion is primarily sexual and surely has nothing to do with Queen Victoria, who remains safely in England the whole time, eyes no doubt averted. It has a great deal to do, however, with the loyal British colonists who served the Queen in a troubled outpost of the Empire, who do pause now and again to toast their monarch ever so solemnly, and who have a great deal of difficulty - when they are not pausing to toast their Queen -in telling the difference between men and women and boys and girls and things like that.

title: Padres 11, Braves 1
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Steve Mura (2-7) broke a personal three-game losing streak and hit a two-run single as San Diego ended a four-game losing streak.

title: Karli Forman Bride Of Air Force Officer
description: Karli Elizabeth Randall Parker Forman and Lieut. James Hagedorn, U.S.A.F., were married yesterday at the Sands Point, L.I., home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Douglas Forman.

title: PLAYING 'CROSSES' IN CURRENCIES
description: T HE largest gambling casino in the world is not located in any particular spot. It is called the interbank market for foreign exchange, and it exists in the telecommunication systems that link banks, multinational corporations and currency speculators all over the globe.

title: CORRECTION
description: A parade notice in the Index yester- day gave the wrong day for a Solidarity Sunday march in support of Soviet Jews. The march will be today, begin- ning at noon on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street. Marchers will head down Fifth Avenue to 47th Street and then walk east to Hammarskjold Plaza at First Avenue for a rally.

title: ELEANOR ANNE GRAY ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Eleanor Anne Gray to Joseph Kenneth Rivara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor L. Rivara of Glen Rock, N.J., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. William V. Gray of Amityville, L.I., parents of the future bride.

title: POLITICIANS IN SALVADOR ARE UNDER THE GUN
description: A recent secret report from the Salvadoran National Guard described suspicious activity observed by troops in the capital. A political party had rented a house, installed file cabinets and hired secretaries, the document noted with alarm. The party in question was not a Marxist group, an assemblage of terrorists or one of the guerrilla organizations seeking armed revolution. It was the Christian Democratic Party of Jose Napoleon Duarte, President of the United States-backed ruling junta. American officials had to talk National Guard commanders out of smashing the operation.

title: Carol Williamson Bride in Alabama Of John W. Dizard
description: Carol Williamson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Jackson Williamson of Greenville, Ala., was married in the First Presbyterian Church there yesterday to John William Dizard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Paul Dizard of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Warren E. Myer performed the ceremony.

title: OFFICER ACCUSED OF SOVIET CONTACTS SAID TO AID INQUIRY
description: The military attorney for Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke, a 25-year-old Air Force officer who has been accused of unauthorized contacts with the Soviet Embassy here, asserted today that his client had been ''cooperating fully'' with an Air Force investigation ''under promise of complete immunity.''

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY SCHEDULES VOTE ON ORDER TO TEACH SEX EDUCATION
description: Nine months after the New Jersey State Board of Education directed local districts to teach sex education, a new effort in the Assembly to overturn the action apparently has enough support to force a vote on the issue.

title: HENRY WEILER
description: Henry Weiler, a partner in the New York law firm of Demov, Morris, Levin & Shein, died yesterday of cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Weiler, a resident of Manhattan, was 46 years old.

title: Judith Gies Bride Of James P. Polk Jr.
description: Judith Ellen Gies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Somerville Gies of Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to James Potter Polk Jr., son of Mr. Polk of New York and Mrs. C. Champe Taliaferro of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Wray MacKay, vicar of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Chelsea, performed the ceremony at the couple's Manhattan home.

title: Penske Wants Outsiders On Indy Appeal Panel
description: Roger Penkse, the racing car owner seeking to have Bobby Unser reinstated as winner of the Indianapolis 500, says that having two former United States Auto Club executives on a three-member appeal panel ''would not be in our best interests.''

title: ISN'T IT STILL PREJUDICE IF IT'S A TINY ONE?
description: ALL right-thinking men and women are agreed upon the evil effects of great prejudice, but I wonder if even the wisest of us gives sufficient attention and concern to the consequences of little ones.

title: Jean Debelle Is Wed to John S. Lamensdorf
description: Jean Heather Debelle, North American syndications manager for The Sydney Morning Herald in New York, and John S. Lamensdorf, an account executive with Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith in New York, were married yesterday in Kent Town, Adelaide, Australia. The Rev. R. Kyle Waters performed the Episcopal ceremony in Wesley Uniting Church.

title:
Gardening;
IT'S TIME FOR SPRAYING AND FERTILIZING
description: WEATHER conditions should have stabilized sufficiently in the last week for tender vegetables and annuals to be planted out without danger of stunting from cold exposure. Tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, squash and cucumber planted at this time will often surpass those planted earlier in growth and production. Zinnias and tall marigolds may also be planted out. However, they often do better if the seed is sown directly. Scatter the seeds three inches apart in the row, then thin to a six- to eight-inch spacing after germination.

title: Personally Speaking
description: Office of Admissions Any College Wherever, U.S.A. Dear Any College:

title: Scott Outkicks Maree in Mile
description: Steve Scott said he felt ''crummy'' from the humidity. If the pace had been fast, he said, he would have been far back. But everything went his way, and he won the men's mile today in the Jumbo Elliott Invitational track meet in 3 minutes 52.26 seconds, the fastest time in the nation this year.

title: Letters; KEMP-ROTH SAVINGS EFFECT MAY BE ILLUSORY
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; A SEAFARER'S SPECIALTY
description: Last week we revealed our discovery that there had been a food column called ''Receipts'' in The New York Times more than a century ago. One of our favorites from that period is for potted salmon. The recipe, which ran on Jan 4, 1880, reads, ''In old times, in the ship stores, there used to be only Scotch put-up salmon, but nowadays, it is the Columbia River that supplies the world. An old man, as I knowed, as good a sailor as ever sailed, was mighty fussy over his eating and he first showed me how to make potted salmon out of the fish in cans. It is a tip-top relish spread on a bit of bread. Take your salmon out of the can, and pick out bones, but mostly they are so soft as to do no harm. Just you pound that smooth in a mortar. Take that pounded fish and put it in a jar, which jar place in a pipkin with hot water. Bring up the water to a boil; when your fish is hot, say for a two-pound can, stir in a quarter of a pound of good butter and a teaspoonful of essence of anchovy; or you may take three anchovies and bruise them up fine and mix them in. It must be hot, so put in a saltspoonful of cayenne pepper and a shred of mace; chop your mace fine. Now you want a teaspoonful of tarragon vinegar and a half dozen whole black peppers.
